DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 1, or the eighth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: British chemist Sir Joseph Priestley announces that he has discovered oxygen.
1834: Robert Morrison, the first English missionary to go to China and translator of the Bible into Chinese, dies.
1894: War between China and Japan over the question of Korea breaks out. The Treaty of Shimonoseki was signed the next year, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaotung Peninsula, Taiwan, and the Pescadores to Japan.
1915: The Peking government mints its silver coin, known as "Yuantatou," bearing the likeness of Yuan Shih-kai.
1926: Kwangtung University changes its name to National Sun Yat-sen University.
1927: The Chinese communists stage the Nanchang Uprising against the Nationalist government.
1928: The Central Broadcasting System is set up in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1941: American volunteer aviators form the "Flying Tigers," with Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault as commander. They help China combat Japanese air superiority in the early stages of World War II.
1943: Lin Sen, chairman of the Nationalist government, dies at the age of 76.
1949: The Office of Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang is established in Taipei.
1958: An insurance program providing 180,000 government employees with coverage for maternity leave, illness, injury, disability and death is put into effect.
1966: The Chinese Communist Party opens a plenum meeting that declares the start of the 10-year Cultural Revolution.
1971: The Tainan Giants of the Republic of China win the Little League Asian and Pacific play-offs.
1973: The Economic Planning Council (EPC) of the Executive Yuan is inaugurated. The EPC replaces the Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development.
1973: Gen. Kao Kuei-yuan takes over from Gen. Cheng Ta-ching as the Republic of China's minister of national defense.
1976: The National Reconstruction Seminar opens in Taipei with 130 local and overseas Chinese scholars participating.
1984: ROC athlete Tsai Wen-yee wins a bronze medal in weightlifting at the 1984 Olympic Games.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a slight increase in the premium rate of laborers' occupational injury insurance. The rates for thirty-two occupations are raised.
1987: The Council of Labor Affairs is formally established under the Executive Yuan.
1989: A foreign currency call loan market designed to make the metropolis an international financial center is established in Taipei.
1992: The National Unification Council defines "one China" as "one country and two areas each ruled separately by a different political entity."
1992: The Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters, the ROC's highest security institution, is disbanded, and the Coastal Patrol General Headquarters is established under the Ministry of National Defense.
1999: The U.S. Defense Department announces the sale of two E-2T Hawkeye 2000E airborne early warning aircraft and related equipment and services to Taiwan.
2000: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh pays a visit to New Party leader Hau Lung-bin, a move Hsieh said is aimed at showing respect to the opposition.
2000: Taiwan resident Huang You-fu becomes the 10 millionth traveler to pass through Macau International Airport.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By attending to the cleanliness and purity of his person and the propriety and dignity of his dress, and in every word and act permitting nothing which is contrary to good taste and decency, that is how the ruler puts in order his personal conduct."

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO EARMARK NT$450 MILLION TO HELP YACHT-BUILDING INDUSTRY(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) decided Monday to earmark NT$450 million (US$13.74 million) to improve facilities at two docks in Kaohsiung Harbor to help Taiwan's yacht-building industry enhance its competitiveness in the world market.
Taiwan now ranks fifth in the world in terms of yacht-building -- next to Italy, the United States, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom.

According to the CEPD, Taiwan's yacht-building industry had its heyday in 1985 when it captured 94.1 percent of the market in the Americas. After that, the number of yachts built each year dropped from 700 to 228 in 1994.

CEPD officials said they believe improved dock facilities would encourage yacht-building companies to make an additional investment of more than NT$3 billion, which in turn is expected to increase the industry's production value from NT$7 billion in 2005 to NT$10 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISTRICT COURT UPHOLDS BAIL RULING ON INSIDER TRADING SUSPECTS(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court upheld its second ruling Monday on allowing three indicted suspects in a high-porfile insider trading scandal involving President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming to remain free.
It was the third time the district court has allowed Chao and the two accomplices in the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stock insider trading scandal to stay free on bail.

In its latest ruling, the court didn't change the bail amount for any of the three suspects; namely, Chao's NT$17 million bail, businessman You Shih-yi's NT$10 million bail and former TDC Chairman Su Teh-chien's NT$5 million bail.

The district court made the third ruling on the case at the instructions of the Taiwan High Court, which rescinded the lower court's July 20 ruling last Friday after the Taipei Prosecutor's Office re-appealed the case July 26 to try to have the trio detained once again.

In its Monday ruling, the district court said it sees no need for continued detention of the trio because previous records show that few suspects continued insider trading once their illegal dealings were exposed. Moreover, the court said proseuctors have completed questioning of the trio and finalized investigations of their allegedly illegal dealings. Against this backdrop, the ruling said prosecutors' claim that the trio may collude among themselves or with witnesses in making false confession seems to be implausible.

Prosecutors formally indicted the three suspects July 10 on charges of using insider information to profit from TDC stock dealings. In the indictment, prosecutors recommended that Chao and Su be sentenced to eight years behind bars, with 10 years for You.
In the evening of that same day, Chao and You were freed on NT$10 million bail and Su on NT$5 million bail.

The prosecutor's office appealed to the high court July 14, seeking to have the trio detained once again. In response to the first appeal, the high court ruled July 17 that the lower court had to review the case again because its previous decision was flawed.

In its second ruling issued July 20, the district court stuck to its decision on allowing the trio to remain free, but raised bail for Chao to NT$17 million from the original NT$10 million, while maintaining that bail for the other two suspects should remain the same at NT$10 million and NT$5 million, respectively.
While granting bail, the district court banned the trio from leaving the country or changing residence without due notice.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS VISITING SOLOMON ISLANDS MINISTER(repeat)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday a soon-to-be-signed volunteer exchange agreement and a cooperative framework agreement between Taiwan and the Solomon Islands are expected to further expand bilateral cooperation.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with Solomon Islands Minister of Foreign Affairs John Patteson Oti and several parliamentarians from the South Pacific island country, who are currently visiting Taiwan.

Noting that relations between Taiwan and the Solomon Islands have been cordial since the two countries forged diplomatic ties in 1983, Chen said none of Taiwan's diplomatic mission staff in the Solomon Islands left its capital even when the country was troubled by serious ethnic conflicts in 2000.
Chen made an official visit to the Solomon Islands in January 2005, making him the first Republic of China head of state ever to visit the South Pacific island country.
Praising Oti for sparing no efforts to promoting Taiwan-Solomon Islands ties, Chen said Oti's current visit is yet another concrete action of his support for Taiwan.

For his part, Oti said the Solomon Islands will continue to speak for Taiwan's cause on international occasions and work in concert with Taiwan in further upgrading bilateral cooperation and exchanges in various fields, including fighting poverty, medical service, health care and narrowing the gap in digitization.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DENIES MISUSE OF STATE FUNDS(repeat)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian denied Monday that he has ever "lined his pockets" with state funds set aside for discretionary state affairs expenses.
Chen was quoted as having made the denial while meeting with a group of legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) earlier in the day.

Chen's remarks came after the Ministry of Audit under the Control Yuan -- the nation's supreme watchdog body -- said last week that documents related to the Presidential Office's reimbursement of expenditures from a "discretionary state affairs expense allowance" fund last year contained irregularitries and had been referred to the prosecutor's office for investigations.

Chen told DPP lawmakers that he had to use the discretionary fund to finance many confidential diplomatic operations. As the operations involved many state secrets, Chen said he couldn't give a clear account in public, which has resulted in a lot of misunderstanding.

In reality, Chen said, the use of the "discretionary state affairs expense allowance" fund has strictly followed the system and regulations adopted during the previous Kuomintang rule. Chen was quoted as having said society, opposition parties in particularly, should not employ different standards to scrutinize the use of the fund.

If investigators pledge not to disclose any confidential diplomatic operations for overall national interests, Chen said he is willing to brief prosecution authorities on the use of the "special state affairs expense" fund in detail and show them all relevant data and documents.
Chen assured DPP lawmakers that he has not feather his nest with the special state funds.

Meanwhile, DPP lawmakers said Chen is scheduled to meet with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng Tuesday, but none of them would reveal the topics to be addressed during the planned Chen-Wang meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: APITAL COST SPIKES IN CHINA INVESTMENT: POLL(repeat)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese business people operating in China, known locally as "Taishang," will encounter problems of rising capital costs for investments in China, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The survey of Taiwanese business people, conducted in 2005, also found that "Taishang" faces a host of problems, ranging from appreciation of the Chinese currency, changing business climate in China, the need to "localize" their Chiense operations and China's efforts to cool down its overheating investment boom and overproduction.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL 'TAIWAN WHO'S WHO' TO BE PUBLISHED TUESDAY(repaat)

TEXT.P: A special "Taiwan Who's Who 2006-2007" will hit bookstore shelves Tuesday, offering a glimpse into the lives and experiences of the most representative figures in all areas of contemporary Taiwanese society.
Mega Forum Publication Co., the new guidebook's publisher, will host a book-launch ceremony Tuesday morning in an international convention center at Taipei 101 Tower.
Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, will speak on the social responsibility of celebrated individuals at the book-launch ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN CAREGIVERS TO BE SUBJECT TO STRICTER JOB ASSIGNMENT RULES

TEXT.P: Foreign caregivers will be subject to stricter job assignment rules from August, and violators will be slapped with fines ranging between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Tuesday.

Starting Aug. 1, employers are prohibited from dispatching foreign caregivers they hire to stay with care recipients at long-term care centers or hospital wards for patients with chronic diseases, CLA officials said.
According to the CLA's job assignment rules, foreign or migrant workers are grouped into four categories -- housemaids, manufacturing workers, construction workers and family caregivers.
In the past, foreign caregivers were eligible to stay with care recipients at professional care centers so long as their employers reported their job assignment plans to the CLA in advance.
As CLA officials found that these foreign caregivers were often asked to do extra work, the CLA decided to ban such job assignments from Aug. 1.

Foreign caregivers will also be prohibited from staying with their patients at hospital wards for those with chronic diseases. They now can only stay with their care recipients at emergency rooms or general hospital wards.
Employers who violate these new job assignment rules will face fines of up to NT$150,000.

The stricter job dispatch rules for foreign caregivers are seen as part of the CLA's efforts to rein in the hiring of foreign caregivers whose numbers have increased significantly since a new hiring system came into effect early this year.
According to CLA tallies, the number of foreign caregivers has increased by more than 23,400 since the new hiring system was implemented in January this year.

Of the 336,000-plus foreigners currently working in Taiwan, about 130,000 are caregivers, with the number of foreign nationals working in the manufacturing and construction sectors hovering between 160,000 and 170,000.

CLA officials said that since the foreign caregiver hiring system was changed, city and county governments have actively helped promote the employment of local caregivers. However, due to a combination of factors, including insufficient incentives offered by the government as well as the much higher wages needed in hiring local caregivers, the number of applications for foreign caregivers has remained high, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REMAINS CONCERNED WHETHER TAIWAN DETERMINED TO BOOST DEFENSES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, July 31 (CNA) (By Timothy Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Washington remains concerned over whether Taiwan is determined to boost its overall defense capabilities, visiting Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Shen Fa-hui said Monday.

Shen, who along with another ruling DPP legislator, Lee Kun-tse, visited Washington, D.C. before arriving in New York Sunday, said U.S. officials expressed "grave concern" during a talk with them last week over whether Taiwan can "effectively" raise its overall defense and combat capabilities as rival China continues its rapid military build-up.

As to the much-talked-about procurement of three major weapon systems from the U.S., Shen said, the U.S. officials did not name any particular item this time around, but they did mention that the designing and building of the eight diesel-fueled submarines that the U.S. has promised to sell to Taiwan could be discussed separately.

Meanwhile, Shen said he and Lee were told by Department of Commerce officials that the signing of a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States is not seen as happening any time soon and that current efforts will continue to focus on ensuing talks under the Taiwan-U.S. Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA).

Shen, nevertheless, noted that the U.S. officials also told them that Taiwan need not worry that the window is closing fast for substantive consideration of an FTA under the Bush administration's Trade Promotion Authority (TPA), which will expire on July 1, 2007. "There probably will be a unique opportunity sometime in the near future for the two sides to embark on new rounds of FTA talks," Shen quoted a U.S. official as saying to him.
The TPA is a fast-track arrangement that allows the Bush administration to negotiate trade deals and present them to Congress for a simple yes-or-no vote.

Shen and Lee visited Jimmy K. Meng, the first American Chinese member of the New York State House of Representatives, Monday at his office, where they wished Meng's daughter Grace success in running in the New York State Democratic primary in September.
The two DPP legislators will head to Detroit after their New York visit. They are also scheduled to visit New Orleans and Hawaii before returning to Taiwan in about two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'FASHION PALACE MUSEUM'-THEMED DESIGN CONFERENCE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An international design conference co-sponsored by the National Palace Museum and the government-funded Taiwan Design Center was held at the Taipei International Convention Center Tuesday.

National Palace Museum director Lin Mun-lee, film directors Wang Hsiao-ti and Cheng Wen-tang, architect J.M. Lin, Philips Design executive Chen Hsie-kuan, as well as Gijs Bakker, the founder of Holland's Droog Design Center, were among the participants in the conference aimed at mapping out plans to transform the museum into a "commodities economy."

The theme of the design conference was "Old is New -- Fashion National Palace Museum, " which is part of a project developed by the museum and the Taiwan Design Center to push for cultural commodities designing and the revival of historical antiques with a modern spirit and fashion.

Prior to the one-day meeting, renowned Dutch designer Gijs Bakker presided over a design camp in Taipei July 29-31, leading a group of local talent to create works based on inspiration derived from the National Palace Museum's treasures.

The museum said its production of derivative commodities is no longer limited to the production of duplicates, while it is forming a marketing management and brand name licensing mechanism in an effort to make the museum famous worldwide.

La Repubblica: Olmert: We will not stop.
Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said Monday that there will be no ceasefire with Hezbollah. His security cabinet decided to widen ground operations in southern Lebanon. United Nations Security Council is to meet on the new situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA OPENS CAMPS TO ATTRACT YOUTH TO AGRICULTURE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Su Jia-chyuan presided over a ceremony held Tuesday to mark the opening of the first round of seven camps which are aimed at attracting more young people to work in the agricultural sector.
The project forms part of the COA's efforts to attract some 1,000 young people to work in the agricultural industry within three years amid the aging agricultural population.
Su said that through the project, the COA hopes to get members of the younger generation to experience nature and grow to love it.

The project includes 42 camps, with each camp receiving 20 young people aged between 18 and 35. The camp activities will include the cultivation of vegetables, fruits, flowers and tea, as well as recreational experiences on farmland. The camps are being held on farmland in Taoyuan County.
A COA official said the agency will draw up measures to assist the camp participants who show a strong interest in farming through the activities.
Concerning those people aged over 35 who are interested in farming, the COA will also offer "gardeners" activities in September to train these middle-aged people how to be farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 18 points to close at 6,379, with 33,712 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September rose 16 points to finish at 6,361, with 214 contracts traded, while December futures remained unchanged to close at 6,374, with 13 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,361 for August, 6,345 for September, 6,374 for December, 6,387 for March and 6,377 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
August TE futures moved up 1.25 points to close at 268.65, with 3,430 contracts traded, while September TE futures rose 2.85 points to finish at 268.95, with 27 contract transactions.
December TE futures gained 0.55 points to close at 268, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures moved up one point to close at 921, with 857 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures lost 1.4 points to finish at 920, with seven contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIKING HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUMS UNFAIR: CONSUMERS FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Commenting on reports that health insurance premiums will be hiked in October, the Consumers' Foundation said Tuesday that a premium hike before key problems that have plagued the system are tackled would be unfair.

Consumers' Foundation Secretary-General Huang Yi-teng said that until the Department of Health (DOH) comes up with measures to adjust and balance the finances of the entire national health insurance system and deal with the "black hole" of pharmaceutical prices -- the core reasons why the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) is running huge deficits -- a premium hike would be unacceptable to the people.
"The DOH should not treat the people as its automatic teller machines," he said.
In order to solve its spiraling financial crisis, Huang said, the BNHI should first strive to cut costs and the squandering of valuable medical resources, instead of asking for extra premiums.

The Consumers' Foundation spokesman said the BNHI should particularly work to retrieve unpaid health insurance premiums owed by the municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung to the program, which exceeds NT$42 billion (US$1.28 billion).

The DOH authorities said earlier this year that the shortage of funds for the National Health Insurance program must be solved by October as the government's last subsidies to the program will run out in June.

Since the BNHI is expected to face a financial shortfall of NT$23 billion next year, the bureau is planning to raise health insurance premiums for two categories of insured groups, including farmers, fishermen and laborers, DOH authorities have said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 40% OF PARENTS UNAWARE FREE CHECKUPS AVAILABLE FOR CHILDREN: POLL

TEXT.P: Although as high as 95.9 percent of families in Taiwan have received child health handbooks for newborns, 40.26 percent of parents have no idea the handbook provides nine free health examinations for children under seven years old, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.

Among the parents who are aware of the service, 32.2 percent did not use it over the past year, with 45 percent of the parents saying they did not use the service because their children were in good health.

While 25.82 percent of the parents do not know that they are supposed to keep the handbooks permanently, 19.58 percent did not bring the handbooks when they brought their children to hospitals for medical visits or vaccination, the survey indicates.
The survey was conducted in 2005 by the Bureau of Health Promotion on 1,966 parents with children under seven years old.
Officials from the bureau said that the results show that many parents are confusing preventive healthcare with other medical care.

According to the officials, the nine free health examinations cover growth and development assessment, physical checkups, vaccination, and health counseling, which are aimed at allowing parents to have a comprehensive understanding of their children's growth and development.

The free health examinations include four provided before the children reach one year of age, two provided when the children are between one and two years old, and one each when the children are between two and three years old, between three and four years old, and between four and seven years old, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LARGEST INT'L BALLROOM DANCE COMPETITION TO OPEN SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest ever international ballroom dance competition is set to be held in Taipei City Sunday, with more than 500 dancers from Europe, Oceania and Asia participating.

Participants in the Taiwan Open Championship, to be held at the Taipei Municipal Stadium, will compete in 26 different events, including an international professional event, an Asia professional competition, an amateur event, and a novice competition.

Michael Wang, chairman of the Taiwan Dancesport Development Association, which is sponsoring the open, expressed the hope that the competition will help promote the sport of dance as well as provide ballroom dance fans with an unforgettable experience of seeing excellent performances.
Wang noted that the participants will come from Russia, Italy, Australia, Great Britain, China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Macau and Japan, adding that local fans can enjoy their world-class performances.
The association arranged for a series of children and Latin dance performances Monday as a warm-up for the upcoming competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO BOYS' BODIES FOUND IN CHANGHUA COUNTY

TEXT.P: Changhua county firefighters discovered two boys' bodies Tuesday in a mangrove swamp near Erlin Creek in the central county.

One of the bodies was identified as an eight-year-old schoolboy surnamed Lin, who lived in the neighborhood. Lin was among three boys who were reported missing Monday by their parents after failing to show up for supper.
The parents said they had found the three boys' slippers and two bikes on a bridge, and suspected the boys may have ignored their warning against swimming in the creek.
In response, county firefighters launched a search mission along the river.

Lin was found lying face up on the ground at the edge of the mangrove swamp near the mouth of Erlin Creek, with his head pointing toward the river's mouth. Police suspected he may have drowned and was carried downriver by the current.
Hours after discovering Lin's body, another boy's remains were found in the same mangrove swamp. Police have began work to identify the body.
As of press time, there is still one boy missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOWED ME RECEIPTS FOR CONTROVERSIAL FUND: SPEAKER WANG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has shown receipts for a controversial state affairs fund to the speaker of the Legislative Yuan, Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday.

Wang declined to comment further on what he had seen during the morning meeting with the president, stressing that meeting Chen does not mean endorsing what the president has done with the funds that were designed for his discretionary use.

Chen invited Wang to the Presidential Office to show him the receipts for the president's NT$35 million budget to purchase gifts, reward the armed forces, visit political and economic establishments and hold social events.

The prosecution, which is investigating whether any irregularities have occurred, claimed it is neither a "special" nor a "secret" fund for the president to use in whatever fashion he chooses, and that receipts or invoices must be provided to auditing authorities.

Wang said since the controversy is currently under investigation, the president will explain to judicial authorities how he has made use of the funds and will likely explain "to an appropriate degree" to the public as well.

Wang said Chen explained to him how previous presidents -- Chiang Kai-shek, Chiang Ching-kuo and Lee Teng-hui -- had used the fund and how they had used "secret" and "special" funds that were also budgeted for the president's discretionary use in carrying out "secret diplomacy" and other presidential duties.
According to Wang, Chen spoke about how the nation's diplomacy functions in the context of using such discretionary funds.
"The president showed me receipts used for various purposes. But I cannot disclose the details," Wang added.
In addition to the controversial state affairs fund, the two also discussed Taiwan's foreign affairs, major bills pending in the legislature and mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Wang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN DENIED ACCESS TO 604 TAIWANESE TOURISTS IN 2005

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese made 1.27 million visits to Japan in 2005, although the Japanese government denied entry to 604 of them that same year, according to tallies from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
Since September 2005, Japan has offered ROC citizens visa-free entry for stays of up to 90 days.

According to Lo Kun-tsan, head of the MOFA's Committee on Japanese Affairs, the Japanese government will deny access to any foreign visitors who have previously resided illegally in Japan or overstayed their visas, as well as those who are suspected of having the intent to work in Japan.
Taiwan's citizens should apply beforehand for a visa if they are visiting Japan for volunteer service, employment or if they have a prior criminal record in Japan, Lo said.
In 2005, there were 6.73 million foreign tourist arrivals in Japan, and 10,722 foreigners were denied entry, including 604 from Taiwan, Lo noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUMS WILL NOT BE HIKED FOR NOW: DOH

TEXT.P: A Department of Health (DOH) official denied Tuesday that health insurance premiums will be hiked in the near future as a means to help cut deficits run up by the cash-strapped Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI).
DOH Deputy Minister Chen Shih-chung assured opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators that he is "sure" that health insurance premiums will not be raised, at least temporarily.

A group of KMT legislators hosted a discussion at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday on the possible repercussions of implementing the proposed second-generation national health insurance program, which is bound to require most people to pay higher premiums.
Chen reiterated that the National Health Insurance Committee of Supervisors has yet to make a decision on any premium hike plans.

The Executive Yuan referred a draft package of amendments to the National Health Insurance Law to the Legislative Yuan May 3 to pave the way toward an overhaul of the nation's health insurance system.

Premiums under the new program would be adjusted according to total household income rather than an individual's salary, as is the case under the existing system -- meaning that it is poised to affect some 70 percent of salary-earning Taiwanese who are medium- and low-income earners.
KMT legislators said it would be unlawful if the DOH pushed for the implementation of the second-generation national health insurance program before the proposal was passed into law.

KMT lawmakers also lambasted the proposal, saying it would increase the health insurance premiums of about 70 percent of Taiwan's salaried population, while leaving the high-income bracket unaffected.

They warned that until health authorities address what they termed "ubiquitous health insurance fraud" and the "black hole" of pharmaceutical prices -- which they claimed as core reasons behind the BNHI's huge deficits -- there would be no chance for the DOH to see the second-generation national health insurance proposal pass into law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 13.12 points to close at 6,441.46.
The bourse opened at 6,464.59 and fluctuated between 6,478.34 and 6,435.93 during trading. A total of 2.44 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$57.36 billion (US$1.75 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 0.9 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.6 percent and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 543 to 414, with 158 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.062 to close at NT$32.818.
A total of US$684 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.786 and hit a high of NT$32.819.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BOROUGH CHIEFS IN KAOHSIUNG CITY ASSUME POSTS

TEXT.P: Ward chiefs in Kaohsiung city, southern Taiwan began their terms Tuesday in a ceremony presided over by Acting Mayor Yeh Chu-lan, who encouraged the new group of 459 local leaders to wholeheartedly dedicate themselves to serving their communities.
The ceremony took place at Kaohsiung City Government's assembly hall, where Yet awarded them all with a plaque to congratulate them on their election victories.

Yeh hailed the new local officials as "behind-the-scenes heroes," expressing hope that they would help strengthen law enforcement, promote law and order and maintain a clean environment while and boost Kaohsiung's status.
Yeh also launched a campaign calling for public efforts to help the rest of Taiwan "get to know Kaohsiung."

As the southern port city will be hosting the 2009 World Games -- in which 5,000 athletes from 50 countries will be competing -- foreign visitors will be able to witness the city's progress and hospitality by that time, she said.
Of the 459 ward chiefs, 63 are female. The eldest of the group is 77 years old, while the youngest is 28.

Two of the incoming chiefs have master's degrees, while 51 have bachelor's and 49 have college education diplomas. A total of 211 are senior high school graduates, followed by 84 senior high school graduates and 58 grade school graduates.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HASN'T POCKETED A CENT OF STATE AFFAIRS FUND: DPP LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Ruling party lawmakers and spokesman who met with President Chen Shui-bian quoted Chen on Tuesday as claiming he has "not pocketed a single cent" of the state affairs fund and they accused the National Audit Office (NAO) of using different standards in reviewing the Presidential Office's accounting reports.
Chen met with Democratic Progressive Party legislators Wang Shih-chien, Hsu Kuo-yung, Wu Ping-jui, Chuang Shuo-han, Lee Wen- chung and Huang Wei-che and DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-lang Monday.
The president showed them documents and stressed that he has used the fund "completely according to precedent and in accordance with the law," they said.

Wang said that after hearing the president's explanation, he was convinced of the "importance, necessity and secretive nature" of the fund and believes Chen has never wasted or pocketed a single cent of it, and that Chen felt he was being "above board" about the situation.

Wang blamed Auditor General Su Chen-ping for using "a double standard" in requiring the Presidential Office to produce receipts or invoices for the use of every single cent of the fund, causing an uproar over the matter.
"It's extremely unfair," he claimed.
Half of the fund can be claimed with receipts and the other half with invoices, and the president has followed exactly that rule, Wang said.

The Control Yuan's National Audit Office (NAO), also known as the Ministry of Audit, has never found any problems with the Presidential Office's accounting reports for fiscal year 2004 or earlier, Wang said.
"So why has the FY 2005 report become a problem, when it was done the same way as previous reports?" he asked.

He accused "people with ulterior motives" -- in particular opposition politicians -- of "political maneuvering over the matter, exaggerating the issue and using smear tactics against the head of state."

He said quite a few DPP legislators have suggested that Chen publish all evidence to prove his innocence, but the president said, "when you chop the wood [for building a fire], you cannot chop the chopping board."

Huang said that in the past, half of the funds could be accounted for without receipts or invoices, but the NAO is now unilaterally interpreting the law and demanding that every cent spent from the fund must be proven with a receipt or invoice, an enormous hassle for the Presidential Office.

Huang claimed he has heard a "clear and logical" explanation from the president about the use of the state affairs fund, but he did not see any documents or hear any explanations about the reported "Southern Line" secret diplomacy project.
Lee said some work in defense, foreign affairs and cross-strait relations is confidential -- activities that cannot be proven with receipts.
"It's the same in all countries of the world, and in Taiwan, it began long before 2000, the year of the peaceful transfer of power, " he added.
Lee said the Presidential Office had been forced to "collect irrelevant invoices" to fulfil the accounting requirements as demanded by the National Audit Office after 2000.
"What should be examined is why the NAO has come up with new regulations for the DPP government, " Lee said, noting that he "totally accepts the president's explanation."

DPP Spokesman Tsai Huang-lang said that during a meeting with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, the president expressed interest in inviting leaders of opposition parties' legislative caucuses to the Presidential Office for a briefing on the use of the state affairs fund.
The president wants to assure them that he has never pocketed or embezzled a cent of the fund, Tsai added.

He said the president showed him and DPP lawmakers files, documents and data about "secret diplomacy, " indicating that only "acknowledgements of receipt" were available to prove that some individuals had received some money to execute the president's instructions.

"The president told us that the legislature has cut his state affairs fund to NT$35 million, far from being enough to carry out 'secret diplomacy, ' while the NAO, starting in 2003, demanded that half of the fund must be accounted for with receipts," Tsai said.
He urged the opposition to stop criticizing the president over his use of the fund for the sake of Taiwan "saving face" in the international community.
"If the secret data were made public, an international row could erupt, damaging Taiwan's relations with other countries," he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES FOR EARLY COMPLETION OF 'ONE LAPTOP PER CHILD' PLAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Tuesday that a "one laptop per child" program will be accomplished early and that Taiwan can participate.

Chen noted that the program, which was initiated by Nicholas Negroponte, a founder of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Laboratory, is dedicated to research to develop a US$100 laptop for children in developing countries.
Pointing out that most of the computers will be produced by Taiwan manufacturers, Chen said Taiwan is pleased and honored to be able to take part in the program to help bridge the global digital gap.
The president made the remarks while receiving a group of Taiwan contestants in the 2006 International Schools Cyberfair.
Chen said this is the fourth consecutive year that Taiwan has won the world championship in the competition, garnering eight platinum medals, 17 golds, 12 silvers and 10 honorable mentions.
The fact that the prizes were won by students from different places around Taiwan demonstrates the government's efforts to eliminate the rural-urban information gap, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO VERIFY REPORT ON CHINA BUYING INTO TVB

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will try to verify reports that China is considering buying into TVB, a Hong Kong-based television group that owns TVB Super Channel (TVBS) in Taiwan, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

Wu made the remarks when asked to comment on news reports that China Central Television (CCTV) -- a government agency under China's State Administration of Radio, Television and Film -- is planning to acquire shares in TVB.
Wu pointed out that the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area does not permit Chinese capital in any Taiwanese media.

He added that if the reports are true, the MAC will strictly enforce the law because with CCTV succeeding in acquiring shares in Hong Kong's TVB, it would turn Taiwan's TVBS into a subsidiary of China's major TV network.
In its 2005 report, TVBS claimed that 47 percent of its shares were held by TVB, with the remaining 53 percent held by Taiwan's Countless Entertainment (Taiwan) Co.
Because TVB is based in Hong Kong, a self-administered Chinese territory, the group is considered a foreign company.
Taiwanese law sets a 50 percent limit on foreign ownership of TV stations, but media ownership by Chinese is out of the question.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRICTIONS ON CHINESE TOURISTS TO EASE: MAC

TEXT.P: There will be a breakthrough by year's end on the issue of opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

The nation's top China policy official made the remarks at a news conference co-convened by himself and the chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Hu Sheng-cheng, to discuss cross-strait trade issues after participants in a July 27-28 conference on sustainable economic development in Taipei reached a series of resolutions, including one on easing cross-strait personnel exchanges.
Wu said cross-strait communications on opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists have been going on smoothly, and he expected to see results by the end of the year.
Wu said in a gathering June 1 with a group of Taiwanese businesspeople operating in China, that cross-strait negotiation on the matter should be completed in four or five months.

Taiwan currently allows 1,000 Chinese tourists into Taiwan every day, and cross-strait talks should focus on verifying the identity of Chinese tourists, travel disputes and handling emergency situations, he said.

Wu also said current limitations on each group of Chinese businesspeople under 30 members has not met the demand, and that the government will be more open when multinational enterprises -- which have a lot of Chinese workers -- come to Taiwan for a meeting.
Noting that Microsoft is applying to hold a regional meeting in Taiwan, Wu said the government will be open to handling the 200 or 300 Chinese Microsoft employees coming for the event.
He also said the limited opening in exchanges of Chinese currency, the yuan, on two outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu on a trial basis last year, has achieved good results.
He asked the central bank, Central Bank of China, to think about related measures on yuan exchange operations in anticipation of an influx in Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN DEMANDS TRUTH ABOUT STATE AFFAIRS SPENDING

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou demanded Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian make a clean breast of a controversy arising from the state affairs spending claimed by the Presidential Office on Chen's behalf.
Ma made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after presiding over a municipal meeting at Taipei City Hall.

Ma's comments came after local media reported that Chen met Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng over the issue earlier in the day at the Presidential Office and showed him some receipts and files while explaining how the money was reimbursed.

Chen claimed that he has not embezzled from the state affairs expenses and told Wang that he might invite the legislative caucus whips of the various opposition parties to a meeting to explain his side of the story to them.
The president also claimed that he is willing to answer questions to clear his name at the State Public Prosecutor General's Office if required.

"No matter who Chen talks to about whatever issues, the key point is that Chen must provide a clear explanation to the public as to how the money has been spent, " Ma said, adding that "the president is responsible for verifying any confidential case that he claims formed part of the spending."

KMT Legislator Chiu Yi brought the controversy to light in late June when he accused the Presidential Office of claiming special state affairs spending on behalf of Chen with false invoices provided by friends of the first family.

An investigation by the Ministry of Audit has found that suspicious invoices worth some NT$20 million were used by the Presidential Office to claim state affairs spending reimbursement between 2003 and 2005, drawing intense flak.

Asked whether the KMT will support a proposal raised by the People First Party (PFP) to launch an impeachment motion in the Legislative Yuan against Chen, Ma said that the KMT has set up a task force to study means of ousting Chen, which also include toppling the Cabinet or recalling him.

In line with the law, the president is entitled to claim as much as NT$50 million per year in state affairs expenses at his discretion to carry out various special tasks, such as providing cash rewards for military personnel and hosting banquets for foreign dignitaries, but not "confidential" or "secret" missions.
The special funds must be screened by the Legislative Yuan and must be claimed with invoices or receipts, according to an anti-corruption task force at the State Public Prosecutor General's Office.

In response to Chen's proposed invitation, KMT legislative caucus whip Tsai Chin-lung said that it would be better for Chen to elaborate on the issue to the State Public Prosecutor General's Office in compliance with the law, rather to the caucus whips.
PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Shueh-chang told Chen to stop playing "closed door" politics and to come forward and make a report to the public.

As the Presidential Office's state affairs spending is not to be used for paying for the nation's "confidential" missions, Chen's claims that he used the money to conduct secret diplomacy are against the accounting law, Tsai noted.
"The PFP will not endorse the issue for Chen and will not hear a report by Chen at the Presidential Office," he said.
However, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislative caucus whip David Huang said that he would be willing to hear a report by the president at the Presidential Office.

In addition to elaborating on how the reimbursement was claimed with invoices or receipts, Huang said that Chen had better produce documents to attest to his claims that he was just following precedents set in place by his predecessors.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA MIGHT COMMISSION PRIVATE SECTOR TO RUN AIR TERMINALS

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Tuesday that it is studying the feasibility of commissioning private sector companies to run air terminals.
CAA officials made the remarks as the Ministry of Audit reported that 15 of the 18 terminals under the jurisdiction of the CAA have lost a total of NT$900 million (US$29.69 million).

The officials said Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) and Kaohsiung International Airports have shown steady growth, but other air terminals in Taiwan have seen their traffic reduced because of increasingly convenient road and rail networks and rising air ticket prices because of soaring fuel prices. After the inauguration of the high speed railway, the domestic air travel industry will face a further blow.

They said terminals in outlying and remote areas will continue to lose money because they are for the traffic needs of the residents of remote areas and must shoulder the public transportation policy mission as well as emergency medical transportation costs.

On its strategy in planning for future air terminals, the officials said the international airport will chiefly be CKS. In terms of domestic airports, the CAA will adopt a conservative attitude in planning for airports in eastern Taiwan while on the outlying islands, the primary concerns will be flight safety and services to local residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WINS IN KINMEN TOWNSHIP ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) scored an overwhelming victory in Kinmen County's elections of township council chairmen and vice chairmen Tuesday.
The elections in six townships took place on the outlying island county shortly after the 42 members of the township councils were sworn in.
KMT councilors won the chairmanships in all six townships -- Chinchen, Chinhu, Chinsha, Chinning, Liehyu and Wuchiu.
Except for two independents who became vice chairmen in the townships of Chinchen and Chinning, the vice chairmanships in the other four township councils also went to KMT councilors.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: The Overview, Israel Pushes On Despite Agreeing to Airstrike Lull
As Israel poured soldiers and artillery shells into southern Lebanon, it vowed Monday to press ahead with its war on Hezbollah and made a number of airstrikes after promising a 48-hour pause in its air campaign. Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said "There is no cease-fire, and there will not be any cease-fire in the coming days."
Wall STreet Journal: Crude Aid, As Global Oil Demand Tightens, A Big Producer Has Own Agenda
Nothing is more central to Venezuela President Hugo Chavez's political fortunes than the oil company PDVSA. The oil giant is the source of the money his government lavishes on the poor and, in many ways, his 60 percent approval ratings. Under Chavez, the priorities of PDVSA, which has funded half of government spending for decades, have changed dramatically. The company still hands over a portion of its profits to the government, but it also gets directly involved in poverty alleviation and economic development. The company's diminished production has cut world output by more than one percent. That may not sound like a lot, but in a global oil market stretched tight by growing demand, political volatility and hard-to-expand supply, the company's production shortfall has contributed to the run-up in oil prices during the past few years, and is likely to continue to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 TAIWAN ATHLETES QUALIFIED FOR ASIAN GYMNASTICS FINALS

TEXT.P: Four of Taiwan's athletes have qualified for the finals of the Asian Gymnastics Championship being held in Surat, India, a sport official said here Tuesday.
They are Lin Hsiang-wei, Huang Che-kuei, Wung Shih-hang and Huang Yi-hsue, the official quoted Yu Chih-ying, the coach of Chinese Taipei team, as saying.
According to Yu, athletes from a total of 18 Asian countries will compete in the finals set for Aug. 1-2.
Yu expressed hope that the four athletes can gain some gold medals in the finals, which might give them better odds in the 2006 Asian Games to be held in Doha in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTRY PRESENTS EDUCATION PLAN AMID ERA OF LESS KIDS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has presented a five-year plan aimed at improving elementary school education amid the current trend of families having fewer children, a MOE official said Tuesday.

As couples in Taiwan tend to have fewer children -- meaning less classes and teachers are needed in schools -- the situation has affected the livelihood of would-be teachers and made the competition for the employment of new teachers fiercer, the official said.
For example, only 0.78 percent of the new applicants for teaching jobs at elementary schools this year will succeed, the official added.
Worse still, there may be no need for new elementary school teachers next year, or some teachers currently employed may face a layoff, he said.
According to Pan Wen-chung, director of the MOE's Department of Elementary Education, there will be some 290,000 new students entering elementary schools this academic year, starting from September.
However, that number will shrink to 270,000 next year, to 240,000 in 2008, and to 206,000 in 2008, Pan added.

Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said the project, which will start in 2007, has been presented to the Executive Yuan for approval and the ministry will announce the details of the plan after the Cabinet approves of it.

Tu stressed that the new project aims to improve elementary school education by reducing the number of students in each class, with educational resources being used more efficiently. He promised that none of the current teachers will be laid off, and that some new teachers would be needed to create a healthy balance.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE SUMO WRESTLERS TO DEMONSTRATE THEIR ART IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: More than 40 renowned sumo wrestlers will be demonstrating the Japanese art of wrestling in a rare overseas performance on Aug. 19-20 at the Taipei Arena.

Luo Kun-tsan, chief executive of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Committee on Japanese Affairs, said Tuesday that the sumo matches will be thefirst for Taiwan, and that they are brought about jointly by his ministry, the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports and the Nihon Sumo Kyokai -- Japan's formal sumo association.

The planned demonstration will also be the first overseas performance-oriented matches of Japanese sumo wrestlers -- known as Japan's national treasure -- since June 1993, when a group of sumo wrestlers demonstrated the art of sumo in Hawaii.
The Taipei games are part of a five-day Taiwan visit by a Nihon Sumo Kyokai delegation, and start Aug. 17. There will be over 100 people in the group, including 45 sumo wrestlers.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOURNALIST ASSOCIATION CONDEMNS JUDICIAL POLICE BRUTALITY

TEXT.P: The Association of Taiwan Journalists (ATJ) condemned Tuesday the violence that judicial police used on a member of a cable television camera crew a day earlier outside the Taipei District Court.

In a written statement, ATJ demanded that judicial agencies investigate the violence that the judicial police inflicted on Chu Wen-cheng, a cable engineer with Sanlih Television, during a free-for-all in front of the court, where hundreds of media and spectators were watching Chao Chien-ming, son-in-law of President Chen Shui-bian, leaving the court after being released on bail.
The ATJ said the Judicial Yuan should review the violence in which several judicial policemen dragged Chu by his hair and limbs into the court and assaulted him.
ATJ said the Judicial Yuan should apologize to Chu and to Taiwan society for the police brutality.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA OFFICIALS MIGHT MEET IN TAIPEI: KMT EXECUTIVE

TEXT.P: If the director of China's Taiwan Affairs' Office, Chen Yulin, visits Taiwan for a planned agricultural forum organized by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in mid-October, it is natural that he will probably meet Taiwanese officials here, a KMT official pointed out Tuesday.
Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, made the remarks at a news conference on the planned forum on cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural cooperation.

According to the initial arrangements for the KMT think tank, the forum and related activities are scheduled to take place Oct. 13-18 in Taipei, Chang said, noting that if everything goes well, the Chinese participants will arrive in Taiwan Oct. 13 for the two-day forum.
They will then visit central and southern Taiwan Oct. 16-17 before returning to China Oct. 18, Chang said.
If the government allows them to enter Taiwan, Chang added, the KMT is willing to help negotiate with the two sides on the trip arrangements.
Chang also urged the government to permit the agricultural forum to go ahead out of concern for local farming interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM PRAPIROON UNLIKELY TO AFFECT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Tropical Storm Prapiroon -- the sixth in the West Pacific this year -- is unlikely to affect Taiwan, as it was moving farther away toward the Chinese island province of Hainan off southern China, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Tuesday.
According to the CWB, by late Tuesday afternoon, the center of Prapiroon was located about 640 km south of Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan.
The tropical storm was moving west-northwest at 17 kph, with its speed expected to slow to 14 kph.
The CWB said that clouds around the tropical storm's 150-km radius might bring showers to southern Taiwan in the next three days.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WATER RATE HIKES THIS YEAR: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san said Tuesday that his ministry will work out a water rate adjustment formula within a month and set a goal of reducing water leaks by 2015.
But he pledged that the ministry will not raise the water rates this year and will continue to review its water rate policy.

Hwang made the remarks as participants in a national conference on sustainable economic development July 27-28 reached consensus on a slew of issues, including one on "reasonable adjustment of water rates."

Hwang admitted that the government pledged not to raise water rates earlier this year, but said that despite this, the rate review will go on and his ministry will study a water rate adjustment formula within a month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC BRACES FOR MAJOR OUTBREAK OF DENGUE FEVER

TEXT.P: With 32 indigenous cases of dengue fever having been reported in Taiwan this summer, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) warned Tuesday that a major outbreak is likely to occur unless the situation is brought under control by November.

According to CDC tallies, there have been 79 confirmed cases of dengue fever this year, with 45 contracted overseas and 34 indigenous cases, including 32 which have been reported since the start of summer.
This is different from last year when the first indigenous case in the summer was not reported until mid-August, CDC officials said.
All of the indigenous cases have been centered in the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas of southern Taiwan, with as many as 30 cases in Kaohsiung City alone.
CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting said this year's situation is similar to that of 2004, when a total of 336 indigenous cases were reported.

Pointing out that most of those cases occurred during a large-scale outbreak in September and October of that year, Lin predicted that a major outbreak could occur this year if the epidemic is allowed to continue into the winter.

Lin said that although the increase in the number of dengue fever cases has slowed over the past two weeks, the next two weeks will be an important observation period, given that the incubation period of the disease lasts three to 14 days.

If the number of cases continues to rise and they are centered around a single county or city, the CDC will investigate to make sure local governments have done their jobs such as eliminating mosquitoes and tracing the contacts of the victims, Lin said.

In light of the fact that as many as 5,336 cases were reported in 2002, the government will set up a cross-ministerial epidemic command center as soon as the number of indigenous cases exceeds 300 this year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AUTHORITIES ISSUE ALERT FOR CHINA-BOUND TRAVELERS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) urged China-bound travelers to be aware of their safety in the wake of news of a Taiwan businessman's murder in Xiamen, Fujian Province.

Chang Shih-chung, director of the SEF's trade and commerce department, called on Taiwan businessmen to assess their investment risks in China and urged Taiwan passengers to pay close attention while traveling in China, particularly during the summer vacation period.
According to Chang, the SEF immediately contacted the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Xiamen after receiving the news about the murder of Tseng Wen-fang, from the outlying island of Kinmen.

The SEF obtained agreement from Tseng's family to notify the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , Xiamen's public security authorities and the city's Taiwan affairs office, demanding that they arrest the murderer as soon as possible, Chang said, adding that the SEF also demanded that Tseng's family be given necessary assistance in handling his affairs.

The SEF helped deal with 83 cases regarding the personal safety of Taiwan businessmen operating in China in the first half of this year -- including robberies, shootings, blackmail, extortion and kidnappings, Chang said, adding that the number for the whole of this year might exceed last year's 133 cases.
The MAC oversees the SEF, which was set up to help deal with cross-Taiwan Strait affairs in the absence of government-to-government contacts. The ARATS is the SEF's Chinese counterpart.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELIZE, TAIWAN SIGN AGREEMENT ON INDIGENOUS AFFAIRS COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Belize, one of Taiwan's allies in Central America, signed an agreement on cooperation in indigenous affairs Tuesday in the hope of cultivating bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
The agreement was signed by Walis Perin, Minister of Taiwan's Council of Indigenous Peoples, and Sylvia Flores, Minister of the Belize Ministry of Human Development, on Taiwan's Indigenous Day.
It is Taiwan's third such cooperation agreement with foreign countries, following the signing of similar agreements with Canada and New Zealand in 1998 and 2004, respectively.

"Indigenous affairs has gradually become a focal point of the international community and we are glad to have an opportunity to work with Belize, a country that places importance on human rights and respects different races, " said Perin.

"We must respect the original people of our countries, " Flores said on the importance of indigenous people. She also said she was deeply moved by the culture and genuine welcome of Taiwan's indigenous people after an earlier visit to a couple of aboriginal villages.

DOC.HEADLINE: YAHOO! TAIWAN EXPLAINS AUCTION TRANSACTION FEE PLAN

TEXT.P: Reacting to complaints from dissatisfied users, Yahoo! Taiwan further explained at a press conference Tuesday a plan to start charging transaction fees for its online auctions.

Users have been complaining about an abrupt change in the past week following the announcement by Yahoo! Taiwan -- Taiwan's largest portal and operator of online auctions -- stating that it will start charging a 3 percent transaction fee on most auction items.
Yahoo also charges users for listing and various other functions.

Yahoo! Taiwan is not the first auction Web site to charge transaction fees and its rates are lower than those in Japan and the United States, according to Charlene Hung, Yahoo! Taiwan's vice president of e-commerce.

To reassure its users, Yahoo! Taiwan will conduct seminars throughout the country and improve its services, such as the mechanism of buying and selling and promotion of its auction service, Hung said.
It will also award each seller with five free item listings per month and raise the maximum compensation fee from NT$7,000 to NT$10,000.

Hung refused to speculate on the potential loss of users after the new plan is implemented. Taiwanese users of Yahoo's auction services have established a union and plan to negotiate with the company, while other users plan to simply use other free auction services.

The auction service of Yahoo! Taiwan was launched in 2001 and boasts 3.7 million listed items. According to market research group ACNielsen Corp., Yahoo captured 57.4 percent of all Taiwanese auction users, compared to 4.9 percent for eBay, which ranks in second place.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S HOUSEMAID RESIGNS FROM PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE JOB

TEXT.P: Lin Hsiu-chen, a housemaid who works for President Chen Shui-bian in a property owned by him and occupied by his daughter Chen Hsing-yu, has resigned as a janitor at the Presidential Office but will remain in Chen's private employ at his own expense, the Presidential Office said Tuesday.

The office's department of public affairs noted that all of the salary and bonuses paid to Lin from Presidential Office funds since Chen Hsing-yu married and moved into her parent's house on Minsheng East Road in Taipei, will be returned to the national coffers.

The department said the Presidential Office's employment of Lin was legal. However, media reports and widespread criticism of her employment have disturbed the presidential family as well as Lin herself.
Lin therefore offered to quit, an offer that the Presidential Office accepted, although the president then decided to hire her to work for his daughter's family.

Earlier, the Presidential Office had argued that the president's house, which he bought long before he became president, is "part of the president's official residence." Chen's official residence is actually on Chung Ching South Road, another part of the city entirely.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES VAGUE ABOUT CHINESE OFFICIAL'S PROPOSED TRIP TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) refused to comment Tuesday on reports that China's chief of Taiwan affairs, Chen Yunlin, will visit Taiwan in October.

A senior MAC official passed over journalists' questions about whether the MAC will approve Chen's trip or demand official negotiations with China before giving it a greenlight, saying that the council has not received an application from Chen to come to Taiwan, and that it would not answer hypothetical questions.

Chen, the director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, has been invited by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to attend an agricultural forum in Taipei Oct. 13-18 as part of exchanges between the KMT and the Communist Party of China.
The KMT also invited Chen to Taipei last October for another forum, but his application was rejected by the MAC on the grounds that it required official negotiations between Taipei and Beijing.
Beijing has refused to have any contact with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration in Taiwan because of the DPP's refusal to accept China's "one China" policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABLE TV CREWMAN BEATEN BY COURT BAILIFFS SEEKS STATE COMPENSATION

TEXT.P: A cable television engineer who was assaulted and injured by a group of bailiffs in front of the Taipei District Court Monday filed a lawsuit Tuesday against the officers and a separate suit seeking NT$1 million in state compensation.

Chu Wen-cheng, an engineer for Sanlih E-Television (SET), was with other TV journalists covering the departure from court of President Chen Shui-bian's son-in law, Chao Chien-ming, who is involved in an insider trading scandal.

A fracas between the bailiffs and some of the journalists developed into a free-for-all, with at least five of the bailiffs pulling Chu's hair and choking him in an attempt to overpower and arrest him.
The bailiffs carried Chu into a room of the courthouse where one of them punched and kicked him, Chu said, insisting that he was innocent and never touched any of the bailiffs as they claimed.
The Taipei Public Prosecutors' Office has charged Chu with interfering in the officers' official duties.
Doctors at National Taiwan University Hospital certified that Chu received multiple injuries to his head, neck, right arm and hip, and that he also showed signs of concussion.
Chu's lawyer said his client is suing the bailiffs for malfeasance in office, interference in his personal freedom and causing physical injury to him.

Earlier Tuesday, the Association of Taiwan Journalists (ATJ) condemned the bailiffs for using violence against Chu and other journalists and called for a judicial investigation to find those responsible for the violence.
The association also demanded that the Judicial Yuan apologize to Chu and to Taiwan society for the brutality in front of the courthouse.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOUR AGENT CALLS POLICE INTO DISPUTE WITH CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: A local tour agency called the police Tuesday over a dispute with a group of Chinese tourists, claiming that the Chinese visitors were intending to leave the group or overstay their visas.

As the 12-member group chose not to buy any products during shopping stops which the Taiwan travel agents brought them to during trips to Hualien, Taitung and Taipei, the travel agents tried to extort US$100 from each passenger for their "losses" in shopping commission.

Pointing out that shopping was not included in their original tour agenda, the visitors refused to pay, whereupon they were then driven by the Taiwan tour agents to the aviation police station in Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
With the intervention of the Travel Agent Association of ROC, the two sides finally settled their dispute but refused to give any details about the settlement.
The tourists, from Shengyang, Liaoning Province in northeastern China, were to continue the rest of their tour and to leave Taiwan Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXHIBITION FEATURING UNIQUE LOCAL PRODUCTS KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: An exhibition organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to showcase unique local products kicked off in Taipei Monday.

County and city governments were invited to show products unique to their regions at the exhibition, titled "One Town, One Product." Lai Sun-quae, director- general of the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the exhibition is also aimed at showing the success of the ministry's program to promote industries with local characteristics.
Under the program, Lai said, more than 2,000 firms in 111 different regional industries have been aided and 7,500 jobs have been created.

The "One Town, One Product" exhibition, which boasts ceramics manufactured in Yingke, Taipei County, the blue dying industry in Sanhsia, Taipei County, glassware manufactured in Hsinchu County, taro products from Tachia, Taichung County, and black tea grown in Yuchih, Nantou County, offers a glimpse into the great impact the program has had on local economies, Lai said.

In order to promote industries with local characteristics, Lai said the program offers soft loans of up to NT$20 million (US$609,633) to firms engaged in businesses associated closely with local history and culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES VAGUE ABOUT CHINESE OFFICIAL'S PROPOSED TRIP TO TAIWAN(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) refused to comment Tuesday on reports that China's chief of Taiwan affairs, Chen Yunlin, will visit Taiwan in October.

A senior MAC official passed over journalists' questions about whether the MAC will approve Chen's trip or demand official negotiations with China before giving it a greenlight, saying that the council has not received an application from Chen to come to Taiwan, and that it would not answer hypothetical questions.

Chen, the director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, has been invited by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to attend an agricultural forum in Taipei Oct. 13-18 as part of exchanges between the KMT and the Communist Party of China.
The KMT also invited Chen to Taipei last October for another forum, but his application was rejected by the MAC on the grounds that it required official negotiations between Taipei and Beijing.
Beijing has refused to have any contact with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration in Taiwan because of the DPP's refusal to accept China's "one China" policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 2, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: William II, known as "William Rufus," king of England from 1087, is slain by an arrow while hunting in New Forest. He was succeeded by his younger brother, who became Henry I.
1798: A 14-vessel naval squadron commanded by Rear Adm. Horatio Nelson scores a brilliant tactical victory over a French fleet of 17 vessels in the Mediterranean.
1918: British, French, and U.S. troops try to smash Lenin's communist revolution by supporting the White Russian forces and seizing Archangel.
1921: Enrico Caruso, the Neapolitan with the golden voice known as the world's greatest tenor of his time, dies at the Hotel Vesuvio in Naples at the age of 48.
1922: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor of the telephone in 1876, dies at the age of 76.
1923: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, dies in office at the age of 58. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1924: The Kwangchow government sets up the Central Bank of China with T.V. Soong (Soong Tzu-wen) as governor.
1934: Paul von Hindenburg, German general, politician, and president of the Weimar Republic, dies at the age of 86. He was succeeded by Adolf Hitler who declared himself "Der Fuhrer."
1938: Chinese troops blow up a bank along a section of the upper Yangtze River in an attempt to slow a Japanese advance.
1939: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, writes to U.S. President Roosevelt urging him to start an atomic project.
1944: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., U.S. Navy pilot and elder brother of John F. Kennedy, is killed when his plane explodes over the Belgian coast.
1945: The Potsdam Conference, the final Allied summit of World War II, comes to an end.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Dahomey, Niger and Upper Volta.
1961: President John F. Kennedy and visiting ROC Vice President Chen Cheng issue a joint statement in Washington, D.C., opposing the admission of mainland China into the United Nations.
1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a retaliatory strike after a torpedo attack on the U.S. Navy ship Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin.
1980: The International Telecommunications Administration inaugurates direct dialing station-to-station telephone service between Taipei and major cities in Britain, France and West Germany.
1985: Kuo Yu-hsin, former member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, dies of illness in Washington, D.C., at the age of 77.
1986: The ROC delegation to the Aug. 4 ROC-U.S. trade talks, headed by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Vincent C. Siew, leaves for Washington, D.C.
1990: Saddam Hussein makes good on Iraq's claim to the oil-rich state of Kuwait by invading it. Thousands of heavily armed Iraqi troops quickly cut through the defenses of their tiny Gulf neighbor and gain firm control of the capital city of Kuwait City.
1996: Michel Debre, former French prime minister, dies at the age of 84. He was Charles de Gaulle's trusted aide and the architect of the Fifth Republic.
1996: Typhoon Herb roars across northern Taiwan, leaving nearly 60 people dead or missing.
1999: The ROC representative to Japan, Chuang Ming-yao, expresses his grave concern to his Japanese counterpart about a plan by a group of Japanese lawmakers to land on the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
2000: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leads a delegation of senior KMT officials to pay a courtesy call on ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh at the DPP headquarters in Taipei.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records announces two of Taiwan's record-setting fathers as part of celebrations for Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8. One of the record-breakers is Lo Tseng-wen, who has five children serving as police officers, and the other is Chang A-piao, a centenarian who is living with four generations of offspring under the same roof.
2001: The final section of the 11.307-kilometer New Kuanyin Tunnel of the North Link Railway is blasted through, making it the longest two-way railway tunnel in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By banishing all flatterers and keeping away from the society of women; holding in low estimation possession of worldly goods, but valuing moral qualities in men: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to worthy men."
