DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN NURSES RECEIVING INTENSIVE TRAINING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A total of 24 senior nursing professionals from 12 countries have arrived in Taiwan for a 22-day intensive training program sponsored by the Taiwan International Health Action (Taiwan IHA).

The 24 senior nurses have come from the Marshall Islands, the Philippines, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, Kiribati, Bangladesh, Nauru, Palau, Indonesia, Vietnam and Mongolia, according to Taiwan IHA officials.
The nurses will receive intensive training Aug. 1-22 provided by the Taiwan Nurses Association, which is one of the 129 full members of the International Council of Nurses, the officials said.

The training program not only aims to offer a platform for senior and influential nurses from around the world to exchange views on their profession but also to increase Taiwan's visibility in the world's public health circles, the officials said.

Taiwan IHA, a supra-division governmental agency formally established in March of this year, is responsible for planning and organizing international public health cooperation between Taiwan and the rest of the world as well as for humanitarian aid and relief work.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES ARMS SALES TO LIBYA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) denied reports Wednesday that Taiwan may sell small arms such as rifles and machine guns to Libya.
"There is no such a thing as the media have reported, " MND spokesman Wu Chi-fang said.

Wu was responding to media reports that the ministry has embarked on military exchanges with Libya and that it invited ranking Libyan military officials to Taiwan to observe the "Han Kuang No. 22" live fire exercise last month. The reports also said that Taiwan may sell small arms and military-related equipment to Libya.
The reports came after President Chen Shui-bian's unexpected transit stop in Tripoli, Libya on his way back home from his two-leg Latin American visit in May.

President Chen signed a memorandum of understanding with Libyan authorities during his brief visit to the North African country, which is expected to boost trade, fishery, tourism, science and technology, as well as petrochemical cooperation between the two countries.
In a move to attract Taiwan tourists and show its friendship with Taiwan, Libya also announced that Taiwan citizens will be allowed to enter the country visa-free.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19 THAI WORKERS REPATRIATED

TEXT.P: Nineteen illegal Thai workers were repatriated back to Thailand Wednesday under the escort of an official Thai delegation.
The repatriation is part of a humanitarian program dedicated to celebrating the 60th anniversary of the accession to the throne of King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand.

The 19 Thai workers, who were arrested for residing in Taiwan illegally or overstaying their visas, were escorted by the Thai delegation comprised of 30 immigration officials and members of a women's association of the Royal Thai Police, which arrived in Taiwan July 31 for the repatriation.
The workers, including 17 men and two women, had been kept in Taiwan police custody because they could not afford to pay their fines or for plane tickets back to Thailand.
They were allowed to depart from Taiwan after their fines and airfare were paid jointly by a number of Taiwan businesspeople and some other related agencies.
More than 400 overseas Thai nationals around the world have benefited from the free repatriation program as part of the Thai king's anniversary celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAUNCHES DRIVE TO IMPEACH PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) initiated Wednesday a campaign to impeach President Chen Shui-bian whom they alleged is corrupt and dishonest.

In a statement, the caucus accused Chen of failing to disclose his assets truthfully and using receipts received by others to claim state affairs expenses, which the caucus said is a betrayal of his oath made during his inauguration.
The motion must be endorsed by more than 50 percent of the legislators before it can be presented to the legislature for consideration.
Caucus convener Lu Hsueh-chang expressed optimism that the campaign will succeed because unlike a presidential recall motion, legislators vote on an impeachment motion by secret ballot.

Also, the impeachment motion is simpler compared with a no-confidence vote against the premier, which can lead to the dissolution of the legislature and interrupt the offices of sitting legislators, Lu said.

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy research center, said he is confident that the motion, if put to a vote, will obtain the support of more than two-thirds of the legislators as long as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party does not interfere in the decisions of its legislators.

If more than two-thirds of the legislators vote for the impeachment motion, it will be referred to the Council of Grand Justices for review. The president will be removed from office if the council finds the impeachment motion well-grounded.
The PFP and its ally, the opposition Kuomintang, initiated a motion to recall Chen in June, but the motion failed to get the support of a two-thirds majority in the legislature.

According to previous reports, the PFP was planning to make a second attempt to recall Chen when the legislature begins its next session in late September and was considering launching a no-confidence vote against Premier Su Tseng-chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGE ON 40% CEILING LIMT ON INVESTMENT IN CHINA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang reaffirmed Wednesday that the current 40-percent ceiling on investment in China by local enterprises remains in place.
Premier Su made the remarks during a weekly meeting of the Executive Yuan in which Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu reported on management of cross-strait trade.

Su said that as no consensus was forged on the issue in the just-concluded national economic conference, which was intended to seek ways to sustain Taiwan's economic development over the next 10 years, "the government has not changed the ceiling limit."

Local enterprises had called for the raising of the limit in the "global deployment and cross-strait economic and trade " session of the conference for their viability, but the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union party was opposed to the proposal, which it said is in line with President Chen Shui-bian's latest Chinese investment policy of "active management and effective opening."
The controversial proposal was later listed under "other options" for reference and further deliberations by the Cabinet.

Su noted that if 70 percent of Taiwan's outbound investment were to go to China, the ratio would be too high, adding that such a figure would be to high regardless of what the destination country were.
The premier urged businesspeople not to put all their eggs in one basket and instead diversify their investment and increase their investment in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE CONSENSUS TAKEN SERIOUSLY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government is taking seriously consensus reached in the recently concluded Conference on Sustaining Taiwan's Economic Development and relevant Cabinet agencies will come up with concrete measures in one month to put those consensus into practice, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday.
Consensus was reached on 516 policy initiatives to realize the goal of expanding investment in Taiwan during the July 27-28 conference, Su said during a regular Executive Yuan meeting.

Those initiatives categorized as "common opinions " will be referred to agencies under the Executive Yuan for planning and implementation, while other initiatives will be compiled to be used by the administration as references, Su was quoted by Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang as saying during the meeting.

According to Cheng, the premier also asked relevant Cabinet agencies to craft bills or revisions to the policy initiatives agreed upon by representatives from different sectors at the conference so that the Legislative Yuan can speed up legislation or law revisions to facilitate the implementation of the policy initiatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOI DENIES AGENTS FORCED TO SIGN CONFIDENTIALITY AFFIDAVITS

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Investigation (BOI) denied Wednesday that a prosecutor investigating alleged misuse of the president's special state affairs funds has told investigators to sign affidavits promising they will not leak any information about the probe.

The United Daily News had claimed that Prosecutor Chen Jui-jen of the Taiwan High Court Prosecutor's Office has called in several investigators to demand that they sign affidavits to ensure they will not leak information about the investigation.

However, the BIO issued a statement denying that any such thing had happened and lodged a strong protest with the newspaper for making a false report aimed at driving a wedge between the prosecution and investigative authorities.

The Prosecutor Office's Anti-corruption Center is reportedly investigating whether the Presidential Office broke the law in its use of a NT$30 million fund budgeted for the president's discretionary use in rewarding the armed forces and holding social events.

Thousands of Israeli soldiers streamed into southern Lebanon on Tuesday, as clashes with Hezbollah fighters in at least half a dozen towns marked an intensified ground campaign to dislodge Hezbollah strongholds that have withstood three weeks of aerial bombardment. (By Jorge Liu)

Premier Romano Prodi's decision to call again a confidence vote on the government's budget for the next year sparked a row Tuesday in the parliament. DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO HELP BUSINESSES REDUCE COSTS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang pledged Wednesday that the government will help businesses reduce their investment costs to achieve the goal of "investing in Taiwan first."
Su instructed relevant Cabinet agencies to review existing measures to facilitate land acqusition and financing of businesses, as well as increasing tax incentives.
The agencies should also seek to improve public infrastructure and labor laws and regulations to create a favorable investment environment, Su said.
In addition, they should integrate government- and private-sector resources to attract foreign investment and assist businesses to remove various investment barriers, he said.
The premier made the remarks during a weekly Cabinet meeting in which he was briefed on the conclusions reached at a conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic development held last week.

Su noted that during the "Tahsi conference" held in August 2002, President Chen Shui-bian first put forth the idea of "investment first, economy first, Taiwan first, investing in Taiwan first" and that the Council for Economic Planning and Development later also worked out an "investing in Taiwan first" plan based on the president's concept.

While addressing the opening of last week's conference, Chen reiterated that "investing in Taiwan first" should be the basic framework of the government's investment policy, which shows that the government is consistent in its policy, Su said.

According to Su, all the issues discussed in the conference were aimed at laying a sound foundation for the "investing in Taiwan first" strategy that encourages Taiwan businesses to increase their investment in Taiwan, making Taiwan their operational hub while laying out their business network globally.

The conference was also intended to continue to create a favorable environment to attract more foreign investment to sustain Taiwan's economic growth, create more employment opportunities and enhance the country's competitiveness, the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 NEW FISH FOUND OFF EAST COAST

TEXT.P: Four new fish varieties have been discovered off the eastern coast, including a member of the apogonidae family and members of the coryphaenidae, ophichthidae and labridae families, the Fisheries Research Institute announced Wednesday.

According to the institute under the Council of Agriculture, apogonidae -- temporarily named apogon sp. -- has never been recorded in any fishery research documents and the institute is currently seeking confirmation as to whether it is a newly discovered species.

As for the three others, an official of the institute said they have been identified as coryphaena equiselis, brachysomophis henshawi and xyrichtys geisha, which are found in other countries but which have never before been spotted near Taiwan.

He explained that as the institute is rearranging its fishery archive and digitizing the entries for Taiwan's National Digital Archives Program, the staff found the four species "suspicious, " so they made close comparisons with the taxonomic database and decided that they were previously unrecorded.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS CONTINUE TO DEFEND PRESIDENT OVER STATE AFFAIRS BUDGET

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators continued Wednesday to defend President Chen Shui-bian in regard to a controversy over how he has used his special state affairs fund.

Yeh Yi-chin, secretary- general of the DPP legislative caucus, said her caucus respects an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) caucus decision to go over every page of the fiscal year 2005 final budget accounts that include Presidential Office budgets.

Like a group of DPP lawmakers who had seen some receipts shown by the president, Yeh claimed that the president "will absolutely stand the test" because he has not pocketed any of the special budget for his discretionary use.

DPP Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni said that if the president has used some state affairs funding to promote the country's foreign relations, he would not be a "pioneer" in so doing, suggesting that Chen's predecessors did the same.
Apparently then admitting that the president has indeed done so, she added: "Nor will he be the last president to do so, " adding that Chen has done so for the sake of "national security."

Huang Wei-che, another DPP lawmaker, said some secret diplomatic tasks can only be conducted through a "one-way command channel" that may not be made known to the foreign affairs and national security authorities.

As to criticism that Chen might be trying to "drag down former President Lee Teng-hui along with him" when he showed the lawmakers how Lee had used the funds, DPP lawmaker Wang Shih-chien denied that this was what Chen was aiming at.

Chen could not show any documents from the authoritarian era of presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo because "during that time, all of the country belonged to the president, who did not need to account for his budget," Wang said.
Yeh said that the president was not intending to imply that Lee Teng-hui did a similar thing with regard to the use of the special state affairs fund.
"Even if files could be found about how both Chiangs used the fund, it would only show that there were no rules at all," she added.

Her KMT counterpart, Tsai Chin-lung, claimed that when it comes to the legislature's turn to screen the 2005 final budget accounts, his caucus would "keep a close watch" over how taxpayers' money had been used.
He urged the Presidential Office to cooperate with the National Audit Office and the prosecution and "bare all receipts and invoices used to claim the special state affairs expenses."
Yeh said individual lawmakers can go to the Presidential Office to see all relevant files and data but they must keep the contents of "secret files" to themselves.
If the KMT caucus demands the Presidential Office make public even those "confidential files, " it must bear the consequences of leaking state secrets, she warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WILL HAVE FINAL SAY ON TAIWAN VISIT BY CHINESE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will have the final say on matters regarding a visit to Taiwan by China's chief of Taiwan affairs, Chen Yunlin, Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Wednesday.

Responding to reports that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will again invite Chen, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, to visit Taiwan in October for an agricultural forum, Cheng said it seems the KMT has not yet filed any application with the MAC for Chen's visit.
The MAC will screen and handle the case in accordance with relevant regulations after it receives an application for a permit for the Beijing official's Taiwan visit, Cheng added.
MAC officials refused to comment the day before on a possible visit by Chen, saying that as the council had not received an application from Chen, it would not answer hypothetical questions.

News reports said Tuesday that Chen has been invited by the KMT to attend an agricultural forum slated for Oct. 13-18 in Taipei as part of exchanges between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC).
The KMT invited Chen to visit Taipei last October for an economic forum, but his application was rejected by the MAC on the grounds that it required official negotiations between Taipei and Beijing.

Consequently, the KMT organized a mission under the leadership of KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chen that traveled to Shanghai last October to take part in a KMT-CPC economic forum -- the first of its kind in nearly six decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 60 points to close at 6,439, with 35,217 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September rose 69 points to finish at 6,430, with 376 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 52 points to close at 6,420, with 10 contract transactions.
June futures remained unchanged to close at 6,395, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,379 for August, 6,361 for September, 6,368 for December, 6,405 for March and 6,395 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

August TE futures moved up 2.15 points to close at 270.8, with 4,542 contracts traded, while September TE futures rose 1.05 points to finish at 270, with 57 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.
August TF futures gained five points to close at 926, with 1,758 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved up 3.4 points to finish at 924.2, with 20 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved up 3.6 points to close at 926.8, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.046 to close at NT$32.864.
A total of US$942 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.818, and fluctuated between NT$32.787 and NT$32.886.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CHENG KUNG UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL REPORTS GOOD PROFITS

TEXT.P: Net profits of National Cheng Kung University Hospital over the past three years are equal to the amount of its first 15 years, hospital superintendent Chen Chih-hung said Wednesday.
Chen said the profits numbered in the tens of millions, although he did not give an exact number during a news conference to mark his re-election as hospital superintendent.
Chen said the hospital's talent nurturing has borne fruit since its opening 18 years ago, although the hardware and equipment have also become outdate and are being phased out and replaced.
He also said he will renovate the wards in the next two years.
The hospital will also spend NT$2.2 billion (US$67.69 million) to build a second medical building, scheduled for completion in four years.
Chen also announced that the hospital will select five young doctors to study at prestigious medical schools overseas in the next three years.
The program will mainly target young doctors interested in research in such areas as oncology, cardiovascular medicine, neurology, and stem cell and regenerative medicine.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC URGES TRAVELERS TO BALI TO AVOID CONTACT WITH BIRDS

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) Wednesday urged travelers heading for the Indonesian island resort of Bali to avoid contact with birds or their droppings in the wake of a bird flu outbreak in the popular holiday destination.

If travelers display flu-like symptoms such as fever and aching muscles after their return they should seek medical treatment immediately and report their travel history to their doctors, CDC officials said.
The virulent H5N1 bird flu virus has been found to have been responsible for the death of 300 chickens in Jembrana in western Bali last week.
CDC officials noted that in April, the virus was also found in a duck farm in Bali's Gianyar region, which led to the slaughter of hundreds of ducks in neighboring areas.
Since 2005, 54 people in Indonesia have been confirmed to have been infected with bird flu, 42 of whom have died, according to CDC tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAILIFFS CRITICIZED AS `TOO ARBITRARY'

TEXT.P: Several civic groups condemned Wednesday the bailiffs of the Taipei District Court as "too arbitrary" and too emotional in their treatment of journalists, expressing fear that Taiwan might become a "police state" should the situation continue.

Chu Wen-cheng, a member of a Sanlih E-Television (SET) crew, was brutally assaulted and detained by a group of bailiffs in front of the Taipei District Court while covering the trial of whether three indicted suspects in an insider trading scandal, including President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming, should be detained again.

Without clear evidence, the bailiffs detained Chu for what they claimed was his "interference in their public duties." However, the televised scenes of the bailiffs behaving like thugs -- brutally pulling Chu's hair and dragging him into the courthouse for a beating -- has imprinted profoundly on public opinion.

Several civic groups, including the Association of Taiwan Journalists (ATJ) , the Judicial Reform Foundation (JRF) and the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU), held a press conference Wednesday to protest against the bailiffs' brutality against innocent people and to urge the government to amend the law on assemblies to ensure the public's right to present petitions and plead their cases.
TEPU Secretary-General Ho Tsung-hsun noted that as well as journalists, social activists are also detained frequently by the bailiffs without clear reasons and usually without evidence.
Ho also claimed that Taiwan's policemen behave hysterically.
JRF executive Ma Tzai-chin claimed that the police today do not think of the basic civil rights of the public and that policemen in the former Kuomintang administration were more tolerant.

ATJ executive Chen Hsiao-yi said the bailiffs' assault on Chu infringed upon journalists' rights to cover the news and affected Chu's personal safety. Chen demanded that the Judicial Yuan review the bailiffs' behavior and apologize to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURS AROUND HENCHUN PENINSULA ORGANIZED

TEXT.P: To help the public gain an understanding of industrial and humanistic relics on the Henchun peninsula, the Kenting National Park Administration and the Henchun Community College will jointly sponsor tours around the region, a spokesman for the administration said Wednesday.

The tours, which will take place Aug. 12, Aug. 13, Aug. 19 and Aug. 20, will allow the public to better understand the traditional culture and folk customs on the Henchun peninsula -- the southernmost tip of Taiwan. The area was important for its production of sisal since the early 1900s until the 1970s, when the sisal industry gradually died out due to the emergence of nylon rope.

The sisal industry has deeply influenced the local economy and environment of the Henchun region, and the tours will take participants to exhibition areas of the sisal industry -- factory buildings and production facilities left from the Japanese occupation period within the Kenting National Park -- the spokesman said.

The exhibition will help the public fully explore the links between the Henchun peninsula and the sisal industry and understand the integration of human activities with the natural environment, the spokesman said, adding that tour guides will also teach participants to dye cloth with natural dyes produced in the region.
The Kenting National Park is one of the most popular tourist spots in Taiwan, attracting millions of foreign and domestic visitors every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OPPOSES MOEA'S PLANNED HIKE IN WATER RATES

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) expressed strong opposition to a planned hike in water rates Wednesday, insisting that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) must not increase the rates without legislative approval.

KMT legislative caucus whip Tsai Chin-lung made the remarks at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan in response to news reports that the MOEA is planning to implement the increase of about 30 percent early next year -- an issue that was agreed upon during a national economic conference on sustainable growth that wrapped up last week.
The KMT is firmly opposed to the MOEA's plan because an adjustment might whip up a chain reaction in consumer prices at a time when workers' salaries are shrinking in real terms, Tsai said.
The MOEA must first submit its pricing formula for discussion at the Legislative Yuan, he insisted.

Since Premier Su Tseng-chang assumed office early this year, prices in oil products have been raised three times and electricity rates once, while a hike for the national insurance program premiums is also being mulled, in addition to the latest one in water rates, Tsai said.
"The price of everything is picking up, while salaries are not, " Tsai argued, criticizing Su for having doing nothing to maintain consumer prices stability and stimulate the economy.

Citing statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Tsai noted that the salaries of Taiwan's 6 million workers averaged NT$34,490 per month last year, reflecting a substantial shrinkage of 1.28 percent in salary after being adjusted for inflation.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING OF HSUEHSHAN TUNNEL HAS LITTLE IMPACT ON YILAN AIR QUALITY

TEXT.P: The opening of the Hsuehshan Tunnel has had little impact on the air quality of Yilan, where the concentration of air pollutants has remained similar before and after the tunnel's opening, the Yilan county government's Bureau of Environmental Protection said Wednesday.

To track the impact of the tunnel on air quality, the bureau has installed monitors at the tunnel's exit to survey pollutants such as carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, ozone, sulfur dioxide, benzene and methyl benzene around the clock.

The results of a month-long survey conducted between June 17 and July 28 show that the concentration of carbon monoxide averaged 0.24 ppm per hour, which is much lower than the maximum acceptable level of 35 ppm, bureau officials said.

While the concentration of carbon monoxide was higher during busy periods, the concentrations of other pollutants show no significant differences before and after the opening of the tunnel, the officials said.

The Hsuehshan Tunnel, which was inaugurated June 16, is the centerpiece of the 55-km Peiyi Freeway linking Taipei to the northeastern county of Yilan. The 13-km tunnel is the fifth-longest of its kind in the world and Southeast Asia's longest.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD HAS GRAND PLANS FOR TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Taipei should be "managed as a capital city, " and what it needs most is a new round of land reforms that will allow more people to share its resources, opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Wednesday.
Soong briefed the media of his plans for the city after he visited all 449 of the city's boroughs, but remained tight-lipped as to whether he will run for mayor later this year.
He criticized the city government led by Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also chairman of the nation's largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT).

The city government has a problem of "not taking the initiative, not coordinating, not being responsible, not attaching importance to the grassroots and not having an overall plan for leading the city, " Soong claimed.
Because earlier KMT governments were interested only in "recovering the mainland" it lost to the communists, city planning and legislation for Taipei were quite sloppy, he said.
"Taipei is by no means a local government, " he claimed, vowing to lead it as "the capital city and an international city, " for which a second round of land reforms would be needed.

In a capital city, it would be unreasonable for the military and the central government to use too large a portion of its land and even more unreasonable for Taipei County to own 880 pieces of land, Soong claimed.
Therefore, he said, Taipei should claim back all of the land that is rightfully its and pursue land reform to allow city residents to share its resources.
"If we continue to allow big enterprises to enjoy priority in developing the city's land resources, it will never make progress, " he claimed.

Soong said that because he has "thought through" a lot of issues facing Taipei, he has decided not to follow in the footsteps of the KMT and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , both of which have taken turns being in charge of the city government.
Instead, he told the media, "I'd like to lead the city's citizens to run toward the whole world."
Opinion polls show that Soong is trailing behind the KMT's mayoral nominee Hau Lung-bin and the DPP's Frank Hsieh and is ahead only of the Taiwan Solidarity Union's Chou Yu-kou.
His candidacy would only serve to boost Hsieh's chances of election, as it would split the "pan-blue alliance" vote, according to most observers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 29.96 points to close at 6,471.42.
The bourse opened at 6,426.23 and fluctuated between 6,488.68 and 6,421.78 during trading. A total of 2.55 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$61.2 billion (US$1.86 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 2.9 percent, followed by construction issues at 1 percent, textile issues at 0.8 percent, electronics and machinery shares at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks at 0.4 percent, and financial shares at 0.2 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged while foodstuff issues dropped 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 539 to 403, with 183 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES EFFORTS TO CHANGE U.S. 'ONE CHINA' POLICY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that as long as there is a will, there is a way to change the U.S. "one China" policy toward Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks when he received a group of Taiwan goodwill ambassadors selected by the U.S.-based Formosa Foundation to visit the United States to seek support for Taiwan's cause.

Chen said the ultimate goal of the foundation, founded in 2001 by Wu Li-pei, one of his former senior advisers, is aimed at swaying U.S. policy toward Taiwan so as to change it from "one China" to "one China, one Taiwan."
Whether this will succeed or not will "depend on the efforts of the people, " he claimed.
Although there is still a long way to go to reaching this goal, "as long as one does not give up and follow the right path, there will be a day of success," he said.
Chen expressed his appreciation for the work done by the Formosa Foundation.

He noted that the foundation invites 10 young men from Taiwan each year to the United States. This year, the young men visited 40 U.S. states, adding that they met with 159 congressmen and aides to elaborate on Taiwan's separate identity and its efforts to defend peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, as well as the difficulties it faces, in particular Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization and its efforts to sign a free trade agreement with the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: We must rethink the War on Terror - Blair
Five years into the War on Terror, Tony Blair called yesterday for a "complete renaissance of our strategy" to defeat militant Islam.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: International Herald Tribune: Israel moves deep in Lebanon. Israeli troops captured suspected Hezbollah militants during an airborne raid in Baalbek, 100 km from the border. The raid was backed by air strikes that killed 19 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Israel Expands Ground Forces Inside Lebanon
Israel sent up to 7,000 troops into Lebanonon Tuesday, a significant increase in a ground offensive aimed at pushing the Hezbollah militia back from the border before a cease-fire is declared and a multinational force deployed. The troops, backed by air support, tanks and armored bulldozers, entered at four places along the border, moving up to 4.5 miles inside to engage Hezbollah fighters and destroy their outposts and structures.
Wall Street Journal: Castro's Illness Opens Window On Cuba Transition
Raul Castro, Cuba's new temporary leader, is beginning what may be a long and uncertain transition from his legendary older brother's long rule over this communist island bastion. The announcement Monday that Fidel Castro, after undergoing surgery for intestinal bleeding, had temporarily handed power to his uncharismatic and widely feared younger brother set off all- night celebrations in Miami. Cuban exiles there are convinced the beginning of the end has arrived for Castro's 47-year-old regime. Castro. In the short run, 75-year-old Raul should be able to maintain control of the island, but over the longer term, any successor to Fidel must be able to cope with the country's deep-seated economic problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VOWS TO FIGHT INTRA-PARTY ELECTION BRIBERY

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) Evaluation and Disciplinary Committee warned the 31 newly elected members of its Central Standing Committee Wednesday that they will be stripped of their qualification to serve on the committee if evidence shows that they have rewarded their voters in any form.

Juan Kang-meng, head of the KMT disciplinary committee, told reporters that his committee was investigating a report that one of the newly elected Central Standing Committee members hosted a dinner party in Kaohsiung July 31 to celebrate his success and thank some 100 supporters and KMT delegates who voted for him in the election.
"If there is concrete evidence that the member in question hosted the dinner to reward those who voted for him, he will be disqualified from the Central Standing Committee," Juan said.

The Central Standing Committee is the KMT's policy-making body. Its 31 new members -- elected by some 1,500 party delegates from 106 candidates serving on the Central Committee -- will serve a one-year term.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou wanted a clean election and declared zero tolerance for any acts of bribery. The KMT offered a NT$1 million reward to anyone who could offer information on incidents of irregularities, including candidates holding parties or giving presents worth more than NT$30.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESENTATION TO BE HELD TO EXPLAIN FTA BETWEEN TAIWAN, GUATEMALA

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) will hold a presentation Thursday on a free trade agreement signed between Taiwan and Guatemala.

BOFT officials noted that the FTA went into effect July 1 and said they will explain the products covered by the FTA, and the certification on the country of origin, to help enterprises make good use of the agreement to expand their business opportunities.
The officials said they will also introduce bilateral trade between Taiwan and Guatemala, the benefits of the FTA and related procedures.

They noted that Taiwan signed the FTA with Guatemala after it signed FTAs with Panama and Nicaragua, which they said will help Taiwan products to make inroads into the market of the American Free Trade Agreement zone.

The BOFT has invited more than 160 Taiwan manufacturers who have exported more than US$50,000 to Guatemala over the past three years to take part in the presentation, they said, adding that anyone interested in the FTA is also welcome to attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACCUMULATED PROFITS FROM LOTTERY SALES TOP NT$107.4 BILLION

TEXT.P: Accumulated profits from the country's welfare lottery sales had reached NT$107.4 billion as of the end of June, Taipei Fubon Bank said Wednesday.

The earnings have been appropriated as reserve funds for both a planned national pension program and the existing national health insurance program and to finance welfare service projects launched by city and county governments around the country, a spokesman for the bank said.

In June alone, welfare lottery sales turned up profits of NT$1.55 billion, of which NT$696 million went to national pension program reserve funds and NT$77.38 million to health insurance reserve funds, with the remaining NT$773 million allocated to various local governments for welfare service projects.
Taipei County received the largest amount of subsidies from lottery profits in June, followed by Taipei City, Taoyuan County, Kaohsiung City and Taichung County, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITY GOVERNMENT URGED TO RECLAIM SALARIES FOR 'FICTITIOUS' EMPLOYEE

TEXT.P: The Transportation Committee under the Taipei city council demanded Wednesday that the city government reclaim salary it paid to a caregiver of first lady Wu Shu-jen.

The committee made the demand after Chang Chi-te, commissioner of the Department of Rapid Transit Systems confirmed a Wednesday newspaper report that the caregiver, Shih Li-yun, was paid by the department between December 1994 and April 1995 when President Chen Shui-bian was serving as mayor of Taipei.

Shih was put on the department's payroll on the orders of Liao Cheng-chin, at the time secretary-general of the city government, and was assigned to work in Liao's office. However, she was actually Wu's caregiver and could often be seen pushing Wu's wheelchair when Wu appeared in public.
Shih quit her job at the rapid transit department April 16, 1995 after drawing about NT$120,000 in salary, Chang said.
As Shih was Wu's personal nurse and had never actually worked at the transit systems department, councilors on the Transportation Committee told Chang to ask Shih to return the money.

The incident came to light after the president, who headed the city between 1994 and 1998, was found to have put one of his housemaids on the payroll of the Presidential Office. The maid works at a house owned by Chen but occupied by his daughter.
In an attempt to calm the "public uproar, " the president's daughter offered Tuesday to reimburse the government for salary paid to the housemaid.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADERS DECIDE TO SUSPEND MANGO SALES TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Officials of Tainan County's Bureau of Agriculture in southern Taiwan said Wednesday that local traders decided to suspend mango exports to Japan for the rest of the year as it is not the fruit's peak season.

The officials were responding to media reports the Japanese government decided to suspend mango imports from Taiwan after its health authorities detected excessive pesticide residue on Taiwan grown-mangoes in mid-July.
The reports were not true, the officials said, adding that it was the decision of local traders.

According to statistics compiled by the Council of Agriculture (COA) , as of July 27 Taiwan's mango exports totaled 599,751 kilos, with 448,071 kilos heading to Japan, 146,785 kilos going to South Korea and 4,895 kilos shipped to New Zealand.
After the discovery of excessive pesticide residue on some Taiwan-grown mangoes, the COA took the initiative of suspending the shipping permission of five mango exporters.

In addition to ordering a thorough investigation into the issue, COA Minister Su Jia-chyuan also suggested the Department of Health disseminate information among local farmers about correct pesticide usage.
Tainan County officials noted that as the harvest season for mangoes has come to a close, there will be no more mango exports to Japan for the rest of this year.
However, the officials added, they will continue inviting Japanese quarantine officials to Taiwan to inspect the quality of Taiwan-grown mangoes next year when the mango crop goes into peak season.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATORS SEIZE LARGE AMOUNT OF FAKE MEDICINE

TEXT.P: Investigation Bureau agents launched a second crackdown on fake medicine in 11 of Taiwan's cities and counties Wednesday, seizing large amounts of counterfeit drugs sold under false brand names.
Led by prosecutors from the Miaoli District Court, some 100 investigators searched 22 locations simultaneously, including 18 pharmacies and several distributor warehouses.
They discovered not only fake drugs under well-known brand names -- such as Viagra, a drug for male impotence, and Reductil, a weight-control medicine -- but also some narcotics.
The investigators questioned 15 suspects and then referred the cases to the prosecutors.
The crackdown was a follow-up operation based on leads obtained during a July 25 raid on a fake medicine distribution center in Taichung.

During that raid, a mobile unit of the Investigation Bureau seized 1 million fake pills of various medicines -- totaling 300 kilograms -- and arrested a chief suspect surnamed Wu, who admitted that he had been supplying counterfeit medicine to pharmacies in various cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP URGES KMT TO BACK IMPEACHMENT MOTION AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong urged the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Wednesday to support an impeachment motion that it has launched at the Legislative Yuan to oust President Chen Shui-bian amid a spate of corruption allegations surrounding his family members and close aides.
Soong issued the call during a lunch meeting with reporters after PFP lawmakers began collecting endorsements at the Legislative Yuan for an impeachment bid that it launched earlier the same day.

According to Soong, the opposition parties must not continue turning a deaf ear to the public's strong discontent with Chen's allegedly corrupt government. The many corruption allegation surrounding members of Chen's family and his trusted followers have seriously tainted Taiwan's democratic image, he claimed.

Meanwhile, PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Shueh-chang criticized Chen's intention to make a report to the public regarding his role in a controversy arising from the questionable reimbursement of state affairs spending by the Presidential Office on Chen's behalf as a scheme to divert public attention away from the corruption allegations.
Chen is being pushed by strong public pressure to do so rather than being driven by his own remorse, Lu claimed, arguing that this "does not deserve public respect."

Lu urged the investigation and accounting authorities to start an immediate investigation into where the special state affairs expenses have gone now that an initial investigation by the Ministry of Audit has already discovered that the reimbursement of over NT$20 million in the funds from 2003 to 2005 claimed by the Presidential Office was suspicious.

According to the law, the president is entitled to claim as much as NT$50 million per year in state affairs expenses at his discretion to carry out various special tasks, such as providing cash rewards for military personnel and hosting banquets for foreign dignitaries, but not "confidential" or "secret" missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY TO BE EXEMPTED FROM OUTPATIENT REGISTRATION FEES

TEXT.P: A Department of Health (DOH) official said Wednesday that starting in September, hospitals under the agency will begin offering several types of preferential treatment to elderly citizens over the age of 70.
As Taiwan is becoming an aging society, medical care for the elderly is becoming a potentially key market.

Lin Shui-lung, the chief executive of a commission responsible for operations at 35 DOH-run hospitals, noted they will be opening more outpatient services for chronic ailments, and citizens over 70 will be exempted from paying outpatient registration fees at DOH hospitals around Taiwan starting from September.

In addition, Lin added, these hospitals will operate registration and medicine counters exclusively for elderly citizens, as a way to shorten the time they generally have to spend visiting the hospital.
Lin recommended visiting the DOH Web site for more information: www.doh.gov.tw

DOC.HEADLINE: 'GIRLS OF SUMMER' BATTLE IN WOMEN'S BASEBALL WORLD CUP

TEXT.P: Uneven scores and little fanfare couldn't stop their love for baseball as seven international teams battle this week in the second Women's Baseball World Cup, which runs from July 31 - Aug. 6 in Taipei.

Host team Taiwan, Australia, Japan, Canada, Hong Kong, Cuba and the U.S. make up the field as the U.S. seeks to defend its crown in the single round-robin tournament that was inaugurated in Edmonton, Canada in 2004.
Compared to their male counterparts, who are often called "boys of summer, " these "girls of summer" haven't seen the popularity or skills of men's baseball, however.

Attendance in Tienmu Baseball Stadium has numbered less than 100 in the first three days of the competition. The fact that Japan pounded Hong Kong in a shutout by an unbelievable score of 43-0 doesn't convince anyone that this is a genuine world cup event, either.

But it shows the game of baseball is still in a promotional stage in the women's world. Cuba, which has been long known as a men's baseball powerhouse, didn't start developing its women's baseball program until two years ago, said Cuba head coach Jesus Escudero Rodriguez.

Home team Taiwan didn't have a women's national team before recruiting softball players for the tournament. Hong Kong, which dropped 86 runs in the first three games while only scoring three times, didn't even have a regular baseball field before last year, said Lee Yat-keung, Hong Kong's head coach.

On the other side of the spectrum, Japanese women's baseball ranks among the world's best, along with the U.S. and Canada. Japan has been developing women's baseball for 10 years and has a women's league of more than 20 teams.
One thing in common is they all love to play the game.
"I love the excitement of baseball compared to softball, " said 33-year-old Liu Tsu-hsin, a former softball player and one of the most senior players on the Taiwanese squad.

"I truly love this game. And we'll get better with more development of women's baseball in Hong Kong," echoed Hong Kong's Lau Tsu-chin, who is only 14 years old but has baseball experience from playing on Hong Kong boys' little league team.
Rodriguez is also optimistic about the game's future, saying that Cuban women's baseball, given time, will one day be as good as men's baseball.

The rules of women's baseball are almost the same as for men, with the same field dimensions and type of hardball. However, women are allowed to use aluminum bats and the regulation play is seven innings instead of nine.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung: Israel cabinet approves expansion of offensive. Advance to Litani River?/Rice hopes for UN resolution this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSUEI MA MA FOUNDATION ISSUES CERTIFICATES TO GOOD MOVING COMPANIES

TEXT.P: Tsuei Ma Ma Foundation for Housing and Community Service announced Wednesday that it has issued a new certificate to 24 moving companies in Taiwan that have passed the foundation's strict standards.

The foundation's executive director, Lu Ping-yi, said the 24 companies have 34 shops within Taiwan's 10 metropolitan areas; all have been jointly evaluated by the foundation and consumers as honest and responsible businesses.
If any dispute should arise between consumers and the recommended companies, the foundation will work as a mediator to help both sides reach a settlement, Lu added.
These 24 companies have signed a contract with the foundation pledging they will offer quality services to customers, she added.

The foundation presented an "excellent moving company" certificate to company executives during a ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of the recommendation service at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei.

Lu said on the heels of issuing this year's "excellent moving company" certificate, next year the foundation will recognize a number of professional movers to further promote quality service in the moving industry.
Tsuei Ma Ma foundation was named after a mother who had dedicated her life to helping people find a good place to live with affordable rent.

The "reasonable rental" campaign was initiated in the late 1980's in Taipei, when people who couldn't afford a house formed an organization called "Snails Without Shells" to air their grievances about skyrocketing housing prices.
The foundation also has a program that teaches people about their housing rights and duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RAILWAY MAY ABOLISH PRACTICE OF 'WOMEN ONLY' CARRIAGE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) is considering whether to abolish its two-month-old practice of keeping a 'women only' carriage in every train after becoming the target of criticism.
The TRA followed Japan's example and launched the special coach service for women June 1 after an increasing number of women passengers complained about groping in crowded trains.

Although the TRA has designated the last coach of every train for female commuters only, many male passengers have refused to honor the practice on grounds that all passengers deserve the same treatment.
Some male passengers criticized the TRA for "depicting all males as sexual maniacs," while others claimed the practice might be "unconstitutional."
Women passengers did not seem to be enthusiastic from the onset, either. Women's rights groups criticized the practice as "reinforcing the stereotype that women need protection."
When told by CNA that TRA will conduct a review next week to decide whether the practice should continue, a few female passengers seemed indifferent.
"It's difficult to find the women only carriage, and when you do find it and get in, you still see men sitting in there. So it doesn't make much difference," one female passenger said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT UNDECIDED ON WHETHER TO ADJUST PAY SCALE: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has not yet decided on whether to increase next year's salaries for government employees, military personnel and public schoolteachers, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Wednesday.

Cheng was responding to media reports that the government's pay scale screening committee reached a consensus Tuesday on recommending the Executive Yuan not adjust salaries for civil servants, military personnel and public schoolteachers next year in consideration of the government's financial straits and salaries in the private sector.

Since many factors have to be weighed before adjusting the government's pay scale -- such as the domestic inflation rate, economic growth rate and the government's financial status -- the relevant government agencies haven't yet considered any pay scale adjustment issue, Cheng said.

Customarily, Cheng said, the Central Personnel Administration and the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics would not address the issue until after all public agencies have drafted budgets for next year by the end of August.
"Up until now, the two agencies have not yet discussed whether to adjust the government pay scale for the coming year," Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS KEY ROLE OF PRAGMATISM IN CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday the government will address issues regarding commercial and tourist exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in a pragmatic manner.

Su was quoted as having made the remarks during a meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Central Standing Committee, in which Vice President Annette Lu asked Su how the Executive Yuan would deal with a planned Taiwan visit by some 500 Chinese employees of U.S.-based software giant Microsoft Corp. later this month.

Su said the government will take active steps to promote cross-strait commercial and tourist exchanges as long as such engagements do not have any adverse impacts on Taiwan's national security and sovereign status.

The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said earlier the same day that it has approved an application by Microsoft Taiwan Corp. for 421 Microsoft China Corp. staff members to visit Taipei late this month, to attend an annual conference of Microsoft senior executives from three Chinese-speaking societies -- Taiwan, China and Hong Kong.

The commission said it has approved the application on grounds the event is purely a commercial activity on the part of a multinational corporation, which may eventually facilitate the multinational business groups' bid to make Taiwan their global outsourcing center -- and in turn contribute toward Taiwan's economic development.
The commission has informed the immigration office under the National Police Agency of its approval, MOEA officials said.

Under current regulations, the number of members of any visiting Chinese business delegation should not exceed 30. But in the past, the government has approved visits by large Chinese delegations under certain special circumstances, such as attending Rotary International's annual conference.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday the government will adopt an open-minded attitude toward handling the Microsoft case now that the just-concluded national conference on sustaining Taiwan's economic development has reached a consensus on easing restrictions on cross-strait personnel exchanges.
The MAC as the country's top mainland policy planning agency has the final say on the Microsoft application.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES NO MISUSE OF STATE FUNDS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with several senior pro-independence activists Wednesday to assure them that he not "feathered his nest" with state funds set aside for discretionary state affairs expenses.

The meeting came after the Ministry of Audit under the Control Yuan -- the nation's supreme watchdog body -- said last week that documents related to the Presidential Office's reimbursement of expenditures from a "discretionary state affairs expense allowance" fund last year contained irregularitries and had been referred to the prosecutor's office for investigations.

Chen was quoted as having told the pro-independence elders, including Examination Yuan President Yao Jia-wen and former presidential advisers Wu Li-pei and Koo Kuan-min, that he couldn't understand why the Ministry of Audit has held him to standards different from those applied to his predecessors.

It was not uncommon that his predecessors, such as the late presidents Chiang Ching-kuo and Yen Chia-kan as well as former president Lee Teng-hui, had used non-confidential special state affairs funds for confidential events, Chen said, adding that none of them had been required to present receipts for reimbursement.

According to media reports, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said during acity council question-and-answer session Tuesday that the late president Yen Chia-kan had typically returned the "discretionary state affairs expense" funds to the national coffers. However, Legislative Yuan documents and records showed that Yen never returned a penny of that fund to the nationl coffers during his presidency from 1975 to 1978.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 3 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Aug. 3:
08:40, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang will attend a seminar on public safety to be sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference.
14:30, Premier Su Tseng-chang will hold an informal gathering with local reporters at the Executive Yuan auditorium.
15:00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with top winners of the 46th academic competitions for elementary and junior high school students.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RAILWAY MAY ABOLISH PRACTICE OF 'WOMEN ONLY' CARRIAGE(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) is considering whether to abolish its two-month-old practice of keeping a 'women only' carriage in every train after becoming the target of criticism.
The TRA followed Japan's example and launched the special coach service for women June 1 after an increasing number of women passengers complained about groping in crowded trains.

Although the TRA has designated the last coach of every train for female commuters only, many male passengers have refused to honor the practice on grounds that all passengers deserve the same treatment.
Some male passengers criticized the TRA for "depicting all males as sexual maniacs," while others claimed the practice might be "unconstitutional."
Women passengers did not seem to be enthusiastic from the onset, either. Women's rights groups criticized the practice as "reinforcing the stereotype that women need protection."
When told by CNA that TRA will conduct a review next week to decide whether the practice should continue, a few female passengers seemed indifferent.
"It's difficult to find the women only carriage, and when you do find it and get in, you still see men sitting in there. So it doesn't make much difference," one female passenger said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS KEY ROLE OF PRAGMATISM IN CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES(repeat)

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday the government will address issues regarding commercial and tourist exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in a pragmatic manner.

Su was quoted as having made the remarks during a meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Central Standing Committee, in which Vice President Annette Lu asked Su how the Executive Yuan would deal with a planned Taiwan visit by some 500 Chinese employees of U.S.-based software giant Microsoft Corp. later this month.

Su said the government will take active steps to promote cross-strait commercial and tourist exchanges as long as such engagements do not have any adverse impacts on Taiwan's national security and sovereign status.

The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said earlier the same day that it has approved an application by Microsoft Taiwan Corp. for 421 Microsoft China Corp. staff members to visit Taipei late this month, to attend an annual conference of Microsoft senior executives from three Chinese-speaking societies -- Taiwan, China and Hong Kong.

The commission said it has approved the application on grounds the event is purely a commercial activity on the part of a multinational corporation, which may eventually facilitate the multinational business groups' bid to make Taiwan their global outsourcing center -- and in turn contribute toward Taiwan's economic development.
The commission has informed the immigration office under the National Police Agency of its approval, MOEA officials said.

Under current regulations, the number of members of any visiting Chinese business delegation should not exceed 30. But in the past, the government has approved visits by large Chinese delegations under certain special circumstances, such as attending Rotary International's annual conference.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday the government will adopt an open-minded attitude toward handling the Microsoft case now that the just-concluded national conference on sustaining Taiwan's economic development has reached a consensus on easing restrictions on cross-strait personnel exchanges.
The MAC as the country's top mainland policy planning agency has the final say on the Microsoft application.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES NO MISUSE OF STATE FUNDS(repeat)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with several senior pro-independence activists Wednesday to assure them that he not "feathered his nest" with state funds set aside for discretionary state affairs expenses.

The meeting came after the Ministry of Audit under the Control Yuan -- the nation's supreme watchdog body -- said last week that documents related to the Presidential Office's reimbursement of expenditures from a "discretionary state affairs expense allowance" fund last year contained irregularitries and had been referred to the prosecutor's office for investigations.

Chen was quoted as having told the pro-independence elders, including Examination Yuan President Yao Jia-wen and former presidential advisers Wu Li-pei and Koo Kuan-min, that he couldn't understand why the Ministry of Audit has held him to standards different from those applied to his predecessors.

It was not uncommon that his predecessors, such as the late presidents Chiang Ching-kuo and Yen Chia-kan as well as former president Lee Teng-hui, had used non-confidential special state affairs funds for confidential events, Chen said, adding that none of them had been required to present receipts for reimbursement.

According to media reports, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said during acity council question-and-answer session Tuesday that the late president Yen Chia-kan had typically returned the "discretionary state affairs expense" funds to the national coffers. However, Legislative Yuan documents and records showed that Yen never returned a penny of that fund to the nationl coffers during his presidency from 1975 to 1978.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 3, or the 10th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
216: An army led by Carthaginian General Hannibal defeats a huge Roman army, seizing its supply depot in the Battle of Cannae and killing some fifty thousand Roman soldiers.
1460: Scottish King James II is killed by the English during the siege of Roxburgh Castle.
1492: A flotilla of three ships, led by Christopher Columbus, sets sail from the Spanish port of Palos de la Frontera in search of a land called India.
1867: Stanley Baldwin, British Conservative prime minister three times between 1923 and 1937, is born.
1872: Haakon VII, Norwegian monarch who refused to surrender to the Germans in World War II, is born in Denmark.
1881: William George Fargo, American pioneer of long-distance express service, dies at his home in Buffalo, New York, at the age of 65.
1904: The Dalai Lama flees Lhasa as British troops invade Tibet. The Ching court on Aug. 26 orders the Pachen Lama to take over Tibetan affairs from the Dalai Lama.
1916: German troops launch a surprise attack on British forces in the Sinai in Egypt. Some 5,000 German soldiers are killed, while British loses amount to 1,100 men.
1929: Emile Berliner, German-born American inventor, dies in Washington D.C. at the age of 78. He greatly improved the telephone and invented the gramophone in 1887.
1940: Lithuania is formally incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
1958: Nautilus, the U.S. atomic submarine, becomes the first vessel to reach the North Pole under the ice.
1959: Japan Airlines formally inaugurates its Tokyo-Taipei route.
1967: The ROC Executive Yuan decides to extend the period of compulsory education from six to nine years beginning in 1968.
1969: Minister of Economic Affairs K.T. Li (Li Kuo-ting) receives the 1968 Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service.
1972: Sheng Chin-lai is appointed dean of the Engineering College at Chiaotung University.
1972: Brig. Gen. William C. Buttows, new chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command, arrives in Taipei.
1973: The Flying Tiger Line inaugurates air freight services between Kaohsiung and New York.
1974: Economics Minister Y.S. Sun and Paraguayan Minister of Industry and Commerce D. Ugarte Centurionuan sign an agreement in Taipei to boost economic cooperation between the Republic of China and Paraguay.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives eight members of the U.S. 14th Air Force Association, including Mrs. Anna Chennault, widow of the 14th Air Force's commander, Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault.
1977: A US$100 million loan agreement is signed in Taipei between the Taiwan Power Company and 17 banks from five foreign nations.
1981: President Ronald Reagan orders the firing of 12,000 striking air traffic control workers.
1986: Construction of the Synchronous Radiation Research Center under the Executive Yuan is started at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park. It is scheduled for completion within five to six years.
1988: Mathias Rust, a West German youth who landed his light air plane near Moscow's Red Square in 1987, is released from prison and expelled from the Soviet Union.
1999: Nine renowned scientists and former intelligence and military officials send a letter to all 100 U.S. senators calling for the prompt ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to prevent the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets by Communist China.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian directs the ROC Air Force to draw up a forward-looking blueprint for developing a new generation of warplanes to ensure supremacy in the skies over the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By extending the powers of their functions and allowing them discretion in the employment of their subordinates: that is how a ruler gives encouragement to the high ministers of state."
