DOC.HEADLINE: NO IRREGULARITIES IN TAIPEI MAYOR'S EXPENSE REPORT: AUDITOR

TEXT.P: No irregularities have been found in Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's 2005 special allowance expenditure report, the Ministry of Audit (MOA) under the watchdog Control Yuan said Thursday.

The government watchdog made the remarks in a letter to Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party who asked the MOA last week to look into Ma's annual special expense accounts amid allegations that half of the mayor's special allowance funds have been remitted into his personal bank account.

After scrutinizing Ma's special expense accounting report, the MOA said the Taipei City government appropriated NT$340,000 (US$10,330) as Ma's special allowance per month in 2005, or NT$4.08 million for the whole year, to finance official function expenditures, including hospitality, gifts and certain public services.

Quoting a 1998 Executive Yuan letter to the Control Yuan, the MOA said half of the special allowance funds for the head of a government agency can be reimbursed with his or her signature guarantee and the remaining half should be reimbursed with invoices or receipts.
According to the Taipei City government's payment regulations, the MOA said, half of the mayor's special allowance fund, or NT$2.04 million for the year, was remitted into Ma's personal bank account.

Another NT$2,039,587 was spent on entertainment, feasts and gifts for official functions, the MOA said, adding that all those spendings were reimbursed with invoices or receipts. The MOA said it didn't find any violations of established budget and audit regulations or misstatements or omissions of information.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTRY OF INTERIOR URGED TO REGULATE POLITICAL PARTY ASSETS

TEXT.P: A civic group called on the Ministry of the Interior Thursday to set rules that would force political parties to manage their assets in a transparent way.
The National League for Monitoring the Reform of Party Assets made the call for the sake of reforming the nation's party politics so that integrity will not be a mere slogan, but a reality.

Yang Wei-che, convener of the league, said the ministry should set the rules in accordance with the civic groups law and then enforce them, since the "political parties law" has not been passed by the Legislative Yuan.
Before the political parties law can be enacted, the ministry should set clear rules on party assets in accordance with Article 66 of the civic groups law, he added.

Chang Ching-yuan, a lawyer who attended the league's press conference urging the government to set the rules on party assets, said it's not strange that companies are set up for the purpose of making profits according to the corporate law.
"It would be terrifying for political parties to own political power and then use that power to make profits," Chang said.

Therefore, he added, the Ministry of the Interior should "administer according to the law" and demand that political parties regularly publicize their asset management and financial reports as a means to stop illegal profit making practices.
Kao Chien-chih, a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said it is completely reasonable to demand transparency for political parties in regard to their management of party assets.
"The law is applicable to all political parties and is not aimed at any specific party," Kao said.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which had been Taiwan's ruling party for over five decades until 2000, is accused of owning a large number of "ill-gotten" assets that the other parties are demanding should be returned to the state.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS NO PLAN TO ADJUST 'MINI THREE LINKS' POLICY

TEXT.P: The government has no plan to adjust its policy on the "mini three links, " which should operate according to Taiwan's laws, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman (MAC) Liu Te-hsun said Thursday.

Liu was responding to a provisional measure announced Wednesday by the government of China's Fujian Province that the direct shipping links between Fujian and Taiwan's offshore islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu will be subject to the regulations governing the transportation industry.
Also, the ships sailing the routes will only fly the flags of their companies and will not raise the flags of the destination ports while entering and leaving the ports, according to the measure.
Liu said that the "mini three links" are operating in accordance with existing regulations and that it is impossible to implement any unilateral measures by China.

While there are regular ferry services between Kinmen and Matsu and Fujian, the shipping links between Penghu and Fujian are being conducted under a "special trial" program, with shipping companies required to obtain the Cabinet's approval before operating the route, Liu noted.

Liu said according to the law governing relations between Taiwan and China, Chinese vessels are not allowed to enter the waters of Kinmen, Matsu or Penghu unless they have obtained the approval of Taiwan's government.

Pointing out that the journey between Penghu and Fujian is a long one and includes a section on the high seas, Liu said that problems could arise if ships sailing the route do not fly the proper flag.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT'S ACCOUNTING RECORDS CONTAINED CONCRETE INFO: WANG

TEXT.P: Legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that former President Lee Teng-hui used to list names, codes and amounts in his accounts of the special state affairs fund while President Chen Shui-bian "has his own way" of making his accounts.

Wang declined to comment on which of the two presidents was following the accounting principles and regulations more "strictly" except to point out that Lee's accounts contained "concrete" information about how the money had been spent.

The speaker was shown classified files concerning the use of the special state affairs fund budgeted for the president's discretionary use when President Chen Shui-bian invited him to the Presidential Office Tuesday.
Chen showed Wang receipts and other documents indicating how Lee used the special fund from 1994 to 2000 during his time in office, according to Wang.

"What I saw were major state secrets, " Wang said, noting that it is quite common in a democracy that the speaker of the legislature gets the chance to have a look at the most important national secrets.

As to what the president had shown to other people, such as Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators and spokesmen, after the controversy erupted over Chen's use of the state affairs fund, Wang said he had no idea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN SCIENCE PARK'S PRODUCTION VALUE TO REACH US$15.38 BILLION

TEXT.P: Tainan Science-based Industrial Park's total production value has shown stunning growth over the last few years, and it is expected to reach NT$500 billion (US$15.38 billion) for this year, the deputy director general of the park's administration said Wednesday.

Wu Meng-fen made the remarks at a forum to solicit manufacturers to set up shop in the park while reporting on the situation of the park, which registered a production value of NT$352.8 billion for last year and a growth in production of 50.68 percent for the first six months of this year.

Wu noted that the 1,000-hectare Tainan Science-based Industrial Park is the largest among all of Taiwan's science parks in terms of a single land area. He added that sitting right next to the park is 3,299 hectares of land dedicated to the production of LCD TVs.
"The park and adjacent land are large enough to form a new community," he said.
He also noted that the central and local government have worked very closely in developing the park, adding that the park is the largest optoelectronic industrial park in Taiwan.

Magistrate Su Huan-dji of Tainan County, where the park is located, also lauded the excellent investment environment of the park which he said has ample supply of water, electricity and land as well as a large pool of workers.
There are also 12 colleges and universities and 15 research institutions nearby and a convenient traffic network that links the park with a nearby airport and high-speed rail station, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HE WAS FORCED TO SHOW CLASSIFIED RECEIPTS: EX-ADVISERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told a group of pro-independence stalwarts Wednesday that he was forced to show receipts on the use of a special fund because "the outside world was accusing me as if I were a suspect of embezzlement, " one of the stalwarts said Thursday.

Wu Li-pei, a former senior adviser to the president, said he and four others met with the president Wednesday. The others were Chen's former senior advisers Koo Kuan-min, Huang Chao-tang and Kang Ning-hsiang, and Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen.
Wu said the president showed them receipts on how he had used the special state affairs fund to "prove his innocence," and "we believed in his innocence."

The prosecution is reportedly investigating alleged irregularities involved in the Presidential Office's accounting records on the use of the special state affairs fund budgeted for the president's discretionary use.
Wu and the other four staunch advocates of Taiwan independence told Chen he needed not explain to them how he had used the fund as they trusted him anyway.
If any violations of the law have taken place, they should be handled by the judicial authorities, they added.

They suggested that instead of spending his time and energy on explaining media reports about his private affairs, the president should use his time to think about how to lead the country for the remainder of his term of office which expires in May 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: STANCE ON RISK MANAGEMENT IN CROSS-STRAIT TRADE UNCHANGED: CABINET

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's stance on risk management in cross-strait trade remains unchanged, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan reaffirmed Thursday.

Cheng's remarks came amid reports that several heavyweights of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party questioned Premier Su Tseng-chang's cross-strait policy in a DPP Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday, believing it might run counter to President Chen Shui-bian's "active management and effective opening" policy on investment in China.

The premier had previously called for more open cross-strait exchanges and put the controversial 40-percent ceiling cap on investment in China by local enterprises on the agenda of the just concluded economic conference, which was intended to seek ways to achieve sustainable economic development over the next 10 years.
Cheng said "some media have reported as if the cap had been eased, although that is not the case, and the Executive Yuan's stance on risk management of cross-strait trade has remained unchanged."

He said that no consensus was reached on the easing of the investment ceiling at the July 27-28 economic conference despite strong urging by local businesses out of concern for their viability, but it was later listed under "other options" for reference and further deliberations by the Cabinet.
Premier Su also said openly Wednesday that the ceiling will remain in place as no consensus was reached at the conference.
Cheng noted that consensus was reached on 516 policy initiatives, and the Cabinet will map out a time schedule to push for the implementation of the initiatives.

On the issue of hundreds of Chinese staff of Microsoft coming to Taiwan for a regional meeting later this month, Cheng said the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei have long suggested that the government allow multinational cooperation to convene meetings in Taiwan.

Now that a consensus has been reached on the matter, it will be left for the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council to screen applications before deciding whether to give the green light, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIPEI HYPERMARKETS POSE FIRE HAZARDS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The environment at most hypermarkets in the city and county of Taipei pose fire hazards, with the most serious problems being found at RT-Mart's Chunho store and Carrefour's Tucheng store, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the Consumers' Foundation.

The survey was conducted from July 28-31 on 12 hypermarkets, including the Chungho, Keelung and Tucheng stores of RT-Mart; the Panchiao, Yungho and Chunghsiao stores of Geant; the Panchiao, Chungho, Tunghsing and Tucheng stores of Carrefour; and the Sanchung and Keelung stores of Megaful.

While RT-Mart's Chungho store and Carrefour's Tucheng store received failing grades in six of 20 safety categories, Megaful's Sanchung store and Geant's Chunghsiao store got failing grades in five categories, and RT-Mart's Keelung store and Geant's Panchiao failed in four categories, according to the survey.

Failing grades included those for fire hydrants being obstructed by other objects, passageways being too narrow, the pressure on fire extinguishers not being set properly, emergency exits being blocked, emergency escape facilities not being installed properly, and safety signs not being set up at escalators.

Officials from the foundation said that as the fire hydrants at some stores were covered by large piles of goods, it would be difficult for consumers to locate the fire hydrants in the event of a fire.
Some stores even turned the fire hydrants into part of the decorations, the officials said.
They urged the government to inspect the hypermarkets regularly to ensure the safety of consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF PEOPLE EXPECT PUBLIC EXPLANATION FROM PRESIDENT: POLL

TEXT.P: A total of 53.1 percent of the people think that President Chen Shui-bian should give the public a complete explanation and accept questions from the media on the corruption allegations against the first family, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by Global Views Monthly.
While 62 percent of the respondents said they do not believe Chen's explanation on the spending of his special state affairs expense allowance, only 18.2 believe it, the survey shows.
Among supporters of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, 53.8 percent said they believe Chen's explanation, while 26.5 percent do not.

On Chen's using the Presidential Office budget to hire a domestic helper to work for his married daughter over the past five years, 68.7 percent of the respondents think that it was inappropriate for the president to do so, compared with 18.2 percent who said it was okay.
Also, 24 percent of the respondents think the corruption scandals involving high-ranking government officials and the first family have done serious harm to the government's credibility.

Meanwhile, 52 percent of the respondents said they hope Premier Su Tseng-chang will dominate the government's cross-Taiwan Strait policy, compared with 21 percent who said Su should fall in line with Chen's policies.
The survey was conducted from Aug. 1-2 on 853 adults around Taiwan, with a margin of error of plus or minus 3.4 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHEEP WITH EXCESSIVE DIOXIN IN BALI TO BE SLAUGHTERED

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei ordered on Thursday that the sheep on a ranch in Bali Village in the suburbs of Taipei City be slaughtered due to excessive dioxin residue in their bodies.
Chou gave the order after two tests confirming that the meat and milk from the sheep on the ranch contain excessive amounts of dioxin.

Taipei County government has excluded the possibility that feed and the incinerator in Bali are the sources of the dioxin contamination, and it will continue checking the land and the livestock and poultry raised on the ranches in nearby Linkou.

Chen Chang-yu, director of Taipei County government's Bureau of Agriculture, said the county government will help ensure the slaughter of all the 49 sheep on the ranch to prevent the mutton and the sheep milk from entering the market.

Teng Chia-chi, director of Taipei County government's Environmental Protection Bureau, noted that the mutton produced on the ranch has been supplied exclusively to the ranch owner's restaurant and has never entered the wider market, urging the public not to panic.
Teng said that this case is likely an isolated one and that sometimes, it is not easy to confirm the source of contamination.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO WATCH WHETHER PREMIER STICKS TO PLEDGE ON CHINA INVESTMENT CAP

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will monitor whether Premier Su Tseng-chang sticks to his pledge on not easing the ceiling on the amount local enterprises can invest in China, the legislative caucus whip of the pro-independence party said Thursday.
David Huang was responding to the premier's open pledge the previous day that the 40-percent investment ceiling will remain in place.

Huang noted that President Chen Shui-bian's latest "active management, effective opening" policy on investment in China is identical to that of former President Lee Teng-hui, the spiritual leader of the TSU.
"Su's pledge Wednesday is only echoing the basic stance of the TSU," Huang said.

Huang noted that under the current system, for those companies whose paid-in capital is under NT$5 billion (US$153.84 million), the cap on investment in China is 40 percent, while for those companies whose paid-in capital is between NT$5 billion and NT$10 billion, the ceiling is 30 percent, and for those companies with paid-in capital of over NT$10 billion, the cap is 20 percent.
He said that what worries his party is that the premier might scrap the "ladder" ceiling structure and set the cap at 40 percent for those companies whose paid-in capital is over NT$5 billion.
"The TSU will not allow such an alternative way of opening, " Huang said.
The party will continue to monitor the Executive Yuan's stance on cross-strait trade and whether the premier will stick to his pledge that the current cap system will remain unchanged, he added.

Huang's remarks came amid reports that several heavyweights of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party questioned Premier Su's cross-strait policy in a DPP Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday, believing it might run counter to President Chen's latest cross-strait investment policy.

The premier had previously called for more open cross-strait exchanges and put the controversial 40-percent ceiling cap on investment in China by local enterprises on the agenda of the just concluded economic conference, which was intended to seek ways to achieve sustainable economic development over the next 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down 31 points to close at 6,408, with 35,058 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 30 points to finish at 6,400, with 441 contracts traded, while December futures moved down two points to close at 6,418, with 16 contract transactions.
March futures lost 28 points to close at 6,437, with only one contract traded, while June futures gained 30 points to finish at 6,410, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,439 for August, 6,430 for September, 6,420 for December, 6,465 for March and 6,380 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

August TE futures moved down 0.55 points to close at 270.25, with 3,807 contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 0.15 points to finish at 269.6, with 107 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.
August TF futures lost 8.8 points to close at 917.2, with 1,205 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 6.6 points to finish at 920, with 18 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CLAIMS IT ISN'T CONVINCED BY PRESIDENT ON SPECIAL FUND ISSUE

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislators who met with President Chen Shui-bian claimed Thursday the meeting did not mean an endorsement of Chen or that they were "bought over" by the president's explanation in a controversy over his use of a special state affairs fund.

Huang Shih-chuo, convener of the TSU's legislative caucus, said he and three other caucus members met with the president Wednesday to "monitor, not to endorse" and to "communicate with, not be bought over" by the president in the controversy over the special state affairs fund, which was budgeted for the president's discretionary use.
Huang, Liao Pen-yen, Kuo Lin-yung and Huang Tsung-yuan heard Chen's explanation about his use of the funds and the accounting procedures that were in place.
"It's beyond our capacity to make a judgment on whether the receipts the president showed us were legal or not, " said the convener.

He noted that the president took the opportunity to clarify that when he met with other people over the matter, he did not compare himself with his predecessor Lee Teng-hui, who is considered the TSU's spiritual leader.
Rather, Huang noted, Chen showed great respect for Lee, praising him for having "institutionalized" Feng Tien and Tang Yang projects for conducting "secret diplomacy."

DOC.HEADLINE: BALL IN TAIWAN'S COURT OVER BEIJING OFFICIAL'S VISIT: KMT

TEXT.P: The ball is in Taiwan's court over deciding whether to allow a senior Beijing official in charge of Taiwan affairs to visit, an official of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, said that Chen Yunlin, director of the Communist Party of China's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, will file an application in mid-August with the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to attend a mid-October forum in Taiwan to be sponsored by the KMT.

To secure the personal safety and convenience of visiting Chinese officials and participants here, KMT-affiliated thinktanks would like to exchange opinions with relevant government authorities over the issue if necessary, Chang said, urging the government to carefully assess the matter.
According to the KMT, the cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural forum is slated to be held from Oct. 13-18.

Honorary KMT Chairman Lien Chan led a KMT delegation to visit Beijing in late April this year, where the two political parties jointly held an economic seminar -- the first of its kind since 1949 after Taiwan and China split in a civil war -- to study ways to bolster cross-strait communication and exchanges.
Lien first visited China in 2005 in his capacity as chairman of the KMT -- a landmark visit by a KMT chief to China in more than 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST SON RETURNS TO TAIWAN FROM U.S.

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's son Chen Chih-chung returned to Taiwan from the United States Thursday.
The younger Chen and his wife Huang Jui-ching arrived at CKS International Airport in the morning, keeping a low profile and carrying only two pieces of luggage between them, airport officials said.

Chen has completed two master's degree in the United States whilst his pianist wife received a master's degree from the Manhattan School of Music. Reports have said Huang is now pregnant with her first baby.

The younger Chen's return comes at a time when the president is embroiled in a controversy over alleged misuse of state funds set aside for his discretionary use, on top of a political storm over a spate of corruption allegations against his close aides and family members, which has seriously dented the image of the president and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Hezbollah Unleashes Fiery Barrage; 230 Rockets Strike Northern Israel, Shattering Brief Lull.
Hezbollah shattered two days of relative calm in northern Israel on Wednesday, spraying the region with more than 230 rockets that set buildings and forests ablaze, wounded at least 33 civilians and killed a man as he rode his bicycle in front of his home.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Israel talks peace as the battle rages
Ehud Olmeert set out his conditions to bring an end to more than three weeks of fighting in Lebanon yesterday when he called for a robust force of 15,000 foreign combat troops, including British soldiers, to be deployed in the south of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAPERLESS PROCESSING OF CAR IMPORT CERTIFICATES TO START AUG. 10

TEXT.P: Paperless processing of car import certificates will officially start Aug. 10, officials from the Directorate General of Customs said Thursday.

Starting Aug. 10, no paper certificates will be issued except in cases where the importation of cars is being exempted from import duties or when the car owner is entitled to a commodity tax refund, the officials said.

They said paperless processing is expected to shorten the amount of time people spend on applying for license plates as well as the time customs authorities spend on processing related documents. The new measure will also help prevent forgery, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.001 to close at NT$32.865.
A total of US$819 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.935, and fluctuated between NT$32.850 and NT$32.949.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 9.1 points to close at 6,462.32.
The bourse opened at 6,496.01 and fluctuated between 6,514.9 and 6,460.03 during trading. A total of 2.97 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.83 billion (US$2.48 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.2 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.

The other five major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.1 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, construction issues at 0.3 percent, and textile stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 483 to 466, with 173 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR SERVES AS SPOKESMAN FOR ANTI-SMOKING CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu acted as a spokesman Friday for an anti-smoking campaign launched jointly by Taichung city's health bureau and Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd.
Hu accepted the offer in a ceremony that was also presided over by Hsieh Chun-ming, deputy general manager of Chunghwa Telecom's central branch.

Stating his ambition to turn Taichung into a "smoke-free happy city," Hu urged citizens to kick the habit and get rid of second-hand cigarette smoke, which can be extremely hazardous to expectant mothers and children.

This is the first time that Taichung city and Chunghwa Telecom have cooperated to raise public awareness by spreading an anti-smoking message throughout the city's main streets and in prime commercial districts.
The municipal health bureau will post 110 public notice boards in government agencies, medical institutions, markets and other public spaces to raise awareness about the dangers of smoking.
Apart from that, bureau officials said, radio stations, bus ads, cable TV stations and print media are also channels that will be used to promote the anti-smoking message.

In line with the campaign, Chunghwa Telecom is also sponsoring a contest to create mobile phone melodies. Eleven of 56 contenders have qualified to enter the final competition, vying for cash prizes. Mobile phone rings created by the 11 winners will be available as a free download starting Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA RESEARCHES KINMEN ISLAND'S 'LIVING FOSSILS'

TEXT.P: Researchers at Academia Sinica have begun a 12-month observation and evaluation project on horseshoe crab habitats on the outlying island of Kinmen, according to a press release issued Thursday by Taiwan's top research institution.

Academia Sinica's Research Center for Biodiversity was commissioned by the Council of Agriculture to study the efficacy of a 1999 conservation drive to protect the species and the possible impact on the crustacean's habitats by the construction of Shui-tou Wharf.

A research fellow at the Biodiversity Center said horseshoe crabs have existed on Earth for more than 400 million years and have remained in their present form for 200 million years; therefore, researchers and Kinmen residents sometimes describe them as "living fossils."

However, he noted, due to over-exploitation by humans, the local genus of horseshoe crab, Tachypleus tridentatus, has become rare in Taiwan and Penghu, while Kinmen is the only remaining major habitat of the horseshoe crab.

He said the Kinmen County Government set aside some 800 hectares of land as a horseshoe crab reserve near Kuningtou beach in 1999, and the size of the horde in that reserve has became an important index of the performance of conservation efforts.
He added that the building of Shui-tou Wharf may also influence the reserve's ecology, so the Biodiversity Center's team was also asked to run an environmental assessment of the construction plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S CAMPAIGNING RULE NOT AIMED AT SPECIFIC CANDIDATE: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A rule approved by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) forbidding party members from stumping for non-party candidates in the year-end mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung is not aimed at any specific individual, a KMT lawmaker said Thursday.
Legislator Tsai Chin-lung, the clerk of the KMT's legislative caucus, said the rule will apply equally to all party members.

Noting that in the past many non-KMT candidates have often claimed that a KMT leader has endorsed their candidacy in hopes of riding to victory on the coattails of their high-profile patrons, Tsai said this has occurred because the KMT didn't forbid its members to campaign outside party boundaries.
Citing himself as example, Tsai said he was often listed as a campaign worker of non-KMT candidates entirely without his knowledge.
Tsai said the new rule will help party members ward off non-KMT candidates' requests to stump for them.

He made the remarks in response to a report carried in the Liberty Times that claimed the rule was crafted to preempt KMT Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng from campaigning for People First Party Chairman James Soong, who is widely expected to run for Taipei mayor.
However, the paper said the rule does not forbid the party's mayoral candidates in the two cities from campaigning for candidates of other parties who support their bid for City Hall.

This means Hau Lung-bin and Huang Chun-ying -- KMT candidates for the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively -- can stump for PFP councilors in the two special municipalities in order to gain their support.

KMT lawmaker Ho Tsai-feng, who did not attend Wednesday's KMT meeting in which the rule was approved, said the limitation is sure to offend PFP candidates and is thereby not in the party's best interests.

Pointing out that the KMT and PFP -- which share the same support base -- had agreed to limit the number of candidates with a quota that was agreed upon by both sides, Ho said forbidding cross-party campaigning will cost the KMT the support of its PFP followers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DENIES SAYING HE WILL RELAX CHINA-BOUND INVESTMENT CAP

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang denied Thursday that he said he will relax the 40 percent ceiling on investment in China by Taiwanese businesses.

Su told reporters that his attitude has been consistent all along and he made clear that the consensus reached at a conference on sustainable economic development for Taiwan at the end of July should be implemented, while further communication should continue on those issues where the participants failed to agree.
He noted that relaxation of the existing cap on China-bound investment was one of the issues on which the participants at the conference did not reach consensus.
"I never said I wanted to relax the restriction or to simplify the issue as a matter of either/or," Su said.

The premier made the remarks after media reports said that his stance on the issue had been assailed by heavyweight figures at a meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's Central Standing Committee, including Vice President Annette Lu, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan.

The premier had previously called for more open cross-strait exchanges and a majority of local businessmen also expected him to further liberalize cross-Taiwan Strait economic ties by increasing charter flights and relaxing investment restrictions.
The Cabinet-held conference July 28-29 was intended to seek ways to achieve sustainable economic development over the next 10 years.

However, delegates of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union and other independence advocates were strongly opposed to lifting the 40 percent investment investment ceiling and on setting up regular direct air links across the Taiwan Strait because they fear Taiwan's national security and sovereignty might be undermined.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATION AGENTS DETAIN NINE PHARMACY OWNERS

TEXT.P: Investigation Bureau agents conducted a massive search of 15 pharmacies in northern and central Taiwan Thursday, seizing large amounts of fake and illicit drugs and detaining nine pharmacy owners for questioning.

According to a spokesman for the bureau's central office, more than 100 agents carried out the raid on the pharmacies and mid-stream distributors in the northern Taipei, Keelung and Taoyuan areas, as well as in the central Taichung area.
The Investigation Bureau turned the nine suspects over to the Miaoli District Prosecutor's Office after initial questioning.
Police also busted pharmacies in Taichung City and Taichung County last week on tipoffs that more and more drug stores were selling fake and substandard pesticides to farmers.

Two drug store owners were arrested in that operation, both of whom were turned over to the Taichung Prosecutor's Office for their alleged involvement in a criminal ring that produced pesticides with substandard imported materials and distributed them to local pharmacies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CROP RICE PRICE GOES UP: COA

TEXT.P: Rice farmers around Taiwan have finished harvesting this year's first crop and production is 2 percent below the previous year's level, prompting a rise in price, the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Thursday.
According to agency officials, the first harvest was brought in by July, with 950,000 metric tons produced, down by 25,000 metric tons from the year-earlier level.
The officials ascribed the fall to a lower spring temperature this year and rice disease in some regions.

The first crop rice price reached NT$18 per kilogram, compared to the average NT$17.49 for the same period of last year, the officials said, noting that NT$18 per kilogram represents a 6 percent increase over the average price in 2000 before Taiwan entered the World Trade Organization early the following year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS TOP IN TERMS OF INSURANCE PENETRATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan topped the world in terms of insurance penetration in 2005, with insurance premiums accounting for 14.11 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP), a local financial magazine reported Thursday.
According to the Risk Management, Insurance and Finance magazine, NT$14.11 out of every NT$100 in Taiwan's 2005 GDP was contributed by the insurance industry.
Of the total, NT$11.18 came from life insurance and the remaining NT$2.93 from non-life insurance, the report said.
In 2004, the report said, Taiwan's insurance penetration ratio was the second-highest.

The United States boasts the world's largest insurance industry, but it ranked 12th in terms of insurance penetration in 2005, while Japan, which has the world's second- largest insurance industry, ranked sixth in terms of insurance penetration.
In terms of the amount of premiums, Taiwan ranked 13th in 2005, with life insurance premiums placing at ninth and non-life insurance premiums at 17th.

In terms of insurance density -- per capita spending on insurance -- Taiwan ranked 20th globally with US$2,145.5, of which US$446.4 was spent on non-life insurance policies and US$1,699.1 was spent on life insurance policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: NET OUTFLOW OF FOREIGN REMITTANCES TOTALS US$860 MILLION IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan registered a net outflow of foreign remittances for the third consecutive month in July, with foreign investors remitting a net amount of US$860 million in equity funds out of the country during that month, according to tallies released Thursday by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).
In July, foreign investors sold listed Taiwan stocks worth a net total of NT$28.89 billion (US$878.12 million) and over-the-counter shares worth a net amount of NT$7.72 billion, FSC tallies show.

From the start of this year until July 28, foreign investors bought listed shares worth NT$2.78 trillion and sold listed shares worth NT$2.61 trillion, with net buying valued at NT$163.1 billion, FSC officials said.

During the same period, foreign investors purchased over-the-counter shares worth NT$138.5 billion and sold over-the-counter shares worth NT$146.7 billion, with net sales registering NT$8.2 billion, the officials said.

Since the government began allowing foreign investment in Taiwan's stock market in December 1990, foreign institutional investors, foreign individuals and overseas Chinese have remitted a net amount of US$118.83 billion into Taiwan as of July 28, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: 200 Missiles Hit Israel as Battle Rages in Lebanon
Hezbollah guerrillas fired the largest number of rockets yet into Israel -- more than 200 -- on Wednesday as thousands of Israeli troops faced fierce fighting in Lebanon, and sought to establish a buffer zone under their control. Battles raged in a half-dozen pockets, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said Israel would fight until an international force moved into southern Lebanon.
Wall Street Journal: Party of God, Why Hezbollah Is Proving So Tough On the Battlefield
A look at how Hezbollah has developed as a military and political force shows why Israel has been having a more difficult time than it expected in driving the group out of southern Lebanon. And it also shows how tough the road will be to permanently disarming Hezbollah and promoting long-term stability in Lebanon. As the group's popularity has swelled in Lebanon's Shiite Muslim community and beyond, so has the sophistication of its weaponry and the lock-step discipline of its core fighting force aimed at Israel. By wedding that sophistic ation to its ideology of martyrdom for the cause, Hezbollah's relatively tiny army -- believed to number several thousand -- has become one of the most effective military forces in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Moscow, Aug.3 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Yushchenko Goes Down to the Wire President Viktor Yushchenko kept Ukraine guessing into Wednesday night whether he would accept his chief political rival, Viktor Yanukovych, as the country's next prime minister. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: FETC STRIPPED OF 'PRIORITY BIDDER' STATUS IN HIGHWAY ETC ROW

TEXT.P: The Supreme Administrative Court ruled Thursday that the Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collecting Co. (FETC) no longer enjoys "priority status" in the procurement process to run a toll system on the nation's freeways.
It said the FETC must vie with the other two bidders on an equal footing because the prior bidding process had violated the principles of equality and the public interest.

The ruling on the Ministry of Transportation and Communications's appeal dealt a serious blow to the ministry's "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) project to facilitate highway traffic and will cause far-reaching effects on motorists.
The FETC has invested more than NT$3 billion in building an infrastructure and installing on-board units in hundreds of thousands of vehicles in order to run the ETC system.
Now that the company's contract with the MOTC must be canceled, a host of problems concerning compensation, bidder rivalry and consumer rights are expected to dog the MOTC.

In February 2006, the Taipei High Administrative Court ruled on the same premise that FETC's "priority bidder" status should be stripped, a ruling that MOTC's National Expressway Bureau appealed to the Supreme Administrative Court. Thursday's ruling was the result of that appeal.
The Supreme Administrative Court is the administrative court of final decision; its verdict on legal interpretations has a binding power for all subordinate levels of administrative courts.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO VISIT WASHINGTON, D.C.

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun will visit Washington, D.C. in September, sources said Thursday.
This will be Yu's first visit to the U.S. capital since assuming the DPP chairmanship earlier this year.
During his visit, Yu will meet with U.S. officials and academics to exchange views on matters of mutual interest.
Yu will also hold seminars with DPP supporters in the Washington area. (By Ada Tsai) entidem/diG

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ROCK FESTIVALS FIND THEMSELVES AT CROSSROADS

TEXT.P: To go commercial or stay underground? Mainstream or independent? Is working with the government a good thing? One thing is certain: Taiwan's rock festivals are at a crossroads, a seminar concluded Thursday.

The participants in the seminar titled "Retrospect on the Independent Spirit in Indie Music" came from every field related to rock festivals, including a musician, a pair of music critics, an event organizer, a music producer and a couple of government officials.

They showed common concern about the commercialization and environmental damage created by rock festivals, which with the help from the government have become one of the most popular summer activities for Taiwanese youngsters in recent years.

There has been controversy and problems with the "big three" rock festivals -- Spring Scream, Formoz Festival and the Hohaiyan Gongliau Rock Festival -- such as political interference, fighting for the same event name by government and independent organizers, drug use at the events and over-commercialization.

"The essence of a rock festival is that it is a showcase for the music industry, but the government looks at it from the tourism perspective, which leads rock festival in different directions, " according to Freddy Lin, lead singer of the band Chthonic and the man responsible for starting Formoz.

There is a fine line between adherence to the indie rock spirit and the help from government or companies, said music critic Chang Tieh-chih, with respect from sponsors for the professionalism of the artists key.
Vanya Chung of Trees Music and Art offered a different view, pointing out that it is not only "big" rock festivals that can have an impact.

"Bigger is not always better, said Chung, who has organized many of the more interesting festivals Taiwan has to offer. Sometimes smaller music festivals provide better local attachment and cultural impact. We need to stop being caught up in the numbers game of thinking that more participants make a more successful event, "she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOG FARM OWNERS WARNED TO DISPOSE OF DEAD STOCK PROPERLY

TEXT.P: Animal health authorities warned Taiwan's hog farmers Thursday that they could face long prison terms plus heavy fines if they fail to dispose of dead stock properly and allow questionable meat to be distributed to food markets.

The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture issued the warning after law enforcement officers arrested several suspects in Tuku township, Yunlin County, for selling pork from carcasses of hogs that had died of unknown causes.
Bureau officials said that instead of having the dead animals disposed of properly, the suspects violated the law by cutting up the carcasses and selling the pork for consumption.
They pointed out that in one such case, the court sentenced the accused man to eight years in prison and fined him NT$9 million (US$273,840).

The officials said that members of the public can get rewards of up to NT$2 million if they provide information leading to the arrest of those involved in the illegal slaughtering, butchering, processing, transporting and selling of un-inspected meat.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ PROMOTES CREATION OF DRUG PREVENTION CENTERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is actively promoting the establishment of drug prevention centers around the island amid growing drug addiction rates, a MOJ official said Thursday.

The official noted that since drug prevention centers will play a vital role in the Cabinet's anti-drug efforts, such centers will be established in every county and large city around the island by early August.
According to the official, MOJ's anti-drug strategy will focus on "reducing the demand for drugs and therefore the drug supply, by strictly controlling and administering the raw materials for drugs."

At a meeting of the nation's chief prosecutors on Aug. 1, the MOJ urged prosecutors' offices in various districts to strengthen their cooperation with drug prevention centers and to disseminate anti-drug awareness among the citizens.
The MOJ will also promote a legal amendment that would extend the period of compulsive treatment in order to help drug addicts kick the habit.

In addition, the MOJ will hold several training courses for court guardians in September and October to strengthen their knowledge of criminal law and the new anti-drug measures so that they can offer better help for drug addicts, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE UNIVERSITY OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS TO TAIWAN NGO PERSONNEL

TEXT.P: Japan's Waseda University will offer scholarships to two members of major Taiwanese non-governmental organizations (NGOs) as a gesture to strengthen NGO cooperation between the two countries, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.
Liao Wen-che, a section chief of MOFA's NGO Affairs Committee, said it will be the first time that Waseda University has conducted exchanges with Taiwan on NGO affairs.

Japan boasts more advanced development in NGO activities, Liao said, adding that domestic NGO members dedicated to international cooperation, human rights, environmental protection, women's and consumer's affairs, are especially welcome to present their applications to the Japanese university.
According to Liao, MOFA has been planning on establishing a cooperation platform with Japan on NGO activities, especially in international rescue.
The two countries have held several seminars related to NGO affairs during the last few years, Liao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISIT BY BEIJING OFFICIAL SHOULD BE BASED ON RESPECT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Thursday that the decision on whether to allow China's head of Taiwan affairs to visit the country would hinge on the principles of reciprocity and mutual respect.

Su was responding at an informal press gathering to reports that the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will again invite Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, to visit Taiwan in October for an agricultural forum.

The premier said, "China is a big power, while Taiwan is a small county, so there is no need for Taiwan to provoke China," adding that bilateral exchanges between the two should be based on "mutual respect, dialogue, consultation, peace and goodwill."
Su said Taiwan welcomed Chen as a visitor, but "if he's coming here for 'united front' purposes, then he shouldn't bother coming."

In addition, if Joseph Wu, chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the top China policy planner, is barred from even setting foot on Hong Kong soil, Su said he sees no need for Chen to make a high-profile visit to Taiwan.
Taiwan is open to guests of good will, but if visitors come with malevolent intent, "then we have to be on guard," he added.

Su reaffirmed the government's stance on separate identity and its independent decision on policies, adding that the public should have confidence in Taiwan's democracy, freedom and openness and that it will welcome Chinese tourists so they can witness for themselves Taiwan's example of freedom and democracy.
Restrictions on Chinese coming to Taiwan for business, performances or film-making purposes should also be eased, but if they come for "united front" purposes, then "we'll kick them out at once."
News reports said Chen has been invited by the KMT to attend an agricultural forum slated for Oct. 13-18 in Taipei as part of exchanges between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC).
The KMT invited Chen to visit Taipei last October for an economic forum, but his application was rejected by the MAC on grounds that it required official negotiations between Taipei and Beijing.
Consequently, the KMT organized a mission under the leadership of the KMT's Honorary Chairman Lien Chen, who traveled to Shanghai to last October to take part in a KMT-CPC economic forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ASKS FOR RELAXATION OF CHINA-BOUND INVESTMENT CAP

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) asked Premier Su Tseng-chang Friday to show "more teeth" and relax restrictions on China-bound investment to help give Taiwan's industry a new lease on life.
KMT legislative caucus whip Tsai Chin-lung issued the call after Su denied earlier in the day that he would take steps to ease ceilings on China-bound investments by Taiwan companies.
According to Su, he has been clear and has not changed his attitude regarding this issue.
Since a recent national conference on economic growth did not reach consensus on removing the existing 40 percent ceiling, the Executive Yuan will not do so, Su explained.
Tsai expressed deep disappointment with Su's comments and claimed that "Su has clearly been held hostage by President Chen Shui-bian and radical pro-independence activists."

In the face of economic sluggishness in Taiwan, Su must be braver to help Taiwan companies find a way to survive -- namely, by eliminating the 40 percent limit to allow Taiwan businesses to freely invest in China -- according to Tsai.

Thanks to frequent and close economic activities between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of US$36.3 billion with China last year -- the prime reason behind Taiwan's overall annual trade surplus of NT$15.7 billion for the whole of last year, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL ORDER IMPROVED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Thursday that social order has not deteriorated but has improved, and he expressed hope that everyone in the country will contribute to upholding social order.

Su made the remarks in response to questions from journalists concerning the country's social order. Su, who assumed office in late January, pledged in March that he will step down and quit politics if social order has not improved within six months.
Claiming that the government's efforts in cracking down on crime will not be perceived by the people "suddenly, " Su said he is sure his administrative team is doing well.
"The job does not only depend on the Ministry of the Interior and requires cooperation from other ministries, " Su said.
Su claimed that the car theft rate has dropped and that cases of debt collecting with violence, as well as illegal car racing, have been reduced.
However, he admitted that the political turmoil causes the public to feel that the social order is bad.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER APPLICATIONS SHOW FEATURES FUTURE DIGITAL LIFE

TEXT.P: Everything in the households will be digital pretty soon in the future, the latest products in the annual Taipei Computer Applications Show, which is taking place from Aug. 3 - 7, showed.
In addition to the computer and communication devices buying and selling, to which most companies and visitors pay attention, in the distant future people will be selling and buying "digital homes".

The theme exhibition entitled "U-Life" (Ubiquitous Life) fortold a future that digital devices and applications are everywhere in an ordinary household, including FFTH (fiber-to-the-home) internet services, car multimedia system, "on-line" white goods (large household appliances such as refrigerators, air conditioners, and washing machines), home security system and even long distance care.

All these mean you don't have to go to a hospital for a medical checkup or a refrigerator to see for yourself when to do the next shopping. Neither do you have to endure the "slow" ADSL internet connection.

And a digital home will be affordable not only for the riches but for middle class people as well, said Chao Teng-hsiung, president of Farglory Land Development. Chao added that more and more real estate buyers place the factor of "how digital it is" over other factors such as structures and interior design.

But for now, most visitors are happy just buying discount computers at the show, which is held at Exhibition Hall I of the Taipei World Trade Center. There are more than 200 companies setting up more over 1,400 booths in seven product display areas this year.
The annual show, which began in 1990, has been averaging more than 300,000 visitors every year and is one of the largest computer shows in Taiwan for domestic buyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA UNVEILS MEASURES TO IMPROVE TREATMENT OF MIGRANT WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) unveiled an explanatory note Thursday explaining its determination, stance and strategies to improve treatment of foreign contract workers.

The note will be referred to the United States and major migrant laborer-exporting countries via the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to seek their understanding of Taiwan's efforts to rein in human trafficking and improve management and care of foreign contract workers.

The explanatory paper is a response to a damning U.S. State Department report issued in early June that placed Taiwan on a "Tier 2 Watch List" for allegedly not fully complying with the minimum standards for the elimination of human trafficking and forced labor and sexual exploitation of migrant workers.

According to the CLA note, a government review system will be installed to better protect migrant workers. Under the new system, local governments will be authorized to verify the legality of early annulment of contracts between employers and migrant workers and to ensure the annulment is not disputed.

The CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training said that the proposed review system will be easy to implement and free of red tape. Three days before the repatriation of the migrant worker after the invalidation of his or her contract, city or county government social workers will interview the migrant worker first by phone to see if there is any labor-management dispute or whether the migrant worker is being forced to return home. If there is any suspicion, the social worker will visit the foreign worker in person. If any labor-management dispute is found, the employer will not be allowed to recruit a new migrant worker to fill the job vacancy.

In its explanatory paper, the CLA also said it will revise the law regarding manpower brokering fee collection standards and forge a "reward" system to screen out bad or poorly managed manpower agencies. Moreover, the CLA said it will step up random checks on the management of foreign workers and their general living conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHOPPING GROWTH RECORDED IN OVERSEAS CHINESE, FOREIGN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Approved investment by overseas Chinese and foreign nationals in the first half of this year increased significantly from the same period of last year, with the total for 2006 expected to set a new record, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Thursday.

According to figures released at a meeting held to review promotional efforts to attract investors to Taiwan, the MOEA's Investment Commission approved 666 investment cases submitted by overseas Chinese and foreign nationals in the first six months of this year, with a total value of US$6,945 million.
While the number of cases increased 31.1 percent from the same period of last year, their total value represented a growth of 530.64 percent.
The Investment Commission said the total value of overseas Chinese and foreign investment in Taiwan for 2006 is expected to surpass US$8 billion and set an all-time high.

In the category of private domestic investment, there were 795 new cases as of the end of July, totaling NT$903.2 billion (US$27.48 billion) in value, with 69 percent of these investment plans having already been carried out, representing a total value of NT$620.96 billion.
Officials said the MOEA will hold an international conference on business opportunities in Taiwan Oct. 12, with promotional efforts to persist throughout the following year.

To help Taiwan's automobile industry develop its own technology to manufacture complete cars, the ministry plans to encourage major automobile manufacturers to invest NT$10 billion in the next four years, with the aim of raising Taiwan's whole-car production value from NT$450 billion this year to NT$650 billion by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC REGRETS COURT RULING ON FREEWAY ETC ROW

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Thursday it respects but regrets a Supreme Administrative Court ruling that the Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collecting Co. (FETC) no longer enjoys "priority status" in the procurement process to run a toll system on the nation's freeways.

Speaking at a late-night news conference, MOTC Deputy Minister Tsai Duei said the ministry will announce in the shortest possible period of time workable options to address the situation in the wake of the ruling.

Protecting the rights of motorists will be the ministry's top concern in mapping out follow-up action plans, Tsai said, adding that starting Friday, motorists can decide on their own whether to install on-board units (OBUs) for the FETC electronic toll collection system.

Tsai said the MOTC has asked FETC to maintain normal operations until after the ministry works out response measures. He made the assurances that the ministry will fully protect consumers' interest no matter whether they have already installed the OBUs or they install the device after the Supreme Administrative Court ruling. If motorists choose to return the OBUs, they will receive a full refund of the OBU cost.
According to the ruling, the FETC must vie with the other two bidders on an equal footing because the prior bidding process had violated the principles of equality and the public interest.

The ruling on the Ministry of Transportation and Communications's appeal dealt a serious blow to the ministry's "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) project to facilitate highway traffic and will cause far-reaching effects on motorists.
The FETC has invested more than NT$3 billion in building an infrastructure and installing on-board units in some 220,000 vehicles in order to run the ETC system.
Now that the company's contract with the MOTC must be canceled, a host of problems concerning compensation, bidder rivalry and consumer rights are expected to dog the MOTC.

As of Wednesday, some 220,000 motorists had installed OBUs on their cars to run the FETC's toll collecting system. The FETC said it will maintain normal operations to fulfill its contract duties and will announce its response measures after the MOTC comes up with a clear-cut policy initiative or option.

In February 2006, the Taipei High Administrative Court ruled on the same premise that FETC's "priority bidder" status should be stripped, a ruling that MOTC's National Expressway Bureau appealed to the Supreme Administrative Court. Thursday's ruling was the result of that appeal.
MOTC Minister Kuo Yao-chi said that with a 14 percent use rate, the ETC system has had an initial result in improving freeway traffic.

16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC SUPPORTS EXPANSION OF KINMEN PORT, AIRPORT FACILITIES

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Kuo Yao-chi said Thursday she fully supports proposals to expand port and airport facilities on the outlying island of Kinmen to cope with the increasing volume of "mini three links" passengers.
Kuo made the remarks during an inspection tour of Shuitou wharf in the company of Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng.

Lee briefed Kuo on the Shuitou port capacity and operations of direct shipping services between Kinmen and Xiamen in China's southeastern Fujian province, commonly known as the "mini three links" service.

According to Lee, Shuitou was originally designed for a traffic volume of 200,000 passengers per year. With the government continually easing restrictions on Taiwan residents qualified for traveling across the Taiwan Strait via the "mini three links" route, Lee said, the passenger volume is expected to top 600,000 this year.

On the other side of the strait, Lee said, China is building a new Dongdu wharf at Xiamen port that will be able to process a traffic volume of 1.5 million passengers annually. In contrast, he said, the customs clearance facilities at Shuitou wharf have gradually fallen short of demand.

Lee said the government should start drafting an expansion plan as soon as possible now that cross-strait civilian exchanges are expected to grow even more significantly in the future. He also suggested that Kinmen's Shangyi Airport be expanded as well to facilitate "mini three links" passengers' transit flights.
Echoing Lee's view, Kuo said the transportation ministry will assist the Kinmen county government in completing expansion projects at Shuitou wharf and Shangyi Airport.

Kuo traveled to Kinmen, which lies closer to Fujian than to Taiwan proper, to attend the opening of a stamp exhibition scheduled for Friday. But she returned to Taiwan in the evening to handle thorny issues regarding a freeway electronic toll collection system row.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL ORDER IMPROVED: PREMIER(repeat)

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Thursday that social order has not deteriorated but has improved, and he expressed hope that everyone in the country will contribute to upholding social order.

Su made the remarks in response to questions from journalists concerning the country's social order. Su, who assumed office in late January, pledged in March that he will step down and quit politics if social order has not improved within six months.
Claiming that the government's efforts in cracking down on crime will not be perceived by the people "suddenly, " Su said he is sure his administrative team is doing well.
"The job does not only depend on the Ministry of the Interior and requires cooperation from other ministries, " Su said.
Su claimed that the car theft rate has dropped and that cases of debt collecting with violence, as well as illegal car racing, have been reduced.
However, he admitted that the political turmoil causes the public to feel that the social order is bad.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER APPLICATIONS SHOW FEATURES FUTURE DIGITAL LIFE(repeat)

TEXT.P: Everything in the households will be digital pretty soon in the future, the latest products in the annual Taipei Computer Applications Show, which is taking place from Aug. 3 - 7, showed.
In addition to the computer and communication devices buying and selling, to which most companies and visitors pay attention, in the distant future people will be selling and buying "digital homes".

The theme exhibition entitled "U-Life" (Ubiquitous Life) fortold a future that digital devices and applications are everywhere in an ordinary household, including FFTH (fiber-to-the-home) internet services, car multimedia system, "on-line" white goods (large household appliances such as refrigerators, air conditioners, and washing machines), home security system and even long distance care.

All these mean you don't have to go to a hospital for a medical checkup or a refrigerator to see for yourself when to do the next shopping. Neither do you have to endure the "slow" ADSL internet connection.

And a digital home will be affordable not only for the riches but for middle class people as well, said Chao Teng-hsiung, president of Farglory Land Development. Chao added that more and more real estate buyers place the factor of "how digital it is" over other factors such as structures and interior design.

But for now, most visitors are happy just buying discount computers at the show, which is held at Exhibition Hall I of the Taipei World Trade Center. There are more than 200 companies setting up more over 1,400 booths in seven product display areas this year.
The annual show, which began in 1990, has been averaging more than 300,000 visitors every year and is one of the largest computer shows in Taiwan for domestic buyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHOPPING GROWTH RECORDED IN OVERSEAS CHINESE, FOREIGN INVESTMENT(repeat)

TEXT.P: Approved investment by overseas Chinese and foreign nationals in the first half of this year increased significantly from the same period of last year, with the total for 2006 expected to set a new record, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Thursday.

According to figures released at a meeting held to review promotional efforts to attract investors to Taiwan, the MOEA's Investment Commission approved 666 investment cases submitted by overseas Chinese and foreign nationals in the first six months of this year, with a total value of US$6,945 million.
While the number of cases increased 31.1 percent from the same period of last year, their total value represented a growth of 530.64 percent.
The Investment Commission said the total value of overseas Chinese and foreign investment in Taiwan for 2006 is expected to surpass US$8 billion and set an all-time high.

In the category of private domestic investment, there were 795 new cases as of the end of July, totaling NT$903.2 billion (US$27.48 billion) in value, with 69 percent of these investment plans having already been carried out, representing a total value of NT$620.96 billion.
Officials said the MOEA will hold an international conference on business opportunities in Taiwan Oct. 12, with promotional efforts to persist throughout the following year.

To help Taiwan's automobile industry develop its own technology to manufacture complete cars, the ministry plans to encourage major automobile manufacturers to invest NT$10 billion in the next four years, with the aim of raising Taiwan's whole-car production value from NT$450 billion this year to NT$650 billion by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 4, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1578: The Portuguese King Sebastian and his court are killed in a failed crusade to Morocco.
1875: Hans Christian Anderson, Danish writer famous the world over for his fairy tales and stories, including "The Princess and the Pea" and "The Ugly Duckling," dies in Copenhagen at the age of 70.
1906: The Education Ministry of the Ching court promulgates a set of "regulations on education for women" governing the establishment of schools for women.
1914: World War I breaks out when German troops invade Belgium. Britain declares war on Germany as the United States declares its neutrality.
1916: Denmark sells the Danish Virgin Islands to the United States for US$25 million.
1922: Fighting breaks out in Italy between the fascists and the socialists.
1938: The Nationalist government moves its offices from Wuchang and Hankow to Chungking in order to cope with the lengthy War of Resistance Against Japan.
1940: Italian troops invade the country of British Somaliland in East Africa.
1942: David Russel Lange, New Zealand Labor politician, is born. He served as prime minister from 1984 to 1989 and was controversial for his refusal to allow nuclear-armed ships to dock in New Zealand.
1944: Anne Frank, a 14-year-old German Jewish diarist, and seven other Jews in hiding in Amsterdam, are captured by the Gestapo and sent to concentration camps.
1950: Gen. Douglas MacArthur dispatches a high-ranking aide to Taipei as a liaison officer as the United States begins providing military aid to Taiwan.
1954: The P-1 English Electronic Lightning, Britain's first supersonic fighter plane, makes its maiden flight.
1960: Chung Li-ho, a noted Taiwanese folk tale author, dies at the age of 45.
1963: The Foreign Ministry declares that the Republic of China will not recognize the border treaty signed between the Peking regime and Afghanistan.
1967: Malawian President Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1972: Ugandan President Idi Amin declares that his country will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports within three months.
1976: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang extends its "deepest sympathy" to victims of the earthquake that struck northern China.
1979: Ho Yen-sheng, former Saigon correspondent for the China Times of Taipei who had been stranded in Vietnam since 1975, arrives in Taipei from an isolated island in the South China Sea where he spent 70 days as a refugee.
1986: ROC-U.S. trade talks begin in Washington. During the five-day talks, the ROC agreed to abandon its use of duty tables as of Oct. 1, 1986.
1990: Iraq installs a nine-man puppet government in Kuwait and sets up a new "People's Army" to control the regime while 12 European Community nations ban oil imports from Iraq, impose an arms embargo on the country and suspend most trade with Iraq.
1993: Japan formally apologizes for the first time to women forced to serve as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers during World War II.
1993: The Japanese Cabinet resigns, ending 38 years of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party.
1999: British Defence Secretary George Robertson becomes the new secretary-general of NATO, succeeding Javier Solana.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Mayor Tarmile Ishoda of Majuro sign a pact of alliance in Taipei, making Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, the 44th sister city of Taiwan's capital.
2000: Government Information Office Director General Chung Chin says that the GIO is mapping out procedures for setting up exchanges across the Taiwan Strait of journalists for long-term postings.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By dealing loyally and punctually with them in all engagements which he makes with them and allowing a liberal scale of pay: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to men in the public service."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ANNOUNCES NEW APPOINTMENTS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang announced Friday the appointments for several Cabinet posts including minister of economic affairs.
According to the new personnel lineup, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long will replace Hwang Ing-san as the economics minister.

Chen pledged Friday that the ministry will create a favorable environment for industrial development and take advantage of Taiwan's sound economic fundamentals to guide local industry to create another economic miracle.

Other appointments announced Friday included the naming of Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Commissioner Shi Jun-ji as FSC chairman and of acting FSC Chairman Lu Daung-yen as chairman of the Over-the-Counter Securities Exchange.
Vice Minister of Finance Chen Shu was named chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp., replacing Wu Nai-jen who tendered his resignation last week.

Central Election Commission Secretary-General Lin Mei-chu was appointed deputy interior minister, a post which has been left vacant since Yen Wan-chin resigned last month following his detention over his alleged involvement in a cable car corruption scandal.
Meanwhile, Shih Neng-chieh, acting chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, was named chairman of the commission.
The appointments were finalized ahead of Premier Su's scheduled departure for Chad Sunday to attend Chadian President Idriss Deby's second inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO ENGAGE IN DIALOGUE WITH TAIWAN LEADERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu, Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A U.S. official in charge of Asia-Pacific affairs reiterated Thursday that Beijing should engage in dialogue with Taiwan's popularly-elected leaders.

Thomas Christensen, newly-appointed deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said he thinks that a visit to Taiwan by China's chief of Taiwan affairs, Chen Yunlin, would be a "positive development" as far as cross Taiwan Strait relations are concerned.

Christensen, who resumed his post with responsibility for affairs concerning China, Taiwan and Mongolia less than one month ago, made the remarks after he attended a hearing sponsored by the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission.

When asked about the probability of China's and Taiwan's leaders meeting for dialogue, Christensen said he is unable to make such a prediction as it is mainly up to Beijing's calculations. He added, however, that Washington has not been particularly happy with relevant developments.
Christensen stressed that the United States will continue to push for a meeting between the Beijing and Taiwan leaders as it is the only primary means of cross-strait dialogue.

He said that he only learned from a newspaper report that Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is again planning to invite Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, to visit Taiwan for an agricultural forum slated for Oct. 13-18 in Taipei as part of exchanges between the KMT and the Communist Party of China.
Meanwhile, Christensen noted, the time for the signing of a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States has not matured yet.
He said Taiwan should try harder to improve its free trade climate so as to create productive conditions for the signing of an FTA in the future.
