DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER-DESIGNATE PLEDGES TO IMPROVE BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: Economics Minister-designate Chen Ruey-long pledged Friday that his ministry will create a favorable environment for industrial development to enhance the competitiveness of the industrial sector.

According to Chen, as an export-oriented economy, Taiwan must keep track of the changes in the international economic environment and should take advantage of its sound economic fundamentals to guide local industries to create another economic miracle.
Chen said the Ministry of Economic Affairs must have the ability to draft plans for the future development of the industrial sector.

When many industries are losing their competitiveness and some have even been forced to move overseas, the ministry must help local industries upgrade themselves in the shortest period of time to sustain the country's economic growth, he said.
Premier Su Tseng-chang announced earlier in the day that Chen, who has been deputy minister of economic affairs since April 2002, will replace Hwang Ing-san as the new minister.
The 58-year-old Chen had previously served as a vice minister of economic affairs and director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 19.71 points to close at 6,442.61.
The bourse opened at 6,483.07 and fluctuated between 6,491.67 and 6,421.55 during trading. A total of 2.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$69.09 billion (US$2.1 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by construction issues and foodstuff issues both at 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.6 percent, textile stocks at 0.5 percent, cement stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.3 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 664 to 325, with 139 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR PROTECTION OF MOTORISTS' RIGHTS AFTER ETC RULING

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang instructed Friday that the rights and interests of motorists who have installed on-board units (OBUs) for an electronic toll collection (ETC) system should be protected to the end amid rows over the running of the toll system on Taiwan's freeways.

Commenting on the possible repercussions of a ruling by the Supreme Administrative Court Wednesday that the Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collecting Co. (FETC) no longer enjoys "priority status" in the procurement process to run the electronic toll collection system on the nation's freeways, Su said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) should thoroughly review the entire development of the case so as to protect the OBU subscribers' rights and reduce the negative impact on the government and consumers to the lowest possible level.

According to the court ruling, the bidding process in which the FETC won the contract to operate the system violated the principles of equality and the public interest. As a result, the company's contract with the MOTC must be canceled, the court said.
The court was upholding a ruling by the Taipei High Administrative Court in February of this year which the National Expressway Bureau appealed.
The court ruling is expected to raise a host of problems for the MOTC concerning compensation, bidder rivalry and consumer rights.
The FETC has invested more than NT$3 billion in building the infrastructure and on installing on-board units in some 216,000 vehicles in order to run the ETC system.
The 216,000 vehicles installed with OBUs represent about 14 percent of all vehicles that use the island's freeways everyday, Su said.

MOTC Minister Kuo Yao-chi said that since the National Expressway Bureau's appeal was rejected, there will unavoidably be a transition period ahead of a new company or organization taking over control of the ETC system.

Kuo stressed that the rights and interests of motorists who have installed OBUs for the FETC electronic toll collection system will be fully protected. However, she called for members of the public who have not yet installed OBUs to avoid doing so for the time being until the situation is resolved.

Kuo said that during the transition period, Chunghwa Telecom and FETC will jointly run the ETC operations and that the ministry will prepare itself for taking over the whole ETC operations in the worst case scenario.
Meanwhile, a party whip of the opposition Kuomintang legislative caucus said the ETC system should be suspended immediately.
Tsai Ching-lung said that a new open bid should be arranged and that Kuo ought to step down to take responsibility for the ministry's "wrong policy" concerning the ETC system.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for September lost 42 points to finish at 6,358, with 502 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 69 points to close at 6,348, with 20 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,408 for August, 6,400 for September, 6,417 for December, 6,421 for March and 6,424 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

August TE futures moved down 1.5 points to close at 268.75, with 3,908 contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 1.6 points to finish at 268, with 62 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.
August TF futures moved down 2.6 points to close at 914.6, with 1,437 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures lost seven points to finish at 913, with 15 contracts traded.
December TF futures dropped 2.8 points to close at 912, with 10 contract transaction, while March TF futures gained 1.6 points to close at 914.8, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC, TAIPOWER EXPENDITURE TO BE CUT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has set a goal of opening up new revenue and cutting expenditure of two state-owned enterprises by NT$1.011 billion (US$30.82 million), economic officials said Friday.

The MOEA made the revision during a meeting with experts and academics to discuss how to deal with the operational difficulties faced by the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) and the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) in the wake of soaring international oil prices.
The officials noted that the price of West Texas Intermediate crude has soared to US$75, up 80 percent per barrel in August, from US$42 in early 2005.

Although the CPC has raised the price of petroleum products three times since the beginning of this year while Taipower has also raised prices, the hikes have not fully reflected the rising costs of purchasing crude oil, the officials said.
They said the losses of Taipower and CPC were around NT$33.2 billion in the first half of the year.

Participants in the meeting decided that the two state-run enterprises have to increase revenues and upgrade efficiency while maintaining the quality of their products and minimizing operational risks resulting from reduced expenditure.

The amount Taipower needs to increase revenues and cut expenditure will be raised to NT$12.4 billion from the original NT$11.5 billion, while the amount for the CPC will be hiked to NT$10.695 billion from NT$10.584 billion, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEACHES FILTHY: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan people still lack social morality and environmental protection awareness in public spaces, according to the results of a recent survey released Friday showing that most beaches are covered in garbage left by visitors.

According to the poll results made public by the Kuroshio Ocean Education Foundation, litter in the form of everyday utensils discarded by visitors is the most commonly seen garbage on beaches around Taiwan -- accounting for 53 percent of nearly 75,000 rubbish samples collected by environmental protection activists since 2004 from beaches around Taiwan, including Peipin in Hualien, Sanchi in Taipei, Changtanli in Keelung and the Erjen stream in Tainan.

Construction debris accounted for 32 percent of the garbage found on the beach, followed by items used for water-borne activities and jetsam from ships that made up 7 percent, the survey discovered. Smoking- related items such as cigarette butts and empty cigarette packs, along with personal health care items, were next on the list.
In general, plastic debris, bottle caps, firecrackers, broken glass and plastic bags are the most often seen types of garbage on Taiwan's beaches, according to the survey.

According to Taiwanese Coral Reef Association Secretary- General Kuo Tao-jen, waste water and discarded fishing gear from ships pose the biggest threat to the marine ecosystem, changing the habitat of all creatures and causing their death.
Eco-friendly activists urged the public not to litter on the beach and called on the government to take effective countermeasures to protect marine environments from all sorts of pollution.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL AUDIT OFFICE DENIES BIAS IN AUDITING STATE AFFAIRS FUND

TEXT.P: The National Audit Office (NAO) under the Control Yuan claimed Friday that it has been "absolutely fair" in its auditing of the president's special state affairs fund.

Deputy Auditor- General Lin Ching-lung made the statement in response to some ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators' accusations that the NAO, also known as the Ministry of Audit, has used double standards in auditing former President Lee Teng-hui's and President Chen Shui-bian's uses of a special fund budgeted for the president's discretionary use.

DPP lawmakers Lee Chun-yi and Hsieh Hsin-ni, who had demanded the NAO audit Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's accounting report on how he has used his special allowance budget, were dissatisfied with the answer from the NAO that no irregularities were found in Ma's report.
Lee and Hsieh visited the NAO Friday to complain that the NAO's reply to the DPP quoted "the wrong law provisions" in auditing Ma's account.
The DPP lawmaker said Chen tried to show him receipts used to claim relevant expenses but he refused to see them on the grounds that "it might add pressure on the president."
He quoted Chen as explaining that the state affairs fund is divided into two portions, one for "confidential tasks" and the other for "ordinary purposes."

Expenses for "ordinary purposes" require receipts to be produced, but if that portion of the allowance is not used up, the remainder can be transferred to the "confidential tasks" portion, whose use does not need to be backed up with receipts, Lee quoted Chen as saying.

He further quoted Chen as saying he has kept receipts from the Lee Teng-hui era that must remain classified because "inadvertent revealing of them" would pose a risk to "frontline secret diplomacy workers."
According to Lee, Chen has not pocketed any public money, nor has he received private business favors, including Sogo department store vouchers.

Lee said that when Lee Teng-hui was president, NAO officials never asked to review receipts for the use of the special fund, and now that Chen Shui-bian has taken the initiative to let the auditors examine his receipts, they claimed they "dared not see" them but then told the press they suspected irregularities, including embezzlement, in Chen's use of the special fund.
"This is clearly double standards in auditing the special fund accounts of the two presidents," according to Lee Chun-yi.
In response to Lee's accusation, the NAO's Lin Ching-lung said the NAO has always exercised its duties "fairly, objectively and independently" and has "absolutely not adopted double standards."

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL AGRICULTURAL GROUP ESTABLISHES TAIWAN BRANCH

TEXT.P: A global agricultural group, the CropLife International, set up a Taiwan branch Wednesday to facilitate local intensive and sustainable agriculture, according to a statement issued by the association Friday.

CropLife International was founded in 2002 by several multinational companies in the plant science industry. The association focuses on crop protection, agricultural biotechnology and sustainable agriculture. Since 2002, the association has established regional branches in North America, Latin America, Europe, Asia and Africa/Middle East, as well as local offices in Japan, Canada and Israel.
A spokesman for the Taiwan office said CropLife specializes in safe and responsible use of crop- protecting products in order to provide trustworthy agricultural products to consumers.

He said the local office will cooperate with the government to introduce the latest crop-protection technology and products in order to reduce the impact on the environment and help the development of local sustainable agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INTERNET PENETRATION RATE TOPS 67%: POLL

TEXT.P: The overall Internet penetration rate of Taiwan is estimated at 67.69 percent, with approximately 15.38 million people being Internet users, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Taiwan Network Information Center (TWNIC).
An estimated 5.25 million, or 72.11 percent, of households in Taiwan have Internet access, with 4.74 million households, or 65.05 percent, using broadband, the survey shows.
The estimates were based on a survey conducted by the TWNIC between May 30 and June 30 among 3,192 Taiwan residents 12 years of age or older. It had a margin of error of 1.79 percentage points.
The survey shows that the household Internet penetration rate was highest in Taipei City (86.01 percent) , followed by Kaohsiung City (84.61 percent).

In terms of the forms of networking, 78.94 percent of the households were using ADSL, 6.22 percent were using cable modem, 4.15 percent were using paid telephone lines, 2.57 percent were using leased line access, 1.12 percent were using free telephone lines and 0.23 percent were using community Internet access.
While the majority of the households with broadband Internet access were using ADSL, 9.16 percent of the respondents were dissatisfied with the broadband services, according to the survey.
While 84.27 percent of the ADSL household subscribers were customers of Chunghwa Telecom's Hinet service, only 2.92 percent were APOL customers and 2.83 percent were TFN customers.

The survey shows that 67.93 percent of men in Taiwan were Internet users, which is higher than the 66.47 percent among women, and 80.64 percent of the individual Internet users had ADSL broadband access.
The ratios of broadband Internet users were 63.82 percent among men and 61.91 percent among women.
By age, 95.57 percent of the people in the 16-25 age group were broadband Internet users, compared with just 9.89 percent among people aged 56 or older.
A total of 92.9 percent of the individual broadband Internet users said they use the Internet most often at home.
While 17.79 percent of the individual Internet users spend one hour to two hours per day on average on weekdays using the Internet, 15.9 percent spend two hours to three hours per day.
Also, the survey shows that the respondents use the Internet most often between 8 p.m. and 11 p.m.

On the most frequently used functions by Internet users, 70.99 percent of the respondents said they use the Internet most often to browse Web sites, 47.5 percent to send or receive e-mail, 34.38 percent to search data, 25.77 percent to use instant messengers to chat with friends, 22.52 percent to play online games and 12.49 percent to download software.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL RICE EXHIBITION OPENS WITH STORIES FROM THE OLD DAYS

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government inaugurated a special exhibition of rice at City Hall Friday, inviting senior citizen Kao Ming-chie to narrate the history of japonica rice.
Kao, a Taipei resident born in 1920, recalled how some local rice traders and farmers imported small quantities of japonica rice from Japan before 1929 for its good taste.

In 1929, a strong typhoon almost destroyed Taiwan's entire rice harvest. As Japanese troops stationed on the island were not used to the taste of Taiwan's local rice, the Japanese government decided to introduce japonica rice to be grown in Taiwan to feed its soldiers, Kao said. Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule until 1945.
Kao, who has been living in Yangmingshan in the suburbs of Taipei since childhood, said that he was assigned by Japanese troops to cultivate the imported japonica rice.
After being introduced to Taiwan, the japonica rice became very popular with the local people, he said.

However, after Japanese troops withdrew from Taiwan at the conclusion of World War II, the cultivation of japonica rice became less rigidly controlled, Kao said. Because of this, along with the hot weather, the japonica rice grown now is not as tasty as that was grown in the past, he said.

Lo Chih-cheng, director of the Taipei city government's Department of Information, said that he would like to encourage local people to eat more rice, regardless of what kind of rice, as it is a healthy and nutritious food.
On display at the exhibition, which will run through Sept. 24, are many types of rice grown in Taiwan, including japonica rice, indica rice and glutinous rice.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MORE INDICTED IN ETC SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Prosecution authorities indicted three business executives on charges of fraud and breach of trust Friday in the Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collection Co. (FETC) scandal, one day after it was stripped of its "priority applicant" status by the Supreme Administrative Court.

The indictments brought to five the number of people suspected of having broken the law in connection with the awarding of a government contract to build and run the electronic toll collection system on the nation's freeways.

The prosecutor's office of the Taipei District Court indicted FETC General Manager Chang Yung-chang and Deputy General Manager Wu Chung-chieh, and Lee Chen-lung, general manager of an engineering consulting company involved in illegally winning the BOT contract from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
The prosecution said they were indicted for conducting false tests on the ETC system.
It is the second wave of charges in connection with the investigations into alleged irregularities in the FETC scandal.

On March 17, the prosecution indicted Sung Nai-wu, secretary to former Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, and Tsai Chin-hung, an assistant manager of one of the four companies that form the FETC, on charges of corruption and leaking information.
The prosecution requested that the court sentence Sung to 12 years in jail and Tsai to four years, plus imposing fines of NT$2 million on each of them.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.004 to close at NT$32.869.
A total of US$514 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.885, and fluctuated between NT$32.650 and NT$32.887.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUSHROOM GROWERS URGED NOT TO TRANSFER TECHNOLOGY TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu visited a mushroom village in Taichung County, central Taiwan Friday and urged mushroom growers not to transfer cultivation technology to China, in order to maintain Taiwan's competitiveness.

Accompanied by Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, Lu visited Hsingshe village, whose mushroom production accounts for 60 percent of the nation's total, as well as several farms in the county.

During her visit to a tourist farm in the county, Lu also hailed the owners of the farm, who left high-paying jobs in the city to contribute to the agriculture and tourism industries in their home town.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG POLICE CONFISCATE FAKE BRAND-NAME PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung police raided a toy distributor's warehouse Friday in Niausung township in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan and confiscated over 3,000 counterfeit items of famous brand-name products.
According to a spokesman for the Kaohsiung police authorities, the fake products seized had a street value of more than NT$10 million.

Acting on tipoffs provided by an informant that a businessman was illegally selling counterfeit brand-name toys, dolls and ornaments acquired from China to boutiques, vendors at night markets and private individuals in the Kaohsiung area, Kaohsiung police broke into his storage facility and discovered the 3,000 pieces, all of which were well-finished, the spokesman said.
Kaohsiung police will continue investigating the sources and distribution network of the pirated products, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREX RESERVES AMOUNT TO US$260.37 BILLION IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves amounted to US$260.37 billion as of the end of July, up US$20 million over the month-earlier level, according to tallies released Friday the Central Bank of China (CBC).
CBC officials attributed the small increase to the outflow of foreign remittances during the month that offset the interest generated from the reserves.

According to the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , Taiwan registered a net outflow of foreign remittances for the third consecutive month in July, with foreign investors remitting US$860 million in equity funds out of the country.
In July, foreign investors sold listed Taiwan stocks worth NT$28.89 billion (US$878.12 million) and over-the-counter shares worth NT$7.72 billion, FSC tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Surprise interest rate rise to curb spending
The unexpected quarter-point rise in base rates, to 4.75 per cent, reversed a cut a year ago and badly wrong-footed most of the City. It sparked immediate warnings that the Bank of England could now spring another shock increase before the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Israel Suffers Highest Toll Yet; 8 Civilians, 4 Troops Killed; Planes Blast Beirut Sites Again.
A new wave of Hezbollah rockets killed eight Israeli civilians Thursday, and four soldiers died in ground combat in southern Lebanon, Israel's highest daily death toll in the three-week-old war. Israeli jets blasted targets in Beirut for the first time in almost a week.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: International Herald Tribune: 12 Israelis die Sheik threatens to bomb Tel Aviv Also, the Israeli defense minister told the army to begin preparing to push to the Litani River, a move that could mean a further call-up of reservists.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND ROUND CABINET RESHUFFLE TO BEGIN AFTER PREMIER'S CHAD VISIT

TEXT.P: A second round of partial Cabinet reshuffle will kick off after Premier Su Tseng-chang returns to the country after a scheduled visit to Chad next week, Executive Yuan officials said Friday.

The appointments for the first round of the partial reshuffle -- including that of minister of economic affairs -- were finalized Friday ahead of Su's departure for Chad Sunday to attend Chadian President Idriss Deby's second inauguration.

The appointments for a new vice economic minister, new vice finance minister, new vice chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) and FSC commissioners, will be decided after next week in the second round of the reshuffle, the officials said.

As the first round of the reshuffle, Su announced Friday a new personnel lineup in which Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long will replace Hwang Ing-san as minister of economic affairs, FSC Commissioner Shi Jun-ji was named FSC chairman, acting FSC Chairman Lu Daung-yen was named chairman of the Over-the-Counter Securities Exchange and Vice Minister of Finance Chen Shu was named chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp., replacing Wu Nai-jen who tendered his resignation last week.
Meanwhile, Cabinet officials said that Shi Jun-ji will succeed Kong Jaw-sheng as the new FSC chairman instead of being an acting chairman.

Kong is suspected of involvement in three counts of irregularities that took place while he was chairman of the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. The Executive Yuan dismissed Kong May 12 but he resisted the executive order and public pressure to resign on the grounds that his term of office -- until June 30, 2008 -- was "guaranteed" according to law.
Kong appealed his case in June and an administrative court is set to review his appeal within three months.

The officials said that should Kong win the appeal, he can be reinstated as FSC chairman, while another possibility is that Kong is willing to yield by himself, enabling Shi to replace him as the FSC chairman.
In Kong's case, the Cabinet can do nothing because there are
no laws regulating the circumstances under which a senior official of an independent institution must step down, the officials said.
At the same time, they argued, there are no laws stipulating that a senior official of an independent institution, like Kong, cannot be fired by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER TO FACE PRISON: PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: A Tainan district prosecutor said Friday that even if a former lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) indicted for embezzling from the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) pleads guilty and returns the money, he will still face prison.

The prosecutor made the remarks one day after the Tainan District Court began a trial on the health insurance fraud carried out by former DPP legislator Chiu Yung-jen and Peter Lin, who is now an independent lawmaker.
Chiu confessed and agreed to a plea bargain and a donation of NT$10 million (US$304,880), while Lin pleaded not guilty.
The prosecutor said that Chiu's confession and donation offer will get him a lenient sentence but will not absolve him. All the money he has embezzled will have to be returned, they added.

Lin and Chiu both run hospitals in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan. Prosecutors completed an investigation into the two in March, demanding five-year prison terms for each of them. Prosecutors charge that they embezzled NT$190 million and NT$110 million, respectively, out of the Bureau of National Health Insurance by making false insurance claims.
Both Lin and Chiu were stripped off their DPP memberships, but they have been allowed to remain free on bail of NT$3 million.
Chiu, who was an at-large legislator, has had his post revoked and filled by Lin Wen-lang.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU HOSPITAL PROMOTES PRIVACY OF MEDICAL RECORDS

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital said Friday that the medical records of President Chen Shui-bian and his family members, as well as the presidents of the five branches of the government, have been kept confidential.

The hospital made the remarks as it launched a "protect the privacy of medical records" drive, the third year in a row it has carried out such an activity, with local model Lin Chi-ling acting as the program's spokeswoman. Lin was hospitalized there after falling from a horse while filming a commercial in China last year.
Taiwan hospitals are notorious for playing fast and loose with what are supposed to be confidential medical records, frequently making them available to the media.
The official in charge of medical records said the records of Chen, the first lady and the heads of the five yuans are locked in the hospital superintendent' office.

The official said that if medical records are to be made public, the consent of the patient must be obtained beforehand and the revelation must be based on the public interest, as well as on the principle of minimum publicity.
The official said the Presidential Office has not commissioned the hospital to report on the health of first lady Wu Shu-jen.
Wu has been out of the public spotlight and is reportedly in poor health since being named in a spate of alleged corruption scandals implicating the president's close aides and family members.

The officials said that around 10,000 medical records are in circulation daily in the hospital, and a questionnaire among more than 3,000 members of staff found that over 70 percent said patient privacy is a matter that needs to be addressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-MINISTER STEPS DOWN 'HAPPILY'

TEXT.P: The former economics minister, who was removed from his job Friday, said later in the day that he was very glad to step down, adding that he had offered to resign four times since late May.
Hwang Ing-san, who handed over his job to his former deputy, Chen Ruey-long, said with a wide smile afterward that he tendered his resignation because the job put too much pressure on his health.
He said he offered his resignation to Premier Su Tseng-chang May 27 for the first time, citing his need for a break, but was asked to stay in the Cabinet.

Hwang said he tendered his resignation again July 12, July 20 and July 30, but all were rejected by Su until Friday, when he learned from newspaper that the premier would announce his successor later that day.
Hwang said that although he served in the post for only 192 days, he did not waste one minute of his time in office.
Thanking his ministry colleagues for their help, Hwang said he did not bungle any of his duties and claimed that the major issues facing the country's economy had "somewhat been addressed."

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE, GERMAN STUDENTS STUDY CHINSE AT CHENG KUNG UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Forty-two college students from Germany and Japan started Chinese-language courses Friday at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
The students include 25 from Nanzan University in Nagoya, Japan and 17 from Germany who are on an exchange program.
University officials said the Japanese students will study for four weeks, while the German students will stay for only six days and then go to other universities.
The officials said the university will hold a Taiwanese cuisine presentation for the students next Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED-RACED STUDENTS TOTAL 60,258

TEXT.P: The number of elementary and junior high school students born to non-Taiwanese spouses totaled 60,258 in the 2005 academic year, up 13,000 from the year-earlier level, according to tallies released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

In terms of the nationalities of the non-Taiwanese parents, Chinese, Hong-kong and Macau citizens accounted for 35.2 percent, while Indonesians made up 23.6 percent, Vietnamese comprised 18.1 percent, Filipinas accounted for 6.3 percent and Thais made up 4.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Israel Renews Attack on Southern Lebanon
Israeli airplanes struck again at Hezbollah strongholds in southern Beirut, in the Bekaa Valley and in Nabatiye, while four Israeli soldiers were killed and four wounded in intermittently fierce fighting. The Israelis are trying to create a new defensive line about four to five miles north of the border, recreating a security zone Israel intends to occupy until a multinational force can take its place. The zone is similar to that held by Israel in an occupation that ended in 2000.
Wall Street Journal: Ancient Rift, Rising Academic Sees Sectarian Split Inflaming Mideast
From the violence in the Mideast, new realities are emerging -- and a new generation of experts to interpret them. Shiite Muslims are asserting themselves as never before. Followers of this branch of Islam, generally backbenchers in the region's power game, are central players in Lebanon, Iran and Iraq -- often acting out against traditional powers such as Israel, the U.S., and Sunni Arab states. Vali Nasr, a professor at the Naval Postgraduate School in Monterey, Calif., calls this a historic "Shiite revival" and has gone further than most in identifying it as a central force in Mideast politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WANTS ADVANCE TALKS OVER CHINESE OFFICIAL'S VISIT

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu reiterated the government's stance Friday that advance bilateral negotiations are necessary before a planned visit to Taiwan by a senior Chinese official can take place.
Wu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after Premier Su Tseng-chang made it clear a day earlier that the issue must be discussed based on reciprocity and respect.

There is no need for Taiwan and China to even discuss the issue if Chen Yunlin, head of the Communist Party of China's (CPC) Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, is to engage in "united front activities" while in Taiwan, Su said.
According to Wu, the MAC will carefully assess Chen's application to visit Taiwan based on the principle laid out by the premier.

The semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , are good channels upon which to conduct two-way negotiations on Chen's visit, Wu said, adding that the MAC has not received an application to visit from Chen.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy director of the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) Policy Coordination Committee, said Thursday that Chen is slated to file an application with the MAC in mid-August to visit Taiwan in mid-October to attend a KMT-sponsored agricultural seminar.
Chen was denied entry to Taiwan late last year to take part in a forum organized by the KMT after former KMT Chairman Lien Chan paid a landmark visit to China in spring of that year.

In his capacity as KMT honorary chairman, Lien visited Beijing again in April this year to take part in an economic forum co-sponsored by the CPC and the KMT at head of a large delegation of KMT officials and business executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER QUALITY AT 10 SWIMMING BEACHES UP TO STANDARD

TEXT.P: Bathers can enjoy clean and safe water at Taiwan's 10 main bathing sites, now that the latest monitoring results indicate that water quality is suitable for swimming at all the swimming beaches.

Tests conducted by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) July 30-31 shows that the water quality at seven of the 10 bathing sites was rated as either "excellent" or "good, " with the other three classified as "average."
Fulong beach in Taipei County and two public bathing sites in Kaohsiung City -- Chichin and Hsitzuwan beaches -- received an "excellent" rating.

Previous testing July 16-17 also rated Fulong beach as "excellent," but five beaches in central and southern Taiwan failed to meet the standards -- mainly because of heavy rain brought by a tropical storm.

The other beaches that received "good" and "average" ratings in the latest tests are: Hsin Chinshan beach in Taipei County, Taan beach in Taichung County, Chiting beach in Miaoli County, Masago beach in Tainan County, Tunghsiao beach in Miaoli County, Kending Tiaoshih Recreational Seashore in Pingtung County and Shanyuan beach in Taitung County.
The results of the water quality testing can be viewed online at http://www.epa.gov.tw/beach.
The EPA said it will keep monitoring bathing water quality throughout the swimming season by conducting tests every two weeks in order to protect bathers from health risks.

Bathing water quality is rated as "excellent," "good," "average" and "below average," based on the levels of escherichia coli, a bacteria that leads to intestinal diseases, and enterococci bacteria in the water.
The EPA cautioned bathers to avoid going to the beach within three days of a storm, because rain can wash pollutants into the sea, rendering the water unsuitable for swimming and other water sports.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR VISITING AUSTRALIA TO SEEK INVESTORS
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Wang Shu-feng and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan is leading a delegation to Australia Friday to solicit investment in Kaohsiung's major construction projects, including bidders for a stadium for the 2009 World Games to be held in the southern port city.

Yeh's delegation visited the Australian Trade Commission (ATC) Friday, where the commission's general manager Peter Obyrne made a brief presentation on Australia's infrastructure and high-tech projects.

In addition to discussing key Australian development projects such as airports, the high-speed railroad, telecommunications, petroleum, natural gas, sewage system and housing, Obyrne also focused on Sydney's stadium, which seated some 110,000 during the 2000 Olympic Games.

Noting that Australia's railway entrepreneurs have participated in testing work on Taiwan's high-speed rail system, Obyrne said they were very familiar with Taiwan's high-speed rail and promised to visit Kaohsiung City from Taipei via the new network.

Yeh expressed hope that Australia's architectural firms would be able to participate in the construction of a world-class stadium for Kaohsiung's 2009 World Games as well as several of the city's other major construction projects, including the subway, broadband services and wharf renovation.

Lin Chin-jung, director of the Kaohsiung city government's Bureau of Public Works, noted that some 80 percent of the electricity used in the main stadium for the 2009 World Games will be supplied by solar energy, and that the city government welcomes interested parties to bid for the construction project.
Obyrne and other members of the ATC showed keen interest in Kaohsiung construction projects, and promised to lead a delegation to the city in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS WITH DELEGATION OF U.S. STATE LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met with a delegation of U.S. state legislators Friday to exchange views on ways to boost bilateral exchanges.

Ma greeted the three influential members from the California state legislature and five leading figures from the New Mexico state legislature at Taipei City Hall. The delegation was led by New Mexico Senator Ben Altamirano, who is serving as acting speaker of New Mexico's state legislature.

Ma is proud that Taipei was awarded in June for being the world's most wired city in terms of using a broadband wireless telecommunication network, telling the foreign dignitaries that the Taipei city government is keen on encouraging citizens to "use the Internet more" rather than "strolling around the streets."
"Building Taipei into a world-class capital is one of my election promises to Taipei citizens," Ma stated.

According to the Taipei mayor, the city will have 4,100 access points available for the public to surf the Internet through their PDAs, computers and handphones by the end of this year, representing a broadband wireless coverage rate of 90 percent.
Ma also introduced the visitors to the city's Ease Card -- an electronic smart card that allows travel on city buses and the mass rapid train system, as well as parking in public lots.
The Ease Card also serves as a student card for Taipei's grade school children, allowing them to relay text messages to their parents immediately after arriving at school, Ma said.
The three state legislators from California also discussed with Ma the possibility of establishing a state trade office in Taiwan.
While the legislators presented Ma with a bottle of California red wine, the Taipei mayor gave each of them the gift of a guidebook, "Insight City Guides: Taipei."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CALL ON PREMIER TO FORGE 'THREE DIRECT LINKS' WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: Two lawmakers of the opposition People First Party (PFP) urged Premier Su Tseng-chang Friday to ignore opposition by independence advocates and to boldly forge "direct links" with China in postal, trade and transportation services.

Commenting on reports that Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long will replace Hwang Ing-san as economic minister, Legislator Lee Hung-chun, a whip of the PFP's legislative caucus, said it would be useless for the Democratic Progressive Party-led government to keep replacing its economic minister while continuing to refuse relaxing restrictions on cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.

He acknowledged that by naming a new minister of economic affairs, the premier has demonstrated a determination to improve Taiwan's economy, but added that Taiwan's economic problems cannot be solved by a partial Cabinet reshuffle.
"All the government's efforts will be in vain if it does not relax restrictions on trade and economic exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China," he said.
PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said the government should face cross-strait affairs squarely becaus the issue has become a central stumbling block in Taiwan's economic development.
Liu urged the government to ignore opposition by independence advocates and to forge the "three direct links" of mail, trade and transport services with China.

Hwang resigned after serving as economic minister for 168 days, but he is not the shortest-serving economic minister in Taiwan's history. Christine Tsung stepped down in March 2002 after serving in the post for only 48 days.
Chen is the sixth economics minister under the DPP government in slightly more than six years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TALKS ABOUT TAIWAN DEMOCRACY IN SYDNEY
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Wang Shu-feng and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan criticized China as a bullying neighbor Friday in Australia, arguing that Beijing's behavior has made Taiwan's political situation very difficult.

Yeh, who is leading a delegation of Kaohsiung city officials to Australia to attract Australian investment in the southern Taiwan port city, made the remarks while meeting with Taiwanese expatriates and young students at the University of Sydney.
Noting that China is targeting Taiwan with more then 800 missiles, Yeh said Beijing also has been transmitting the wrong message to the world community -- that Taiwan is a part of China.
"Beijing's efforts to squeeze Taiwan's development space in the world community have seriously damaged the friendship between people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait," Yeh added.

Taiwan is already an independent country, but China has no courage to recognize that reality, Yeh stressed, urging the Taiwanese people to bravely brace against Beijing's bullying by actively participating in international activities.
Yeh also introduced charms of Kaohsiung to the audience, saying that the city has great development potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS SERIOUSLY ABUSED IN TAIWAN MEDIA: MEDIAWATCHERS

TEXT.P: Basic human rights, including privacy and the right to refuse to be interviewed, have been seriously abused by Taiwan's media, especially in television news, a media watchdog said in a seminar Friday.

Respect for human rights has been ignored for so long because of agrowing competition in the media, and it's time to solve the problem no matter how long it takes, said Connie Lin, CEO of the Broadcasting Development Fund (BDF) , a non-profit media watch group which organized the seminar "Human rights under the camera lens."
One of several TV newsclips played before the seminar showed a six-year-old girl refusing to be interviewed but ignored by the media and the face of a mentally ill patient.

The mother-in-law, first grandson and even butler of President Chen Shui-bian were followed by media everywhere, with more than two dozen reporters camped daily outside their residence in an attempt to follow their every move, the video also showed.

The current media chaos in Taiwan can be traced back to the "media explosion" after the end of the martial law era, and the situation has worsened in recent years, said Cheryl Lai, president of Radio Taiwan International.

Lai said that besides the "survival of the fittest" dynamic, the media should shoulder most of the responsibility for the decline in journalism's professionalism in recent years, because the media has gotten caught up in the numbers game -- doing whatever it takes to get higher ratings.
Not only have viewers felt frustration toward the media but reporters have as well -- which is why Chin Yu-chung became a print media reporter after five years as a TV cameraman.

With nine 24-hour news channels competing year-round, it's hard to believe the current situation will see any dramatic improvements, although a self-restraint and self-discipline agreement has been signed by all news channels, Lin said.

The media should start respecting basic human rights before it's too late, Lai said. Otherwise, she added, the general public will one day spurn the media because viewers have the ultimate power: turning off the television.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME TO GET MEDIA BACK ON THE RIGHT TRACK: WATCHDOG

TEXT.P: News-gathering organizations and the general public can both play a critical role in getting Taiwan's media back on the right track to eliminate human rights abuses, a watchdog group said in a seminar Friday.

The seminar titled "Human rights under the camera lens" was organized by Broadcasting Development Fund (BDF), a non-profit media watch group, and focused on growing cases of human rights abuse by Taiwan's media.
Cases discussed in the seminar included ignoring privacy and people's right as well as revealing the faces and names of patients with various illnesses without their prior consent.
"Most people nowadays are well aware of their own rights," said Yu Ying-fu, an attorney. "But mostly all they do is complain when they are offended by the media."
As an attorney, Yu said, he probably shouldn't encourage people to take legal action against the media.
"But by doing this, maybe the media will learn the lesson and finally understand the fine line between freedom of press and individual privacy."

"Reporters need a re-education in communication ethics, " said Paul Tsai, deputy manager of Formosa Television's news gathering center. "On the other hand, members of the public should also know their rights."

Tsai also mentioned several mechanisms that can help keep a tight rein on electronic media, including tighter supervision of the National Communication Commission (NCC) and regular human rights reviews by print media, media watchdogs and human rights groups.
"It is time to solve the [human rights abuse] problem, no matter how long it takes," BDF's CEO Connie Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STILL HOLDS THIRD MOST FOREX RESERVES IN WORLD

TEXT.P: After China and Japan, Taiwan is still the world's third largest holder of foreign exchange reserves, according to figures released Friday by the Taipei-based Central Bank of China.
The figures show that as of the end of July, Taiwan's foreign currency reserves stood at US$260.37 billion -- a slight increase over US$20 million in June.

News reports in late July quoted Russia's central bank as saying that thanks to oil exports, Russia's gold and foreign currency reserves grew by $7.2 billion to US$262.9 billion as of July 21, replacing Taiwan as the world's third largest holder of foreign currency reserves.

Lin Sun-yuan, director of the Central Bank of China's foreign exchange department, explained that in terms of foreign currency reserves Taiwan is still No. 3 in the world because the Russian statistics included gold reserves.
If Taiwan's gold reserves were added to its foreign currency reserves, that figure would still amount to US$268.2 billion -- higher than Russia's US$262.9 billion, Lin said.
At the end of June, China was the world's largest holder of foreign currency reserves, with US$925 billion, followed by Japan's US$842.8 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC CHAIRMAN-DESIGNATE OUTLINES WORK AGENDA

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission's (FSC) chairman-designate said Friday he will do his utmost to regain public confidence in the commission after assuming the post.

Shi Jun-ji, an FSC commissioner who has been designated as the next FSC chairman, made the remarks at his first news conference since Premier Su Tseng-chang announced his new assignment earlier in the day.

Noting the commission's core work comprises buoying up the financial services industry and maintaining a stable financial environment, Shi said his top priority will be to ensure the FSC's smooth and efficient operations.
Shi further said that impartiality, integrity and circumspection will be his modus operandi during his term at the FSC.
Shi, who has a doctorate from National Taiwan University, said although he is not an "insider of the securities and futures market," he is not a layman in the financial profession, either.

One of his most urgent tasks after assuming the post is to draft a concrete action plan to implement a number of "common opinions" reached at a recent government-sponsored economic conference on financial reforms, Shi said.
The two-year-old FSC has traveled down a bumpy road since its inauguration July 1, 2004. Several of the commission's key posts have been vacant for some time.

Shi will succeed Kong Jaw-sheng as new FSC chairman instead of being an acting chairman. Kong was dismissed in May after being suspected of involvement in three counts of irregularities that took place during his tenure as chairman of the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp.

Over the past couple of months, FSC Vice Chairman Lu Daung-yen has served as FSC acting chairman. After Shi takes over the FSC chairmanship, Lu will serve as chairman of the Over-the-Counter Securities Exchange.

As the FSC is responsible for many onerous assignments, Shi said he will urge the premier to name a new vice chairman and replacements to fill up other vacant posts in the commission as soon as possible to ensure the FSC's smooth operation.

The top post at the FSC's Examination Bureau has been left vacant since the resignation of Lee Chin-cheng more than a year ago. Lee has been indicted on charges of leaking official secrets and corruption.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT EXPENDITURE TO INCREASE 6% NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The central government's expenditure is projected at NT$94.1 billion in 2007, marking a 6 percent increase from this year's level, according to a draft budget plan referred to the Presidential Office Friday.
Executive Yuan officials briefed President Chen Shui-bian on the highlights of the 2007 central government budget plan during a meeting at the Presidential Office.

After listening to the briefing, Chen praised the Executive Yuan for its efforts to realize two policy goals in its 2007 draft budget plan -- appropriating an outlay equivalent to 3 percent of the country's domestic gross product (GDP) as the total research and development fund for the coming year and raising the ratio of defense budget to 2.85 percent of GDP.
"Given the government's financial straits, I know the executive branch must have overcome many difficulties realizing these two policy goals," Chen said during the meeting.

Nevertheless, the president questioned whether the outlay set aside for boosting domestic economic development in the draft budget plan is sufficient enough to bolster the projected 4 percent to 5 percent GDP growth while keeping the unemployment rate below 4 percent and accomplishing a per capita GDP of US$30,000 by 2015.

Stressing that promoting investment in Taiwan is the most urgent and critical task of the government, Chen said the Executive Yuan may have to review its 2007 budget plan in this regard and make necessary amends.
According to the Executive Yuan-drafted budget plan, the government expenditure will spike NT$94.1 billion or 6 percent over the 2006 level. It will be the largest increase in eight years.
The budget plan will be referred to the Legislative Yuan later this month for approval at the next legislative session scheduled to begin Sept. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 5, or the 12th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: Henry I, the youngest son of William the Conqueror, is crowned king in Westminster Abbey, three days after his brother William Rufus was killed in a hunting accident in the New Forest.
1858: The laying of the world's first transatlantic telegraph cable between Ireland and Newfoundland is completed.
1792: Frederick North, British politician known as "Lord North," dies at the age of 60. He served as prime minister (1770-1782) under George III and instituted policies that led to the rebellion of the American colonies.
1861: A national income tax is introduced in the United States, initially to fund the Civil War.
1895: Friedrich Engels, German socialist theorist and writer, dies at the age of 75. He met Karl Marx in Paris in 1844 and collaborated with him on "The Communist Manifesto" in 1848.
1930: Neil Armstrong, American astronaut and the first man on the moon, is born.
1948: The Republic of China and the United States agree to organize the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, with Chiang Meng-lin, James Yen and Shen Chung-han from the ROC, and Dr. Raymond T. Moyer and Dr. John Earl Baker from the United States as commissioners.
1949: The United States issues a "White Paper" on Sino-American relations, blaming the Nationalist government for the occupation of the Chinese mainland by the communists.
1950: A Kuomintang Central Reform Committee is set up in Taipei.
1950: The U.S. 13th Air Force is stationed in Taiwan to help the ROC guard against possible mainland Chinese air attacks.
1952: The first Japanese Embassy in Taiwan officially opens on Taipei's Chungshan North Road following the exchange of diplomatic notes ratifying the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Liberia.
1958: The nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus completes a historic 2,000-mile (3,200-km) underwater journey from Point Barrow in Alaska to the Greenland Sea, passing directly under the North Pole during its five-day voyage.
1958: Vice President Chen Cheng, who was appointed on July 1 to the concurrent post of Executive Yuan president, presides over a ceremony laying the foundation for the construction of the NT$3,200 million Shihmen Dam.
1971: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with the Republic of Turkey.
1973: The Hua Hsing Junior High School baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to represent the Far East in the Senior League World Series.
1974: The Republic of China Amateur Big League baseball team leaves Taipei to participate in the 1974 Amateur Big League World Series in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla.
1976: The Executive Yuan approves the extension for two years of the Sino-Panamanian pact on technical fishery cooperation.
1984: Richard Burton, Welsh-born actor and twice husband of actress Elizabeth Taylor, dies of a stroke at his home in Switzerland.
1986: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team leaves for Moscow to compete in the 10th Women's Basketball World Championships.
1991: President Lee Teng-hui receives Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara.
1999: The 18th International Baseball Association World Amateur Big League Baseball Championship opens in Kaohsiung County with 12 teams from Cuba, Japan, South Korea, Panama, the United States and Taiwan participating.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces the list of members for his inter-party task force on cross-strait relations, which he said will be an advisory body for the ROC president and not a policy-making unit.
2001: National Defense University President Gen. Hsia Ying-tsou says that Taiwan's first state-financed military think tank, the National Center for Strategic Studies, will be inaugurated on Sept. 1.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By strictly limiting the time of their service and making all imposts as light as possible: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to the mass of the people."

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission's (FSC) chairman-designate said Friday he will do his utmost to regain public confidence in the commission after assuming the post.

Shi Jun-ji, an FSC commissioner who has been designated as the next FSC chairman, made the remarks at his first news conference since Premier Su Tseng-chang announced his new assignment earlier in the day.

Noting the commission's core work comprises buoying up the financial services industry and maintaining a stable financial environment, Shi said his top priority will be to ensure the FSC's smooth and efficient operations.
Shi further said that impartiality, integrity and circumspection will be his modus operandi during his term at the FSC.
Shi, who has a doctorate from National Taiwan University, said although he is not an "insider of the securities and futures market," he is not a layman in the financial profession, either.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STILL HOLDS THIRD MOST FOREX RESERVES IN WORLD(repeat)

TEXT.P: After China and Japan, Taiwan is still the world's third largest holder of foreign exchange reserves, according to figures released Friday by the Taipei-based Central Bank of China.
The figures show that as of the end of July, Taiwan's foreign currency reserves stood at US$260.37 billion -- a slight increase over US$20 million in June.

News reports in late July quoted Russia's central bank as saying that thanks to oil exports, Russia's gold and foreign currency reserves grew by $7.2 billion to US$262.9 billion as of July 21, replacing Taiwan as the world's third largest holder of foreign currency reserves.

Lin Sun-yuan, director of the Central Bank of China's foreign exchange department, explained that in terms of foreign currency reserves Taiwan is still No. 3 in the world because the Russian statistics included gold reserves.
If Taiwan's gold reserves were added to its foreign currency reserves, that figure would still amount to US$268.2 billion -- higher than Russia's US$262.9 billion, Lin said.
At the end of June, China was the world's largest holder of foreign currency reserves, with US$925 billion, followed by Japan's US$842.8 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME TO GET MEDIA BACK ON THE RIGHT TRACK: WATCHDOG(repeat)

TEXT.P: News-gathering organizations and the general public can both play a critical role in getting Taiwan's media back on the right track to eliminate human rights abuses, a watchdog group said in a seminar Friday.

The seminar titled "Human rights under the camera lens" was organized by Broadcasting Development Fund (BDF), a non-profit media watch group, and focused on growing cases of human rights abuse by Taiwan's media.
Cases discussed in the seminar included ignoring privacy and people's right as well as revealing the faces and names of patients with various illnesses without their prior consent.
"Most people nowadays are well aware of their own rights," said Yu Ying-fu, an attorney. "But mostly all they do is complain when they are offended by the media."
As an attorney, Yu said, he probably shouldn't encourage people to take legal action against the media.
"But by doing this, maybe the media will learn the lesson and finally understand the fine line between freedom of press and individual privacy."

"Reporters need a re-education in communication ethics, " said Paul Tsai, deputy manager of Formosa Television's news gathering center. "On the other hand, members of the public should also know their rights."

Tsai also mentioned several mechanisms that can help keep a tight rein on electronic media, including tighter supervision of the National Communication Commission (NCC) and regular human rights reviews by print media, media watchdogs and human rights groups.
"It is time to solve the [human rights abuse] problem, no matter how long it takes," BDF's CEO Connie Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS SERIOUSLY ABUSED IN TAIWAN MEDIA: MEDIAWATCHERS(repeat)

TEXT.P: Basic human rights, including privacy and the right to refuse to be interviewed, have been seriously abused by Taiwan's media, especially in television news, a media watchdog said in a seminar Friday.

Respect for human rights has been ignored for so long because of agrowing competition in the media, and it's time to solve the problem no matter how long it takes, said Connie Lin, CEO of the Broadcasting Development Fund (BDF) , a non-profit media watch group which organized the seminar "Human rights under the camera lens."
One of several TV newsclips played before the seminar showed a six-year-old girl refusing to be interviewed but ignored by the media and the face of a mentally ill patient.

The mother-in-law, first grandson and even butler of President Chen Shui-bian were followed by media everywhere, with more than two dozen reporters camped daily outside their residence in an attempt to follow their every move, the video also showed.

The current media chaos in Taiwan can be traced back to the "media explosion" after the end of the martial law era, and the situation has worsened in recent years, said Cheryl Lai, president of Radio Taiwan International.

Lai said that besides the "survival of the fittest" dynamic, the media should shoulder most of the responsibility for the decline in journalism's professionalism in recent years, because the media has gotten caught up in the numbers game -- doing whatever it takes to get higher ratings.
Not only have viewers felt frustration toward the media but reporters have as well -- which is why Chin Yu-chung became a print media reporter after five years as a TV cameraman.

With nine 24-hour news channels competing year-round, it's hard to believe the current situation will see any dramatic improvements, although a self-restraint and self-discipline agreement has been signed by all news channels, Lin said.

The media should start respecting basic human rights before it's too late, Lai said. Otherwise, she added, the general public will one day spurn the media because viewers have the ultimate power: turning off the television.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TALKS ABOUT TAIWAN DEMOCRACY IN SYDNEY(repeat)
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Wang Shu-feng and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan criticized China as a bullying neighbor Friday in Australia, arguing that Beijing's behavior has made Taiwan's political situation very difficult.

Yeh, who is leading a delegation of Kaohsiung city officials to Australia to attract Australian investment in the southern Taiwan port city, made the remarks while meeting with Taiwanese expatriates and young students at the University of Sydney.
Noting that China is targeting Taiwan with more then 800 missiles, Yeh said Beijing also has been transmitting the wrong message to the world community -- that Taiwan is a part of China.
"Beijing's efforts to squeeze Taiwan's development space in the world community have seriously damaged the friendship between people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait," Yeh added.

Taiwan is already an independent country, but China has no courage to recognize that reality, Yeh stressed, urging the Taiwanese people to bravely brace against Beijing's bullying by actively participating in international activities.
Yeh also introduced charms of Kaohsiung to the audience, saying that the city has great development potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AMERICA'S 13TH-CLOSEST ALLY: POLL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is considered by some Americans as the 13th- closest ally of the United States among a list of 25 countries, ranking far ahead of China, which takes 23rd place, according to the results of a survey released recently by Harris Interactive Inc.
The survey was conducted from July 5-11 among 1,020 adults, but only approximately 500 people were asked about each country. It had a margin of error of 4 percentage points.

The survey shows that 25 percent of the respondents think Taiwan is a close ally of the United States, 36 percent think Taiwan is friendly but not a close ally, 21 percent think Taiwan is not friendly but not an enemy either, and 6 percent think Taiwan is unfriendly and an enemy. Another 12 percent of those surveyed said they did not know or declined to answer the question.

On Americans' perception of China, only 9 percent of the respondents described China as a close ally, 37 percent said China is friendly but not a close ally, 33 percent said China is not friendly but not an enemy either, and 17 percent said China is unfriendly and an enemy. Another 4 percent did not know or declined to answer the question.

Meanwhile, Great Britain has for the third consecutive year been considered by Americans as the closest ally of the United States, with 74 percent of the respondents saying Great Britain is a close ally.

The other countries on the top four list are Canada, Australia and Japan, which are considered by 64 percent, 61 percent and 50 percent of the respondents, respectively, as a close ally of the United States.

Harris Interactive has conducted the survey since 1982. The countries included in this year's list are Great Britain, Canada, Australia, Japan, Israel, Italy, South Korea, Mexico, Germany, Sweden, Spain, Norway, Taiwan, the Netherlands, Greece, France, India, Brazil, South Africa, Chile, Russia, Argentina, Colombia, China and Pakistan.
