DOC.HEADLINE: FANS TO VISIT NEW YORK TO CHEER TAIWAN-BORN YANKEES PITCHER

TEXT.P: Local fans of Taiwan-born New York Yankees starting pitcher Wang Chien-ming are welcome to join a tour group to cheer their idol at the legendary Yankee Stadium in New York Sept. 13, a lawmaker said Saturday.
Legislator Tang Bi-a of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said she is organizing a 100-member fan group to cheer for Wang.
Tang, a passionate baseball fan, said Wang is the "pride of Taiwan" as he has made incredible achievements in his two-year career in the U.S. Major League.

Wang, 26, has quickly become one of the Yankees' most reliable starting pitchers, with 13 wins so far this season. Since June 6, Wang is 8-2 with a save and a 2.41 ERA in 11 starts and one relief appearance. On Wednesday, the right-hander pitched eight more shutout innings to win his fifth straight start for the Yankees, who defeated the Toronto Blue Jays 7-2. With Wednesday's win, Wang improved to 13-4 and ran his scoreless streak to 18 innings.

"This is an amazing career record for a rookie Asian pitcher in the American Major League. Actually, this is just his first full season in the Major League. Last year, he was forced out halfway through because of a wrist injury, " Tang said.
Tang said she is cooperating with China Airlines in organizing an eight-day New York tour for Wang's fans.
The group is scheduled to leave for New York Sept. 12, Tang said, adding that registration will close Aug. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE BUDGET TO BE RAISED TO 2.85% OF GDP NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The country's defense budget will be increased to account for 2.85 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) next year, up from this year's 2.45 percent, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Saturday.
The whole of the extra budget will be used for military arsenal procurement instead of financing personnel costs, according to Lin Chin-ching, director of the MND's strategic planning department.
Lin made the remarks at an international seminar being held in Taipei on Taiwan-Australia-Japan strategic dialogue and the Asia-Pacific security environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIANG WEI-SHUI MEMORIAL PARK INAUGURATED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A park commemorating pioneering Taiwan democracy activist Chiang Wei-shui was inaugurated in Taipei City Saturday, the 75th anniversary of Chiang's death.
Presiding over the inauguration of the park, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Chiang made a great contribution to Taiwan, dedicating a large part of his life to promoting Taiwan's democratic movement.

The Taipei city government has renamed the Chinhsi Park in the city's Tatung district as the Chiang Wei-Shui Memorial Park. It is located near a hospital formerly run by Chiang, a physician-turned democracy activist.

Born in 1891, Chiang was a mover in the forerunner of the Taiwanese nationalist movement under Japanese colonial rule. From 1921, he fought against the Japanese colonial regime by uniting students and social leaders under the banner of the Taiwan Cultural Association, cultivating a sense of national awareness.
He was jailed by the Japanese in 1923 and while in prison, he wrote extensively on humanitarian issues and opposed Japanese atrocities.
In 1927, he established Taiwan's first political party, the Taiwan People's Party, and later consolidated Taiwan's labor movements by forming the Taiwan Labor Alliance.
Chiang was incarcerated a dozen times during his lifetime and was lauded as "the savior of the Taiwan people" when he died in 1931 at the age of just 40.
Also that day, a ceremony was held at Taipei's Ching Hsiu Girls' High School -- the original site of the Taiwan Cultural Association headquarters -- to commemorate Chiang.

Former Control Yuan member Huang Huang-hsiung, who convened the ceremony, said Chiang represents the Taiwan spirit and the nationalist spirit and he urged the people, regardless of their political affiliations, to keep in mind the contribution Chiang made to Taiwan.
Huang pointed out that this year's ceremony marks the first time members of different political parties and ethnic groups have participated together.
Since a ceremony was held five years ago to remember the 70th anniversary of Chiang's death, various sectors of society have used different methods to express their gratitude for Chiang, Huang said.
For example, he said, the Cabinet has decided to name the Peiyi Freeway the Chiang Wei-shui Freeway, and a series of publications concerning Chiang are soon to be published.
The Yilan county government has also established a park to commemorate Chiang, who came from the northeastern county, Huang noted.
Ma also participated in that ceremony, along with Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Su Tseng-chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DENIES PRESIDENT HAS 'SECRET ACCOUNT'

TEXT.P: A Presidential Office spokesman denied Saturday an opposition legislator's allegation that President Chen Shui-bian has a secret bank account, claiming that the account in question is an open account used for political contributions ahead of the 2004 presidential election.

Lee Nan-yang made the statement to rebut the accusation made by Kuomintang Legislator Chiu Yi, who showed what he claimed is evidence Friday that Chen has a secret account with the Taishin International Bank that was opened in 2002 and was valued at NT$169 million (US$ 5.15 million) shortly after the presidential election in March 2004.
Chiu also claimed that Chen ordered a close aide to transfer the money in the account abroad in May 2004 and claimed that Chen has never declared this account to the Control Yuan.
According to Chiu, the president, who feared he might lose the election in 2004, ordered the transfer of the money into his personal account for the preparation for its transfer abroad.
However, Lee said the account was opened to receive donations from Chen's supporters for the 2004 presidential election and closed soon after the election.
In addition, Lee went on, Chiu just listed the receipts into the account and ignored the expenditure.

Noting that the Presidential Office closed the account shortly after the 2004 presidential election, Lee said the money in the account was not transferred abroad and that as the account does not belong to the personal assets of the president, it is therefore not necessary for Chen to declare it to the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL ORDER IMPROVING: NATIONAL POLICE CHIEF

TEXT.P: National Police Agency Director Hou You-yi said Saturday that the country's social order is improving in several aspects.

Hou made the remarks during a community meeting on social order in Taichung City, central Taiwan that was also attended by Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi, as well as several legislators and city councilors.

During the meeting, the legislators suggested that the central government assign more budget to local governments for the installation of more CCTV monitors in boroughs and villages around the island to improve social order.

You admitted that the installation of CCTV monitors would indeed help reduce the crime rate. However, due to the limitations of the government's budget, You encouraged private enterprises to install the monitors under the established investment encouragement regulations as a contribution to the communities.
Crime busting has become a top priority for Premier Su Tseng-chang, who pledged in March that he will step down and quit politics if social order had not improved within six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTS US$206 MILLION IN THAILAND'S ELECTRONICS INDUSTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses funded 35 investment projects with a total value of 7.8 billion baht (US$206.35 million) in Thailand's electronics industry in the first half of this year, according to tallies released Saturday by Thailand's Board of Investment.
The investment amount was the fifth- highest after Japan, the United States, Singapore and Hong Kong, while the number of projects was the third-highest after Japan and Singapore.

Board officials said delegations organized by the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturer's Association and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council to Thailand since the start of this year have been very helpful in boosting Taiwanese investment in Thailand.

The expected establishment of an Association of Southeast Asian Nations free trade zone has also been attractive to Taiwan businessmen, who can take advantage of their investments in Thailand to made inroads into the Southeast Asian market, they said.
The officials added that as Taiwan is a global leader in the electronics and information industries, the investment will help enhance Thailand's development of these areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIABETES DEATHS INCREASE IN 2005

TEXT.P: Over 10,000 people died from diabetes in 2005, averaging 1.2 deaths every hour, the Taiwanese Association of Diabetes Educators (TADE) said Saturday.
TADE President Hsu Huei-huan made the remarks in a seminar marking the 10th anniversary of the association's founding.
He noted that the mortality rate from diabetes is rising rapidly, making it, along with suicide, two of the nation's top 10 causes of death that have registered rapid increases.

Hsu noted that the mortality rate from diabetes increased by 13.8 percent last year compared with 2004, a rate of increase that surpassed those of malignant tumors, stroke and cardiovascular disease, which were the top three causes of death in 2005.
He cited statistics compiled by the Department of Health as saying that 10,501 people died from diabetes in Taiwan in 2005, averaging 28.7 deaths every day.

Up to 800,000 diabetes patients need medical treatment, with medical expenses surpassing NT$30 billion (US$91.46 million) , accounting for over 10 percent of the health insurance reimbursement payments.

He said the figure is an understatement, noting that if the figure were to be combined with deaths from complications from diabetes, the number would be even bigger, especially because 30 percent of diabetes patients can expect to suffer from retinal, neural and kidney problems within 10 years of diagnosis.
He cited kidney dialysis as an example, saying that out of 40,000 patients who need kidney dialysis at present, between 15,000 and 20,000 are diabetics.

Although the prevalence of diabetes is still the greatest among those over 40, accounting for between 11 percent and 13 percent, Hsu said there are also many cases of younger people suffering from the disease.
Around three-quarters of diabetics have difficulty controlling their disease, mainly because they do not follow a diet regimen.
He advised diet control, regular exercise and medication as the best ways to control the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIRELESS, MOBILE INTERNET ACCESS NEED PROMOTION: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Of Taiwan's Internet users, 18.37 percent, or 3.57 million, have wireless broadband access and 9.53 percent, or 1.85 million users, access the Internet through mobile broadband services, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Taiwan Network Information Center (TWNIC).

A TWNIC official explained that compared with an 80.64 percent penetration rate for ADSL broadband access, the ratios of wireless and mobile access are significantly lower, indicating that efforts are required to make them available to more users.

The survey was conducted by the TWNIC between May 17 and Aug. 4 among 3,192 Taiwan residents aged 12 or over. The survey, conducted through computer assisted telephone interviews, had a margin of error of 1.79 percent.

A similar poll conducted in July 2003 showed that the penetration rate of wireless access at that time was 1.51 percent. The estimated ratio grew to 3.07 percent in July 2005 and 3.56 percent this year.
This year's survey also shows that 47.56 percent of the wireless users access the Internet at home and that 31.28 percent of the respondents connect to the Internet at the office.
As for mobile services, the polled ratio in July 2003 was 0.96 percent, while the ratio grew to 1.48 percent in July 2005 and 1.66 percent this year.
According to this year's poll, 60.67 percent of mobile access users choose GPRS service, 12.95 percent use PHS, 11.06 percent use 3G, and 9.47 percent use WAP.
Of the mobile users, 39.80 percent said they use the service to download ring-tones, 18.27 percent said they use it to surf and 12.91 percent said they use it to send or receive e-mails.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN'S REACTION TO FIRST LADY'S JEWELRY REPORTS `WEAK': KMT

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, was "weak" in its response to a jewelry assets report filed by President Chen Shui-bian and first lady Wu Shu-jen, a lawmaker of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday.

KMT Legislator Tsai Ching-lung made the remarks one day after the Presidential Office replied to the Control Yuan in a letter that because the first lady borrowed some jewelry from relatives and friends, she could not list it in the report "for privacy reasons."
According to Tsai, the Control Yuan should "voice strong discontent" over this reply, instead of saying that the first couple has not violated the law.
The first couple sent a corrected version of jewelry assets to the Control Yuan in early July, listing 15 pieces of jewelry and watches that they own, with a value of NT$3.725 million (US$113,560).

Legislators from the opposition KMT and People First Party then showed photos of 31 pieces of jewelry worn by the first lady on various occasions. The Control Yuan therefore asked for an explanation from the first family within 15 days.

The first couple, replied Friday -- the last day of the deadline -- that they had acquiesced to the Control Yuan's request by filing reports on their jewelry, but had not reported on jewelry borrowed from relatives or friends because the relatives and friends were not being audited and should have the privacy of their assets protected.
Hsieh Yu-nan, a Control Yuan official in charge of asset reports, reportedly said that the first family has not violated the law in this regard.

Noting that according to the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, any piece of jewelry, including watches, worth over NT$200,000 (US$6,100) must be listed with the Control Yuan, Tsai said that the Control Yuan must demand that the public functionary give an explanation if asked, or face repeated fines of between NT$20,000 and NT$100,000 until an explanation is forthcoming.
Tsai said the KMT caucus will lodge a strong protest with the Control Yuan over its "weakness."

DOC.HEADLINE: ORAL HEALTHCARE AWARENESS POOR AMONG TAIWAN UNDERGRADUATES: STUDY

TEXT.P: Twenty percent of Taiwan undergraduates under the age of 20 have had at least one of their molar teeth extracted because of tooth decay, according to a study released Saturday by the Taiwan Oral Health Society.
The rate is 13 times higher than that of Japan, which shows that oral healthcare awareness among Taiwanese is insufficient, the society said.

The study was conducted by the society in cooperation with 16 countries in July and August 2005. A total of 2,800 undergraduates under 20 from Taiwan and Japan were surveyed, with the results set to be collated later along with the findings of similar surveys conducted in the other countries involved.
According to Chang Chin-shun, president of the society, the study found that the ratio of Taiwan undergraduates with gum inflammation is also higher than that of Japan.
Chang attributed the situation to failure by Taiwan undergraduates to clean their teeth thoroughly, which causes dental plaque that induces inflammation and bleeding.
Meanwhile, Chang said, diabetics should pay extra attention to their oral healthcare, because their susceptibility to inflammation can easily lead to periodontal disease.
As shown in a survey conducted last year among 250 diabetics
aged between 50 and 64 around Taiwan, 92.3 percent of those surveyed suffered from moderate or severe periodontal disease, Chang noted.

While 63.8 percent of diabetics had moderate periodontal disease, 28.5 percent had severe periodontal disease, he said, adding that the ratios compare with just 7 percent and 2.5 percent, respectively, among healthy people.
Also, each diabetic on average has had 14.37 teeth extracted because of tooth decay, which means that each one has lost almost half of his or her teeth, Chang said.

DOC.TEXT: The Times: Dozens of farm workers killed in airstrike on fruit warehouse Four missiles from Israeli fighter jets struck a Lebanese fruit-packing warehouse near the Syrian border yesterday, killing at least 33 mainly Kurdish farm workers and wounding a dozen.

New York Times: Risks Escalate as Israel Fights a Ground War
After resisting a major ground offensive for three weeks, Israel now has an estimated 10,000 troops in southern Lebanon trying to build a buffer zone free of Hezbollah, and the risks are already evident. In the past few days the troops have crossed the border by the thousands -- with seven brigades, including reserve units, totaling around 10,000 troops -- now in Lebanon, according to army radio and other Israeli news reports. The ground operation poses acute dangers for Israel and will severely complicate international efforts to end the fighting.
Wall Street Journal: Weaker Reception, Satellite TV Growth Is Losing Altitude As Cable Takes Off
The two leading satellite companies in the United States, DirecTV Group Inc. and EchoStar Communications Corp. are seeing a sharp slowdown in the number of new subscribers. In the last year, their gains have shrunk to half of what they were during the industry's heyday early in this decade, and they are projected to decline further. Meanwhile, the cable-TV industry, after years of seeing satellite steal market share and customers by pitching better service and more variety, is regaining ground. Companies like Time Warner Inc. and Cablevision Systems Corp. are wooing customers by providing video, telephone and high-speed Internet services in an attractively priced "triple play" bundle.

Premier Romano Prodi said that his government will promote a legislation to grant grant the citizenship to foreigners who live in Italy for five consecutive years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREATING FAVORABLE BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT PRIORITY FOR NEW MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister-designate Chen Ruey-long said Saturday that creating a business environment favorable to investment will be his top priority job after he assumes his post.
Chen made the remarks a day after Premier Su Tseng-chang announced his Cabinet reshuffle. Chen, who has been vice minister of economic affairs since 2002, will replace Hwang Ing-san.

Chen noted that the most important task for his ministry will be to create a business environment in which entrepreneurs want to invest, and help enterprises boost their competitiveness to ensure Taiwan's stable economic growth.

Noting that domestic investment has focused on flat panel displays and semiconductors for the last few years, Chen said he will encourage other industries to increase investment after he assumes his new post.
In addition, he said he will also consult with the representatives of the country's six major trade organizations and industrial leaders to better understand the problems facing the business sector.

In addition to helping foreign investors better understand Taiwan's investment environment through an international investment conference to be held in Taiwan in October, the ministry will try to attract Taiwanese businessmen with operations abroad to invest at home, taking advantage of preferential loans, Chen added.

According to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , the number of new investment projects launched by Taiwan's private sector during the first seven months of this year reached 795, with a value totaling NT$620.9 billion (US$18.9 million).
These investments represent 69 percent of the MOEA's goal for this year, or NT$903.2 billion.
Among the various sectors, electronics and information accounted for the bulk of new investment projects during the period.
Meanwhile, the number of new investment projects made by foreign and overseas Chinese investors totaled 666 during the first half of this year, with a value of NT$6.94 billion.

The value of the investment represented a growth of 530 percent over the same period of last year, with foreign investments expected to break NT$8 billion this year, a record high, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PLAYS `CRITICAL ROLE' IN TAIWAN STRAIT ISSUE: ACADEMICS

TEXT.P: Australia plays an "important role" in Taiwan Strait issues and should clearly oppose any change by force to Taiwan's sovereign status because it is in Australia's best interests, according to academics who attended an international seminar in Taipei Saturday.

"It would make Beijing understand that not only the U.S. and Japan, but also Australia, will provide support, if needed, on Taiwan Strait security, " said Bill Chang, a PhD student at the University of New South Wales, in the seminar, titled "The Asian Pacific Security Environment After the Enactment of the Anti-Secession Law."

"It is inconceivable that Canberra would not become involved if a war erupts in the strait with U.S. involvement. The Australian Armed Forces has clearly been geared toward providing assistance in combat, " according to You Ji, a professor at the University of New South Wales.
"Canberra's Taiwan policy is also clearly set on war prevention through maintaining the status quo in the strait. This is totally in line with Washington's position, " he added.

Eight of Australia's top 10 trade partners and 65% of its foreign trade come from the Asia-Pacific region, Chang pointed out. If military conflict between Taiwan and China were to occur, it would have a serious impact on Australia's interest in the region, he added.

The dilemma for Australia, You said, is that it strongly disapproves of China's politico-social system but has a pragmatic need to deepen export dependence on the Chinese market, which is why Prime Minister John Howard quickly altered his initial 1996 China policy from "balance-of-power based" to "cooperation based."
"If the U.S. is in for dealing with Taiwan Strait conflict, it's hard for Australia not to be in, " said Australian Adm. Chris Barrie.
"On the other hand, it seems to be time for a proper debate in Taiwan about future security and prospects," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-GRAFT CAMPAIGN SHOULD GO ALL OUT: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that an ongoing anti-graft campaign should go all out rather than being directed only at specific targets.
Lu made the remarks while announcing the establishment of a "blue sky, green land, good Taiwan alliance" to promote social harmony and political reconciliation.

As Taiwan is still in transition from authoritarian rule to democracy, Lu said, it must generate effective transitional justice mechanisms to address past abuses and reform society, including establishing clean politics.
"Taiwan's young democracy has yet to mature. We need to devote more energy to developing viable and workable mechanisms to uphold the rule of law," Lu said.
As far as the anti-corruption campaign is concerned, Lu said, it should be an across-the-board undertaking instead of being confined to certain specific targets.
She was referring to the spate of corruption allegations against the first family that has gripped the nation for past several months.

In her view, Lu said, the so-called "first family scandal" should be treated according to the same standards as those applied to other people. "We should follow due process in dealing with all corruption cases, " she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS IN ASIA-PACIFIC `DELICATE': ACADEMICS

TEXT.P: Strategic partnerships in the Asia-Pacific region, especially from U.S. allies' points of view, are a delicate issue, academics at an international seminar said Saturday.

The academics, from Australia, Japan and Taiwan, were attending the seminar, titled "The Asia-Pacific Security Environment After the Enactment of Anti-Secession Law, " organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy and the Cross-Strait Study Association.

A ministerial-level conference of U.S. Secretary of State Condoleeza Rice, Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Aso and Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer in March strengthened the strategic partnership between three countries, said Bill Chang, a PhD student at the University of New South Wales.

The partnership is obvious and regarded as a balance of China's growing impact in the region, as former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Perry once described Australia and Japan as two "anchors" of the U.S. Asia-Pacific strategy.
However, South Korea, which once was seen as a U.S. ally, seems to be drifting out of the equation, said Tomohide Murai, a professor at Japan's National Defense Academy.

"It seems to me that South Korea is no longer a reliable partner for the U.S., as 40 percent of the respondents to a South Korean public opinion poll said the U.S. is the biggest threat to South Korea. Also, 60 percent of the respondents supported North Korea's nuclear program, " Murai added.
The anti-U.S. atmosphere was not only felt in South Korea but in Japan as well, especially Okinawa Prefecture, he added.
Taiwan on the other hand has never been officially seen as a strategic partner of the U.S. because of the cross-strait situation, he said.
The partnership will be even more complicated if trade relations with China are factored into the equation, said You Ji, a professor at the University of New South Wales.

DOC.HEADLINE: `30-HOUR FAST' TAKES TO RAILS

TEXT.P: Some 650 people ranging from six to 86 years old set off Saturday from Taipei on a one-week train journey around Taiwan as part of a "30-hour fast" organized by World Vision Taiwan (WVT) and a convenience store chain to raise money for famine victims and the underprivileged.
The train ride is one of a wide variety of charity activities organized by WVT this year to collect NT$100 million (US$3.04 million) in humanitarian relief funds.

WVT plans to use NT$50 million of the funds raised for assistance within Taiwan, while the remaining NT$50 million will be distributed among rescue and medical care projects abroad, especially in southern Africa and some Asian countries.
WVT officials urged local people to donate generously to the cause by making donations directly through the WVT Web site or through any 7-11 stores.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS TRANSPORT HEAD IN ETC SYSTEM CONTROVERSY

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday that although Minister of Transportation and Communications Kuo Yao-chi is in charge of dealing with the shambles surrounding the controversial electronic toll collection (ETC) system, she should not be held responsible for the chaos.

Su made the remarks after the Supreme Administrative Court decided Thursday to revoke the "priority bidder" status of the Far Eastern Electronic Toll Corp. (FETC), which has been running the ETC system on the nation's freeways since February, ruling that it was a flawed screening process that enabled the FETC to obtain priority status over two other bidders.

The ruling put the ETC controversy back to square one, despite the fact that around 220,000 on-board units (OBUs) have been installed in cars using the FETC's system since February. The opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party had demanded that Kuo step down to take administrative responsibility for the mess.
Su noted that the planning and the bidding process did not take place during Kuo's tenure, as she only assumed the post early this year and is only in charge of taking care of the aftermath.
Su said the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC) should "review seriously the earlier bidding process and find out who should be held responsible."
He said the most important thing is to protect the rights of the 220,000 OBU users and to keep the damage to the government and the subscribers to a minimum.

In February 2006, the Taipei High Administrative Court ruled on the same premise that FETC should be stripped of its "priority bidder" status, a ruling that the MOTC's National Expressway Bureau appealed to the Supreme Administrative Court. Thursday's ruling was the result of that appeal.

The FETC, which has invested more than NT$3 billion in building the infrastructure and installing the OBUs necessary to run the ETC system, expressed the hope that the government will take over the system, but promised to continue operations to ensure the rights of users and to refund them fully.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS OFFICIAL INSPECTS WATER, POWER FACILITIES ON PENGHU

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Hou Ho-shong arrived on the outlying island of Penghu Saturday to inspect water and power facilities.
Hou visited two of the island county's scenic spots -- Wangan and Chipei townships -- to inspect first-hand the water and electricity supply situation.

Hou said that Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) and Taiwan Water Corp. lose money every year on Penghu but have continued to provide the same steady, quality services to the island as provided to Taiwan proper.
He said his inspection tour was aimed at obtaining a better understanding of Penghu's water and electricity needs and to learn what assistance the ministry can provide.
He lauded Taipower's efforts in energy conservation, especially its recycled energy and the tapping of wind power.
Wind power will be a major "green" energy, as the world price of crude oil soars, he claimed, expressing the hope that Penghu will not face water and electricity shortages in the future.
Hou is scheduled to inspect a desalination plant in Makung, Penghu's capital, Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ALLIANCE FORMED TO PROMOTE HEALTHY CROSS-PARTY COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced the formation of a new alliance Saturday that she said will work for clean politics and healthy competition among local political parties.
Lu said she came up with the idea of forming a "blue sky, green land, good Taiwan" alliance after the June 27 failure of an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

"The recall move caused turmoil in society and a constitutional crisis. After fierce inter-party confrontation, a common value has emerged in society. That is, political integrity and good governance. From now on, the ruling and opposition parties should enter a new stage of competition, with ethics, competence, rationality and accountability as common values," Lu said.

As Taiwan is still in transition from authoritarian rule to mature democracy, Lu said, occasional disturbances and chaos are inevitable. "We need not feel despair over scandals and should instead try to turn a crisis into an opportunity."
With the support of several private social groups, the "good Taiwan alliance" has been formed to work toward political stability, social harmony and economic prosperity, Lu said.
"We'll pool wisdom and resources to push for our country's healthy development," Lu added.
Touching on an ongoing anti-graft campaign, Lu said, the undertaking should go all out and inclusive instead of being directed only at specific targets.
In this transitional period, Lu said, Taiwan must generate effective transitional justice mechanisms to address past abuses and reform society, including establishing clean politics.
"Taiwan's young democracy has yet to mature. We need to devote more energy to developing viable and workable mechanisms to uphold the rule of law," Lu said.
As far as the anti-corruption campaign is concerned, Lu said, it should be an across-the-board undertaking instead of being confined to certain specific targets.
She was referring to the spate of corruption allegations against the first family that has gripped the nation for past several months.

In her view, Lu said, the so-called "first family scandal" should be treated according to the same standards as those applied to other people. "We should follow due process in dealing with all corruption cases, " she added.

According to the Corruption Perception Index compiled by the Transparency International, Taiwan ranked 28th among the 90 countries studied in 2000 and the rating dropped to 30th in 2003. Amid the recent overblown corruption allegations, Lu said she is worried that Taiwan's rating would plunge further this year.
Quoting the results of a public opinion poll, Lu said 38 percent of people interviewed said none of Taiwan's major political parties is clean.
Six years after the launch of a campaign against political corruption, Lu said law enforcement authorities have handled 3,241 corrupt cases, with 7,959 suspects indicted and 2,879 of them convicted.

Lu said the new alliance will address issues such as eliminating corruption, improving law and order, re-establishing ethical standards, life-long education and educational reform, the enhancement of industrial development, Taiwan's investment environment and globalization of Taiwan.

Stressing that the nation's two major political camps -- the opposition "pan-blue alliance" and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led "pan-green camp" must reconcile for the sake of political stability, Lu said the alliance has worked several key proposals to that goal.

While major political parties should seek to establish a mechanism for rational consultation and healthy competition, Lu said, the ruling party should reform itself to form a clean and efficient administration.
Meanwhile, Lu said the Legislative Yuan should approve the nominations for the Control Yuan and state public prosecutor-general and pass a series of sunshine laws as soon as possible.

Moreover, she added, the judicial authorities should maintain their independence and impartiality and uphold justice. Lu also urged the mass media to fulfill its social responsibility and be truthful in news reporting.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTRA DEFENSE BUDGET TO FINANCE ARSENAL PROCUREMENT: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The country's defense budget will be increased to account for 2.85 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) next year and to 3 percent of GDP in 2008, compared to this year's 2.45 percent, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Saturday.
The whole of the extra budget will be used for military arsenal procurement instead of financing personnel costs, said Lin Chin-ching, director of the MND's strategic planning department.
Lin made the remarks at an international seminar being held in Taipei on the Asia-Pacific security environment after the enactment of China's Anti-Secession Law.

According to Lin, Taiwan's annual defense budget is about US$8 billion, half of which is appropriated for personnel costs. The remaining US$4 billion is used for maintenance of weapons and R&D projects.
After the defense budget ratio is increased next year, Lin said the extra budget will all be used to finance arsenal procurement and rennovation as well as development of new defense technology.

Stressing that none of the extra budget will be spent on personnel salary, Lin said the MND will continue its troops-reduction project in line with its goal of establishing an elite deterrent force in the face of China's military threat.
Lin said the military will complete the integration of command, control, communications and information system by the end of this year to upgrade its early warning combat capabilities.

Noting that China's announced defense budget reaches US$30 billion annually, Lin said the actual amount of China's annual military spending is at least three times the announced amount. Given the face that China doesn't have any real enemy in teh Asia-Pacific region, Lin said it is baffling that China spends such a huge sum of money on military buildup. ( Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO LEAVE FOR VISIT TO CHAD

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang will depart for Chad Sunday to attend Chadian President Idriss Deby's second inauguration scheduled for Tuesday.
It will be Su's first overseas trip since assuming the premiership in late January this year.

Su will attend Deby's inauguration as President Chen Shui-bian's special envoy. He will also inspect operations of the country's embassy as well as technical and medical missions in Chad, a Central African inland country that has maintained cordial diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Su will be accompanied by an entourage comprising Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang, Council of Agriculture Chairman Su Jia-chyuan, Department of Health Minister Hou Sheng-mao, Government Information Office Director-General Cheng Wen-tsang, Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng of the Council for Economic Planning and Development and Chinese Petroleum Corp. Chairman Pan Wen-yen. Su's wife will also accompany him on the visit.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Aug. 6:
10:25, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a news conference at Ambassador Hotel in Kaohsiung to be hosted by Chen Chu, the DPP's candidate for the year-end Kaohsiung mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CUTS OFF DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH CHAD

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced early Sunday that the Republic of China government has decided to break off diplomatic ties with the central African country of Chad.
The announcement came on the eve of Premier Su Tseng-chang's planned visit to Chad to attend Chadian President Idriss Deby's second inauguration scheduled for Tuesday.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said Su has canceled his Chad travel plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SU CANCELS CHAD TRAVEL PLAN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang has canceled his plan to visit Chad as the government has decided to cut off diplomatic ties with the Central African country, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced early Sunday.
Su was originally scheduled to depart Taipei late Sunday for Chad to attend Chadian President Idriss Deby's inauguration Aug. 8 for a new term.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu told a news conference around Saturday midnight that the government decided to terminate diplomatic ties with Chad and immediately cease all of the aid projects to the country after learning that Chad is ready to switch its diplomatic recognition to Beijing.

"To safeguard national dignity, sovereignty and popular well-being, the government of the Republic of China decided to cut off diplomatic ties with Chad and immediately suspended all of the aid projects to the country, " the foreign ministry said in a statement issued at midnight.
Since the beginning of this year, Lu said, the ROC government has kept vigilant that China's support for Chadian rebels might left Taiwan-Chad relations in tatters.

Over the past half year, Lu said the government has pulled out all the stops to consolidate ties with Chad. But all those efforts turned out to be futile and bootless. Chad was forced to give up its ties with Taiwan in exchange for China's aid in resolving its domestic rebellion and disputes with neighboring Sudan.
Lu condemned China for trying to profit from Chad's misfortune and its relentless efforts to suppress Taiwan's diplomatically.
He also expressed regret over Chad's capitulation to China's temptation at the expense of its national dignity and its promise to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO CONTINUE OIL EXPLORATION PROJECTS IN CHAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said Sunday it will continue its oil exploration projects in Chad even though the two countries have severed diplomatic ties.

CPC President Chen Pao-lang said oil exploration is a commercial activity that has nothing to do with politics. Noting that oil producing countries tend to welcome foreign investment in oil prospecting in their territories regardless of political or diplomatic ties, Chen said CPC has a long history of joining oil exploration investment projects in countries that do not maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
Chad is one of the major oil producing countries in Africa and a newly emerging oil exploration areas amid the current upward spiral in international crude oil prices.

CPC began to seek oil exploration deals in Chad in 2003. Taiwan and Chad signed an initial agreement on cooperation in oil exploration in 2004. In January this year, CPC signed formal oil fields and joint operations contracts with Chad to secure its rights to prospecting for crude oil in the Central African inland country.
According to Chen, CPC has obtained rights to explore oil in three Chadian oil fields and has sent a working mission to conduct geological surveys there.
Even after Taiwan cut off diplomatic ties with Chad, Chen said CPC will continue carrying out its oil prospecting projects in that country to protect its legitimate rights.

Taiwan announced its decision to break off diplomatic relations with Chad at Saturday midnight after its received information that the African state is ready to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
China has intensified a diplomatic and trade offensive in Africa to increase its influence there and squeeze Taiwan's diplomatic frontiers.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS REGRET RUPTURE OF TAIWAN-CHADIAN TIES

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from across the political spectrum expressed regret Sunday over the rupture of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Chad, but they didn't see eye to eye on reasons behind the diplomatic setback.

While legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) castigated China for forcing Chad to switch diplomatic allegiance in its favor, their opposition colleagues said the DPP administration is to blame for the embarrassing fiasco.

DPP Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim said it's no news that China pressures or lures Taiwan's diplomatic allies into its fold. The most vicious was that China chose a special timing to deal a severe blow to Premier Su Tseng-chang, a popular bigwig in the DPP administration.

Upon learning that Chad was ready to resume diplomatic ties with China, Taiwan announced its decision to sever diplomatic ties with Chad on the eve of Su's scheduled departure for the Chadian capital of N'Djamena late Sunday to attend Chadian President Deby's inauguration for a new term.

"The timing gave me feeling of deja vu, " Hsiao said, adding that the Pacific island nation of Nauru announced its decision to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing July 22, 2002 -- the day when President Chen Shui-bian concurrently took up the post of DPP chairmanship.
China obviously intended to embarrass Su by choosing this special timing to force Chad to cut ties with Taiwan, Hsiao claimed.
However, Legislator Tsai Chin-lung of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said the DPP's incapacity to govern efficiently is the root cause of the slew of diplomatic debacles.

"The DPP has typically failed to pick the best persons to fill key government posts," Tsai contended, adding that the DPP tends to be arrogant with power while lacking in the capability to rev up the economy or expand diplomatic frontiers.

Meanwhile, KMT deputy spokesman Huang Yu-chen said it's "unimaginable" that the government announced termination of diplomatic ties with a country where the premier was originally scheduled to visit the following day.
Huang said the DPP administration should review whether diplomatic staff were guilty of malfeasance, incompetence or gross negligence.

Wu Kun-yu, deputy director of the opposition People First Party's publicity department, echoed Huang's view, saying the government should conduct a thorough review to determine which units or individual staff members should be held responsible for the latest diplomatic setback.

"The event came so abruptly, indicating that our diplomatic and national security systems have not functioned effectively. They have obviously failed to grasp the situation well, " Wu argued, adding that the government should make amends swiftly enough in order to cement ties with all of the country's remaining diplomatic allies.
In recent decades Taiwan has been fighting an offensive by Beijing -- often involving enormous infusions of developmental aid -- to squeeze its number of diplomatic allies.
Beijing is now focusing its pressure on Africa, using its economic clout to offer lucrative aid, trade and investment deals in exchange for oil, raw materials and diplomatic allegiance.

Taiwan has been one of Chad's major foreign allies, helping to develop its infrastructure and offering to assist it in expanding its oil industry. Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang met with Chadian leaders in N'Djamena last month to try to shore up bilateral relations, but to no avail.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 6, or the 13th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1806: Holy Roman Emperor Francis II is forced to resign due to the third defeat in the war against Bonaparte Napoleon.
1825: Bolivia declares independence from Peru.
1890: A murderer named William Kemmler is the first prison executed by electric chair in the United States.
1914: Yuan Shih-kai declares China's neutrality in World War I.
1932: The first international film festival opens in Venice, Italy with 29 motion pictures from the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Soviet Union and Italy being shown.
1945: U.S. plane drops the first atomic bomb in Hiroshima, Japan, killing more than 90,000 and injuring over 9,000.
1949: At the invitation of Korean President Syngman Rhee, President Chiang Kai-shek flies to Chinhae, Korea to discuss the formation of a Pacific alliance.
1962: Jamaica declares independence from Britain.
1997: Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman Lacayo arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1997: A South Korean Boeing 747-300 jetliner crashes in Guam, killing 234 on board.
2001: After careful planning, prayer rooms are formally opened at CKS International Airport. The three adjacent prayer rooms have one room equipped with rush mats for kneeling, another fitted with rows of chairs and still another with mattresses and a mark to show the direction of Mecca.

Israeli forces killed 33 agricultural workers Friday in northeast Lebanon in a wave of airstrikes that also pierced the country's Christian heartland for the first time and severed its last major highway link to the outside.

The Japan Times Tojo: Yasukuni solely for those killed in war
