DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
Chad severs formal ties with ROC hours before Premier Su's departure for visit.
The United Daily News:
Su's Chad visit halted upon rupture of diplomatic ties.
The Liberty Times:
Premier's trip canceled upon severance of Taiwan-Chad ties.
The China Post:
VP Lu calls for rational, benign competition.
The Taiwan News:
Magistrates stonewalled in Lafayette case.
The Taipei Times:
UN moves toward Lebanon resolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTRA DEFENSE BUDGET TO FINANCE ARSENAL PROCUREMENT: OFFICIAL(repeat)

TEXT.P: The country's defense budget will be increased to account for 2.85 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) next year and to 3 percent of GDP in 2008, compared to this year's 2.45 percent, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Saturday.
The whole of the extra budget will be used for military arsenal procurement instead of financing personnel costs, said Lin Chin-ching, director of the MND's strategic planning department.
Lin made the remarks at an international seminar being held in Taipei on the Asia-Pacific security environment after the enactment of China's Anti-Secession Law.

According to Lin, Taiwan's annual defense budget is about US$8 billion, half of which is appropriated for personnel costs. The remaining US$4 billion is used for maintenance of weapons and R&D projects.
After the defense budget ratio is increased next year, Lin said the extra budget will all be used to finance arsenal procurement and rennovation as well as development of new defense technology.

Stressing that none of the extra budget will be spent on personnel salary, Lin said the MND will continue its troops-reduction project in line with its goal of establishing an elite deterrent force in the face of China's military threat.
Lin said the military will complete the integration of command, control, communications and information system by the end of this year to upgrade its early warning combat capabilities.

Noting that China's announced defense budget reaches US$30 billion annually, Lin said the actual amount of China's annual military spending is at least three times the announced amount. Given the face that China doesn't have any real enemy in teh Asia-Pacific region, Lin said it is baffling that China spends such a huge sum of money on military buildup. ( Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ALLIANCE FORMED TO PROMOTE HEALTHY CROSS-PARTY COMPETITION(repeat)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced the formation of a new alliance Saturday that she said will work for clean politics and healthy competition among local political parties.
Lu said she came up with the idea of forming a "blue sky, green land, good Taiwan" alliance after the June 27 failure of an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

"The recall move caused turmoil in society and a constitutional crisis. After fierce inter-party confrontation, a common value has emerged in society. That is, political integrity and good governance. From now on, the ruling and opposition parties should enter a new stage of competition, with ethics, competence, rationality and accountability as common values," Lu said.

As Taiwan is still in transition from authoritarian rule to mature democracy, Lu said, occasional disturbances and chaos are inevitable. "We need not feel despair over scandals and should instead try to turn a crisis into an opportunity."
With the support of several private social groups, the "good Taiwan alliance" has been formed to work toward political stability, social harmony and economic prosperity, Lu said.
"We'll pool wisdom and resources to push for our country's healthy development," Lu added.
Touching on an ongoing anti-graft campaign, Lu said, the undertaking should go all out and inclusive instead of being directed only at specific targets.
In this transitional period, Lu said, Taiwan must generate effective transitional justice mechanisms to address past abuses and reform society, including establishing clean politics.
"Taiwan's young democracy has yet to mature. We need to devote more energy to developing viable and workable mechanisms to uphold the rule of law," Lu said.
As far as the anti-corruption campaign is concerned, Lu said, it should be an across-the-board undertaking instead of being confined to certain specific targets.
She was referring to the spate of corruption allegations against the first family that has gripped the nation for past several months.

In her view, Lu said, the so-called "first family scandal" should be treated according to the same standards as those applied to other people. "We should follow due process in dealing with all corruption cases, " she added.

According to the Corruption Perception Index compiled by the Transparency International, Taiwan ranked 28th among the 90 countries studied in 2000 and the rating dropped to 30th in 2003. Amid the recent overblown corruption allegations, Lu said she is worried that Taiwan's rating would plunge further this year.
Quoting the results of a public opinion poll, Lu said 38 percent of people interviewed said none of Taiwan's major political parties is clean.
Six years after the launch of a campaign against political corruption, Lu said law enforcement authorities have handled 3,241 corrupt cases, with 7,959 suspects indicted and 2,879 of them convicted.

Lu said the new alliance will address issues such as eliminating corruption, improving law and order, re-establishing ethical standards, life-long education and educational reform, the enhancement of industrial development, Taiwan's investment environment and globalization of Taiwan.

Stressing that the nation's two major political camps -- the opposition "pan-blue alliance" and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led "pan-green camp" must reconcile for the sake of political stability, Lu said the alliance has worked several key proposals to that goal.

While major political parties should seek to establish a mechanism for rational consultation and healthy competition, Lu said, the ruling party should reform itself to form a clean and efficient administration.
Meanwhile, Lu said the Legislative Yuan should approve the nominations for the Control Yuan and state public prosecutor-general and pass a series of sunshine laws as soon as possible.

Moreover, she added, the judicial authorities should maintain their independence and impartiality and uphold justice. Lu also urged the mass media to fulfill its social responsibility and be truthful in news reporting.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: World education conference opens
Seeking to build a culture of peace for a civil society, some 1,500 delegates from various educational institutions in 110 countries gather today at the historic landmark Manila Hotel for the start of the week-long World Council for Curriculum and Instruction (WCCI) 12th World Conference in Education.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Busloads of Filipinos flee
EFLYING the Philippine flag and with markings to signify that they were not the enemy, nine buses carrying hundreds of Filipino workers sped from Beirut yesterday using a new untried route to escape a country slowly being turned to rubble.
The Philippine Star: Troops overrun Abu Sayyaf training camp in Sulu town
Government forces battling Abu Sayyaf terrorists in Sulu since early last week overran yesterday what military officials believe is a training and bomb-making facility.
The Manila Times: Nursing decline: Heavy toll on nation's health
THE state of nursing education in the country is a favorite topic among reform-minded government officials, health experts, lawmakers, nurses and the media. (By Emerson T. Lim) DNDITEM

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S., France Agree On Plan to Halt Lebanon Fighting; Beirut, Hezbollah Balk at U.N. Terms.
United Nations, Aug. 5 -- The United States and France reached agreement Saturday on a draft Security Council resolution calling for "full cessation of hostilities" between Israel and Hezbollah and outlining initial steps to end their 25-day conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TO EXPLAIN 'SECRET BANK ACCOUNT' ALLEGATION

TEXT.P: Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general to President Chen Shui-bian, said Sunday the Presidential Office has provided an "initial explanation" in response to an opposition legislator's allegation the president has a "secret bank account" at Taishin International Bank that may have been used to launder slush funds.

Director Lee Nan-yang of the office's department of public affairs said Saturday that what Kuomintang (KMT) legislator Chiu Yi claimed to be a "secret" account is actually an open account set up during the 2004 presidential elections, and that Chiu has made the "groundless" allegation as a way to smear the president.
Tan Sun Chen said if there is need for further understanding of the issue, the Presidential Office will provide a public explanation.
Chiu said if the secret account were, as Lee had said, "used to handle political contributions, " why had Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter Chen Hsing-yu deposited money into it?

He claimed there were four records of the president's son and daughter depositing money into the "secret account" at the bank's Nanmen (South Gate) branch, including a "critical" deposit of NT$2 million made by Chen Hsing-yu on Feb. 6, 2004.

He claimed "a great number of large-sum contributions" had been deposited into that account. If these political donations were not so shady that they must remain in the dark, "then President Chen should tell people who had donated how much to him," Chiu added.
He said he suspected these big donations were made as tradeoffs in some unspeakable dealings that could serve as "key evidence" of the president's suspected involvement in corruption.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY MUM ON NEW U.N. BID UNDER NAME OF 'TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman kept mum Sunday on whether the Republic of China government would adopt a new strategy this year to gain United Nations membership by applying under the name "Taiwan" instead of the "ROC, " "Chinese Taipei" or other titles.

Michel Lu declined to comment on a cable television news report Sunday that Taiwan will embark on a new U.N. bid under the name of "Taiwan" and will submit the bid via Taiwanese authorities rather than through representatives of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, as was the case over the last 13 years.

Lu only said that Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang will tell the country next week how the foreign ministry is striving to renew the U.N. bid by allowing the 23 million people of Taiwan to be represented.

John Chen, director-general of the foreign ministry's Department of International Organizations, said several days ago that Taiwan will basically follow the same strategies as last year. In its failed 2005 bid, Taiwan called for the U.N. to help maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait and for the international body to pay attention to the representation of Taiwan's 23 million people at the United Nations.

This year, Chen said, Taiwan will call for the U.N. to play a more active role in maintaining peace in the Asia-Pacific region and again stress the imperative nature of Taiwan's representation in the world body.
President Chen Shui-bian said July 15 that Taiwan deserves a seat in the United Nations because it is a basic human right for Taiwanese people to be able to join international organizations.
Taiwan has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971, when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the China seat to Beijing at Taiwan's expense.
While Resolution No. 2758 resolved the issue regarding China's U.N. representation, President Chen said it did not address the representation of Taiwan's people.

"In terms of the principle of membership universality prescribed in the U.N. charter, Taiwan deserves a U.N. seat, " the president said, adding that Taiwan's bid for U.N. accession is part of its efforts to maintain its population's basic human rights.
"Our rights to participate in the United Nations and fulfill our international duties should not be kept from us or denigrated," he said.
"We plan to expand our perspective by calling for U.N. attention to the Asia-Pacific regional peace, which implies the need to maintain cross-strait stability," the president added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Agreement on U.N. resolution for ceasefire in Lebanon.
The United States and France reached an agreement Saturday on a draft United Nations resolution calling for a halt to the violence in Lebanon, while the Israel-Hezbollah fighting grew particularly intense.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU UNAWARE OF LEE'S CONDITIONS TO BACK VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: In response to a local media report that former President Lee Teng-hui conditionally backs Vice President Annette Lu as President Chen Shui-bian's successor, an official of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Sunday that they had never heard of such a notion.

Lo Chih-ming, the TSU's secretary-general and a lawmaker, denied Sunday's report in the China Times that Lee, the TSU's spiritual leader, has laid out three conditions for Lu in the event the vice president takes over the presidency from Chen, who has been dogged by a spate of corruption allegations.

According to the China Times report, Lee asked Lu to honor the following conditions -- -- pardon Chen, not to run in the 2008 presidential election and to nominate Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng as premier. Lee pledged that he would help oust Chen, should Lu be willing to live up to these three promises, the report said.

Claiming that the TSU has never heard of the three conditions that Lee laid out for Lu in exchange for his assistance in Lu's succession, Lo stressed that it is impossible that Lee, a figure devoted to Taiwan's democratization, would get involved in such a matter.

According to Lo, however, the former president said he suggested that Lu first seek the trust and understanding of the United States to assuage the outside world's fear of her radical pro-Taiwan independence stance.

Lee's comments came at time when opposition parties -- such as the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party -- are mulling the possibili ty of booting out Chen if there is solid evidence to prove his role in several high-profile scandal allegations.

Main opposition KMT lawmaker Chiu Yi unveiled Chen's "secret" account of nearly NT$170 million at a local bank Saturday -- the newest corruption allegation related to Chen following questionable reimbursements of state affairs funds claimed by the Presidential Office on Chen's behalf -- which was also brought to light by Chiu in late June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA USED REBELS TO FORCE CHAD TO CUT TIES WITH TAIWAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: China has long supported Chad's rebel forces, which it has just used to force the Chadian government to cut off diplomatic ties with the Republic of China, a senior official said Sunday.
Three factors have contributed toward Chad's decision to sever official ties with Taiwan, according to an analysis of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

First, through Sudan, China has been supporting insurgent forces opposing the Chadian government. If the Chadian government wants to make peace with both China and the insurgents, it must work with China, which demanded it cut ties to Taiwan.
The second factor is that Chad became an oil-exporting country in 2003, and China increased its purchase of Chadian crude in the first half of this year by 50 percent over the same time last year.
A third factor is that China has used huge sums of money to "buy off" Chad in the form of aid programs and other measures, according to the senior official who asked not to be identified.
He noted that in a letter to President Chen Shui-bian, the Chadian president said he was forced to make the decision "for the sake of my country's survival."
The Chadian leader also expressed hope his country would remain "a friend of Taiwan" so that unofficial exchanges can continue in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, according to the official.

He added that Chinese Petroleum Corp.'s (CPC) oil exploitation pact with Chad would continue because it was a commercial contract. If Chad reneges on it, "the state-run enterprise could file a lawsuit against the Chadian government," he added.
MOFA announced a severance of official ties with Chad early Sunday, bringing down the number of countries that keep official relations with Taiwan to 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD LAMBASTES BEIJING OVER SEVERANCE OF TAIWAN-CHAD TIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of China policy severely criticized Beijing Sunday over the rupture of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Chad.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Beijing is to blame for the severance of Taiwan-Chad formal ties -- which occurred in Sunday's wee hours -- and that Beijing should bear all responsibility for any adverse impacts on developments in cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a result of Chad's diplomatic about-face.

Chad's switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing occurred only hours prior to Premier Su Tseng-chang's scheduled departure for Chad on an official visit, and was Beijing's conspiracy to humiliate Taiwan's government and its people, Wu asserted.

Wu said Beijing has always adopted a two-pronged strategy toward Taiwan -- currying favor with Taiwanese people through a series of overtures on one hand, while on the other relentlessly trying to contain Taiwan in the international community.

It's bitterly ironic that while suffocating Taiwan diplomatically in the international community, Beijing has continued to make overtures to Taiwan's people, including offering pandas as gifts, helping Taiwan's farmers export their products to China, allowing cross-strait exchanges between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC), as well as agreeing on a proposed visit to Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, head of the CPC's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, Wu said.
Wu called on all of Taiwan's sectors to no longer harbor illusions about China and to instead begin discerning Beijing's "true colors."

He said all of Taiwan people should condemn China with the strongest words possible over China's bullying of Taiwan and that opposition parties should put aside political differences with the Democratic Progressive Party administration to jointly defend Taiwan's dignity and its interests on the diplomatic front.

Meanwhile, MAC officials said the administration may consider allowing Chen Yunlin, China's chief of Taiwan affairs, to visit Taiwan later this year if he comes to Taiwan to apologize to Taiwan's people for the country's latest diplomatic setback.
"There's no chance of Chen coming if he does not offer an apology," MAC officials said.

MAC officials said that it marked the second time in three months that Premier Su's scheduled overseas state visit was brought to a halt, all because of Beijing's interference. Su planned to visit Haiti in May but the trip was canceled as a result of Beijing's intervention.

Responding to MAC officials' remarks that Chen would not be welcome if he does not apologize, Chang Jung-kung, deputy director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, said rejecting Chen's visit is not conducive to broadening Taiwan's diplomatic horizons.

Instead, Chang said, if Chen is allowed to visit Taiwan, it will demonstrate Taiwan's magnanimity, which will in turn win the international community's hearts and minds and consequently help Taiwan break through Beijing's diplomatic suppression.
According to Chang, Chen has planned to file an application with the MAC in mid-August to visit Taiwan in mid-October for a KMT-sponsored agricultural forum.
The KMT invited Chen to visit Taipei last October for an economic forum, but his application was rejected by the MAC on the grounds that it required official negotiations between Taipei and Beijing.

Consequently, the KMT organized a mission under the leadership of KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chen that traveled to Shanghai last October to take part in a KMT-CPC economic forum -- the first of its kind in nearly six decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: OIL EXPLOITATION IN CHAD NOT TO BE AFFECTED: CPC

TEXT.P: The suspension of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Chad is not expected to affect Taiwan's oil exploitation in that central African country, state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said Sunday.

According to a CPC spokesman, the oil exploitation contract signed between Taiwan and Chad are purely a business arrangement that should not be hindered by changes in diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Nevertheless, the CPC will continue closely watching follow-up developments on the issue, although relevant work has proceeded in line with the contract inked by the two countries, he said.

Through the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) , the CPC signed the contract in January this year with Chad to exclusively explore and jointly manage three oil fields in Chad during a four-year period. The combined size of the three fields totals some 26,000 square meters.

Under the terms of the contract, the CPC has set up an office in Chad and is slated to funnel US$30 million into the oil project, the spokesman pointed out, adding that the CPC has paid US$17 million to sign the contract with Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD CALLS FOR ENGAGEMENT AS MEANS TO BREAK DIPLOMATIC IMPASSE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou called for engagement with China Sunday in order to allow a breakthrough in Taiwan's current diplomatic dilemma, as Beijing has increasingly contained Taiwan in the international community.

Responding to Taiwan's severing of formal diplomatic ties earlier Sunday with its African ally, Chad, Ma said in the eastern city of Yilan -- where he was attending an international children's folklore and folkgame festival -- that China has been Taiwan's greatest nightmare on the diplomatic front.

Ma said Taiwan faces tremendous pressures due to China's rapid, continued rise in strategic and economic clout in the international community, adding that the only way to break through the current diplomatic impasse is to improve cross-strait relations.
Ma called for the Democratic Progressive Party administration to resume a pragmatic approach in diplomacy, saying that a zero-sum approach, hatred or revenge "will get Taiwan nowhere."

Apparently under Beijing's influence, Chad announced late Saturday night that it had severed diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs immediatedly responded by declaring a rupture in formal ties with Chad.
Chad's diplomatic about-face came only hours prior to Premier Su Tseng-chang's scheduled departure for Chad on an official visit aimed at bolstering bilateral ties with the African country.
Commenting on the latest diplomatic setback, Ma said it was an indication that the intelligence-gathering methods of relevant agencies need to be improved.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOHA ROUND WON'T BE REOPENED FOR AT LEAST 5 MONTHS: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization's (WTO) Doha Round negotiations, which collapsed in July, will not be suspended indefinitely but may take at least five or six months to reopen, a senior economic official said Sunday.

Chen Ruei-long, who has been appointed economic affairs minister, said the Doha Round setback deals a big blow to multilateral trade mechanism and Taiwan, which relies heavily on the export market for its economic development.
Chen has been involved in Taiwan's foreign trade negotiations. He said the GATT, the predecessor of the WTO, had contributed a great deal to global trade, from which Taiwan has also benefited.

If multilateralism suffers as a result of the Doha Round setback, it will affect the driving force of the trade and economic liberalization agenda -- a result that will not only hurt export-oriented Taiwan but other developing countries as well, he added.
Because of the severe consequences, Chen said he believes the talks will not be delayed indefinitely, though his most upbeat forecast is five to six months before talks will be reopened.

Even if talks resume, said Huang Chih-peng, director of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, it would be difficult to predict how much can be achieved from the Doha Round of negotiations, which were supposed to reach an agreement on the solution to the "triangular issue" -- lowering tariffs on farm products, cutting farm subsidies and decreasing tariffs on agricultural and fishery products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE BASEBALL PITCHER TO BE HONORED WITH COMMEMORATIVE T-SHIRT

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government plans to produce 10 commemorative T-shirts in honor of Taiwan-born pitcher Wang Chien-ming, famed for his outstanding performance in the U.S. Major League, according to a spokesman of the municipal Information Department.
The 10 T-shirts will be on permanent display at the Discovery Center of Taipei, the spokesman said.

Other people whose portraits might be used to make the commemorative T-shirts include Taipei Mayor Ma Yin g-jeou, Taiwan-born U.S.-based film director Ang Lee and writer Wang Wen-hua, the spokesman said, adding that the Information Department will make public the celebrity T-shirts in the near future.

According to a Taiwanese student studying in New York surnamed Fang, Wang not only has succeeded in gaining personal fame in the international sports arena, but he has greatly helped New Yorkers increase their understanding of Taiwan.
"Many New Yorkers might have not heard of Taiwan before, but the situation has changed since Wang came," Fang said.

Since last year, Wang's remarkable performance as a starting pitcher in the Yankees has helped the team improve its record, and the local media, including the New York Times, have made intensive reports about Wang's contribution to the baseball team.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER APOLOGIZES FOR FAILING TO SAVE CHAD TIES

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang expressed apologies to the people of Taiwan Sunday after the country severed its official ties with the central African country of Chad.

He told a press conference that his staff had launched a mechanism to save the official ties but yet still failed to retain diplomatic ties, for which he said he had already offered his apologies to President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang.
He denied some media reports the president had tried to rescue the ties by visiting Chad, noting that a presidential visit could not have been arranged in two or three days.
The president did try to speak to Chadian President Idriss Deby by telephone when bilateral ties went into high alert, Huang said, adding that the effort produced no results.

Huang disclosed that Chen last spoke with Deby July 27, when Deby had warmly welcomed a scheduled visit by Premier Su Tseng-chang to congratulate him over his inauguration. Su canceled his visit Sunday, on the day he was to leave.

Huang accused China of willfully humiliating not just Premier Su but also the people of Taiwan by poaching one of Taiwan's allies right before Taiwan's premier was to depart on a "congratulatory" visit to Chad.

As the Chinese Communists used to say, where there is suppression, there will be resistance, Huang said, claiming that China's suppression of Taiwan can prevail only for a time -- but never succeed forever.
"China will not be able to suppress the Taiwanese people's strong will to fight for freedom and democracy and to maintain their national sovereignty," he asserted.

Claiming the Chinese move will definitely have an adverse effect on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, he also called on all sectors of Taiwan's society to rise above partisan affiliation and act together to "forcefully resist China's suppression."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHIEF TO ATTEND JAPANESE EX-PRIME MINISTER'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun will attend the funeral of Japanese ex-Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto in Tokyo on Aug. 8 in lieu of the Secretary-General of the Presidential Office, Tan Sun Chen, a press release issued by the Presidential Office said Sunday.
The statement said Chen -- who had been invited by Japan's Liberty Democratic Party to the funeral -- is tied to business at home and will be unable to visit Tokyo that day.

Japan's Sankei Shimbun said Saturday that Chen -- who was named by Taiwanese authorities as its envoy to the funeral -- was rejected by Tokyo, which didn't want to see a Taiwanese representative with Chen's profile at the funeral of its ex-prime minister.

Although Taipei used to blame China for whatever diplomatic setbacks it suffered, an official at the Presidential Office denied that Chen was replaced by Yu because of Beijing's interference, citing Chen's tight schedule as the primary reason.

The Presidential Office's press release said Yu is no stranger to Taiwan-Japan ties, adding that he had served as head of a panel in charge of diplomacy toward Japan in 2000 during his term as President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, and helped launch the Taiwan-Japan forum which brings together scholars from Japan and Taiwan every year for discussion on bilateral issues.
Ryutaro, who served as Japan's prime minister between 1996 and 1998, died on July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC TO OPEN OFFICE IN CZECH REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) will establish a new liaison office in the Czech Republic by October in order to facilitate scientific cooperation with Eastern European countries, an NSC spokesman said Sunday.

The new office -- officially titled the "NSC Science and Technology Division in the Czech Republic" -- will function as a part of Taiwan's Representative Office there. The Czech division is the 16th of its kind in the world, and the NSC currently plans to create a 17th in South Korea.

Lin Kwang-lung, head of the NSC's Department of International Cooperation, said that until now there have been only four liaison offices in Europe -- the Britain, Belgium, France and Germany divisions -- and that the office in Germany has been tasked with contacting scientific institutions and organizations in Germany, Switzerland, Austria and all Eastern European countries.

The German office's workload is too heavy, Lin explained, so the NSC has mulled for some time to establish a new office in Eastern Europe, adding that the council finally decided to set up a new one in the Czech Republic to enhance ties with academia in the Czech Republic, Bulgaria, Slovakia, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and Ukraine.

Taiwan has already initiated dozens of collaborative projects with research groups in the region, such as an observation project on migratory fish and cooperation on improving blood testing for cancer, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS PROPOSE BANNING VISIT BY BEIJING OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers Sunday proposed banning a planned visit by a senior Beijing official to Taiwan, citing Chad's severing of diplomatic ties with Taiwan as clear proof of Beijing's scheme to squeeze Taiwan out of the international arena.

DPP lawmakers Trong Tsai, Chuang He-tsu and Hsueh Ling said in a statement that they will jointly put forward a proposal in the Legislative Yuan demanding the government temporarily cease all opening measures in cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges after Chad announced the severance of diplomatic links with Taiwan early Sunday morning.

According to the DPP lawmakers, the matter was a result of Beijing's relentless attempts to block Taiwan internationally. Beijing's plot has provoked fresh resentment among Taiwanese people against China, they claimed.

Tsai said in the statement that the government must not approve the application of Chen Yunlin -- the head of the Communist Party of China's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs -- to visit unless Beijing shows goodwill and respect for Taiwan and treats it as an independent sovereignty.

Taiwan and China must conduct exchanges on an equal footing, and senior Chinese officials' plans to visit must be approved by Taiwan's government through official channels, Tsai said in the statement, adding that opposition parties are not entitled to arrange visits for Beijing officials to Taiwan as a means of helping Beijing evade government-to-government negotiations over their visits.

China has increasingly intensified its "carrot-and-stick" strategy toward Taiwan, using every cultural, economic, agricultural, diplomatic and military means to suppress Taiwan, Tsai said, urging Taiwan's people to be wary of Beijing's ambitions to swallow up Taiwan, as evidenced in Beijing's enactment of an Anti-Secession Law in March last year.

According to the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Chen is slated to file an application with the Mainland Affair Council in mid-August to visit Taiwan in mid-October, where he will take part in a KMT-sponsored agricultural forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHOR CLAIMS EX-PRESIDENT OFFERED FINANCIAL AID TO DPP

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui, also former chairman of Kuomintang (KMT) , offered financial assistance to the financially strapped opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the 1990's, according to a new book titled "Ten Lessons Lee Teng-hui Teaches Young People."
The book's author, Tzou Ching-wen, has interviewed Lee many times before completing the book which was published recently.

According to the senior journalist's account, When Shih Ming-teh became DPP chairman in 1993, Lee asked the KMT's chief financier Liu Tai-ying to approach Shih, asking if he would be interested in a NT$150 million offer from Lee -- on no conditions at all, not even penning a receipt for accepting the money he could use at his discretion.
In response, Shih told Liu, "You've got the wrong guy (to take the money), " according to the book. Shih, who was DPP chairman from 1993 to 1996, confirmed the story during a recent TV interview.

His predecessor and successor, Hsu Hsin-liang (DPP chairman 1991-1993 and 1996-1998) was famous for an incident in which Taiwan's media described as "Hsu visited the enemy camp after dark" for a secret meeting with Lee Teng-hui.
During that meeting, Hsu suggested that if the ruling KMT could pass a law on providing financial assistance to political parties, it would help promote party politics in Taiwan.
In response, says the book, Lee said he would immediately told his staff to complete the legislation, because the KMT needed DPP help to amend the Constitution at the National Assembly.
The book further pointed out that in 1996, the DPP went into financial trouble again as it could not pay its office rent and worker salaries.
Again, Lee asked Liu Tai-ying to meet with Hsu, telling Hsu that the KMT could make a loan to the DPP and help it find a new place for use as office. The DPP declined that offer.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIPINO WORKER WINS FIRST PRIZE WITH POEM IN CONTEST IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The contract to work in Taiwan is like a puzzle which adds mystery to the life, Filipino homemaid Edcel Benosa said in a poem which earned her the first prize Sunday in a contest of poem and essay sponsored by the Taipei city government.

Donned in a tailor-made gown mailed to her by her mother in the Philippines, Edcel Benosa proudly received the prize and a certificate for Mayor Ma ying-jeou in a ceremony at a downtown park in the city.

In a brief introduction of the winner, the city government said Benosa, aged 27, has begun to work oversea to help her family ever since she graduated for the junior high school, and had financed her elder brother's education at college.
She was given by her local employer a seven-day's leave of absence last year to visit her young brother who fell sick seriously and returned only after her brother began to recover.
Benosa said her local employer gave her an extra pay of NT$10,000 to celebrate her winning of the fist prize in the poem and essay contest.
The second prize went to Dewi Rosa Ernawati, an caregiver from Indonesia. She wrote a letter, in the form of poem, to the old lady who was in Ernawati's charge in her last five months in the world.

Although the old lady had passed away, Ernawati said in her poem, "my heart is occupied by your voice and desperate eyes. The scenes of your last days in beds, with your arms bristled with needles, feeding tube and life-supporting systems lingering in my head."
The last paragraph of the poem which said " Goodbye forever my dear lady, I will prayer for you every night." is sure to touch a chord with any readers regardless of their nationalities.
Vietnamese homemaid Nguyen Thi Lien won the third prize with an article about her experience of accompanying her employer to watch a Taiwanese opera outdoors.
Ma who presented 18 winners with prizes thanked the 35,000 foreign labor working in Taipei, saying the city could be paralyzed, but for their contribution.
The mayor said the contest, the sixth of its kind, will be expanded next year to prizes for all kind of literature works created by foreign workers in the city.

New York Times: U.S. and France Back Plan to End Lebanon Fight
France and the United States reached agreement Saturday on a Security Council resolution to halt the war in Lebanon, as the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah raged for a 25th day. The text called for "immediate cessation of all attacks by Hezbollah, " and of "offensive military operations" by Israel. But it did not include a prisoner exchange or require Israel to immediately withdraw from Lebanon, which immediately raised dissent among members of the Security Council as they met Saturday afternoon to consider the text.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIPINO HOUSEMAID WINS 1ST PRIZE IN POEM AND ESSAY CONTEST IN TAIPEI(repeat)

TEXT.P: "A contract to work in Taiwan is like a puzzle which adds mystery to life, " Filipino housemaid Edcel Benosa said in a poem which won first prize Sunday at an essay and poem contest sponsored by the Taipei City government.

Donning a tailor-made gown mailed to her by her mother in the Philippines, Benosa proudly received the prize and a certificate from Mayor Ma Ying-jeou in the ceremony held at a downtown park in the city.

In a brief introduction of the winner, an emcee said Benosa, aged 27, has worked overseas to help her family ever since she graduated from junior high school and has financed her older brother's college education.
She was given by her local employer a seven-day leave of absence last year to visit her seriously ill younger brother and returned only after her brother began to recover.
Benosa said her local employer gave her an extra NT$10,000 in pay to celebrate her winning of the first prize in the poem and essay contest.
The second prize went to Dewi Rosa Ernawati, a caregiver from Indonesia. She wrote a letter, in the form of poem, to the old lady whom she had taken care of for the last five months of her life.
Vietnamese housemaid Nguyen Thi Lien won third prize with an essay about her experience of accompanying her employer to watch a Taiwanese opera outdoors.
Ma, who presented 18 winners with prizes, thanked the 35,000 foreign laborers working in Taipei, saying the city "would be paralyzed without their contribution."
The mayor said the contest, the sixth of its kind, will be expanded next year to include prizes for all kinds of works of literature created by foreign workers in the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 7, or the 14th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of the Dominion of Canada.
1903: Louis Leakey, British anthropologist, is born. He uncovered crucial evidence of man's early evolution, including a 1,750,000-year-old skull.
1904: Ralph Johnson Bunche, American diplomat, is born. He helped found the United Nations and won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the 1949 Arab-Israeli truce.
1912: Japan and Russia sign an agreement determining their spheres of influence in Manchuria and Mongolia.
1913: Samuel Cody, American aviator, becomes Britain's first air fatality when his plane crashes at Famborough.
1942: U.S. marines land on Guadalcanal in the Pacific during World War II.
1945: The Soviet Union declares war on Japan seven days before the Japanese surrender in World War II.
1948: The Yangtze River overflows its banks, forcing three million people into homelessness.
1952: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the designation of July 1, instead of January 1, as the beginning of the fiscal year.
1957: The ROC Navy sinks four Communist Chinese warships south of Kinmen.
1957: Oliver Hardy, the husky one in the Laurel and Hardy comic-duo who made more than 100 films from 1926 until 1950, dies of a stroke at the age of 65.
1959: The worst floods in more than 60 years hit central and southern Taiwan, killing 1,075 people, injuring 852, and causing more than NT$3.4 billion in property damage.
1974: Pingtung's Mei Ho Senior Little League baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to participate in the 1974 Little League World Series.
1974: Paul Hogberg, president of the International Handball Federation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Vice Foreign Minister H.K. Yang meets with President Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay.
1976: Kin Aziwa, newly-appointed deputy chief of the Japanese Interchange Association, Taipei Office, arrives to assume his post.
1983: Communist Chinese air force pilot Sun Tien-chin flies his MiG-21 jetfighter to South Korea to seek political asylum. He arrived in Taipei on Aug. 24.
1987: The leaders of Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Costa Rica sign a 14-page peace plan in Guatemala City aiming to settle a 10-year-old conflict in the region.
1990: President George Bush orders U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraq.
1992: Beijing signs an agreement with Washington promising to probe any allegations that goods produced by prison labor are being shipped to U.S. markets.
1998: Bombs explode almost at the same time outside the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing more than 80 people and injuring over one thousand others.
1999: The Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew ends a five-day visit to Macedonia after a meeting with his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng says the KMT is happy that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to hold a multiparty roundtable meeting to discuss major national issues with the heads of the opposition parties.
2001: The third cross-strait symposium about sports terms opens in Taipei, with sports representatives from Taiwan and mainland China sitting down to discuss the "unification" of various sports terms between the two sides.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: RAINY WEATHER FORECAST FOR WHOLE WEEK AS STORM SYSTEMS APPROACH: CWB

TEXT.P: Three tropical storm systems have been lurking in the western Pacific in recent days, with two of them poised to affect Taiwan later this week, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Monday.

Typhoon Saomai, the eighth typhoon reported in the Pacific area this year, was located about 760 km northwest of Guam, moving northwesterly toward Taiwan at a speed of 24 kph as of 10: 30 a.m. Monday, CWB meteorologists said.
Meanwhile, tropical storm Bopha was located about 420 kilometers south-southeast of Okinawa, moving in a west-northwest direction toward Taiwan at a speed of 13 kph, the meteorologists said.
The weather bureau said it may issue a sea warning Tuesday at the earliest for tropical storm Bopha if the system maintains its current speed and direction.
The forecasters urged those operating on seas near Okinawa or off Taiwan's east coast to be on alert for changes in weather conditions.
The weather bureau said it will have a better indication on Thursday or Friday as to whether Bopha and Saomi will effect Taiwan.
It is possible that the two storm systems may combine and double their force to produce what is known as the Fujiwara Effect, the meteorologists said.

Meanwhile, Typhoon Maria, the seventh typhoon in the Pacific area this year, is not expected to affect Taiwan as it was located some 640 kilometers south-southeast of Japan's Osaka and sweeping toward Osaka at a speed of 20 kph as of 10:30 a.m. Monday, according to the meteorologists.
The weather bureau added that Taiwan is expected to experience mostly cloudy and rainy weather through next Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER DUCKS QUESTIONS ABOUT SERVING ANOTHER TERM

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng ducked Monday the issue of whether he would accept opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's invitation to be a KMT legislator-at-large and continue to lead Taiwan's legislature.

Wang, formerly a KMT vice chairman whose third consecutive term as legislative speaker will end in 2007, would not confirm news reports that Ma had met with him July 20 to invite him to be the first candidate in a KMT legislator-at-large lineup for the 7th legislature, which is scheduled to be elected December 2007 and sworn in February 2008.
Wang said he has a wide variety of plans for his life after February 2008, adding that running for another legislative seat is only one of the options.

The next legislative elections will be held in December 2007, unless the opposition topples the Cabinet in a no-confidence vote and President Chen Shui-bian dissolves the legislature before that time.

Following the failure of a presidential recall motion June 27 at the Legislative Yuan, the opposition People First Party (PFP) has been actively pushing for the initiation of a no-confidence proposal, which would require the endorsement of at least one-third of the 221 lawmakers and a "yes" vote by half of the lawmakers,

The KMT, an ally of the PFP, has not been as enthusiastic as the PFP about initiating a no-confidence motion, saying that adequate accompanying measures should first be worked out and that related conditions must be ripe.

According to the law, should a no-confidence vote pass the Legislative Yuan, the premier would have to either resign in 10 days or ask the president to dissolve the Legislative Yuan, paving the way for new legislative elections. If the no-confidence vote failed to clear the legislature, lawmakers would not be able to initiate another no-confidence vote against the same premier within one year of the previous one.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT POLICY REMAINS UNCHANGED: CABINET

TEXT.P: A Cabinet official dismissed as "mere speculation" a media report suggesting that the government will tighten up its cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade policy in the wake of the severance of ROC-Chad diplomatic relations owing to China's sabotage.

Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said the government's cross-strait policy is aimed at protecting the country's interests and sovereignty and maintaining cross-strait peace and stability, adding that these objectives remain unchanged.
Cheng denied there is any disagreement between President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang on cross-strait policy.
Cheng noted that Beijing has used every possible means to suppress Taiwan and isolate Taiwan diplomatically, which he said has been clearly demonstrated in the cases of Chad and Haiti.

Early Sunday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced that Su had canceled his plan to visit Chad and that the government had decided to cut off diplomatic ties with Chad, after learning that the African nation was ready to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing.

Earlier this year, Chen's plan to appoint Su as his special envoy to attend the inauguration of Haitian President-elect Rene Preval was also obstructed because China had pressured the Caribbean nation through U.N. channels not to invite Su for the event.
Cheng stressed that the Chad case is not an isolated incident but is the result of China's diplomatic containment policy against Taiwan.

As to whether the severance of diplomatic ties with Chad will affect Taiwan's oil supply, Cheng said the state-owned China Petroleum Corp. has been looking for suitable cooperation partners around the world and has not targeted any single region or country.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES PRESIDENT TO TAKE LEGAL ACTION AGAINST OPPOSITION SMEAR

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged President Chen Shui-bian Monday to take legal action against what it called a smear by an opposition lawmaker regarding what the lawmaker claimed is a secret bank account of Chen.
DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang issued the call during a news conference at the party's headquarters.

Tsai advised Chen to seek legal means to clear his name and blasted main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Chiu Yi's accusation. "The president must take legal action to stop such foulness," he said.

Chiu, who has blown the whistle on several high-profile corruption scandals allegedly related to the first family and Chen himself, claimed Saturday that Chen has a secret account containing NT$170 million at the Nanmen branch of the Tsaishin Bank.

According to Tsai, the bank account was set up by Chen Jan. 5, 2004 to receive political donations from the public prior to the March 20 presidential election that same year. The bank account was closed April 1, 2004, with only over NT$1.7 million left, he claimed.
Denying that the bank account was secret, Tsai said that it was scrutinized by the financial committee of the DPP's election campaign headquarters at that time.
Tsai also called on Chen to make public the relevant details as soon as possible to put an end to what he called Chiu's "unscrupulous" accusation.

In response to Chiu's accusation that Chen failed to report the bank account to the Control Yuan, either in line with the Political Donations Law or the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, he pointed out that the Political Donations Law was promulgated March 30
2004 -- later than the account's opening, while assets reporting required at the end of each year.
Tsai blasted Chiu for nitpicking over the fact that Chen did not have to report the bank account to the Control Yuan.

As to a claim by Chiu that Chen's Formosa Foundation also owns a secret bank account, Tsai said that the account has existed for more than 10 years, adding that Chiu should immediately stop smearing the president and the DPP government.

DOC.HEADLINE: OSTEOPOROSIS PATIENTS URGED TO BE CAREFUL USING MASSAGE CHAIRS

TEXT.P: A doctor of Chinese medicine said Monday that high blood pressure and osteoporosis patients should exercise caution when they use massage chairs.

Tien An-jan made the remarks at a news conference sponsored by the Consumers' Foundation to warn anyone thinking of buying massage chairs as presents on Father's Day, which falls on Tuesday this year.

Tien said that massage chairs work well for those who suffer from sprains or tense muscles, but said that for people suffering from high blood pressure, overuse could lead to strokes, while people with osteoporosis risked bone fractures.
Tien advised users to consult their doctors before using the chairs and suggested that massage sessions should not exceed 15-30 minutes one or twice per week.

Jason Lee, chairman of the Consumers' Foundation, said a lot of massage chair manufacturers claim that their products can detect acupuncture points on the body, but he said their claims have not been substantiated by medical theory or clinical tests.
He also said the chairs are often based on "foreigner sizes" and do not necessarily fit the ergonomics of Taiwan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HAS `MINIMIZED DAMAGE' FROM CUTTING OF TAIWAN-CHAD TIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang will take responsibility for the severance of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Chad if necessary, although he believes the ministry has managed to minimize the damage from the incident, a ministry official said Monday.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) had announced a day earlier that Premier Su Tseng-chang had canceled a plan to visit Chad and that the government had decided to cut off diplomatic ties with Chad, after learning that the African nation was ready to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing.

According to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu, Chad intended to inform Taiwan of its decision in a letter dated Aug. 6 -- the same day that Su was scheduled to depart for Chad to attend the second inauguration of Chadian President Idriss Deby.
"We have sufficient reason to believe that China was out to embarrass Taiwan. Our announcement to sever diplomatic ties with Chad early Aug. 6 has thwarted China's plan," Lu said.
Lu said there were several reasons leading to the severance of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Chad.

While China has put a lot pressure on the Chadian government by providing support to rebel forces in Chad, it has also on the other hand been trying to tempt Chad with offers to procure oil from the African nation, which was dissatisfied with the financial aid provided by Taiwan, Lu said.
However, Lu said the ministry will need to conduct further investigations to find out how much financial aid China has offered Chad.
Pointing out that it was impossible for Taiwan to satisfy every request made by Chad, Lu said Su had originally planned to discuss Chad's request for increased aid during his trip.

As to whether the incident will affect President Chen Shui-bian's plan to visit Africa later this year, Lu said the president's overseas visit is a routine matter and that the details of the visit will be make public as soon as the planning is completed.
Lu said the 22 Taiwan personnel who are still in Chad will withdraw in separate groups.
The families of the members of technical and medical missions will withdraw first, followed by the members of the missions and designated workers, Lu said.
The Republic of China ambassador to Chad will return to Taiwan after confirming the principle of withdrawal, he added.
Lu said the MOFA is closely monitoring the situation in each of the country's diplomatic allies, as Beijing is harboring an obvious intent to woo away all of Taiwan's allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 26 points to close at 6,416.61.
The bourse opened at 6,425.99 and fluctuated between 6,450.06 and 6,405.09 during trading. A total of 2.21 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$56.12 billion (US$1.71 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 2.1 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.4 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent, textile stocks at 0.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 741 to 260, with 122 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN FATHERS DO NOT CONSIDER THEMSELVES GOOD FATHERS: POLL

TEXT.P: Whether they are self-effacing or simply lack self-confidence, most of Taiwan's fathers do not consider themselves "good fathers, " according to the results of a recent public opinion poll released Monday.

Taiwan fathers aged between 16 and 45 gave themselves scores averaging only 65.49 points (using 100 points as "perfect") in terms of determining what makes a "good father, " with fathers in the 36-45 age group being the lowest scorers, with an only passable average of 63.59 points, according to the poll conducted by the online 1111 Job Bank.
The figure could also reflect that fathers in the 36-45 age group have the highest ability to conduct self-examination among fathers of all three age groups, the pollsters said.

Fathers aged between 26 and 35 gave themselves an average score of 67.06 points, while young fathers aged between 16 and 25 gave themselves an average score of 71.79 points, according to the poll conducted to mark Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8.

Meanwhile, according to an estimate compiled by the Ministry of the Interior, educating a child from birth to graduation from graduate school costs between NT$4.5 million and NT$6.4 million in Taiwan.

The poll found that 75 percent of the fathers who responded to the poll said their incomes were always behind the household costs, including education costs, and 55 percent of the respondents blamed inflation as the major culprit causing their financial difficulties.
The poll also found that most of the fathers do not regret having children, but some 44 percent said they would choose to have smaller families if they were allowed to do it again.
The respondents named Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, Kuo Tai-ming, a high-technology industrial tycoon, and actor-turned-Taipei City Councilor Ouyang Lung as the top three "model" fathers.
The 1111 Job bank received 510 valid responses to the poll, which was conducted via Internet between July 19 and Aug. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA PROMOTES CENTRALIZED BURNING OF GHOST MONEY

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) urged the public Monday to take advantage of the centralized ghost money burning service during Ghost Festival to reduce air pollution.

EPA officials noted that environmental protection authorities in various counties and cities are offering the service during specific festivals including Ghost Festival and that the amount of ghost money burnt in this manner has increased from 260 tonnes to 1,800 tonnes over the past three years.
According to the Air Pollution Prevention and Control Act, those who cause air pollution by burning ghost money outdoors can be fined up to NT$1 million, they said.
A recent survey conducted by the Consumers' Foundation shows that ghost money and incense release hazardous substances such as benzene, methyl benzene and ethyl benzene upon burning.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC FULLY ASSESSING BEIJING OFFICIAL'S VISIT: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will carefully assess the question of whether to allow a senior Beijing official to visit Taiwan, taking into account the political situations both at home and abroad, Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said Monday.

According to Cheng, the MAC will thoroughly assess the possibility of Chen's visit to Taiwan at a time when Taiwan has just suffered a diplomatic setback due to its severing of diplomatic ties with Chad shortly before the Central African state set up diplomatic relations with Beijing.

China's continuous attempts to suppress Taiwan in the international community will seriously affect the nation's development, and the Taiwan people should loudly denounce China's hostility, Cheng said.

According to the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Chen is slated to file an application with the MAC in mid-August seeking permission to take part in a KMT-sponsored agricultural seminar planned for mid-October in Taiwan.

The purpose of Chen's visit is to find ways to step up bilateral agricultural exchanges and help Taiwan farmers improve their livelihoods, KMT legislative caucus whip Tsai Chin-lung claimed at a news conference.
The government's attempts to politicize Chen's visit is a reflection of its ignorance of the importance of cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic interactions, according to Tsai.

KMT Legislator Hsu Shao-ping contended that "banning Chen from coming to Taiwan will not help Taiwan explore new diplomatic horizons, but rather will intensify the political wrangling between the two sides."
"Sure, we have to denounce China's ambitions against Taiwan, but it is inappropriate to slam the door on Chen," Hsu claimed.

David Huang, a legislative caucus whip of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , said TSU lawmakers will join an endorsement campaign initiated by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers demanding that the government ban Chen from visiting.
"Chen is planning to engage in united front activities here and to provoke confrontation in Taiwan, in cooperation with the KMT and the People First Party," Huang speculated.

DPP lawmaker Trong Chai said a day earlier that he and other DPP lawmakers will put forward a proposal at the Legislative Yuan demanding that the government ban Chen's visit and temporarily cease all opening measures in cross-strait activities after Chad's decision to recognize China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC MINISTER TENDERS RESIGNATION OVER ETC MESS

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Kuo Yao-chi tendered her resignation to Premier Su Tseng-chang Monday to assume responsibility for a controversy surrounding a freeway electronic toll collection (ETC) system.
Noting that it is a matter of course for a political appointee to take responsibility for a major policy flop, Kuo said she will begin a leave of absence Tuesday.

Kuo's resignation came after the Supreme Administrative Court ruled last Thursday that the "priority bidder" status of the Far Eastern Electronic Toll Corp. (FETC), which has been running the ETC system on the nation's freeways since February, should be revoked because it was a flawed screening process that enabled the FETC to obtain priority status over two other bidders.
The ruling put the ETC bidding back to square one, despite the fact that around 220,000 on-board units (OBUs) have been installed in cars using the FETC system since February.
The opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party had demanded that Kuo step down to take administrative responsibility for the mess.

Nevertheless, Su said Saturday that although Kuo is in charge of dealing with the shambles surrounding the ETC controversy, she should not be held responsible for the chaos as the controversy began long before Kuo took the MOTC post early this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AID TO CHAD SHOULD BE USED TO FEED TAIWAN'S SCHOOL CHILDREN: KMT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should use the NT$1.4 billion formerly spent on aid to Chad plus the NT$170 million in his so-called "questionable" Taishin International Bank account for a free-lunch program for more than 3 million school children, the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) legislative caucus said Monday.

Hou Tsai-feng, deputy secretary-general of the caucus, said the aid to Chad could feed 2.7 million school children and claimed that the president's "secret" bank account had unreported political donations enough to pay for lunches for 327,000 school children.
"We urge the president to use those funds to save the people of Taiwan who are living without hope, " she said.
Tsai Chin-lung, the caucus secretary- general, accused Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang of having done a poor job with regard to official ties with Chad.

"The minister visited Chad just last month, unaware that it was ready to recognize Beijing diplomatically. He even handed over a big stash of cash to Chad's president and arranged for Premier Su Tseng-chang to visit for the president's inauguration, " according to Tsai.
Now that Taiwan has severed ties with Chad, Huang can only shift all of the responsibility to China, Tsai said, claiming that the minister is "evidently not fit for his job."
