DOC.HEADLINE: SEA WARNING FOR TROPICAL STORM BOPHA MIGHT BE ISSUED: CWB

TEXT.P: A sea warning for tropical storm Bopha might be issued later Monday if the storm maintained its current speed and direction, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said that day.
Forecasters said Bopha was centered 420 km south-southeast of Okinawa at 8 a.m., moving in a northwesterly direction toward Taiwan at 13 kph.
Meanwhile, typhoon Saomai was located southeast of Bopha, and the CWB is monitoring to see if the two systems will interact with each other as they come closer to each other, forecasters said.
They said that if such a phenomenon happens, the impact brought about by Bopha on Taiwan will be reduced, although the intensity of the storm will remain the same.
Meanwhile, they said typhoon Maria was heading toward Japan and not expected to affect Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES DENY REPORTS ON TOPPLING CABINET

TEXT.P: Two opposition parties denied Monday that they will collaborate in proposing a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet, while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that if the opposition makes the proposal, the DPP will demand that the president dissolve the legislature.

The People First Party (PFP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) dismissed the reports by the mass-circulation China Times that claimed they would propose the no-confidence vote when the new legislative session opens next month.

The reports also said that if the Cabinet is toppled, President Chen Shui-bian will not dissolve the legislature out of concerns for political stability. The election of the next legislature will have to follow the new electoral "single-member constituency, two votes" system, and the number of legislative seats will be cut in half to 113.
Chang Hsien-yao, director of PFP's department in charge of policy research, said the party's focus is to push for an impeachment of the president.
According to Chang, Chen must take political responsibility for what the opposition claims is his "illicit use" of a state affairs fund for his discretionary use.

Chang noted that the PFP advocated a no-confidence vote on the Cabinet one-and-a-half months ago, believing that Premier Su Tseng-chang has endorsed a corrupt president and that his administration should no longer enjoy legitimacy, but Chang noted that the PFP's focus now is impeachment of the president.
He said the PFP still has the option of toppling the Cabinet when the new legislative session begins but has not contacted the TSU over the matter.
David Huang, a TSU caucus whip in the legislature, also said the caucus has not received any information on toppling the Cabinet, and dismissed the media reports as speculation.
Huang said the TSU is opposed to Su's earlier advocacy of more open cross-Taiwan Strait relations, while the PFP is supportive of more opening.
For this reason, it is imposible for the TSU to work with the PFP on proposing a no-confidence vote, he added.
Yeh Yi-jin, a DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said that if the Cabinet is toppled, she will suggest that Chen dissolve the legislature and hold another election.
But she also urged the opposition parties to stop political infighting and preserve the nation's stability.

According to the Constitution, one-third of the legislators are needed to make a valid no-confidence proposal, and the premier will have to resign within 10 days should the proposal be approved by half of the legislators.
The president could name another premier or dissolve the legislature, whose new members would have to be elected in 60 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL BASEBALL RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT CENTER ESTABLISHED

TEXT.P: A National Baseball Research and Development Center was formally established in Taipei Monday to boost the development of baseball -- Taiwan's national sport.

The center, located at the Tienmu Stadium, is expected to become a cradle for top baseball talent such as Chien-ming Wang, who made a name for himself recently by mastering the heat and the Devil Rays in a 6-0 shutout and scoring 13-4 so far this season as a New York Yankees starting pitcher.

The center, which has a world-class baseball equipment technology laboratory endorsed by the International Baseball Federation (IBF) , was established after seven years of preparation, according to Chang Ming-feng, vice president of the Taipei Physical Education College, which is one of the co-sponsors of the center.

IBF Executive Director Miguel Ortin visited Taipei twice over the past seven years to oversee the building of the baseball equipment technology lab, which is the only such lab to be endorsed by the IBF, Chang said.

A ceremony marking the establishment of the center was held at the Tienmu Stadium, with Ortin, Chang, Chen Chuan-show, minister of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, and Peng Cheng-hao, chairman of the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association ROC Amateur Baseball, jointly presiding.
The center has departments of operations for administration and management, international affairs and competitions, sports sciences, and baseball equipment technology and testing, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEAROOM CATERING FOR MEN OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A tearoom for men to air their grievances was opened Sunday in Taipei by a private group on behalf of the Department of Social Welfare under the Taipei city government.

The Taipei Kuanyin Counseling Hotline Association, which was asked by the city government to run the tearoom, invited single fathers, men in midlife crisis, unemployed middle aged men and men with grievances against life to share their frustrations and desperation with each other at the tearoom.

Lee Yi-wei, president of the association, said the stereotype of men is that they are supposed to be tough enough to bear the frustration in daily life and should not reveal their feelings, as this is considered a sign of weakness.
As a result, Lee claimed, men are more fragile than women psychologically and often resort to alcohol or gambling for stress relief.

Hsu Chung-kuang, the manager of the tearoom and a psychologist with 23 years of experience in counselling, said the tearoom is designed to be a place for men to bare their souls and console each other.

Hsu said the tearoom will organize lectures every Tuesday on the male role, father-child relations, midlife crisis, feeding infants and raising children, and other issues of concern to men to help them understand themselves and others.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: U.S. Punishes Arms Trader, Sukhoi
The United States has slapped sanctions on state arms trader Rosoboronexport and jetmaker Sukhoi, accusing them of helping Iran acquire weapons of mass destruction. ( By Chang Hung-kuang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORT MINISTER QUITS OVER POLICY DIFFERENCES

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Kuo Yao-chi tendered her resignation Monday, citing "policy differences" with the premier and other superiors.
She was sworn in as a minister on the day Premier Su Tseng-chang launched his new Cabinet Jan. 25.
Vice Transport Minister Tsai Tui also tendered his resignation after learning of Kuo's surprise move.
In her resignation letter, Kuo thanked President Chen Shui-bian and Su for promoting her to a key post.

During her time in office, she said, two major construction projects have gone well -- the 12.9-km Hsuehshan Tunnel, which opened to motorists in June, and the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp., which is expected to launch services in late October.

Although she has worked "day and night" to promote major transportation and communications projects and has faced criticism for some policy flaws, "a political appointee must know when to quit if his policy ideas are not in agreement with those of his superiors, " she added.
Kuo did not elaborate on what policy differences she has had with her superiors.
When reporters asked if she was fatigued by the political row over the highway electronic toll collection system, she asked: "Do I look fatigued?"

The ETC project, which had already become a scandal when she took over as transport minister from Lin Ling-san, was ruled by the Supreme Administrative Court last week as illegal because the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) did not follow the principles of equality and public interest in awarding the project to Far Eastern Electronic Toll Co. (FETC).
The FETC, which was stripped of its "priority applicant" status in winning the contract as a result of the ruling, has been running the shambolic system for several months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down 16 points to close at 6,350, with 31,285 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September decreased 18 points to finish at 6,340, with 517 contracts traded, while December futures decreased 40 points to end at 6,337, with five contract transactions.
March futures moved down 44 points to close at 6,335, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,366 for August, 6,358 for September, 6,377 for December, 6,379 for March and 6,382 for June.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower. August TE futures moved down 0.2 points to close at 268.55, with 3,463 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 0.55 points to finish at 268.55, with 74 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

August TF futures lost 5.6 points to close at 909, with 1,079 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 4.6 points to finish at 911, with eight contracts traded. December TF futures decreased four points to end at 910, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, decreasing NT$0.066 to close at NT$32.803.
A total of US$549 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.869 and fluctuated betwen NT$32.769 and NT$32.890.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEVELOPS NON-DESTRUCTIVE FRUIT QUALITY INSPECTION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Scientists in Taiwan have developed their own version of an on-line system for non-destructive inspection of fruit quality, which runs faster than similar foreign-made facilities but costs only one-third as much.

Using infrared and photometric imaging devices, the automatic evaluation and sorting system can detect the sugar content and acidity of fruit on an assembly line, as well as other data such as weight, color and internal defects.

Officials at the Agricultural and Food Agency under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said that accurate information provided by the equipment about fruit quality can help make fruit grading more precise, thus giving Taiwan fruit a more competitive edge on the international market.
The officials said the system was developed by a group of Taiwanese scientists with the help of a grant from the COA.
The scientists were from National Taiwan University, National Chung Hsing University, National Ping Tung University of Science and Technology and National Yilan University.
The system can process an average of 75 pieces of fruit per minute, with an accuracy of over 90 percent.
Compared with similar equipment made in other countries, the fruit quality inspection system's unit price of NT$6 million is two-thirds cheaper, but the system can operate more than twice as fast.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ TO STEM LOOPHOLES ON DRUG-SMUGGLING LAWYERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Monday that it will make a review in the wake of reports that a lawyer sneaked drugs to an inmate at the Taipei detention center earlier this year.
Cheng An-hsiung, head of the ministry's department of correctional affairs, said the ministry has sent officials to the detention center to learn more about the situation.
He noted that prisons and detention centers generally trust lawyers not to violate the law by bringing in drugs or controlled substances to the cells.
Currently, detention centers and prisons only record and videotape meetings between lawyers and inmates being held incommunicado, Cheng said.
For inmates not being held under such circumstances, there is no recording or videotaping, and the prison guards have to follow the principle of "seeing, but not hearing anything," he added.

On whether such meetings will be recorded in the future, Cheng said the ministry will have to make an overall consideration in terms of the facilities and personnel increase of the detention centers and prisons, the views of the Bar Association, and whether such an approach is legitimate.
At present, the ministry will focus on reviewing the current work force and the system, and will implement rigorous body searches after inmates meet with their lawyers.

Peng Huan-ming, an inmate of the Taipei detention center, died unexpectedly in January and investigators found evidence of drugs in his system. Prosecutors later found that lawyer Peng Yung-chang, while meeting with his client who was Peng's cellmate, had sneaked in drugs several times.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS IN JULY SET SINGLE-MONTH RECORD

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced Monday that July exports totaled US$19.58 billion, a record single-month high.
MOF officials said July exports represent an increase of 21.2 percent from the same month of last year, while July imports totaled US$17.78 billion, up 17.5 percent year on year.

The officials said that exports and imports in July were brilliant, mainly because exports to Hong Kong, China, the United States, six Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries and South Korea increased by more than 18 percent, while imports from Hong Kong, China, the United States, six ASEAN countries, the Middle East and Africa increased by 13 percent.
They noted that export orders in June also recorded the second-highest level, showing that the momentum of exports has been strong.

The officials noted that because crude oil imports averaged US$65.09 a barrel in July, resulting in rising oil cost and slower economic growth in the United States, exports in the latter part of the year will be affected.

Taiwan still has a chance of reaching the goal of exporting more than US$20 billion-worth of goods in a single month in the latter part of the year and of maintaining double-digit export growth, although the increase is not expected to be higher than 21.2 percent in July, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER'S PANAMA VISIT IN THE WORKS: MOFA

TEXT.P: A visit to Panama planned for Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang is a routine trip for which a detailed schedule is still being worked out, a senior official said Monday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu was responding to media reports that Huang will travel to Panama next week to preside over a regional working meeting of Taiwan's diplomatic mission chiefs in Latin America and the Caribbean.

Following the breakdown of Taiwan-Chad diplomatic ties last weekend, diplomatic work in Latin America and the Caribbean has become even more important, as half of Taiwan's diplomatic allies are located in the region.

Media reports had speculated that Huang's trip to Panama at this moment might be aimed at shoring up diplomatic ties with the country as China has never ceased its attempts to sway Panama's diplomatic support for Taiwan.

Lu said he would not make any comments on speculative media reports. He instead stressed that Huang's planned Latin America trip is a routine and that his travel schedule will be announced when details are fleshed out.
Meanwhile, Lu confirmed that Honduran President Manuel Zelaya has again postponed his planned visit to Taiwan indefinitely because of his busy schedule.

Zelaya was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan in mid-July, but he postponed his trip to Aug. 9. He then informed Taiwan's embassy in Honduras last week that he had to postpone his visit again because of a teachers strike.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEMALE TEENS ACCOUNT FOR 40.8% OF MISSING YOUTHS IN TAIWAN: REPORT

TEXT.P: Of all the missing children and juveniles in Taiwan, more than 40 percent are females aged between 12 and 18, which is considerably higher than the ratio among males and a cause for concern, a child welfare organization said in a report released Monday.

According to the "Status Report on Missing Kids and Juveniles in Taiwan" released on the eve of Fathers' Day, there were 509 females aged between 12 to 18 among 1,246 missing children and juveniles reported to the Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) during the last 14 years, said CWLF Executive Director Wang Yu-min.

Females also dominate most of the runaway juveniles that left home to meet Internet friends, totaling 89 cases. These cases account for 7.1 percent of all cases and have increased dramatically in recent years, Wang said.

An encouraging fact is that 872 of the 1,246 missing children -- a little over 70 percent -- were found after an average of 154 days. However, less than 50 percent of missing children under 6 years of age were found.

The months that registered the most missing cases are March and September. "The fact reminds every parents that they should pay more attention to children during the winter and summer breaks, " said Wang.
However, the report appears to be woefully inaccurate, as National Police Agency records show that the number of missing children already exceeds 3,000.

A documentary recording the life stories of two families that have not found their missing children after more than 13 years but who have never give up searching, premiered at the press conference in the hope of boosting public support in the search for missing children.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Violence Rocket Barrage Kills 15 Israelis Close to Border
The deadliest barrage of Hezbollah rocket attacks in nearly a month of fighting hit northern Israel on Sunday, killing 12 army reservists resting near the Lebanon border and 3 civilians in a dusk attack in the port of Haifa.
Wall Street Journal: End Game, After Court Ruling, Calderon Is Closer To Leading Mexico
Conservative Felipe Calderon is on the verge of winning the Mexican presidency, one month after his narrow victory at the ballot box set off a round of street blockades, demonstrations and legal challenges. The 43-year-old lawyer still must surmount several more challenges, but Los Pinos, Mexico' s White House, seems within his grasp after an electoral tribunal on Saturday turned down his opponent's request for a national recount. Instead, the court ordered a review of just 9 percent of the 42 million votes cast.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARENTS STILL HOPE TO FIND MISSING CHILD AFTER 35 YEARS

TEXT.P: Tsai Kuang-shen and Ho Li-lan still believe that one day they will see their missing son again, although their last glimpse of the baby boy was almost 35 years ago.

Tsai Ming-chih, who was only 2 years old when he was taken from his parents in 1972, is one of more than 3,000 missing children in Taiwan, according to National Police Agency (NPA) records. Although NPA records show one case in which a family succeeded in finding a missing child after 13 years, the Tsais have never found their beloved son.
Still, Tsai Kuang-shen has managed to keep the faith and was optmistic about finding his son at a press conference in Taipei Monday.

"I imagine that somewhere, Ming-chih -- 36 years old by now -- has a family and a successful career. I used to hope we would have him back for a family reunion. Not anymore. The only thing I need right now is to know where he is and how he's doing," said Tsai.
According to witnesses, Tsai Ming-chih was taken away in front of his grandmother's house in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, by a woman dressed in red on the afternoon of October 3, 1972.
The Tsais would never see him again. And they were unable to identify the woman, even with the assistance of police and child welfare organizations over the next 35 years.

Thousands of sleepless nights and tears did not impede their search for Ming-chih, as numerous bits of information -- notes on tips, photographs and news clippings -- piled up in the Tsais' living room.

"You don't often find such a determined family like the Tsais. A lot of parents give up [searching for their children] after a number of years," said Wang Yu-min, executive director of Child Welfare League Foundation, an organization founded 14 years ago to help parents like the Tsais find their children again.
"After all these years, I believe it's easier if he [Tsai Ming-chih] comes to us instead of going out to find him," Tsai said, adding that media outlets would be of great help by spreading the news.
"Sometimes all parents need is a definite answer -- no matter what that answer may be. The last thing they need is a question mark in their minds," Wang said.
"If we can eventually find Ming-chih again, it will be another inspiring Taiwan Miracle," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN TO CHECK 'SECRET ACCOUNT' ALLEGATION WITH TAISHIN BANK

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan said Monday it will ask the Ministry of Finance to provide data concerning an alleged "secret bank account" of President Chen Shui-bian, and that it would ask Taishin International Bank to confirm whether such an account exists.

The Control Yuan made the statement in response to media reports the president may have violated laws governing public functionaries' private assets and political donations by failing to report his alleged Taishin Bank account to the Yuan.
If it turns out that such a bank account exists and the account holder has failed to abide by relevant laws, the Control Yuan said it would "take further steps" as necessary.

The Presidential Office has not yet provided what it called "further explanation" about the alleged account, which opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiu Yi claimed was used to launder slush funds.
Lee Nan-yang, director of the office's department of public affairs, has said the alleged account was actually an open account set up during the 2004 presidential elections.

Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general to the president, referred the press to Lee's "initial explanation" about Chiu's allegation, adding that if there is need for further understanding on the issue, the Presidential Office will provide further explanation to the people.
Tsai Huang-lang, spokesman for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, claimed that Chiu was using the "open fund-raising account" to smear the president.
Urging the president to sue Chiu for defamation, Tsai also called on the Presidential Office to immediately publish all details of the account as a means to stop Chiu's "allegation politics."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEITOU CABLE CAR PROJECT WILL GO AHEAD: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that a controversy over land development in the city's Beitou District would not affect the city government's determination to push ahead with a "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) project to build a cable-car system.
Ma made the remarks at a meeting of the city's tourism committee, whose members said they were concerned the building of the cable-car system could be delayed because of the recent controversy.
Some members said they were worried about Beitou District's tourism industry because fewer people have visited the area after Hsuehshan Tunnel opened to motorists in June.

Ma told them that suspected irregularities had occurred when land developers tried to bribe Ministry of the Interior officials, and that a controversy erupted over whether an "environmental review" should have been conducted on two of the area's housing development projects.
"Both the suspected crime and the environmental review controversy will not affect the city government's plan to build the cable-car system," he added.
According to Ma, the decision to build the cable-car system was made while Chen Shui-bian was mayor in 1998.

In 2001, when Ma was mayor, Ma said the city government sent a copy of its "environmental impact assessment report" to the Yangmingshan National Park Administration even though the Environmental Protection Administration did not require such a report for projects covering less than 10 hectares of land.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN TO ASK FIRST LADY TO PROVIDE INFO ON JEWELRY LENDERS

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan will send a letter to the Presidential Office asking for names of individuals who President Chen Shui-bian and first lady Wu Shu-jen claimed have lent pieces of jewelry to the first lady, a Control Yuan official said Monday.

Hsieh Yu-nan, director of the department in charge of asset reporting by high-ranking officials, indicated that the Control Yuan has received a supplementary explanatory note from the Presidential Office saying that some jewelry worn by the first lady was borrowed from relatives and friends, and that the Presidential Office cannot disclose their identities out of personal privacy considerations.

Under Taiwan's Law of Asset Disclosure by Public Functionaries, all high-ranking officials are obliged to provide an annual report of their assets to the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body.

According to a mid-July report on the first lady's jewelry -- the first such report by the first couple in six years -- the first lady owns 15 pieces of jewelry and luxury watches valued at NT$3.725 million (US$113,560).
However, opposition legislators produced photos of the first lady wearing expensive jewelry on various occasions and claimed that she owns at least 31 pieces of jewelry worth NT$50 million.

Hsieh said the Control Yuan will send another letter to the Presidential Office, asking for names of those who have lent jewelry to the first lady in order to verify the first couple's asset report, and that the Presidential Office should respond within 15 days.

According to law, any jewelry -- including watches -- worth over NT$200,000 (US$6,100) must be reported to the Control Yuan. A high-ranking official may face repeated fines of between NT$20,000 and NT$100,000 until satisfactory reporting has been submitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL RESIDENTS PROTEST AGAINST MERCURY-LACED SLUDGE

TEXT.P: Residents of three townships near a Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) plant in Kaohsiung county, southern Taiwan staged a protest Monday against a local plant's decision to transport and deal with mercury-laced sludge that was improperly dumped in a neighboring county.

More than 50 residents of Chunghua, Wuho and Chuho townships in Jenwu village gathered in front of FPG's factory, displaying large white banners decrying the planned return of toxic industrial waste the plant had stored in Wantan township, Pingtung county.

According to organizers of the rally, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) under the Executive Yuan has notified FPG's Jenwu plant to prepare to process the mercury-tainted sludge, as it is slated to be transported back to the plant Aug. 9.

Protesters accused the Jenwu plant of trying to hide the truth and demanded that plant authorities call a coordination meeting to forge a consensus with local residents. They also warned they would resort to more violent means of resistance if the plant fails to reach a consensus with them on the issue -- first, before the toxic waste is delivered.
Local residents continued protesting about thirty minutes after law enforcement officers asked them to leave for not having obtained advance permission from police to demonstrate.
Lin Chen-jung, manager of FPG's Jenwu plant, received a petition from the protesters and pointed out the whole matter was being directed and arranged by the EPA.
Claiming the Jenwu plant is only responsible for disposing of the mercury-tainted sludge, Lin expressed hope the EPA would first talk with local residents to settle the issue.

A large amount of mercury-laced sludge was created by PFG's Jenwu plant, but illegally dumped by a waste disposal company and later uncovered by EPA inspectors in Wantan township, Pingtung county in 1996. Some 8,300 metric tons out of a total 34,000 metric tons of toxic sludge were found to contain high levels of mercury.
Through an out-of-court settlement, FPG's Jenwu plant agreed to process the mercury-tainted sludge using an EPA subsidy of NT$90 million.

But residents living in Kaohsiung's Jenwu township rejected the EPA's proposal in July this year to allow the industrial waste dumped in Pingtung's Wantan township to be transported back to the Jenwu plant for processing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS WITH HEAD OF PANAMANIAN SUPREME COURT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that judicial independence, modernization and transparency are critical to a country's democratic development.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Graciela Dixon, president of the Republic of Panama's Supreme Court, who is currently visiting Taiwan accompanied by her husband.
Dixon, who concurrently serves as president of the International Association of Women Judges, is a vocal advocate of judicial independence, modernization and transparency.

Chen said he shares Dixon's ideals because judicial independence, modernization and transparency are all crucial to the health of a country's constitutional system, whether it is the Republic of China's five-power Constitution or checks and balances among three powers as in the case of Panama's constitution.
Noting that Taiwan and Panama have long maintained cooperation in various fields, Chen said he hopes Dixon's visit will help strengthen bilateral judicial cooperation in the future.
This is Dixon's first trip to Taiwan. Chen asked Dixon to convey his regards to Panamanian President Martin Torrijos.
Dixon and her husband, Humberto Cerrud, visited the Presidential Office in the company of ROC Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chang Siao-yueh.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR NABBED FOR COERCING FEMALE WITNESS TO HAVE SEX

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung district court prosecutor was detained and kept incommunicado for forcing a female witness involved in a case under his jurisdiction to have sex with him on two occasions, a judge said Monday.
The judge ruled that Prosecutor Wu Jen-chieh's suspected criminal behavior is punishable by a jail sentence of over five years under laws governing corruption and coercive sexual relations.
The prosecutor's office of the district court issued a public apology for a member whose behavior "has brought shame upon all prosecutors and tainted the image of judicial authorities."
In Taipei, Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin said he was appalled by Wu's conduct, which he vowed to "severely punish."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES CABINET NOT TO BLOCK CHINA OFFICIAL'S VISIT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged the Cabinet Monday to allow the director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office to visit Taiwan for a forum on cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural cooperation.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, said the Cabinet should not allow Chad's switching of diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China to interfere in a decision of whether to grant an entry visa to Chen Yunlin, director of Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council.

"Chen's participation in the forum will be beneficial to Taiwan's farmers," Chang said, adding that if the Democratic Progressive Party-led government blocks Chen's visit to Taiwan, it will only hurt Taiwan's farmers.

Noting that Premier Su Tseng-chang said last week that Chen should not come to Taiwan if his purpose is to engage in a "united front tactics," the KMT official said, "The government should allow Chen to visit Taiwan and face the counter united front tactics" of Taiwan's 23 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG WRITERS INVITED TO SUBMIT PAPERS FOR LITERATURE CONFAB

TEXT.P: Young writers and academics under 30 years of age from around the world are invited to submit academic papers in the Chinese language for discussion at a youth literature conference in December, organizers said Monday.
Graduate students are exempted from the age limit, organizers said.

Conference themes will focus on how Taiwanese writers utilize geography in their work and literary experiences, such as writer Wu Jo-liu's Nanjing experience, Lin Wen-yueh's lyrical writing on the ancient Japanese capital of Kyoto, Chung Li-ho's nostalgic description of his hometown of Menung in southern Taiwan, and changes in Taipei's urban face as described in Wang Wen-hsing's early novels.
Originality is a prerequisite for submissions, organizers said, adding that each should not exceed 15,000 words in length and be postmarked by Aug. 31.

The conference is jointly organized by Academica Sinica's Institute of Chinese Literature and Philosophy, the National Museum of Taiwan Literature and the Taiwan Literature Development Foundation. Further information is available at www.nmtl.gov.tw and www.wenhsun.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS SCANT INTERACTION BETWEEN TAIWAN'S FATHERS, KIDS

TEXT.P: Local fathers aged between 20 and 45 spend an average 10.76 hours with their children per week, according to the results of a survey released Monday by an online job bank.

The "1111 Job Bank" released the findings on the eve of Father's Day which falls on Tuesday this year. It conducted an Internet survey between July 19 and Aug. 4, targeting fathers aged between 20 and 45, with 510 valid samples collected.

According to the results, 25.61 percent of respondents said they spend more than 18 hours with their children per week, 24.18 percent said the time ranges between 12 hours and 18 hours, and 23.36 percent said they spend less than six hours with their children every week.
The figures indicate young fathers have scant or insufficient interaction with their kids, an 1111 Job Bank spokesman said.

The survey found that 51 percent of respondents who already have one child said they would not have any more, with 65 percent citing limited financial resources and the high cost of education as the main reasons for that reluctance.
Meanwhile, 75.2 percent said their income is insufficient to cover the family's basic living expenses and the children's education; only 23.77 percent gave a positive response.

Among fathers who said their income is sufficient to cover family expenditures, 43.1 percent attributed this to their frugality or thriftiness, 33.62 percent said their pay is ample, and 31.03 percent said their wives are working mothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC AIR PASSENGERS DROP 11.8%

TEXT.P: The number of arrivals and departures at airports around Taiwan totaled 21.43 million in the first half of this year, down 2.3 percent year on year, according to statistics released Monday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
DGBAS officials attributed the decline mainly to a significant 11.8 percent drop in domestic air passengers during the six-month period.
In contrast, the number of international flight passengers rose 5.9 percent from the year-earlier level.

Of the figure, international flight passengers accounted for 11.52 million, marking a 5.9 percent year-on-year increase, while domestic flight passengers numbered 8.63 million, down 11.8 percent. The rest were transit passengers.

DGBAS officials said it requires a further study to determine whether the substantial drop in domestic flight passengers was caused by local people's choice of other transport vehicles or their declining interest in domestic leisure trips.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 8 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Aug. 8:
10:00, The Taiwan Thinktank will hold a seminar on Taiwan's external relations in the wake of the rupture of ties with Chad.
15:00, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news briefing.
17:00, A changeover ceremony for the Financial Supervisory Commission chairman will be held.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEA WARNING ISSUED AGAINST TROPICAL STORM BOPHA

TEXT.P: A sea warning was issued Monday evening againt tropical storm Bopha as the tropical depression continued swirling toward waters off southeastern Taiwan coast.
The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Bopha was centered 630 km east of Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, at 8 p.m. Monday, moving in a westerly direction toward eastern Taiwan at 15 kph.
If the storm maintains its present course and speed, CWB meteorologists said Bopha will be centered about 290 km east-northeast at 8 p.m. Tuesday.

They also forecast that occasional showers or thundershowers will hit eastern and northern parts of Taiwan Tuesday because of the influence of Bopha's surrounding airstreams. Rainfall in eastern Taiwan will become even heavier Wednesday, CWB analysts said.

Nevertheless, they added that Bopha is likely to sweep a bit southward due to the effect of medium Typhoon Saomai. Should Bopha moves southward earlier, they said, its influence on Taiwan's inland will be minimized.

"It remains uncertain whether the weather bureau will issue a land warning against Bopha. We are closely monitoring several variables, including the storm's direction and strength. If it tilts southward earlier, we may not issue a land warning, " said Lin Hsiu-wen, deputy director of the CWB's forecast center.
According to Lin, Bopha is likely to weaken in strength and shrink in radius because of certain weather conditions unfavorable to its development into a typhoon.

Meanwhile, Lin said Typhoon Saomai is still far away from Taiwan. It is forecast to gradually move close to the Japanese island of Okinawa Wednesday or Thursday. Whether Saomai will influence Taiwan requires further monitoring, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS MAKE 3RD APPEAL AGAINST BAIL RULING

TEXT.P: The Taipei Prosecutor's Office filed its third appeal with the Taiwan High Court Monday against a lower court's ruling on bail for three indicted suspects in a high-porfile insider trading scandal involving President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming.

Prosecutors asked the high court to revoke the Taipei District Court's bail ruling on the ground that the crime committed by the three suspects deserve continued detention in accordance the Criminal Procedure Law.

Prosecutors formally indicted Chao and two accomplices July 10 on charges of using insider information to profit from Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stock dealings. In the indictment, prosecutors recommended that Chao and former TDC Chairman Su Teh-chien be sentenced to eight years behind bars, with 10 years for businessman You Shih-yi.
In the evening of that same day, Chao and You were freed on NT$10 million bail and Su on NT$5 million bail.

The prosecutor's office appealed to the high court July 14, seeking to have the trio detained once again. In response to the first appeal, the high court ruled July 17 that the lower court had to review the case again because its previous decision was flawed.

In its second ruling issued July 20, the district court stuck to its decision on allowing the trio to remain free, but raised bail for Chao to NT$17 million from the original NT$10 million, while maintaining that bail for the other two suspects should remain the same at NT$10 million and NT$5 million, respectively.

The prosecutor's office re-appealed the case July 26 to try to have the trio detained once again. On July 28, the high court rescinded the district court's second ruling and demanded a further review.
On July 31, the district court upheld its second ruling on allowing the trio to remain free on bail.

In is third appeal, the prosecutor's office rebutted the district court's argument that as insider trading suspects are normally unlikely to repeat their illegal stock trading practice once their case are exposed, they need not be detained in the wake of their indictment.

Quoting the Criminal Procedure Law, the prosecutor's office said that any suspect who faces a recommendation of five years behind bars can be kept in custody pending trial regardless whether he or she is likely to repeat previous criminal acts.
In the TDC case, the prosecutor's office argued that as all the three suspects deserve a minimum seven-year prison term, the high court should invalidate the district court's bail ruling.
While granting bail, the district court banned the trio from leaving the country or changing residence without due notice.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR NABBED FOR COERCING FEMALE WITNESS TO HAVE SEX(repeat)

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung district court prosecutor was detained and kept incommunicado for forcing a female witness involved in a case under his jurisdiction to have sex with him on two occasions, a judge said Monday.
The judge ruled that Prosecutor Wu Jen-chieh's suspected criminal behavior is punishable by a jail sentence of over five years under laws governing corruption and coercive sexual relations.
The prosecutor's office of the district court issued a public apology for a member whose behavior "has brought shame upon all prosecutors and tainted the image of judicial authorities."
In Taipei, Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin said he was appalled by Wu's conduct, which he vowed to "severely punish."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES CABINET NOT TO BLOCK CHINA OFFICIAL'S VISIT TO TAIWAN(repeat)

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged the Cabinet Monday to allow the director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office to visit Taiwan for a forum on cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural cooperation.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, said the Cabinet should not allow Chad's switching of diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China to interfere in a decision of whether to grant an entry visa to Chen Yunlin, director of Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council.

"Chen's participation in the forum will be beneficial to Taiwan's farmers," Chang said, adding that if the Democratic Progressive Party-led government blocks Chen's visit to Taiwan, it will only hurt Taiwan's farmers.

Noting that Premier Su Tseng-chang said last week that Chen should not come to Taiwan if his purpose is to engage in a "united front tactics," the KMT official said, "The government should allow Chen to visit Taiwan and face the counter united front tactics" of Taiwan's 23 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG WRITERS INVITED TO SUBMIT PAPERS FOR LITERATURE CONFAB(repeat)

TEXT.P: Young writers and academics under 30 years of age from around the world are invited to submit academic papers in the Chinese language for discussion at a youth literature conference in December, organizers said Monday.
Graduate students are exempted from the age limit, organizers said.

Conference themes will focus on how Taiwanese writers utilize geography in their work and literary experiences, such as writer Wu Jo-liu's Nanjing experience, Lin Wen-yueh's lyrical writing on the ancient Japanese capital of Kyoto, Chung Li-ho's nostalgic description of his hometown of Menung in southern Taiwan, and changes in Taipei's urban face as described in Wang Wen-hsing's early novels.
Originality is a prerequisite for submissions, organizers said, adding that each should not exceed 15,000 words in length and be postmarked by Aug. 31.

The conference is jointly organized by Academica Sinica's Institute of Chinese Literature and Philosophy, the National Museum of Taiwan Literature and the Taiwan Literature Development Foundation. Further information is available at www.nmtl.gov.tw and www.wenhsun.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS SCANT INTERACTION BETWEEN TAIWAN'S FATHERS, KIDS(repeat)

TEXT.P: Local fathers aged between 20 and 45 spend an average 10.76 hours with their children per week, according to the results of a survey released Monday by an online job bank.

The "1111 Job Bank" released the findings on the eve of Father's Day which falls on Tuesday this year. It conducted an Internet survey between July 19 and Aug. 4, targeting fathers aged between 20 and 45, with 510 valid samples collected.

According to the results, 25.61 percent of respondents said they spend more than 18 hours with their children per week, 24.18 percent said the time ranges between 12 hours and 18 hours, and 23.36 percent said they spend less than six hours with their children every week.
The figures indicate young fathers have scant or insufficient interaction with their kids, an 1111 Job Bank spokesman said.

The survey found that 51 percent of respondents who already have one child said they would not have any more, with 65 percent citing limited financial resources and the high cost of education as the main reasons for that reluctance.
Meanwhile, 75.2 percent said their income is insufficient to cover the family's basic living expenses and the children's education; only 23.77 percent gave a positive response.

Among fathers who said their income is sufficient to cover family expenditures, 43.1 percent attributed this to their frugality or thriftiness, 33.62 percent said their pay is ample, and 31.03 percent said their wives are working mothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC AIR PASSENGERS DROP 11.8%(repeat)

TEXT.P: The number of arrivals and departures at airports around Taiwan totaled 21.43 million in the first half of this year, down 2.3 percent year on year, according to statistics released Monday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
DGBAS officials attributed the decline mainly to a significant 11.8 percent drop in domestic air passengers during the six-month period.
In contrast, the number of international flight passengers rose 5.9 percent from the year-earlier level.

Of the figure, international flight passengers accounted for 11.52 million, marking a 5.9 percent year-on-year increase, while domestic flight passengers numbered 8.63 million, down 11.8 percent. The rest were transit passengers.

DGBAS officials said it requires a further study to determine whether the substantial drop in domestic flight passengers was caused by local people's choice of other transport vehicles or their declining interest in domestic leisure trips.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON HAS NOT RULED OUT POSSIBILITY OF TAIWAN-U.S. FTA: ROC REP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Lin Chieh-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government has not ruled out the possibility of signing a free trade agreement (FTA) with Taiwan, although there are a number of problems to overcome, ROC Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Monday.

Lee was commenting on recent remarks by Thomas Christensen, newly-appointed U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, that the timing for the signing of an FTA between Taiwan and the United States has not matured yet.
Christensen said Taiwan should try harder to improve its free trade climate so as to create favorable conditions for the signing of an FTA in the future.
Lee said Christensen's remarks should not be interpreted as a negative development as the signing of a Taiwan-U.S. FTA is not something that can be attained in a short period of time.
Lee said Taiwan does not expect the goal to be achieved in the next couple of months because Taiwan still needs to take a lot of measures to remove the obstacles between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 8, or the 15th day of the seventh month of the Year of the dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1549: France declares war on England.
1588: The Spanish Armada is defeated by the British.
1900: The first Davis Cup tennis tournament, named after Dwight Filley Davis, begins in Brookline, Massachusetts.
1901: Ernest Lawrence, the American physicist who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1939, is born. He invented the first subatomic particle accelerator and the color television tube.
1918: The Battle of Amiens begins when Allied forces advance against 20 German divisions and take 16,000 prisoners in two hours.
1919: A peace conference between India and Afghanistan results in the signing of the Treaty of Rawalpindi.
1923: Esther Williams, the American actress and former champion swimmer, is born. She became best-known for her appearance in "Bathing Beauty."
1944: Adolf Hitler has four of his top men hanged with piano wire for attempting to assassinate him.
1945: The United States drops its second atomic bomb, "Fat Man," on the Japanese city of Nagasaki, days after devastating Hiroshima with "Little Boy," the first such device ever used.
1957: General Chow Chih-jou is appointed governor of Taiwan, succeeding C.K. Yen.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1961: Mei Lan-fang, noted Beijing opera actor, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 67.
1963: In one of the most audacious holdups of all time, robbers involved in "The Great Train Robbery" net an estimated 2.5 million pounds (US$4.6 million) in unused bank notes from a night mail train traveling between Glasgow and London.
1963: The United States, Britain and the USSR sign the nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the Kremlin.
1967: The "Bangkok Declaration" is signed by the foreign ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. The declaration led to the formation of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
1974: Richard Nixon makes history as the first U.S. president to resign from office.
1977: The Interior Ministry reports that at the end of June, the population of Taiwan reached 16,655,140 and that of Taipei hit 2,113,030.
1983: A military coup led by Defense Minister General Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores overthrows President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala.
1988: ROC swimmer Wang Han and a six-man team swim across the English Channel in relays in 14 hours and 31 minutes.
1988: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa announces the decision to build a new highway linking Ilan and Nankang in Taipei County.
1990: National Defense Minister Chen Li-an announces that the Red Cross Society of the ROC will handle the repatriation of illegal mainland entrants in the future.
1994: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait sign and make public a joint announcement confirming the results of the second round of talks between Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei.
1999: The Fifth Asia Children's Literature Convention opens in Taipei with 300 authors of children's literature from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia and the ROC attending.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records names 109-year-old Hu Chin-yao as Taiwan's oldest father.
2001: Officials from Taiwan and Australia gathers in Taipei to participate in a two-day conference on mineral and energy resources.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If those in authority have not the confidence of those under them, government of the people is an impossibility."

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST FAMILY WILL RESPOND AFTER RECEIVING REQUEST ON JEWELRY ASSETS

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office said Tuesday that it will only respond after receiving a request from the Control Yuan concerning the sources of the first lady's jewelry assets.

Officials from the Department of Public Affairs of the Presidential Office made the remarks as reports said the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog party, will ask the Presidential Office to reveal the identity of relatives and friends from whom the first lady has borrowed jewelry.
The Control Yuan needs information related to those who lent jewelry to the first lady for further checks, the reports also said.
However, the Presidential Office officials reaffirmed that "it is not convenient" for the first family to reveal their names "for privacy reasons of individual assets."

The first couple sent a corrected version of jewelry assets to the Control Yuan in early July, listing 15 pieces of jewelry and watches that they own, with a total value of NT$3.725 million (US$113,560).

Legislators from the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party then produced photos of 31 pieces of jewelry worn by the first lady on various occasions. The Control Yuan therefore asked for an explanation from the first family within 15 days.

The first couple, replied last Friday -- the last day of the deadline -- that they had acquiesced to the Control Yuan's request by filing reports on their jewelry but had not reported on jewelry borrowed from relatives or friends because the relatives and friends were not being audited and should have the privacy of their assets protected.
According to the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, any piece of jewelry, including watches, worth over NT$200,000 should be listed with the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH RELEASES GUIDEBOOK ON SUICIDE PREVENTION

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) released Tuesday a guidebook on the prevention of suicide, which has been one of the top 10 killers in Taiwan for nine consecutive years.
According to DOH tallies, 4,282 people died by suicide in Taiwan last year, for a figure of 18.84 suicides for every 100,000 people -- the highest level in the past 20 years.

The guidebook is a Chinese translation of the article "Preventing Suicide" released by the World Health Organization. It provides advice and strategies on suicide prevention to physicians, healthcare workers, teachers, reformatory institutions, media workers and suicide survivor support groups, who are most likely to have contact with people who are prone to attempt suicide.
The DOH has prepared 10,000 copies of the guidebook for distribution to local health authorities, medical associations and educational institutions, officials said.

Lee Ming-pin, director of the DOH's center for suicide prevention and control, noted that more than 50 percent of those who committed suicide had directly or indirectly disclosed their intent to their friends or relatives or had received non-psychiatric treatment before killing themselves.
"This shows that suicide can be prevented as long as people are sensitive enough to these signs," Lee said.
He pointed out that among the people who died by suicide, men outnumbered women 2.3 to 1, and 70 percent were between the age of 25 and 64.
To enhance the effect of suicide prevention, the DOH should strengthen the ability of physicians and relevant workers to identify those who are at high-risk of committing suicide, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S DAUGHTER REIMBURSES OVER NT$2 MILLION IN 'JANITOR' SALARY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's daughter Chen Hsing-yu has reimbursed over NT$2 million (US$61,000) that the Presidential Office paid to "janitor" Lin Hsiu-chen who actually worked as a housemaid at Hsing-yu's home, a spokesman said Tuesday.

Lee Nan-yang, director of the office's department of public affairs, said Chen Hsing-yu has paid that amount to the accounting office of the Presidential Office, which then passed it on to the national coffers.

The first family made the move following media reports that Lin Hsiu-chen, also known as "Sister A-Ching, " had been paid by the government to work as a housemaid at the president's previous residence, now occupied by his married daughter.

The reports created quite a stir, as calls for "integrity" and "clean politics" rose again amidst a spate of corruption scandals involving members of the first family and close aides to the president.

On Aug. 1, 2006, the Presidential Office announced that Lin had resigned as a janitor but then was reemployed by the president to work at his daughter's home on Minsheng East Road in Taipei and that Lin's salary and bonuses from Oct. 2001, when Hsing-yu got married to Chao Chien-ming and moved to the current home, would be reimbursed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 85.53 points to close at 6,502.14.
The bourse opened at 6,442.68 and fluctuated between 6,502.14 and 6,441.16 during trading. A total of 2.31 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.24 billion (US$1.8 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.61 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.43 percent, construction issues at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.13 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.87 percent, cement stocks at 0.79 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.43 percent, and textile stocks at 0.33 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 736 to 241, with 154 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOOMING EXPORTS TO HELP BOLSTER TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Booming exports will bolster the nation's economy, and there is a good chance that economic growth this year will surpass 4 percent, the head of a local think tank said Tuesday.

Liang Kuo-yuan, president of the Polaris Research Institute, noted that soaring crude oil prices this year will "place a tremendous burden on Taiwan's imports, " although strong exports will provide momentum for the economy's continued growth.

Liang noted that there's a good chance that average crude oil prices will break the US$70 per barrel mark for this year, given the fact that West Texas Intermediate crude oil averaged US$68.24 a barrel in the first eight months this year,

He said that soaring oil prices will lead to a rapid increase in imports. He cited 2005 as an example, saying that crude oil imports totaled US$18.8 billion that year, leading to a dramatic decline in the nation's trade surplus.
Crude oil prices have continued to increase this year, and if exports cannot maintain the same strong momentum, then Taiwan's economic prospects will become worrisome, he added.

However, he said, exports have been more brisk than expected, noting that July exports totaled US$19.58 billion, setting a single-month record and an increase of 21.1 percent over the same month last year.

He attributed the increase mainly to the fact that 60 percent of Taiwan's exports go to China, Japan, and member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) -- all high economic growth areas.
The Ministry of Finance noted Monday that export orders in June also recorded the second-highest level in history, showing that the momentum of exports has been strong.
Ministry officials noted that because of rising oil prices and slower economic growth in the United States, Taiwan's exports in the latter part of the year will be affected.

Taiwan still has a chance to reach the goal of exporting more than US$20 billion worth of goods in a single month in the latter part of the year and of maintaining double-digit export growth, although the increase is not expected to be higher than 21.2 percent in July, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA LAUNCHES DRIVE TO COLLECT COMPUTERS FOR DISADVANTAGED KIDS

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has launched a drive to collect second-hand computers to help disadvantaged children.
EPA officials said they welcome groups or individuals to donate their spare computers before the end of December so as to help narrow the digital gap between the urban and rural areas.

They noted that this is the second year the EPA has launched the drive, adding that all collected computers will be repaired and installed with related software before being donated to children from low-income families and those residing in remote areas.

They said the goal for this year will be 3,800 computers. Judging from past experience, the officials said, they can only assemble one usable computer from between three and five old computers donated. In other words, they need to collect about 18,000 computers to reach the goal.

Those who want to donate computers can visit the Web site www.istec.iii.org.tw or contact the EPA by phoning the toll-free number 0800-000-156. The EPA will send officials to collect donations of 20 or more computers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S CHIU YI FILES SLANDER SUIT AGAINST DPP'S WANG SHIH-CHIEN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiu Yi said Tuesday that he has filed a slander suit against ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Wang Shih-chien for alleging that Chiu had sexually assaulted former Miss China Liao Hsien-ling.
Chiu said Wang's "totally groundless" allegation was "purely a smear tactic" that has degraded the image of elected officials.
"Even if Wang wants to defend a corrupt regime led by [President] Chen Shui-bian, he should at least retain some character," Chiu said.
He demanded NT$100 million (US$3.05 million) in compensation for his damaged reputation.
Wang said Chiu need not get so angry as to sue people before "thoroughly explaining himself with regard to the sexual assault allegation."

DOC.HEADLINE: 11 FUGITIVES REPATRIATED FROM CHINA TO KINMEN

TEXT.P: Several fugitives wanted by Taiwan's authorities for alleged involvement in a spate of scams were repatriated from China to the outlying island of Kinmen Tuesday, a spokesman for the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said.

According to the CIB spokesman that same day, the 11 fugitives were sent back from Mawei in Fujian province to Kinmen Island on the "three mini links" shipping route under the terms of the "Kinmen agreement" -- a set of crime-fighting mechanisms agreed upon by Taiwan and China in the early 1990s.

The number of repatriates is the highest-ever in Taiwan's history, with most being masterminds behind various criminal fraud rings -- marking a departure from similar cases in which only "downstream" ciphers were detained, the spokesman said.

The 44-year-old Hsu Shiou-ting, one of the fugitives returned to Taiwan, was on the run in China for little more than two months. The Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office issued a warrant for Hsu's arrest May 30 after he repeatedly failed to show up in court for questioning.

In May, Hsu was caught and detained by police in Kaohsiung on charges of allegedly cajoling an accomplice into smuggling illicit narcotics into Taiwan through Kaohsiung's Hsiaokang airport. The drug trafficker was apprehended by airport police early that month, trying to enter the airport with heroin in his anus, looking suspicious.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER UNDER FIRE FOR MEETING WITH HEZBOLLAH LEADER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators accused Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang Tuesday of damaging Taiwan's international image after Huang was reported to have met with Hezbollah leader Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah during a secret visit to Lebanon in April.

According to the Apple Daily, the meeting was covered by local media in Lebanon, and related information has also been posted on the official Web site of Hezbollah, a Shi'a Islamic organization and the political party defending Southern Lebanon against Israel's occupation and current offensive -- and considered by the United States, Canada and Israel as a terrorist organization.

Tsai Chin-lung, a KMT legislative caucus whip, demanded that Huang provide a public explanation for the matter, which Tsai said has betrayed Taiwan's image as a democratic country practicing the rule of law and an advocate against terrorism.
Tsai said the incident shows Huang is incompetent as minister of foreign affairs and that Huang should resign to take responsibility for the mistake in judgement.

Accusing Huang of "dancing with the devil," KMT Legislator Joanna Lei said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party pays no attention to the well-being of Taiwan's people while repeatedly claiming it "loves Taiwan."

In response to the allegations, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu clarified that Huang was only paying a courtesy call on Nasrallah and that the meeting took place before the conflict began between Lebanon and Israel.

Lu said the purpose of Huang's Lebanon visit was to try to establish substantive relations with the Middle East nation, and the minister had arranged a meeting with Nasrallah because Hezbollah is the governing party of the Lebanese government.

He said Taiwan has no intention of getting involved in disputes between Israel and other countries in the Middle East, adding that different parts of the world have different interpretations as to what constitutes terrorism.
