DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WANTS BEIJING'S EXPLANATION OVER CHAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is still willing to promote exchanges and visits by ranking officials between Taiwan and China if Beijing provides a reasonable explanation for the Chad incident, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng said Tuesday.
Huang made the comments while delivering a speech on the outlook of Taiwan's foreign relations at a seminar sponsored by Taiwan Thinktank.

Early Sunday morning, Taiwan announced the severing of diplomatic ties with Chad after learning the central African county had decided to switch official recognition from Taiwan to China -- the latest setback for Taiwan in its cross-strait diplomatic struggle.

If Beijing would offer a fair explanation to Taiwan's people about why it employs every possible means in its arsenal to suppress Taiwan, the government would still do its best to boost two-way exchanges by ranking officials, including a planned mid-October visit to Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, head of the Chinese Communist Party's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, Huang said.

Stating that it is a set government policy to step up exchanges and dialogue between Taiwan and China, Huang suggested that Beijing demonstrate concrete acts of goodwill toward Taiwan before the two sides begin negotiations.

The government will continue trying to forge a consensus with the Chinese side on opening up Taiwan to Chinese tourists and implementing direct cross-strait charter flights, the MAC vice chairman said.

According to the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Chen will file an application with the MAC later this month to visit Taiwan, where he hopes to take part in a KMT-sponsored agricultural seminar in mid-October.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER-DESIGNATE SOON TO ASSUME NEW POST
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Ada Tsai)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ambassador to El Salvador, Javier Ho, who was promoted to become vice foreign minister in June, will leave that central American state in mid-August to assume his new post in Taipei.

In a telephone interview with CNA's correspondent in Panama City on Monday, Ho outlined the achievements of his 19-month tenure in San Salvador, saying an agreement will soon be inked to set up an industrial park in El Salvador with Taiwan's assistance, and that several Taiwan-based firms -- mainly textile companies -- have already promised to operate in the park.

Furthermore, Ho said, two rounds of bilateral talks with the purpose of securing a free trade pact have come to a close and laid the groundwork for the pact's conclusion in October, when El Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca Gonzalez will be visiting Taipei.
Ho said Taiwan's ties with El Salvador are very stable and that his embassy has ample channels of communication with the host country's leaders, including with opposition parties.

Ho is to replace Francisco Huang who has been transferred to Madrid as Taiwan's representative to Spain, while Ho's vacancy in San Salvador will be filled by Taiwan's deputy representative to Mexico, Carlos Liao.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTION UNAWARE WHETHER BOI PROBING PRESIDENT'S BANK ACCOUNT

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court Prosecutor's Office, which has been investigating an insider trading case in which President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming was indicted, said Tuesday it was unaware of the Bureau of Investigation's (BOI) investigation into the president's allegedly "secret" bank account.

Prosecutor Lin Pang-liang said the Prosecutor's Office had "no idea at all" whether the BOI has been probing the president's Taishin International Bank account, and that his office does not have any information about the president's bank accounts.

He noted that prosecutors pursuing the insider trading case had discussed with BOI officials whether illegal funds were used in Chao's bank accounts, but the discussion "was not expanded to cover other people's accounts."

According to a BOI press release Monday, investigators helping prosecutors with the insider trading case discovered in May that between January and March of 2004, Chen Chen-hui, the cashier at the president's office, deposited large sums of cash into the president's bank account at Taishin Bank's Nanmen (South Gate) branch.

That information, obtained from the currency exchange center, did not show where the cash came from but indicated that the large sums of money were unrelated to the insider trading of Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stocks, so it was not forwarded to prosecutors investigating the insider trading case, the BOI said.
It noted that Prosecutor Hsu Yung-chin, who is in charge of the insider trading case, has not asked investigators to do anything about the president's Taishin Bank account.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.013 to close at NT$32.816.
A total of US$491 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.853 and hit a low of NT$32.805.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAND WARNING ISSUED FOR TROPICAL STORM BOPHA

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning Tuesday for tropical storm Bopha, urging residents in Taitung, Pingtung, Green Island and Orchid Island to take necessary precautions against the storm.
Bopha was centered 260 km northeast of Taitung at 2 p.m., moving southwest at 15 kph toward Taiwan and packing winds of up to 72 kph, meteorologists said.
They said the storm was approaching the southeastern part of Taiwan, posing a threat to Taitung, Hengchun peninsula and Pingtung.
They warned ships operating in waters northeast and southeast of Taiwan, Bashih Channel and southern Taiwan Strait to guard against strong winds and high waves triggered by the storm.
Bopha is expected to bring about heavy rains in the northeastern and eastern parts of Taiwan as well as mountainous areas in northern Taiwan, they added.
Meanwhile, meteorologists said the CWB might issue a sea warning after midnight for Typhoon Saomai.
Saomai was located 1,245 km east of Hengchun as of Tuesday afternoon and was moving at 27 kph toward Taiwan, according to the CWB.
The typhoon is expected to come close to Taiwan by Wednesday night and pose a threat in waters north of Taiwan, meteorologists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 151 points to close at 6,501, with 37,968 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September rose 144 points to finish at 6,484, with 1,458 contracts traded, while December futures gained 124 points to close at 6,478, with 17 contract transactions.
March futures moved up 96 points to close at 6,489, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,350 for August, 6,340 for September, 6,354 for December, 6,393 for March and 6,366 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
August TE futures moved up 6.95 points to close at 275.5, with 4,303 contracts traded, while September TE futures rose 6.15 points to finish at 274.7, with 388 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures gained 15.6 points to close at 924.6, with 1,606 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved up 13.4 points to finish at 924.4, with 128 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved up 15 points to close at 922.8, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD INCREASE ITS DIPLOMACY BUDGET: ACADEMICS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government should increase its diplomacy budget to counter China's relentless oppression in the international community, academics said in a seminar Tuesday.

China has been pouring money in every imaginable way into Africa, South America and the South Pacific since its economic rise, said Michel Lu, spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) . And one of its main objectives is to win over Taiwan's allies in those regions, he added.

The number of Taiwan's allies went from 29 in 2000 -- when the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) became the ruling party -- down to the present 24. The five countries were won over by more aid and financial promises from China, and switched diplomatic recognition.

With a NT$28 billion diplomacy budget, which accounts for less than one percent of the NT$320 billion gross domestic product (GDP), it's difficult for Taiwan to counter China's influence, Lu said, adding that only half the budget -- NT$14 billion -- is designated for international aid expenditures.

"I think Taiwan should increase its diplomacy budget. A diplomacy budget under one percent of the nation's GDP, especially in Taiwan's case, is unfathomable," said Lin Cheng-yi, a research fellow specializing in European and American studies at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institution.

The seminar was organized by Taiwan Thinktank to dicuss Taiwan's foreign relations after diplomatic ties were severed Sunday with the central African country of Chad. Taiwan cut off diplomatic ties with Chad on Aug. 6 after learning the African nation was ready to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Lieberman and Lamont Battle to the Wire
As Connecticut voters prepared for their highly anticipated Democratic primary today, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and Ned Lamont, the two rivals for United States Senate, used sharply different tactics yesterday to gain a final advantage in a contest that appeared to be tightening. The Connecticut race, which has been regarded by some Democrats nationally as a referendum on the party's wartime posture.
Wall Street Journal: Mixed Message, In Volatile Mideast, U.S. Finds a Use For Old Autocrats
With radicalism on the rise and battles flaring from Beirut to Baghdad to Gaza, the Bush administration's quest for democracy in the Middle East is literally under fire. the administration is also showing new eagerness to maintain pillars of the old Middle East -- particularly America's steadiest allies in the region, the autocracies of Egypt, Jordan and Saudi Arabia. It was Israel's bombardment of Lebanon, designed to cripple the Hezbollah militant group, which most recently underscored America's need for friends in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP SEEKS TO TOPPLE CABINET, IMPEACH PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will seek to topple the Cabinet through a no-confidence vote in the legislature while asking the Council of Grand Justices to impeach the scandal-ridden president, a PFP legislative caucus whip said Tuesday.
Legislator Lee Hung-chun, general secretary of the PFP's caucus, said the PFP will use the two-pronged approach to apply pressure on President Chen Shui-bian to make him step down as head of state.
Chen, his family members and senior aides have been implicated in a series of corruption and embezzlement scandals, some of which have entered legal proceedings.

Lee indicated the PFP is unlikely to cooperate with the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- a partner of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the "pan-green camp" -- although the TSU also plans to topple the Cabinet.
"The TSU wants to introduce a motion to topple the Cabinet because it is displeased with Premier Su Tseng-chang's policy, which favors relaxing restrictions on exchanges with China," he said.

"Our reason for toppling the Cabinet is different," Lee said, adding that the PFP is unhappy with the premier because instead of distancing himself from the president, the premier chose to support Chen's leadership after a presidential recall bid failed to pass the Legislative Yuan in late June.

Lee acknowledged that although the PFP will try to oust the premier and topple his Cabinet through a no-confidence vote in the next legislative session, the party's prime target for doing so remains the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER DECLARES WAR AGAINST TAX EVADERS

TEXT.P: Tax evaders beware -- Taiwan's Minister of Finance Ho Chih-chin has declared a war on you, and has vowed to exact an additional NT$30 billion in income taxes for the government.

In an interview with CNA, Ho -- who helped the United States set up a tax management mechanism to stamp out tax evasion -- said he has recruited a Yale professor who is an expert in tax collection to help transplant the U.S. tax management system in Taiwan in October.
The system, which is expected to be in place by early next year, will help the Ministry of Finance more effectively collect personal and corporate income taxes, Ho said.

Citing his experience in the United States, Ho estimated that about 17 dollars out of every 100 dollars in taxes will be evaded for various reasons, and that about five dollars of that sum could be reclaimed by an effective tax management system.

In light of the fact that personal income taxes and corporation income taxes total NT$600 billion in Taiwan every year, the minister predicted the new tax management system would help his ministry collect NT$30 billion more in taxes next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARSHIPS TO CONTINUE FOR CHADIAN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will continue its scholarship program for 17 Chadian students until they have completed their studies in Taiwan, despite the rupture of diplomatic relations between the two countries, a MOFA official said Tuesday.
This will mark a shift in Taiwan's policy on financial aid for foreign students receiving college education or doing advanced studies in Taiwan.
In the past, the ministry has usually terminated scholarships for foreign students as soon as their countries forged diplomatic ties with China.
This time, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said, the ministry decided not to go this route, in line with new thinking in terms of diplomatic affairs.
After discussing the issue with Premier Su Tseng-chang, Lu said, Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang decided to continue offering scholarships to the 17 Chadian students.

"The breaking of diplomatic ties is not the fault of those students and we need not punish them by withdrawing their scholarships. We should instead continue our financial aid in the hope that they will contribute to international society after concluding their studies," Lu said.

Some of the 17 students came to Taiwan just earlier this year to receive one year of Chinese language training before starting four-year university programs, while the others are doing master's or doctoral programs here.

Taiwan announced its decision to cut diplomatic ties with Chad at midnight Aug. 5 after learning that the central African country was ready to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing the following day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD CHANGE APPROACH ON ALLIES: ACADEMICS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's diplomacy has been long caught up in the "myth" of the numbers of diplomatic allies, and it is probably time to adopt a new approach, academics said Tuesday.

The academics were attending a seminar organized by the Taiwan Thinktank that focused on cross-Taiwan Strait relations after Taiwan cut its official ties with the central African country of Chad, which switched its diplomatic ties to China Aug. 6.
"Theoretically, the more allies the better, because it helps us in international organizations, " Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said.
"If Taiwan had 60 or 80 allies, the situation would definitely not be the same, " said Lu. But he admitted that it is "almost impossible" for Taiwan to add more allies within a short period of time.

"How many allies do we need? What does an ally mean to Taiwan? Is it realistic and meaningful to offer financial aid that exceeds our capability just to keep an ally that could switch recognition at any time? It's time for us to re-visit these basic issues, " said Chen Wen-hsien, a professor at National Chengchi University.

As more and more people disapprove of the so-called "checkbook diplomacy" in which Taiwan has been engaged for the past several decades, the government will definitely change its direction to a more pragmatic route, said Lu.
"We will no longer promise our allies something we cannot do. We won't accept blackmail either, " he said.

Lo Chih-cheng, chairman of the Department of Political Science of Soochow University, offered a different perspective on the numbers of Taiwan's allies. The fact that China has wrestled away five allies from Taiwan in the past five years means that China has changed the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, he said.

Lo encouraged the international community to pay attention to the decreasing numbers of Taiwan's allies and the increasing numbers of China's ballistic missiles across the Taiwan Strait -- both a sign of the change of status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAD LATEST CASE OF CHINA'S TWO-HANDED STRATEGY: MAC

TEXT.P: China never stops its suppression of Taiwan although it talks about friendship and goodwill all the time, as can be seen in its move to induce Chad to switch diplomatic recognition, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Deputy Chairman David Huang said Tuesday.
Taiwan cut diplomatic ties with Chad Aug. 6 after learning that the African nation was ready to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing.
Since 2001, Huang said, China has wrested five allies from Taiwan. It also did so with plotted timing to humiliate the Taiwan government.
"China always talks about its goodwill toward the Taiwanese people -- if not the government -- but what it has done has obviously hurt their feelings deeply, " according to Huang.
At the end of the day, it just shows us that China has never given up on its military threats, said Huang.
"It tells us that China will never give Taiwan any 'breathing room' internationally if Taiwan does not recognize Beijing's 'one China' policy, " he said.
He also said the MAC will pragmatically keep working on vested plans such as cross-Taiwan Strait cargo flights and allowing Chinese tourists to visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER SETS 2011 GOAL FOR BALANCED BUDGET

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Ho Chih-chin said Tuesday that he has begun work on building a "financial forecast" system in order to reach the goal of balancing the budget by 2011.

During an exclusive interview with the CNA, Ho said balancing the budget by 2011 was a consensus reached at a recent Cabinet-sponsored economic sustainable development conference and that his ministry will push for its realization.

At present, the central government's debts account for 34 percent of the gross national product (GDP), and although the budget deficit has dropped from NT$310 billion (US$9.45 billion) in 2001 to NT$250 billion (US$7.62 billion) , it is still "quite some distance away" from a balanced budget, Ho said.

In order to have a balanced budget, it is critical to honor "financial disciplines," he said, adding that his staff are studying whether to propose legislating a "financial disciplines law" to stave off political pressure calling for tax reductions and increased welfare spending.

He pointed out that to reach the 2011 goal, the Ministry of Finance will have to manage the "income" part of the balance sheet well by continuing to pursue such reforms as cancelling tax exemptions for school teachers and men and women in uniform, combining corporate and personal income taxes, and levying heavier taxes on business net income that is not disbursed as dividends to shareholders.

In this connection, the national tax administration should be reformed and new methods of cracking down on tax evasion should be adopted so that government revenues can be increased by about NT$30 billion (US$0.91 billion) annually, an income that will go a long way to balancing the budget, he said.

He also recommended using the U.S. experience of a "financial forecast" mechanism that enables government departments to understand that different policies will have different impacts on government revenues, which will help each department contribute to a balanced budget and decide on government subsidies to industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD MAY DISCUSS IMPEACHING PRESIDENT WITH LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will likely discuss impeaching the president and a no-confidence vote on the premier when he meets with Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng Wednesday, KMT sources said Tuesday.
The sources said they are also likely to discuss the possibility of a visit to Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, China's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs.

Impeaching the president and toppling the Cabinet are priorities for the KMT's "pan-blue alliance" ally, the People First Party (PFP), while inviting Chen Yunlin to an agricultural forum in Taiwan is high on the KMT's agenda.
The sources noted that after meeting with Wang, Ma will probably meet with Lien Chan, the party's honorary chairman, to brief him on his talks with Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TO PROTECT PREGNANT WOMEN FROM SECOND-HAND SMOKE LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: The Taipei county government launched a campaign Tuesday to protect pregnant women and their unborn children from second-hand smoke.

Officials of the county government's Public Health Bureau said that with smokers accounting for 4.6 percent of Taiwan's population, more than 50 percent of pregnant women may be exposed to second-hand smoke in their own homes.
The officials urged pregnant women not to smoke and to say "no" to second-hand smoke.
They also urged smoking fathers-to-be to give their unborn children a gift by kicking their habits to provide the next generation with a healthy, clean environment to grow up in.

Medical studies conduced in advanced countries have shown that mothers-to-be and their unborn children can develop lung cancer, heart disease, emphysema, allergies, asthma and other health problems if they are exposed to second-hand smoke.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT UNINTERESTED IN MEETING PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui was quoted as saying Tuesday that there is no need for him to meet with scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian for the time being, but he expressed hope that Chen will do his job well.
Lee urged his followers in the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) not to relish on the dropping popularity of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), TSU officials said.

TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang and other Central Executive Committee members called on Lee at his Taoyuan residence to extend their best wishes on Father's Day. Lee is considered to be the TSU's spiritual leader.
Lo Chih-ming, TSU nominee for Kaohsiung mayor, said Lee encouraged him and Chou Yu-kou, the party's nominee for Taipei mayor, to run a good campaign in the December elections.
Lee promised to attend the party's anniversary celebrations on Aug. 12 and to hold a press conference the next day to air his views on current affairs, Lo said.

Other participants quoted Lee as responding to recent polls showing that the DPP's popularity has dropped drastically due to Chen's and his family's suspected involvement in various corruption scandals, while that of the People First Party (PFP) has also declined.

Only the Kuomintang, which Lee led until 2000, and the TSU are enjoying rising support from the people, according to the polls, which show that TSU's support rate has risen even more than that of the KMT.
To this, Lee urged TSU supporters to "stick firmly to Taiwan sovereignty" but not to be delighted by the DPP's falling fortunes, TSU executives said.
Lo said, Lee wants TSU members to work with Taiwan society in finding out a new direction for Taiwan's industries and a strategy to attract investment to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DADS GET HELP FINDING WORK ON FATHER'S DAY

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government's Bureau of Labor Affairs sponsored a seminar Tuesday to help unemployed fathers plan their career development and get their professional lives back on track, according to a spokesman for the bureau.

Human resource experts spoke to jobless dads -- some middle-aged or elderly -- on various topics, including analyzing the local job market, new trends in the workplace, career development and planning, issues related to workers' rights and interview skills, the spokesman said.

The bureau also offered job opportunities and placement tests to Taipei city residents as well as those from other areas during the seminar in hopes that qualified, job-seeking fathers will find work on Father's Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER OUTLINES TAX REFORM PRIORITIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Ho Chih-chin said Tuesday that he will give top priority to pushing for a law revision to cancel the longstanding income tax exemption privilege for military personnel and elementary and junior high school teachers.

When the Legislative Yuan opens its new session next month, Ho said in an interview with CNA that he will vigorously lobby legislators to pass the long-talked-about tax reform proposal to reinstate income tax levies on military service members and compulsory education school teachers.
Ho, an academic-turned-technocrat who had a long service record with the U.S. tax authorities before returning to Taiwan, said that tax reform is one of his favorite research topics.
"I look forward to introducing into Taiwan the U.S.-style taxation system and its efficient tax management system," Ho said.
Acknowledging that Taiwan has held extensive discussions on various tax reform initiatives and options over the years, Ho said Taiwan now needs to take action to implement them.

In addition to pushing for reinstatement of income taxes on military personnel and elementary and junior high school teachers, Ho said he will begin to promote reforms in inheritance and bequeathment taxes in the first half of next year.

Ho said there is still ample room for improvement in Taiwan's inheritance tax management efficiency. Noting that high inheritance tax rates tend to push rich people to keep their capital or assets abroad, Ho said Taiwan should work out a viable mechanism to lure back those assets.
According to foreign studies, Ho said the cost for wealthy people to keep their assets abroad to save on taxes tends to reach 15 percent of their financial holdings.

"So long as we can craft a sound and profitable mechanism, rich people will be willing to remit their funds back to Taiwan for lucrative investment projects under a healthy income and inheritance taxation system," Ho said.

As for business tax reform, Ho said the timing should take into account the domestic inflation situation. If apprehension about domestic consumer price fluctuations remains high, he said, the finance ministry will not be hasty in taking relevant reform steps.

"In any event, reforms in income tax, inheritance and bequeathment taxes, as well as business tax, will be kickstarted gradually and significant progress will definitely be achieved next year, " Ho said confidently, adding that the Finance Ministry will infuse new thinking and new vigor into the tax reform operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC TO REGULATE TV CHANNELS' USE OF FILE, SIMULATED FOOTAGE

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) indicated Tuesday that it will require all television channels using file footage or simulated news footage in their news programs to inform their viewers with written descriptions about what they are watching.

Members of the NCC agreed at a meeting that some TV channels in Taiwan have been using such footage in their news programs as if it were part of the current news -- a practice that often misleads the viewers.

As a result, the NCC members decided that the NCC will formally send a notice to all TV channels, asking them to indicate with written descriptions through the duration of such footage to inform their viewers that what they are watching is either file or simulated footage.
According to the NCC members, if the result of the notice is unsatisfactory, they will considering amending the relevant law to ban all TV channels from continuing the practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU COAST GUARD TO INTENSIFY DISPERSAL OF INTRUDING CHINESE SHIPS

TEXT.P: Coast guard officers said Tuesday they will step up dispersal of Chinese fishing boats intruding into waters surrounding several uninhabited islets and reefs off the Taiwan-held Matsu island group, as the areas have been reserved for wildlife protection.

According to the officers, the waters around Sanlien, Paimiao and Chungtao islets and reefs have recently been dotted with a large number of buoys believed to have been placed by Chinese fishing boats to facilitate their operations in those regions. Some of the vessels have even sneaked into waters near Pekan to poach oysters.

As those regions have been designated as a nature reserve for terns -- Matsu's most important wildlife resource -- coast guard officials said they have intensified patrols and will disperse all the intruding Chinese fishing boats.

The Lienchiang county government, which administers the Matsu island group, which lies closer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan proper, has announced eight outlying reefs and isles as a nature reserve for terns.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND MUM ON 'FAILED' RESEARCH PROGRAM WITH U.S.

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) declined to comment Tuesday on a media report that a five-year cooperative research program with the United States on a mobile electronic warfare system ended in failure.

According to a local evening newspaper, the U.S. military proposed the cooperative R&D program with the Republic of China Army after the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis in which China lobbed missiles into waters close to Taiwan's Keelung and Kaohsiung ports in an attempt to intimidate local voters ahead of the country's first-ever direct presidential election.

The report said the research project, dubbed "Iron Fist, " was launched in 1998, but the program, which cost Taiwan taxpayers NT$2.2 billion, turned out to be a flop and closed in 2004. According to the report, eight senior military officers have been punished for the botched program.

MND spokesman Wu Chi-fang said relevant information was mentioned in an annual accounting report submitted by the Ministry of Audit to the Legislative Yuan. Now that the program was already closed and the guilty were punished in accordance with relevant regulations, Wu said the ministry had no comment on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 9 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, Aug. 9:
09:00, The Executive Yuan will hold a weekly meeting.
13:30, The Democratic Progressive Party will hold a weekly central standing committee meeting.
15:00, The Kuomintang will hold a weekly central standing committee meeting.
17:00, The Finance Ministry will hold a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB SCHEDULED TO ISSUE SEA WARNING AGAINST TYPHOON SAOMAI

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) is scheduled to issue a sea warning against medium Typhoon Saomai at 2:30 a.m. Wednesday.

Acording to CWB meteorologists, Typhoon Saomai was centered more than 1,000 km east of Hengchun on the southerntip of Taiwan at 10 p.m. Tuesday and was moving west-northwesterly toward Taiwan at a speed of 27 kph.
The typhoon, packing winds of up to 130 kph, is expected to come close to Taiwan by Wednesday night and pose a threat in waters north of Taiwan, meteorologists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 9, or the 16th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1794: General Napoleon Bonaparte is arrested in France on suspicions of Robespierrism.
1814: Under the terms of the Treaty of Fort Jackson signed between the U.S. government and the native Creek tribe, the Creeks lose 9.3 million hectares of land -- over half of Alabama and part of southern Georgia -- to the United States.
1842: The United States signs the Webster-Ashburton Treaty with Britain, establishing the boundary between the U.S. and Canada from Maine to the Great Lakes.
1867: John Harrison Surratt is arrested for being an alleged conspirator in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln.
1902: Edward VII, 64, is crowned King of Great Britain and Ireland after a six-week delay due to an emergency appendectomy.
1903: Giuseppe Sarto becomes Pope Pius X following the death of Pope Leo XIII.
1919: India concludes a secret pact with Britain, recognizing Britain as India's protector after Britain promised India a major role in its own government.
1928: Italian divers find precious diamonds in the wreckage of "Elizabethville," a Belgian ship sunk during World War I.
1937: Japanese troops clash with Chinese forces at Hungchiao airport in Shanghai.
1938: Rod Laver, Australian tennis star, is born. He won the singles title at Wimbledon four times.
1942: Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress, is arrested in Britain for his "Quit India" campaign, which demands that the British should withdraw from India.
1945: Soviet troops enter Manchuria after the Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1946: Henry Pu Yi, who was enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists on Mar. 1, 1934, arrives in Tokyo to testify before an international court against Japanese war crimes committed during the invasion of China.
1954: The Republic of China Navy sinks 12 Communist Chinese ships at Tungshan seaport, Dongshan Island, near Fukien province.
1965: Singapore is separated from Malaysia and becomes an independent state within the Commonwealth of Nations.
1973: Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves for Washington to attend a WACL Executive Committee meeting.
1974: Gerald R. Ford is sworn in as the 38th president of the United States after the resignation of Richard Nixon.
1979: Councilors in the English seaside town of Brighton cause a furor by agreeing to allow naturalists to bare all on "Cliff Beach," one of the less popular beaches in the district.
1990: Communist China's first airship, with a length of 40 meters, makes its maiden flight over Hupei province.
1994: The U.S. government announces trade sanctions against the ROC under the Pelly Amendment, placing a ban on imports of Taiwan wildlife products effective from August 19, 1994.
1999: The China External Trade Development Council signs a memorandum of understanding on technological cooperation with the Agency for International Development of Technology and Trade under the Trade and Industry Ministry of France.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui says the main reason he voiced the "special state-to-state relations" statement regarding cross-Taiwan Strait ties the previous month was to elucidate the fact that the Republic of China exists in the world.
2000: The Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association is established to promote Taiwan's trade and cooperation with the international community.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to gain confidence for one's authority. If a man is not trusted by one's friends, he will not gain the confidence for his authority."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. BELIEVES TAIWAN REMAINS COMMITTED TO COUNTERING TERRORISM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Lin Chieh-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Washington believes that Taipei remains committed to countering terrorism despite an April meeting between a Taiwan official and the leader of a Lebanese group considered by the United States to be a terrorist organization, a senior U.S. State Department official said Tuesday.
It was reported in Taiwan Tuesday that ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang had met with Hezbollah leader Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah during his secret visit to Lebanon in April.

While opposition legislators in Taiwan claimed that the meeting has damaged the nation's image, Huang clarified that he was only paying a courtesy visit to Nasrallah since Hezbollah holds one-third of the seats in Lebanon's parliament.

The State Department official said that the United States was aware of the meeting between Huang and Nasrallah and that there have been no signs since the meeting indicating that Taiwan has changed its commitment to fighting terrorism.

According to the department's Office of the Coordinator for Counterterrorism, Hezbollah has been listed by the United States as a terrorist organization since 1997 and has killed more Americans than any other terrorist groups besides al-Qaida.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW AIT TAIPEI DEPUTY DIRECTOR TO RESUME POST AUG. 11
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Robert Wang, newly-appointed deputy director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Friday to resume his post, diplomatic sources reported Tuesday.

Wang, a senior foreign service officer with more than 20 years of experience in the U.S. State Department, was recently appointed to take over the post from David J. Keegan, who has been assigned to serve as a senior official with the U.S. Embassy in New Zealand.

Wang, who holds a doctoral degree in political science from the University of Iowa, began his diplomat career as an officer with the U.S. Embassy in Japan in 1985. His most recent post was the economics minister counselor at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing which he served between 2001-2005.
His professional career has also included service in Singapore, Hong Kong and Shanghai. He has been appointed to serve as a diplomat-in-residence at UCLA for the 2005-2006 academic year.
Before joining the U.S. Diplomatic Corps, Wang taught international relations at Whittier College in California from 1977 to 1984.

Wang is a Chinese American whose father was also a diplomat, with the Nationalist government of the Republic of China. The Wang family emigrated to the United States after the ROC government moved its seat from mainland China to Taiwan in 1949.

Wang, whose ancestors were Hakkas from Fujian Province, cannot speak the Hakka dialect but is fluent in mandarin Chinese. He has also received intensive training in Taiwanese prior to assuming his new post in Taipei.
His wife, Katherine Xiao, is also a Chinese American.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB ISSUES LAND WARNING FOR TYPHOON SAOMAI

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for Typhoon Saomai at noon Wednesday, urging people in northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan to be on guard against gusty winds and torrential rainfall.
The weather bureau issued a sea warning for Saomai, the eighth typhoon reported in the Pacific area this year, at 2: 30 a.m. Wednesday as the storm system continued to sweep toward Taiwan.
The typhoon was located about 600 km east of Taiwan's northernmost port city of Keelung as of 11 a.m., moving west-northwesterly toward Taiwan at a speed of 28 kph., CWB meteorologists said.

Packing winds of up to 155 kph, Typhoon Saomai is expected to come close to Taiwan between Wednesday night and Thursday, prompting the weather bureau to call for people in Keelung, Yilan, Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu counties to be on extra guard against the the storm system's threat.

Meanwhile, tropical storm Bopha swept through southern Taiwan Wednesday morning before weakening into a tropical depression system. CWB forecasters said those operating on seas near the Taiwan Strait, Bashi Channel and Tungsha (Pratas) Islands should still be on high alert against the storm.
Typhoon Saomai and tropical storm Bopha did not combine and double their force to produce what is known as the Fujiwara Effect as was earlier feared might happen.
The weather bureau added that Taiwan is expected to experience mostly cloudy and rainy weather through Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PUBLIC LIBRARY TO KICK OFF READING CAMPAIGN FOR INFANTS

TEXT.P: The Taipei Public Library and the Hsin-Yi Foundation will launch a "Bookstart" campaign starting Sept. 1 which is aimed at helping children establish the habit of reading in their early childhood, library officials said Wednesday.
The program will target infants between six months and 18 months of age whose households are registered in Taipei City, the officials said.
They said parents with children in this age group can apply for a library card with the library and participate in a series of lectures organized by the library.

Parents taking part in the campaign will receive two children's books, a recommended reading list, and a handbook providing guidance on reading and learning for children at different stages, they said.

While applications for library cards will be accepted at any branches of the library, 15 lectures have been scheduled between September and December at the library's headquarters and its Minsheng, Wanhua, Chinghsin and Tunghu branches, the officials said.

According to the library, the Bookstart campaign was first held in 1992 in the United Kingdom. A survey on the children taking part in that campaign revealed that they perform better than other children in terms of their language and arithmetic abilities after entering primary school.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA SIGNS COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH THAILAND'S MAHIDOLUNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Zep Hu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Academia Sinica and Thailand's Mahidol University signed a memorandum of understanding on research and development cooperation Tuesday, according to a joint statement released by both institutions Wednesday.

Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institution, and Mahidol University, renowned for medical research, agreed in the MOU to enhance their academic exchanges by increasing bilateral visits and allowing more visiting scholars.
The two institutions also agreed to expand such exchanges to more universities and institutions in Taiwan and Thailand, according to the MOU.

Ovid J.L. Tzeng, vice president of Academia Sinica, said after signing the MOU that Mahidol has formed alliances with several universities in Thailand and that Academia Sinica also has cooperative ties with 12 Taiwan universities, adding that it will be very meaningful if the two institutions can serve as connecting nodes to facilitate links between Taiwan's and Thailand's academia.

Mahidol University, established in 1890, changed to its present name in 1969, in honor of Prince Mahidol of Songkhla, who is generally considered in Thailand to be the founding father of modern medical services and public health system in the country. Although Mahidol started as a medical college, it has expanded its faculties recently in areas such as management and computer science.

The bourse opened at 6,493.89 and fluctuated between 6,574.49 and 6,488.59 during trading. A total of 2.91 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.08 billion (US$2.67 billion).

The other three major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 0.17 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.1 percent, and construction issues at 0.08 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 667 to 319, with 140 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: POVERTY CYCLE UNFAVORABLE TO TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC TRANSITION: ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: Increased unemployment among the older segment of the population, lowering real-term income and higher costs of education are aggravating a "poverty cycle" that will have an adverse impact on Taiwan's plan to upgrade its economy, an academic warned Wednesday.

Tai Chao-yang, a department director of the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) , issued his warning in an article he contributed to the electronic newspaper of the Ministry of Economic Affairs aimed at Taiwan's business people around the world.

He wrote that recent statistics about unemployment, real-term income growth and other aspects of the economy reflect an "unsatisfactory" reality about people's livelihoods that points to a "worrying" trend of a vicious cycle of poverty leading to worse and greater poverty.

In terms of unemployment, he said that although the official rate reached a high of 5.17 percent in 2002, a number of the government's "make-do" projects to expand employment led to an apparent reduction in the jobless rate while in fact "hidden" unemployment has gone up.
Tai referred to the situation in which businesses use outsourcing strategies that offer only temporary jobs and non-fixed incomes -- incomes that are often barely enough to support a normal family.
As to the lack of growth in incomes, Tai said a sluggish economy has been the main reason for a minimal increase in salaries and wages in recent years.

Soaring international crude oil and commodity prices have forced manufacturers relying on their imports to adjust their export prices as well as salaries. He noted that the minimal increase in wages has failed to keep pace with consumer price hikes, indicating that real-term incomes have decreased.

He went on to quote Ministry of the Interior statistics as showing that some 200,000 people in 80,000 low-income families have been strapped by the rising cost of education, making it more and more difficult for them to change their fortunes through education.

Tai said that when more people in advanced-age groups are jobless, people's real-term incomes are dropping and the number of poor families are increasing, the mechanism of realizing social justice through education is crumbling, delaying the schedule of economic transition to a higher level of development.

The issue of the "poverty cycle" in Taiwan society is in fact more serious than attracting investment and easing up on the 40 percent- of-net-assets limit for Taiwan companies investing in China, he added.
Until the issue can be solved, he went on, it is quite unlikely that Taiwan's economy will develop in a healthy way and he called on the government to face the issue and come up with a solution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WANTS PEOPLE TO KNOW CHINA'S 'TRUE COLORS'

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged the Taiwan people Wednesday not to harbor any illusions about China following Taiwan's severance of diplomatic ties with Chad.

Speaking during a weekly Executive Yuan meeting, Su said that the public should "perfectly know China's true colors, " as the rupture of Taiwan-Chad diplomatic ties orchestrated by Beijing is the latest proof of its attempts to suppress Taiwan.
Su described the incident as humiliating for Taiwan and called for close attention to be paid by all political parties to China's ambition to swallow Taiwan.
The premier also thanked Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang and the ministry staff for their hard work in minimizing the impact of the Chad incident.

The ministry's monitoring system effectively helped detect changing relations between Taiwan and Chad, enabling it to announce the Taiwan government's decision to cut diplomatic links with Chad before the central African country announced its diplomatic recognition of Beijing, the premier said.
Turning to the question of 17 Chadian students pursing academic degrees on Taiwan scholarships, Su said they should be allowed to stay in Taiwan until they have completed their studies.

"Allowing this will not cost much but will help the Chadian students get to know the Taiwan people's hospitality and kindness, " he said, adding that "this should help them gain a good impression of Taiwan and spread the message to their compatriots after they return to Chad."
The Ministry of Education and relevant government agencies should continue allocating budgets to offer scholarships to foreign students, allowing elite students from other countries, regardless of
whether they have diplomatic ties with Taiwan or not, to better understand the country.

Although it is not a key point to care about the number of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, the premier claimed, the government should help the people gain an understanding of its efforts in reaching out to the rest of the world.
For instance, Taiwan has sent healthcare, agricultural and technical missions to many countries in need, helping such countries improve the livelihoods of their people, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP TO PROVIDE FREE ENGLISH COURSES FOR DISADVANTAGED

TEXT.P: The I-Link Community Services Association will provide free English courses for disadvantaged children in Taipei area starting Aug. 24, association officials said Wednesday.
The targets of the program will be primary school children from single-parent families, unemployed families and low-income families, the officials said.

The four-month courses will cover English language and "life education" to help the children "know themselves and understand others, " while their parents will be offered a growth course on parent-child relationships, they said.
The officials said registration will be accepted until Aug. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARTS FESTIVAL TO RAISE AWARENESS OF DIVERSE CULTURAL HERITAGE

TEXT.P: The 2006 Asia-Pacific Traditional Arts Festival, which starts Aug. 12 in the northeastern Taiwan county of Yilan, will try to raise awareness of the diversity of cultural heritage with more than 20 local and foreign performing groups showcasing the richness of traditional cultural resources in the Asia-Pacific region, the organizers said at a press conference Wednesday.

Taiwanese people have long valued Western culture and have "neglected" the rich cultural assets of neighboring countries, according to Lin Chao-hao, Director of The National Center for Traditional Arts (NCFTA). The event, which runs from Aug. 12-Sept. 3, will include artistic performances, demonstration lectures, special exhibits and academic seminars.

Four foreign groups highlighting the event include the Muqam Art Ensemble from China's Xinjiang Province, the Yuanshe Water Puppet Troupe from Vietnam, a group from Thailand performing Ramayana traditional dance and the National Center for Korean Traditional Performing Arts from South Korea.
The groups will perform for three weeks in a tour that will also take them to Taipei, Taoyuan, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Taitung.
Also on the performing list will be more than a dozen local groups, such as the Ju Percussion Group, the Lan Yang Dancers and various groups of the Songjiang Battle Array.

The event will focus on the topic of "Proclamation of Masterpieces of the Intangible Heritage of Humanity" in response to "Convention for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage, " which was adopted by UNESCO in 2003 and entered into force in April this year.

In addition to artistic performances, an international conference will discuss the topic of "East Asian music and modernity." An exhibition on the traditional percussion instruments of the Asia- Pacific area will also be held from Aug. 12-Sept. 30 at the NCFTA.

In the past four festivals, over 500 events performed by groups from more than 20 countries were held. The festival covers music, dance, fine arts, drama, crafts and installation art, and has become one of the biggest platforms of Asian traditional culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOULD SERIOUSLY CONSIDER OWN FATE: FORMER DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Beleaguered President Chen Shui-bian should answer the question of whether he will stay on or step down from his post, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

Shih Ming-teh, a close comrade of Chen until they went their separate ways in recent years, made the remark at a news conference called to explain why he wrote a letter Monday to the president urging him to quit.
The Presidential Office declined to respond to Shih's call.

Shih claimed in the letter, which was prominently reported by the mass-circulation China Times Wednesday, that Chen "blatantly embraced conglomerates" by forming an advisory group comprised of major businessmen and academics shortly after he was first elected president, claiming that this was "the first step toward his downfall."
"If you yourself are so close to the conglomerates, how can you expect your right-hand men, your family and your in-laws to keep a distance from them?" Shih asked in the letter.

Shih urged Chen and his administration, whose popularity has continued to slip since a spate of corruption allegations implicating his close aides and family members came to light earlier this year, not to force the people "to openly stand up against them."

Shih said the people have the power to demand a breaking of the stalemate and an end to chaos. When such demands cannot be met, they will have to seek "other political methods from outside the existing system."
He claimed he does not want to see "revolutionary methods" being used, but said that if the present chaos continues, Chen will not come out unscathed.
"The people have lost trust and faith in the government, " Shih said, adding that this has become the biggest crisis of the nation.
The president cannot rely on "his supporters, DPP legislative caucus, the DPP to come to his defense," he said.
He called for Chen to come up with effective solutions, adding that "persistent arguments and defense will not help national stability."
He said that he submitted all possible options for the reference of the president more than a month ago, but has received no response.
"As a national leader, you are obligated to solve the problem, but when you yourself have become the source of this chaos, you should consider the question of stepping down."

Asked whether Chen should again report to the people, Shih said that "the people do not need an orator but an executor and political leader." The president reported to the people in June on TV in response to an opposition-initiated motion to recall him, instead of giving a written rebuttal to the Legislative Yuan.
Shih said that the more important thing is for the president to present objective evidence to assuage the misgiving of the people, adding that the people have to learn about the truth.

DOC.HEADLINE: FTC PROMISES FAIR PROBE INTO YAHOO! TRANSACTION FEE DISPUTE

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission (FTC) emphasized Wednesday that it will deal with every complaint concerning fair trade violations impartially, including the dispute surrounding Yahoo! Taiwan's decision to charge transaction fees for its online auction service.
The commission made the remarks after some Internet users expressed doubt about the FTC's ability to handle the Yahoo! case.

The users alleged that the FTC is "only good at slapping flies but dares not fight tigers, " saying that of the more than 1,000 complaints received by the commission every year, less than 20 cases are considered valid.

The announcement by Yahoo! Taiwan -- Taiwan's largest portal and operator of online auctions -- that it will start charging a 3 percent transaction fee on most auction items in August has generated strong reactions from sellers, which has forced the company to postpone the implementation of the policy until Sept. 1.
FTC officials noted that the commission started an investigation into the case immediately after Yahoo! Taiwan made the announcement July 24.

They said that since the commission was established in 1992, it has handled 1,000 to 2,000 cases of alleged fair trade violations per year, with an average of 150 cases per year having been determined as valid.
While the commission looked into 143 cases last year, it has investigated 194 cases between January and July this year, they said.
As of the end of July 2006, the fines the FTC has handed down on law-breaking companies have amounted to NT$1.86 billion, they said.
They said Yahoo! Taiwan can be fined up to NT$25 million if the company is determined to be a monopoly that has abused its market status.
