DOC.HEADLINE: BOWING OUT IS NOT WHAT PEOPLE WANT FROM PRESIDENT: DPP WHIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian quitting the presidency is not what the people want at present, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

Responding to a recent letter sent to Chen by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh calling for the president to step down, Yeh Yi-jin, chief secretary of the DPP legislative caucus, said it would not be in line with the people's expectations if the president bowed out without evidence proving that he has committed certain crimes.
Yeh said Shih might have been out of the party for too long and might have become unfamiliar with the "ecology" of the DPP and its modern core values.

In his letter, which was reportedly sent to the president Monday, Shih urged Chen to relinquish the presidency as his credibility is in tatters and he has lost the people's trust, which Shih described as the biggest crisis facing the nation.
Shih urged Chen to be "courageous" by relinquishing his post "for the benefit of the people and the country."

Yeh argued that stepping down now would be easier for the president than continuing to serve his term, but Taiwan is a country upholding rule of law and any alleged wrongdoings or irregularities should be referred to the judicial system and handled through legal channels, including those allegedly committed by the president and his family.

Yeh said the DPP has not deviated from its path and tradition, nor is it supporting Chen "blindly, " adding that the DPP will not condone the president if he is discovered to have been involved in any wrongdoing.

Meanwhile, Tsai Huang-liang, director of the DPP Department of Culture and Information, offered his appreciation for Shih's concern for the DPP, saying that the party must "reform boldly and resolutely" to regain the people's confidence in the ruling party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP AIDE HOPES TO ARRANGE MEETING BETWEEN PRESIDENT, EX-DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: A top presidential aide said Wednesday that he hopes to arrange a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh after Shih wrote a letter to Chen asking him to step down "for the sake of Taiwan's future."

Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, expressed the hope after the China Times reported earlier the same day that Shih, who described himself as "an old battle companion" of the president, sent Chen Shui-bian a letter Aug. 7 urging him to resign as the people have lost confidence in him.

Shih also called a news conference Wednesday in which he urged the president to bravely "acknowledge his wrongdoing" and voluntarily step down to help Taiwan get back to its right track at a time when the country has been plunged into a confidence crisis.
Tan Sun Chen said he hopes to arrange a tete-a-tete between the two "old friends" because the president deeply respects Shih and since they have not met for a long time.
Tan Sun Chen also denied a rumor that Chen had rejected an earlier proposal by Shih for a meeting.

In the face of repeated calls from the public and academics for Chen to quit the presidency to take responsibility for a spate of corruption allegations related to his family members and close aides, the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) suggested that the president respond to the situation.
According to TSU legislative caucus whip Lo Chi-ming, Chen must face the current situation with clear-cut moves, despite having vowed to cede some administrative power to Premier Su Tseng-chang.
"The difficulties faced by the president now are not a question of offering an apology or a pledge to delegate his power to the Executive Yuan," Lo said.

TSU lawmaker Ho Ming-hao prodded Chen to comprehensively gauge his next move as the Taiwan people are carefully examining his response in line with a set of principles that underpins Taiwan's core values.
Citing former President Lee Teng-hui, the TSU's so-called "spiritual leader, " Ho said the that most important quality in a head of state is his "moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION WANTS PRESIDENT TO STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: The caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the legislature expressed the hope Wednesday that President Chen Shui-bian will heed the advice of former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh and step down to "return the nation to a clean space."
Tsai Chin-lung, KMT caucus whip in the legislature, made the remarks in the wake of a letter to Chen by Shih.
Shih claimed in the letter that if the embattled president refuses to step down, democracy in Taiwan will continue to suffer and the nation will flounder.

Tsai noted that Shih said in the letter that the president has reneged on his pledges prior to the 2000 presidential election that he would form a five-member advisory team including himself and another former DPP chairman, Lin Yi-hsiung. However, Chen later invited academics and big businessmen to join the team instead.
Lu Hsueh-chang, a caucus whip of the opposition People First Party, predicted that Chen will turn a deaf ear to Shih's advice and to an earlier call by a group of pro-DPP academics for him to quit.

Lu said that the judicial authorities must get tough and be relentless in its probe into various irregularities, including the alleged abuse of state funds for Chen's discretionary use, in order to find solid and unequivocable evidence that will force the president's resignation.
KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou also said he feels the president "will cling onto his post."

But Ma said the opposition will not take action to topple the Cabinet lest it be construed as rivalry between the ruling and the opposition parties and shift the focus on the ongoing probe by the judicial authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S IN-LAWS TELL DIFFERENT STORIES ABOUT INSIDER TRADING

TEXT.P: Lawyers for President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming and Chao's father Chao Yu-chu, both indicted in a high-profile insider trading case, told conflicting stories Wednesday about how the senior Chao obtained insider information about Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stocks.

Chao Yu-chu's lawyer said his client did not have any contact with his son before making a decision to invest in TDC stocks but made the decision at the recommendation of Tsai Ching-wen, a board member of the Waterland Securities Co. and another suspect in the case.
He denied that Chao decided to buy TDC stocks after his son told him that TDC stocks were worth investing in -- which is what the investigative report shows.

Chao Chien-ming's lawyer said his client had admitted talking to his father about the TDC stocks and asking him to contact Tsai about how to invest. After that, Chao told investigators, Chao senior and Tsai were in direct communication with each other.

If Chao Yu-chu denied he had heard his son talking about the TDC shares, he might have had a "slip of memory" or a "hearing" problem because he did not hear his son's recommendation clearly, according to the lawyer, Ku Li-hsiung.
The lawyers made the remarks in reply to media questions after a court hearing on the case, which has greatly hurt the image of the president even though he has apologized for his in-law's actions.
The two Chaos, Tsai, businessman You Shih-yi and former TDC Chairman Su Teh-chien -- all indicted on insider trading charges -- appeared in court.
Two other suspects -- business executives Chen Ching-yao and Hung Min-sen, who were indicted on misappropriation of funds in connection with the case -- will appear in another court hearing Aug. 19.
The Taipei District Court will hold another trial session Sept. 8 on the insider trading case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN YOUTHS ARE MOST FREQUENT INTERNET USERS IN EAST ASIA: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan youths between the ages of 15 and 24 spend more than 30 hours per week using the Internet, which is the highest among young people in East Asia, according to the results of an international survey released Wednesday.

The results were unveiled by Zhu Jian Hua, a professor at City University of Hong Kong's Department of English and Communication, during the third conference of the Asia Pacific International Research Alliance hosted by the Taiwan Network Information Center in Taipei.
According to Zhu, East Asia is home to more than 20 percent of the world's Internet users and mobile phone users and the Internet penetration rate in the region is also higher than that of Europe.
Zhu said more than 90 percent of youths in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau, South Korea, Japan and China are Internet users.

He said in Taiwan, men in the 15-24 age group spend an average of 36.2 hours per week using the Internet, while women in the same age group spend an average of 32.5 hours. These figures compare with 16.7 hours per week by men in the same age group in South Korea and 15.4 hours per week by women, he added.

On the preferences of young Internet users in East Asia, the survey shows that South Korean youths use the Internet most frequently to browse Web sites, entertain themselves, search for data and blog, while Hong Kong youths do so most often to browse Web sites, use instant messenger services and receive or send e-mail, Zhu said.
In Taiwan, youths use the Internet most often to browse Web sites, do online shopping, receive or send e-mail, use instant messenger services and watch movies, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CLEARS MINISTER'S NAME

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that former Economics Minister Hwang Ing-san resigned rather than being dismissed, as had been reported by local newspapers.

Presiding over a ceremony in which Hwang handed over his office to his successor Chen Ruey-long, Su said he rarely administers handover ceremonies of misterial chiefs because of his busy schedule, but he attended Hwang's handover because he wanted to clear his name.

Contradicting news reports that Hwang's performance on the job did not meet Su's expectations, which was the cause of his sudden ousting, the premier awarded Hwang a medal in recognition of his excellent contributions.
"I have never been displeased with his performance, but he asked to be relieved of his responsibilities, citing heavy stress, " Su said.
Although Hwang had submitted several letters of resignation to the premier, Su said he did not accept them until the end of a national conference for sustainable development of Taiwan July 28.
In response, Hwang said he took heart from the premier's remarks and that he had been prepared to step down at any time ever since he assumed office Jan. 23.
Hwang was ridiculed as a layman in economics by the newspapers and billed as the shortest-lived economics minister in five decades, with only 198 days on the job.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU COUNTY MAGISTRATE INDICTED ON CHARGE OF TAKING BRIBES

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Prosecutor's Office indicted Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-ching Wednesday on charge of taking bribes.

In the indictment, the prosecutors noted that Cheng's crime is serious as he took the advantage of his public post to take bribes and recommended that the court sentence Cheng to 10 years in prison and deprive him of his civil rights for five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU COUNTY HEAD SAYS HE WILL RESPECT KMT RULES AFTER INDICTMENT

TEXT.P: Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-ching of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Wednesday that he will respect KMT regulations concerning his rights in the party after he was indicted on charge of taking bribes.

Cheng made the remarks after the Hsinchu Prosecutor's Office indicted him earlier in the day on charge of taking bribes. The prosecutors recommended that the court sentence Cheng to 10 years in prison and deprive him of his civil rights for five years.
Cheng said he took the initiative in soliciting a suspension of his party rights immediately after being informed that he was being indicted.
In response, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said the party will suspend the rights of a party member if he or she is indicted on charge of a criminal act.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU STEPS UP RAIDS ON CHINESE FISHING BOATS

TEXT.P: Coastal patrol agents of the outlying island of Matsu have dispersed four Chinese vessels poaching in waters near the island group since the start of a massive operation launched a day earlier, a spokesman for the Matsu coastal patrol authorities said Wednesday.

According to the spokesman, the authorities were acting on tipoffs provided by local fishermen who said that increasing numbers of fishing boats from China were illegally operating in waters near the islands, which lie just off the coast of China's Fujian Province.

In response to the situation, the authorities decided Tuesday to initiate a massive clampdown on the illegally operating Chinese fishing boats, the spokesman said, adding that six police speed boats will be in charge of the mission, carrying out blanket inspections.
The round-the-clock mission will intensify during the night in conjunction with local fishermen, who will provide breaking information according to the actual situations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING POLICE EMBARK ON PATROL MISSION IN ATLANTIC

TEXT.P: An official Taiwan fishery training ship embarked Wednesday on a six-month mission to police Taiwan vessels and foreign ships operating in the Atlantic Ocean.

The Yuhsun No. 2 -- authorized by the Coast Guard administration and the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA) -- left the southern port city of Kaohsiung for the Atlantic Ocean fishing grounds to monitor fishing boats operating there for 184 days to demonstrate Taiwan's determination to strengthen fishery management on the high seas.

It is the first time Taiwan has sent a fishing police vessel to the Atlantic Ocean since the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) late last year cut Taiwan's total allowable bigeye tuna fishing quota and slashed the number of Taiwan vessels allowed to operate in the Atlantic, said Sun Chih-peng, director of the southern Taiwan operations of the Fisheries Administration.

Sun said police and ocean patrol officers aboard the vessel will not only police Taiwan fishing boats operating in the Atlantic but will also report their findings to the ICCAT authorities if they find irregularities committed by other foreign fishing boats operating there to jointly help maintain fishing order.
The Yuhsun No. 2, which is expected to navigate nearly 30,000 nautical miles on the mission, is scheduled to return to Taiwan next February.

Meanwhile, Sun noted that operations to cut the number of Taiwan tuna fishing boats is being continued, aiming at dismantling another 60 deep-sea fishing vessels by October this year and sinking another 50 into the seas surrounding the island to be used as artificial fish culture reefs.
Both measures are designed to help protect deep-sea fishery resources and maintain sustainable fishing operations, Sun noted.

More Taiwan fishing vessels will be allowed to return to the Atlantic Ocean only if the ICCAT decides in its annual meeting, to be held in November, that Taiwan has done a satisfactory job in curbing its overfishing and helping replenish fishery resources, according to Sun.
The ICCAT cut Taiwan's total allowable bigeye tuna fishing quota from 14,900 tons in 2005 to a mere 4,600 tons for 2006 because of alleged overfishing by Taiwan vessels.
The ICCA also allowed only 15 out of Taiwan's 60-strong bigeye tuna fleet to continue their operations in the Atlantic Ocean for 2006 on a trial basis.
The decision was made during the ICCAT's 19th regular meeting held in Spain in late December 2005, after Japan proposed a quota cut, citing overfishing by Taiwanese vessels.

Most bigeye tuna caught by Taiwanese boats are sold to Japan. The amount exported to Japan over the past two years has exceeded the total yearly catch quota, prompting the charge of overfishing by the Japanese.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL TRAVEL AGENT FINED AFTER TAKING CHINESE TOURISTS TO POLICE

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Tourism on Wednesday slapped a fine of NT$150,000 (US$4,570) on a local travel agency who had a dispute with a group of Chinese tourists it was hosting and took them to the police.
Tourism officials said the travel agent did not handle the matter properly, resulting in damage to the nation's image.
The officials urged all travel agents to learn a lesson and to charge reasonable fees, instead of relying on commission from colluding WITH shops and tourist spots.
The officials said the incident, which took place Aug. 1, was the result of the travel agency demanding an extra US$100 from the tourists when it was settling the total bill.

The Chinese leader of the 12-member group said he was not aware that it was a shopping group, which is often charged a cheaper fee and on which the travel agent makes up the losses from commissions collected from the shopping stops, and refused to pay the Taiwan travel agent any extra money when his group members did not buy anything.

The angry tourists said they wanted to return a day earlier, whereupon the travel agent took them to the aviation police bureau at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, claiming that the tourists wanted to abscond. After questioning, police found the tourists had no such intention.
The tourists continued their scheduled itinerary after both sides reached a settlement under mediation from the Travel Agent Association of ROC, Taiwan.
Tourism officials said any discrepancy in regular fees should be discussed between Taiwan travel agents and their Chinese counterparts and should not concern the tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO ASK FOR ARBITRATION IF CONTRACT WITH CHAD BREACHED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said Wednesday that if an oil exploration contract between the company and Chad is breached, it will ask for international arbitration.
CPC officials made the remarks after Taiwan severed ties with its former African ally last Sunday when it discovered that Chad was about to recognize Beijing.
The CPC signed a contract with Chad through its overseas subsidiary, Offshore Petroleum Investment Corp., to obtain the exclusive right in January to dig three prospecting wells in Chad.
CPC officials said it is a business move and should not be affected by the rupture of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Chad.

They said that if the contract is breached in any way, the CPC will ask for international arbitration and that there will be no throwing of money into a "bottomless black hole" as had been claimed by the opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO DONATES NT$13 MILLION TO 'HONEST, SMART' SCHOOLCHILDREN

TEXT.P: AU Optronics Corp. (AUO), a leading maker of LCD products, announced Wednesday it has set up a NT$13 million (US$0.4 million) "honest and smart scholarship" for underprivileged children who need tuition assistance to finish their studies.

The company said it has asked educational authorities in eight cities and counties in central and northern Taiwan, including Hsinchu, Taichung and Miaoli, to help identify highly motivated and high-achieving students from cash-strapped families who may be interested in applying, and to distribute the scholarship.
Chen Hsuan-pin, AUO president, said the company has been upholding its core values of "honesty and straight-forwardness" ever since it entered the LCD business 10 years ago.
Helping nurture more "honest and smart" people is one of the company's social charity targets, Chen added.

AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) is a world-leading manufacturer of thin film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) panels, the most widely used flat panel display technology found in notebook computers, desktop monitors, televisions, digital cameras, portable DVD players, mobile phones and other products.
AUO is the first pure TFT-LCD manufacturer to be successfully listed on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE).
AUO was formed in Sept. 2001 by the merger of Acer Display Technology, Inc. and Unipac Optoelectronics Corporation.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BUST PHONE `PHREAKING' RING

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung city police announced Wednesday that they have uncovered a phone "phreaking" ring and arrested five suspects.

Police said the ring was led by the 36-year-old mastermind surnamed Kuo. The five suspects were nabbed after separate raids in Taipei City, Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County. Also seized in the raids were 10 cell phones, nine cell phone SIM cards, several computers and other tools used in gaining illegal access to other people's phone systems.
According to the police, the stolen phone numbers have been used by other crime rings, including those based in China, to conduct telephone fraud. The police are still tracing members of those rings.
Over the past year, the ring managed to "steal" more than 10,000 phone numbers around the island, selling them to fraud rings in Taiwan and China for NT$3,500 apiece.

Initial investigations show that Kuo was in charge of making contact with the ring's counterparts in China, while other members were responsible for hacking into the telephone systems of residential buildings at dawn when most people were asleep.
Police warned local telephone subscribers to inform the telephone company if they hear any abnormal sound or a pause in their telephone conversations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Lamont Defeats Lieberman in Primary
Ned Lamont, a Connecticut millionaire whose candidacy for the United States Senate won a narrow victory in the Democratic primary last night over the incumbent, Joseph I. Lieberman. Senator Lieberman, a national party leader and the Democratic nominee for vice president in 2000, declared that he was not dropping out of the race, but would instead run for re- election as an independent this fall. Advisers to the senator said that Lieberman was emboldene d to continue in the race because of the narrow margin of Lamont's victory. Yet he might still drop out if the next round of opinion polls showed Lamont well ahead of Lieberman in the fall general election.
Wall Street Journal: Local Force, Lebanon's Army, Key to U.S. Plan, Is Work in Progress
With the United Nations pushing to disarm the militant group Hezbollah, the U.S. and other countries have expressed confidence that Lebanon's army can handle the job with help from a multinational force.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YORK'S HISTORIC PRESERVATION MOVEMENT SERVES AS EXAMPLE FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The historic preservation movement in New York serves as an excellent example for Taiwan, Taiwanese scholars said after a videoconference with a preservation leader Wednesday in Taipei.

Lee Chian-lang, a professor and historic buildings expert, and Ma Yi-kung, a professor at National Tsing Hua University, exchanged views and opinions with Barbaralee Diamonstein-Spielvogel, chairwoman of the Historic Landmarks Preservation Center in a teleconference hosted by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).

The program, in conjunction with the Landmarks of New York photo exhibition now on display at the National Taiwan Museum, aimed to draw upon the experience of New York landmark preservation to tackle the importance of cultural heritage and historic legacies for a city or a country, while making progress toward the contemporary.
"Among American cities, New York is the leader in the preservation of its landmarks, and in the range and quality of its surviving architectural resources," said Diamonstein-Spielvogel.

"This year marks the 40th anniversary of the enactment of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Law. Since its passage on April 19, 1965, the result of an awareness of the increasing loss of New York's iconic historic, architectural and cultural monuments ... New York City has been in the forefront of what has become an established worldwide preservation movement," she said.
New York boasts 1,118 landmarks, 104 interior landmarks, 9 scenic landmarks and 84 historic districts.
While New York preserves interior and scenic landmarks, it seems Taiwan only preserves "buildings" -- although the awareness of historic preservation in Taiwan has been making headway, Lee said.
Lee also mentioned Taiwan should work on "minority preservation," which the New York program paid attention to in preserving some African burial grounds and aboriginal buildings.

"The preservation of our landmarks provides a sense of continuity between the past and present, and an appreciation of the accomplishments that outlast an individual life, " Diamonstein-Spielvogel said.
Representatives from the Department of Cultural Affairs of Taipei City and Taipei County asked about the problem of private property with historic value.
"It's a universal problem [dealing with private property]," she answered. "We should educate the public and let them know that we have only 'temporary custody' of the landmarks."
For compensation, the U.S. government also offers tax breaks for those who donate their private property, she added.

However, Diamonstein-Spielvogel pointed out that designated landmarks in New York's preservation program account for only less than two percent of "the buildings, property or objects that are at least thirty years old and have a special character, esthetic value or meaning" -- New York's definition of a landmark.
It means even New York has a long way to go, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PROPOSES CHANGHUA 'MEATBALL FESTIVAL'

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou suggested Friday that Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan sponsor a "meatball festival" to raise the central county's image.
Ma made the proposal during a meeting with Cho at Taipei City Hall.
Cho was visiting Taipei at the head of a 30-member official delegation to exchange views on urban development.

Urging Cho to take advantage of Changhua's specialty food -- meatballs -- to foster a distinctive image for the county, Ma took pride in Taipei's "beef noodle festival" and encouraged the magistrate to follow suit by sponsoring a festival spotlighting Changhua's own specialty.
Taipei City held the first beef noodle festival last year and will celebrate the second in September, in hopes of making the event an annual festivity.
Ma proposed that Cho devise original and creative ways to make the "meatball festival" into a success.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKER REVIVES BID TO GET ANCESTORS' SOULS FROM JAPAN

TEXT.P: A five-member Taiwanese delegation led by an aboriginal legislator will depart for Japan Thursday in a second bid to have the names of their ancestors who died as Japan's colonial soldiers removed from Japan's national war shrine.

Legislator Kao-Chin Su-mei and the group will file a lawsuit with an Osaka court to have Yasukuni Shrine remove the names of their ancestors, so that their spirits will not be worshipped along with the spirits of Japanese war criminals.

Another group, formed by 45 Taiwanese aborigines, will depart for Japan Sunday to join a protest demonstration in Tokyo that will be staged simultaneously with other demonstrations by some 3,000 people in Taiwan, South Korea and Okinawa to express anger with Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's annual visits to the Yasukuni Shrine.
In June last year, Kao-Chin and fellow aborigines representing nine tribes from Taiwan attempted to visit Yasukuni Shrine to take their ancestors' tablets back to Taiwan, but were barred entry.
The shrine also rejected their requests to perform religious rituals on the property to call home the spirits of their ancestors.

Japanese police even prevented the group from leaving their buses on grounds they had to be separated from Japanese protesters to avoid clashes. The Taiwanese group reportedly received death threats from radical Japanese.
Kao-Chin and other plaintiffs won a court case against Koizumi in September last year when the Osaka High Court ruled that Koizumi had violated the Japanese constitution by visiting Yasukuni Shrine.

Since 2001, Koizumi's successive visits to the shrine have drawn outrage from those countries that fought Japan during and before World War II, because homage paid to war criminals is perceived as a sign that Japan is still clinging to the same militarism that prompted its aggression against other countries.
Koizumi has insisted his visits to the shrine were made as a private citizen.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LOSING SELF-REFLECTING ABILITY BY BUTTRESSING CHEN LEADERSHIP: KMT

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has lost its ability for self-examination as its members are still trying to "consolidate the leadership" of scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian, an opposition leader said Wednesday.

Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou made the remarks after former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh published an open letter urging the president, whom Shih called an "old comrade," to step down so the DPP and Taiwan would have a future.
Shih loves the DPP very much, and he has a special love for the president, Ma said.

"That's why he is urging the DPP to distance itself from the president, but DPP members are acting in a strange way, making it a rallying point that they must stand together to uphold the top leadership."

"Consolidating the top leadership" is a feudalistic term that belongs to the era of Chiang Kai-shek, former leader of the KMT, and yet the DPP is turning it into a precious motto, much to the surprise of current KMT members, Ma said.
"If the DPP insists on a practice the KMT has cast aside, it means the DPP is losing its ability for self-reflection," he added.
For the KMT, he said, "We should not rejoice in the DPP's chaos. Rather, we must remind ourselves never to make a similar mistake."

DOC.HEADLINE: 25 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS CHARGED WITH TAKING BRIBES

TEXT.P: Twenty-five officials assigned by the Keelung Customs Office to work at CKS International Airport may face heavy sentences ranging from 11 to 15 years in prison after the Taoyuan Public Prosecutors' Office charged them with taking bribes Wednesday.

According to the prosecution, the defendants accepted more than NT$30 million (US$915,470) in bribes. In return they allowed import and export companies to provide false or incomplete information on declaration forms in order to evade customs duties.

The prosecution alleged that by accepting the bribes in the form of kickbacks, the accused have neglected their duties and caused more than NT$1 billion worth of revenue losses to the nation's coffers.
As a result, the prosecution is seeking heavy sentences for them, ranging from 11 to 15 years in prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTALISTS REFLECT ON TOURING TAIWAN BY FOOT

TEXT.P: A walk for Taiwan's environment concluded Wednesday after participants reached the final destination -- Providence University in central Taichung County -- after 45 days traveling around the island by foot.
The activity, which was jointly organized by Providence University and the Taiwan Academy of Ecology, is aimed at raising awareness about environmental protection.

With the help and support of people around the island, the 36 participants -- ranging from 13 to 80 years of age -- completed the 1,100-kilometer journey, braving Taiwan's sultry summer temperatures, two typhoons, heavy rains and the hustle and bustle of Suao Hualien Highway.
Chung Ting-mao, a professor of ecology at Providence University, noted that the activity aims to call the public's attention to the environment in which they live.
According to Chung, the hardest part of the journey was not the physical fatigue the walkers suffered, but witnessing the contamination and destruction of the environment.

Chung urged the public to leave nature in its original state, while the government needs to stop developing high-energy consumption industries such as steel refinery plants and naphtha cracker projects, which also emit high quantities of greenhouse gases.

He urged the government to abide by conclusions reached at the country's first energy conference -- by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and assuming its global responsibilities as a member of the international community.
The 80-year-old Chen Kuo-hen said he has come to understood more about Taiwan's environmental problems from the trek, and promised to do it again next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSFORMED SONGJIANG BATTLE ARRAY MARCHES INTO NEW CENTURY

TEXT.P: The Songjiang Battle Array has been a traditional component of Taiwan's religious ceremonies for over two centuries, and will have a new and improved format in the 2006 Asia-Pacific Traditional Arts Festival.
A pair of Songjiang Battle Array groups are among over 20 performing groups from Asian countries at the fifth annual festival, which takes place in Ilan from Aug. 12 - Sep. 3.

The Songjiang Battle Array of National Taitung University and the Creative Songjiang Battle Array of National University of Tainan will try to change society's negative impression of the ritual procession troupe, which has become a major cultural experience in Taiwan.

Over 200 years ago, Taiwanese developed the Songjiang Battle Array to fight against raiding bandits. Today, it is still a major component of religious ceremonies at many temple festivals and has evolved into a type of folk performance combining martial arts, religious dance, folk music and local literature.
Many are now viewing the event in a different light, as its performers used to be dominated by gangsters before the Tourism Bureau and locals worked together to get it back on track.
The Tourism Bureau designated the Songjiang Battle Array as one of the county's 12 major activities, while a couple of Songjiang Battle Array competitions have been held in various townships.
The results have been optimistic. More than a dozen universities have established Songjiang Battle Array groups and bring modern and creative elements to the traditional activity.

At the Asia-Pacific Traditional Arts Festival, the group from Taitung University will showcase the 36 heavenly chieftains of Mount Liang -- characters from the Chinese epic novel the Water Margin, all carrying different weapons and dressed distinctively.

The group from National University of Tainan, the two-time winner of the Neimen Creative Songjiang Battle Array competition, will combine the elements of Songjiang Battle Array, Competitive Dragon Dance, and Lion Dance with Battle Drums, with interaction between the three elements during the show.
As one of the cultural events that attracts the most foreign attention, the Songjiang Battle Array will try to march into another century with the transformation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60 PERCENT HAVE BAD EXPERIENCE WITH TV SHOPPING CHANNELS

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of consumers who have purchased goods from TV shopping channels say the experience was an unpleasant one, according to results of a survey released by the Consumers' Foundation Wednesday.
The online poll was conducted between June 29 and July 7, and collected 132 valid responses from consumers who had bought goods from home shopping channels.
The results showed 59 percent of respondents acknowledging they had a negative experience with TV shopping.
While 38 percent said the goods they received were not the same as those advertised on TV, 20 percent complained the products they received were defective.

Another 14 percent of home shoppers said they had tried to ask questions about the goods they purchased, but had found the shopping channels and product agents were just passing the buck to each other.
Asked why they chose this method of shopping, 68 percent said it was because they happened to see products that they needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER LAWMAKER GETS 4-YEAR JAIL TERM FOR SEXUAL ASSAULT

TEXT.P: A former legislator was sentenced to four years in prison after he was convicted Wednesday of charges of sexually assaulting his Philippine maid in 2004.

Feng Hu-hsiang, a former New Party lawmaker, lost his legal battle at the Taiwan High Court, where judges ruled that the maid's videotapes in which she recanted her previous testimony were insufficiently convincing evidence.
That videotape was Feng's key weapon to prove his innocence. He has tried to use it to appeal a lower court ruling that found him guilty in July 2005.
Feng was accused of assaulting the maid in August 2004, but both sides later reached a settlement under which the maid was paid NT$800,000 and returned to the Philippines.
The court said it handed down the sentence based on forensic evidence and witness statements from all sides.
As for the videotape that was made in the Philippines, the court said several key points were inconsistent with the facts, and therefore deemed inadmissable evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: SANYI WOOD-CARVING FESTIVAL TO SHOWCASE ARTWORK FROM ASIA, AFRICA

TEXT.P: The 2006 Sanyi Woodcarving Festival, one of Taiwan's most important cultural festivals, begins Aug. 19 and is designed to celebrate the beauty and diversity of woodcarving arts, a Miaoli county government official said Wednesday.
Peng Chi-shan, director of the Miaoli county government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, announced at a news conference in Taipei that the festival will take place in the county's Sanyi township.
The festival, now in its 14th year, will showcase more than 200 works by woodcarvers from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Indonesia, Vietnam and 14 African countries, including Ghana and Mali, Peng said.

"This year's activities will feature exotic themes to promote cultural exchanges with Asian and African countries," Peng said, adding that noted woodcarving masters and craftsmen from those countries have been invited to exhibit their work at the festival, which runs until Aug. 27.

With "metamorphosis and a happy life" as the festival's main theme, Peng said that the festival's series of woodcarving demonstrations and training programs will enable interested individuals to experience the beauty of woodcraft and stimulate their interest in the art.

On opening day, Peng said, concerts and dance performances showcasing Taiwan's ethnic and cultural diversity will take place at the main exhibition site at Tzuchi parking lot on Sanyi's famous Shuimei Street, which is dotted with numerous handicraft shops.
Sanyi, a hilly township, has been known internationally as the center of Taiwan's woodcarving and woodworking industry. Its streets are perfumed with the fragrance of freshly cut sawdust.

Along Shuimei Street's half-kilometer stretch, there are some 160 shops selling everything from trinkets to Buddhist statues and furniture. Two other streets -- Sculpture South Street and Shuanghu Old Sculpture Street -- form the heart of Sanyi's wood-carving and woodworking industry, where carving tools designed by local sculptors of olden days are shown on display.

In 1995, the Miaoli Wood Sculpture Museum was established to house sculptures by members of both aboriginal and Han groups in Taiwan, and representing numerous ethnic traditions around the world. Further information about the festival is available at www.31wood.net.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BECOMES INCREASINGLY RELIANT ON CHINESE MARKET: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's reliance on the Chinese market increased further in the first half of this year, with 39.4 percent of its exports going to China and Hong Kong, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Wednesday.

Quoting official tallies, the Cabinet-level council further said Taiwan's trade surplus with China and Hong Kong amounted to US$29.41 billion during the six-month period, marking a 17.3 percent year-on-year growth.
All these figures indicate that Taiwan has not indiscriminately restricted commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, CEPD officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 10 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Aug. 10:
10:00, A changeover ceremony for Taiwan Stock Exchange chairman and president will be held.
10:20, Government Information Office Director-General Cheng Wen-tsang will attend a news conference on the 2006 manga fair to be held at the Taipei World Trade Center's second exhibition hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD UNVEILS HALF-YEAR TRADE ANALYSIS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's reliance on the vast Chinese market increased further in the first half of this year, with 39.4 percent of its exports going to China and Hong Kong, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday.

In a half-year analysis on Taiwan's global trade, the Cabinet-level council also said Taiwan's trade surplus with China and its special administrative region of Hong Kong amounted to US$29.41 billion during the six-month period, marking a 17.3 percent year-on-year growth.
All these numbers indicate that Taiwan has not obstinately restricted commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, CEPD officials said.

According to the CEPD report, Taiwan's exports picked up 16.7 percent in the January-June period from the year-earlier level, while the ratio of its sales to China and Hong Kong surged to 39.4 percent from 38.1 percent recorded a year earlier.
During the same period, imports from China and Hong Kong spiked 15.5 percent and the ratio of imports from the two Chinese-speaking societies advanced to 12.6 percent of the total.

The CEPD report also said Taiwan's exports to the United States posted a 10.8 percent gain in the first half of the year, with the year-on-year growth rate topping 13.5 percent in the second quarter and 7.9 percent in the first quarter.
In contrast, Taiwan's imports from the United States declined 3.8 percent from the year-earlier level, which enabled Taiwan to enjoy a trade surplus of US$4.92 billion, up 64.3 percent year-on-year.

On trade with Europe, Taiwan recorded a 6.4 percent rise in sales to European countries as a whole, with the annual growth rate reaching 8.4 percent in the second quarter and 4.5 percent in the first quarter. The CEPD report attributed the surge to faster-than-expected economic growth in the euro zone.

During the same period, Taiwan's imports from Europe dwindled 3.3 percent. As a result, Taiwan reaped a trade surplus of US$1.75 billion with the continent -- a figure nearly 1.7 times the amount recorded in the same period of last year.

Trade with major Southeast Asian countries, including Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines and Indonesia, also posted a remarkable increase, with exports up 14.8 percent and imports up 15.9 percent. Taiwan raked in US$3.41 billion in trade surplus with its Southeast Asian trade partners, up 11.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSFORMED SONGJIANG BATTLE ARRAY MARCHES INTO NEW CENTURY(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Songjiang Battle Array has been a traditional component of Taiwan's religious ceremonies for over two centuries, and will have a new and improved format in the 2006 Asia-Pacific Traditional Arts Festival.
A pair of Songjiang Battle Array groups are among over 20 performing groups from Asian countries at the fifth annual festival, which takes place in Ilan from Aug. 12 - Sep. 3.

The Songjiang Battle Array of National Taitung University and the Creative Songjiang Battle Array of National University of Tainan will try to change society's negative impression of the ritual procession troupe, which has become a major cultural experience in Taiwan.

Over 200 years ago, Taiwanese developed the Songjiang Battle Array to fight against raiding bandits. Today, it is still a major component of religious ceremonies at many temple festivals and has evolved into a type of folk performance combining martial arts, religious dance, folk music and local literature.
Many are now viewing the event in a different light, as its performers used to be dominated by gangsters before the Tourism Bureau and locals worked together to get it back on track.
The Tourism Bureau designated the Songjiang Battle Array as one of the county's 12 major activities, while a couple of Songjiang Battle Array competitions have been held in various townships.
The results have been optimistic. More than a dozen universities have established Songjiang Battle Array groups and bring modern and creative elements to the traditional activity.

At the Asia-Pacific Traditional Arts Festival, the group from Taitung University will showcase the 36 heavenly chieftains of Mount Liang -- characters from the Chinese epic novel the Water Margin, all carrying different weapons and dressed distinctively.

The group from National University of Tainan, the two-time winner of the Neimen Creative Songjiang Battle Array competition, will combine the elements of Songjiang Battle Array, Competitive Dragon Dance, and Lion Dance with Battle Drums, with interaction between the three elements during the show.
As one of the cultural events that attracts the most foreign attention, the Songjiang Battle Array will try to march into another century with the transformation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60 PERCENT HAVE BAD EXPERIENCE WITH TV SHOPPING CHANNELS(repeat)

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of consumers who have purchased goods from TV shopping channels say the experience was an unpleasant one, according to results of a survey released by the Consumers' Foundation Wednesday.
The online poll was conducted between June 29 and July 7, and collected 132 valid responses from consumers who had bought goods from home shopping channels.
The results showed 59 percent of respondents acknowledging they had a negative experience with TV shopping.
While 38 percent said the goods they received were not the same as those advertised on TV, 20 percent complained the products they received were defective.

Another 14 percent of home shoppers said they had tried to ask questions about the goods they purchased, but had found the shopping channels and product agents were just passing the buck to each other.
Asked why they chose this method of shopping, 68 percent said it was because they happened to see products that they needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER LAWMAKER GETS 4-YEAR JAIL TERM FOR SEXUAL ASSAULT(repeat)

TEXT.P: A former legislator was sentenced to four years in prison after he was convicted Wednesday of charges of sexually assaulting his Philippine maid in 2004.

Feng Hu-hsiang, a former New Party lawmaker, lost his legal battle at the Taiwan High Court, where judges ruled that the maid's videotapes in which she recanted her previous testimony were insufficiently convincing evidence.
That videotape was Feng's key weapon to prove his innocence. He has tried to use it to appeal a lower court ruling that found him guilty in July 2005.
Feng was accused of assaulting the maid in August 2004, but both sides later reached a settlement under which the maid was paid NT$800,000 and returned to the Philippines.
The court said it handed down the sentence based on forensic evidence and witness statements from all sides.
As for the videotape that was made in the Philippines, the court said several key points were inconsistent with the facts, and therefore deemed inadmissable evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 10, or the 17th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1821: Missouri is admitted as the 24th state of the United States.
1846: The Smithsonian Institute is established in Washington as a center for scientific research with a bequest from English scientist James Smithson.
1874: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, is born. His belief in individual freedom led him to reject federal relief for unemployment during the Depression and lost him the 1932 election to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
1894: Varahagiri Venkata Giri, president of India from 1969 to 1974, is born. He was prominent in India's labor movement.
1904: During the Russo-Japanese War, the Russian fleet suffers heavy loses when the Japanese fleet blocks it from escaping from Port Arthur in the Battle of the Yellow Sea.
1913: The Treaty of Bucharest is signed, ending the second Balkan War and partitioning Macedonia among Serbia, Greece, Romania and Bulgaria.
1926: Northwest Airlines is established in Chicago.
1944: Yicheng County in Hupei Province changes its name to Chihchung County in memory of the bravery of Gen. Chang Chih-chung who died in action during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1944: American forces recapture Guam from the Japanese after three weeks of fighting in which only 500 of the 18,000 defending Japanese troops survived and surrendered.
1945: Robert H. Goddard, American pioneer of rocket science, dies at the age of 63. He conducted the first successful launch of a liquid-propellant rocket in 1926. The rocket climbed 184 feet (56 meters) into the air at a speed of about 60 miles (97 kilometers) per hour.
1946: Gen. George C. Marshall, a special envoy of U.S. President Harry Truman to China on a mission to mediate the civil war between the Nationalists and the Chinese communists, issues a statement declaring that his efforts have failed.
1950: U.S. State Department official Karl L. Rankin arrives in Taipei as charge d'affaires of the U.S. Embassy.
1961: Britain applies to join the European Economic Community.
1966: Orbiter I, the first American moon satellite, is launched from Cape Kennedy.
1975: Flight service between the Republic of China and Japan resumes after the ROC government announced on April 20, 1974 the termination of the Taiwan-Japan flights of China Airlines and Japan Airlines.
1979: The newly completed Keelung-Suao Highway is opened to traffic.
1981: The joint meeting of the Second Asian Conference of the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology and the First Asian Conference of the International Council of Psychologists opens in Taipei.
1990: The ROC government declares its support of a United Nations call for world sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.
1993: The New KMT Alliance breaks with the ruling Kuomintang and forms the New Party.
1993: Shih Yueh-po, a Chinese passenger, hijacks a mainland Chinese Boeing 767 passenger plane to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
1998: Some 2,000 people die in floods in China.
1998: Prince Al-Muhtadee Billah, eldest son of Sultan Hassan Bolkiah of Brunei, is proclaimed heir to the throne.
1999: The Republic of China inaugurates Asia's first flight recorder laboratory, allowing local personnel to analyze aircraft flight recorder (black box) data rather than having to send such data to a third country for analysis.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian accuses Beijing of hypocrisy in terms of its definition of "one China," and reiterates Taiwan's rejection of Beijing's demand that it embrace "one China" on Beijing's terms.
2001: After being on death row for almost 10 years, mainland Chinese hijackers Cho Chang-jen and Chiang Hung-chun are executed at the Taipei Prison for kidnap and murder.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to be trusted by one's friends. If a man does not command the obedience of the members of his family, he will not be trusted by his friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSWOMAN LISTED AS SUSPECT IN 'STATE AFFAIRS FUND' CASE

TEXT.P: The owner of a pharmaceutical company was listed as a suspect and banned from leaving the country early Thursday after being questioned by investigators in connection with a controversy over President Chen Shui-bian's use of a special "state affairs fund."
Lee Pi-chun told investigators that she had given Hyatt Hotel invoices to "other people" but that she had no idea why those invoices ended up in the accounting reports of the Presidential Office.

Opposition politicians have charged that the president used "fake invoices" to claim his "state affairs" expenses after the National Audit Office (NAO) under the Control Yuan found irregularities in the Presidential Office accounts.

Lee also admitted that some of the invoices she gave out belonged to her cousin Lee Hui-fen, a businesswoman in Australia who has claimed she would come back to Taiwan to give testimony about how her receipts and invoices had been "abused" by some corrupt officials.

Lee Pi-chun denied that she has ever given the controversial invoices directly to first lady Wu Shu-jen, who might have used them to help her husband claim the "state affairs" expenses. The president has denied that he has ever pocketed a single cent from the fund budgeted for his discretionary use.

Taiwan High Court prosecutors will summon accounting department staff at the Presidential Office and other witnesses as they continue their investigations into alleged irregularities in connection with the "state affairs fund."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKER URGES JAPAN TO MAKE YASUKUNI SHRINE INTO PEACE SHRINE

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan aborigines led by Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei left for Japan Thursday in a fresh attempt to have the Japanese government remove the names of their ancestors from a controversial shrine for war dead.

Kao Chin said that she and the aboriginal representatives whose ancestors were forced to fight for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II will file a new suit with a court in Osaka to have their ancestors' names removed from the Yasukuni Shrine.
They will also demand that the Japanese government set up a committee to investigate the matter and make public the true version of the historical episode, Kao Chin said.
"The aborigines have the right to know how their ancestors died. The Japanese government should not only offer a verbal apology but also apologize with concrete actions," she said.

Also, the legislator said she and the aboriginal representatives will join more than 4,000 protesters from Korea and Japan in staging a demonstration at the Yasukuni Shrine to demand that the names of 13 war criminals be removed from the shrine and that the shrine be transformed into a "peace shrine."
Kao Chin said they plan to return to Japan next year if the Japanese government does not respond to their requests.
Last year, the legislator also led an aboriginal delegation to Japan for a similar purpose.

She won a suit against Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi in September 2005 when the Osaka High Court ruled that Koizumi had violated the Japanese constitution by visiting the Yasukuni Shrine, which is perceived by many as a symbol of Japanese militarism.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORCING PRESIDENT TO RESIGN COULD SPARK SOCIAL UNREST: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A ruling party lawmaker warned Thursday that since Taiwan is a democratic country ruled by law, using non-institutional means to force its president to resign could create social turmoil and affect the daily life of the people.

Yeh Yi-jin, secretary-general of the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislative caucus, issued the warning as former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh was reportedly preparing to kick off a high-profile signature-collecting drive to call for President Chen Shui-bian to step down.

Chen has been dogged by a series of corruption scandals involving his family members and close aides, and now even he himself has become embroiled in suspected irregularities revolving around Presidential Office accounting reports on his use of a special "state affairs fund" budgeted for his discretionary use.
A businesswoman was listed as a suspect early Thursday after being questioned by prosecutors investigating alleged use of "fake invoices" to claim "state affairs" expenses.
Shih, who calls himself an "old comrade" of Chen, published an open letter Wednesday urging Chen to quit so that the DPP and Taiwan "can have a future."

Shih reportedly will stage a signature drive on Saturday at the 228 Peace Memorial Park near the Presidential Office to push for Chen to step down, a campaign that influential figures from legal and medical professions, political circles and other sectors of society are expected to support.

Yeh said that the nation's problems cannot be solved by the resignation of the president, claiming that his resignation would only increase social chaos and affect national security and that a majority of the people agree social unrest would affect their daily life.
She urged Shih to "understand" that all these controversies over the president's integrity and competency have been caused by "political strife" and are not "legal issues."
DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun has said that the president need not step down as he has not violated the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO RESTRICT PRODUCTION, SALE OF MERCURY-CONTAINING BATTERIES

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will restrict the production, import and sale of mercury-containing batteries starting next month to reduce the mercury hazard to the environment and human health, EPA officials said Thursday.

Starting Sept. 1, battery manufacturers and importers must present test reports proving that their products contain less than 5 ppm of mercury before they are permitted to manufacture or import the products, the officials said.
Also, battery sellers will be forbidden from selling or giving away mercury-containing batteries that have not passed EPA inspection, they said.

After the new policy comes into force, the EPA will send officials to inspect and sample batteries sold at supermarkets, night markets and street vendors, with sellers to be subject to fines of up to NT$6,000 (US$183.49) if their products are found to contain an excessive level of mercury, the officials said.
Manufacturers and importers violating the rule can be fined up to NT$300,000 and ordered to recall their products, they added.

The officials said that the new policy will help reduce the circulation of an estimated 217 kg of mercury per year and that 254 kinds of mercury-containing batteries have so far been certified by the EPA.
According to the EPA, many countries around the world have restricted or banned mercury-containing products in light of the hazard they pose to the environment and human health.
While Japan banned the production of mercury-containing batteries in 1995, the European Union has recommended that its member nations ban the sale of batteries containing more than 5 ppm of mercury.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT WANTS TSU TO GET READY FOR PRESIDENT'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui has instructed the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) to get ready for the possible resignation of President Chen Shui-bian, a TSU lawmaker said Thursday.

Lo Chih-ming, who is also TSU secretary-general, quoted Lee as saying that following former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh's call for Chen to step down, DPP members will probably demand the same, so the TSU must be prepared for the eventuality of the president resigning.

In fact, according to Lo, Lee had told his followers in the TSU, which considers Lee as its spiritual leader, to "get fully prepared" last week for Chen's leaving the scene because "a regime that cannot win the hearts of the people will not last long."
The popularity of the president and his DPP has drastically dropped in recent months as Chen has been dogged by a spate of corruption charges against his family members and close aides.
In recent days, the president himself has become embroiled in suspected irregularities revolving around Presidential Office accounting reports on his use of a special "state affairs fund."

Lo quoted Lee as predicting that calls for Chen to step down will rise within the DPP now that Shih has openly made the call and that once his own party members begin demanding his head, the chances of him resigning will become "quite great."
If that should come to be, Lee said the TSU must do what it can to help stabilize the domestic situation, according to Lo.

Lee's main concern, Lo said, is that the pro-independence and Taiwan-sovereignist political forces must remain in power, so the TSU must do all it can to "retain the ruling power of a sovereignist regime."
The TSU is an ally of the DPP in the "pan-green camp," as opposed to the Kuomintang and the People First Party, which form the "pan-blue alliance."

DOC.HEADLINE: CITY COUNCILOR ORDERED TO COMPENSATE FOOD VENDORS FOR FALSE CLAIMS

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court ruled Thursday that Taipei City Councilor Wang Yu-cheng and his assistants should pay a total of NT$3.25 million in compensation to 46 food vendors affected by his falsified claim that some vendors in the city used funeral offerings to prepare food for sale.

According to the verdict, Wang's use of false images as if they were true evidence to back up his claim violated established morality, and such dishonest behavior is not protected by the liability immunity enjoyed by city councilors for their speeches.

In June last year, Wang released film images that he said supported his claim that workers at city government-run funeral parlors were reselling funeral offerings as food ingredients to certain restaurants and food vendors located in the city's Roosevelt Road and Nungan Street areas.

However, it was later discovered that the alleged funeral offering collectors appearing in the film were just actors, prompting Wang to admit that the images were "simulated" and staged by his assistants.

Wang's claim triggered a public scare and reportedly affected the business of many restaurants and food vendors located in the mentioned areas, which later filed a suit against Wang demanding compensation for their loss of business.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON SAOMI'S OUTER RIM SWEEPS ACROSS NORTH, NORTHEAST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The outer rim of Typhoon Saomai swept across northern and northeastern Taiwan Thursday morning, bringing heavy rains and strong winds to the region.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, Typhoon Saomai was located about 180 kilometers east of the northern port city of Keelung at 5 a.m., moving in a northwest direction at a speed of 28 kph and packing sustained winds of 173 kph.

The weather bureau issued Wednesday night a land warning for Typhoon Saomi for Keelung, Yilan, Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli, as well as a sea warning for waters off the north and northeast coast of Taiwan and the northern part of the Taiwan Strait.
In a response to the warning, UNI Airlines canceled all its flights from Taiwan to the frontline island of Matsu Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB LIFTS TYPHOON WARNING FOR TAIWAN PROPER

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) lifted the warning against Typhoon Saomai for Taiwan proper and most of its surrounding waters at 2: 30 p.m. Thursday as the storm system swept toward southeastern China.

CWB meteorologists said Saomai, the Vietnamese word for the planet Venus, was centered about 150 kilometers northeast of the Taiwan-held outlying island of Matsu at 2 p.m. and moving west-northwesterly at a speed of 23 kph.
They added that the typhoon will weaken in strength after making landfall in southeastern China.

The land warning against Saomai remains in effect for Matsu where rainfall and winds became ever heavier and stronger in the hours after noon Thursday, CWB officials said. Matsu lies closer to the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper.
The sea warning against the typhoon also remains in effect for waters off the northern Taiwan coast, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUDITORS UNDER PRESSURE WHILE CHECKING PRESIDENT'S ACCOUNTING BOOKS

TEXT.P: Government auditors felt "great pressure" when they visited the Presidential Office in June to examine its allegedly questionable accounting records, the National Audit Office's (NAO) spokesman said Thursday.

Wang Yung-hsing said when a group of auditing officials went to the Presidential Office June 28, they discovered Hyatt Hotel invoices that were suspected to have been used to claim the president's special "state affairs" expenses.

The president's staff tried to show them three envelopes whose contents the staff claimed "showed what we have done which cannot be disclosed, and so we used Hyatt Hotel invoices for accounting purposes."
The auditors, unsure of the connection between the "secret" contents in the three envelopes and the accounting books, left without seeing what was inside the envelopes, Wang said.

Even though the Presidential Office staff would not allow auditors to take a look at half the files and receipts they asked for, they still found "suspicious" receipts worth more than NT$10 million (US$0.3 million).
There was no record of what the sums shown on the receipts were used for, he explained, adding that the presidential staff simply replied "I forgot" when asked how this money had been spent.
He suggested that the Presidential Office improve its staff's ability to manage and record the use of public funds.
Wang complained that when the auditors asked to make a photocopy of some receipts for further analysis, Presidential Office officials refused.

To fulfill their official duties, he added, the auditors then asked the presidential staff to fill in forms with the serial numbers of Hyatt Hotel receipts and Sogo Department Store vouchers -- another source of controversy over the first family's integrity.

The auditors asked Presidential Office officials to fill in the serial numbers of all Hyatt Hotel invoices, but they provided only numbers of those kept in the accounting office, refusing to provide information about those kept in the president's office, according to Wang.

As regards the Sogo vouchers, Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general to the president, filled in only the numbers of five batches which Cho had shown earlier to the press, although it was evident the Presidential Office was in possession of additional Sogo vouchers.
He would not go into details about these "other" vouchers on grounds they are currently being investigated by the prosecution.

In spite of efforts to carry out the auditing as required by law, Wang said some critics still suspected his colleagues of being "pro-pan-blue alliance" and betting their future on the election of Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou as president in 2008.
In response to the criticism, he said, "This is the most ridiculous joke I've ever heard."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 5.39 points to close at 6,578.61.

The bourse opened at the day's low of 6,555.28 points and closed at the day's high of 6,606.28 points during trading. A total of 3.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$100.16 billion (US$3.07 billion).
