DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGHUA DUCK FARMERS WANT GOVERNMENT AID OVER DIOXIN POLLUTION

TEXT.P: A group of duck farmers from Changhua county in central Taiwan demanded Thursday that the government set up a task force to help cope with the aftermath of an incident involving dioxin pollution that occurred in late 2004.

The group of farmers issued the appeal at a coordination meeting held by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Lin Chan-ming and Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) lawmaker Chen Ching-ting. Officials from the Executive Yuan, the Council of Agriculture (COA) and the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) were also invited to take part.

The Changhua duck farmers complained about the government's failure to set forth a concrete solution to help them overcome their difficulties when they were forced to stop raising ducks and destroy all duck eggs after a case of dioxin pollution broke out in Hsiensi township in late 2004.

According to the duck farmers, the Changhua County Government did not come up with a compensation package until September 2005, when it offered farmers NT$12 per duck by requiring them not to raise any during a four-month period.

But they pointed out that the government did not continue offering monetary compensation as required by law at a time when farmers were allowed to begin raising ducks again in July this year, they said, adding that the central government should also grant the local government the right to make environmental impact assessments.

Chen asked the government whether the dioxin pollution has now been fully eradicated in Hsiensi township, whether it is safe to eat duck meat and eggs and if duck farmers are leading a satisfactory life.

Chen also suggested that the government establish a task force to carry out monthly inspections of duck farms and nearby sources of pollution to secure a safe environment that is free from pollution for the public.

If the government remains inactive in responding to the duck farmers' requirements after a limited period of time, lawmakers attending the coordination meeting claimed that they would boycott the 2006 budgets for the EPA and other relevant agencies.

According to COA officials, they have developed a new and advanced nurturing technology which would help duck raisers reduce dioxin pollution. But the high cost of employing the technology is still a big problem, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.191 to close at NT$32.586.
A total of US$1.12 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.777 and hit a low of NT$32.576.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune: Terror plot thwarted in Britain.
British authorities thwarted a plot to blow up "a number of aircraft" in mid-flight between the U.S. and U.K. using explosives smuggled in hand baggage, police said Thursday. Security at British airports was increased and additional measures - including a ban on all hand luggage - were put in place on all flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Britain facing a new breed of fascist, warns Reid
Britain is facing a new breed of "unconstrained" terrorists who have access to chemical and biological weapons to cause mass destruction, the Home Secretary warned today.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DENIES ANY PRESSURING OF AUDITORS

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office denied Thursday that the presidential staff had placed any pressures on National Audit Office (NAO) officials or refused their requests to check files related to their auditing inspection in June.
NAO spokesman Wang Yung-hsing said the auditors felt "great pressure" when they visited the Presidential Office June 28 to examine its allegedly questionable accounting records.

Wang complained that when auditors asked to make a photocopy of some receipts for further analysis, the president's staff refused. The prosecution is probing whether the allegedly illegal receipts have been used to claim special "state affairs" expenses.
A presidential staff member explained that the request was turned down because the receipts NAO officials tried to photocopy involved "classified information."
Although the Presidential Office refused to allow a photocopy to be made, it did permit the auditors to examine the sensitive receipts, the staff member said.
In fact, he noted, the Presidential Office was quite cooperative with NAO officials and "absolutely did not put any pressure on them."

As to why they still felt pressure, he said it might have been caused by the two sides' different understandings of the institution and that the Presidential Office hopes to narrow these differences by building a more transparent mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFLATION BOOSTS MARKET FOR OUTSOURCED JOBS

TEXT.P: More office workers are looking for outsourced jobs in an attempt to supplement their income as consumer prices in the country continue to rise, an online employment service provider said Thursday.

According to Tien Chu-cheng, the manager of an outsource jobs Web site operated by 104 Job Bank, the number of job-seeking members on the site increased 6.3 percent in July compared to June, with as many as 75 percent of job-seekers being office workers looking for moonlighting opportunities.

The number of outsourced jobs available in July also saw a 6.3 percent increase, with job openings in the category of "animated graphics/design" accounting for the largest proportion at 43.1 percent, Tien said.
While job openings in the category of "Internet/information technology" accounted for 31.1 percent, those in the category of "writing/publishing" accounted for 14.5 percent, Tien said.

Tien said thanks to the recovery of the real estate market in the past two years, many housing developers are outsourcing their achitectural graphic and design projects, with candidates for the position required to be familiar with software such as Corel Draw and AutoCAD.
The increasingly popular trend of online shopping among Taiwanese women has also boosted the demand for Web designers, Tien said.

For example, there is an outsourced project offering NT$150,000 to NT$200,000 for the establishment of a shopping Web site for women, and there is also another project offering NT$10,000 to NT$50,000 for the planning and design of a cosmetics shopping Web site, he said.
Meanwhile, the demand for English and Korean translators is also rising due to the popularity of foreign TV drama series, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF URGES LEGISLATORS, RAP SINGER TO SETTLE OUT OF COURT

TEXT.P: Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsang expressed hope Thursday that several legislators and a rap singer could reach an out of court settlement in a defamation lawsuit.
Cheng made the remarks after the leader of a rap band was indicted by the Taipei Prosecutor's Office on charge of damaging the reputation of several legislators in his songs.

The singer, Jeff Huang, argued he was only expressing dissatisfaction over a proposal by several legislators to amend copyright laws in 2003, which if passed would have allowed artists to receive some compensation for their work when downloaded by clients at legal download Web sites, while operators would also have to pay a certain percentage of their benefits to copyright holders.
Huang found the Web sites' compensation "trivial, " claiming such Web sites infringe artists' intellectual property rights.

Last year, a not-guilty ruling by the court on the music download Web site ezPeer ignited Huang's fury. Huang then composed a song in which he directly named those legislators, saying they were bribed by Web site operators and therefore "murdering" Taiwan's music industry.

In response to Huang's lyrics, the legislators, including former legislator Chiu Yi-ying, who is now a deputy head of the Council for Hakka Affairs, decided to sue Huang for damages to their reputation.

Noting the amendment proposal was aimed at protecting artists' intellectual property rights, Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang said Huang can express his difference of opinion in this regard but it is inappropriate for him to criticize the legislators in such a "radical" way.
For his part, Cheng said establishing legal download Web sites is the government's set policy, which he said is a "benign development in the music industry."
He urged people in all social quarters to discuss the proposed legal amendment with peace and patience.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY ORGANIZING FOOD & BEER FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Government is planning to hold a beer and food festival at Chichin port every weekend starting this week, allowing the public to get a taste of its delicious seafood and beer in a cozy context, according to a city government spokesman.

The municipal Marine Bureau has been renovating surrounding areas of Chichin port on one of the islets off Kaohsiung city, the spokesman said, adding that the city government hopes to transform the fishing port into a multi-functional park suitable for a host of leisure activities.

In preparation for the food and beer festival's opening this coming Saturday, the bureau has grown flowers and plants and installed large-scale decorations in public spaces near Chichin fishing port, the spokesman said.

Starting Aug. 12, visitors will be able to enjoy seafood such as squid, tuna and sanma -- three of the most popular types of fish in the Kaohsiung area -- outdoors in garden-like surroundings, with a summer breeze and seascape, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT POSTPONING ENTRY VISA APPLICATION FOR BEIJING OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has decided to postpone applying for an entry visa for a senior Beijing official due to the current cross-Taiwan Strait relations following the breaking of Taiwan-Chad diplomatic relations, a party spokesman said Thursday.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy director of the KMT Policy Coordination Committee, said that the party will put the application on hold as the government has made it clear that Beijing must apologize to Taiwan over the Chad issue before Chen Yunlin, head of the Communist Party of China's (CPC's) Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, can visit Taiwan.

Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that the public must not harbor any illusions about China, calling the rupture in Taiwan-Chad ties a Beijing scheme -- the latest setback for Taiwan in its diplomatic battle against China.
The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) a day earlier demanded an explanation from Beijing over its forging of diplomatic relations with Chad at the expense of Taiwan.
The KMT was originally slated to submit a visa application for Chen with the MAC Aug. 13 prior to his plan to take part in a KMT-sponsored agricultural seminar in Taiwan Oct. 13.

According to Chang, the government has made it clear that it will boycott the KMT-CPC agricultural seminar. Against this backdrop, the KMT has decided not to apply for an entry visa application for Chen for the time being until the cross-strait situation has cooled down, he said.
"The KMT has always tried to serve as a bridge between Taiwan and China, but the government has failed to recognize this, " Chang claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUA WILL HONOR COOPERATIVE PROJECTS WITH TAIWAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: A foreign ministry official said Thursday that regardless of which candidate wins Nicaragua's next presidential election, the country's cooperative projects with Taiwan will be honored.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu was responding to media reports that if the Sandinista National Liberation Front (SNLF), Nacaragua's opposition party, wins the Nov. 5 presidential election, the Central American country will switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

The reports quoted an SNLF National Assembly member as saying in late June that if the presidency is won by Daniel Ortega, the SNLF secretary-general who is also the party's candidate for the upcoming presidential election, China will send a high-level delegation to attend his inauguration in preparation for resumption of bilateral diplomatic ties.
Commenting on the reports, Lu said that since Nicaragua is now a democracy, the election results will logically have an impact on the country's major policies.

"The MOFA will keep a close watch on developments in Nicaragua, particularly the platforms and policy goals of its various political parties. And we are convinced that whoever wins the Nicaraguan presidency will not neglect or ignore the many cooperative projects with Taiwan, as well as Taiwanese investments in the country," Lu said.

Nicaragua's diplomatic relationship with the Republic of China dates back to the 1930s, but the country switched its diplomatic recognition to the People's Republic of China in 1985. In 1990, Nicaragua resumed diplomatic ties with the ROC and has since maintained close cooperation with Taiwan in many fields, from agriculture, education, public health to infrastructure construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE AMOUNT OF SUBSTANDARD PESTICIDES SEIZED IN CHIAYI

TEXT.P: More than 10 metric tons of over 60 categories of fake and substandard pesticides were seized by Investigation Bureau agents Thursday in southern Taiwan's Chiayi county.

According to a bureau spokesman, prosecutors from the Chiayi District Prosecutor's Office, quarantine officials from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) and local county government agricultural officials took part in a series of raids on pharmacies in the Chiayi area.

The seizure is the largest since May, when the Investigation Bureau launched a large-scale crackdown on fake and substandard pesticides, nabbing more than 50 metric tons of toxic substances in the Taipei, Tainan and Chiayi areas, the spokesman said.

Some of the illicit and bootleg drugs and pesticides seized by the investigation agents and prosecutors were found to contain various strong toxic substances, such as Nitrofen, ingestion of which can lead to deformed fetuses and liver cancer, the spokesman said.
The COA has banned the use, manufacture and importation of Nitrofen since the 1980s.

A pharmacy store owner, Chang Hui-chung, was detained in Putsu city in Thursday's operation and was transferred to the Chiayi Prosecutor's Office later that day for questioning to find out his supply sources and the distribution network.
Chang is alleged to have been selling fake pesticides at his pharmacy, according to information collected by the investigators.
The Ministry of Justice ordered an across the board crackdown in view of rampant sales of bootleg pesticides.

DOC.HEADLINE: BTCO ISSUES NOTICE AFTER TERROR PLOT TO BLOW UP PLANES

TEXT.P: The British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) issued an urgent notice Thursday about new boarding arrangements for passengers at U.K. airports after a terrorist plot to blow up planes in mid-flight from the U.K. to the U.S. was foiled.

The BTCO, the U.K.'s representative office in Taiwan, said in the press release that passengers boarding flights at any U.K. airport will be asked to pass through an airport security search point carrying only a single (ideally transparent) plastic carrier bag.
And only the following items may be carried in pockets:
-- Pocket-size wallets and pocket-size purses plus contents (for example money, credit cards, identity cards etc (not handbags).
-- Travel documents essential for the journey.
-- Prescription medicines and medical items sufficient and essential for the flight, except in liquid form or unless verified as authentic.
-- Spectacles and sunglasses, without cases.
-- Contact lens holders, without bottles of solution.
-- For those travelling with an infant: baby food, milk and sanitary items sufficient and essential for the flight.
-- Female sanitary items sufficient and essential for the flight, if unboxed.
-- Tissues (unboxed) and/or handkerchiefs.
-- Keys (but no electrical key fobs).

All passengers must be hand-searched, and their footwear and all items they are carrying must be X-rayed. Baby prams and walking aids must be X-ray screened, and only airport-provided wheelchairs may pass through the screening point.

In addition to the above, all passengers boarding flights to the USA and all items they are carrying, including those acquired after the central screening point, must be subjected to a secondary search at the boarding gate.
Any liquids must be taken from the passenger.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO SUPPORTS PTS DECISION TO BROADCAST YANKEES BASEBALL GAMES

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) backed the Taiwan Public Television Service (PTS) Thursday in its decision to broadcast Major League baseball matches in which New York Yankee's Taiwanese pitcher Wang Chien-ming plays a major role.
GIO Director-General Cheng Wen-tsan said Wang, who has posted 13 wins in the 2006 season, is "Taiwan's pride" and that the government fully supports PTS broadcasting games in which he pitches.
Cheng claimed that it serves public interests better for PTS to broadcast Yankees games because any baseball games televised live will not be interrupted by commercials.
PBS was criticized earlier this week for paying expensive television rights fees to focus the limelight on Wang, while not paying enough attention to local baseball.
PBS defended itself, saying it did so because of a need to serve the public interest.

Wang, 26, a second-year starting pitcher for the Yankees, has earned the status of a "top 10" pitcher in the American League of Professional Baseball. His record of 13 wins and four losses this season ties him with four other pitchers for the second highest number of wins in Major League baseball.
Wang is the third Taiwanese recruited into the Major League but is apparently the most successful. The others are Dodgers outfielder Chin-Feng Chen and Rockies pitcher Chin-hui Tsao.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN PROFESSIONAL BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT TO BEGIN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Five top Asian basketball teams have gathered in Taipei for the Asian Professional Basketball (APB) tournament, which will be played from Aug. 11-19, to vie for the position as the top club in Asia.
The Taiwan national team, the only non-club participant, will be joined by four teams from Japan, Korea, the Philippines and Australia in the nine-day, 18-game tournament.

The visiting teams include Niigata Albirex of the Basketball Japan League, the LG Sakers of the Korean Basketball League, the San Miguel Beermen of the Philippines Basketball Association, and the Perth Wildcats of Australia's National Basketball League.
The APB is patterned after the Asia Series of professional baseball.

The Taiwan team, which will use the tournament as part of its preparations for the Asian Games in Doha, Qatar, will face the LG Sakers on the opening day, while the Perth Wildcats will take on Niigata Albirex.
The inaugural game will be played at the Taipei Physical Education Gymnasium.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DIPLOMATS URGED NOT TO BE DAUNTED BY SETBACK

TEXT.P: Former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, who is now a legislator, urged Taiwanese diplomats posted abroad to show faith in Taiwan and to pursue the country's highest interest.
Chang, who is visiting South Africa, made the remarks after being informed about the operations of the Taipei Liaison Office in Johannesburg by Hsu Huai-tsung, head of the office.

Noting that Taiwan's severance Sunday of official ties with Chad has placed some pressures on the nation's diplomats abroad, Chang urged them not to be daunted by the setback and instead work even harder for the country's best interest by working with Taiwanese expatriates there.
Hsu also noted their office is expected to handle the interests of some 10,000 Taiwanese expatriates residing in six provinces of South Africa -- 26 times the area of Taiwan's territory.
With the office's help, Hsu added, South African police could solve a homicide case in 10 hours in which several members of a Taiwanese family were killed.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Aircraft Bomb Plot Thwarted in Britain
British authorities said Thursday that they had thwarted a terrorist plot to blow up multiple airliners travelling between Britain and the United States, creating "mass murder on an unimaginable scale." The police said they had arrested 21 people in connection with the plot, which apparently involved plans to smuggle explosives onto aircraft in hand luggage. In response, flights into London Heathrow Airport were canceled and airlines banned hand luggage on departing planes, causing chaos and long delays.
Wall Street Journal: Diplomatic Moves, Rice Pushes Envoys To Spend Time In Hardship Posts
The Bush administration is pushing a very grass-roots diplomacy to make up for the diplomatic damage done by the Iraq war and to try and leave the U.S. better positioned to respond to -- and possibly even pre-empt -- conflagrations of the future. Instead of dictating terms from on high, the administration is trying to nudge along reforms from below, often far from national capitals. And that, goes the new logic, requires making the U.S. diplomatic corps more agile and less hemmed in by the high walls and bureaucracies of the traditional embassy. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has quietly made the push a central plank of the administration's second-term drive to promote ground-level change in some of the world's remotest nooks and crannies.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMIC FAIR OPENS AT TAIPEI WORLD TRADE CENTER

TEXT.P: The seventh Comic Exhibition was inaugurated Thursday at Taipei World Trade Center, with Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsang and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presiding over the opening.
Despite the threat of a typhoon, many comic fans had lined up since late Wednesday to enter the exhibition hall.
According to the organizer, 75,000 people visited the exhibition on the first day, including former Premier Frank Hsieh.
Comic book publishers said they were satisfied with Thursday's sales, with some companies already selling a third of their stock. The fair will run through Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ECONOMICS MINISTER NAMES TWO DEPUTIES

TEXT.P: Shih Yen-shiang, an administrative deputy minister of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), was promoted to the ministry's second- highest post Thursday to serve as its political deputy minister.
Shih, 56, will fill the post left vacant by Chen Ruey-long who took over as minister of economic affairs a day earlier.
The post to be vacated by Shih's promotion will be filled by Fadah Hsieh, a vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the two new appointments were decided after extensive discussions between Premier Su Tseng-chang and the new economics minister.

Shih, who has a doctorate in chemistry from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has worked his way up in the MOEA since his return from the United States. His previous posts at the ministry included director of the Industrial Development Bureau and director of the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration.

Hsieh, 56, who holds a master's degree from National Chengchi University's Graduate Institute of Economics, worked at Taiwan's overseas offices and at the MOEA head office in Taipei before being transferred to the CEPD in 2002.

Hsieh likened his four-year stint at the CEPD as an "advanced study journey" that has helped expand his vision and perspective, as the CEPD is charged with charting the country's overall economic development and various key projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUA NAN COMMERCIAL BANK ALLOWED TO SET UP OFFICE IN HANOI

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) approved Thursday an application by the Hua Nan Commercial Bank to set up a liaison office in Hanoi, capital of Vietnam.

According to FSC officials, the bank has operated a liaison office in Ho Chih Minh City in southern Vietnam for several years, and applied for permission from the Vietnamese authorities to upgrade its office in that city into a branch. Vietnam has agreed to the application in principle and Hua Nan is preparing for the branch's formal inauguration later this year.
Taiwan has replaced Singapore as Vietnam's largest source of foreign capital, with investments accumulating to US$8 billion, according to FSC Vice Minister Chang Hsiou-lien.
Predicting that more Taiwanese enterprises will invest in Vietnam, the Hua Nan Commercial Bank plans to make its service network more complete by adding the Hanoi office, a bank official said.
According to an FSC official, Taiwanese banks have already set up six branches, one subsidiary and 10 representative offices in Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI POLICE CRACK ROBBERY RING, ARREST FOUR SUSPECTS

TEXT.P: Police in the southern city of Chiayi cracked a robbery ring Wednesday night, arresting four men who are suspected of having committed a series of household robberies in the Chiayi area.

According to the police, the victims had reported that the robbery ring consisted of four men who dressed in black and were armed with black handguns and knifes. The group was described as having committed the robberies "with military precision."

After two recent household robberies July 2 and July 20, police screened thousands of videotapes from close-circuit TV cameras in the city and pinpointed Tsai Cheng-ting, a 27-year-old Chiayi resident, as the suspected ringleader.

Led by Tsao Ho-yi, a prosecutor from the Chiayi Public Prosecutor's Office, police arrested Tsai and the other members of the ring -- Hsu Huan-kai, 36; Yang Ying-chan, 24; and Huang Yi-hau, 19 -- and seized three handguns and four samurai swords.
They were immediately referred to the Chiayi Public Prosecutor's Office.
A police spokesman said the ring members divided the work among themselves and even used rehearsals to sharpen their team effectiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN TO LAUNCH DRIVE TO DEPOSE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday he will gauge public opinion by launching a fundraising drive to see how badly the people want to oust President Chen Shui-bian, who is dogged by a series of corruption and embezzlement scandals implicating himself, his family members and senior aides.

Shih Ming-teh, who served as DPP chairman from 1993 to 1996, said he will announce in detail Saturday his plan to call on 1 million people in Taiwan to each make a donation of NT$100 (US$3) -- to a fund to finance a campaign to force Chen to step down.

A bank account will be opened to accept donations from Aug. 14, Shih said, adding that if the target of 1 million donors can be reached within one month, the campaign to depose Chen will be launched Sept. 9 with daily sit-ins by protesters in front of the Presidential Office.
He said that if the target of 1 million can be achieved sooner, the campaign will also start to roll earlier than planned.

Shih became a focus of national attention this week after he sent a widely publicized letter to the president, urging him to step down so that his party and the nation "will not be doomed to collapse."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICE IN LONDON FORMS EMERGENCY RESPONSE TASK FORCE
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By J. J. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in London has set up an emergency response task force after British police uncovered an alleged terrorist plot to blow up trans-Atlantic flights in mid-air, an official said Thursday.

Edgar Lin, Taiwan's top representative in Britain, said the representative office has informed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the newest British security measures adopted after police uncovered the plot to blow up several aircraft in flight to the United States using explosives smuggled in hand luggage.

As the foiled plot came at a peak season for the 14,000-plus Taiwanese expatriates and students in Britain to return to Taiwan and for Taiwan citizens to travel to Britain, Lin said the representative office will offer round-the-clock information services and emergency assistance to ROC passport holders in need.

Lin reminded Taiwan citizens intending to travel to Britain to be careful of their personal safety. At Lin's recommendation, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued a yellow-level travel advisory for Britain-bound Taiwan citizens, urging them to remain vigilant while traveling in the U.K.

Would-be travelers should also acquaint themselves with the newest British boarding arrangements for air passengers, Lin said, adding that only a few items may be carried in the pockets, such as travel documents essential for the journey, pocket-size wallets and pocket-size purses plus contents (for example money, credit cards and identity cards.)
The representative office's emergency phone number is 44-7768-938-765 and the number for office hours is 44-20-7881-2650.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGERS BOUND FOR U.S., U.K. SUBJECT TO STRICTER SECURITY CHECKS

TEXT.P: Administrators at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, decided Thursday to set up a special boarding area for aircraft bound for the United States and the United Kingdom to facilitate security inspections for their passengers.
The airport administration announced the new measure after British police uncovered a suspected terrorist plot earlier in the day to blow up trans-Atlantic flights in mid-air.
Besides tightening overall security measures at the airport, a special boarding area has been designated for aircraft bound for the U.S. and the U.K., CKS Airport officials said.

In addition to receiving normal security inspections, passengers bound for the U.K. and the U.S. will be required to undergo another round of security inspections, inclduing carry-on luggage and body inspections, at the special boarding zone prior to getting aboard the aircraft.
According to the newest U.K. security requirements, passengers are banned from carrying hand luggage, liquids and all but a handful of essential items.

Major Asian airlines also tightened security on flights bound for Britain and the United States but avoided significant delays after British police uncovered the alleged terrorist plot to bomb aircraft out of the sky.

In some of the tightest restrictions ever placed on air travelers, Britain's Department of Transport said passengers traveling from British airports could carry only a clear plastic carrier bag containing:
--pocket-sized wallets and purses containing money, ID and credit cards
--passports and tickets
--prescription medicines and medical items
--glasses and sunglasses, but not their cases
--contact lens holders, but not the lens solution
--baby formula and milk _ but the contents of each bottle must
be tasted by the passenger
--diapers, wipes, creams for infants
--tampons, sanitary and tissues, but not their boxes --keys
Prohibited items:
--liquids except medicine verified as authentic. The U.S. government also has banned all liquids and gels from flights, including toothpaste, makeup, suntan lotion.
--food bought at the airport
--handbags
--all electrical and battery-powered items, including laptop
computers, mobile phones and iPods.
--electric key fobs
--wheelchairs except those provided by the airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH COURT REJECTS APPEAL AGAINST TDC SUSPECTS' BAIL RULING

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court rejected Thursday a third appeal by the Taipei Prosecutor's Office against a lower court ruling that freed on bail three indicted insider trading suspects, including President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law.

The high court said in its latest ruling that the three suspects in the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stock insider trading scandal do not warrent a "preventive detention" prescribed in Article 101 of the Criminal Procedure Law. As a result, the high court rejected prosecutors' appeal seeking continued detention of the trio.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 11 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, Aug. 11:
11:00, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference on Taiwan's U.N. bid.
16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference.
18:30, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a dinner meeting of a major business association at Grand Formosa Regent Hotel.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPEAL FOR CONTINUED DETENTION OF TDC SUSPECTS REJECTED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court rejected Thursday a third appeal by prosecutors against a lower court ruling that freed on bail three indicted insider trading suspects, including President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming.

The disapproval marked a dramatic departure from the high court's previous views. In its response to the prosecutors' two previous appeals, the high court rescinded the Taipei District Court's bail ruling for the three suspects in the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stock insider trading scandal and demanded it take a second look at the case.

In its latest ruling, the high court argued that the three suspects do not warrent a "preventive detention" mandated in Article 101 of the Code of Criminal Procedure that says the accused may be detained after examination if there are facts sufficient to justify an apprehension that they may abscond, or destroy, forge or alter evidence, or conspire with a co-offender or witness.

As to whether the trio meet the requirements for continued detention in congruent with conditions set forth for those facing felony charges, the high court said it's up to the discretion of the district court.

Since the district court has explained in detail why it sees no need to continue holding the three suspecs in custody, the high court said the Taipei Prosecutor's Office's defiance against the lower court's bail ruling lacks justification.

Moreover, the high court went on, prosecutors have concluded investigations and indicted the three suspects after having held more than 150 hearings in which the three suspects and numerous witnessed had been subpoenaed and cross-examined.

On prosecutors' argument that if Chao remains free, he may collude with other suspects or witnesses to confront or overturn the insider trading charge, the high court contended that should that be the case, prosecutors would have been guilty of malfeasance for failing to get to the bottom before indicting the suspects.

Under the current criminal procedure system, the high court continued that prosecutors can cross-examine witnesses after they make direct testimonies. If witnesses make false testimonies, they will face perjury charges.

As to prosecutors' misgivings that Chao may jump bail or flee the country because he purchased a flight ticket to Japan when the TDC scandal just came to light, the high court said although Chao indeed had a Japan-bound ticket dated May 20, he also booked a seat for return five days later.
Given Chao's high-profile status, the high court claimed that it's hardly possible for Chao to flee abroad.

On the prosecuttors' argument that the bail amounts for two accomplices -- businessman Yu Shih-yi and former TDC Chairman Su Teh-chien -- are disproportionate to the profits from their illegal stock trading, the high court said there have been no established bail amount calculating formula.
Noting that bail is neither damages nor fines, the high court said the main purpose of bail deposits is to ensure smooth proceeding of follow-up judicial procedures.

Claiming the bail amounts demanded by the lower court for the two suspects are not below the average figure, the high court said that judging from the fact that the defendants have consistently appeared in court on time so far, it sees no flaws in the lower court's ruling on bail amounts.

The high court made the ruling in response to the prosecutors' Aug. 7 appeal seeking to have the three suspects, or Chao in particular, detained again on the ground that their crime warrants continued detention in line with existing legal provisions.

Prosecutors formally indicted Chao and the two accomplices July 10 on charges of using insider information to profit from TDC stock dealings. In the indictment, prosecutors recommended that Chao and former TDC Chairman Su Teh-chien be sentenced to eight years behind bars, with 10 years for businessman You Shih-yi.
In the evening of that same day, Chao and You were freed on NT$10 million bail and Su on NT$5 million bail.

The prosecutor's office appealed to the high court July 14, seeking to have the trio detained once again. In response to the first appeal, the high court ruled July 17 that the lower court had to review the case again because its previous decision was flawed.

In its second ruling issued July 20, the district court stuck to its decision on allowing the trio to remain free, but raised bail for Chao to NT$17 million from the original NT$10 million, while maintaining that bail for the other two suspects should remain the same at NT$10 million and NT$5 million, respectively.
The prosecutor's office re-appealed the case July 26 to try to have the trio detained again. On July 28, the high court rescinded the district court's second ruling and demanded a further review.
On July 31, the district court upheld its second ruling on allowing the trio to remain free on bail.

In is third appeal, the prosecutor's office rebutted the district court's argument that as insider trading suspects are normally unlikely to repeat their illegal stock trading practice once their case are exposed, they need not be detained in the wake of their indictment.

Quoting the Criminal Procedure Law, the prosecutor's office said that any suspect who faces a recommendation of five years behind bars can be kept in custody pending trial regardless whether he or she is likely to repeat previous criminal acts.
In the TDC case, the prosecutor's office argued that as all the three suspects deserve a minimum seven-year prison term, the high court should invalidate the district court's bail ruling.
While granting bail, the district court banned the trio from leaving the country or changing residence without due notice.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN TO LAUNCH DRIVE TO DEPOSE PRESIDENT(repeat)

TEXT.P: A former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday he will gauge public opinion by launching a fundraising drive to see how badly the people want to oust President Chen Shui-bian, who is dogged by a series of corruption and embezzlement scandals implicating himself, his family members and senior aides.

Shih Ming-teh, who served as DPP chairman from 1993 to 1996, said he will announce in detail Saturday his plan to call on 1 million people in Taiwan to each make a donation of NT$100 (US$3) -- to a fund to finance a campaign to force Chen to step down.

A bank account will be opened to accept donations from Aug. 14, Shih said, adding that if the target of 1 million donors can be reached within one month, the campaign to depose Chen will be launched Sept. 9 with daily sit-ins by protesters in front of the Presidential Office.
He said that if the target of 1 million can be achieved sooner, the campaign will also start to roll earlier than planned.

Shih became a focus of national attention this week after he sent a widely publicized letter to the president, urging him to step down so that his party and the nation "will not be doomed to collapse."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICE IN LONDON FORMS EMERGENCY RESPONSE TASK FORCE(repeat)
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By J. J. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in London has set up an emergency response task force after British police uncovered an alleged terrorist plot to blow up trans-Atlantic flights in mid-air, an official said Thursday.

Edgar Lin, Taiwan's top representative in Britain, said the representative office has informed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the newest British security measures adopted after police uncovered the plot to blow up several aircraft in flight to the United States using explosives smuggled in hand luggage.

As the foiled plot came at a peak season for the 14,000-plus Taiwanese expatriates and students in Britain to return to Taiwan and for Taiwan citizens to travel to Britain, Lin said the representative office will offer round-the-clock information services and emergency assistance to ROC passport holders in need.

Lin reminded Taiwan citizens intending to travel to Britain to be careful of their personal safety. At Lin's recommendation, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued a yellow-level travel advisory for Britain-bound Taiwan citizens, urging them to remain vigilant while traveling in the U.K.

Would-be travelers should also acquaint themselves with the newest British boarding arrangements for air passengers, Lin said, adding that only a few items may be carried in the pockets, such as travel documents essential for the journey, pocket-size wallets and pocket-size purses plus contents (for example money, credit cards and identity cards.)
The representative office's emergency phone number is 44-7768-938-765 and the number for office hours is 44-20-7881-2650.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGERS BOUND FOR U.S., U.K. SUBJECT TO STRICTER SECURITY CHECKS(repeat)

TEXT.P: Administrators at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, decided Thursday to set up a special boarding area for aircraft bound for the United States and the United Kingdom to facilitate security inspections for their passengers.
The airport administration announced the new measure after British police uncovered a suspected terrorist plot earlier in the day to blow up trans-Atlantic flights in mid-air.
Besides tightening overall security measures at the airport, a special boarding area has been designated for aircraft bound for the U.S. and the U.K., CKS Airport officials said.

In addition to receiving normal security inspections, passengers bound for the U.K. and the U.S. will be required to undergo another round of security inspections, inclduing carry-on luggage and body inspections, at the special boarding zone prior to getting aboard the aircraft.
According to the newest U.K. security requirements, passengers are banned from carrying hand luggage, liquids and all but a handful of essential items.

Major Asian airlines also tightened security on flights bound for Britain and the United States but avoided significant delays after British police uncovered the alleged terrorist plot to bomb aircraft out of the sky.

In some of the tightest restrictions ever placed on air travelers, Britain's Department of Transport said passengers traveling from British airports could carry only a clear plastic carrier bag containing:
--pocket-sized wallets and purses containing money, ID and credit cards
--passports and tickets
--prescription medicines and medical items
--glasses and sunglasses, but not their cases
--contact lens holders, but not the lens solution
--baby formula and milk _ but the contents of each bottle must
be tasted by the passenger
--diapers, wipes, creams for infants
--tampons, sanitary and tissues, but not their boxes --keys
Prohibited items:
--liquids except medicine verified as authentic. The U.S. government also has banned all liquids and gels from flights, including toothpaste, makeup, suntan lotion.
--food bought at the airport
--handbags
--all electrical and battery-powered items, including laptop
computers, mobile phones and iPods.
--electric key fobs
--wheelchairs except those provided by the airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH COURT REJECTS APPEAL AGAINST TDC SUSPECTS' BAIL RULING(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court rejected Thursday a third appeal by the Taipei Prosecutor's Office against a lower court ruling that freed on bail three indicted insider trading suspects, including President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law.

The high court said in its latest ruling that the three suspects in the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stock insider trading scandal do not warrent a "preventive detention" prescribed in Article 101 of the Criminal Procedure Law. As a result, the high court rejected prosecutors' appeal seeking continued detention of the trio.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 11, or the 18th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Christiaan Eijkman, the Dutch physician who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B, is born.
1863: The French, who occupy southern Vietnam, make Cambodia a protectorate.
1919: Scottish-born American industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie dies at the age of 84. He amassed a fortune in the steel industry and donated millions of dollars for the benefit of the public.
1921: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, formally invites China, Japan, Britain, France and Italy to join a disarmament meeting in Washington, D.C. to cope with an increasingly dangerous international situation after World War I.
1930: Britain goes broke. The United States and France each lend it US$46 million, while American bankers extend another US$111 million.
1932: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, says it is time to scrap Prohibition. He lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt later that same year.
1936: Nationalist Chinese forces of Chiang Kai-shek enter Canton after foiling a rebellion led by Chen Chi-tang in the city in southern China.
1945: The Allies inform Japan that its surrender offer is acceptable.
1945: Communist "Yenan General Headquarters" orders Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the Republic of China government.
1950: The U.N. Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out in protest.
1960: Chad gains independence from France.
1960: The ROC recognizes the Ivory Coast and Chad.
1966: A peace treaty is signed in Jakarta, ending three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia.
1972: President Richard M. Nixon completes his "Vietnamization" of the Vietnam War by pulling out the last 92 American soldiers from the Southeast Asian country.
1973: The Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens its three-day 19th Conference in Taipei.
1975: The first meeting of the Asian and Pacific Congress on Health, Physical Education and Recreation opens in Taipei with 250 experts from 17 nations and areas attending.
1976: The industrial and commercial panel of the National Reconstruction Seminar opens a three-day meeting to make recommendations to the government.
1986: Sixteen people are killed and 87 others injured in an accidental explosion aboard the tanker SS Canari which is waiting to be scrapped in a shipwrecking yard in Kaohsiung Harbor.
1992: The United States, Canada and Mexico reach an agreement to set up a North American free-trade zone that would rank as the world's largest single trading bloc.
1993: The ROC Cable Television Law goes into effect.
1997: An international meeting called to shore up the shaky Thai economy offers loans of US$16 billion to the financial crisis-hit country.
1999: Taiwan's China Airlines signs an agreement with Boeing Co. of the United States to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion.
2000: A "Tzu Chi Village" in South Africa built by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, a charity organization, is formally inaugurated. Meanwhile, the Tzu Chi Medical Center announces the 99th and 100th overseas cases in which it has supplied bone marrow for transplant operations.
2001: The Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the Finance Ministry and the Central Deposits Insurance Corp. take the initiative to put 36 faltering local financial institutions under supervision, the first phase of a "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" action to consolidate the operations of local banks and farmers as well as fishermen's cooperatives.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to command the obedience of the members of one's family. If a man looking into his own heart is not true to himself, he will not command the obedience of the members of his family."

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:

The United Daily News: UK thwarts terroist plot to blew up planes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES FORMER CHAIRMAN NOT TO PUSH FOR PRESIDENT'S OUSTER

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday urged its former chairman Shih Ming-teh not to target President Chen Shui-bian and set his ouster as the only criterion in examining the ruling party.

DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang made the remarks one day after Shih, who served as DPP chairman between 1994 and 1996 before quitting the party in 2000, said he will gauge public opinion by launching a "one million citizens to oust President Chen" fundraising drive to see how badly the people want the resignation of President Chen, who has been dogged by a series of corruption and embezzlement scandals implicating his family members and senior aides.

Shih, often called "the Nelson Mandela of Taiwan" after a 25-year imprisonment for his dedication to the democratic movement, also said that if the target of one million donors can be reached within one month, the campaign to depose Chen will be launched Sept. 9 with daily sit-ins by protesters in front of the Presidential Office. If the target of one million can be achieved sooner, the campaign will also start to roll earlier than planned, according to Shih.

"The DPP holds Shih in great esteem, and the party will seriously address his recent move, " Tsai said, referring to Shih's recent letter to the president urging him to step down. In the letter, Shih also criticized Chen for blatantly embracing major businesspeople, saying that it was a step toward his downfall and that he has lost the trust of the public.
Tsai expressed the hope that Shih will not use President Chen's resignation as the only criterion in examining the party.
Tsai said that trust among people is currently weak due to long-term political rivalry, and he called for officials and politicians to show restraint instead of fueling restive sentiment.
"We should not ask whether President Chen will step down or not, but instead ask what he can do during his remaining years in office," Tsai added.

"The DPP is willing to work with Shih and all others who criticize the DPP administration, " Tsai said, stressing that "discussing what Chen can still do for society and constitutional reform is more significant than discussing who should step down and who should succeed."
DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling also said the party "will not condone" any irregularities in the administration.

"However, the current three-stage mode of making sensational allegations, inciting public discontent and launching social movements to oust President Chen will only cause further social divisions and animosity," she added.
Kuan called for the use of methods within the framework of the nation's system to solve controversial issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PLANNING SLANDER SUIT AGAINST KMT LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that legal action is being planned against opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiu Yi over his allegations that President Chen Shui-bian had maintained a secret bank account to launder money.

Dismissing the allegations as "total nonsense" based on gossip and misleading information, DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang said a slander suit will be filed against Chiu as soon as lawyers decide on whether the DPP or Chen himself should make the move.

At issue is Chiu's claim that Chen had a secret account at the Taishin International Bank from 2002 to 2004 which he said was used by the president to receive "unlawful donations" from businesses and that the account had a balance of more than NT$190 million (US$5.82 million) when it was closed in May 2004, with some of the money having been remitted overseas.

Also, the legislator claimed that Chen's daughter, Chen Hsin-yu, had remitted NT$2 million into the account after receiving the amount of money from her husband, Chao Chien-ming, who was charged with insider trading of Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stocks last month.
Chiu said he suspects that Chao was only a middleman who was helping Chen launder money, and he urged investigative authorities to start a probe into the president.

Showing a transaction statement of the account in question Friday, Tsai said the account was opened only on Jan. 5, 2004 to receive donations for Chen's second presidential campaign and had only a balance of NT$1.7 million when it was closed on April 1 the same year.
In addition, Tsai clarified that neither the president's daughter nor his son has remitted any money to the account, nor was any money from the account remitted overseas.

He said that the account was taken charge of by a financial management committee during Chen's presidential campaign and that its operation did not violate the Political Donations Law or the law governing the asset disclosure of public functionaries.
Also Friday, Chiu challenged the DPP to present the passbook of the account instead of showing some transaction statement which he said is "insufficient to prove anything."
Chiu claimed he has managed to trace 16 secret remittances with a total amount of NT$170 million in the account and that there are other more suspicious remittances.

Noting that the Bureau of Investigation's Money Laundering Prevention Center has referred the case to the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court for investigation, Chiu said the authorities would not have done so if the account had been a clean one.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Friday for August moved down 17 points to close at 6,538, with 26,788 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 22 points to finish at 6,525, with 2,041 contracts traded, while December futures dropped 35 points to close at 6,520, with 12 contract transactions.
March futures gained seven points to close at 6,542, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,555 for August, 6,547 for September, 6,555 for December, 6,535 for March and 6,533 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
August TE futures moved down 0.15 points to close at 281.8, with 3,696 contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 0.55 points to finish at 281.551, with 831 contract transactions.
March TE futures lost 0.2 points to close at 282.8, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures gained 3.2 points to close at 918.8, with 1,161 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved up 0.6 points to finish at 918, with 109 contracts traded.
December TF futures rose 3.6 points to close at 916, with eight contract transactions, while March TF futures gained 2.8 points to finish at 917.8, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIR CANNOT LEGALLY ACCEPT DONATIONS AS AN INDIVIDUAL: MOI

TEXT.P: Former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Shih Ming-teh is not eligible according to the law to accept political donations in his planned fundraising campaign, an official of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Friday.

Huang Li-hsin, director of MOI's Department of Civil Affairs, made the remarks one day after Shih, who served as DPP chairman betweeen 1994-1996 before quitting the party in 2000, said he will soon launch a "one million citizens to oust President Chen" fundraising drive to gauge the level of support among the people to depose Chen, who has been dogged by a series of corruption and embezzlement allegations implicating his family members and senior aides.

Huang, together with Tseng Chung-ming, director of the MOI's Department of Social Affairs, said in a news conference held at the ministry that such fundraising is governed by the public interest donation statute as well as the political donation law.
According to Article 3 of the statute governing donation for public interest purposes, such fundraising activities must be initiated by a group or organization.

Huang said that according to the statute, donations collected in the name of the public interest are to be used for social welfare or humanitarian assistance, and not for political or religious activities.

Shih's planned campaign clearly falls into the category of political activities and should be governed by the political donation law, Huang said, citing Article 5 of the law as stating that only political parties, political groups or candidates running in elections can accept such donations.
"As Shih is not a candidate in any election, he should not accept political donations as an individual," Huang said.

If Shih insists on pushing forward with his plan, he will be in violation of the law, Huang said, adding that anyone found guilty of violating the law must return all the funds collected and pay a fine equal to the total amount collected.

Shih, often called "the Nelson Mandela of Taiwan" after a 25-year imprisonment for his dedication to the democratic movement, said Thursday that a bank account will be opened to accept donations from Aug. 14.

If the target of one million donors can be reached within one month, the campaign to depose Chen will be launched Sept. 9 with daily sit-ins by protesters in front of the Presidential Office. If the target of one million can be achieved sooner, the campaign will also start to roll earlier than planned, according to Shih.

DOC.HEADLINE: REAL ESTATE WEB SITE INAUGURATED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presided over a ceremony Friday marking the launch of a Taipei City real estate Web site.

At the ceremony, Ma noted that the Web site at www.tred.tw will allow the general public, government agencies, real estate developers and brokerage agencies, as well as members of the construction, financial and insurance sectors to have quick and easy access to real estate information about Taiwan's capital.
"This marks another step forward in making Taipei a real Internet-savvy city, " a city government official said at the ceremony.

An official of Taipei City government's Department of Land noted that as the public can obtain detailed real estate information, including land prices, maps and urban planning projects, from the Web site, this will help reduce costs in searching for information and help boost the number of real estate transactions in the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: IBM CALLS FOR TAIWAN PARTICIPATION IN GLOBAL GRID PROJECT

TEXT.P: International information technology giant IBM has launched a non-profit project with the collaborative efforts of several renowned institutions in the United States by utilizing the capacity of the World Community Grid to facilitate cancer research.

The company's Taiwan branch said Friday that it hopes as many Taiwanese as possible can join the grid computing effort, called the "Help Defeat Cancer" project, to further accelerate the research process.
The researchers have begun analyzing breast cancer and will soon proceed to evaluating protein and molecular expression patterns in head and neck cancers, according to the company.

The World Community Grid, initiated in 2004 by IBM and 213 partners, is dedicated to humanitarian research. To date, the project has already arranged research efforts in several areas, including a "Smallpox Research Grid, " the "Human Proteome Folding Project, " "FightAIDS@Home, " as well as the most recent "Help Defeat Cancer" -- which has been organized by IBM, the Cancer Institute of New Jersey, Rutgers University and the University of Pennsylvania.

The "Help Defeat Cancer" project has adopted a newly developed investigative technique, called tissue microarray, to compare therapies and combinations of treatments against various kinds of cancers and cancer subclasses, in order to prescribe optimal courses of treatment to cancer patients.

Through the use of the tissue microarray technique, researchers can now simultaneously examine specimens totaling up to 2,000 on a single biopsy slide. Meanwhile, arrays can also be digitized for computer-assisted cross-examination.

An IBM research fellow explained that within a general category of cancer, there are a number of subclasses, each of which requires a specific treatment or a combination of treatments. Although the introduction of tissue microarrays has facilitated the biopsy process, running interactive evaluations amongst tissue microarray samples and cancer therapies is still beyond human ability or the capacity of a single super-computer, he added.

Grid computing is thus required to manage such an enormous task, he said, adding that by pooling unused computer time of millions of single users around the globe, the World Community Grid can complete in a single day computations that would take a single computer running continuously for 130 years to complete.
According to IBM tallies, 209,278 members with 385,031 computing machines have joined the World Community Grid to date, generating a run time totaling 51,760 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ICT MARKET TO GROW LESS THAN 5% IN 2006: IDC

TEXT.P: The Taiwan market for information and communications technology (ICT) hardware, software and services will see growth of less than 5 percent in 2006, according to a report released by the International Data Corp. (IDC) Friday.
The report said growth momentum is lacking in the Taiwan market mainly because the market is mature and saturated, while many contract high-tech manufacturers have moved to China.

While Taiwan's business application software and business intelligence products posted total sales of US$71 million and US$10.8 million, respectively, in 2005, the market for these products is expected to expand slightly by 1.1 percent in 2006, the report said.

Educational institutions were the major clients of the personal computer market in 2005 and the government's measures to stimulate domestic demand also helped encourage businesses to replace and upgrade their computer systems, according to the report.

Sales of notebook computers were boosted by promotional packages offered by manufacturers such as Acer, Asus and HP in 2005, with the shipments of notebook computers 30 percent higher than that of personal computers in the third quarter of 2005, according to the report.

Taiwan's fixed-line telecommunications services saw a 2.9 percent growth in 2004 and sales of the traditional telephone service market did not decline despite the popularity of mobile phones and Internet telephones, the report said.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's mobile phone penetration rate stood at 92.5 percent in 2005, while the launch of 3G services is expected to further boost the penetration rate, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SNAKE CAUSES LARGE SCALE POWER FAILURE IN CHIAYI

TEXT.P: A Taiwan beauty snake that entered a substation in Chuchi, Chiayi County, caused a power failure that affected more than 300,000 households, according to officials from the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) office in the southern Taiwan county.
The blackout affected Chiayi City and the urban townships of Minhsiung, Chuchi and Chungpu, and flooded the Taipower office with phone calls inquiring about the cause.
Taipower technicians tracked the cause of the power disruption to the one-meter snake that had caused a short circuit.
Power was restored within six minutes, but power company workers could not explain how the snake managed to get into the substation, which is netted and protected by poison to deter animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHIEF'S FUNDRAISING NOT AGAINST LAW: SPOKESWOMAN

TEXT.P: The spokeswoman for former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh's "one person, NT$100" campaign to call for President Chen Shui-bian's resignation claimed Friday that the fundraising activity is not breaking any law.

Ho De-fen, professor emeritus of National Taiwan University, was responding to a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official's claim that because Shih was not a candidate in any elections, he cannot use his name to raise political donations.
The MOI official was hinting that it would be illegal for Shih to collect a targeted NT$100 million (US$3.06 million) for what he calls a "one million people to topple the president" drive.
Shih is scheduled to kick off the campaign Saturday at Taipei's 228 Peace Memorial Park.
Ho said the NT$100 (US$3.06) contribution is a "registration fee" for joining the campaign, not a donation for somebody to engage in a political activity.

Some critics said the fund-raising drive might be violating the law governing the collection of charity donations, but Ho pointed out that the campaign is not a charity and that there is no "institutional person" in charge of the movement.

The NT$100 contributions from the people would be used to pay for food and drinks and cleaning the proposed sit-ins, she pointed out, noting that it would mean an individual citizen's commitment and authorization in support of the campaign.
Ho said the organizers will hire professional accountants to keep tabs on how the public donations are used and an auditing report will be made available on the Internet every day.

She said that if indeed 1 million people stage a sit-in, NT$100 million will not be enough to keep the activity going. If there should be surplus, it will be donated to schools to help pay for poor children's lunches, she added.

The spokeswoman said that she and other organizers had studied relevant laws and concluded that no laws will be broken if they urge the public to make a NT$100 donation. She added that the three account numbers that will be used to receive people's contributions are: Changhua Bank Tucheng Branch #9283-51-41111-700; Union Bank #0049-10-0002991; and Post Office Remittance #19990461 -- all under the name of Shih Ming-teh.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 TAIPEI CHINESE FOOD FESTIVAL OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2006 Taipei Chinese Food Festival opened Friday at the Taipei World Trade Center, exhibiting until Monday foods that are representative of various regions of Taiwan.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Tui said that the food festival will provide visitors with a chance to taste Taiwan's delicious and speciality dishes -- one of the country's major attractions for foreign tourists, in addition to the local culture and the people's hospitality.
There will also be a cooking contest in which local chefs will compete for a prize and the right to represent Taiwan in an international competition next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD AGENTS DETAIN DRUG TRAFFICKER AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Taichung Coast Guard agents detained a man late Thursday for allegedly smuggling in illicit drugs worth millions of dollars from the Philippines, a spokesman for the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Friday.

According to the spokesman, the suspect, surnamed Tsai, was arrested by CGA agents at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport when he was found to have brought in 2.695 kg of heroin hidden in a bottle of powdered milk. The drugs have a market value of millions of dollars in Taiwan, he said.
The CGA agents were acting on a tipoff provided by an informant who revealed that Tsai had been hired by a criminal ring to bring in drugs from the Philippines, the spokesman said.
According to the informant, the criminal ring usually employs individual tourists -- different people each time -- to act as mules.
Tsai claimed that he had no idea the heroin was concealed in the powdered milk and that he was only doing a favor for a friend by bringing the item into Taiwan. He had no previous criminal record.
The CGA said that it will continue investigating the case under the assumption that the drug traffickers have used the method more than just once.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Reppublica: Islamic terrorists want massacre in sky.
British police cracked down a massive terrorist attempt and arrested 24 islamic terrorists who were trying to board 10 airplanes bound for the United States in London airports Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS DISPLAY CONTINUED SUPPORT FOR PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers displayed their full support for President Chen Shui-bian Friday amid mounting pressure from all walks of life demanding that he step down amid many corruption allegations involving his family members and close aides.
The demonstration of their loyalty came one day after former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh declared that he will launch a national campaign to oust Chen "for the sake of Taiwan's future."

Shih also said that Vice President Annette Lu is one of the key factors as to whether the campaign will succeed because many people are terrified of the idea of Lu being put in charge of state affairs, out of fear of her radical pro-Taiwan independence stance.
However, DPP lawmaker Huang Wei-cher claimed that DPP members are not fearful of Lu and that most of the party's members still support Chen.
"Unless new evidence is found showing Chen's clear involvement in any allegation, DPP members will continue to support the president, " Huang said.

According to DPP lawmaker Cheng Yun-peng, the government is operating in line with the constitutional system rather than with personal preference. The question of whether Chen should step down or stay on must be determined by constitutional practices, he contended.

DPP lawmaker Huang Chien-hui said that all the corruption allegations that have surfaced so far are unrelated to Chen personally and he argued that there is no need for Chen to quit the presidency to take responsibility for the allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF GUEST HOUSES INCREASES BY 42% ANNUALLY

TEXT.P: As of June, there were 1,755 guest houses around Taiwan, representing growth of 42.2 percent over the same month of last year, according to statistics released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
A DGBAS official said that as the government has been encouraging tourism and extending assistance, the number of beds and breakfasts has also increased rapidly during the last few years.
Among the 1,755 guest houses, 1,426 have obtained government permission offering a total of 5,773 rooms.

The statistics also show that as of June, the number of world-class and ordinary hotels on the island reached 60 and 28, respectively, offering 21,486 rooms and representing a slight growth of 3.5 percent over June of last year.
The average price for one night in a Taiwan hotel was NT$3,125 (US$95), according to the statistics.
The official noted that most of the country's guest houses are in Hualien County, Nantou County and Yilan County.
In Hualien County alone, there are already 343 guest houses, showing an annual increase of 57.3 percent.

The official went on that although the number of rooms offered by guest houses lags behind the number offered by tourist hotels, the rise of guest houses around the island still poses a considerable threat to tourist hotels.

For example, the occupancy rate in tourist hotels averaged 69 percent in the first six months of this year, representing a decrease of 2.1 percent over the same period of last year, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Times: A plan 'to commit unimaginable mass murder' Alarming intelligence that an attack was imminent was the trigger for police raids which captured 24 terrorist suspects, including two white converts to Islam, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.058 to close at NT$32.644.
A total of US$895 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.685 and fluctuated between NT$32.565 and NT$32.700.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERING CHAD TIES WILL NOT AFFECT TAIWAN'S U.N. BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Timothy Hwang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Severance of official ties with Chad will not affect Taiwan's campaign to join the United Nations, a senior Taiwan official said Friday.

Andrew Hsia, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York, said Taiwan will keep telling the U.N. that it is determined to be part of the U.N. family in spite of its recent break-off of ties with Chad.
Hsia was scheduled to hold a press conference later in the day to announce which of Taiwan's remaining 24 allies will sponsor a motion for the U.N. General Assembly to discuss Taiwan's participation.
This year, Taiwan's U.N. campaign will focus on the theme of "UN-HUMAN" to underscore the world body's "unhuman" treatment of Taiwan's people, he said.

Last year, Taiwan campaigned on the theme of "UN-FAIR" and the U.N. turned out to be "unfair" to Taiwan by not just refusing to discuss Taiwan's representation in the organization but also cutting short the time its allies had to speak for it.

The Republic of China gave up its U.N. membership in 1971 when the China seat was given to the communist regime in Beijing. Since 1993, it has been calling for international attention to its plight and asking its allies to push for U.N. recognition.
This year's campaign will be Taiwan's 14th attempt to obtain U.N. membership. All of its previous attempts have failed because of China's obstruction.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Israel readies Broader Push as Losses Rise. While Plan for an expanded ground offensive signal a possible escalation of the war with Hezbollah, Israel suffered its worst military death toll in a month of fighting in southern Lebanon, when 15 soldiers were killed Wednesday during skirmishes with Hezbollah guerrillas.

DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Aug.11 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Moscow Tackles Its Cold War Image
Moscow officials will open a public-relations shop and launch media offensives in foreign countries as they embark on a $27 million, three-year campaign to combat Cold War bias and bolster the city's image abroad. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

The Japan Times: U.K. thwarts plot to blow up jetliners
British authorities thwartsed a terrorist plot to blow up several aircraft in flight between the United States and the United Kingdom using explosives smuggled in hand luggages, officials said Thursday.
