DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Tip Followed '05 Attacks on London Transit.
It all began with a tip: In the aftermath of the July 7, 2005, suicide bombings on London's transit system, British authorities received a call from a worried member of the Muslim community, reporting general suspicions about an acquaintance.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTED ALLIANCE NOT HELPFUL IN SOLVING PROBLEMS: DPP LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday they are not in favor of a reported alliance between former President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Annette Lu and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, claiming that the idea will not solve any problems.

The DPP legislators were responding to reports that some DPP members are worried that if such an alliance is formed, the DPP will not only lose its grip on power, but will run the risk of being splintered.

The reports have as their premise the idea that Lu would succeed President Chen Shui-bian if he were to step down as a result of the series of corruption allegations against his close aides and family members, while Wang would be appointed premier, which reportedly is what Lee would like.
DPP Legislator Lin Cho-hsui said the current political turmoil can be traced to the corruption allegations implicating the first family, as well as the DPP's lack of dominance in the legislature.
If a Lu-Wang team were to be formed, then it would be "one minority rule replacing another minority rule" that will not solve the current impasse the DPP fares in the legislature, according to Lin.
However, Legislator Huang Wei-cher pointed out that unless the DPP or Lee confirms the report, it remains no more than idle press speculation.

The DPP's aim is to continue the DPP or "pan-green camp" rule, but if the Lu-Wang team were to be formed it's purpose would be to rival Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang and the best bet for the party in the 2008 presidential election.
DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling also said the reports are aimed at creating the impression that the party is about to collapse and that Chen will soon step down.
DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang also said that the reported alliance is an attempt to drive a wedge into the party.

Reports have said that with Chen embroiled in alleged misuse of state affairs funds and former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh calling for his resignation, Lee has instructed the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, to prepare a contingency plan should Chen leave the scene.

The reports have speculated that Lee, the so-called spiritual leader of the TSU, is worried that if Premier Su Tseng-chang, who was appointed by Chen, is ousted along with the president, fighting within the DPP could erupt. Lee therefore supports Lu to take over the presidency with Wang heading the new Cabinet to stabilize political situation, according to the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME HAIR DRYERS SOLD IN TAIWAN TOO NOISY: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Some hair dryers sold in Taiwan make too much noise or provide too much heat, which can be dangerous for users, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Consumer's Foundation.
The foundation sampled 23 hair dryers sold in stores in the Taipei area in April. While six of the products were made in Taiwan, 16 were made in China and one was made in Thailand.

Tests conducted on the products showed that three produced more than 90 decibels, two produced heat that was higher than the maximum accepted level of 110 degrees Celsius, and one even melted while in use.

Wu Chia-cheng, a chemistry professor at National Taiwan Normal University and a member of the foundation, said hair dryers should be produce between 55 decibels and 65 decibels and should not exceed 75 decibels.
While the noise made by the surveyed products ranged between 72 decibles and 98 decibels, only four were lower than 75 decibels and three were higher than 90 decibels, Wu said.

In terms of temperatures, the Sunpentown SH-6512 hair dryer and Lapolo HD-275 hair dryer both released maximum heat of more than 110 degrees Celsius, with the maximum heat by the former even reaching 130 degrees Celsius, which can burn the scalp, Wu said.
According to Wu, the temperature of hair dryers should not exceed 55 degrees Celsius, as heat exceeding that level can damage the hair.
Meanwhile, the funnel of the Hsueh Yin SI-170 hair dryer melted due to the heat released by the product, Wu said.
He warned that the melted plastic cover of the hair dryer can release toxic substances and he urged the government to step up inspections of hair dryers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 7.51 points to close at 6,571.1.
The bourse opened at 6,612.48 and fluctuated between 6,617.23 and 6,559.27 during trading. A total of 3.07 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$87.27 billion (US$2.67 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up at 0.2 percent and machinery and electronic shares increasing 0.1 percent.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, and textile stocks at 0.4 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 641 to 353, with 139 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: RACING PIGEON THEFT RING SMASHED

TEXT.P: Nine members of a racing pigeon theft ring were apprehended by police late Thursday in the central Miaoli and southern Tainan areas, Miaoli police announced Friday.

According to the Miaoli policy authorities, the nine suspects are repeat offenders who had allegedly been netting racing pigeons in mountainous areas of Miaoli, in particular in April, when the local racing season begins.
The suspects would demand between NT$2,500 and NT$5,000 for each pigeon, police said, adding that their initial investigation shows that the ring has made hefty profits.

The suspects would destroy any pigeons believed to come from the Miaoli area in an effort to avoid being caught, police said, adding that it was "terrifying" to see many dead pigeons in Miaoli's mountainous areas, usually burned to death or killed within the nets erected by the ring.
According to the Miaoli police, the suspects showed no remorse for their alleged crime after being detained. Rather, they shouted at police to vent their anger and claimed innocence.
Breeding racing pigeons is a very popular activity in Taiwan, with raisers hoping to make a fortune in local contests with their high-quality birds.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Officials Cite Sophistication and Scale of Plane Scheme
U.S. Intelligence and counterterrorism officials said yesterday that the scale and sophistication of the scheme to blow up jetliners over the Atlantic could mean that Al Qaeda, whose central command has been severely damaged since 2001, was again able to direct attacks. But some specialists on the shifting networks of international terrorism said the alternative explanation -- that homegrown British jihadists had managed to conceive a plot of such ambition -- might hold even graver implications for the future.
Wall Street Journal: U.K. Terror Plot Points to New Threat
Britain's disruption yesterday of what authorities say was an audacious plot to blow up trans-Atlantic airliners increases the fear among terrorism investigators that significant numbers of Islamic radicals born or raised in the West intend to carry out sophisticated, large- scale attacks, inspired or guided by al Qaeda. The possibility that home-grown radicals could link up with international terrorist networks or simply draw inspiration from them to wreak mass destruction complicates the challenge of identifying and tracking potential terrorists, according to people involved in those efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIDS FOR U.N. SEAT AGAIN

TEXT.P: Taiwan will again bid for a seat in the United Nations, with two proposals presented by its diplomatic allies and the bid will be a continuous effort even if it fails once again, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said in a press conference Friday.

The government does not rule out the possibility of applying for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan, although the issue is still under discussion, said John Chen, director-general of MOFA's Department of International Organizations.

Taiwan's allies submitted two proposals -- the "participation proposal" and the "peace proposal" -- to the U.N. Secretariat in New York early Friday, Lu said, requesting that the General Committee put the proposals on the assembly agenda.
The participation proposal was very similar to those put forward in the past -- urging the U.N. General Assembly to ensure the representation of the 23 million people of Taiwan in the world body.

There is a modification in the peace proposal, Lu said. The proposal requests the U.N. to play a proactive role in maintaining peace in the East Asia region instead of last year's proposal, which mentioned only the Taiwan Strait.

With China's military budget showing double-digit growth for the 18th consecutive year and the latest North Korean missile test, the regional security in East Asia -- not just the Taiwan Strait -- is becoming a notable issue in global security, Lu said.
"The proposal calls for the U.N. to urge East Asian countries to settle arguments peacefully and to take necessary measures to prevent the regional tension from rising," Chen said.
Since 1993, Taiwan has failed 14 times in its bids to enter the U.N.

When the U.N. was founded in 1945, the Republic of China was one of its founding members. However, it has been shut out of the body since 1971, when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the "China" seat to the People's Republic of China at the ROC's expense.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES PUBLIC TO READ MORE BOOKS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged the public Friday to read more books instead of gossiping about politicians.
Su made the appeal at a ceremony held at a bookstore chain in which he bestowed awards on publishers of the best government publications.
Admitting that government publications might seem very boring to many people, Su claimed that they are now "diverse and interesting" due to the creativity of many people.
In addition to publishing good books, Su said he also wants to increase book-reading among local people.

The premier refused to comment on a campaign to be launched by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , to oust President Chen Shui-bian, who is mired in a series of corruption scandals allegedly involving his family members and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2.3 MILLION PEOPLE SIGN PETITION SEEKING PRESIDENT'S RECALL: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: While former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh was calling on 1 million people to donate NT$100 each for a campaign to topple President Chen Shui-bian, an opposition leader said Friday his party's campaign to recall the president has actually won the support of 2.3 million people.

Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT), said that is the number of signatures collected in his party's drive to pass a recall motion at the legislature. The Legislative Yuan failed to pass the motion during an extra session in June.
Asked if he would donate NT$100 (US$3.06) to Shih's campaign to topple the president, Ma said money is a minor matter and that the real issue is "people" if the president is to be overthrown.

In response to a forecast that even if the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party manage to win back power in Taiwan, the political situation will still be chaotic, Ma said he disagrees.
"A 'pan-blue alliance' government will not lead to political chaos in Taiwan," he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S U.N. BID A JOINT AND CONTINUOUS EFFORT: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's bid to become a member of the United Nations is a joint and continuous effort, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Friday.

It will not be easy for Taiwan to enter the U. N., as evidenced by the last 14 failed attempts to do so. But Taiwan has shown time and again that it is willing and capable of being a responsible member of the international community, according to Lu.
Even China, he said, spent 22 years before securing its U.N. membership -- although it was at Taiwan's expense.

"And China has been doing whatever it takes to block Taiwan from international organizations and events. That tells us we don't have any reason to stop working at a bid, which has become an annual task for us, " he said.

Taiwan shares the same values -- which Lu claimed are "democracy, human rights and development" -- with the 192 member countries of the United Nations and went from an aid recipient to a contributor that reaches out a helping hand to less-developed countries, Lu said.
The U.N. bid is always a priority issue for MOFA and every Taiwan president since 1972, when the Republic of China was replaced in the U.N. by the People's Republic of China.

Over 100 embassies and representatives offices around the world have spent countless hours delivering Taiwan's message and hope, while MOFA has been tackling the New York area, where the U.N. headquarters are located, with publicity campaigns, parliamentary lobbies and mobilizing overseas Taiwanese groups, said John Chen, director- general of MOFA's Department of International Organizations.

It is also possible that President Chen Shui-bian will discuss the bid with the U.S. media in a teleconference, which is si miliar to the one Chen had with European media when Taiwan was trying to bid for World Health Assembly observer status earlier this year, Chen said.
"It has not been and will not be easy, but the 23 million people of Taiwan have the right to participate in international affairs. We will keep working on it, " Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAS PRESIDENT MAY VISIT TAIWAN IN OCTOBER
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Raymond Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Honduras President Manuel Zelaya is expected to visit Taiwan and sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with President Chen Shui-bian in October, Republic of China embassy officials stationed in the Central American country said Friday.
The officials noted that Taiwan and Honduras have completed two rounds of negotiations on the singing of an FTA, with the next round scheduled for September.
The officials said Honduras has maintained close relations with Taiwan, and Zelaya's postponement of a scheduled trip to Taiwan this month is mainly because of a teachers' strike.

They noted that Zelaya said right after his election as president Nov. 27 last year that he will visit various countries, including Taiwan, which shows his attachment to relations with Taiwan. He was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan in June but it was postponed to mid-August because he had to attend a summit meeting of the Central American Integration System.
Meanwhile, Honduras Congress President Roberto Micheletti is scheduled to lead a six-member delegation to visit Taiwan to attend the Double Ten National Day celebrations in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD OPTIMISTIC ABOUT BUSINESS IN FREE TRADE PORT ZONES

TEXT.P: The number of companies willing to open up shop in Taiwan's five free trade port zones might exceed 100 by the end of this year, as the figure has already hit 73, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.

CEPD Vice Chairman Thomas M.F. Yeh said that the 73 companies have applied to set up shop in the five free trade port zones located in Keelung, Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung ports, as well as at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

He predicted that the number will further increase, probably to 105 in the initial stage, by the end of December, providing a major fillip for the government in its efforts to make Taiwan into an international business procurement and operations hub.

The goal to develop the five free trade port zones is one of the prime objectives outlined by the Executive Yuan in its 2008 national development program, Yeh said, adding that the CEPD will do its best to provide comprehensive information in this regard to lure both foreign and local companies to establish footholds there, where personnel and capital can freely move in and out.
According to Yeh, the CEPD will being running a Web site from October this year to serve that end.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S HOUSEMAID'S 'SECRET SERVICE SUBSIDY' DRAWS FLAK

TEXT.P: Monthly payments to Lin Hsiu-chen, a housemaid who works for President Chen Shui-bian in a property owned by him and occupied by his daughter, drew flak from opposition lawmakers again Friday after it was revealed that she had received a "secret service subsidy" from the National Security Bureau (NSB) over the past five years.

Local reports cited NSB officials as saying that in addition to receiving a monthly payment of NT$25,000 while named as a janitor on the payroll of the Presidential Office, Lin also received more than NT$20,000 per month from the NSB as a "secret service subsidy."

NSB officials said Lin received the subsidy because she "assisted and worked with the secret service." But because of changes in her working conditions, the subsidy was stopped in August, according to the reports. The subsidy is given to secret service staff maintaining the security of the president and the vice president, and Lin's subsidy was equal to that paid to an army captain, the reports said.

Opposition lawmakers lambasted the subsidy payments as "very improper, " but the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said that in view of the public feelings, the subsidy for the past five years -- estimated at around NT$1.17 million -- had been returned.

Tsai Chin-lung, a caucus whip of the main opposition Kuomintang in the legislature, said it is "pathetic" to use taxpayer money to pay for Lin, and ridiculed her for being described as a member of the secret service while actually working as a housemaid.
Lu Hsueh-chang, a caucus whip of the People First Party noted that Lin is neither a secret servicewoman, nor a plain clothes policewomen, and so had no right to claim such a subsidy from the NSB.
Lo Chih-ming, a caucus whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, said that Lin's claiming of the subsidy was outrageous and that the NSB should make a full review.
Reports have said that although Lin claimed a monthly salary of NT$25,000, she actually received nearly NT$60,000 from other sources.

After the matter came to light, Lin resigned from the Presidential Office but remains in Chen's private employ at his own expense, while his daughter has also returned more than NT$2 million, including salary and bonuses paid to Lin from Presidential Office funds since she married and moved into her parent's house on Minsheng East Road in Taipei five years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP AFRICAN COUNTRIES IMPROVE BANANA CULTIVATION

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institution, will assist African countries in improving the disease-resistance capability of bananas by authorizing a transfer of technology to the African Agricultural Technology Foundation (AATF).
A technology-transfer agreement signing ceremony was held at Academia Sinica Friday, with its Vice President Michael Lai and AATF Chief Executive Officer Dr. Mpoko Bokanga signing the agreement.
An Academia Sinica official noted that bananas are a main staple in African countries; however, bacterial wilt disease has seriously affected crops.
To help Africa cultivate more disease-resistant bananas, Academia Sinica has decided to transfer technology developed at the institution to the AATF based on humanitarian grounds, the official added.

The AATF, established in Great Britain in 2003, is a transnational philanthropic organization dedicated to transferring global technologies to African farmers through technology-transfer contracts in order to improve food security and farmers' livelihood in Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF SUPPORTS FORMER DDP HEAD'S CAMPAIGN TO TOPPLE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: An opposition party leader voiced support Friday for former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh's campaign to topple President Chen Shui-bian, claiming he was the first to have such a call.

James Soong, chairman of the People First Party, said he was the first politician to have called on Chen to step down to take moral and political responsibility for a spate of corruption charges against the first family and senior aides.

Shih and another former DPP chairman, Hsu Hsin-liang, said they had lost confidence in the president because Chen's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, was at the center of a high-profile insider trading scandal. Chao and his father were among the seven indictees in the case.

While calling on the public to support Shih's "one person, NT$100" drive to topple the scandal-ridden president, Soong devoted more time attacking his "pan-blue alliance" ally, Chairman Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang (KMT).

Soong said he admired Shih's views of the political situation, including Shih's satirization of an opposition leader as a "fodder-fed chicken" -- an apparent reference to Ma, who has been criticized for being too weak during the pan-blue alliance's presidential recall campaign.
Soong said while the campaign was being waged, even DPP members realized that if Chen remained in the executive, it would be a shame not only for Taiwan but also for the DPP.
"If the KMT had insisted on recalling the president and followed up with a no-confidence motion against the Cabinet, Chen would have been thrown out by now," Soong said.
Instead of being tough with the president, Soong said the KMT backed down right before the recall motion went to a vote in the legislature, considering non-judicial means to be "too radical."
That, Soong claimed, was "conceding defeat even before the battle."

Ma was not immediately available for response to Soong's comment, nor did he specify whether he would donate NT$100 in support of Shih's campaign, saying "money is a minor matter" and the real issue is "people" if the president is to be overthrown.
Ma claimed that his party's drive to recall the president has managed to collect more than 2.3 million signatures.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NOMINEE FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYOR REGRETS SHIH'S CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Chen Chu, who was a fellow inmate of former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh during the Kuomintang (KMT) rule, said Friday that she regretted Shih's campaign to topple President Chen Shui-bian based on moral grounds.

Chen, a former chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and now the ruling DPP's nominee for Kaohsiung mayor, said she opposed the idea of forcing a president to step down when he has done nothing illegal, on moral considerations.

"I respect our friendship developed in our joint efforts to oppose the KMT's authoritarian rule, but I cannot agree with [Shih's] accusation that President Chen is at the heart of Taiwan's turmoil, " she said in a statement.

She claimed that the real "center of turmoil" lies with "pan-blue alliance" legislators who make all sorts of allegations against the president, as well as TV personalities who are bent on toppling Taiwan's "democratic, sovereign government."
She called on Shih to beware of these "reactionary" forces working to return the pan-blue politicians to power at any price.
She advised Shih to "respect judicial proceedings" and to bow to the popular will with regard to political stability and economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT: MY DUTY IS TO HELP PRESIDENT COMPLETE TERM OF OFFICE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that it was her constitutional duty to help President Chen Shui-bian complete his term of office, and she called on the public to "continue supporting the president and help him weather the difficulties."
She made the remarks after attending a business group's changeover event.
She denied that she had made a phone call to former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who has kicked off a campaign to topple the president "for the sake of Taiwan's future."
Lu also denied that she was forming an alliance with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng in the event of Chen's resignation.
"The media just love to write about fiction, rather than news stories," she said.
Shih has commented that many people did not wish to see Chen step down, fearing Chen would be replaced by Lu.
In response, Lu said, "I suppose it is he [Shih] who fears this the most."

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPENSION OF CHARGES OFFERED TO HELP DRUG ADDICTS KICK THE HABIT

TEXT.P: The Tainan Prosecutor's Office in southern Taiwan will launch an experimental program Sept. 1 to offer drug addicts suspended indictments on condition of compulsory treatment as part of efforts to reduce overall drug dependency, a spokesman said Friday.

Under the program, addicts who voluntarily undergo treatment will have their legal charges suspended if they contribute NT$50,000 toward a special fund that finances the cost of compulsory rehabilitation.
Drug addicts who are first caught by law enforcement will have to contribute NT$100,000 toward the special alternative treatment fund to qualify for the suspension of charges.
Chu Chao-liang, chief prosecutor at the Tainan Prosecutor's Office, said the contribution requirement is congruent with the "making users pay" principle.

The compulsory treatment will require drug addicts to visit a designated hospital regularly to drink a dose of Methadone -- a substitute drug that reduces dependency on more lethal drugs such as heroin -- and reduce the risk of contracting diseases through hypodermic needle infections.
Chu unveiled the experimental program at a coordination meeting of officials from the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), the Tainan county government and the Tainan city government.

Speaking at the meeting at the DOH-run Chianan Psychiatric Center in Tainan County, Kuo Hsu-sung, director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said the DOH welcomes the new experimental program to help drug addicts quit the vice by offering suspended indictment charges on condition of compulsory treatment.
"We hope the new program will provide an incentive in our fight against drug hazards and drug addiction," Kuo said.

As drug addiction has become a main source of Taiwan's AIDS/HIV transmissions -- with two out of every three new HIV carriers being intravenous drug users -- the DOH launched an experimental needle exchange project in Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County and Tainan County last year.

The project has initially borne fruit, as all new HIV infection rates in those areas have fallen below the country's average level of 56.38 percent. Since July 1 this year, the "clean needle" program has been implemented across the country.
Kuo said Tainan County has been the most successful in the first stage of the DOH's drug reduction plan by integrating the clean needle and alternative treatment projects.

A total of 129 drug addicts have entered the Chianan Psychiatric Center's alternative treatment program. With the Tainan Prosecutor's Office and additional medical institutions in the region taking part as well, Kuo believes the results will be even more remarkable.
Kuo added that the DOH plans to invite U.S. and Australian experts to Tainan in September to review the county's achievements in drug hazard control and prevention.
"We'll also introduce Tainan's drug-fighting experience to other counties and cities around Taiwan," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES REPORTED ARMS DEAL WITH LIBYA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) denied Friday a media report that Libya sent delegates to review Taiwan's just-concluded Hankuang No.22 military exercise as the northern African country plans to purchase firearms from Taiwan.
The report was sheer speculation and completely unfounded, the MND said in a press statement.
The statement said the military didn't invite any Libyan military personnel to review the Hankuang drill and has not had any plan to sell weapons or military equipment to that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SPICY GIRL' AT TOURISM PROMOTIONAL EVENT RAISES EYEBROWS

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu felt acutely embarrassed when he removed a placard at a promotional event Friday to unveil a bikini-clad young woman lying on a buffet table.

The event was organized by a travel agents association in the central city of Taichung to promote an agricultural fair, slated to take place at the city's Dakeng Scenic Area from this weekend through Oct. 1.
The scantily-dressed woman was covered with salad made of bamboo shoots, one of the specialty farm products to be promoted at the upcoming fair, dubbed the 2006 Taichung Bamboo Shoot Festival.
Although the emcee of the ceremony invited Hu to remove bamboo shoot pieces from the prostrate woman's body, Hu remained unmoved and declined to do so.

While admiring the private travel association's efforts to promote the city's tourist attractions and agricultural resources, Hu said he hadn't expected the organizers to adopt such a publicity gimmick.
Critics said the organizers employed the wrong promotional strategy for the event, which was aimed at showcasing the city's beautiful scenery and cuisine, rather than eroticism.
The Dakeng area produces bamboo shoots, organges, WenXin orchids and many kinds of watercultivated vegetables.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 12 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Aug. 12:
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will give a speech at a training class at Ketaglan Institute.
15:00, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend cultural promotion program at Huashan cultural center in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 12, or the 19th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1099: The Crusaders defeat the Egyptians at Ascalon on the Palestine coast in the First Crusade.
1813: Austria declares war against Napoleon.
1848: George Stephenson, the British railway pioneer who built the first passenger railway in 1825, dies at the age of 67. He also developed the first practical steam locomotive, the "Rocket."
1877: A group of people witness a public demonstration of a new device, a phonograph that records the human voice, at Thomas Edison's "invention factory" at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1881: Cecil B. De Mille, the American film director, is born. He is legendary for his large-scale Biblical and historical epics such as "The Ten Commandments," "Samson and Delilah" and "Cleopatra."
1898: The United States and Spain sign a protocol ending the Spanish-American War, with Spain relinquishing Cuba and ceding Puerto Rico to the United States. In addition, the Hawaiian Islands are formally annexed by the United States.
1908: The Ford Motor Co. introduces its Model T car, a sturdy, black, four-cylinder number that comes in two versions: tourer and roadster. Both retail at incredibly low prices: the roadster at US$825 and the tourer for just US$25 more.
1912: William Booth, a Methodist minister who founded the Salvation Army in London in 1865, dies of illness in London at the age of 83. The Salvation Army works to foster a love of God and to provide for the needy. It offers its services to people of any race, creed, sex or age.
1914: Britain declares war on Austria-Hungary.
1946: The stolen body of dictator Benito Mussolini is found in northern Italy.
1948: The United States recognizes South Korea.
1954: The last batch of United Nations forces in the Korean War pulls out of Korea.
1961: Chen Chia-keng, an overseas Chinese from Singapore and founder of Amoy University, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 88.
1970: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and West Germany sign a non-aggression pact in Moscow.
1970: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane of the Republic of China crashes into a mountain on its way from Hualien in eastern Taiwan to Taipei, killing or injuring 31 people.
1978: Taiwan's fastest electrified train, the Tzu Chiang Express, makes a test run between Taipei and Taichung.
1978: Mainland China and Japan sign a treaty of peace and friendship in Beijing.
1985: A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 Jumbo jet crashes into Mount Osutaka on its way from Tokyo to Osaka, killing all but four of the 524 people aboard.
1990: Beijing's attempt to restore its tarnished image after the slaughter in Tiananmen Square receives a severe setback. Official documentation of the disturbances now reveals that more than 450 were killed, the majority by bullets, while 750 were injured and 3,000 were detained.
1991: Two mainland journalists arrive in Taipei, marking the first-ever visit to the ROC by the mainland Chinese press.
1995: The United States government decides to stop all nuclear testing.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for the Dominican Republic to attend the Aug. 16 inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez.
1999: CAL signs an agreement with Airbus Industrie of Europe for a US$1.8 billion order for seven A340-300 passenger jets, with an option for one more A340-300 and four A330-300s.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh urges mainland China to produce a president through popular elections so as to bridge the gap between the political systems and public opinion on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political party formed by some of former President Lee Teng-hui's followers is formally inaugurated, with a written congratulatory message from President Chen Shui-bian read out at the ceremony.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way for a man to be true to himself. If he does not know what is good, a man cannot be true to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT: MY DUTY IS TO HELP PRESIDENT COMPLETE TERM OF OFFICE(repeat)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that it was her constitutional duty to help President Chen Shui-bian complete his term of office, and she called on the public to "continue supporting the president and help him weather the difficulties."
She made the remarks after attending a business group's changeover event.
She denied that she had made a phone call to former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who has kicked off a campaign to topple the president "for the sake of Taiwan's future."
Lu also denied that she was forming an alliance with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng in the event of Chen's resignation.
"The media just love to write about fiction, rather than news stories," she said.
Shih has commented that many people did not wish to see Chen step down, fearing Chen would be replaced by Lu.
In response, Lu said, "I suppose it is he [Shih] who fears this the most."

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPENSION OF CHARGES OFFERED TO HELP DRUG ADDICTS KICK THE HABIT(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Tainan Prosecutor's Office in southern Taiwan will launch an experimental program Sept. 1 to offer drug addicts suspended indictments on condition of compulsory treatment as part of efforts to reduce overall drug dependency, a spokesman said Friday.

Under the program, addicts who voluntarily undergo treatment will have their legal charges suspended if they contribute NT$50,000 toward a special fund that finances the cost of compulsory rehabilitation.
Drug addicts who are first caught by law enforcement will have to contribute NT$100,000 toward the special alternative treatment fund to qualify for the suspension of charges.
Chu Chao-liang, chief prosecutor at the Tainan Prosecutor's Office, said the contribution requirement is congruent with the "making users pay" principle.

The compulsory treatment will require drug addicts to visit a designated hospital regularly to drink a dose of Methadone -- a substitute drug that reduces dependency on more lethal drugs such as heroin -- and reduce the risk of contracting diseases through hypodermic needle infections.
Chu unveiled the experimental program at a coordination meeting of officials from the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), the Tainan county government and the Tainan city government.

Speaking at the meeting at the DOH-run Chianan Psychiatric Center in Tainan County, Kuo Hsu-sung, director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said the DOH welcomes the new experimental program to help drug addicts quit the vice by offering suspended indictment charges on condition of compulsory treatment.
"We hope the new program will provide an incentive in our fight against drug hazards and drug addiction," Kuo said.

As drug addiction has become a main source of Taiwan's AIDS/HIV transmissions -- with two out of every three new HIV carriers being intravenous drug users -- the DOH launched an experimental needle exchange project in Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County and Tainan County last year.

The project has initially borne fruit, as all new HIV infection rates in those areas have fallen below the country's average level of 56.38 percent. Since July 1 this year, the "clean needle" program has been implemented across the country.
Kuo said Tainan County has been the most successful in the first stage of the DOH's drug reduction plan by integrating the clean needle and alternative treatment projects.

A total of 129 drug addicts have entered the Chianan Psychiatric Center's alternative treatment program. With the Tainan Prosecutor's Office and additional medical institutions in the region taking part as well, Kuo believes the results will be even more remarkable.
Kuo added that the DOH plans to invite U.S. and Australian experts to Tainan in September to review the county's achievements in drug hazard control and prevention.
"We'll also introduce Tainan's drug-fighting experience to other counties and cities around Taiwan," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES REPORTED ARMS DEAL WITH LIBYA(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) denied Friday a media report that Libya sent delegates to review Taiwan's just-concluded Hankuang No.22 military exercise as the northern African country plans to purchase firearms from Taiwan.
The report was sheer speculation and completely unfounded, the MND said in a press statement.
The statement said the military didn't invite any Libyan military personnel to review the Hankuang drill and has not had any plan to sell weapons or military equipment to that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SPICY GIRL' AT TOURISM PROMOTIONAL EVENT RAISES EYEBROWS(repeat)

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu felt acutely embarrassed when he removed a placard at a promotional event Friday to unveil a bikini-clad young woman lying on a buffet table.

The event was organized by a travel agents association in the central city of Taichung to promote an agricultural fair, slated to take place at the city's Dakeng Scenic Area from this weekend through Oct. 1.
The scantily-dressed woman was covered with salad made of bamboo shoots, one of the specialty farm products to be promoted at the upcoming fair, dubbed the 2006 Taichung Bamboo Shoot Festival.
Although the emcee of the ceremony invited Hu to remove bamboo shoot pieces from the prostrate woman's body, Hu remained unmoved and declined to do so.

While admiring the private travel association's efforts to promote the city's tourist attractions and agricultural resources, Hu said he hadn't expected the organizers to adopt such a publicity gimmick.
Critics said the organizers employed the wrong promotional strategy for the event, which was aimed at showcasing the city's beautiful scenery and cuisine, rather than eroticism.
The Dakeng area produces bamboo shoots, organges, WenXin orchids and many kinds of watercultivated vegetables.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POLITICAL SITUATION COMPLICATES U.S. POLICY: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The public enthusiasm displayed formerly by the U.S. government for supporting Taiwan initiatives appears to have abated in the wake of recent political developments in Taiwan, according to a report released Friday by the U.S. Congressional Research Service (CRS).

"While still pursuing a closer U.S. relationship with Taiwan, U.S. officials now appear to be balancing criticisms of the PRC military buildup opposite Taiwan with periodic cautions and warnings to the effect that U.S. support for Taiwan is not unconditional, but has limits," the report said.
The report titled "Taiwan: Recent Developments and U.S. Policy Choices" was written by Kerry Dumbaugh, a specialist in Asian affairs at the CRS' Foreign Affairs, Defense, and Trade Division.

The report said that early in its tenure, the George W. Bush administration seemed to abandon the long-standing U.S. policy of "strategic ambiguity" on Taiwan in favor of "strategic clarity" that placed more emphasis on Taiwan's interests and less on PRC concerns.
For example, Bush publicly stated in 2001 that the United States would do "whatever it takes" to help defend Taiwan and approved a substantial sale of U.S. weapons to Taiwan, the report noted.

It said the White House was more accomodating to visits by Taiwan officials than previous U.S. administrations, permitting visits by President Chen Shui-bian in 2001 and by Vice President Annette Lu in 2003.
With support for Taiwan growing in the U.S. Congress, a House Congressional Taiwan Caucus was established in 2002 and a Senate Taiwan Caucus was set up in 2003, it said.

However, while Chen's position that Taiwan already "is an independent, sovereign country" has worried many Taiwan voters, the recent string of corruption scandals allegedly involving government officials and Chen's family members have led to record-low approval ratings for Chen and a mounting political outcry against him, the report said.
"These political trends have raised anxieties about the possibility of a future political or constitutional crisis in Taiwan that could further complicate U.S. policy," the report said.
It said U.S. officials have been under subtle but increasing pressure from both Taipei and Beijing to become directly involved in some aspects of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

In late 2003, Beijing officials began quietly urging Washington to pressure Chen into shelving plans for a national referendum, and in 2004, they pressed U.S. officials to avoid sending the "wrong signals" to Taiwan, the report said.
Taipei officials, on the other hand, have begun suggesting that the United States strengthen or reevaluate the Taiwan Relations Act and support Chen's constitutional reform plans, the report said.
Meanwhile, Taiwan supporters within the U.S. Congress continue to press for more favorable U.S. treatment of Taiwan and for Taiwan's inclusion in international organizations, it said.

"Faced with competing pressures and with continuing transformations in both the PRC and Taiwan systems, U.S. officials may be facing new and more difficult policy choices concerning Taiwan in the next few years," the report said.

Under these circumstances, the U.S. government might take any number of actions, including reassessing all the fundamentals of U.S. China/Taiwan policy in light of changing circumstances, reinforcing American democratic values by providing greater support for Taiwan and possibly support for Taiwan independence, or abandoning Taiwan in favor of the geopolitical demands and benefits of close U.S.-China relations, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS TO GIVE REPORT ON PROGRESS IN 'STATE AFFAIRS FUND' PROBE

TEXT.P: The first-stage probe into the "possible irregularities" in the handling of President Chen Shui-bian's special state affairs expenditure account has almost been completed, the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office (THPO) said Saturday.

"After more than a month of intensive investigations, we have accumulated a rich collection of data on the use of the president's special 'state affairs fund' and plan to give a public briefing on progress in our work next week," a THPO official said.

The THPO formed a special task force in late June to investigate the case after receiving suspicious financial data and accounting records related to the president's special "state affairs fund" from the Ministry of Audit (MOA) under the Control Yuan.

Members of the task force confirmed for the first time Saturday that they have interviewed at least 20 people, including the Presidential Office accounting department staff, about the "state affairs" expenditure account.

Some of the task force members have visited the Presidential Office to gather information, including examining classified files. Nevertheless, they declined to confirm whether they had interviewed former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng, who used to be Chen's right-hand man.
So far, only Lee Pi-chun, the owner of a pharmaceutical company, has been listed as a suspect and banned from leaving the country.
Opposition politicians have accused Chen of using "fake invoices" to reimburse the special "state affairs" expenses after the MOA found irregularities in the Presidential Office accounting report.

During Wednesday's questioning, Lee Pi-chun told the prosecutorial task force that she had given Grand Hyatt Hotel invoices to "other people" but that she had no idea why those invoices ended up in the accounting reports of the Presidential Office.

Lee denied that she has ever given the controversial invoices directly to first lady Wu Shu-jen. Opposition lawmakers had alleged that Wu might have used the controversial invoices to help her husband reimburse the "state affairs fund." The president has repeatedly denied that he has ever pocketed a single cent from the fund budgeted for his discretionary use.

According to a long-established custom, half of the president's "state affairs fund" can be reimbursed with just his personal signature, while the remaining half requires invoices or receipts for reimbursement.

Prosecutors said they have focused probes on the part that requires invoices for reimbursement, adding that they have discovered some suspicious invoices and receipts as well as cases in which invoices provided by "unrelated individuals" were used to reimburse the fund.
Those involved may face charges of fraud and document forgery, prosecutors said, adding that if necessary, they will interview more suspects and witnesses, including President Chen himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMBATTLED PRESIDENT ADDRESSES CALLS FOR HIS OUSTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday indirectly answered the mounting calls for his resignation over a series of corruption allegations implicating his close aides and family members by stressing that all actions taken should adhere to constitutional procedures.

The embattled president made the remarks while delivering a speech on "the art of leadership" at a training class at the Ketagalan Institute, a school which he founded in 2003 with the aim of nurturing the nation's future leaders.

On calls by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, to launch a "one million citizens to depose President Chen" drive the same day, the president said all actions taken must fall within the framework of the Constitution.
Shih's call came on the heels of an appeal for the president's resignation by a group of pro-green academics July 15.

Chen stressed the importance of "the rule of law in a democracy," adding that "if a president has done a poor job, then the Constitution has provisions for recalling or impeaching the president or even holding a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet, " which he said are "all important parts of constitutional order by which everyone should abide."
"Using revolutionary means which lead to the shedding of blood does not mark progress in a democracy, but instead marks its regression, "he said.
"The issue is by no means who should step down and who should take over. The core issue is the constitutional system, " he continued.
He also touched on the issue of "transitional justice, " saying that many difficulties could arise in the transformation of a nation from authoritarian to democratic rule.

The controversial issues of his alleged misuse of the "state affairs fund" put under his discretionary use, as well as his sending of his housemaid to work at his residence occupied by his married daughter at the public's expense are examples of "legacies from the past" when such actions were permitted but which are criticized harshly nowadays.
Many of the old practices and irregularities could be thoroughly reviewed and a fair governing system established for the future in order to avoid unnecessary controversies, he added.

Chen's words came against the backdrop of the People First Party, the second largest opposition party, mulling whether to move to introduce a motion to impeach him in the upcoming legislative session.

President Chen survived a recall attempt in late June when an opposition-initiated motion to recall him failed to receive the required endorsement of two-thirds of all lawmakers in order to be put to a national referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RENEWS PROPOSAL ON U.N. APPLICATION UNDER TAIWAN'S NAME

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian renewed his proposal Saturday that the country should seriously consider applying to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.

Stressing that identifying with Taiwan and sticking to the Taiwanese identity is the right path for the country, Chen said Taiwan should not waste any more effort competing for China's representation in the United Nations and disputing the rightfulness of Resolution 2758 under which the Republic of China's U.N. seat was given to the People's Republic of China in 1971.

"Taiwan is Taiwan, and China is China. Taiwan is definitely not China, " Chen said while giving a lecture at the Ketagalan Institute which he founded in 2003 with the aim of nurturing the country's future leaders.
"We should consider applying to join the United Nations directly under the name of Taiwan, and it's time for us to conduct a serious review of our policy, " he added.
Chen said Taiwan is facing a problem that does not exist in other countries, namely that people in this country are split in terms of their national identity.

Chen noted that a travel guide on Taipei mentions that some people who immigrated to Taiwan from China after 1949 do not feel comfortable being called "Taiwanese, " and this makes him feel very strange and is hard for him to accept.
While some politicians in Taiwan have claimed to be "new Taiwanese, " they should not feel ashamed but should be proud of being Taiwanese, Chen said.
He said the "one China" policy adopted by the former Kuomintang government has led to Taiwan's exclusion from the United Nations and its isolation in the international community.
Over the past 35 years, Taiwan has been forbidden from using its official name "Republic of China" and asked to change its name, he said.

While Taiwan has taken part in the Olympic Games under the name of "Chinese Taipei" since 1984, the country became a member of the World Trade Organization in 2002 under the name of "the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu," Chen pointed out.
He noted that Taiwan has been trying to gain entry to the World Health Organization for the past decade but that the bid has been unsuccessful even under the name of a health entity.
The president said the recent severance of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Chad has again demonstrated the limitations that the country is subject to under China's diplomatic suppression.

According to Chen, China was not any more lenient toward Taiwan during the past KMT government, with Taiwan losing 13 diplomatic allies to China during the 12 years that President Lee Teng-hui was in office.
"This shows that the 'one China' policy adopted by the former government was nothing but a myth," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSAT-3 ON POSITION, SENDING OBSERVATION DATA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's recently launched sounding satellite, FORMASAT-3, has begun sending weather data, as the first micro-satellite of the constellation settled in its designated orbital plane, a senior official of the FORMOSAT-3 Program Office said Saturday.

Yen Lung-cheng, director of the program office, said that FORMOSAT-3 at present stage is only able to collect and transmit per day 700 entries of atmospheric data and 2,500 entries of ionospheric data, adding that when all six micro-satellites are in position, the satellite constellation will reach its full capacity of sending per day 2,500 pieces of atmospheric data and ionospheric data each.

FORMASAT-3, an atmosphere observing constellation of six micro- satellites, lifted off in the U.S. state of California in April 15 and reached its initial parking orbit of 500 kilometers above ground. The six micro-satellites will gradually move into position on their orbital planes at 800 kilometers above ground by mid 2007, with the first of the micro-satellites already having done so July 19.

According to the program office, the other five are still on the parking orbit at an altitude of around 500 kilometers to 550 kilometers and waiting to lift to the final orbits to carry out their five-year weather observation mission.

FORMASAT-3 is Taiwan's third satellite project, following the launch of FORMOSAT-1 in 1999 and FORMOSAT-2 in 2004. FORMOSAT-3 -- also known as Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate -- is a collaborative project between Taiwan' s National Space Organization and the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research in the United States.

Researchers from 26 countries, as well as Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau and weather centers in the United States and Britain, have been using FORMOSAT-3's sounding data for weather forecasts and atmospheric research, Yen said, adding that the preliminary research results will be presented at a seminar on FORMAT-3 to be held Nov. 28 to Dec. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS DREAM OF CRAFTING NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Saturday his dream of crafting a new Constitution for the country, saying that it is his "historic mission."

The president made the remarks while delivering a speech titled "The Art of Leadership" at a training class at the Ketagalan Institute, a school he founded in 2003 to nurture the nation's future leaders.
Chen, currently dogged by a series of corruption allegations implicating his top aides and family members, said that the issue now is not who should step down or who should assume office.
"The serious issue is the constitutional system, and we need to make efforts to firmly establish a constitutional system," he said.
He said his "biggest dream is to bring about a timely, relevant and viable Constitution that Taiwan needs."
"If this is done, I'll accomplish my historic mission. If not, I'll regret it forever. I'll feel sorry for this nation and its great people," he said.

The president stressed that in his remaining time in office, he will "shoulder the cross of Taiwan history, insist on Taiwan's sovereignty, push for constitutional re-engineering and follow the right path, " even if this means enduring "injury to myself or the shedding of my blood."

He said that the present Constitution has to be changed, adding that Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , has advocated a "parliamentary system" in which the dominant party in the legislature forms the Cabinet, in contrast to the current system in which the president appoints a premier who then forms the Cabinet.
He stressed that every one is entitled to freedom of speech and that he has no preset ideas on which kind of system should be adopted.

Pointing out that any changes to the Constitution will require the consent of the people, he said that as long as a revised version can gain the support of three-fourths of the legislature and be passed by a majority of the people in a national referendum, he will have no objections.

Noting that the DPP is scheduled to propose its version of a new Constitution next month, while its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , will also submit its own version, President Chen that it is "very gratifying" that many are moving in the same direction.

The president began his speech by congratulating the TSU on the fifth anniversary of its founding and expressing his respect for the contribution of former President Lee Teng-hui, the spiritual leader of the TSU, to the nation's democratization as well as his guidance in 2000 when the DPP swept the Kuomintang from power after five decades of rule.
Chen lauded Lee as the "father of Taiwan's democracy" and said he should be considered the spiritual leader of the 23 million people of Taiwan.
Although former DPP Chairman Shih called a news conference to explain his drive to depose the president the same day, Chen lauded Shih as one of the major forerunners of Taiwan's democratic movement.
"The DPP is a homegrown political party, and one that stresses Taiwan identity and democracy, " Chen said, expressing his appreciation to pioneers of the democratic movement such as Shih.

Without Shih, who served as the DPP chairman 1994-1996 before quitting the party in 2000, Chen said, it would have been impossible for him to have won the 1994 Taipei mayoral election, a DPP victory in the city's first direct mayoral election in 30 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ENERGY CONSUMPTION UP 2.52% IN FIRST HALF 2006

TEXT.P: Taiwan's energy consumption amounted to 53.34 million kiloliters of crude oil equivalent (KLOE) in the first half of 2006, up 2.52 percent over the year-earlier level, according to tallies released Saturday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Energy supplies amounted to 68.48 million KLOE during the same period, up 4.66 percent year-on-year.

Of these supplies, oil and related products amounted to 36.28 million KLOE, up 7.71 percent over the same period last year; coal amounted to 29.9 million KLOE, up 1.96 percent year-on-year; natural gas and liquefied natural gas amounted to 4.7 billion cubic meters, up 8.18 percent; and renewable energy amounted to 978,903 KLOE, down 2.01 percent year-on-year.

In the first half of 2006, energy consumption by the industrial sector increased 3.41 percent year-on-year, while that by the transportation sector rose 2.19 percent, and that by the commercial sector climbed 3.48 percent.
Meanwhile, energy consumption by the agricultural sector dropped 24.52 percent year-on-year, and that by the household sector dipped 0.72 percent.

The capture of a British national in Pakistan was the trigger for the arrests of 24 men suspected of plotting to blow up transatlantic airliners.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PROPOSES DRAWING UP NEW CONTROL YUAN NOMINEE LIST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday proposed drawing up a new list of Control Yuan member nominees if the opposition promises not to insist on raising the threshold of confirmation to two-thirds of the Legislative Yuan.
The president made the proposal during his speech at the Ketagalan Institute, a school he founded in 2003 to nurture future national leaders.

The president stressed that before the current five-branch system of government is changed to a three-branch system, he hopes the legislature will confirm the Control Yuan member and the State Public Prosecutor-General nominees speedily.

The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, has been left vacant since the terms of the previous Control Yuan members expired in January 2005 as the opposition-dominated legislature is unsatisfied with some of the president's nominees, especially the nominee to serve as Control Yuan president, namely Clement C.P. Chang. The opposition also rejected a nominee to serve in the nation's top prosecutorial post earlier this year.

The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) immediately dismissed Chen's proposal as a ploy to shift public attention away from the ongoing investigations into a series of corruption allegations implicating his family members and his top aides.

Tsai Chin-lung, KMT caucus whip in the legislature, expressed suspicions about President Chen's intentions in offering to draw up a new list at a time when he is embroiled in allegations of misusing a "state affairs fund."
Tsai called for the president to "first clear up the scandals" before dealing with other issues, such as the nominee list.

Lu Hsueh-chang, a PFP caucus whip, said that legislators have yet to reach a consensus on raising the threshold for the confirmation of Control Yuan member nominees, adding that the opposition's rejection of the list has to do with the nomination procedures as well as misgivings about the nominees and that it is not related to the threshold issue.
"If the president wants to redraw the list, then he should just go ahead and do it without linking it to the threshold issue, " Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Timothy J. Hwang)
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.N. Council Backs Measure to Halt War in Lebanon The Security Council agreed unanimously on Friday on a measure calling for a full cessation of hostilities in Lebanon, deploying 30,000 Lebanese and United Nations forces in southern Lebanon and calling upon Israel to withdraw its forces "in parallel." After rejecting earlier versions, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel accepted the resolution. But, under a deal an Israeli official said was approved by the United States, Mr. Olmert will wait until Sunday to obtain his cabinet's approval. Until then, he will expand his monthlong military campaign against the Hezbollah militia and its rocket arsenal.
Wall Street Journal: Terror Probe Eyes Pakistani Links Of British Suspects On Wednesday, Pakistani authorities arrested Rashid Rauf, a young Briton wanted on charges that he murdered his uncle in 2002. Soon thereafter, British police 4,000 miles away moved in to break up a terrorist cell they say was planning to blow up several airliners midflight.

DOC.HEADLINE: STILL A LOT MORE FOR PRESIDENT TO DO: FORUM PARTICIPANTS

TEXT.P: Whether President Chen Shui-bian should resign ought to be determined according to the Constitution, and there are many more tasks for the president to complete during the remainder of his term, a group of Taiwan independence advocates said at a forum Saturday.

"The president's legitimacy is regulated and defined by the Constitution. Taiwan's ongoing problems should be resolved within the framework of the Constitution, instead of by resorting to 'outside powers'," political commentator Chin Heng-wei said.

The forum, titled "2008 and Taiwan's Future, " was organized by Taiwan Society North, a Taiwan independence advocacy group, on the same day that a number of public rallies were held in several cities calling the president to step down.

"What the president should do is tell the Taiwan people what he will do in the future as a president and apologize for what he has done wrong, " said Koo Kuan-min, a former senior advisor to President Chen.

Koo further said that President Chen failed to deliver on his promises related to all-out reform and economic policies during the last six years, adding that he has been unable to "flex his muscles" because of the "Four Noes" pledge given in his inaugural speech in 2000.

On the topic of the 2008 presidential election, Koo made clear that the election will be a choice between unification with China and Taiwan independence, adding that he is still optimistic that "the local regime will not be defeated."

"The outcome of the 2008 presidential election will be a defining moment for President Chen. If the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) fails to win, it will be seen as a 'one-hit wonder' and Chen will be remembered for this," Chin stressed.

Chen Mao-hsiung, a professor at National Sun Yat-sen University, said that both Ma Yin-jeou, the possible presidential candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , and Chen both value short-term "tactics" over long-term "strategies" because both of them have been through so many elections.
"All they want is to win (the elections). However, sometimes this does not serve the public's interests, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GARBAGE REDUCTION CAMPAIGN ACHIEVES GOAL AHEAD OF SCHEDULE: EPA

TEXT.P: The government's "garbage classification" campaign has achieved its initial goal of "cutting trash volume by 25 percent in three years" ahead of schedule, an environmental protection official said Saturday.

The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) launched a three-year compulsory waste classification campaign in 2004 with an aim of reducing the country's overall garbage volume by 25 percent by 2007.

"At the end of May this year, the amount of recycled garbage was 836,200 tons, with the recycling rate reaching 26.13 percent, " said Sung Yi-jen, a division chief with the EPA's Waste Management Department.

The recycling rate marked an increase of 8.24 percentage points over the figure of 17.89 percent recorded in 2003, Sung said, adding that the figures indicate that the country's waste volume has been reduced by 25 percent through recyling, a goal that was originally set for completion in 2007.
In May, recycled kitchen leftovers totaled 228,400 tons for a recycling rate of 7.14 percent, compared to a mere 2.19 percent two years ago, Sung said.
Meanwhile, the average daily amount of trash per person declined to a record low of 0.618 kg in May from 1.143 kg in 19976, Sung said.

Despite the encouraging results, Sung said, the EPA will not be complacent and will work even harder to push for realization of a further goal of cutting garbage volume by 40 percent in 2011 and 75 percent by 2020.

DOC.HEADLINE: CULTURAL LUKANG TOPS IN 'SMILING TOWN' CONTEST

TEXT.P: Lukang in Changhua County in central Taiwan has been chosen as the top township in terms of friendliness, taste and distinctive features in a "smiling town" contest whose results were published Saturday.

In terms of friendliness, cleanness, taste, distinctive features and sense of happiness, Taiwanese people appreciate Lukang most. It was followed by Suao in Yilan County, Tamshui in Taipei County, Chiunglin in Hsinchu County, and Tachia in Taichung County.

Further analysis found that Lukang, which is dotted with cultural relics in central Taiwan, has been the most friendly, tasteful and distinctive town, while Suao has been the cleanest and has given the greatest sense of happiness.

The contest was the climax to a "revisit 319 towns with a smile" activity launched by a local major magazine, the Commonwealth, in July 2005. The voting was held between July 9, 2005 and June 30, 2006, with more than 34,660 members casting votes online.
At least 595 residents completed the "visit-towns-around- the-island" journey and received a certificate from Premier Su Tsang-chang in a ceremony Saturday.

Su said he admires the nearly 600 people who possessed the passion and persistence to complete the journey, expressing the hope that "all will love the land with their feet" in similar activities in the future.

The premier also recalled that when he graduated from National Taiwan University, he rode around the island on a bicycle. He said he hopes that he can repeat the same journey with his daughters someday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFECT OF OPENING TO CHINESE TOURISTS WILL BE LESS THAN EXPECTED: CIER

TEXT.P: The contribution to Taiwan's economy of opening the country to mainland Chinese tourists will not be as great as most people expect, a think tank said Saturday.

The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) made the prediction after the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said recently that Chinese tourists are expected at the end of the year judging from the progress in negotiations between the two sides on the matter.
Chou Ji, director of the institute's center for economic outlook, said that if 1,000 Chinese tourists visit Taiwan each day, then there will be 365,000 visits by Chinese tourists a year.
The Bureau of Tourism said that if Chinese tourists spend US$180.5 per day on average and stay for 7.61 days per visit, then this will translate into US$501 million in tourism revenue for Taiwan.

Chou noted that tourism revenue should be counted as commodity and service exports. The institute had originally estimated that if Chinese tourists began arriving in August, then the commodity and service exports in the third quarter would increase by around NT$3 billion (US$91.46 million), or a 0.04 percentage point increase in the nation's economic growth, pushing growth to 4.15 percent from the original estimate of 4.11 percent.
However, as the policy is not expected to be implemented until the end of this year, the contribution to Taiwan's economic growth will only begin next year, Chou added.

In 2007, the opening will bring in roughly NT$16 billion in tourism revenue, and economic growth will be a modest 4.22 percent, showing that the benefits of the opening will not be as great as anticipated.

Chou explained that the main reason is that Taiwan's policy is to set a ceiling of 1,000 Chinese tourists per day. Even if there are a total of 365,000 visits by mainland Chinese to Taiwan a year, the number of mainland Chinese tourists will only account for 9.25 percent of the total number of foreign tourists to Taiwan.
Until the government raises the ceiling on the number of Chinese tourists, there will not be a significant boost to economic growth, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY MAKES RARE APPEARANCE

TEXT.P: First lady Wu Shu-jen, who has not been seen in public since April, made an unexpected appearance at her old residence on Taipei's Minsheng E. Road Saturday.

Her appearance caused a commotion as a crowd of journalists swarmed to interview her. The journalists have been camping outside the house since her son-in-law Chao Chien-ming's alleged involvement in an insider trading scandal came to light in May.
Asked whether she was visiting the house to see Chao, the wheelchair-bound first lady said she just wanted to take a brief rest.
After a 30-minute stay, Wu left the house which has been occupied by President Chen Shui-bian's daughter Chen Hsing-yu since she got married in October 2001.

Wu was last seen in public April 11 when she accompanied her husband to greet visiting Marshall Islands President Kessai Note. For the past few months, Wu herself has also been dogged by allegations that she profited from the transfer of ownership of an upscale Taipei department store. There have also been reports that she is in a poor health.
Chao, an orthopedic surgeon who was released on bail July 10 shortly after being indicted on the charge of using insider information to profit from trading Taiwan Development Corp. stock.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLOMON ISLANDS PM UNDERGOES PHYSICAL CHECKUP AT KAOHSIUNG HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: Visiting Solomon Islands Prime Minister Hanasseh Sogavare underwent a physical checkup at Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital in southern Taiwan Saturday.

Sogavare, who arrived in Taipei Friday for a six-day visit in the company of his wife and more than 10 senior officials, was briefed on the hospital's history, latest developments and facilities before undergoing a thorough physical checkup.
Sogavare's wife and members of his entourage also underwent similar checkups.

Later in the day, Sogavare and his entourage visited the Nantze export processing zone on the outskirts of Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second largest city. Sogavare said he was impressed by the contributions of export processign zones in Taiwan's economic development over the past decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEPATITIS C-RELATED LIVER CANCER MORTALITY ON THE RISE: REPORT

TEXT.P: Mortality of hepatitis C-related liver cancer has been rising in Taiwan, particularly in the southern counties of Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan, according to a study report released Saturday.

The report, prepared by eight medical centers around the country, analyzed more than 18,000 liver cancer cases recorded between 1981 and 2001, which found an upward trend in over liver cancer mortality.
As deaths from hepatitis B-related liver cancer didn't increase during the period, the report said the surge could largely be attributed to rising mortality from hepatitis C-related liver cancer.
The report also found that the Yunlin-Chiayi-Tainan area was hardest hit by hepatitis C as the region's liver cancer mortality was higher than the national average.

According to the report, about 40 percent to 50 percent of male liver cancer deaths in the region were hepatitis C patients, while the ratio among women in the three counties ranged between 60 percent and 80 percent.

Chen Chien-hung, a doctor at National Taiwan University Hospital's department of internal medicine, said the high hepatitis C mortality in the Yunlin-Chiayi-Tainan region might be related to inappropriate medical treatment administered by unlicensed doctors there some 20 years. But he added that it's just speculation that requires epidemiological surveys to verify.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 13, or the 20th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, located at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish-American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho" and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander in chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Zedong names Beijing as Communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1974: Mort Young, deputy editor-in-chief of Hearst Newspapers in the United States, arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit.
1975: An eight-member Taiwan dance troupe leaves for La Paz to perform at celebrations marking Bolivia's independence day.
1976: Over 140 youths from 20 nations join in the opening ceremony of the International Youth Recreation Tour to the Republic of China sponsored by the China Youth Corps.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves extension of the Sino-Uruguayan Agreement on Agricultural Cooperation for two years.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seekers freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Communist Chinese Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria, to Seoul, South Korea, on May 5, 1983.
1989: Two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of the balloons plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1993: A hotel collapses in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
1999: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan estimates that the ROC's economic growth rate will reach 5.5 percent for the year.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and his 200-member entourage leave Taipei, beginning a 13-day visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa.
2001: Academia Sinica member George C. Tiao becomes the first scholar and the first ethnic Chinese to receive both the prestigious Wilks Memorial Award and the Julius Shiskin Award in statistics in the same year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Trust is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."
