DOC.HEADLINE: FAIR TRADE COMMISSION WARNS AGAINST PRICE FIXING

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission (FTC) warned manufacturers, distributors and retailers in all industries Sunday that they could face heavy fines or even prison terms if they take concerted action to fix prices.

A spokesman for the FTC noted that market prices have fluctuated frequently in the past year and that more and more suppliers of similar products or services have collaborated with one another to adjust their prices.

Taiwan's Fair Trade Law prohibits suppliers from taking "concerted action" to fix prices of goods and services, the spokesman said, adding that violators can be fined NT$25 million (US$765,955), and that repeat offenders are likely to face a maximum sentence of three years in prison.

He said the FTC will hold a seminar Aug. 15 in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, to explain Article 7 of the Fair Trade Law governing monopoly and concerted action in price fixing, which occurs when two or more competitors agree on how they will charge customers for products or services.

The Hualien seminar will be the third in a series held by the FTC to help businesses understand the Fair Trade Law. The previous two seminars took place in Taichung and Kaohsiung on July 21 and Aug. 4, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL NOT TAKE PART IN ANTI-PRESIDENT DRIVE: CAUCUS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will not get directly involved in an anti-President Chen Shui-bian drive initiated by a former chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) but is supportive of such an action, a high-ranking KMT official said Sunday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said the KMT approves of former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh's launch of the anti-Chen drive a day earlier and will not rein in its members or followers who want to support the movement demanding that Chen step down, but will not take part in the campaign directly in order to avoid providing Chen and the DPP administration with an opportunity of accusing the KMT of orchestrating "party-to-party struggle."

Tseng said that since the KMT has been long considered by Chen and the DPP administration as a sworn enemy, participation in Shih's movement might provide Chen and his government with an opportunity to blur the focus of the movement.

He said this stance is in line with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's viewpoint that Shih has a greater chance of dragging the president from office than does the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party.
Shih, who was DPP chairman between 1993 and 1996, launched the campaign that calls on the people to stand up to force Chen to step down amid corruption allegations dogging his family and close aides.

Meanwhile, Tseng said that Chen's renewed calls for crafting a new constitution and for Taiwan to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" amid mounting pressure for his resignation are only ploys to shift public attention away from the ongoing investigations into the series of corruption allegations in which he is allegedly involved.

Tseng urged Chen to clear the people's doubts about his alleged use of the Presidential Office's special state affairs fund for his family's own expenses and to stop "fooling the country with political hot air."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi: Italy ready for Lebanon peace mission.
Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi said Saturday that Italy is ready to participate in the international peacekeeping force in Lebanon under the United Nations mandate. Military sources revealed that 3,000 to 3,500 soldiers could be sent to Lenanon for the peace mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT: TAIWAN EXPERIENCING UNPRECEDENTED CALAMITIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu claimed Sunday that Taiwan is experiencing an "unprecedented calamity" and she urged the ruling and opposition politicians to stop bickering and pray for their "common mother" -- Taiwan.

Lu made the remarks while addressing a gathering of Buddhist monks and practitioners in Kuishan, in Taoyuan County, to which opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and other political leaders were also invited.
She cited the war between Israel and Hezbollah in southern Lebanon to warn of the consequences that might befall Taiwan if the public do not cherish what they have.

"Stop the ruling and opposition stand-off and duel, " she urged, adding that she has been calling for establishing a "grand alliance of blue sky and green earth" because "only through working together can we hope to create a bright future for Taiwan."
While calling on the ruling and opposition politicians to cast aside their grudges against each other, she also urged the Buddhists to pray for peace in the Middle East.
Lu said Buddhism has been a positive force in educating the people and improving social mores and she prayed that the all-merciful Buddha will bless Taiwan.

She did not elaborate on why she sees Taiwan as in the midst of an "unprecedented" haochieh -- a Buddhist term for catastrophe or holocaust, and she was tight-lipped when reporters questioned her on her status as "substitute president" -- as the possibility loomed larger one day after former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh launched a campaign to oust President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU SEES 'INDIVIDUAL HEROISM' IN ANTI-PRESIDENT CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) criticized former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh Sunday for showing "excessive individual heroism" by launching a "one million people campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian."
Ho Min-hao, executive director of the TSU Policy Committee, said Shih has "made some contribution" to Taiwan's democracy, but whether his current campaign will "move the people" remains to be seen.

The president should do some soul searching as to why his six years in office have produced such poor results, but Shih is not acting in a rational way, Ho claimed, describing Shih's depose-Chen campaign as "insignificant."

The TSU executive lauded Chen's promise to kick off a national campaign to "rectify the national title and introduce a new Constitution for Taiwan" -- a promise Chen has made many times but on which he has consistently failed to act.
Ho said he hopes this time the president means what he says. If Chen were to keep his promise, people would stand behind him, Ho speculated.
He noted that Chen would have to overcome huge pressure from the United States and the People's Republic of China if he were to push for a new name and a new constitution for Taiwan.
However, if he eats his words yet again, he will lose his credibility with the people altogether, Ho warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT CONCERNED ABOUT FEWER NEWBORNS, WORKING ON INCENTIVES

TEXT.P: Facing a plunge in Taiwan's birth rate, the government is projecting to increase subsidies on various fronts to help couples get better monetary aid and assistance to overcome their difficulties in raising children.

According to Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng, although the impact of a shrinking workforce on the economy remains to be seen, a conclusion was reached in the recent Conferene on Sustaining Taiwan's Economic Development that the government should offer incentives to encourage people to have more children.

Hu said that Taiwan couples have fewer children than couples in other major countries, and cited statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) to validate his concern.

In 2005, Taiwan women of child-bearing age had an average of 1.1 children in their lives, far lower than the world average of 2.7 and an average of 1.6 in the world's industrialized countries, according to CEPD tallies.
Compared with neighboring countries, Taiwan's 1.1 was only slightly ahead of Hong Kong's 1.0, but still lagging behind China's 1.6, Japan's 1.3 and South Korea's 1.2.
The number of Taiwan's newborns this year might not break 200,000, the DGBAS forecast.

After having assessed measures adopted by other nations, the CEPD is working to provide better subsides for maternity leave and inexpensive high-quality day care services for career women, Hu said, adding that detailed measures will be made public by the end of this month.
But he pointed out that it is critical to win support from enterprises to put the measures in place, predicting that this should take place in a piecemeal fashion.

As Taiwan's population is rapidly greying, Taiwan's industry is set to suffer a worsening labor shortage, Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung warned, suggesting that the business community make adjustments to secure persistent growth both at home and abroad.

Despite the fact that the increase in Taiwan's population will not come to a halt suddenly, Chen said that its gradual decline will still deal a heavy blow to the social, educational and political sectors.

The DGBAS predicted that by 2018, the number of people in Taiwan's 20-24 age group will be fewer than that of the 60-64 age group. Japan, Germany and Italy have already experienced this change in demographic structure, while France and Canada are expected to face the same situation in 2010 and 2015, respectively, and the United States and Britain in 2020, according to the DGBAS.

In the late-July Conference on Sustaining Taiwan's Economic Development, it was agreed that the government must do something to boost Taiwan workers' participation rate, in particular among women and middle-aged and elderly workers, Economics Ministry officials said.

Although Taiwan still has some 20 years before the pain to be created by a dropping workforce becomes acute, the officials said that the government must take precautions to fend off the possible impact.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARGO SHIP SINKS AFTER SIDESWIPING FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: A cargo ship sank off the coast of Yunlin in southern Taiwan Sunday after sideswiping a passing fishing boat, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) authorities reported.

The Lungyun No. 3, a 668-ton cargo vessel from Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, sideswiped the fishing boat Hunghui, also from Kaohsiung, about 15 nautical miles off Yunlin's Taitzu port at around 1 a.m. Sunday, according to Chiayi-based CGA officers.
The Lungyun began to take in water from a large rift on its side soon after the crash, causing it to sink very quickly, the officers said.
All eight crew members were rescued by three CGA patrol boats, they said.

Of the eight crew members, Ye Mintun, a deckhand of Myanmarian nationality, who suffered cuts to his side, was airlifted to a hospital in Putzu, Yunlin County, for treatment. The other seven crew members were unharmed, the officers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WOULD APOLOGIZE AGAIN IF GOVERNMENT HAS DONE POOR JOB

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that it is the government's job to insist on Taiwan identity, realize social justice and develop the economy, and he added that if the government has not done a good job, he would like to apologize and make a self-examination before "making new start."
The president made the remarks while talking to a group of people representing different sectors of society in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.

Reiterating remarks he made a day earlier in Taipei, Chen said he will "carry the cross of Taiwan's history" during the remainder of his term, which expires May 20, 2008, although more and more people are demanding that he step down much earlier than that.

Following a call last month by a group of pro-Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) academics for him to resign to take moral and political responsibility for a spate of corruption charges against his family members and close aides, former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who described himself as a "comrade" of the president, kicked off a "one million people depose the president" campaign Sunday.
Chen said that like other emerging democracies, Taiwan is experiencing a difficulty of "transition from authoritarianism to democracy" for which he is under pressure from his critics.
"But it is the people who have the greatest power. Let's believe in the people and let them decide [whether I should step down ahead of schedule]," he said.
He said his role during the coming one year and nine months will be like "a trailblazer in the mountains, " with him leading the way despite injury.
"But it does not matter. My personal suffering is nothing, " he added.

The president reiterated that he respects freedom of the press and freedom of expression, and he that would rather be criticized by the media than return the country to the authoritarian days when the media did not enjoy such freedoms.
He added that he believes history will leave a record of which the public will be the best judge.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN: USELESS FOR PRESIDENT TO KEEP 'TOSSING OUT TOPICS'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will not succeed in his attempts to divert public attention from a series of corruption and embezzlement scandals implicating himself, his family members and senior aides, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.

Commenting on the president's address a day earlier at a training class at the Ketagalan Institute, Ma said it is useless for Chen to keep tossing out debate topics in an attempt to shift the people's attention from the scandals.

Chen proposed a series of plans Saturday, including drafting a new constitution, applying to join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan, " submitting a new list of Control Yuan member nominees to the legislature, and measures to strengthen the people's identification with Taiwan, including changing the name of Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to Taipei International Airport.
Describing Chen as a "spent force," the KMT chairman said tossing out a series of topics will not make the people of Taiwan believe Chen is clean and innocent.

Citing an example, Ma pointed out that the city of Taipei already has an airport, called Sungshan Airport. "Why should Chiang Kai-shek international Airport in Taoyuan County be renamed Taipei International Airport?" he asked.

An unofficial tally kept by TV commentators shows that the president, his family members and senior aides have been involved in at least 29 corruption and embezzlement scandals since Chen began serving his first term as president in 2000. Only a few of the scandals have entered legal proceedings.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER OPPOSES OFFERING FREE NEEDLES TO DRUG ADDICTS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Huang Wei-cher expressed opposition Sunday to a plan by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) to provide free clean needles at convenience stores across Taiwan for drug addicts.
Huang expressed his disagreement with the DOH plan at a news conference in the Legislative Yuan that was also attended by officials from the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC).
Huang urged the DOH to put auxiliary measures in place before kicking off the plan to avoid causing panic among local community residents.

"It is important to ward off the spread of AIDS, but it should not be done at the extra cost of public order in local communities, " Huang argued, saying that "helping addicts to quit narcotics and forging a sound policy to raise public AIDS-prevention awareness should be the best remedy."

The CDC started offering clean needles for drug addicts free of charge at convenience stores around the clock in Taipei city, Taipei county, Taoyuan county and Tainan county last year on a trial basis, and is planning to set up over 400 posts in other cities and counties to provide similar services and public health counselling about AIDS.
According to a CDC official, the services have been effective in preventing the spread of AIDS.
For instance, he said, the number of new AIDS patients dropped to 62 as of May this year from 163 in 2004 in Tainan county, with 430,000 clean needles given away during the same period.
According to CDC statistics, the number of Taiwan's AIDS patients totaled 12,012 as of the end of July this year, 4,423 of whom were drug addicts.
During the July 1 - Aug. 11 period, a total of 2,655 needles were given away to drug addicts, CDC statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT DESCRIBES RELATIONS WITH PRESIDENT AS 'CALM'

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said in southern Taiwan Sunday that relations between himself and President Chen Shui-bian are "calm and easy, " seen as an attempt to dispel allegations that Lee and the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will bash Chen for the string of corruption allegations against members of his family and close aides.

During talks with the media after attending a ceremony held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung to mark the fifth anniversary of the TSU's founding, Lee said that as a retired president, he had better not attempt to exert any influence on the incumbent president.
Lee said Chen and he should show respect and cordiality to each other and that the last thing he should do is to criticize Chen.
However, he said it is not the right time for him to meet with Chen when the country is wracked by the string of corruption allegations dogging Chen.

The former president also drew a clear line between him and a rumor that he is supportive of Vice President Annette Lu's succeeding Chen with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng as premier should Chen resign, saying that the rumor is a complete fabrication.

Lee also lambasted Premier Su Tseng-chang's advocacy of a more liberalized China policy, which runs counter to the "active management, effective opening" principle that Chen spelled out at the beginning of this year.
Lee said Su's proposal is nothing but an "economic unification" plot, which he said not only reneges on the Taiwan people's will but will also lead Taiwan to across-the-board unification with China.
Responding to Lee's criticism of Su, Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the Cabinet respects Lee's freedom of speech.
Meanwhile, Lee said he is scheduled to visit Japan in September but added that the exact time and itinerary of the trip will not be announced until the day prior to his departure.
He was originally scheduled to visit Japan in May this year but the trip was canceled because he fell ill and checked into a hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO FIND OUT BUSINESSES' 'REAL NEEDS': ECONOMICS MINISTERBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: New Economics Minister Chen Ruei-long acknowledged that cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economy is a "sensitive and difficult" issue that cannot be solved by his ministry alone, but he said his staff will find out businesses' "real needs" before coming up with possible solutions.
During an exclusive interview with the CNA, Chen claimed that lifting an investment ceiling on Taiwan companies investing in China would be "oversimplifying" the issue.

At present, the government bans Taiwan companies from investing more than 40 percent of their total assets in their operations in China, a restriction that businesses have long complained limits their leverage to win greater access to the market.

"What are their real problems? Are there any alternatives to investing in China? What would be the impact on Taiwan if other alternatives were to be adopted? " he asked, adding that he was still thinking about the precise measures to be adopted.

Another concern of the business community is that quite a number of Taiwan's world-leading products have now fallen to No. 2, No. 3 or even lower in ranking, with critics wondering if Taiwan's competitiveness has been falling too.
To this, Chen said that if "made by Taiwan" products are also counted, as well as "made in Taiwan, " Taiwan could still be ahead in the individual industries.

For example, Chen noted, although many of Taiwan's notebook computer manufacturing lines have moved to China or elsewhere, Taiwan still controls them and therefore remains influential in this industry.

He said that "we need not make everything ourselves. If we could keep R&D and design, marketing and capital on the island, we would not have to worry too much about moving manufacturing lines to other countries."

Chen suggested that Taiwan corporations devote more human resources to enhancing competitiveness for items with high added value, since securing competitive edges for low value-added products will not be cost-effective.

He said he is optimistic about the future of Taiwan's high-tech and service industries, particularly in combining the manufacturing capabilities with services or high technologies -- an area that he said Taiwan should invest in.

On the overall economy, Chen, who became minister barely a week ago, also showed his upbeat attitude toward the second half of the year, in which he said he expects performance to be "at least as good as the first half."

He cited the export orders and export volumes of recent months, such as June's record export orders totalling US$24.9 billion and July's exports totalling US$19.6 billion, both of which represent monthly highs.
Since export orders are a leading indicator for the coming months, Taiwan's exports and industrial production will be quite impressive for the second half of this year, he predicted.

The only variables would be rising international oil prices and interest rates in major economies such as the United States, Japan and Europe, as oil prices and interest rates will affect Taiwan's economy, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNITY IN NANTOU COUNTY WORRIED ABOUT WORSENING SOCIAL ORDER
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, central Taiwan, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Residents of Chung Hsing New Village -- the seat of the former Taiwan provincial government -- urged Taiwan's top police officer Sunday to take effective measures against thefts and burglaries in their community.
More than 200 local residents joined a discussion session on how to improve their social order, chaired by National Police Agency Director-General Hou Yu-ih.
Among the residents were Nantou County Magistrate Li Chao-chin, legislators Tang Huo-sheng and Lin Yun-sheng, and several members of the Nantou county council.
Many residents who spoke at the seminar complained about deteriorating social order in the community, especially increasing thefts and burglaries.

They called for more police action to restore peace and safety in their community, including setting up more close-circuit cameras to monitor crime in the neighborhood, mounting more frequent police patrols and cutting off the channels used by thieves to sell their loot.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELDERLY WILL DEPEND MORE ON SOCIAL WELFARE THAN FILIAL PIETY

TEXT.P: The elderly in Taiwan are expected to rely more on social welfare than on filial piety by 2030, by which time the country's family and demographic structures will have experienced major changes, government sources said Sunday.

With increasing number of Taiwan people getting married later in life while the country's birth rate continues to decline, financial support for Taiwan elderly will diminish year by year, causing social welfare and public services to become important sources of support, according to officials from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

According to DGBAS officials, the average age of first-time mothers in Taiwan stood at 27.7 in 2005, 1.6 years older than that posted in 1995, while the birth rate declined to 1.1 children in 2005 from 1.8 children posted in 1995.
In addition to the impact of a shrinking workforce on the economy, the greying of the population is having a major impact on Taiwan society, they added.

The number of people aged over 65 stood at 2.22 million in 2005, a number which is expected to have tripled by 2050, making Taiwan a truly grey society, DGBAS officials said in a recently released demographic report.
Although there were still 61.7 percent of the elderly aged over 65 who lived with their adult children in 2002, the figure was a decline of 8.5 percentage points from 1986, the officials said.

They predicted that most of the elderly in Taiwan will still depend on their children for financial and family support prior to 2030, but said the situation will change dramatically after that point as a result of changes in social aspects and demographic structure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE HESITANT ABOUT GETTING MARRIED: POLL

TEXT.P: Amid the alarming drop in Taiwan's birth rate, government authorities attributed the phenomenon Sunday to Taiwan people's reluctance to get married.

According to the results of a telephone poll carried out by the Bureau of Health Promotion (BHP) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, the ratio of people willing to get married dropped to 58.2 percent at present from 61.5 percent two years ago, while the percentage of those who are not interested in forming a family rose to 24.5 percent from 16 percent during the same period.
On average, nearly 30 percent of Taiwan's single men and women aged between 20 and 39 are not interested in having a family, according to the survey.

As high as 35.9 percent of Taiwan's single men in the 20-39 age group said that they would not consider getting married due to economic constraints, while 21.9 percent of their female peers said that they prefer to enjoy greater freedom by staying unmarried.

The prime reasons cited by Taiwan's single men and women that prevented them from getting married were poor economic conditions, preference for singleness, not having a suitable partner for marriage and fearing trouble, the poll found.

As more and more Taiwan people prefer to remain single and more and more couples have fewer children, the number of this year's newborns might not exceed 200,000 -- further dropping from last year's 206,000, the DOH estimated.

If the situation persists, Taiwan will see a zero-growth rate in population in 2017, a few years sooner than the earlier projected 2021, BOH officials said, warning that a continued low birth rate will eventually lead to a shortage in the workforce and put the spotlight on health care for the elderly.

According to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), Taiwan's women of child-bearing age had an average of only 1.1 children last year -- lower than the world average of 2.7 children and the average 1.6 children in developed countries.
Taiwan's level of 1.1 children per woman is only higher than Hong Kong's 1.0, but lower than China's 1.6, Japan's 1.3 and South Korea's 1.2, the DGBAS statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRAUDSTER SELLING REPLICA FIREARMS AS REAL ONES NABBED IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Police in Kaohsiung City announced Sunday the arrest of a fraudster who sold replica firearms as real guns through the Internet and cheated nearly NT$500,000 out of at least 20 buyers.
A police spokesman said they arrested Koh Chao-chin, 44, in an operation Saturday and seized a number of replica handguns and submachine guns, along with toy rifle grenades.
The spokesman said Koh posted a notice on the Internet saying that he owned a variety of firearms, including rocket launchers, and would offer low prices to interested buyers.
Criminals attracted by the seeming bargains remitted money to Koh's bank account at NT$20,000 for a handgun and NT$100,000 for a rocket launcher, but Koh never delivered the goods.

When buyers began to phone Koh to demand delivery, he sent them photos through the Internet showing himself in handcuffs, along with a message that he was now in police custody for selling firearms and that police were trying to find out who the buyers were.
Fearing they might become targets of police investigation, most of Koh's victims wrote off the money they had lost, according to police.

DOC.HEADLINE: NINE SELF-RELIANCE MODELS HONORED BY FUND FOR CHILDREN, FAMILIES

TEXT.P: "Thanks for your help. Without it, I would not be what I am today, " Lee Chun-cheng, associate professor of accounting at Soochow University, said at a ceremony Sunday to mark the 56th anniversary of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families.
Lee said his father died when he was a university freshman, plunging the family into poverty.
As the eldest son, Lee said he undertook the responsibility of tending the family's rice field, although he could only plow, plant and harvest during weekends and vacations.
In order to continue his studies at university, Lee said he applied for and got grants from the children and families fund.
Lee said he felt shy when he went to the fund's branch office near his home to get his first grant, which was paid monthly, but was
comforted by the fund's staff, who encouraged him not to give up his aspirations to further his studies.
"I took heart from the aid granted to me by the children and families fund and vowed to become a sponsor of it if I became capable of doing so," he said.
"I owed the fund whatever little achievement I have had today. It's help encouraged me to take the bit between my teeth and face up to the hardship in my life," he went on.
Lee was one of nine people honored at Sunday's ceremony, all of whom had been helped by the fund and are now its sponsors.

The others included the owner of a bakery, the hostess of a radio show, the owner of a company, a councilor of Pingtung County, a manager, an engineer, a water technician and a chief of a cleaning squad at a local government.

The fund, founded in 1938 under the name of China's Children Fund by a group of American Christians, has expanded its original cause of helping Chinese children bereaved of parents by war to helping abused children or children whose families cannot afford to pay for their tuition. It now operates 23 offices around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL UNIVERSITY YOUTH LEADERSHIP SUMMIT TO OPEN

TEXT.P: The first Global University and College Youth leadership Summit will open Monday at Yuan Ze University in Chungli, Taoyuan County, according to a university press statement released Sunday.
The summit is being sponsored by the university and the World Leadership Education Foundation.

More than 150 university and college student leaders, including 60 foreign students from 26 countries, will discuss war, racial conflict, energy, the prevention of contagious diseases, environmental protection and various other topics during the four-day summit, which will be conducted in English.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-AVIAN FLU DRUGS ENOUGH FOR 10% OF POPULATION IN STORAGE: DOH

TEXT.P: Anti-avian flu drugs enough for 2.37 million people, or 10 percent of Taiwan's population, have been prepared for possible epidemics, according to a statement released Sunday by the Department of Health (DOH).

Liao Chi-jou, director-general of the Pharmaceutical Affairs Bureau under the DOH, said the drug reserves includes 627,000 doses of Tamiflu in capsule form, 1,694 kg of Tamiflu powder and 49,000 diskhalers of Relenza.

As of the end of July, the DOH had completed the prescription training of 1,573 local pharmacists on anti-bird flu drugs, who will be able to prepare dosages for at least 63,000 people per day, Liao said, adding that in case of extreme situations, the pharmacists will be able to prepare dosages sufficient for a maximum of 500,000 patients per day.

Liao noted that 70 percent of the reserved drugs are pharmaceutical raw materials of Tamiflu, which can be kept for up to 11 years, adding that the expiration period of Tamiflu in capsules is only five to six years.

According to DOH estimates, besides the current reserves, the National Health Research Institute, which has received a compulsory license for Tamiflu from Roche, can also produce Tamiflu from stored shikimic acid to increase the dosage amount to provide for 17 percent of Taiwan's population in case of an outbreak.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG FREE TRADE PORT FULLY OPEN TO BUSINESS

TEXT.P: Taichung Free Trade Port in central Taiwan is now fully open to business after the port's Zone Two won a Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) approval to join Zones One and Three which have been in operation since late Oct. last year.

With seven companies running, Taichung Free Trade Port handled 250,000 tons of cargo from January to July, 2006, achieving trade worth NT$2.68 billion (US$82 million) -- the best performance among Taiwan's four sea and one air ports that are allowed to conduct free trade.

The opening of Zone Two makes Taichung Free Trade Port a 536-hectare business area near scores of wharfs. Harbor Bureau officials said quite a number of businesses have shown an interest in setting up shops in the free trade port.
Besides the three designated zones, the free trade port has an additional 158 hectares of land that is available for business, they said.
The bureau will attend business shows and seminars to attract investors to the free trade port, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP HEAD DISMISSES DOUBTS ABOUT DEPOSE-PRESIDENT FUNDS

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh was quoted as saying Sunday that he has never used a cent of public money.

Ho De-fen, spokeswoman for Shih's "one million people campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian, " quoted Shih was answering DPP Legislator Chiang Chao-yi's question as to why he was launching a "one person, NT$100" drive to fund a planned sit-in calling for Chen's ouster.
Chiang asked if Shih has owed any money to the banks, demanding that Shih open up his bank books and publicize his finances.

Shih said, through Ho, that former President Lee Teng-hui had tried to give him NT$150 million for his discretionary use when he was DPP chairman but he refused to take it, and he has not claimed NT$10 million that the government agreed to pay him as compensation for his long jail term imposed by unjust court sentences.
Shih was a famous political prisoner who spent over a quarter of a century behind bars from 1970s to 1980s for opposing former Kuomintang's authoritarian rule.
Shih said since he has never borrowed money from banks, whose money comes from the people, he can boast that he has never spent one cent of public money.

In response to Huang Wei-che, another DPP lawmaker who urged Shih to "hate President Chen less but hate the Chinese Communists more, " Ho said Shih does not hate Chen. "It's totally inappropriate to use that word on Shih," she claimed.
She reiterated that every cent of public donations that go into Shih's three published bank or postal accounts will be used to sponsor the sit-in in protest against the corruption-ridden president.
If there is to be any surplus at the end of the campaign, it will be used to help pay for lunches for poor school children, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATIONARY HORSES FOR WOMEN UNVEILED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Horse-riding machines aimed at helping women improve their shape were unveiled Sunday by a firm specialized in the manufacturing of massage chairs.

Just like stationary bicycles, the horse-ring machines or stationary horses are touted as an efficient, safe means of exercise, but unlike stationary bicycles, riding on the machines is very interesting, according to its manufacturer.

By mimicking the trot of a horse, the manufacturer said, the machines provide local people a rare chance of enjoying horse-riding and help them firm their muscles around their belly, and inside their thighs where fat accumulate easily.

By riding on the machines 20 to 30 minutes a time and two or three times per week, its manufacturer said, women can easily get rid of the fat around the thighs and belly and improve their figure significantly.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: After U.N. Accord, Israel Expands Push in Lebanon
Israel poured troops into southern Lebanon on Saturday, making its deepest push yet toward the Litani River and suffering its highest daily losses, including having a helicopter shot down by Hezbollah guerrillas for the first time in the fighting. The fighting, including dozens of Israeli airstrikes, intensified a day after the United Nations Security Council approved a resolution for a truce. In a statement released Saturday night, Secretary General Kofi Annan said that he had been in touch with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel and Prime Minister Fouad Siniora of Lebanon and that both had agreed that the end of fighting would take effect at 8 a.m. Monday in Lebanon and Israel (1 a.m. U.S. Eastern time).

The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Ceasefire won'tstop evacuation of OFWs PRESIDENT Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo yesterday welcomed the UN resolution calling for a ceasefire in Lebanon, but Philippine officials feared the situation remained volatile and urged Filipinos to take advantage of the truce to leave the war-battered country.
