DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 14, or the 21st day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: The British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy -- march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The Republic of China Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
1949: Konrad Adenauer becomes the first chancellor of West Germany.
1951: Randolph W. Hearst, the newspaper publisher known as the king of America's "yellow press," dies at the age of 88. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire comprising 28 major newspapers.
1951: Seamen aboard the Ta Han, a 2,000-ton mainland Chinese freighter, defect to Taiwan, sailing their ship to the port of Kaohsiung.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down three Communist Chinese MiG-17s over Matsu.
1958: The United States decides to maintain an embargo on trade with Communist China, North Korea and North Vietnam, despite NATO's announcement of a relaxation of trade restrictions with the Soviet bloc and Communist China.
1971: Ground for the construction of Taiwan's north-south freeway is broken near Linkou.
1973: Over 300 Chinese and foreign computer scientists meet at the Academia Sinica for the First International Symposium on Computers.
1974: The Taipei Century Symphony Orchestra leaves for the United States on a three-week goodwill tour.
1977: The ROC Air Force celebrates the 40th anniversary of its victory over the Japanese at Hangchow, with Gen. Szetu Fu presiding.
1979: Wang Yun-wu, senior advisor to the president of the Republic of China, dies of heart failure at Veterans General Hospital at the age of 92.
1980: More than 360 scholars from home and abroad take part in the International Conference on Sinology at the Academia Sinica.
1985: The ROC Executive Yuan issues a report on the investigation of official administrative responsibilities regarding the 10th Credit Cooperative scandal. Fifteen financial officials are reprimanded, given demerits or dismissed.
1988: Major racial conflict breaks out in the African country of Burundi, with more than 24,000 people being killed in the conflict.
1999: The United States defeats Chinese-Taipei 10-9 to win the 18th International Baseball Association Big League Championship in Kaohsiung.
2000: Premier Tang Fei instructs the Ministry of Justice to review and revise relevant laws and regulations so as to enable the government to effectively crack down on the types of crimes that are increasingly harming Taiwan society.
2001: Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, a 1987 Nobel Peace Prize winner, says in Kinmen that Taiwan and mainland China should engage in dialogue to ease the tension across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who intuitively apprehends truth is one who, without effort, hits what is right, and without thinking understands what he wants to know; whose life is easily and naturally in harmony with the moral law. Such a one is what we call a saint or a man of divine nature."

DOC.HEADLINE: WITNESS IN 'STATE AFFAIRS FUND' CASE RETURNS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Taiwan businesswoman based in Australia who has claimed to hold documents proving that some of her receipts have been used by the first lady returned to Taiwan early Monday morning to undergo questioning by Taiwan High Court prosecutors as a witness.

Ligi Lee, also known as Lee Huei-fen, said upon her arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at around 1 a.m. that she has brought with her four full paper bags of documents, mostly photocopies of receipts and invoices, so that she can show the investigators how some of her receipts have been misused.

President Chen Shui-bian's wife, Wu Shu-jen, has been accused of pocketing cash from the Presidential Office's special "state affairs fund" through reimbursements for fake expenditures, using receipts provided by Lee Bi-chun, who is a cousin of Ligi Lee.
According to the investigators, there are mountains of receipts that President Chen has used to claim "state affairs" expenses, and Ligi Lee's receipts only constitute a small portion of the total.

Lee Pi-chun told investigators last week that she had given Hyatt Hotel invoices to "other people" but that she had no idea why those invoices ended up in the accounting reports of the Presidential Office. She also admitted that some of the invoices she gave out belonged to her cousin Ligi Lee.

Lee Pi-chun denied that she has ever given the controversial invoices directly to the first lady, who might have used them to help her husband claim the "state affairs" expenses. Chen has denied that he has ever pocketed a single cent from the fund budgeted for his discretionary use.

Opposition politicians have charged that the president used "fake invoices" to claim his "state affairs" expenses after the Ministry of Audit under the Control Yuan found irregularities in the Presidential Office accounts.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ASSESSING POSSIBILITY OF OIL EXPLORATION IN PARAGUAY, GUATEMALA

TEXT.P: The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will step up overseas oil exploration amid soaring world oil prices, and it is assessing the possibility of oil exploration in Paraguay and Guatemala, CPC officials said Monday.

The CPC has sent officials to the two countries in Central and South America to learn more about the oil reserve information there, they said. Guatemala is rich in crude oil, while Paraguay is rich in natural gas, as far as they know, the officials said.
The CPC is also interested in Sao Tome and Principe after reports said there are probably oil reserves in waters near the African country, they said.

However, the oil reserves are reportedly in a deep-water zone, and exploration could be costly, they said. With a limited budget for overseas oil exploration, the CPC will collect more information for further study, they added.

The officials made the remarks as new Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said in a recent interview with CNA that he will agree to the CPC's duly increase of its budget for oil exploration, although the budget will still have to be passed by the Legislative Yuan.

CPC officials noted that the budget for oil exploration in 2006 has been set at NT$3.2 billion (US$97.56 million) . The company has submitted a budget of around NT$3 billion for next year, with overseas exploration accounting for a large part of it.

They also said that the CPC's oil exploration in Ecuador and Venezuela has borne fruit. Crude oil production has begun in Ecuador, while production in Venezuela will begin at the end of this year or early next year.

They stressed that if oil exploration in overseas is successful, it will not only bring a steady supply of oil but will also create a surplus for the company and mitigate the impact of soaring oil prices, which they said are positive for the nation, the company as well as consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER DEPARTS FOR THREE-LEG CENTRAL AMERICA VISIT

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang departed Sunday for a five-day, three-leg visit to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.

During his stay in Panama, Costa Rica and Honduras, Huang is expected to call on the presidents, foreign ministers as well as ranking officials of the three countries to exchange views on bilateral relations as well as various cooperation projects to cement and promote friendly ties, the MOFA said in a press release.
Huang will also convene a regional working meeting with ROC ambassadors and representatives stationed in Central and South America during his stay in Panama, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said.

Huang's visit comes on the heels of Taiwan's severing of diplomatic ties with Chad in early August. Upon learning that Chad was ready to resume diplomatic relations with China, Taiwan announced its decision to sever diplomatic ties with Chad hours before its premier's scheduled departure for the Chadian capital of N'Djamena Aug. 6 to attend Chadian President Deby's inauguration for a new term.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO OPEN TAIWAN'S DOORS TO CHINESE GRAD STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education was urged Monday to open Taiwan's doors to Chinese students for postgraduate studies to help solve problems that have plagued the country's higher education system.

At a news conference, a group of scholars associated with the Taiwan Provincial Education Association and the Education Reconstruction Alliance urged the education ministry to allow Chinese college and university graduates to come to Taiwan to attend graduate school.

By allowing in Chinese students, they said, Taiwan can solve problems that have plagued the country's higher education system, including the fact that many universities have difficulty recruiting new students due to the large number of universities in the country.

According to Wang Ling-hui, executive director of the Taiwan Provincial Education Association, the number of university graduates in Taiwan doubled within seven years as a result of the government's relaxing of restrictions on the establishment of new universities and on the upgrading of colleges and vocational institutes to university status.
Wang said that nowadays, higher academic degrees in Taiwan do not guarantee "higher quality or higher proficiency of the graduates."

Instead, Wang said, an increased number of university graduates means higher unemployment. Citing government tallies, she said the jobless rate among new university graduates surged from 2.67 percent in 2000 to 4.23 percent in 2005.

Meanwhile, Huang Kuang-kuo, a professor at National Taiwan University and a leader of the Education Reconstruction Alliance, said the government's "mass production of university graduates" in recent years has led to low-quality graduates.

Huang noted that another problem facing Taiwan's higher education system is that most of the institutes have been unable to raise funds. Instead, he said, these universities, both public and private, have relied on government subsidies, with those receiving fewer subsidies running operating deficits.
Recruiting students from China will also help these universities financially, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 40.8 points to close at 6,611.9.
The bourse opened at 6,588.47 and fluctuated between 6,634.73 and 6,587.36 during trading. A total of 2.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.64 billion (US$2.09 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by construction issues at 1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, textile stocks at 0.7 percent, and foodstuff issues, paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares all at 0.3 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving down at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 586 to 381, with 173 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Aug.14 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Boeing, VSMPO Sign $18B ln Deal
With President Vladimir Putin's blessing, Boeing struck an $18 billion deal Friday with VSMPO-Avisma to supply titanium for its airplanes. The agreement came exactly a week after the United States announced it had imposed sanctions on state arms trader Rosoboronexport, which is acquiring VSMPO-Avisma, and could help Boeing land a large planes order with Aeroflot. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Reppublica: Prodi: Constitution to be respected.
Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi said Sunday that his government will respect the Constitution on sending troops to Lebanon to participate in an international peacekeeping force under the United Nations mandate. The Cabinet will decide Aug. 18 the number of soldiers assigned for the peace mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY WITNESS PRESENTS 'UNEXPOSED' EVIDENCE TO PROSECUTION

TEXT.P: An Australia-based Taiwanese businesswoman presented investigators with what she described as "unexposed evidence" as she was questioned Monday in connection with allegations that the Presidential Office used fake invoices and receipts to claim special "state affairs" expenses.

Lee Hui-fen, who arrived in Taiwan from Australia earlier in the day, said she was ready to "tell everything, " be cross-examined and undergo a polygraph in regard to the state affairs fund scandal, the latest in a series of corruption scandals dogging President Chen Shui-bian.

Before she left for the investigator's office, she met with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiu Yi, who quoted her as saying she had brought to Taiwan a number of invoices and receipts from hotels, restaurants and other stores that she had gathered during previous trips to Taiwan.

She also told Chiu that in addition to her cousin Lee Pi-chun, who is a suspect in the case, other people -- such as women who allegedly chipped in funds to buy Sogo department store vouchers together with first lady Wu Shu-jen -- have contributed invoices and receipts to the Presidential Office.
Lee Pi-chun, who owns a pharmaceutical company, is banned from leaving the country after being questioned by investigators last week.
She told investigators that she had given Hyatt Hotel invoices to "other people" but claimed that she had no idea why those invoices ended up in the accounting reports of the Presidential Office.
The prosecution was expected to interrogate Lee Pi-chun again after questioning Lee Hui-fen to compare their testimonies.
The investigators are also expected to summon again Presidential Office officials, accountants and clerks who have already been questioned in connection with the scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CRACK DOWN ON LOAN SHARKS

TEXT.P: Police islandwide recently cracked down on a total of 123 cases of usury, arresting 154 people for allegedly lending money at usurious interest rates and using violence to collect debts, a spokesman for the National Police Administration (NPA) reported Monday.

The clampdown, the fifth of its kind, was carried out from Aug. 8 to Aug. 11 by police stations across Taiwan, the spokesman said, adding that Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang has demanded that the NPA bust underground loan sharks and gangsters who use violent means to collect debts in view of a growing number of people who have been driven to suicide by the criminals.

The spokesman urged the public never to borrow money from loan sharks and provided the telephone numbers 110 or (02) 2356- 5009 for debtors to use when faced by gangsters who use violent means to recover their money.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEWS FROM EX-PRESIDENT ON JAPAN VISIT: INTERCHANGE ASSOCIATION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By M.C. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Japan's Interchange Association said Monday that it has yet to receive any information from Taiwan's former President Lee Teng-hui about his planned visit to Japan in September.

The association's comments came after Lee told a news conference Sunday in southern Kaohsiung city that he plans to visit Japan next month -- a move that may coincide with the election of a new Japanese prime minister to succeed outgoing Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi.

Lee originally planned to visit Japan in May this year, where he hoped to tour the famed Okunohosomici region northeast of Tokyo, which includes Sendai and Nikko, but was forced to postpone the trip after contracting a serious cold in March.
It would be Lee's third trip to Japan since he stepped down from the presidency in 2000.
He first visited Japan in 2001 to receive surgery for a heart condition and paid a second visit in late December 2004, visiting Nagoya, Kyoto and Kanazawa.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCOMPETENT MINISTERS SHOULD GO AT ONCE: POLL

TEXT.P: Over half of the respondents to a recent poll say any ministers that are unfit for their jobs should step down immediately, according to the survey results released Monday.

The poll, conducted by local Global View magazine, shows that 52.4 percent said the economic and finance ministers should step down immediately if they are not fit for their posts, compared with 18 percent who said a dramatic change of Cabinet ministers would be unfavorable to the continuity of government policies.

The poll was unveiled on the heels of a series of major changes in the nation's financial and economic heads. Chen Ruey-long took over from Hwang Ing-san as minister of economic affairs, He Chih-chin replaced Joseph Lyu as finance minister and Shih Jun-ji took over from Kong Jaw-sheng as chairman of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission.

The magazine said amid a sluggish economy, more than half the respondents said newcomers should bring freshness to the administrative team, with even 47.3 percent of respondents professing to be supporters of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) holding that view.
In addition, the magazine said that more than half of those polled think Premier Su should dictate his own policy instead of acting as the executive director of President Chen Shui-bian.

Although Chen announced May 30 that he would delegate some of his power so as to let the premier have a full rein over the Cabinet personnel, 55.6 percent said they feel that the premier still cannot act independently, with the controversy over cross-Taiwan Strait issues during a national economic development conference in late July an example of this.

The premier is believed to have advocated a more open attitude toward cross-strait issues, but the president reiterated the "active management and effective opening" cross-strait trade policy prior to the July 27-28 conference.
On Taiwan's announcement of severing diplomatic ties with Chad Aug. 5, the poll also found that 59 precent said there is no need to disrupt cross-strait exchanges.

Fifty-seven percent also said the government should agree to a visit by Chen Yulin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, at the invitation of the main opposition Kuomintang for a forum in Taipei. The KMT later suspended the invitation due to the sour cross-strait situation resulting from the Chad issue.
The magazine polled 803 people aged over 20 around the island Aug. 10-11, with a margin of error of 3.5 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO OFFICIATE AT LEADERS' SUMMIT IN PALAU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that he might visit Palau in September to officiate at the first leaders' summit of the Republic of China and its South Pacific allies.
Chen invited visiting Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare to also attend the summit meeting.

Sogavare, who arrived in Taipei last Friday, met with Chen at the Presidential Office, where Chen asked Sogavare to speak for Taiwan in his capacity as one of the representatives from the Solomon Islands at the United Nations when it convenes its annual general assembly in September.

Chen told Sogavare that for the first time, Taiwan will try to gain U.N. membership this year under the title "the Republic of China (Taiwan) ." Taiwan has been using "the Republic of China" in its U.N. bid for the past 13 years. All attempts have failed due to the intervention and opposition of Beijing.

The ROC has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971, when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the China seat to Beijing at Taiwan's expense. While Resolution No. 2758 resolved the issue regarding China's U.N. representation, Chen said it did not address the representation of Taiwan's people.

According to Chen, Taiwan and the Solomon Islands have maintained formal diplomatic relations for the past 23 years and exchanges in urban development, anti-poverty projects, agricultural development and medical as well as public health between the two countries have been flourishing.
Chen said it was his honor to pay a state visit to the Solomon Islands in January 2005, making him the first ROC president to visit the South Pacific country.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CLAIMS KMT IN SURPLUS WHEN HE WAS KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Former President and Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lee Teng-hui said Monday that when he left office as KMT leader in 2000, the party's enterprises as a whole were making money, not running a deficit as some media have reported.

Lee's office issued a press release in response to United Daily News reports that the KMT suffered a deficit of NT$50 billion (US$1.53 billion) under Lee's watch and that the party, now in opposition and led by Ma Ying-jeou, is ready to review Lee's record at the helm of the then-rich KMT.

The release pointed out that it was Lee who took the initiative in overhauling the management of the party's businesses and assets, ensuring that the businesses were run by professionals and that the assets would not be misappropriated.
"In fact, Chairman Lee made quite a substantial contribution to protecting the KMT's assets," it added.

It noted that investment is accompanied by risks and suggested that how the KMT-owned enterprises were operated should be judged by their net asset values, not by underscoring some profits and losses related to certain investment projects.
It said that when Lee left office as KMT chairman, the party's assets were overall in surplus.

Investments by the party's enterprises were just "part of the use of the party assets, " it said, adding that the party leadership should tell the people what happened to the party's assets, including how they were used to fund the party's election campaigns in 2000 and 2004.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said some people have raised questions about the KMT's assets, which should not be confused with its finances.

Commenting on the newspaper reports that the KMT is ready to "cut its ties with Lee, " the so-called "spiritual leader" of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Wang said it would be difficult and unrealistic for Ma to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN RETURNS TO TAIWAN AFTER BEING STRANDED IN XIAMEN

TEXT.P: A 78-year-old veteran returned to his Taoyuan home Friday after being stranded penniless for several days in Xiamen City, in China's Fujian Province, officials on the outlying county of Kinmen said Monday.
Liu Chia-ho departed for Yunnan Province in southern China Aug. 10 last year to visit his relatives there, and planned to return to Taiwan via Kinmen, which has ferry service linking with Xiamen.

However, when he arrived in Xiamen in early August, Liu was denied entry into Taiwan via Kinmen on the grounds that the ferry service is reserved only for Taiwan businessmen working in China and residents of Kinmen.
He asked the Xiamen authorities to relay his requests for entry permission to the Kinmen county government, which refused him entry.
Kinmen officials, however, informed the Veteran Affairs Commission in Taipei of Liu's case, and the commission bought Liu a ticket for him to return via Macau.

Noting that many senior veterans originating from China are not permitted to visit China via Kinmen, the Kinmen county government called for the relaxation of the current rules to accommodate them, pointing out that they are usually living on meager government pensions and are categorized as disadvantaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEEWS

TEXT.P: International Herald Tribune: Fierce attacks on eve of Mideast truce
Hours before a cease-fire was due to start, Israel bombed Beirut's suburbs as Hezbollah fired more than 220 rockets into northern Israel.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER URGES PRESIDENT TO RE-DRAW CONTROL YUAN NOMINEE LIST

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng urged President Chen Shui-bian Monday to draw up a new Control Yuan member nominee list on his own initiative and "not worry" about how and whether the legislature will handle it.
Wang said Chen should redraw the list of nominees since some of his original nominees have passed the legitimate age to be a member, while others have joined the Cabinet over the past two years.

The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, has been left incomplete since the terms of the previous Control Yuan members expired in January 2005, as the opposition-dominated legislature is unsatisfied with some of the president's nominees, especially the nominee for Control Yuan president, Clement C.P. Chang.
Chen proposed Saturday drawing up a new list of Control Yuan member nominees if the opposition promises not to insist on raising the threshold of confirmation to two-thirds of the Legislative Yuan.

Wang called for the president not to worry that his list will not have a chance of clearing the legislative floor if the lawmakers decide to raise the threshold from one-half to two-thirds of the legislature for approval of the new Control Yuan members.

Wang said the proposal demanding an amendment to the Organic Law of the Legislative Yuan to raise the threshold of confirmation of the members of Judicial, Examination and Control Yuans nominated by Chen is still pending at the Legislative Yuan Procedure Committee.

He reiterated that the president should redraw a Control Yuan member nominee list regardless of whether the two-thirds threshold is passed or not, adding that the Control Yuan must resume its operations as soon as possible as a show of respect for the five-branch government system and to live up to the expectations of the public.
"The Legislative Yuan will dutifully perform its task in handling the Control Yuan member nomination list once the president redraws and submits the list," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS HUALIEN MAN BEAT FATHER'S FRIEND TO DEATH

TEXT.P: A jobless man was detained by Hualien city police while strolling drunkenly in the street Monday after allegedly punching a friend of his father the previous night, an attack that allegedly caused the man's death early this morning.
According to Hualien police, 31-year-old Wu Chih-wei admitted to beating his father's friend and was turned over to the Hualien Prosecutor's Office on a homicide charge.

Wu was accused of forcing the victim to go to an open plot nearby and angrily punching him in the head until he fell to the ground unconscious. Wu left alone without aiding the man, who was already in a coma, police said.
According to an initial investigation by police, the two men began having a row after the friend of his father sneered at Wu over his joblessness.
The victim was found by Wu's neighbors, who reported the case to police.
Hospital authorities pronounced the victim dead early Monday morning and said that his brain was already seriously damaged when he arrived at the hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT: PARTY ASSETS REPORT DOES NOT TARGET FORMER CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The implication that an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) party assets report is aimed at shifting some responsibility to former President Lee Teng-hui, who was the KMT's chairman from 1988-2000, is taking the report out of context, the party's spokesman said Monday.
According to Huang Yu-chen, the leaked report simply details how party assets were managed at different times and does not target or criticize Lee.

He noted that the report, prepared by the party's Deputy Secretary-General Chang Che-chen and lawyer Lee Yung-jan, describes how the assets were managed when Chiang Kai-shek, Chiang Ching-kuo, Lee Teng-hui, Lien Chan and Ma Ying-jeou were at the helm of the party.

Ma, who was elected chairman in July last year, has asked his staff to tackle the controversy over the party's assets "as soon as possible " and so the party is ready to look at the issue one year after Ma became party leader, Huang said.
He said the party will bare all of its assets in an open, transparent and comprehensive manner and will not try to "shun or hide" any questions.
He acknowledged that investment profits and losses, included in the report, might have been leaked and made into news stories.
Ma said the report is simply the KMT's "response to people's expectations" and he expressed surprise it has been interpreted as an attempt to "cut off ties" with Lee.
He added that he will explain how the party is going to handle its assets following an Aug. 23 KMT Central Standing Committee meeting, when members will discuss the report.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its "pan-green camp" ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union have tried to legislate a law to tackle what they call the KMT's "ill-gotten" assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH CONFIRMS LEGIONNAIRES' DISEASE CONTRACTED VIA SPA

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) confirmed Monday the first case of legionnaires' disease contracted at a spa, but said the patient has fully recovered after a course of antibiotics for a few days..

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of DOH's Center for Disease Control, said the patient was a 39-year-old man who was infected by legionella, a bacterium found primarily in warm water environments, at the spa in February 2005. Both the disease and the bacterium were first isolated following an outbreak traced to a 1976 American Legion convention in Philadelphia.
Medical examiners found the bacterium in the man's phlegm after he developed the disease and they also found the bacterium to be identical to that found in a specimen taken from the spa.
The specimen had a low level of bacterium, but no signs of the bacterium were found at the man's home, showing that he was infected at the spa.
The operator of the spa has since disinfected his facility, Shih said.
The DOH also checked the health of the other patrons of the spa, but found no additional cases, he added.
Shih speculated that the man, a heavy smoker and drinker, has poor lung function and weakened resistente to the bacterium, making him vulnerable.
He said the annual incidence rate of legionnaire's disease is between 0.2 and 0.4 per 100,000 and that Taiwan reports between 10 and 100 cases annually.

The high risk groups are those who smoke, the elderly, diabetics and sufferers of kidney disease, with an average mortality rate of around 15 percent, although there have been no deaths for the past five or six years, he added.
The DOH has written a paper based on the case that was published by the U.S.-based medical journal Microbiology and Immunology.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Travel chaos as airlines ordered to slash flights.
Airport authorities ordered airlines to cut outgoing flights by 30 per cent yesterday or be banned from using Heathrow altogether at the peak of the holiday season, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL COMMITTEE FORMED TO OVERSEE TAIWAN-GUATEMALA FTA EXECUTION

TEXT.P: An executive committee was established in Taipei Monday to oversee the execution of a Taiwan-Guatemala free trade agreement (FTA) that took effect July 1.

Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and his Guatemalan counterpart, Marcio Cuevas, announced the inauguration of the new commission at a ceremony held at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
Chen said the committee will be charged with handling matters related to the FTA, including addressing bilateral trade disputes.
The committee passed at its Monday meeting unified "country of origin" certification forms and enforcement rules for resolving trade disputes under the FTA.
The agreement is the second such accord Taiwan has signed following a similar pact with Panama. It is also Guatemala's first FTA with an Asian country.

Describing the two countries' economies as complementary to each other, Chen said the free trade pact will spawn new business opportunities for both sides, with Guatemalan farm produce finding new markets in Taiwan while Taiwan's industrial goods will enter Guatemala on better terms.

Under the FTA, Chen said, Taiwan has agreed to offer an annual 60,000 ton quota for Guatemalan sugar, which, besides benefiting Guatemalan farmers, is expected to help stabilize domestic sugar prices.

As a Guatemalan FTA with the United States has entered into force, Chen said, the Central American country can become a major bastion for Taiwan manufacturers, particularly textile makers, seeking to tap into the vast U.S. market.
Under the FTA, 3,964 categories of Taiwan-produced items can now enjoy tariff-free status on entering the Guatemalan market, while Taiwan offers tariff-free privileges for Guatemalan products.
Besides using the tariff-free treatment to expand their Guatemalan market shares, Chen said, Taiwan companies can also set up footholds in Guatemala to explore regional markets.

Meanwhile, Chen went on, Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will negotiate with the Guatemalan authorities the possibility of cooperation in prospecting for oil in that country, which has rich reserves. The CPC sent oil prospectors to Guatemala last year on an oilfield survey mission, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GANGSTER INDICTED ON FIREARMS SELLING CHARGE

TEXT.P: A gangster was recommended for a 10-year prison term by prosecutors Monday for his alleged involvement in selling modified arms and collecting debts through violent means.

According to Wang Chieh-tuo, a prosecutor at the Taichung Prosecutor's Office who conducted the investigation, Chan Yi-shin, head of the "Green Grass Gang" in the Miaoli area, was arrested by police in April in Miaoli and a batch of firearms were discovered.

Police and prosecutors also found that Lee Ching-lung, a captain serving in Miaoli in the military police, maintained close contacts with Chan, who sometimes hid his weapons in Lee's official dormitory, Wang said.
Lee, who is good at modifying arms, frequently asked Chan to sell modified pistols for him at a cost of NT$30,000-NT$60,000 each, Wang said.
Lee had already been arrested by the military police for his suspected role in a kidnapping case. He is now been questioned by military prosecutors.
Prosecutors were also seeking a five-year term for Tsai Hung-min, another of Chan's accomplices, for violations of the firearms control act.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCES OF JOINING U.N. UNDER NAME OF 'TAIWAN' THIS YEAR MINIMAL: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday that the possibility of the nation applying to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" this year is small.

The vice president made the remarks when she attended a ceremony marking the first anniversary of the Democratic Pacific Union, an organization she helped found. President Chen Shui-bian and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng also attended the ceremony.

Asked about Chen's proposal Saturday that the nation should seriously consider joining the U.N. under the name of Taiwan, Lu said that "some friends" strongly recommended the proposal and that the Presidential Office convened meetings to study it.

"But as the General Assembly of the United Nations will soon open, the timing seems a bit late and the possibility is small this year, " she said, adding that "whether we should make such a proposal in the future remains to be seen."
Wang claimed that the name of the nation has been "the greatest contention" in the country, where the dispute over unification vs. independence is persistent.
Given the sensitivity of the issue, Wang suggested that "the nation act cautiously and take into consideration the views of other countries before making a move."
Lu also said that a Democratic Pacific Legislative Caucus will be established Dec. 8, which will rely heavily on Wang's assistance. This, she went on, is the gist of a so-called "Lu-Wang alliance."

The reported alliance surfaced last week when a local newspaper said that should Lu succeed Chen -- who has been dogged by corruption allegations implicating himself, members of his family and his top aides -- Wang would be appointed premier, which reportedly is favored by former President Lee Teng-hui, who still has some clout in Taiwan politics.
Lu said that the forming of the legislative caucus will need the cooperation of the Legislative Yuan and that Wang also thinks the matter is important.
"There is no need to speculate further," Lu said.
Wang said the second DPU conference will be held Dec. 8, at which point the legislative caucus will be established.

Lu said more than 50 legislators from at least 20 countries will take part in the conference, hoping to increase understanding of the operations and elections of the legislatures in various countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY HEAD WANTS BINAN INDUSTRIAL PARK PROJECT SCRAPPED

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih urged Premier Su Tseng-chang Monday to abolish the Binan Industrial Park development plan in order to preserve the county's Chiku wetland habitat for the critically endangered black-faced spoonbill.

Su vowed that during his four-year term as magistrate, he will never issue a permit to allow the project to begin, although an environmental impact assessment approved by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration in 1999 was finalized by the Democratic Progressive Party-led government in January this year.
Su recommended that the Cabinet withdraw its approval of the report on grounds the Binan industrial complex project would ruin 6,000 hectares of wetlands and seriously impact the local ecosystem.
He pointed out that the industrial park would become the site of highly polluting industries, such as Taiwan's Seventh Naphtha Cracker and the Yieh Loong steel plant.
Moreover, he added, the development plan goes against Taiwan's commitments to control the level of greenhouse gas emissions, as set by the Koyto Protocol.
"The project is totally contradictory to the concept of ecological conservation," he said, adding that procedures behind the government's review of the environmental impact are "highly suspicious."

International conservationists have reminded Taiwan's authorities of the critical role played by the Chiku wetlands -- it is the winter habitat of more than 70 percent of the world's population of black-faced spoonbills.
The rare birds -- estimated at about 800 -- migrate between areas in North and South Korea, Japan, Taiwan, China, Vietnam and the Philippines.

In addition to the threat to wildlife in the Chiku wetlands' ecosystem, there are serious concerns the park's construction may speed up coastal erosion, destroy sandbars, adversely affect water resources and harm the local fishing industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Cease-Fire Begins After a Day of Fierce Attacks
A cease-fire negotiated by the United Nationss went into effect at 8 a.m. local time (1 a.m. U.S. Eastern time) on Monday, the 34th day of this latest Middle East conflict, with Israeli troops ordered to halt their offensive against Hezbollah and Lebanon agreeing to halt Hezbollah attacks on Israel. Hours before the cease-fire started, both sides carried out fierce attacks, with Israel launching air strikes in eastern Lebanon and near Sidon and shelling areas around Tyre and Khiam. No timetable was clear for when an expanded United Nations force, known as Unifil, would be ready to deploy, nor was there a deal on which country would lead it.
Wall Street Journal: Flight Risk, Laptop Dangers Draw Scrutiny From Airline-Safety Regulators
Long before last week's foiled plot to blow up airlines using material secreted in carry-on luggage, a growing number of transportation and product-safety officials had expressed concerns that batteries in laptops and other electronics pose a serious risk to airplanes -- for reasons completely unrelated to global terror. Although the risk is small, the Consumer Product Safety Commission has documented 339 cases of lithium and lithium-ion batteries for portable electronics overheating, emitting smoke and fumes or exploding since 2003. There is no record of a serious injury or death, but the Federal Aviation Administration has logged 60 incidents since 1991. In the past two years, six incidents have occurred on aircraft, including five fires and an overheated flashlight that had to be handled with oven mitts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KAOHSIUNG CITY OFFICIALS FOUND NOT GUILTY IN THAI WORKERS CASE

TEXT.P: Two former Kaohsiung City officials in charge of labor affairs were found not guilty Monday of charges related to importing Thai workers to work on the city's rapid transit project.
A surprised prosecution said they would consider appealing the ruling after receiving the Kaohsiung District Court's verdict.
Both Fang Lai-chin, former director of the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs, and Kuo Keng-hua, a section chief under Fang, were found not guilty based on the prosecution's lack of evidence.

The court ruled it was the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) that had authorized bringing more than 1,800 Thai workers to Taiwan through a special program -- not the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs.

The judges said there was no evidence to prove Fang and Kuo had attempted to profit Kaohisung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) and Huapan Administration Consultant Co., which was authorized to import and manage the Thai workers.
Kuo was also found not guilty on charges of dereliction of duty -- for having failed to act on an "early warning" petition from Thai workers complaining of harsh treatment by Huapan staff.

The court said Kuo must have had the petition translated into Chinese to learn of the real circumstances of the situation, and that his handling of it did not have a cause-and-effect relationship with the workers' riot in August, 2005. That riot brought to light a host of suspected irregularities concerning labor management and the awarding of construction projects for the transit system.
Prosecutors have indicted a number of KRTC managers, Huapan managers, business contractors and a senior aide to President Chen Shui-bian for suspected involvement in the KRTC scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 57 points to close at 6,595, with 33,840 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September increased 73 points to finish at 6,598, with 7,424 contracts traded, while December futures increased 31 points to end at 6,560, with 16 contract transactions.
March futures moved up 50 points to close at 6,585, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,538 for August, 6,525 for September, 6,529 for December, 6,535 for March and 6,516 for June.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher. August TE futures moved up 3.6 points to close at 285.4, with 4,199 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 2.45 points to finish at 284, with 1,748 contract transactions.

December TE futures increased 3.2 points to end at 284, with one contract traded, while March TE futures moved up 2.05 points to end at 283, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.

August TF futures gained 5.2 points to close at 924, with 1,913 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved up seven points to finish at 925, with 1,067 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.101 to close at NT$32.745.
A total of US$732 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.745 and fluctuated between NT$32.665 and NT$32.752.

DOC.HEADLINE: TINY KUIPER BELT ROCKS DISCOVERED BY TAIWAN ASTRONOMERS

TEXT.P: Tiny Kuiper Belt objects, rocks of 100 meters or less in diameter, have been spotted for the first time by an astronomical research team at National Tsing-hua University (NTHU), according to a press release issued by the university Monday.
The team, organized by Professor Chang Hsiang-Kuang, proved the existence of the objects by analyzing the time "bins" -- the duration of occultations -- in X-rays emitted by the star Scorpius X- 1.
Their findings have been published by the renowned scientific journal Nature in its Aug. 10 issue.

Astronomers have long suggested that there should be billions of Kuiper Belt objects beyond the planet Neptune, which are sometimes referred to as "trans-neptunian objects." However, due to the limits in visible light observation, objects with diameters of less than 1, 000 meters had never been discovered.
The Kuiper Belt is an area surrounding the solar system extending from the orbit of Neptune, at 30 astronomical units (AU) , to 50 AU from the Sun.

Chang and his team utilized X-ray data collected by the Rossi X- ray Timing Explorer (RXTE) of the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration to see the minute rocks, because occultations as short as one millisecond are still perceivable in X-ray observation.

When combing through the RXTE database, the team found 58 suspicious time bins -- dips in light -- in the X-ray records of Scorpius X-1, a neutron star 9,000 light years from Earth. These possible occultations were later re-examined in a control comparison by the team.

Chang explained that in order to rule out the possibility that the dips are caused by instrumental errors, they ran a second search through the data of the Crab nebula, which is an extensive source of X-rays, unlike Scorpius X-1, a point source of X-rays.

The reason to use the Crab nebula is that if there is really a tiny rock existing in Kuiper belt, while the rock can entirely block Scorpius X-1's light, it would not be able to obscure the Crab nebula's, Chang noted, adding that if the time bins exist in both databases, then they are uncertainly instrumental errors; otherwise, the dips would lead to the finding of trans-neptunian objects.
The result showed that the dips were caused by tiny rocks in the Kuiper Belt and the estimated the number of rocks as being up to 10 to the power of 15.
The team now plans to measure the distance from Earth to these small objects.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TURNOVER OF 3 HIGH-TECH PARKS MAY HIT RECORD: NSC

TEXT.P: The combined business turnover of the country's three largest high-tech industry parks may hit a record high of NT$2 trillion (US$60.61 billion) this year, the National Science Council (NSC) said Monday.

According to NSC tallies, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park's business turnover amounted to NT$540 billion in the first half of the year, compared to the Central Taiwan Science Park's NT$70.56 billion and the Southern Taiwan Science Park's NT$211.97 billion.
The three parks' year-on-year growth rates were 21 percent, 198.4 percent and 50.7 percent, respectively, according to NSC statistics.

NSC Vice Chairman Tai Chien said the three parks' combined business turnover for 2006 is conservatively estimated at NT$1.77 trillion, but if the global economy remains robust or grows even faster, their total sales may set a record of NT$2 trillion by year's end.

Yen Chung-ming, deputy director of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration, said the park posted a 21 percent year-on-year growth in its first half-year business volume, with IC, optoelectronics and precision machinery industries registering the most significant gains of 21 percent, 54 percent and 40 percent, respectively.

In contrast, computer peripherals manufacturers in the Hsinchu park suffered a 2 percent decrease in business turnover in the first half of the year; the communications industry registered a 16 percent decline; while business in the biotechnology sector was flat for the same period. The Hsinchu park's overall business revenues for 2006 are estimated at NT$1.15 trillion, Yen added.

Chen Ming-huang, deputy director of the Central Taiwan Science Park Administration, said the park's overall business volume for the first six months doubled year-on-year, with the optoelectronics industry accounting for 93.13 percent of the total. The park's annual turnover is expected to hit NT$120 billion.

Chen Chun-wei, director of the Southern Taiwan Science Park, said companies there have become more pessimistic about business prospects in the coming three to six months because of a combination of factors, including skyrocketing crude oil prices, re-emergence of terrorist attack threats and the domestic political turmoil.

Nevertheless, Chen said, the park's overall business volume is expected to increase to NT$500 billion by year's end thanks to a rebound in the TFT-LCD industry boosted by a steady decline in flat panel prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST DAY OF DRIVE TO REMOVE CHEN FROM OFFICE DRAWS NT$10 MILLION

TEXT.P: Between 50,000 and 70,000 people donated nearly NT$10 million to a campaign calling for "one million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian" Monday, in a drive initiated over the weekend by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh.

Shih called on members of the public to each contribute NT$100, saying if within 30 days less than one million people have made donations, it would mean the country's "anti-corruption forces" are still not strong enough and that Chen will likely continue to be their national leader.

Accountant Lin Hsien-lang said NT$9.35 million was received in two designated bank accounts. If donations made to a designated postal account are added, the first-day amount would exceed NT$10 million.

But he said not all donors were contributing NT$100 as campaign organizers hoped -- some have remitted NT$10,000 or NT$5,000. He urged supporters to contribute just NT$100 to make it easier to calculate the number of donors.
Lawyer Huang Hsu-tien said all donations will be used to organize sit-ins scheduled to begin Sept. 9 in front of the Presidential Office.

"Each dollar from the donations can be used only after my chop and that of Yeh Ta-hui, another lawyer, have been stamped on a receipt. We will monitor the use of the funds very closely, " Huang added.
Shih said he was organizing the campaign because "legal means within the establishment" were no longer useful to solve current problems.

He claimed that what he and fellow organizers were adopting was "political means within the establishment" -- by rallying the voices of a million people to give Taiwan a fresh start, after driving Chen out of office.
He said the current DPP leadership is "corrupt at the roots" and people in Taiwan will teach them "what morality means."

In response, DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-lang said 99 percent of DPP politicians in government and party posts are "hard-working and clean, " as all of the DPP members are required to observe the "highest moral standards."

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-PROFILE PROTECTION OF KEY WITNESS JUSTIFIED: PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: The Public Prosecutors' Office at the Taiwan High Court defended itself Monday, saying that its high-profile protection of a key witness in a case involving President Chen Shui-bian's suspected embezzlement of state affairs funds is justified.

A spokesman for the High Court's Prosecutors' Office made the remarks in response to criticism by legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that the Investigation Bureau "made a fuss" by providing "chief of state-class protection" to a Taiwanese businesswoman based in Australia who returned to Taiwan around midnight Sunday to provide evidence in the case.

More than 100 law enforcement officers were escorting Lee when she arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. Agents from the Investigation Bureau are reportedly providing round-the-clock protection during Lee's stay in Taiwan.
The spokesman also said that before Lee departed from Australia, the High Prosecutors' Office had obtained her consent that she would be protected as a key witness.

"Providing protection for Lee is fundamental and necessary," he said, adding, "The measure will allow prosecutors to proceed with their investigation smoothly and let other witnesses feel safe during the investigation."
Lee claimed she has brought documents with her to prove that her cousin, Lee Bi-chun, took many of her hotel and shopping receipts and gave them to the first lady, Su Shu-jen.
Initial probes by the Ministry of Audit showed some of Lee's receipts were used by the president to claim state affairs allowances for fake expenditures.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Israel Accepts U.N. Deal; Both Sides Warn of More Fighting.
The Israeli military halted its combat operations against Hezbollah guerrillas in southern Lebanon and Hezbollah rockets stopped raining on Israel early Monday morning as a tenuous U.N.-imposed cease-fire took effect after more than a month of fighting that devastated parts of Lebanon and sent hundreds of thousands of Israelis into bomb shelters.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA PLANS TO INCREASE PENALTY FOR MISTREATMENT OF ANIMALS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Cabinet is considering amending the Animal Protection Act to increase the penalty for maltreatment of animals.
A COA spokesman said Monday that a recent case of animal cruelty indicates that it may be time to amend the law to provide better protection for animals.
Under Taiwan's Animal Protection Act, promulgated in 1998, those found guilty of animal cruelty can face a fine of between NT$10,00 and NT$50,000.
Animal welfare advocates have complained that the current law does not serve as a deterrent against cruel behavior toward animals.

An Internet user recently posted photos online showing how he enjoyed abusing his kitten in a sadistic manner. Other animal-loving Internet users managed to track him down, but law enforcement agencies found the most they could do was to fine him NT$50,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPENDING 4TH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT CONSTRUCTION COST NT$7.2 BILLION

TEXT.P: How much does a policy flip-flop cost? For stopping and then resuming construction on the fourth nuclear power plant in Taipei County, taxpayers paid NT$7.2 billion (US$2.2 million), according to a report released by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Monday.

Meanwhile, the total budget for building the controversial plant has been adjusted upward from NT$169.7 billion to NT$233.5 billion, the CEPD said, adding that if all goes well, the power plant will begin commercial operations in 2009.
The government halted the plant's construction in 2000 but resumed work the next year, a delay costing NT$7.2 billion in broken contractual obligations.
When the project was announced in 1992, the government approved a total budget of NT$169.7 billion for its completion; by 2004, that figure had increased to NT$188.8 billion.

At one time, the Ministry of Economic Affairs called for a total of NT$243.1 billion to wrap up the project. A CEPD work group cut NT$9.6 billion from that estimate, leaving the final budget of NT$233.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIONS CLUB JOINS PROGRAM TO SPONSOR PHILIPPINE CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Taichung-based Yuta Lions Club in central Taiwan joined a program sponsoring disadvantaged children in the Philippines Monday to show that its altruistic commitment has no national boundaries.

Liu Pei-feng, president of the Yuta Lions Club, informed the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) of the club's decision to sponsor 16 Philippine children from impoverished families after learning the fund was seeking donors for its global program.

The club will pay NT$700 per month for each child it chooses to sponsor in the Philippines, financing the provision of daily meals, nutrients, healthcare, improved drinking water, cleaner living environments and vocational training for the kids' parents.

The TFCF, one of Taiwan's largest child and family welfare organizations, is a founding member of ChildFund International, which currently has more than 100,000 disadvantaged children around the globe awaiting sponsorship.
In addition to matching sponsors with local disadvantaged children, the TFCF has also offered sponsorships for 31,858 children from impoverished families in 28 countries around the world.
TFCF Executive-Director Chen Pang-hung said the foundation appreciates the Lions Club's support, and hopes more citizens will follow suit to show the benevolence of the Taiwanese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER ARRIVES IN PANAMA FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang met with Panamanian President Martin Torrijos Monday for talks of matters of mutual concern.
Huang, heading an official delegation, arrived in Panama City Sunday evening on the first-leg of his three country Central America visit that will also take him to Costa Rica and Honduras.
On Monday, Huang also met with Panamanian First Vice President/Foreign Minister Samuel Lewis Navarro for wide-ranging talks.
During his stay in Panama, Huang will preside over a regional working meeting with ROC diplomatic mission chiefs stationed in Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTISTIC YOUTH WITH MUSIC TALENT GAINS ADMISSION TO UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Lee Shang-hsuan, a 19-year-old autistic pianist with multiple disabilities, has successfully gained admission to a local university to further develop his musical talent.

Lee was born with G-6-PD deficiency -- a hereditary, sex-linked enzyme defect that results in the breakdown of red blood cells when the person is exposed to stress from infection or certain drugs. He was further diagnosed as a "hyperactive autistic child with medium-grade mental disability" at the age of 3 -- yet he is gifted with an extraordinary memory for numbers and musical scores.
Undaunted by his multiple deficiencies, his parents have devoted an enormous amount of energy and patience toward fostering and developing his talent in the musical field.

He began to play piano at the age of 4. With his acute sensitivity to sound and rhythm and his exceptional ability to memorize musical scores, Lee quickly excelled; his piano teacher praised him as a genius.

Over the past 15 years, Lee has taken part in numerous piano competitions, both nationwide and for the mentally or physically challenged, winning numerous medals. In 2005, he won one of the top honors in a national piano contest for senior high school students.

Lee has gradually gained international fame, capturing two awards in the first international Paralympic piano competition held in Japan last year, and is scheduled to give a piano recital at the National Concert Hall in Taipei Jan. 27, 2007.
Lee graduated from a special school in NanTzu, Kaohsiung last year. Because of his multiple disabilities, he was unable to pass any entrance exams for local universities.

But through coordination among the Presidential Office, educational authorities and several universities in southern Taiwan, Pingtung University finally agreed to admit Lee as a student at the school's special educational resources center so he can continue his musical training.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN APPRECIATES BRITISH PARLIAMENTARY SUPPORT: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed gratitude Monday for a report released by the British House of Commons' Foreign Affairs Committee a day earlier that urges the British government to work to have the European Union maintain its ban on arms sales to China.
The report also urged the British government to increase political contact with Taiwan and support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 15 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Aug. 15:
10:00, The Taiwan Thinktank will hold a seminar on Taiwan's diplomacy.
15:00 The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSAI DUEI TO BE NEW TRANSPORTATION MINISTER

TEXT.P: Tsai Duei, political deputy minister of transportation and communications, will take over the helm of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), Executive Yuan sources said Monday.
According to the source, Premier Su Tseng-chang made up his mind to promote Tsai to the MOTC's top post after comprehensive talks with Tsai in the evening.
Tsai will succeed Kuo Yao-chi who tendered her resignation Aug. 7 amid the shambles surrounding the controversial electronic toll collection (ETC) system on the nation's freeways.
A seasoned technocrat at the MOTC, Tsai said he is grateful to the premier for promoting him to a key post.
On the thorny ETC issue, Tsai said the MOTC will deal with it in a very circumspective manner under the principle of respecting the Supremer Administrative Court ruling on the case.
Throughout his 37-year career in public service, Tsai has spent 36 years working at the MOTC, with only a one-year stint at the Public Construction Commission.

Before becoming an MOTC deputy minister, Tsai had been director of the Civil Aeronautics Administration and a deputy director of the Directorate General of Telecommunications, which used to be under the jurisdiction of the MOTC, but is now administered by the National Communications Commission.

The ETC project, which had already become a scandal when Kuo took over as transport minister Jan. 25 this year, was ruled by the Supreme Administrative Court early this month as illegal because the MOTC did not follow the principles of equality and public interest in awarding the project to Far Eastern Electronic Toll Co. (FETC).
The FETC, which was stripped of its "priority applicant" status in winning the contract as a result of the ruling, has been running the shambolic system for several months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 15, or the 22nd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1057: Macbeth, King of Scotland who ascended to the throne after killing his cousin King Duncan in battle in 1040, is killed by Duncan's son Malcolm at Lumphanan, near Aberdeen. The legend of his rise to power and his reign are the basis of Shakespeare's tragedy "Macbeth."
1769: Napoleon Bonaparte, military leader and the emperor of France from 1804 to 1815, is born in Ajaccio, Corsica.
1900: The Kuang Hsu Emperor and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, flee to northwestern China from Beijing as the capital is captured by the forces of eight foreign powers during the Boxer Uprising.
1914: The 82-km-long Panama Canal, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, is opened after 35 years of construction.
1945: The Republic of China Legislative Yuan unanimously approves the United Nations Charter.
1947: India gains independence from Britain with Jawaharlal Nehru as the first prime minister.
1948: President Syngman Rhee formally proclaims South Korea as the Republic of Korea.
1949: A Southeast China Governor's Office is established in Taipei with Gen. Chen Cheng as governor.
1959: The ROC Army receives Nike-Hercules surface-to-air missiles from the United States under a military aid program.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan rules that, according to Article 77 of the ROC Constitution, courts of all levels shall be placed under the jurisdiction of the Judicial Yuan.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Congo (Brazzaville) Republic.
1962: The Netherlands signs a treaty agreeing to Indonesian rule of Irian Jaya (Netherlands New Guinea).
1967: Kung Hsiang-hsi, former ROC premier and finance minister, dies in the United States at the age of 88.
1974: South Korean President Park Chung Hee's wife is shot dead by an assassin in an attempt on Park's life.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo urges college students to contribute their wisdom and energy to the country as he presides over the closing ceremony of the summer vacation military training program of college students at the Cheng-kung base in Taichung.
1979: Direct dialing service to the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore is initiated by the Taiwan Telecommunications Administration.
1980: The wreckage of the Titanic, the British luxury liner which sank after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York on April 14, 1912, is found laying on the ocean floor 3,657 meters below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.
1981: The First ROC-Indian Cultural and Economic Seminar on India's 34th Independence Day is held in Taipei.
1981: The Republic of China and Saint Vincent establish formal diplomatic relations.
1985: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa accepts the resignation of Finance Minister Loh Jen-kong.
1986: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa, in an interview with Saudi Arabian journalists from the Okaz Daily and Al-Bilad Daily, points out that the achievements of the ROC over the past thirty-odd years has won the nation international recognition and made it an indispensable force against communist expansion in the Asia-Pacific region.
1990: President Mikhail Gorbachev restores Soviet citizenship to Nobel Prize-winning author Alexander Solshenitsyn, who was exiled to the West in 1974 for his novels attacking Stalinism.
1995: The Chinese mainland begins eleven days of tactical guided missile exercises by firing live artillery shells into the sea 136 kilometers north of Taiwan.
1999: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Commission, donates US$100,000 and 20 computers to the Chinese Benevolent Federation in San Francisco.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture announces that beef imports from Argentina and Paraguay will be temporarily banned due to an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in the two South American countries.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party formally establishes the Taiwan-Japan Goodwill Association to further bolster bilateral ties between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who acquires truth is one who finds out what is good and holds fast to it."

Taipei, Aug. 14 (CNA) The Public Prosecutors' Office at the Taiwan High Court defended itself Monday, saying that its high-profile protection of a key witness in a case involving President Chen Shui-bian's suspected embezzlement of state affairs funds is justified.

A spokesman for the High Court's Prosecutors' Office made the remarks in response to criticism by legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that the Investigation Bureau "made a fuss" by providing "chief of state-class protection" to a Taiwanese businesswoman based in Australia who returned to Taiwan around midnight Sunday to provide evidence in the case.

More than 100 law enforcement officers were escorting Lee when she arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. Agents from the Investigation Bureau are reportedly providing round-the-clock protection during Lee's stay in Taiwan.
The spokesman also said that before Lee departed from Australia, the High Prosecutors' Office had obtained her consent that she would be protected as a key witness.

"Providing protection for Lee is fundamental and necessary," he said, adding, "The measure will allow prosecutors to proceed with their investigation smoothly and let other witnesses feel safe during the investigation."
Lee claimed she has brought documents with her to prove that her cousin, Lee Bi-chun, took many of her hotel and shopping receipts and gave them to the first lady, Su Shu-jen.
Initial probes by the Ministry of Audit showed some of Lee's receipts were used by the president to claim state affairs allowances for fake expenditures.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIONS CLUB JOINS PROGRAM TO SPONSOR PHILIPPINE CHILDREN(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Taichung-based Yuta Lions Club in central Taiwan joined a program sponsoring disadvantaged children in the Philippines Monday to show that its altruistic commitment has no national boundaries.

Liu Pei-feng, president of the Yuta Lions Club, informed the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) of the club's decision to sponsor 16 Philippine children from impoverished families after learning the fund was seeking donors for its global program.

The club will pay NT$700 per month for each child it chooses to sponsor in the Philippines, financing the provision of daily meals, nutrients, healthcare, improved drinking water, cleaner living environments and vocational training for the kids' parents.

The TFCF, one of Taiwan's largest child and family welfare organizations, is a founding member of ChildFund International, which currently has more than 100,000 disadvantaged children around the globe awaiting sponsorship.
In addition to matching sponsors with local disadvantaged children, the TFCF has also offered sponsorships for 31,858 children from impoverished families in 28 countries around the world.
TFCF Executive-Director Chen Pang-hung said the foundation appreciates the Lions Club's support, and hopes more citizens will follow suit to show the benevolence of the Taiwanese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA PLANS TO INCREASE PENALTY FOR MISTREATMENT OF ANIMALS(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Cabinet is considering amending the Animal Protection Act to increase the penalty for maltreatment of animals.
A COA spokesman said Monday that a recent case of animal cruelty indicates that it may be time to amend the law to provide better protection for animals.
Under Taiwan's Animal Protection Act, promulgated in 1998, those found guilty of animal cruelty can face a fine of between NT$10,00 and NT$50,000.
Animal welfare advocates have complained that the current law does not serve as a deterrent against cruel behavior toward animals.

An Internet user recently posted photos online showing how he enjoyed abusing his kitten in a sadistic manner. Other animal-loving Internet users managed to track him down, but law enforcement agencies found the most they could do was to fine him NT$50,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTISTIC YOUTH WITH MUSIC TALENT GAINS ADMISSION TO UNIVERSITY(repeat)

TEXT.P: Lee Shang-hsuan, a 19-year-old autistic pianist with multiple disabilities, has successfully gained admission to a local university to further develop his musical talent.

Lee was born with G-6-PD deficiency -- a hereditary, sex-linked enzyme defect that results in the breakdown of red blood cells when the person is exposed to stress from infection or certain drugs. He was further diagnosed as a "hyperactive autistic child with medium-grade mental disability" at the age of 3 -- yet he is gifted with an extraordinary memory for numbers and musical scores.
Undaunted by his multiple deficiencies, his parents have devoted an enormous amount of energy and patience toward fostering and developing his talent in the musical field.

He began to play piano at the age of 4. With his acute sensitivity to sound and rhythm and his exceptional ability to memorize musical scores, Lee quickly excelled; his piano teacher praised him as a genius.

Over the past 15 years, Lee has taken part in numerous piano competitions, both nationwide and for the mentally or physically challenged, winning numerous medals. In 2005, he won one of the top honors in a national piano contest for senior high school students.

Lee has gradually gained international fame, capturing two awards in the first international Paralympic piano competition held in Japan last year, and is scheduled to give a piano recital at the National Concert Hall in Taipei Jan. 27, 2007.
Lee graduated from a special school in NanTzu, Kaohsiung last year. Because of his multiple disabilities, he was unable to pass any entrance exams for local universities.

But through coordination among the Presidential Office, educational authorities and several universities in southern Taiwan, Pingtung University finally agreed to admit Lee as a student at the school's special educational resources center so he can continue his musical training.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH GOV'T URGED TO HEED PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE'S ADVICE ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The British government should take heed of the British House of Commons' Foreign Affairs Committee's calls for more political contact with Taiwan, a diplomatic official said Tuesday.
The British parliamentary committee issued its first East Asian report in seven years on Monday. The 152-page report contains nine pages exclusively dealing with Taiwan-related topics.

The report urged the British government to work to have the European Union (E.U.) maintain its ban on arms sales to China. The ban has remained in place since the 1989 Tiananmen massacre in which Chinese troops brutally cracked down on pro-democracy demonstrators.

It further called for the British executive branch to back Taiwan in the latter's quest for full membership in the World Health Organization (WHO), in addition to increasing political contact with Taiwan.

Noting that China's military expansion, particularly its missile deployment along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan, poses a threat to East Asian peace and stability, the report said the British government should continue pushing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resolve their disputes by peaceful means.

Commenting on the report, the official with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said the Republic of China government appreciates the British Parliament's Taiwan-friendly proposals and hopes other E.U. member states can take a similar stance and support Taiwan's WHO bid.

The British parliamentary committee started a review of British relations with East Asian countries early this year. In May, Mike Gapes, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Commons, headed a nine-member group on a visit to Hong Kong, Beijing, Tibet, Shanghai and Taipei to gather first-hand information about the latest situation in the region in preparation for collating a comprehensive report for policymaking reference.

During the delegation's visit to China, Chinese officials fiercely dissuaded the delegation from traveling to Taiwan. However, the delegation issued a statement rejecting China's request and reaffirming that the committee will continue voicing its support for democratic countries around the world, including Taiwan.

The British parliamentary delegation arrived in Taiwan May 17 for a two-day visit, during which the group met with President Chen Shui-bian, Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang and other senior government officials to obtain a better understanding of Taiwan's political and economic development and cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA, TAIWAN TO CONTINUE TO BOLSTER BILATERAL TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Bilateral cooperation between Panama and Taiwan has been close and strong, and the Panamian government will continue to bolster such exchanges in years to come, Panamian First Vice President and Foreign Minister Samuel Lewis Navarro said Monday.
Lewis said that Panama-Taiwan bilateral cooperation has taken root, with exchanges expected to bloom in profusion in the future under further concerted efforts.
Lewis made the remarks in a news release issued immediately after his meeting with visiting Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang for wide-ranging talks.

The Panamanian first vice president and foreign minister extended a hearty welcome to Huang's visit, during which the ROC foreign minister is expected to further cement bilateral ties between the two countries.
Lewis said that all bilateral cooperative projects between Panama and Taiwan have been promoted transparently and on a nation-to-nation basis.
Taiwan will help Panama battle poverty, making the plan the centerpiece of all cooperative projects between the two countries, Lewis said.
Existing cooperative projects, ranging from agricultural, husbandry and fishery cooperation to educational and training courses, have continued to proceed under a scholarship formula, he added.
In the agricultural and husbandry sectors, Lewis said, Taiwan has helped Panama raise its productivity in horticulture, tropical fruit plantation, fish culture and poultry farming.

Other Panamanian Cabinet officials, including Housing Minister Balbina Herrera, Social Development Minister Maria Roquebert, Health Minister Camilo Alleyne, Agricultural and Husbandry Development Minister Guillermo Salazar, and Commercial and Industrial Development Minister Alejandro Ferrer, were also present at the talks with Huang.

After hearing the Panamanian officials' briefing on the proposed Panama Canal expansion project, Huang said Taiwan is one of the major users of the canal and is determined to take part in the expansion work, adding that the cooperation is expected to begin soon after Panama holds a nationwide plebiscite on the project.
Before talking to the Panamanian officials, Huang met with Panamanian President Martin Torrijos Monday for talks on matters of mutual concern.
Huang, heading an official ROC delegation, arrived in Panama City Sunday evening on the first leg of his three-country Central America visit that will also take him to Costa Rica and Honduras.
While in Panama City, he is also scheduled to preside over a regional working meeting with ROC diplomatic mission chiefs stationed in Latin America Tuesday.
Huang is scheduled to depart from Panama for Costa Rica Wednesday.
