DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LOCALLY-DEVELOPED ROV MAKES DEBUT

TEXT.P: Two national universities jointly debuted Taiwan's first locally-developed remotely operated underwater vehicle (ROV) Tuesday, marking a giant step forward for Taiwan in the development of ocean exploration technology.

The unmanned, highly maneuverable underwater robot, jointly developed by students and professors from National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) and National Sun Yat-sen University (NSYSU) , was officially presented at a news conference held at the Ministry of Education.

After three years of planning, research, development, design and testing, the Taiwan-made ROV underwent final laboratory testing at a depth of 200 meters earlier this year. The vehicle passed the 12-hour test, said Fang Ming-chuan, a professor with NCKU's Department of Systems and Naval Mechatronic Engineering, who is also director of the ROV development project.

The ROV passed further testing in June in waters off Hsiaoliuchiu, an islet to Taiwan's southeast, operated by a person aboard a surface vessel, Fang said, adding that the vehicle successfully acquired underwater images and other information about the seas, including the depth, location, water clarity, light penetration and temperature, during the testing.

Fang said ROVs and ROV technology can be used for many applications, including national defense, ocean energy development, underwater engineering, underwater rescue and search, archaeological work and maritime environment research.
He said that the Taiwan-developed ROV is equal in quality to those currently available in Western countries and that its production cost is only about half that of Western-made ROVs.

According to Fang, since most foreign-made ROVs are not capable of resisting strong currents, which are prevalent in the seas surrounding Taiwan, his team will focus on the development of current-resistant ROVs as the immediate goal of the team's work.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORIAL OFFICE ASKS TO SEE PRESIDENT'S ASSET REPORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Prosecutors Office has twice asked the Control Yuan for asset reports filed by President Chen Shui-bian, a Control Yuan official confirmed Tuesday.

Hsieh Yu-nan, director of the department in charge of asset reporting by high-ranking officials, said that the Control Yuan first received a request from Taiwan High Prosecutors Office to provide all asset reports filed by the president dating back to the start of his first term in 2000, including two recent corrected versions on the assets of the first family, on Aug. 4.
Taiwan High Prosecutors Office asked to review President Chen's supplementary report on 31 pieces of jewelry of first lady Wu Shu-jen again Monday, Hsieh added.
Asked about the reasons for reviewing the asset reports, Hsieh said that whenever law enforcement officials feel there is a need in their investigations, they will make such a request.
According to the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, any piece of jewelry, including watches, worth over NT$200,000 (US$6,100) should be listed with the Control Yuan.
The first couple sent a corrected version of jewelry assets to the Control Yuan in early July, listing 15 pieces of jewelry and luxury watches that they own, with a total value of NT$3.72 million.

Legislators from the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party then produced photos of 31 pieces of jewelry worn by the first lady on various occasions. The Control Yuan therefore asked for an explanation from the first family within 15 days.

The first couple replied on the last day of the deadline that they had acquiesced to the Control Yuan's request by filing reports on their jewelry but had not reported on jewelry borrowed from relatives or friends because the relatives and friends were not being audited and should have the privacy of their assets protected.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER URGES FORMER CHAIRMAN TO STOP DEPOSE-PRESIDENT CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: A Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator urged former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh Tuesday to stop his campaign calling on one million people to donate NT$100 each toward deposing scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian.

Wang Shih-chien called on Shih not to "please our enemy and inflict pain on our camp" after some 70,000 people donated almost NT$10 million in support of Shih's campaign on the very first day Monday. Shih launched the drive over the weekend.

Shih has said that if the one million target is reached earlier than Sept. 9, he will move ahead his schedule to take the people to the streets to demand that the president step down for the sake of Taiwan's future.

Wang said it would not be a problem at all for Shih to win one million supporters since the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) alone has more than two million members and the KMT has recently been "fattened" by selling huge amounts of its "ill-gotten" assets.
"As long as the KMT clandestinely encourages its members to donate money to Shih, his good reputation will be ruined, " Wang claimed.
He said that he believes Shih will be able to collect NT$100 million soon, adding, however, that he would like to remind Shih "not to take the KMT's money" in order to avoid tainting his own name.

DOC.HEADLINE: 79% SUPPORT APPLYING FOR U.N. MEMBERSHIP UNDER NAME OF TAIWAN: POLL

TEXT.P: As high as 79 percent of the people in Taiwan are in favor of the proposal that the country apply to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Taiwan Thinktank.
The survey, conducted by Focus Survey Research for the think tank from Aug. 10-11 on 1,072 adults, has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.99 percentage points.

According to the survey, 81.4 percent of the respondents said they are aware that Taiwan and Chad recently severed diplomatic relations. While 42 percent of the respondents think that China's suppression of Taiwan and its efforts to tempt Taiwan's diplomatic allies with financial offers were to blame for the outcome, 24 percent think that the failure of Taiwan's diplomatic policy was responsible, and 23 percent think that the Chadian government was acting "too expediently."

Sixty-five percent of the respondents think that it was an insult to the people of Taiwan for Chad to announce its decision to switch recognition to Beijing right before Premier Su Tseng-chang's scheduled visit to Chad.
The survey shows that after this incident, only 8.6 percent of the people have a positive impression of China.
Meanwhile, 68 percent of the respondents think that Taiwan should continue to develop its foreign relations even if this leads to increased tensions in cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

With Taiwan facing increasingly relentless suppression from China, 38 percent of the respondents think that Taiwan should negotiate with Beijing for a resolution, 35 percent think that Taiwan should seek breakthroughs on its own, and 18 percent think that Taiwan should seek the assistance of other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA CARD SPENDING BY FOREIGN VISITORS IN TAIWAN UP IN Q1

TEXT.P: Visa credit card transactions by foreign visitors in Taiwan during the first quarter of this year totaled NT$4.7 billion (US$147 million) , up by 0.8 percent year on year, a report made public Tuesday by the Visa International Service Association showed.

According to the report, nearly 75 percent of the foreign visitors to Taiwan in the first quarter were from Japan, the United States, Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore. Most of their spending was on accommodations (30 percent), retail purchases (28 percent) and transportation (12 percent).
Department stores, duty free shops and boutiques were most frequented by foreign visitors to Taiwan during the January-March period, the report said.

It is worth noting that more and more foreign visitors to Taiwan have been engaging in different ways of shopping, with the number of transactions made through telephone by foreign visitors to Taiwan using Visa credit cards in the first quarter increasing the most by 162 percent over the level for the same period a year earlier, the report said.

Online shopping transactions by foreign visitors in Taiwan with Visa credit cards accounted for 2.7 percent of the total Visa card spending by foreign visitors in Taiwan during the three months, and the ratio is expected to continue growing in the future, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S DIPLOMATIC SUPPRESSION HAS HURT CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: MAC

TEXT.P: China's relentless diplomatic suppression of Taiwan has hurt cross-strait exchanges, Huang Wei-feng, deputy chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , said Tuesday.
Huang made the remarks during a seminar on "The Public's View on Taiwan's Current Diplomacy" sponsored by the Taiwan Thinktank.
He said Beijing's suppression has not only hurt the Taiwan people's feelings and dignity, it has also led the Taiwan people to doubt China's sincerity in trying to improve cross-strait relations.

He noted that Beijing has adopted a policy "of sabotaging Taiwan's diplomatic relations with its allies, containing the maneuvering space of Taiwan internationally, and squeezing all of Taiwan's bargaining chips for engaging in talks with China on an equal footing."
"And this diplomatic offensive has been conducted under the guise of a peaceful development," he added.

Hsu Yung-ming, an assistant researcher at Academia Sinica, the nation's highest research institute, said on the same occasion that Taiwan's severance of diplomatic ties with Chad recently was due to the internal struggle between China's forces in charge of cross-strait affairs and those in charge of diplomatic affairs.

Hsu, who just returned from a visit to China, said that those forces in China in charge of cross-strait affairs have performed brilliantly over the past few years, resulting in pressure on those forces in charge of diplomatic affairs.

Taiwan severed diplomatic ties with Chad hours ahead of Premier Su Tseng-Chang's scheduled departure for Chad Aug. 6. Taiwan made the move upon learning that the Central African country was about to re-establish diplomatic relations with China.
Ministry of Foreign AFfairs spokesman Michel Lu said that the Chad incident has made the Taiwan people realize the diplomatic difficulties that the nation is facing.

Lu expressed the hope that the public will understand that although the number of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, currently standing at 24, is important, more attention should be paid to "substantive diplomacy, " referring to such matters as trade, high-tech exchanges, medical assistance, and exchanges between non-governmental organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY ACTION LEAGUE WELCOMES SHIH SUPPORTERS TO JOIN SIT-IN

TEXT.P: The Democratic Action League (DAL), which has obtained a permit to use Ketagalan Boulevard in downtown Taipei Sept. 9-10, said Tuesday it has invited supporters from former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh's "one million people campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian."

DAL convener Huang Kuang-kuo said since his group launched a "democracy night market" campaign at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall July 27, it has also been engaged in a national campaign to drive the scandal-ridden president out of office.
"We've been trying to awaken people's social conscience, hoping they can rise above their political differences marked by the 'pan-blue' and 'pan-green' colors," Huang said.

Since DAL and Shih's campaigns share a common goal, Huang said his group would be happy to share the boulevard with Shih's supporters so more people can join forces and push for change in the nation's politics.

Huang said as the president appeared dead set on remaining in power, the DAL's national campaign would "wage a war of nerves" with Chen, a war he claimed would never cease until the president steps down.

Besides rallying on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office, DAL members -- mostly intellectuals -- and supporters will also stroll past the president's residence -- code-named Yushan or Jade Mountain -- to show their discontent with Chen, whose family members and senior aides have been indicted on insider trading and other corruption charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTALISTS FILE LAWSUIT AGAINST TAINAN COUNTY GOV'T

TEXT.P: A group of environmental activists filed a lawsuit against the Tainan County Government Tuesday, accusing it of profiteering by allowing a waste disposal company to dump waste near the Wushantou Reservoir.

The group, led by Tainan City Environmental Protection Alliance head Huang An-tiao, lodged the lawsuit at the Tainan Prosecutor's Office -- the latest act in a seven-year struggle against the waste disposal company that has gained the county government's approval to dump garbage at a site near the water catchement of the reservoir.

Huang said that they will also petition the Tainan County Government demanding a ban on the company's incoming operations in order to fully protect water resources in the area. Wushantou Reservoir is one of the most important water providers in southern Taiwan.
The Tainan County Government respects the group's move and hopes that the truth will be fully explored through legal means, Tainan Deputy Magistrate Yen Chun-tso said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET ANNOUNCES PROMOTION OF DEPUTY TRANSPORT MINISTER

TEXT.P: Tsai Tui, deputy minister of transportation and communications, will be promoted to take over the helm of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Tuesday.

Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang confirmed at a news conference that Premier Su Tseng-chang decided to promote Tsai to the MOTC's top post after having comprehensive talks with Tsai the previous evening. Tsai, 59, will be succeeding Transportation and Communications Minister Kuo Yao-chi, who offered to resign Aug. 7.

Su wanted Tsai to work toward solving disputes surrounding the freeway electronic toll collection system, which has whipped up political rows around the country and constituted one of the reasons Kuo quit the post.
For his part, Tsai answered the premier by saying he was extremely grateful for the promotion and was determined to do his job devotedly, according to the spokesman.

Cheng said Tsai, a Ph.D. in electrical engineering from National Taiwan University, is a seasoned technocrat who has held other prominent MOTC posts, including deputy director-general of the Directorate General of Telecommunications; director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration; and senior supervisor to the MOTC.

Kuo Yao-chi tendered her resignation Aug. 7, citing "policy differences" with the premier and other superiors. Kuo served the shortest ministerial term in Taiwan's history as transportation and communications minister. She was sworn in as minister on the day Premier Su Tseng-chang launched his new Cabinet Jan. 25.

Commenting on Tsai's promotion, a whip of the opposition People First Party legislative caucus said Tsai's professionalism is beyond question, but it remains to be seen whether Tsai will be able to survive political pressure and resist the push from interest groups.
Lee Hung-chun said if these adverse conditions aren't tackled, no one in the country could be a good transportation and communications minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY WITNESS CALLS FOR PUBLIC TRUST IN TAIWAN'S JUSTICE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese businesswoman who has returned from Australia to provide testimony about her knowledge of a special state affairs fund urged the people of Taiwan to "have confidence in the justice system" Tuesday.

Lee Hui-fen, also known as Ligi Lee, was interrogated for 15 hours after arriving from Australia early Monday by investigators who are probing suspected irregularities in the use of the state affairs fund by Presidential Office staff and potentially President Chen Shui-bian.
A recent investigation found that fake invoices and questionable receipts had been submitted to claim "state affairs" expenses, and some of that evidence had originated from Lee.
Lee reportedly handed over many invoices from her business trips in Taiwan to her cousin Lee Pi-chun, owner of a pharmaceutical company and a friend of first lady Wu Shu-jen.

Lee Pi-chun has confessed to the prosecution that she had given some of her cousin's invoices to "other people" but had no idea why they ended up in the accounting reports of the Presidential Office on the use of the state affairs fund. Pi-chun is a suspect in this case and barred from leaving the country.
Lee Hui-fen said she was quite hesitant, even suspicious, before telling anything to prosecutors.
"I have been convinced by Prosecutor Chen Jui-jen, " who has investigated a series of major political and economic scandals including the "Stock Vultures" case, she said.
"When I realized that judicial officials were really serious about pursuing all the facts and delivering justice, I started to tell everything I know about this case," she added.

Now that she has been convinced she can trust the justice system, "I need not worry about the case being 'eaten up' or going nowhere," she said, urging the public to also have confidence in the country's judicial authorities.
Lee, who runs Taiwan Ang Corp. which sells designer jewelry and apparel, told the press that when she provided testimony she intended to strike at no one, including the president.
But out of her love for Taiwan, she said she has donated NT$100 to a campaign calling upon one million people to stand up and depose the scandal-ridden president.
The campaign was initiated by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who vowed to lead a million people to topple Chen Shui-bian if they each donate NT$100 toward the campaign.
"I am a Taiwanese, and I love Taiwan," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE PERFORMANCES EVERY SATURDAY AT TAICHUNG'S FORMER WINERY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Art Design and Architecture Center (TADA) in Taichung city, central Taiwan, will feature free performances every Saturday until the end of September, the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) announced Tuesday.
Under CCA's sponsorship, TADA has lined up a series of performances by local artists and performing groups at the site of a former Taichung winery near the Taichung railway station.

Members of the public are invited to the free performances, which are scheduled to begin from 4: 30 p.m. every Saturday at TADA, which has been declared a historical site by the Taichung city government.

Artists and groups scheduled to perform at TADA include: the National Taiwan Symphony Orchestra, the Little Frog Theater, Tulanshan Troupe with Canadian musician Matthew Lien, the Sky Bridge Singing Group, Casper Tsai with the Boys From Bolivia, and a youth diabolo dancing group.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 3.23 points to close at 6,615.13.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,628.5 and closed at the day's low of 6,595.35. A total of 2.66 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.6 billion (US$2.09 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares increasing 0.4 percent.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.2 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares and textile stocks remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 500 to 484, with 156 stocks remaining unchanged.

La Repubblica: Prodi: Ceasefire in Lebanon takes effect.
The United Nations brokered ceasefire in Lebanon took effect Monday while both Israel and Lebanese militant group Hezbollah claimed victory in the five-week-long conflict that triggered by the incursion of Hezbollah members into the Israeli territories July 12, killing eight Israeli soldiers and kidnapping another two.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune: Firat the truce, then the test
The fate of the cease-fire may lie in whether the Lebanese regard the conflict as a victory or blame Hezbollah for the destruction. Thousands of Lebanese returned home after the cease-fire began.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: First the Truce, Then the Test of How Long It Can Last
The U.N. Security Council has passed far-reaching resolutions on Lebanon before -- especially Resolution 1559, in September 2004, which called for the disbanding of Hezbollah's fighting force and all other militias and the extension of Lebanese government control over the entire country. That resolution had no enforcement mechanism and was largely ignored. After 34 days of warfare, the latest resolution, 1701, repeats the goals of 1559 but provides more teeth. But will it be effective? As always, the real test is not in the resolution but in its fulfillment, and there are reasons for skepticism. If the skepticism turns out to be correct, how long will Israel stand by and watch the rearmament of Hezbollah in violation of the resolution?
Wall Street Journal: Student Plagiarism Stirs Controversy At Ohio University
Vipul Ranatunga, an engineering professor at Miami University of Ohio, was found that in his 1999 thesis had taken about seven pages directly from the thesis of a Chinese student who had re ceived his master's degreee at Ohio the year before. The lapse of attribution has embroiled him in one of higher education's largest plagiarism scandals. Plagiarism, of course, isn't limited to international students. According to a 2005 study by Duke University's Center for Academic Integrity, 40 percent of all U.S. college students admit to having woven unattributed material from the Internet into their written work. Still, international students may lack the English fluency needed to read and paraphrase scientific literature, and may come from countries with less-rigorous academic standards.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER DENIES CENTRAL AMERICAN TRIP AIMED AT AVOIDING DOMINO EFFECT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang denied Tuesday reports suggesting that his current visit to three of the country's diplomatic allies in Central America is aimed at preventing a possible domino effect from Chad's recent switching of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

Huang pointed out to CNA that the trip to Panama, Costa Rica and Honduras was arranged long before Taiwan severed diplomatic ties with Chad Aug. 6 and that the trip has nothing to do with the Chad incident.
Huang said the major purpose of the visit is to discuss bilateral cooperation projects.

On Honduras President Manuel Zelaya's two cancellations of planned visits to Taiwan, Huang said Zelaya's decision should not be "over-interpreted" as a move to express his displeasure with Taiwan, as Zelaya is beset with domestic problems.
Huang said his ministry will do its utmost to maintain the country's relations with its diplomatic allies while China is using every possible means to suppress Taiwan.
He said the other purpose of his Central American trip is to attend a meeting with Taiwan diplomats in the Central and Southern American and Caribbean regions.

Noting that Central America is home to the largest number of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, Huang said he hopes the diplomats will use the opportunity to exchange views on the problems faced by the country and do some brainstorming.

On his present visit in Panama, Huang said he had met President Martin Torrijos and held talks with First Vice-President and Minister of Foreign Relations Samuel Lewis Navarro and seven other members of the Panamanian Cabinet to discuss bilateral cooperation plans.

For example, Taiwan is planning to build bamboo houses in mountainous areas in northern Panama, where there are a large number of indigenous people, in a bid to help Panama eliminate poverty, he said.
In addition, Taiwan will also help enhance education, health and medical services for the middle and lower classes in Panama, he said.

Huang said that during his meeting with Torrijos, he expressed his approval for Torrijos' policies to improve social welfare, take care of disadvantaged groups, eliminate poverty and enhance the standard of education.
Huang said he told Torrijos that Taiwan's experience in terms of education, health and agriculture can be a good reference for Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST ORGANIC FASHION, LIFESTYLE EXPOSITION

TEXT.P: The Taiwan 2006 International Organic Fashion and Lifestyle Exposition will open Aug. 24 at the Taipei World Trade Center and last for four days, organizers said Tuesday.

According to Organic Lifestyle magazine -- sponsor of the exhibition -- the event is intended to strengthen Taiwan's organic industries and "lifestyles of health and sustainability"-related industries.
Executives of the magazine decided to hold the exhibition after they achieved great success with a Vegetarian and Organic Expo last year.
The Organic Trade Association -- a membership-based business association representing the organic industry in North America -- will also take part in the exhibition.
Unofficial statistics show that in 2005, Taiwan consumed US$60 million-worth of organic food products, of which US$30 million-worth was imported.
Domestic organic industry leaders say Taiwan's organic food market still has a lot of room for growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOULD CANCEL PALAU VISIT: PFP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong urged President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday to cancel a planned visit to Palau at this sensitive moment when he is at the center of allegations of corruption regarding the Presidential Office's state affairs spending.

Calling on the president not to go abroad at this critical juncture and to stay in Taiwan to face the public's questions about his role in the alleged corruption, Soong said that Chen should take on the public's challenge unless he plans to flee into exile overseas -- a suggestion put forward by former Control Yuan President Wang Tso-yung.

Chen has announced that he is slated to visit Palau early next month -- a time that might coincide with a plan by the Democratic Action Alliance to stage a large-scale demonstration Sept. 9 on the square in front of the Presidential Office to demand his resignation.

Soong said that he fully supports and wishes the best for the civic group's drive to unseat Chen, saying that "no one wants a corrupt regime." But he added that the PFP will not take part in the activity to avoid confrontation between the opposition "pan blue alliance" and the "pan green camp."
Soong also prodded main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to "have more teeth" and to show his determination to boot out Chen to meet what he claimed are public expectations.
"The people are entitled to ask for a clean and proficient government when a nation's leadership has gone wrong," he said.

The PFP has raised a proposal to impeach Chen at the Legislative Yuan, Soong said, calling for firm support from other opposition parties in its bid to remove Chen in an attempt to end the woes and disorder that have "tainted Taiwan's democratic image."

Wu Kung-yu, deputy director of the PFP's publicity department, echoed Soong's remarks, saying that Chen should stay in Taiwan and provide a clear explanation to the public as soon as possible at a time when Chen himself and members of his family are dogged by a spate of corruption scandals.
Members of the legislative caucus of the KMT criticized Chen earlier the same day for attempting to shift the public's attention from the corruption scandals.
Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, KMT legislative caucus whip Tsai Chin-lung questioned the motive behind Chen's Palau visit.
If Chen does not mean to divert away public attention with the Palau trip, he must be seeking to find a way out, KMT lawmakers claimed.

KMT lawmaker Chiu Yi also called a news conference at the Legislative Yuan asking the prosecution and investigation authorities to get to the bottom of the various high-profile corruption allegations, such as the suspicious reimbursement of state affairs expenses by the Presidential Office on behalf of Chen and the acceptance of Sogo Department Store gift vouchers by first lady Wu Shu-jen.

Citing Ligi Lee, a businesswoman roducing who returned to Taiwan from Australia early Monday to answer prosecutors' questions regarding irregularities found in the president's use of the state affairs spending, Chiu said that it is clear that the Presidential Office used Lee's invoices to claim state affair funds.
The key point in the issue is whether the Presidential Office used other people's invoices to obtain reimbursement from the funds, rather than the number of invoices it has used, Chiu argued.

According to Lee, she brought solid evidence from Australia to prove that her cousin, Lee Pi-chun, a close friend of first lady Wu Shu-jen, took away many of her invoices to "help" Wu during the 2003-2005 period.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISTS INFECTED WITH DYSENTERY IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) urged travelers to Indonesia to avoid eating raw food and drinking unboiled water Tuesday after three people returning from Indonesia were diagnosed with dysentery.
According to the CDC, the three were members of a 43-member tour group that visited Bandong, Java last month for religious activities.
Six of the visitors had fever on arrival at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport July 31, two had diarrhea and one had stomachache.
After collecting samples from all the group members for tests, the CDC confirmed that three were infected with bacillary dysentery.
CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said the visitors had eaten raw fish and fruit during their stay in Indonesia, which could have been the cause of their infection.

The latent period of bacillary dysentery usually lasts from one to three days and sometimes extends as long as one week, and the symptoms of the disease include diarrhea, fever, nausea, vomiting, cramps and bloody stools, according to the CDC.
The CDC called on travelers to Indonesia to pay extra attention to food hygiene, to avoid consuming food sold on the street and to wash their hands before eating to prevent infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOSE COLLABORATION BETWEEN TAIWAN'S BUSINESS, ACADEMIC BODIES: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked 12th in the world and second--next only to Singapore-- in Asia, in terms of the collaboration between business and academic institutes, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.

CEPD officials made the remarks when they unveiled a report on how to increase collaboration between business and academic institutes in order to create a more favorable environment for an innovative and value-added era.

The officials cited a 2006 global competitiveness report by the Lausanne-based International Institute for Management Development in pointing out that in the index of "knowledge transfer between companies and universities, " Finland was top, followed by the United States. Taiwan ranked 12th, ahead of Hong Kong, Japan and South Korea. Singapore was sixth.

They also cited the World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Report 2005-2006 to note that Taiwan ranked eighth in the index of collaboration among industries, academic and research organizations, putting it ahead of South Korea in 10th and Hong Kong in 24th.

In addition, the Taiwan Institute for Economic Research found in a survey of 900 manufacturers that 43 percent of enterprises have worked with colleges and universities on research and development, showing that businesses attach importance to cooperation with colleges and universities to improve business efficiency.
The CEPD said the ratio of college and university R&D budgets coming from enterprises accounted for 5.2 percent in 2004 up from 4.2 percent in 2003, representing a new high in nearly six years.

But the ratio still lagged behind that of 6.1 percent on average among members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), showing that there is room for growth in collaboration between the business and the academic and research sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION VALUE OF HI-TECH INDUSTRY TOPS NT$5.7 TRILLION IN 2005

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's hi-tech industry amounted to NT$5.78 trillion in 2005, up 30 percent compared with the level of 2000 and accounting for 54 percent of the total output of the manufacturing sector, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
However, the amount represents an increase of only 2.8 percent from 2004, owing to the exodus of Taiwan businesses to China, DGBAS officials said.

While the electronic parts and components industry contributed 37.4 percent to the total production value of the hi-tech industry in 2005, the semiconductor industry contributed 16.9 percent, marking the first time the ratio of the semiconductor sector has declined since 2001, the officials said.
Meanwhile, the contribution of computer, communications and video and audio electronic products dropped to 15.3 percent, they said.
In 2005, Taiwan exported US$45.7 billion- worth of electronic products, up more than 40 percent over the 2000 level, according to the officials.
The export value of information and communications products fell to US$10.5 billion in 2005, down 46 percent from 2000, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.011 to close at NT$32.756.
A total of US$869 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.745 and fluctuated between NT$32.545 and NT$32.783.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 12 points to close at 6,607, with 22,235 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September decreased eight points to finish at 6,590, with 1,0313 contracts traded, while December futures decreased two points to end at 6,590, with four contract transactions.
March futures moved down 15 points to close at 6,590, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,595 for August, 6,598 for September, 6,592 for December, 6,605 for March and 6,573 for June.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower. August TE futures moved up 0.75 points to close at 286.15, with 3,718 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 0.75 points to finish at 284.75, with 3,068 contract transactions.
December TE futures decreased 0.9 points to end at 284.05, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures lost nine points to close at 915, with 1,946 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 13 points to finish at 912, with 1,909 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 10TH IN TERMS OF GLOBAL DIGITAL OPPORTUNITY

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks 10th among 180 economic bodies in terms of digital opportunity, the Government Information Office said Tuesday, citing a 2006 global information report.
The Global Information Report is compiled by the International Telecommunication Union for observing the development of telecommunications.
The report also points out that Taiwan ranks 5th in the world in terms of ADSL coverage. The fee for ADSL is the fourth-lowest, higher only than Japan, South Korea and the Netherlands.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN `HOME AWAY FROM HOME' FOR INDIAN PH.D STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The friendliness of the Taiwanese people was not why Vikas Saxena and Gopi Kuppuraj, a pair of Ph.D students from India studying in the Taiwan International Graduate Program (TIGP) of Academia Sinica, came to Taiwan, but it is why they gradually have come to view Taiwan as "a home away from home."

"Taiwanese are helpful in nature. They would even leave their job to try to help you, " says Kuppuraj, who comes from the southern Indian city of Chennai and has been in Taiwan for two years. Friendliness of local people was what brought him out of his "little shell" and prompted him to start exploring Taiwan, he said.
Saxena's most unforgettable memory is similar. Saxena, a former veterinarian who was admitted to the program one year ago, recalled an incident at Moon Festival last year.

Saxena went out that night trying to find a restaurant to celebrate the festival. "Surprisingly, all the stores and restaurants nearby were closed, " he said, adding that restaurants in India would stay open all night on traditional holidays like the Moon Festival.

A family having a barbecue party, a traditional Moon Festival activity for local people, invited Saxena to join them. "Then a girl took me far away to find a restaurant, " said Saxena, who comes from a city near the Indian capital of New Delhi.
The first six months in Taiwan was hard for Kuppuraj, who experienced culture shock. "I didn't speak or read Chinese. The food was different. I was totally lost, " he said.
"I still get lost sometimes, but at least I knew how to get back to the dormitory, " said Kupperaj, who studies chemical biology and molecular biophysics.

Saxena, who has at least three more years to go in the molecular and cell biology program, is also getting comfortable with the environment as he now switches between cooking with Indian friends and eating in Indian restaurants in Taipei.

TIGP, a program established by Academia Sinica in 2002, is open to local and international students. Academia Sinica currently administers eight such programs, with degrees issued from partner universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 200,000 PEOPLE DONATE NT$25.5 MILLION TO DEPOSE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Supporters of a "one million people campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian" donated NT$16.2 million to two designated bank accounts Tuesday, bringing to NT$25.5 million the total donations by more than 200,000 people in the first two days of the campaign, according to a spokeswoman for the campaign.
The figures do not include donations to a third postal account that received 53,600 remittances totalling NT$8.67 million Monday. Organizers are urging people to give just NT$100 per person.

Ho De-fen, spokeswoman for the campaign initiated by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh, said no cash will be accepted and all donations must be made to the two bank accounts and the one postal account under the name of Shih Ming-teh.

Ho urged the public not to be defrauded after it was reported that in Hsinchuang, Taipei County, some people have claimed to be campaign workers offering "the service" of remitting NT$100 on behalf of donors.
"We do not accept cash and we do not raise funds through telephones or cell phones," she added.

The campaign has caught attention abroad, according to the spokeswoman, who said she has been approached by overseas Chinese asking if they could run ads for the campaign in local media. She said she has declined their offers.

She added that people in Shanghai and Heilongjiang in northeastern China have also called her to express their envy of Taiwan people, who enjoy the freedom to demand that their corrupt government leader step down.
"They also said they wanted to donate to our campaign. But we will never accept even one cent from them," Ho said.

She claimed that she has never been disappointed by Taiwan's democracy, although she sometimes feels frustrated. However, she added: "I believe we will weather this difficult time. Taiwan's democracy is a proud example for the Chinese world."

Starting Wednesday, each day's donations will be published on the Internet. In addition, she said, campaign leaders will organize speech tours to cities and towns to explain why and how to drive the scandal-ridden president out of office.
Shih has planned to start a mass sit-in Sept. 9 calling on Chen to step down. He said that if the one-million-person target is reached earlier, he will move the schedule forward.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN STUDENTS ENCOURAGE MORE EXCHANGES BETWEEN INDIA, TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Misconceptions about India can be corrected if there are more exchanges between India and Taiwan, according to a couple of Indian students in a graduate program run by Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute.

"In Taiwan, most information on India comes from English channels, but all they show is images of flood, drought, dying people, starving skinny kids. It's not the whole picture of India, " said Vikas Saxena, who is pursuing a doctoral degree in molecular and cell biology in one of eight programs offered by the Taiwan International Graduate Program (TIGP).

TIGP, a program established by Academia Sinica in 2002, is open to local and international students for Ph.D programs. Currently Academia Sinica administers eight such programs, with degrees issued by partner universities.
With more exchanges between India and Taiwan, Taiwanese people will be able to see "the better parts of India, which no-one has shown you before, " according to Saxena.
Gopi Kuppuraj, who is in the chemical biology and molecular biophysics program, agreed and encouraged Taiwanese people to visit India.

"Taiwanese need to know more about India. On the other hand, most people in India do not know much about Taiwan, " he said, adding that most of his friends did not even know where Taiwan is until he showed them photos the last time he went home.
Kuppuraj said he would also like to see more collaboration between India and Taiwan, which boasts strong competition in the software and hardware sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN STUDENTS DOMINATE TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL GRADUATE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Indian students account for 37 of the 203 students in the Taiwan International Graduate Program (TIGP) , the first program in Taiwan offering doctoral degrees to foreign students, more than any other country.

"Indian students make up 18 percent of our student body, which ranks No. 1 among 25 foreign countries, " said Hong Seau-feng, TIGP Executive Secretary for Student Affairs. Local students comprise 56 percent of the student body.
Behind India, Vietnam follows with eight students while Malaysia ranks third with seven.
TIGP, a program established in 2002 by Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, is open to local and international students.

Academia Sinica currently administers eight such programs, with degrees issued by partner universities such as National Taiwan University, National Tsing Hua University and National Chiao Tung University.

All courses and seminars of the program are conducted in English, Hong said. Fellowships are granted for applicants who receive admission. In addition to providing accommodation and free Mandarin classes, a stipend of about US$11,000 per year is also provided to foreign students.
"The program offers them a great opportunity to know more about Taiwan. Hopefully, they can share the experience with their countrymen when they go home, " Hong said.

Programs offered by TIGP include chemical biology and molecular biophysics, molecular science and technology, molecular and biological agricultural sciences, molecular and cell biology, bioinformatics, nano science and technology, molecular medicine, and computer linguistics and Chinese language processing.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY COUNCIL YIELDS WEB SITE NAME TO NCC
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, central Taiwan, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The Nantou county council will yield its Web site name -- http: //www.ncc.gov.tw -- to the Cabinet-level National Communications Commission (NCC) , Wu Chi-hsiang, speaker of the Nantou county council, said Tuesday.

Wu agreed to change the county council's initials in its Web site name from "NCC" to "NTCC" after NCC Chairman Su Yung-chin paid him a visit to sort out the problem of the NCC and the Nantou county council sharing the same initials.
Wu said he will ask the county council to formally endorse the decision for the change.
He said the county council, as a local authority, is most willing to yield the name "NCC" to the National Communications Commission -- an agency in the central government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG VOTES FOR BEST FOOD STALLS

TEXT.P: An on-line vote kicked off Tuesday in Taichung City to choose food stalls that best represent the central Taiwan city.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said at a news conference to promote the vote that many food stalls in the city have been around for decades and are well-known for turning out delicacies that are associated closely with Taichung.

Flanked by a group of food stall operators, Hu touted his plan to compile a guide of the city's delicacies based on the results of the vote, which he claimed will be a book "similar to the Michelin restaurant guide in France."
The process began Tuesday with interested food stalls nominating themselves, to be followed by an on-line vote from Sept. 18-20 and wrapping up with an on-the-spot review by judges Nov. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL APPLIED RESEARCH LABORATORIES PICKS NEW HEAD

TEXT.P: Chuang Che-nan, head of the National Center for High-performance Computing in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan was chosen Tuesday as the new president of the National Applied Research Laboratories in Taipei.
The board of directors of the laboratories approved Chuang's appointment for a three-year term until the end of August in 2009.
Chuang, who holds a doctorate in engineering, will replace Lee Lou-chuang, who has been recruited by the National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County as its president.
Founded in 2003 by the National Science Council, the laboratories is a non-profit organization comprising of eight research laboratories which focus on research in basic and applied sciences.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 16, or the 23rd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Americans led by Gen. John Stark defeat the British at the Battle of Bennington during the American Revolution.
1825: Bolivia declares its independence from Spain.
1909: Japanese Chutaro Kido discovers an iron mine in Anshan, Liaoning Province, located in Manchuria, where Japan has extensive economic privileges. The Southern Manchuria Railway later sets up a steel plant in Anshan.
1913: Menachem Begin, Israeli prime minister from 1977 to 1983, is born in Russia. He shared the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize with Anwar Sadat of Egypt.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who had participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty, organizes a revolt in Tahu, Hsinchu County, against Japanese rule of Taiwan in the so-called Miaoli Incident. He was executed after the uprising failed.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1990, is born.
1923: Shimon Peres, Israeli prime minister from 1984 to 1986, is born in Poland.
1937: The Supreme National Defense Council decides at a meeting that the Nationalist government should authorize Chiang Kai-shek as generalisimo to lead the Republic of China armed forces in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: George Herman Ruth, known as "Babe" Ruth, the most famous baseball player of all time, dies in New York City at the age of 53. He broke the Major League home run record in three consecutive seasons (1919-21), and then again in 1927 with a staggering 60 home runs.
1949: Margaret Mitchell, the author of "Gone with the Wind," dies after being hit by a car two days earlier. She was 49.
1950: Taiwan, formerly comprising eight counties and nine cities, is re-divided into 16 counties and five cities.
1960: The new republic of Cyprus comes into being, with Archbishop Makarios as its first president.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Gabon.
1968: The first Poseidon missile is launched.
1974: Wu Kuan-hsiung, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, and Ahmad Sowaidi, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of Qatar, sign a trade cooperation memorandum.
1975: The Republic of China and Nauru sign a civil aviation agreement.
1977: Elvis Presley, the king of rock and roll, dies of heart failure at the age of 42 after collapsing in his mansion in Memphis, Tenn.
1978: Cardinal Yu Pin dies of a heart attack in Rome at the age of 77.
1979: John G. Diefenbaker, Canadian politician who served as prime minister from 1957 to 1963, dies at the age of 84. The Progressive Conservative government he headed lost the 1963 general elections because of opposition to his proposals to build nuclear weapons in Canada.
1990: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warns U.S. President George Bush that thousands of the troops he has sent to the Gulf will return home in coffins.
1996: Leonel Fernandez becomes the 100th president of the Dominican Republic.
1999: Two Republic of China warships, the Hui Yang and the Han Yang, are decommissioned after almost 30 years of service, bringing to 10 the total number of naval vessels decommissioned by the ROC.
2000: Visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation take part in the inauguration of Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia held at the Parliament Building.
2000: ROC Premier Tang Fei unveils a proposal to transform Taiwan into a knowledge-based economy that is on par with those of the world's most advanced nations within ten years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In order to acquire truth, it is necessary to obtain a wide and extensive knowledge of what has been said and done in the world; to critically inquire into it; to carefully ponder over it; to clearly sift it; and to earnestly carry it out."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CRITICIZES MA'S PERFORMANCE SINCE ASSUMING KMT CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) criticized opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Wednesday for causing his party "to degenerate" and the city's development "to regress" over the past year since he assumed the chairmanship.

Making the comment on the first anniversary of Ma's inauguration, DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang said Ma has been busy during the past year taking trips around Taiwan and overseas to pave the way for his presidential bid and has neglected municipal governance, with a series of corruption scandals having been reported in the city.

Tsai noted that several KMT politicians whose campaigns Ma supported, including Hsinchu Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin and Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li, have been charged with corruption since being elected, which he said proves that "the corrupt system of the KMT has remained unchanged."

Tsai said that while Ma has repeatedly promised to deal with the controversies surrounding the party's "ill-gotten" assets, the KMT has sold a total of NT$23 billion (US$703.36 million) worth of its assets under Ma's leadership.

He said that the DPP has begun a signature drive for a proposal to hold a public referendum to reclaim the KMT's "ill-gotten" assets and that it will submit more than 80,000 signatures to the Central Election Commission (CEC) for review by next Wednesday.
He said that after the CEC finishes the review process, the DPP will kick off a second-stage signature drive with the goal of collecting 800,000 signatures by the end of this year.
The DPP hopes that the referendum will be held next year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONWIDE BIRD FLU PREVENTION DRILL TO KICK OFF

TEXT.P: A nationwide bird flu drill will kick off on the outlying island of Matsu Thursday as part of the government's efforts to prevent avian flu outbreaks.

After the Department of Health (DOH) made 2006 a "Bird Flu Prevention Drill Year" earlier this year, the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) announced Wednesday that a series of drills, dubbed the "White Egret, " will take place nationwide beginning Thursday in Matsu.

The drills, to take place around the nation without notification in advance, are aimed at testing the central and local governments' preparedness for dealing with bird flu outbreaks, CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said.
The drills are designed to bolster Taiwan's preparedness against bird flu, which seems to be making a comeback in recent days after having disappeared for nearly half a year, Shih said.

Recent reports of new cases of bird flu include cases in Thailand, Russia and a case in China's Xinjiang Province, in which a person died after being infected with the avian flu virus. The fatality was the 14th among 21 confirmed human bird flu cases in China over the past three years.
The appearance of new cases has raised concerns among World Health Organization specialists that the avian flu virus may have mutated into a new and more lethal strain.
Among other preventive measures, the DOH established the National Influenza Center (NIC) last month to serve as Taiwan's command post against flu epidemics, including potential bird flu outbreaks.

The duties of the NIC include integrating the country's flu virus monitoring efforts, reporting and analyzing data, providing complete epidemic information, monitoring new types of flu virus and related developments, and producing antibodies against indigenous strains of the flu virus.

Shih said that although Taiwan remains free of highly pathogenic avian flu, precautions should still be taken against a possible flu pandemic, adding that the establishment of the NIC is a necessary first step.

Defying repeated warnings from China and South Korea, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi visited Yasukuni Shrine on Tuesday, the 61th anniversary of Japan's surrender in World War II, paying his respects at the Shinto site that honors the nation's 2.5 million war dead and 14 Class-A war criminals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE ARCHITECTS TO PRESENT MICRO CITIES CONCEPT AT VENICE FAIR

TEXT.P: Taiwanese architects will offer introspection on micro cities at the upcoming Venice Architecture Biennial to confront the trend of "The Meta City" -- the main topic of the prestigious architectural exhibition.

The exhibition will take place in Venice, Italy from Sep. 8 to Nov. 9. Taiwanese architects Hsieh Ying-chun, Huang Sheng-yuan and Liu Kuo-chang will present their works in an exhibit titled "Micro Cities and Non-Meta Architecture in Taiwan" along with a pair of Nordic studios.

The meta-city -- defined as a city with a population of over 5 million people -- is the contemporary trend, said curator Roan Ching-yueh. However, the Taiwan architects want to reflect at the exhibition on the price our environment has paid for this trend and on how conventional structures, including culture, society, morality and religion, are losing out in "the global giant system."

"This is where the concept of the micro city comes from, " Roan said, explaining that "a micro city is a small, self-sufficient city with a complete cycle of food, energy, waste and information. It is able to face the individual needs of its residents."
"Such a city can also co-exist inside or outside any mega-city, " he added.

Taiwan will also host an East Asia forum in Palazzo delle Prigioni, where the Taiwanese design will be displayed, discussing the global impact of emerging East Asian cities. Forum participants will include architects from Taiwan, Korea, Singapore and China.
The architecture section of the Venice Biennale, which includes art, cinema, music dance and theater categories, was established in 1980.

Moscow, Aug.16 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Mazeikiu Pipeline's Future in Doubt
Russia could be forced to close down the pipeline that feeds the Mazeikiu refinery in Lithuania because it is more than 40 years old and constructed with banned metals, said Semyon Vainshtok, the president of pipeline monopoly Transneft. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: PART OF PRESIDENT'S STATE AFFAIRS FUND USED BY VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has been giving NT$150,000 to Vice President Annette Lu every month from his special "state affairs fund, " the use of which has become a hot topic and which is being investigated by the prosecution, officials of the public affairs department of the Presidential Office said Wednesday.

The department denied a United Daily News report that the vice president has been given NT$4 million per year from the president's "state affairs" budget and claimed that the correct figure is NT$1.8 million (US$55,000).
The prosecution is investigating alleged irregularities surrounding the accounting reports on the special fund budgeted for the president's discretionary use.

Presidential staff have been found to have used fake invoices to claim "state affairs" expenses, invoices that are said to have originated from a businesswoman being probed for her role in the scandal.

Australia-based businesswoman Lee Hui-fei was summoned as a witness for the second time Wednesday for further questioning and possible cross-examination, along with her cousin Lee Pi-chun, who runs a pharmaceutical company and is a friend of first lady Wu Shu-jen.
A prosecution document providing security protection for Lee Hui-fen said she was involved in a "corruption and forgery" case.

Her cousin, a suspect in the case, told investigators she had given Lee Hui-fen's invoices to "other people" but claimed she had no idea why the invoices ended up in the Presidential Office's accounting books.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREYING OF SOCIETY GIVES RISE TO NEW JOB OPPORTUNITIES

TEXT.P: As the greying of Taiwan society has boosted the market demand for care-giving services, health institutions and retirement financial planning services, job opportunities in these fields are also increasing, an online employment service provider said Wednesday.

According to statistics from the Ministry of the Interior, the number of elderly people accounts for 9.83 percent of Taiwan's population at present and is expected to continue to expand, with at least one in every five people in Taiwan expected to be a senior citizen 20 years from now.
While more than 650,000 elderly people in Taiwan require long-term care in 2006, there is a severe shortage of caregivers in the country.

Chiu Wen-jen, marketing director of the 104 Job Bank, noted that a lot of local families have problems hiring cheap foreign caregivers for sick and elderly family members since the government tightened the hiring requirements, although of course they are still free to hire local caregivers.
Chiu said there is a shortfall of at least 5,000 caregivers in the Taiwan market and some institutions offer pay of between NT$40,000 and NT$60,000 to qualified candidates.

Also, as many elderly people living alone or those with chronic diseases are being sent to health institutions, there is a demand for a total of more than 4,000 licensed nursing workers by these institutions, Chiu said.

In term of retirement financial planning, Chiu said local insurance and financial companies have launched various finance management programs to help people plan their retirements, with approximately 7,000 job openings for financial advisers available.
Meanwhile, a number of companies providing services to help retirees fulfill their dreams and travel plans are also looking for sales agents to promote the services, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO LEVY HEAVY PUNISHMENTS ON BROKERING OFFSHORE ORGAN TRANSPLANTS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) has decided to levy heavy punishments on doctors or medical personnel who broker offshore human organ transplants, a DOH spokesman said Wednesday.

Doctors and medical personnel who are found to have engaged in brokering cross-border organ transplants for patients, no matter whether they just act as a go-between or personally take patients to receive operations overseas, will be punished by the DOH in line with a set of newly revised regulations, the spokesman said, adding that serious offenders could have their licenses revoked.

The DOH hopes to wipe out such malpractice and to help maintain medical ethics in view of a growing number of Taiwan patients undergoing organ transplants overseas -- mostly in China and the United States, the spokesman said, noting that last year alone, 450 Taiwan patients headed for China to undergo an organ transplant.

Of the 450 patients, 118 were questioned, with 69 of them admitting that they were brokered through a doctor, while 49 said they were introduced by friends. Another three gained access through brokers.

According to relevant statistics, about 6,900 Taiwan patients were waiting for a healthy organ to save their lives as of the end of July, with a vast majority of 6,178 awaiting a kidney, followed by those waiting for a heart or lung.

Most of the Taiwan patients received their transplants in Beijing and Tianjin in China's Hebei Province as well as in Guangdong Province. Each human organ transplant operation in China costs from NT$300,000 to NT$1.2 million.

La Repubblica: 3,500 UN peacekeeping force in Lebanon in 15 days.
The United Nations expected that the first 3,000 to 3,500 of the proposed 15,000-man peacekeeping force would be deployed in Lebanon in 15 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEMALE MAINLAND CHINESE TAIWANESE WRITING GROUP TO KICK OFF

TEXT.P: The second female mainland Chinese Taiwanese writing class organized by the Association of Mainlander Taiwanese will kick off in September in five community universities around the country, according to its organizers.

The class, which trains and encourages female mainland Chinese to write about their experiences of relocating from China to Taiwan after 1945 will be opened simultaneously at the community universities in the cities of Taipei, Yunghe in Taipei County, Tainan and Kaohsiung.
Female mainland Chinese who are interested in recounting their personal experiences are invited to enroll in the free classes, organizers said.

Meanwhile, the Association of Mainlander Taiwanese said a book consisting of 30 stories written by the 19 students of the first class held at the Yunghe Community University will be published Aug. 30.

The association said the stories in the book will offer glimpses into the chaotic time when the country was engaged in a fierce civil war with the Chinese Communist Party and are sure to contradict "the stereotype of mainland Chinese."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO FURTHER CLARIFY PARTY ASSETS AUG. 23

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that he will explain Aug. 23 how the party has handled its assets, which its rivals claim are "ill-gotten" properties, acquired at a time of authoritarian one-party rule when the KMT equalled the state.

Ma made the remarks in response to reports that a group is planning to initiate a nationwide referendum to have the KMT return its assets to national coffers and that the group has also questioned why the assets, valued at around NT$150 billion (US$4.58 billion) under the leadership of former Chairman Lien Chan between 2000 and 2005, have diminished precipitously to some NT$5 billion since Ma took the helm last year.

Discounting the reports as "the result of misunderstanding, " Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, said that is why he will explain following an Aug. 23 KMT Central Standing Committee meeting how the party has handled the party assets, including investment profits and losses.

Ma, who was elected chairman in July last year, has asked his staff to tackle the controversy over the party's assets "as soon as possible " and so the party is ready to look at the issue one year after he became party leader.

Ma's proposed "explanation" will come on the heels of a report issued by the KMT earlier this month. The report, prepared by the party's Deputy Secretary-General Chang Che-chen and lawyer Lee Yung-jan, describes how the assets were managed when Chiang Kai-shek, Chiang Ching-kuo, Lee Teng-hui, Lien Chan and Ma Ying-jeou were at the helm of the party.

The compilation of the report was aimed at baring all of the KMT assets in an open, transparent and comprehensive manner and not trying to "shun or hide" any questions, according to KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRIVE TO HOST 2011 WORLD DESIGN CONFERENCE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang exhorted the country Wednesday to strive to win the right to host the world design conference authorized by the International Council of Societies of Industrial Design (ICSID) in 2011.

Hosting the conference would help raise Taiwan's design standards and capabilities as well as improve the country's image in the international community, Su said during a meeting at the Industrial Development Bureau.

Su asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs to work with the Government Information Office and other relevant government agencies to coordinate resources from the official, industrial, academic and research sectors for the purpose of winning the right to sponsor the 2011 ICSID meeting.
Meanwhile, the premier also gave thumbs up to the progress of the government authorized Designed in Taiwan (DIT) project.

The DIT project -- a four-year, NT$800 million (US$24.46 million) program that began last year -- has yielded fruit this year in either efforts to win prizes in international design competitions, or to upgrade industrial design ability and capability and promote the public's recognition of industrial design, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY'S EMERALD EARRINGS 'BORROWED FROM FRIENDS': CONTROL YUAN

TEXT.P: The distinctive emerald earrings that first lady Wu Shu-jen wore at her son's wedding were "borrowed from friends, " according to a "corrected version" of the presidential couple's report to the Control Yuan.
But Wu and President Chen Shui-bian did not disclose who loaned her the earrings, other than describing them as borrowed from "friends and relatives, " a Control Yuan official said Wednesday.

Hsieh Yu-nan, director of the Control Yuan's department in charge of public functionaries' private assets reporting, pointed out that his department has sent official requests three times to the Presidential Office for more information about the "friends and relatives."

According to law, the president must explain who are the real owners of the earrings within 15 days -- by Aug. 25. However, Hsieh admitted that if he continues to refuse to do so, "we don't have any law based on which we can fine him."

The latest report filed by the presidential couple regarding their jewelry shows that they have reported 15 items with a total worth of NT$3.73 million (US$114,000) , five which were gifts from Wu's mother and old friends, the prices of which are not known but which are estimated to be worth less than NT$200,000 each -- the legal bar for reporting to the Control Yuan.
If an individual item is worth less than NT$200,000, it need not be included in the report, according to the law governing the registration of private assets with the Control Yuan.

The 10 items that they are legally required to register with the Control Yuan are: two watches worth NT$500,000; a diamond watch worth NT$400,000; diamond earrings valued at NT$800,000; a diamond bracelet worth NT$175,000; a pearl necklace worth NT$500,000; pearl earrings worth NT$200,000; a pearl ring worth NT$150,000, a set of gold/pearl jewelry worth NT$400,000; earrings of uncut emeralds worth NT$400,000 and an emerald ring worth NT$200,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET HOPES TO GET TO BOTTOM OF NOISE-CONTROL SCAM SOON: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan hopes prosecutors will get to the bottom of a noise control scam at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport as soon as possible, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Wednesday.

Cheng made the remarks one day after Taoyuan Prosecutors Office questioned Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng and other aviation officials over a noise-control project in which villagers living under the flight paths were provided with subsidies for installing soundproof glass and air conditioners, even though they were scheduled to be relocated away from the airport. Chang and other officials are suspected of lining their own pockets from the scam.
Chang was released on NT$1 million (US$30,480) bail, while CAA Secretary-General Wang Teh-he and CKS Air Terminal Director Wei Sheng-chi were each released on NT$500,000 bail.
The prosecutors also suspect that the decision-making process in awarding the subsidies was flawed.
Chang for his part denied any wrongdoing or profiteering but said the execution and verification process indeed "had problems."

He noted that the air terminals started to levy noise control fees on airlines in 1996, and it was established in 2001 that the villagers would not get compensation directly but would instead be subsidized for the cost of installing the soundproof windows and air conditioners.
Chang noted that after the subsidy program began in 2002, it was established that residents in one village would be relocated, but they still demanded the subsidy.

As the airport could not distribute them directly, and it was a waste to install soundproof windows in houses that would soon be demolished, the airport agreed to subsidize the villagers for air conditioners if they presented photos of the installed air conditioners.
However, the villagers used various fraudulent means to obtain the subsidies without actually buying air conditioners.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICES INDUSTRY ENGINE OF TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH: CEPD

TEXT.P: Combining the services industry with the information technology sector will be a major policy of the government to boost the development of the services industry, which is a major engine for the country's economic growth, the Council for Economic Planning and Development said Wednesday.

CEPD officials noted that trade in services has become an important part of the international industrial division of labor since the 1990s, with World Trade Organization statistics showing that global trade in services registered an average growth rate of 7.6 percent between 1981 and 2005, which was higher than the 6.8 percent for merchandise trade.

In 2005, global trade in services contributed 22 percent to the growth of world trade, which indicates that trade in services is playing an increasingly important role in world trade, the officials said.
Taiwan's trade in services accounted for 1.2 percent of the world's total in 2005, while Taiwan's merchandise trade accounted for 1.8 percent of the world's total, they went on.
Between 1996 and 2005, Taiwan's trade in services posted an average growth rate of only 4.2 percent, which was lower than the 5.8 percent registered by the merchandise trade, they said.

The officials added that as the services industry contributed as high as 73.56 percent to Taiwan's gross domestic product and is a major engine for the country's economic growth, the government will try to expand trade in services by combining the services industry with information and communications technology in an effort to make inroads into the international market.

In light of the potential of the information software industry, the green industry, the sport and leisure industry, the tourism industry and the culture and creativity industry, Taiwan should work out a strategy to integrate their development, they said.

In addition, the government should establish a high-quality and friendly travel environment to attract more foreign tourists to Taiwan to increase the country's income from trade in services, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS HONORED FOR EFFORTS TO GET OUT OF POVERTY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou encouraged poor young people to study hard to raise themselves out of poverty Wednesday while attending a ceremony in which he presented certificates to students from low income families in recognition of their efforts in this regard.

Ma issued the call while taking part in a ceremony held by the municipal Department of Social Welfare and the Taipei Fubon Bank Charity Foundation, which have been jointly sponsoring a three-year program to help students from underprivileged families finish their studies and lead better lives through working part-time jobs and saving money.

Ma presented certificates to 70 students who took part in the program over the past three years, hailing their endurance and courage in overcoming great difficulties and calling them good models of self-respect and independence.
According to Ma, the three-year program is the first of its kind in Taiwan and it has been quite successful.

Of the 70 students, eight have been admitted to graduate schools, and 47 have entered universities, respectively, while 14 have got jobs, department officials said, noting that 28 of the 70 families have managed to lose the status of low-income families -- a success rate of 40 percent, according to department statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLOWING 0.18 MICRON PROCESS TO GO TO CHINA NOT BAD FOR TAIWAN: TSMC

TEXT.P: Allowing 0.18 micron process technology to go to China will not be detrimental to Taiwan's high technology industry but will instead help sharpen Taiwan companies' competitiveness, the founder and chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) claimed Wednesday.

Morris Chang, who has been nicknamed the founding father of Taiwan's semiconductor industry, claimed that Taiwan's export of 0.18 micron process technology to China will not backfire as some people have predicted, because it is now a mature technology and Chinese manufacturers have for long used it with proven high yields.

In a speech delivered to a gathering of industrial leaders on the prospects of Taiwan's hi-tech development, Chang said that when Taiwan hi-tech companies decide to invest in China, they must first acquire permission from the Republic of China government and then permission from the U.S. Department of Commerce if their production equipment and technologies originate from the United States.

Chang said Taiwan's restrictions are even stricter than those imposed by the U.S. government and he suggested that Taiwan further relax its restrictions, at least restrictions on technologies that are already fully developed and commonly used.
Chang claimed that TSMC relocating part of its production lines to China was "not for the purpose of cutting costs, but to seek added value."

However, he admitted that if Taiwan were to allow the 0.18 micron process technology to be exported to China, it would help TSMC win a larger market share in China, which is currently "the world's factory."
He said TSMC, one of the biggest IC chip foundries in the world, is expected to post a 20 percent growth in its overall transactions this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH HUMAN RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT CONFERENCE TO OPEN AUG. 17

TEXT.P: The National Youth Commission (NYC) and the Council of Labor Affairs will hold a human resources development conference Thursday focusing on the youth population, according to officials.
NYC officials said the conference will be aimed at mapping out a policy that meets the needs of young people and enhances youth employment.

They noted that since the 1990s, employability has become an important issue in the youth policy of developed countries and that enhancing the employability of college graduates has also become a major driver of education reforms in Europe and the United States.

They said the themes addressed by the conference will include enhancing youth employability and entrepreneurship, promoting equal employment opportunities for young people and increasing job creation targeting the youth population.

In addition to government officials, representatives of businesses and non-profit organizations, presidents of universities and colleges and academics, representatives of the youth demographic aged between 18 and 30 will also take part in the conference, the officials said.
