DOC.TEXT:
The Times:
Terror 'mastermind' faces swift extradition
Britain is seeking the urgent extradition of Rashid Rauf, named by Pakistan as the "key planner" of the alleged terrorist plot to blow up transatlantic airliners in mid-flight.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.007 to close at NT$32.749.
A total of US$709 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.756 and fluctuated between NT$32.756 and NT$32.69.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY TO STEP UP CARE OF FAMILIES WITH FOREIGN SPOUSES

TEXT.P: The Nantou county government convened a meeting Wednesday to discuss how to step up care of families with foreign spouses, noting that there is one foreign spouse in every 20 households in the central Taiwan county.

Officials in charge of social, police and civil service affairs attended the meeting to exchange their experiences in the hope of establishing a more comprehensive network to provide services to the foreign spouses.

Hsiung Chun-ping, director of the Department of Social Affairs, said the number of Chinese and foreign spouses has exceeded 7,000, accounting for 1.3 percent of the county's total population. In terms of families, those with foreign spouses account for 5 percent of total households.
This ratio is bound to affect the fabric of the next generation in Nantou, said Hsiung.

He added that Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-ching attaches great importance to the disadvantaged groups. To take better care of the new arrivals, the county has established a service center so as to mitigate the impact of cultural differences and help them in their daily lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH COURT REFUSES TO FREE INDICTED SENIOR PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court overruled Wednesday an appeal by President Chen Shui-bian's former deputy secretary- general to be freed from detention.
Chen Che-nan, who has been detained since April 4, claimed that he should no longer be kept in custody since the court has obtained testimony against him from a businessman.
But the court ruled that more investigations are needed to gather the facts from him and other witnesses regarding fraud and insider trading charges against him.

Since Chen has already been found to have been in contact with witnesses over his case, the court decided to deny his request for release to minimize the likelihood that he will collaborate with others to destroy evidence against him.
Chen has been indicted on charges of accepting bribes from Liang Po-hsun, a bankrupt businessman and an economic criminal, to help Liang settle embezzlement charges.
The prosecution has requested an eight-year sentence for Chen for his suspected graft and corruption offenses.

He has also been charged with violating the Stock Exchange Law for suspected insider trading while he served as a senior official at the Presidential Office, an offense that the prosecution said deserves another four years in jail.
In Kaohsiung, Chen stands accused of taking NT$94,700 (US$2,900) in illicit profits from a private contractor involved in the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. scandal.
Chen's involvement in these and other scandals has tainted the president's image and damaged his reputation, as has his son-in-law Chao Chien-ming's indictment on insider trading charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPEAL COURT FINDS EX-PRESIDENT GUILTY OF SLANDER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court upheld Wednesday a guilty ruling against former President Lee Teng-hui for slandering opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.

Although the court's finding that Lee should be held responsible for defaming Soong is similar to that of a lower court, it cut the damages Lee should pay to Soong from NT$10 million (US$305,469) as ordered by the lower court to NT$2 million.
The court also ordered Lee to run an apology in three major newspapers for one day rather than in nine newspapers for three days in a row as prescribed in the lower court's judgment of Nov. 18, 2005.

The case stemmed for Lee's remarks April 24, 2004 when he suggested in a public speech that Soong was playing mahjong with friends while his followers were fighting the police in an April 10 protest against President Chen Shui-bian's re-election.
Angered by Lee's remarks, Soong brought a lawsuit against Lee, demanding compensation for damage to his reputation and an apology in newspapers.
Lee's attorneys offered to settle the dispute out of court with Soong after Lee lost the case in the first trial, but were rejected by Soong.
The Taiwan Hight Court's ruling is subject to further appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S TOP SUMO WRESTLERS TO STAGE EXHIBITION COMPETITION IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A 100-strong delegation of the Japan Sumo Association, including 42 top-ranked professional sumo wrestlers, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Thursday for a five-day visit.
The sumo wrestlers will stage exhibition matches Aug. 19-20 in the Taipei Arena.
This will be the first visit to Taiwan by a Japanese sumo wrestling team since the end of World War II.

Conspicuous among the wrestlers will be Asashoryu Akinori, the first sumo wrestler from Mongolia to reach the rank of yokozuna -- the highest sumo rank. As of 2006, he is also the only active yokozuna.
Another well-known wrestler of Mongolian origin is Hakuho Sho, who is the sixth foreign-born wrestler to reach the rank of ozeki, the champion rank immediately below yokozuna.

The sumo exhibition competition in Taipei is sponsored by Asia Plus Broadcasting, a cable TV network, which invited a group of sumo wrestlers from Japan to tour Taiwan in mid-June and promote the August event.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Hezbollah Leads Work to Rebuild, Gaining Stature
As stunned Lebanese returned Tuesday over broken roads to shattered apartments in the south, it increasingly seemed that the beneficiary of the destruction was most likely to be Hezbollah. In addition to its hard-won reputation as the only Arab force that fought Israel to a standstill, Hezbollah is already dominating the efforts to rebuild with a torrent of money from oil-rich Iran. Hezbollah's reputation as an efficient grass-roots social service network was in evidence everywhere.
Wall Street Journal: Fractured Land, Vast Rebuilding Job Looms in Lebanon; It, Too, Is Political
An estimated 35,000 homes and business places have been destroyed in Lebanon by fighting and Israeli bombs. Perhaps a quarter of the country's four million residents were in temporary housing when the cease-fire took hold Monday. Some 400 miles of Lebanese roadway have been destroyed, along with about 150 bridges and interchanges - - one of every four in the country. Now, as residents pour back into Lebanon's ravaged south, hundreds of thousands will need food, water and shelter in the coming weeks. And wrapped in the reconstruction challenge is a critical struggle for Lebanon's weak government: seizing the political initiative from a Hezbollah energized by its battlefield performance against Israel. "The postwar period...is the real war," says Jihad Azour, Lebanon's finance minister. The rebuilding of Lebanon, and who gets credit for it, are part of a larger battle for influence between the central government and Hezbollah.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX SURGES TO ONE-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose across the board Wednesday following a strong rally on Wall Street overnight.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, moved up 81.5 points to close at 6,696.63, its highest closing level since July 4 when it ended at 6,734.51.

The bourse opened at 6,686.23 and reached a high of 6,699.83 at one point, but dropped a bit before the end of the session. A total of 3.83 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$108.23 billion (US$3.31 billion).
Gainers outnumbered losers 735 to 272, with 136 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER UNEXPLODED BOMB BOUND ON MRT CONSTRUCTION SITE

TEXT.P: Workers on a construction site of the Neihu Line of Taipei's MRT system found another unexploded bomb Wednesday, the second one in a week.
Police said workers found the giant bomb while digging a passageway between the Sungshan domestic airport and the Sungshan MRT station, prompting police to seal off the area immediately.

A member of the bomb squad said the bomb could have been dropped by a U.S. plane during World War II and had probably been buried for more than 50 years, given the corrosion of the surface and the fuse. There was no danger of the bomb exploding accidentally, he added.
The location of the 500-pound bomb was only a dozen meters from the one that was found last Friday. Construction workers first dug out a one-meter Word War II-era U.S. bomb in July 2004.
Aviation police pointed out that the location of Sungshan Airport was an airfield during the Japanese colonial era and could very well have been a target of U.S. bombing during the war.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 85 points to close at 6,692, with 15,698 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September grew 81 points to finish at 6,671, with 26,098 contracts traded, while December futures rose 87 points to end at 6,675, with 40 contract transactions.
March futures moved up 91 points to close at 6,678, with five contract transactions, while June futures increased 75 points to end at 6,660, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,607 for August, 6,590 for September, 6,588 for December, 6,687 for March and 6,585 for June.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher. August TE futures surged 4.15 points to close at 290.3, with 2,767 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 4.3 points to finish at 289.05, with 4,069 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

August TF futures moved up 6.8 points to close at 921.8, with 1,241 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures surged 9.2 points to finish at 921.2, with 2,617 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE COMPANY KEEN ON BOT PROJECT FOR SENIOR COMMUNITY

TEXT.P: A Japanese company has expressed keen interest in a build-operate-transfer (BOT) project for a community for senior citizens in Pinglin, Hualien County, the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior said Wednesday.

Officials said that if all goes well, the project will set a good example for providing an excellent living environment for the elderly. It will also introduce billions of dollars and create around 300 jobs, as well as promoting the full use of local land and the development of related industries.

The officials noted that with the graying of the Taiwanese population, the ratio of Taiwan elderly -- defined as those aged over 65 -- has continued to rise. The ratio of the elderly was 7 percent of the total population in 1993, but it had increased to 9.87 percent as of the end of last month.
In view of the need for communities for the elderly, the administration promoted the BOT project in Pinglin and invited bidders, although during its first attempt in March 2005 attracted no bidders.
However, after active promotion of its proximity to a noted farm, hospital and scenic spots, several domestic and overseas enterprises have expressed interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE SHARPENING CHINESE TEACHING SKILLS AT LOCAL COLLEGE

TEXT.P: A group of 15 Chinese-language teachers from Vietnam arrived at the Wen Tzao Ursuline College of Modern Languages in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung Wednesday to take part in a two-week training course to sharpen their teaching skills.
The group, mainly composed of Chinese-language teachers from the Normal University in Ho Chi Minh City, were warmly greeted by Wen Tzao President Lee Wen-ruey and Chinese language center staff.

Lee said that he was deeply touched by the Vietnamese teachers' high spirits and their mastery of Chinese and added that he is confident they will reap a handsome harvest by the time they end their studies at the end of the month.

In addition to attending Chinese language classes at the college, the Vietnamese teachers will also visit various tourist spots around Taiwan to familiarize themselves with local customs and the everyday lives of the people.

Giap Van Guong, head of the Chinese literature department at Ho Chi Minh Normal University, who led the group to Taiwan, expressed the hope in Chinese that they can learn more about teaching Chinese and gain an understanding of the language's development in Taiwan.

According to Giap, Chinese is the second most popular foreign language in Vietnam only after English. Currently, there are more than 1,000 students specializing in Chinese at the university, he said, explaining that Chinese language ability has become a plus for job seekers in Vietnam's employment market.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN ASKS FORMER CHAIRMAN FOR 'SELF-RESTRAINT'

TEXT.P: Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), urged the party's former Chairman Shih Ming-teh Wednesday to show "self-restraint" in his push to oust President Chen Shui-bian.
Yu made the appeal after an estimated 400,000 people donated NT$100 each to Shih's campaign of "one million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian," a mere three days after its launch.

The public response is in defiance of the Ministry of the Interior's warning that the "political" donations are illegal, and bolster the efforts of Shih, who claimed the public contributions were "registration and authorization fees" for his planned sit-ins.

Yu warned the campaign would create a "blue-green" standoff and scuttle government operations, referring to the political confrontation between the ruling "pan-green camp" and the opposition "pan-blue alliance."

He called on the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party to join forces with the ruling party in initiating a "new sunshine political movement" and to legislate laws ensuring clean politics are carried out in the country.
He said forcing the president to step down is not a priority for the country, and that people should not view the DPP based only on the criteria of whether the president would step down or not.
"There are many more things we can do to help the president do what he needs to accomplish during the remainder of his term in office," he added.
Turning to Shih's anti-president drive, Yu said some DPP lawmakers -- such as Wang Hsing-nan -- have expressed an interest in organizing "counter-Shih" forces.
Some DPP senior executives, including Legislator Wu Ping-jui and Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, were also suggesting the party launch a fund-raising campaign in support of the president.
These radical "countermeasure" proposals were turned down because Yu said he would not like to further stimulate Shih at this moment.
"Rather, more efforts should be made to start the new sunshine political movement," he added.
He blamed the opposition KMT for not being keen on a sunshine law or setting up an anti-corruption agency which, he claimed, would have gone a long way in establishing clean politics in this country.
Because of the legislature's failure to pass relevant laws on clean politics and anti-corruption institutions, society has paid a huge cost, Yu said.

He called on Shih and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou not to "over-simplify" the issue by stirring up another round of "blue-green" confrontation, but instead to "rise above political differences and build an effective system" that benefits the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PALAU DIPLOMATIC TIES NORMAL: MOFA

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Palau remain normal and President Chen Shui-bian is still planning to visit the South Pacific diplomatic ally early next month, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said Wednesday.
Lu's remarks came after local media speculated earlier the same day that Chen's planned visit to Palau might be aborted.

Stressing that Taiwan-Palau diplomatic relations remain "business as usual, " Lu said that Palau President Tommy Esang Remengesau Jr. already sent an invitation to Chen Aug. 14, inviting him to take part in the first summit between the Republic of China and six South Pacific nations.
"There aren't any problems in bilateral Taiwan-Palau ties, " he assured.

Lu also refuted a local media report that Taiwan-Naura diplomatic links might be broken off, calling it "sheer speculation" given that he has twice spoken by telephone with Ambassador Yu King-yung in Naura, who pledged that two-way ties remain sound.
Chen also plans to include Naura in his early September tour of the South Pacific, but it is still in the pipeline, Lu said.

But Lu was reluctant to answer the question of how many of the Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific would participate in the summit, saying only that "he could not reveal anything in this regard due to a tacit agreement."
The MOFA has been closely observing China's moves aimed at luring away Taiwan's diplomatic partners in the region," he said.

Chen's projected diplomatic tour to the two South Pacific nations has come under strong attack from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), which have criticized the president for trying to divert public attention at a time when he and members of the first family are being dogged by a series of high-profile corruption allegations.
But the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the "pan-green camp" with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that it supports Chen's plan to visit Palau and Naura.

TSU legislative caucus whip Ho Ming-hao urged the KMT and PFP to stop speculating about Chen's motives behind his plan to go abroad, as the president truly wants to do something to improve Taiwan's foreign relations -- particularly after diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Chad were broken recently due to Beijing's meddling.
"Taiwan must not engage any further in 'checkbook diplomacy' in its diplomatic battle against China and the president deserves our encouragement for trying to contribute something," he said.
He also opined that Chen does not need to step down from the presidency because no concrete evidence has shown his involvement in any of the corruption scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDY SHOWS CHILDREN OF TAIWAN'S FOREIGN BRIDES ARE HEALTHIER

TEXT.P: Children born to foreign mothers who are married to Taiwanese are generally healthier then children of native Taiwanese mothers, according to a study by National Cheng Kung University Hospital.
Lin Hsiu-chuan, a pediatrician at the hospital's center for genetics, analyzed data for 230,000 births by foreign brides in Taiwan between 1998 and 2003.
She found that only 5.8 percent of newborns of foreign mothers weighed less than 2,500 grams, while 7 percent of Taiwanese mothers gave birth to newborns with a low birth weight.

The study also found that newborns of foreign mothers -- mostly from southeast Asian countries, including Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, Cambodia and Thailand -- also had a lower death rate than children of Taiwanese mothers, although the two groups were comparable in terms of birth defects.

In her analysis, Lin said the reason why children of foreign mothers are generally healthier may be attributed to the fact that their husbands underwent a strict screening process and selected only young and healthy women as their spouses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC SUPPORT EXCEEDS FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN'S EXPECTATIONS

TEXT.P: Almost half a million people have donated NT$45.79 million (US$1.4 million) to former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh's campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian, a level of support that Shih said Wednesday has gone far beyond his expectations.

He had estimated that it would take nearly a month before one million people signed up and contributed NT$100 toward his populist campaign, which he said signifies "water can float a boat and sink it, too."

He said he might have to skip a plan to tour the countryside to solicit support so he can begin a sit-in early, which he vowed "would not be a nine-to-five job" as he has determined to carry on day and night until he achieves his purpose -- the resignation of President Chen.
Shih called on the nation's religious workers -- monks, nuns, priests, fathers and sisters -- to come forward and act as security personnel during the sit-in.
He noted that campaign organizers have obtained permission to use Ketagalan Boulevard for a mass sit-in from Aug. 23 to Sept. 14 with the exception of Sept. 8-9 and Sept. 13.
Two other groups have secured the right to use the road on those three days and Shih said he would move elsewhere to continue his campaign, without elaborating on the alternative site.

Shih stressed he would not heed the legal ban on public gatherings after 10: 00 p.m. -- a law that would be enforced by the Taipei City government led by Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
"We won't disperse. We will move to other places to continue our sit-in, 24 hours a day, day after day, until we have achieved our purpose," he claimed.

He reminded the ruling and opposition politicians that the law on marches and assemblies was a "violent law" left over from the KMT's authoritarian rule, and that if the Chen administration dares to use it to drive rally participants out, "they should remember what happened to the KMT."

Shih said he has not contacted Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh or former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung over his current campaign, which he said aims to "appeal directly to the people to exercise their own power."
Shih is using two bank accounts and one postal account under his name to collect public donations.

According to the post office, more than 87,000 remittances were made to his campaign account Tuesday, compared to 50,000-odd deposits Monday. All told, the postal account has received more than NT$20 million in support of Shih's campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP TO SEEK AID FROM NYC MAYOR'S ANTI-SMOKING DONATION

TEXT.P: The John Tung Foundation, Taiwan's largest anti-smoking advocacy group, said Wednesday it will seek aid from billionaire New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg to help finance an Asia-Pacific anti-smoking conference to be held in Taipei next year.

The foundation made the statement after Bloomberg, a former smoker, announced a day earlier that he will pour US$125 million of his own money into a worldwide campaign against smoking, a cause he said is largely neglected by philanthropists.

Bloomberg's fortune is estimated at US$5.1 billion, making him the 40th richest American and 112th in the world, according to Forbes magazine. He built his wealth after founding the financial information company that bears his name, and he gives away millions of dollars each year to benefit medical research, arts groups and education, among other causes.

Lin Ching-li, a division chief at the John Tung Foundation, said the foundation had approached three world-renowned charitable organizations, including the Rockefeller Foundation, to ask them to help finance an annual conference of the Asia-Pacific Association for the Control of Tobacco to be hosted by the foundation in Taipei from Oct. 17-20, 2007. However, all of them have rejected the foundation's application.
"Bloomberg's latest announcement is a welcome fillip to us. We'll apply for financial aid from the New York mayor's foundation," Lin said.
According to Lin, 5 million people around the world die from smoking-induced diseases every year, outnumbering deaths from accidents, suicide or cancers.

Taiwan now has about 4.9 million smokers and an estimated 19,000 people die from smoking-related diseases or second-hand smoking each year, Lin said, adding that the annual medical and economic expenses from those diseases far exceed NT$50 billion.
Lin lamented that Taiwan lags behind many other countries in its campaign to ban smoking in all public places.

About 400 to 600 public health and anti-smoking advocacy groups from around the world are expected to send representatives to the 2007 Asia-Pacific conference on tobacco and health issues, Lin said, adding that the foundation is raising funds for the conference through various channels.

Bloomberg, who quit smoking about 30 years ago, typically writes his charitable checks without announcing he is doing so, but he made a special effort to publicize his anti-smoking donation, which will be spread among several established organizations that have not yet been selected.

"Unless we take urgent action, this century a billion people will die from smoking," Bloomberg said Tuesday. "It is one of the world's biggest killers, and it has sadly been overlooked by the philanthropic community."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHOU SHIH-YUAN PAYS TRIBUTE TO LATE GRANDFATHER THROUGH BASKETBALL

TEXT.P: Grief-stricken over his grandfather's death last week, Taiwanese basketball player Chou Shih-yuan said his performance in an Asia Professional Basketball (APB) tournament game Wednesday night was in tribute to his grandfather.

The Taiwanese national team lost the opening game of the second round 99-93 to the Perth Wildcats, but it was Chou's four three-pointers in the third quarter that ignited a furious rally that almost helped the home team pull off a come-from-behind win.
Chou was raised by his grandparents until his junior high school graduation in the southern city of Kaohsiung. Chou's father worked in another city at the time and was seldom at home.
For almost ten years, his grandparents were his only family, said Chou, who learned of his grandfather's death via a cellphone text message after a team practice session last week.
"Later, he was bedridden with diabetes and lost most of his vision, but he listened to almost every one of my basketball games on television. He always wanted to know if I played well," Chou said.

"I wasn't able to think about him much while I was on the court today. But I am glad I had a good game and did not disappoint him," said Chou, who scored 16 points in 22 minutes and had his best game in the tournament so far.
Chou will miss the next two games as he will be back in Kaohsiung for the funeral.

The five-team APB tournament invited four basketball clubs from Japan, Korea, Australia and the Philippines. The tournament enters the single round-robin second round Wednesday and concluded on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTION TO TOPPLE CABINET SHOULD BE RECONSIDERED: PFP LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) should reassess whether it is necessary to introduce a motion in the next legislative session to topple the Cabinet through a no-confidence vote, a PFP lawmaker said Wednesday.

Legislator Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy research center, told reporters that when PFP Chairman James Soong first announced the PFP would seek to topple the Cabinet, he did it against a background of Premier Su Tseng-chang voicing support for President Chen Shui-bian after a legislative motion to recall Chen failed in late June.
The recall motion was introduced because the president had been dogged by a series of corruption scandals implicating his family members and senior officials at the Presidential Office.

Chang said, however, that the relationship between the premier and president seems to have deteriorated recently because in a partial reshuffle, Su replaced several Cabinet members who were considered Chen's proteges.
"The situation is fluid. The PFP must now take into consideration the tension between the president and the premier, along with other political factors," Chang said.
"If we succeed in toppling the Cabinet, we may actually be doing a service for President Chen by causing the premier to be replaced," he explained.

Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang, convener of the PFP's legislative caucus, said although the domestic political situation seems unpredictable, the PFP must still be prepared in case new developments warrant a no-confidence vote on the premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL OFFENSES INVOLVING CHINESE CITIZENS ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: The number of illegal offenses committed by Chinese visitors has risen since the Taiwan's government opened its doors wider to Chinese tourists last year, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) reported Wednesday.

According to MOJ tallies, Chinese citizens made 130,000 to 150,000 visits to Taiwan annually between 2001 and 2004. In 2005, that number increased to 170,000 as Taiwan allowed in more Chinese tourists as part of efforts to step up civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Between 2001 and 2005, a total of 9,456 Chinese citizens were caught entering Taiwan illegally, with the annual number hitting a record of more than 3,000 in 2003.
Over the past five years, more than 3,000 Chinese citizens have been convicted of various offenses, accounting for 0.5 percent of total convictions during the period.
The Chinese offenders were mainly convicted of document forgery in marriages of convenience or violating the national security law due to illegal entry, according to MOJ tallies.

As of the end of July, 55 Chinese citizens were serving time in Taiwan's prisons, most of whom were convicted for violating Taiwan's national security law. Further, 263 other Chinese were being detained for investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN, U.S. SCHOOLS TO EXCHANGE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Five students from National Kinmen Institute of Technology (NKIT) on the outlying island of Kinmen will travel to the United States in September to study at the University of West Florida (UWF) as part of an exchange program between the two schools, an NKIT spokesman said Wednesday.

It will be the first group of NKIT students to study at the Florida university since the two schools signed a cooperative agreement last November when UWF President John Cavanaugh visited Kinmen, a Taiwan-held defense outpost which lies closer to the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper.

According to the NKIT spokesman, UWF will also send students to study at the Kinmen technology institute under the exchange program to boost mutual academic cooperation and expand their students' vision and perspective.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER HEADS FOR COSTA RICA TO CONTINUE DIPLOMATIC TOUR

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang left for Costa Rica Wednesday after concluding his visit to Panama.

Prior to his departure for Costa Rica, Huang told the Panamanian news media that ROC-Panama relations have continued to grow and that the two countries have agreed to further strengthen bilateral cooperation.

During his stay in Panama, Huang met with Panamanian President Martin Torrijos, First Vice President/Foreign Minister Samuel Lewis Navarro and other senior Panamanian officials for wide-ranging talks.
Huang also presided over a working meeting of ROC diplomatic mission chiefs stationed in Central and South America.

Huang, heading an official delegation, arrived in Panama City Sunday evening on the first-leg of his three-country Central America visit. Following his Costa Rica diplomatic tour, he will also visit Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUG. 17 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Aug. 17:
09:15, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend the opening of a national youth human resources development conference to be held at a National Taiwan University Hospital convention hall.
10:00, Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen will preside over a parent-kid day activity at the Presidential Office.
14:50, President Chen Shui-bian will visit a precision machinery company at the Taichung industrial park in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DOMESTIC VIOLENCE VICTIMS UP 10%

TEXT.P: The number of domestic violence victims in Taipei City reached 2,799 in the first half of this year, marking a 10 percent increase year-on-year, the city government's domestic violence and sex crime prevention center said Wednesday.
Among the victims, 94 percent were women and 39 percent were between the ages of 24 and 39, according to statistics compiled by the center.
Meanwhile, 2,459 of the domestic violence cases involved married couples, marking a 15.34 percent year-on-year rise.

During the six-month period, 182 senior citizens sought the center's protection, an increase of 28 people from the year-earlier level. Among the elderly domestic violence victims, 51.64 percent were women.

As to juvenile protection, the center provided assistance to 158 citizens under the age of 18, representing a marked decrease of 80 underaged victims. Among the young victims, 63.29 percent were under the age of 10.

From January through June, the center received a total of 5,197 phone calls for assistance in domestic violence cases and the center assisted victims in 502 cases in securing protection decrees from local courts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang arrived in Costa Rica Wednesday for a whirlwind one-day visit.
Huang, who just concluded a four-day visit to Panama, will meet with his Costa Rican counterpart, Bruno Stagno, for talks on matters of mutual concern.
The two ministers will sign a memorandum of understanding on Taiwan's promise to assist Cost Rica in rebuilding the Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia hospital which was destroyed in a fire recently.

Taiwan originally pledged to donate US$15 million for Costa Rica to build an international convention center, but the two sides have reached an agreement on transferring the fund for rebuilding the hospital.
During his stay in Costa Rica, Huang will also meet with the Central American ally's two vice presidents.
Huang is scheduled to leave for Honduras Thursday on the third and last leg of his current "shuttle diplomacy" tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 TAIWAN ACTIVISTS DEPART FOR TIAOYUTAIS TO PROTEST SHRINE VISIT

TEXT.P: Five Taiwanese activists left for the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands aboard a boat for recreational fishing late Wednesday to protest Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visit to a controversial Tokyo shrine a day earlier.

The five protestors, led by Huang Hsi-lin, a member of the Yungho city assembly in Taipei County, started their voyage from the county's Shenao fishing port in northern Taiwan. Four journalists were accompanying them on the voyage.

Huang said they will sail to waters near the Tiaoyutais -- an uninhabited island group about 200 km east of Taiwan which is now held by Japan but also claimed by Taiwan and China -- to protest Koizumi's visit to the Yasukuni Shrine which honors Japan's war dead, including 14 Class-A war criminals.

Moreover, Huang said, the demonstration was also aimed at protesting Japan's frequent detention and dispersal of Taiwanese fishermen operating in the overlapping area of the two countries' 200-mile economic zones.

According to Huang, some Hong Kong activists originally promised to join them at waters near the Tiaoyutais. But their Hong Kong counterparts have dropped the plan because their ship has been impounded by Chinese authorities for unknown reasons, he added.

Local coast guard officials reminded the protestors not to sail past the 24-mile demarcation line off the Taiwan coast in line with the domestic rules governing their stated purpose of "recreational fishing."

Koizumi, who intends to step down next month, dealt a blow to Japan's ties with its Asian neighbors, particularly China and South Korea, Tuesday by visiting the controversial shrine on the especially symbolic date of Aug. 15, the anniversary of Japan's surrender in World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursdayy, Aug. 17, or the 24th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: The English defeat the Scots and the French at the Battle of Verneuil during the Hundred Years' War.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a U.S. representative from Tennessee who joined with Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico. He died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West, American comedy actress and international sex symbol known for her sultry stage persona during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage productions and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold field at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England, by a car traveling at just 6.4 kilometers per hour.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon premiers in Paris.
1943: U.S. forces under Gen. George S. Patton liberate Messina, Italy, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After the end of Japanese occupation, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist Yenan General Headquarters issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch a full-scale war against the Nationalists.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator is formally inaugurated in Geneva, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan, following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the United States and mainland China. The ministry also asks the United States to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the previous 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when his camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, faster than the previous record by one hour and 20 minutes.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy for the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing his KMT membership, which he has held for 42 years.
2000: Chen Yi-song, leader of the Agriculture Technical Mission to the Republic of the Gambia, says that ROC agriculture technologists have transformed the Gambia River basin, which used to yield nothing but peanuts, into the "rice bowl of West Africa" over a period of five years.
2001: Taiwan's two major paper makers -- Yuen Foong Yu Paper and Chung Hwa Pulp -- sign a merger agreement and promise that there will be no layoffs in the new company.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learning a thing, you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: State Creates Marine Havens. The California Fish and Game Commission on Tuesday banned or severely restricted fishing across nearly 18% of the waters off Central California, beginning to roll out the nation's first network of marine reserves next to a heavily populated coastline.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Won't consider running for PM- GMA
President Arroyo yesterday ruled out any ambitions to become the country's first Prime Minister in case the country shifts to a parliamentary government as part of the planned changes in the Constitution.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: House panel kills impeachment bid
IN ANOTHER KILLING, President Gloria Macapagal- Arroyo's dominant allies threw out yesterday a second attempt to unseat her in two years. The House committee on justice voted 56-24 to trash the impeachment complaint backed by civil society.
The Philippine Star: House panel kills impeachment
The House committee on justice last night killed the new impeachment complaint against President Arroyo, with one member telling the opposition and petitioners that their case "was already dead on arrival."
The Manila Times: Impeachment dead
The House Committee on Justice on Wednesday threw out the impeachment complaint against President Arroyo, ruling that it lacked sufficient substance to form the basis of a trial in the Senate.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News

DOC.HEADLINE: CHOU SHIH-YUAN PAYS TRIBUTE TO LATE GRANDFATHER THROUGH BASKETBALL(repeat)

TEXT.P: Grief-stricken over his grandfather's death last week, Taiwanese basketball player Chou Shih-yuan said his performance in an Asia Professional Basketball (APB) tournament game Wednesday night was in tribute to his grandfather.

The Taiwanese national team lost the opening game of the second round 99-93 to the Perth Wildcats, but it was Chou's four three-pointers in the third quarter that ignited a furious rally that almost helped the home team pull off a come-from-behind win.
Chou was raised by his grandparents until his junior high school graduation in the southern city of Kaohsiung. Chou's father worked in another city at the time and was seldom at home.
For almost ten years, his grandparents were his only family, said Chou, who learned of his grandfather's death via a cellphone text message after a team practice session last week.
"Later, he was bedridden with diabetes and lost most of his vision, but he listened to almost every one of my basketball games on television. He always wanted to know if I played well," Chou said.

"I wasn't able to think about him much while I was on the court today. But I am glad I had a good game and did not disappoint him," said Chou, who scored 16 points in 22 minutes and had his best game in the tournament so far.
Chou will miss the next two games as he will be back in Kaohsiung for the funeral.

The five-team APB tournament invited four basketball clubs from Japan, Korea, Australia and the Philippines. The tournament enters the single round-robin second round Wednesday and concluded on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTION TO TOPPLE CABINET SHOULD BE RECONSIDERED: PFP LEGISLATOR(repeat)

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) should reassess whether it is necessary to introduce a motion in the next legislative session to topple the Cabinet through a no-confidence vote, a PFP lawmaker said Wednesday.

Legislator Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy research center, told reporters that when PFP Chairman James Soong first announced the PFP would seek to topple the Cabinet, he did it against a background of Premier Su Tseng-chang voicing support for President Chen Shui-bian after a legislative motion to recall Chen failed in late June.
The recall motion was introduced because the president had been dogged by a series of corruption scandals implicating his family members and senior officials at the Presidential Office.

Chang said, however, that the relationship between the premier and president seems to have deteriorated recently because in a partial reshuffle, Su replaced several Cabinet members who were considered Chen's proteges.
"The situation is fluid. The PFP must now take into consideration the tension between the president and the premier, along with other political factors," Chang said.
"If we succeed in toppling the Cabinet, we may actually be doing a service for President Chen by causing the premier to be replaced," he explained.

Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang, convener of the PFP's legislative caucus, said although the domestic political situation seems unpredictable, the PFP must still be prepared in case new developments warrant a no-confidence vote on the premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL OFFENSES INVOLVING CHINESE CITIZENS ON THE RISE(repeat)

TEXT.P: The number of illegal offenses committed by Chinese visitors has risen since the Taiwan's government opened its doors wider to Chinese tourists last year, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) reported Wednesday.

According to MOJ tallies, Chinese citizens made 130,000 to 150,000 visits to Taiwan annually between 2001 and 2004. In 2005, that number increased to 170,000 as Taiwan allowed in more Chinese tourists as part of efforts to step up civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Between 2001 and 2005, a total of 9,456 Chinese citizens were caught entering Taiwan illegally, with the annual number hitting a record of more than 3,000 in 2003.
Over the past five years, more than 3,000 Chinese citizens have been convicted of various offenses, accounting for 0.5 percent of total convictions during the period.
The Chinese offenders were mainly convicted of document forgery in marriages of convenience or violating the national security law due to illegal entry, according to MOJ tallies.

As of the end of July, 55 Chinese citizens were serving time in Taiwan's prisons, most of whom were convicted for violating Taiwan's national security law. Further, 263 other Chinese were being detained for investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN, U.S. SCHOOLS TO EXCHANGE STUDENTS(repeat)

TEXT.P: Five students from National Kinmen Institute of Technology (NKIT) on the outlying island of Kinmen will travel to the United States in September to study at the University of West Florida (UWF) as part of an exchange program between the two schools, an NKIT spokesman said Wednesday.

It will be the first group of NKIT students to study at the Florida university since the two schools signed a cooperative agreement last November when UWF President John Cavanaugh visited Kinmen, a Taiwan-held defense outpost which lies closer to the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper.

According to the NKIT spokesman, UWF will also send students to study at the Kinmen technology institute under the exchange program to boost mutual academic cooperation and expand their students' vision and perspective.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER HEADS FOR COSTA RICA TO CONTINUE DIPLOMATIC TOUR(repeat)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang left for Costa Rica Wednesday after concluding his visit to Panama.

Prior to his departure for Costa Rica, Huang told the Panamanian news media that ROC-Panama relations have continued to grow and that the two countries have agreed to further strengthen bilateral cooperation.

During his stay in Panama, Huang met with Panamanian President Martin Torrijos, First Vice President/Foreign Minister Samuel Lewis Navarro and other senior Panamanian officials for wide-ranging talks.
Huang also presided over a working meeting of ROC diplomatic mission chiefs stationed in Central and South America.

Huang, heading an official delegation, arrived in Panama City Sunday evening on the first-leg of his three-country Central America visit. Following his Costa Rica diplomatic tour, he will also visit Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEZBOLLAH USES SOPHISTICATED WEAPONS MADE BY CHINA, RUSSIA: ISRAEL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Hezbollah has used sophisticated weapons made by China and Russia during its latest conflict with Israel, Israeli Deputy Prime Minister Shimon Peres said Wednesday.
Peres, who is on a visit to the U.S. capital, told a Jewish gathering that China and Russia sold the weapons to Iran, who then supplied them to Hezbollah.
It is widely known that Iran and Syria back Hezbollah, Peres said, noting that Iran gives US$100 million in aid to Hezbollah per year, including advanced weapons purchased from China and Russia.

Iran also helps train Hezbollah fighters, sending at least 100 instructors to Lebanon for that purpose, while Hezbollah has sent its soldiers to Iran and Syria to receive training, according to Peres.
Although Israel has been fighting Hezbollah and Palestine, it is fully aware that the real source of the conflict lies in Iran and Syria, he stressed.
Israeli authorities estimated that Hezbollah had 12,000 missiles and rockets, 4,000 of which have been fired at Israel during the recent skirmishes.

"Hezbollah had hoped these missile and rocket attacks could have destroyed Israel," Peres said, adding, however, most of the mid- and long-range rockets and missiles were intercepted by Israel's air force, and only short-range missiles and rockets have caused damage to Israel.

The Israeli army was responsible for coping with the short-range missile and rocket attacks. During the latest conflict, 150 Israeli soldiers have been killed, and the nation has suffered about US$2 billion worth of damage, he reported.

On the other side, Peres estimated that 600 Hezbollah fighters have been killed and nearly 1,000 wounded -- which he called a heavy blow to its 2,500-strong militia. In addition, 15,000 civilian houses were damaged or destroyed, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO WORK TO BOOST ICT PLATFORM INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has set its goals for the development of the country's information and communications technology (ICT) platform industry, which include expanding the production value of the industry from NT$221 billion (US$6.78 billion) at present to NT$1 trillion by 2012.

Also, the Cabinet aims to nurture three world-class ICT platform enterprises in the fields of manufacturing services, health services and Chinese-language digital learning, with the goal of having Taiwan gain a 50 percent share of the world's Chinese-language digital learning market by 2012.
It is the Cabinet's target to shift the pattern of the country's industries from "Made in Taiwan" to "Service via Taiwan."
The goals were unveiled during a conference on industrial technology strategy held Wednesday by the Cabinet.

The Cabinet predicted that services will become an important trend in the future, with the services sector contributing 73.2 percent to Taiwan's gross domestic product in 2005 and workers in the sector accounting for 58.3 percent of the country's employed population.
Participants in the conference proposed that Taiwan should take advantage of information and communications technology to develop technology-based services.

Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching pointed out that there are already several international examples in which ICT is used to innovate services models, including Skype's interpretation services and iTune's online music download.

Lin said Taiwan is in a highly advantageous position in light of its strong foundation in the manufacturing sector, the popularity of broadband Internet services in Taiwan, the high quality of Taiwan's talent pool, and the use of the Chinese language in the country.

Participants at the conference noted that thanks to the "Chinese-language fever, " an estimated 30 million people around the world are learning the Chinese language, with the number expected to increase to 100 million by 2010.

While there is a demand for 1 million Chinese-language teachers around the world, only 100,000 teachers are available now, they said, predicting that online learning will become an alternative channel for language learning.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO CREATE EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang pledged Thursday that the government will create a wide variety of opportunities to allow young people to display their talent.
Su said that the youth are an asset of the country and that the government will help them enrich their knowledge and abilities so that they can put their learning to practical use.
He said that the government will create various employment opportunities so that young people can distinguish themselves in whatever trade or profession they choose.

As the division of professions is becoming increasingly sophisticated, it is very important that education meet the demands of businesses to ensure that students are properly trained to enter their chosen professions, Su said.
The premier made the remarks during the opening of a national conference on the development of youth human resources.
Also at the conference, Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng noted that European countries have in recent years emphasized that universities should nurture students' employability.
However, this does not mean that universities are to be turned into some kind of vocational training center, he added.

With more than 90 percent of senior high school graduates in Taiwan being admitted to universities nowadays, universities are no longer places for only a small number of elites and should adjust their concepts accordingly to take into consideration the problems that graduates might face when seeking employment, Tu said.

Tu said that in addition to professional knowledge and technical skills, universities should provide students with training in core abilities such as problem-solving and working in harmony with others.
He said that as long as universities strengthen the cultivation of the humanities and the nurturing of creativity among their students, no students will lose their employability upon graduation.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN AGREES IN PRINCIPLE TO FORMER PRESIDENT LEE'S VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Japanese government has agreed in principle to a planned visit to the country in September by former ROC President Lee Teng-hui, a Japanese TV report said Thursday.

According to Japan's public station NHK, the Japanese government has made the decision based on the judgement that Lee is visiting the country for sightseeing purposes and has no intention of engaging in political activities.

As Japan has offered visa-free entry for Taiwanese tourists since September last year, the Japanese government is still reviewing if Lee, as a civilian, is required to apply for a visa for his upcoming visit, the report said.
Even if a visa is required, the Japanese government is expected to issue it promptly, it added.
Lee first indicated his plan to visit Japan in September during a news conference Sunday in the southern city of Kaohsiung.

It will be Lee's third trip to Japan since his retirement in May 2000. He first visited Okayama prefecture in April 2001 to receive medical treatment for his heart disease and made a second trip between December 2004 and January 2005 to several Japanese cities, including Nagoya and Kyoto.
Lee had originally planned to visit Japan again in May this year but cancelled the trip after catching a mild case of tuberculosis in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST INT'L HEALTHY CITY FORUM AUG. 22-23

TEXT.P: An international forum on healthy cities is scheduled to take place in Taipei Aug. 22-23 with delegates from 28 cities from home and abroad taking part, Taipei city government officials said Thursday.

The forum, dubbed the 2006 Taipei Healthy Cities Leaders Roundtable and International Healthy Cities Conference, will bring together mayors and city officials from the Asia-Pacific, Europe and the Americas to exchange views on disease prevention, city dwelling and management of cities, officials from the Taipei City Department of Health said.

The forum, sponsored by the Taipei City Department of Health, will focus on three themes for discussion -- how to optimize city living standards to make it the most "livable, ' how to instill civic pride in the city, and city management, said Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Ma said that by holding the international forum, Taipei will hopefully be transformed into a world-class healthy city.

Twelve foreign cities are expected to take part, according to Ma. He said Finland's first capital city of Turku will share its development experiences at the forum, in particular the city's renowned birth subsidy plan, its experience in developing automatic kitchen cabinets and automatic medication boxes for the elderly who live alone.

Meanwhile, Sung Yen-jen, director of the Taipei Department of Health, said discussions regarding new types of influenza, pneumonia and AIDS -- as well as relevant healthy policies -- will form the centerpiece of the two-day forum.
Other major issues the forum is expected to tackle include cultural exchanges, cultural phenomena and the infrastructural development of cities, Sung added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD MAY CANCEL U.S. VISIT AS DOMESTIC CONFRONTATION LOOMS

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that he is worried about the possible eruption of conflict between radical forces calling for President Chen Shui-bian to step down and those opposing such calls.
Senior DPP officials who have been discussing the domestic situation suggested that Yu consider canceling his scheduled visit to the United States in early September.

According to the DPP officials, the DPP leadership is concerned as former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh's campaign to depose the president has been winning much public support while "pan-green camp" radicals like TV personality Wang Pen-hu and Legislator Wang Hsing-nan have been urging their supporters to demonstrate their "power" to protect Chen.

During a meeting of DPP officials, Yu said if the trend continues, a conflict could erupt between "depose-the-president" forces and those vowing to "protect the president, " with social chaos possibly to follow.

Senior DPP officials said that as the ruling party, the DPP's priority is to maintain political stability and concentrate on national development. For that reason, they said, the DPP will not organize any "counter-Shih" activities.
On the other hand, they noted, the party cannot ignore "grass-roots voices" that call for counter-measures against Shih's campaign. "The party leadership is indeed in a quandary," they said.
Yu has called on Shih to exercise "self-restraint" and tried to pacify people like Wang Pen-hu and Wang Hsing-nan, but to no avail.
Wang Pen-hu ran an ad Friday urging the public to do something to "counter" Shih, an indication that he simply could not be pacified, according to DPP sources.
The DPP said it is paying close attention to what might happen if the "counter-Shih" forces continue to gain momentum.

Since Shih has claimed that he might start a sit-in by late August, and his opponents are readying for a fight, Yu and his staff have discussed whether to go ahead with their planned visit to the United States in early September, DPP officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 36.83 points to close at 6,733.46.
The bourse opened at 6,752.99 and fluctuated between 6,761.79 and 6,722.58 during trading. A total of 3.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$118.86 billion (US$3.64 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.1 percent, and textile stocks at 0.3 percent.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 0.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks and paper and pulp issues both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 518 to 507, with 129 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER CALLS FOR 'STYLE' IN FACE OF OUTCRY AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Thursday urged party members to react with reason and style in the face of a former DPP chairman's campaign to depose the embattled President Chen Shui-bian.
DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung made the remarks after Shih Ming-teh's launch of a drive calling for "one million people to depose President Chen."

Lee said that he himself does not support Shih's drive but "feels ashamed and chose to keep his mouth shut" facing a mounting public outcry in the wake of a string of corruption allegations implicating the president himself, his close aides and family members.

However, he said that he feels "more ashamed for the way some DPP politicians responded to Shih, " and he urged them "to act with panache whether they are for or against President Chen, " or it "will only create further social divisions."
He called for DPP politicians to engage in "deep soul-searching" and to show humility instead of resorting to sensational "character assault."
Legislator Wang Shih-chien said that many "core" supporters of the DPP can no longer put up with Shih.

Wang said that Wang Peng-hu, a former TV host of a political commentary program, has decided to hold a rally at the 228 Peace Memorial Park Aug. 26 to highlight a drive to safeguard President Chen and Taiwan and to stand up to Shih.

Shih launched his drive at the same park last Saturday, urging people to each donate NT$100 to the campaign. If the target of one million donors can be reached within one month, the campaign to depose Chen will be launched Sept. 9 with daily sit-ins by protesters in front of the Presidential Office. If the target of one million can be achieved sooner, the campaign will also start to roll earlier than planned, according to Shih.
Legislator Wang estimated that between 10,000 and 20,000 people will attend the Aug. 26 rally, but there will be no donation solicitation.

Wang urged Shih "to stop before the edge of the precipice, " noting that Shih devoted himself to the democratic movement for over two decades in his younger years and that he "shouldn't be taken advantage of by others who have other motives" in the waning years of his life.

He referred to the "others" as being the opposition parties, adding that the main opposition Kuomintang could funnel money from selling its "ill-gotten" party assets into Shih's accounts. This is the reason why the amount of money collected in the drive has already reached NT$45 million as of Wednesday, Wang claimed.
Yet another DPP legislator, Huang Wei-cher, said that Shih has turned a deaf ear to goodwill advice from within the party.
Huang suggested that Shih should not be aloof and not harbor ill will for the suggestions from within the party, saying that he does not want to see Shih display "moral arrogance."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PROMOTES LOVE FOR IMPOVERISHED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian asked the children attending a Parent-Child Day activity at the Presidential Office Thursday to pledge to open up their piggy banks at the end of the year and donate the money to help impoverished children around the world.

President Chen said that in the spirit of voluntarism, the Presidential Office has formed a volunteer service corp to sponsor impoverished children at home and abroad, which he said is the embodiment of love and compassion.
The president also said that it is very good for the Presidential Office to promote a drive to use the piggy bank money to help needy people.
He asked the children to pledge to open up their piggy banks on International Volunteer Day on Dec. 5 to help impoverished children.
The president also said that parent-child relations are the core of family values, urging all parents to spend more time with their kids.
He noted that his grandson Chao Yin-an was crying for his father, Chao Chien-ming, an orthopedist at National Taiwan University Hospital, Wednesday night, and ignored his offer to play with him.
Chao, indicted in July for insider trading of Taiwan Development Corp. stocks, was released on NT$17 million (US$521,470) bail later.

DOC.HEADLINE: IDEOLOGICAL GAP MAY BE BEHIND SHIH'S REFUSAL TO COOPERATE WITH DAA

TEXT.P: Ideological differences over cross-strait relations may be behind former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh's refusal to cooperate with the Democratic Action Alliance (DAA) , even though both are dedicated to deposing scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian, a DAA leader said Friday.
Huang Kuang-kuo, DAA convener, said the alliance has invited Shih several times since June to lead a populist movement to topple the president, but Shih has consistently refused.
"Now I realize that it might be our proposal for 'one China, two Constitutions' that has been the problem," he said.
The two Constitutions refer to those of the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China (Taiwan) . Shih is a staunch Taiwan sovereigntist.

Huang, Chang Ya-chung and other DAA leaders gave a press conference in which they announced that after paying a visit to an ancient temple in Tainan last week, they plan to pay tribute to another ancient deity in Chiayi's Cheng Huang Temple this weekend.
They will also continue pushing their proposal to depose the president in a peaceful, legal and non-violent way in the "democracy night market" at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
They again invited Shih to discuss coordinating a plan to topple the president, as they have obtained permission to use Ketagalan Boulevard for a mass sit-in.

As the protest may draw a large crowd, DAA leaders are demanding that Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who concurrently serves as opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairman, to make clear his position with regard to the street rally.
"Do you want to be an opposition leader, or a mayor of the capital city that stands on the side of a corrupt regime? " they asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TAIPEI MAYORAL ASPIRANT REQUESTS DEBATE ON 2020 OLYMPIC BID

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) nominee for Taipei mayor, challenged his Kuomintang (KMT) opponent Hau Lung-pin Thursday to a debate on Hsieh's proposal for Taipei to host the 2020 Olympic Games.
Hsieh said he hopes Hau will not evade a public debate on the issue, since Hau has openly expressed disapproval of it.

According to Hsieh, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is expected to decide on a host city for the 2020 Olympic Games in 2013, and cities vying for the right will file an application with the IOC in 2011.

Therefore, a country should decide in 2009 or 2010 as to which city will represent it, Hsieh said, adding that it is mistaken for Hau to say that making such a bid would keep Taipei residents waiting 14 years for a decision on the application.
In response to Hsieh's invitation, Wu Hsiu-kuang, the spokesman of Hau's office, said at present it would be impractical for Taipei to focus its attention on making a bid to host the Olympic Games.
Wu said a successful bid would be impossible when Taipei lacks the funds and a proper venue for hosting the event.
Hau will only enter a debate on issues related to municipal governance with other mayoral candidates after he officially registers his candidacy with election authorities, Wu said.
