DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER SPEAKS ON SHIFTING 0.18 MICRON TECH TO CHINA-BASED PLANTS

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said Thursday that the key to allowing local companies using 0.18 micron process technology to invest in China is implementing the proper complementary measures.

Chen made the remarks one day after Morris Chang, founder and chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), urged the government to allow local chip makers to set up factories in China using the advanced 0.18 micron process technology.

Chang argued that doing so will not be detrimental to Taiwan's high-technology industry but will instead help sharpen Taiwan companies' competitiveness. The TSMC is one of the biggest IC chip foundries in the world.
"The ministry fully understands the stance of TSMC, " Chen said, adding that the ministry's position is "similar to that of industry and that the opening is only a question of timing."

The ministry will convene a meeting with the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs for further discussions on the matter and will hold consultations with the Mainland Affairs Council, the nation's top China policy planner, Chen said.
"Whatever the final decision on the matter is, the most important thing is working out good complementary measures," he stressed.

Meanwhile, Theodore M.S. Huang, president of the influential Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, said that business hopes that the government will cut its interference in their affairs to a minimum. He was referring to the present 40 percent ceiling on local businesses investing in China.
Huang made the remarks after paying a visit to Chen to congratulate him on assuming his new post last week and to get a better understanding of his trade and economic policy.

Huang said that the attitude of the business sector is clear, namely that the government should reduce its interference to a minimum and adopt an "active opening" policy toward cross-strait economic and trade affairs instead of the "active management" policy advocated by President Chen Shu-bian earlier this year.
Huang said that local businesses will make decisions on whether to invest in China based on considerations of economic efficiency and not on political considerations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Lebanon Sending Troops Into South; Compromise Will Allow Hezbollah to Keep Arms.
Breaking an impasse, the Lebanese government on Wednesday ordered army troops to deploy across southern Lebanon under a compromise arrangement that allows the Hezbollah militia to retain some of its arms caches near the border with Israel.

DOC.HEADLINE: REASSESSMENT OF UNIVERSITY EDUCATION NEEDED: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: In a time of globalization and when the college acceptance rate is nearing 100 percent, traditional thinking on university education should be re-evaluated to meet the challenges of today, government officials said Thursday at a conference.

"Several decades ago, a university graduate was almost guaranteed an upper-level position within a public or private organization, but now times have changed," said Premier Su Tseng-chang in his opening remarks at the National Youth Human Resources Development Conference.

The impact of globalization and an increasing number of universities and graduates are two key factors posing problems for youth who are seeking employment today, since everyone is facing tougher domestic and international competition, he said.
"What we need to do is create a diversified environment that allows young people to find the most suitable profession," Su said.

"Obtaining employment -- not passing a college entrance exam -- has thus become the first and greatest challenge for local university graduates," said Chen Bo-chih, an economist and president of Taiwan Thinktank.
However, the growing unemployment rate among youth is not -- at least directly -- the result of booming numbers of universities and graduates, Chen said.
The key will be closing the gap between university education and corporate needs, which currently do not fit, said Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng.
Tu stressed this does not signify that university education should and will become a form of pre-employment training for students.
"A university education should place more of an emphasis on core competencies such as humanity, responsibility, leadership, communication, teamwork and entrepreneurship," he said.
"Professional skills and expertise, the other part of employee qualifications, can be developed on and off campus," Tu said.

The National Youth Human Resources Development Conference was held to tackle four issues -- "employability," creating jobs, entrepreneurship and equal opportunity -- as proposed by U.N. Secretary Kofi Annan in 2003.

For the first time, the conference was coordinated by five governmental organizations, including the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the National Youth Commission, the Council for Labor Affairs and the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR HOPES KETAGALAN SIT-IN WILL REMAIN QUIET AT NIGHT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that although the site where an anti-President Chen Shui-bian sit-in will be held -- Ketagalan Boulevard -- is not in a residential area, he called for peace, order and tranquility, particularly during the evening.

Ma made the remarks in response to media reports that Professor Ho De-fen, spokeswoman for former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh's "one million people campaign to depose the president, " has signed an affidavit pledging to keep peace and order when the rally continues at night.

He said the law does not specify a certain time of day for marches and assembly, but police have discretionary power to disperse the crowd to ensure the quality of life for local residents. He said the police would be flexible on this issue.

Shih has said if the police drive them out at night, usually after 10:00 p.m., he will lead the crowd to "move to other places to continue our sit-in, 24 hours a day, day after day, until we have achieved our purpose."
Asked if he would ask for leave in order to attend the sit-in, Ma, who currently serves as chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said, "There is no need."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE ACTIVISTS PROTEST KOIZUMI SHRINE VISIT

TEXT.P: A group of political activists lodged a protest against Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's pilgrimage to a war shrine by sailing to an area near the Tiaoyutai Islands late Wednesday night.
The activists, including some members of the Taiwan Islands Union, set sail aboard a chartered fishing boat from the northern fishing port of Shenao at 11:14 p.m. Wednesday.

They released protest balloons into the air when they reached some 15 nautical miles away from the Tiaoyutai Island group around 4 a.m. Thursday as a gesture to protest Koizumi's visit to Yasukuni Shrine Tuesday and Japan's frequent detention and dispersal of Taiwanese fishermen operating in the overlapping area of the two countries' 200-mile economic zones.
The Japanese Defense Agency mobilized seven patrol boats to guard against the chartered boat, with one surveillance aircraft hovering above.
The protesters yielded to the Japanese patrol boats' intimidation and sailed back to Shenao port shortly before noon Thursday.
The Tiaoyutais, an uninhabited island group about 200 km east of Taiwan, which for decades has been claimed by Japan, China and Taiwan, are currently held by Japan.
Koizumi's visit to Yasukuni Shrine Tuesday dealt a blow to Japan's ties with its neighbors, particularly China and South Korea, and also whipped up anger among Taiwan's political activists.

The activists' protest at sea has also drawn the attention of the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) , which sent a patrol boat to sail alongside the chartered fishing boat -- on one hand to protect the protesters, CGA authorities claimed, while gathering evidence about the activity on the other, which the CGA deemed illegal.

CGA authorities said the protesters may face fines of between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000 for being in violation of the country's maritime laws, which stipulate that chartered fishing boats can be used only for their designated purposes, and must not sail beyond Taiwan's territorial waters.

Protesters' leader Huang Hsi-lin, a member of the Yungho city assembly in Taipei County, said Thursday's protest was just a "warm up" of their protest against Japan. Huang said a large-scale protest, with the participation of protesters from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and China, will be staged at the end of this year.
By Deborah Kuo

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT BETTER EQUIPPED FOR SECURITY REASONS

TEXT.P: The Taichung District Court in central Taiwan has recently installed an X-ray inspection machine to check bags brought into the building by the public to better maintain security, a court spokesman said Thursday.

Visitors to the court must now have their bags checked by the X-ray machine to ensure that they do not contain any dangerous or unlawful items, the spokesman said, adding that a recent visitor was found to have attempted to bring a knife with him into the court.
Currently, only the Taiwan High Court and the Taichung District Court are equipped with the machines, which cost around NT$780,000 each.
Bailiffs are taking training classes to learn how to use the machines, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMOTING YOUTH EMPLOYMENT A FULL-SCALE TASK

TEXT.P: It will take a full-scale cross-departmental effort to promote youth employment, a growing concern and critical factor for Taiwan's future national competitiveness, a national conference concluded Thursday.

The National Youth Human Resources Development Conference, organized by five government agencies, invited more than 400 attendees and laid out a detailed conclusion that covered four topics -- employability, employment creation, entrepreneurship and equal opportunity.

A large part of the suggestions made in the conference were education-related, including a complete review of the military conscription system and better integration between vocational education and corporate needs to improve youth employability. Attendees also called for only core classes to be taught in the freshman and sophomore years at universities.
To promote entrepreneurship, universities are encouraged to establish entrepreneurship courses and facilitate more exchanges between students and corporations.

Government should also play an important role in providing more business start-up loans, re-defining underprivileged people and protecting their employment, promoting gender equality and cutting the salary gap between men and women.

Employment creation will be one of the most urgent tasks for the government, the conference concluded. To create more jobs the government should work on the development of industries such as the culture and creative industries. Young people should also be encouraged to work for non-governmental organizations and non-profit organizations.

The one-day conference gathered university presidents, academics and representatives from both industries and youth organizations. Three regional conferences were held in the north, central and south of the country before the main conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRIVE TO OUST PRESIDENT DIFFICULT TO ACHIEVE: PFP

TEXT.P: A nationwide campaign initiated by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh seeking President Chen Shui-bian's ouster will have difficulty achieving its aim, the opposition People First Party (PFP) predicted Thursday.

PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Shueh-chang told a news conference at the Legislative Yuan that Chen will not voluntarily quit the presidency, despite the ouster drive, unless all opposition parties unite in launching a motion to impeach Chen or proposing a second motion to recall the president, or unless the United States puts pressure on him.

"Only putting forward a motion to impeach Chen or launching a second recall vote in the Legislative Yuan will keep strong enough pressure on Chen and force him to step down, " said Lu, calling for full inter-party cooperation at the Legislative Yuan to impeach Chen or pass a no-confidence vote.

According to Lu, the PFP has already prepared a no-confidence proposal statement to topple the Cabinet and October would be a good time to call for the vote after the new legislative session opens in late September.

Some of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers have agreed to endorse the PFP's no-confidence proposal, while various DPP legislators have also reacted positively to the planned move, he said.

Lu also urged KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to "help form a Cabinet" since the ruling DPP has performed poorly since coming to power in 2000 and because the KMT and the PFP together control more than half of the seats at the legislature.

Lu further pointed out that "the PFP would not oppose Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT member, forming a Cabinet" if incumbent Premier Su Tseng-chang steps down following the success of a no-confidence vote.
According to Lu, Chen may replace Su should the opposition launch a no-confidence vote and will suggest forming a Cabinet with the opposition as a means of splitting them.

However, Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy center who is also a legislator, dismissed Lu's rhetoric later that same day, describing it as "just Lu's personal opinion" and pointing out that "it is too early to talk about the issue as Chen has not even questioned Wang regarding his willingness in this regard."

The China Times daily newspaper quoted an unidentified DPP heavyweight as claiming that day that relations between Chen and Su have become tense recently and that Chen "might very probably" nominate a candidate to replace Su if the opposition resorts to a no-confidence vote at the Legislative Yuan.
The DPP old guard has also predicted that Wang will not accept Chen's nomination for the premier post due to pressure from the KMT and that Su may step down before Chen, the China Times reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, decreasing NT$0.122 to close at NT$32.627.
A total of US$967 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.749 and hit a low of NT$32.550.

DOC.HEADLINE: CUSTOMS SEIZE FAKE GOODS WORTH OVER NT$20 MILLION

TEXT.P: Customs agents have seized counterfeit fashion items and pirated video games in recent months worth a combined NT$20 million, a spokesman for the Taipei Customs Bureau under the Ministry of Finance's Directorate- General of Customs reported Thursday.

According to the spokesman, customs agents seized 1,713 items of fake brand-name products, including leather goods, sunglasses and clothes since customs agents began stepping up inspections of international express delivery packages in June. The pirated products bearing the Luis Vuitton, Gucci, Burberry and Ralph Lauren labels had a market value of NT$11 million, he said.

A total of 6,800 fake Sony video game disks were nabbed by Taipei Customs Bureau agents Aug. 14 -- the second seizure of its kind after 1,626 bootleg X-Box video game disks were seized, the spokesman said, noting that the two seizures were worth more than NT$10 million.

Since the Taipei Customs Bureau has implemented a fast clearance measure to allow for quick passage of express delivery packages and low-priced items within three minutes, smuggling of pirated items using the method has been on the rise, he said, pointing out that customs agents will further strengthen inspections and submit relevant documents and suspects to prosecutors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 24 points to close at 6,695, with 31,341 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October increased 19 points to finish at 6,692, with 228 contracts traded, while December futures increased 17 points to end at 6,691, with 25 contract transactions.
March futures moved up 30 points to close at 6,700, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,671 for September, 6,673 for October, 6,674 for December, 6,670 for March and 6,665 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

September TE futures moved up 2.65 points to close at 291.7, with 6,200 contracts traded, while October TE futures increased 0.75 points to finish at 289.9, with 25 contract transactions. December TE futures increased 2.5 points to end at 291, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures lost 2.4 points to close at 918.8, with 3,177 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 0.4 points to finish at 921, with seven contracts traded. December TF futures increased 9.6 points to end at 927, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REPORTS SUCCESS IN BREEDING GERM-FREE MICE, RATS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is able to breed germ-free mice and rats for research and experimental purposes after five years of efforts, an associate research fellow of the National Applied Research Laboratories (NARL) reported Thursday.
Y.C. Huang of the NARL's National Laboratory Animal Center said they have been successful in establishing isolators and developing technology to breed the germ-free mice.

The center now has 38 units of isolators for the germ-free mice and rats, Huang said, adding that although it can produce 50 germ- free mice a month, it still cannot mass produce to meet the needs of researchers.

He noted that laboratory mice are usually the first stage in animal testing. The germ- free mice are the highest level of laboratory mice, in contrast to mice commonly known as specific pathogen free (SPF), which are only free of specific pathogens.

Huang said the feed, water and other items for the germ- free mice and rats have to undergo rigorous sterilization, which is why only a few laboratories in Europe, Japan and the United States are capable of breeding germ-free mice and rats, he added.
He noted that the center sent officials to Japan to learn quality control and management procedures five years ago.
He said germ-free mice and rats are especially useful in the research of genetic engineering, cancer, normal intestine flora, immunology and nutrition research.
The cost of breeding germ- free mice and rats is high, he added, with the cost of each isolator as high as NT$400,000.
Fortunately, he said the center has worked with universities and research institutes to obtain funds from the National Science Council for a three-year project to build a bigger isolator.

Six strains of mice and rats at the center have been kept germ- free since August 2003, Huang said, adding that he expects the number of germ- free mice bred by the center to increase 500 by the middle of next year.
Because of the success, the Riken BioResource Center of Japan has expressed the desire to cooperate with the center for research, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Aug.17[CNA] The Moscow Times: Ukraine Gas Prices to Remain Steady
Prime Minister Mikhail Fradkov signaled Wednesday that Ukraine would not have to pay more for Russian natural gas until at least the end of the year. An agreement -- even for a stopgap measure -- would be an important first victory for new Ukrainian Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych, who met with Fradkov on the sidelines of an economic meeting in Sochi. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Timothy J. Hwang)
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Lebanon Sends National Army to Patrol South
The Lebanese Army moved into the country's south at dawn on Thursday, a day after the cabinet approved the deployment under a United Nations-mandated cease-fire, but finessed the delicate issue of disarming Hezbollah.
Returning Home At several points, soldiers crossed the Litani River, about 15 miles north of the Israeli border, into the long-held separate realm of Hezbollah.
Wall Street Journal: An Entrepreneur Has Quixotic Goal Of Wiring Rwanda
Greg Wyler, an American tech entrepreneur, dreams of bringing the Internet to this troubled country. There are a few hurdles. One is a battered communications tower atop this 14,787-foot volcanic peak. The air is too thin for helicopters to transport the several tons of equipment needed for repairs. Instead, it has to go by hand.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN COUPLE ADOPT TAIWANESE GIRL AS THEIR NINTH CHILD

TEXT.P: An American couple adopted a Taiwanese girl in the southern city of Chiayi Thursday, making her their ninth child.

William Adams, an emergency room surgeon at a hospital in Pennsylvania, and his wife Betty adopted 11-year-old Fan Ya-hui at a ceremony held at a Catholic church under the witness of Liao Su-hui, the wife of the Chiayi county magistrate, officials from the Chiayi county government in charge of social affairs, and church workers.

At the ceremony, Adams said he and his wife have four children of their own, four adopted children, and that Ya-hui will be their fifth adopted child. The four other adopted children include two sons and one daughter from China, aged four, five and six, respectively, and one son from South Korea, who is three years old.

Adams said there are no cultural problems at his home with so many kids with different ethnic backgrounds around. He said he and his wife brought their own children to China when they went there to adopt the three Chinese kids. The "field trip" allowed the children to get into contact with different cultures and it helped instill harmony at home, Adams said.
During the Chinese New Year, he added, the Adams invited other American families that have adopted Chinese children to their home to celebrate the Chinese New Year.
Betty Adams expressed her appreciation for the Catholic church for its help in the adoption of Ya-hui, describing her as a "beautiful child."

Ya-hui was born in 1996 to a mentally disturbed woman who was raped by an unknown assailant. Ya-hui's grandmother was also mentally disturbed and unable to raise her, so Ya-hui's grandfather sent her to an orphanage in 1998.
At the ceremony, Adams' youngest daughter, 12-year-old Rebecca Erin, held Ya-hui by the hand and welcomed her "new sister."

Addressing the ceremony, Liao said that every life in the world has a place suitable for it. She wished Ya-hui good luck living in the United States and offered her appreciation to the Adams, saying that with Adams' medical professionalism and the love of him and his wife, Ya-hui will certainly lead a happy life in her new home.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S TOP SUMO WRESTLERS IN TAIPEI FOR EXHIBITION MATCHES

TEXT.P: Japan's 42 highest-ranked sumo wrestlers in the top Makuuchi division of the sport arrived in Taipei Thursday as part of a delegation of the Japan Sumo Association for a five-day tour of Taiwan.

The 100-strong delegation also includes sumo judges and logistics workers who will support the wrestlers in two days of exhibition competition Aug. 19-20 at the Taipei Arena, known as "the Little Dome."

The delegation arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport aboard two flights. Donning Japanese traditional costumes and standing out among the other passengers, the wrestlers, called rikishi or sumotori in Japan, attracted immediate attention as they entered the arrivals lounge.
Japanese tourists, who looked surprised when they recognized their heroes of the sumo ring, swarmed around the stars for photos.

This is the first visit to Taiwan by a Japanese sumo team since the end of World War II. It is also seen as the first major cultural exchange between Taiwan and Japan since Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China in 1972.

Most conspicuous among the wrestlers is Asashoryu Akinori, 26, the first sumo wrestler from Mongolia to reach the rank of yokozuna, or grand champion -- the highest sumo rank. Standing 184 cm and weighing 148 kg, he is also the sole active yokozuna at present.

Since being granted the title of yokozuna in January 2003, Asashoryu has won 14 tournaments and has set a record of seven consecutive tournament victories, including two 15-0 wins in January and May of 2005.

Yokozuna is the ultimate goal for a sumo wrestler and is a rank greatly respected by everyone associated with the sport. Records show there have been 68 rikishi crowned yokozuna in the entire history of the sport. This means that only one in every 1,000 rikishi can achieve this status.

Another star wrestler of Mongolian origin is Hakuho Sho, 22, who is the sixth foreign-born wrestler to reach the rank of ozeki, the champion rank immediately below yokozuna. He is 192 cm tall and weighs 153 kg.
Also ranked as an ozeki is the 23-year-old Bulgarian sumo wrestler Kotooshu Katsunori, who stands 203 cm tall and weighs 147 kg.

Loved by the Japanese as the "prince of sumo" because of his good looks, Kotooshu reached his current rank from the bottom Jonokuchi division after only 19 tournaments from his professional sumo debut in November 2002 -- the most rapid rise for a professional sumo wrestler.
He is also the first wrestler of European origin to hold the ozeki rank. Like Hakuho, he is one of only six non-Japanese to have achieved that status.

Also ranked as an ozeki is Chiyotaikai Ryuji, 30. Measuring 181 cm in height and weighing 158 kg, he joined professional sumo in 1992 and is one of only three wrestlers in history who have retained the ozeki rank for seven years. He is known for his explosive first strike at the start of a bout.

Another ozeki in the team is Kaio Hiroyuki, 34, who is 185 cm tall and weighs 170 kg. He has won five top division tournament championships -- a record for any rikishi who has not achieved the status of yokozuna.
Makuuchi, the top division in the sumo sport, consists of four levels. Below the ranks of yokozuna and ozeki are sekiwake, komusubi and maegashira.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW POSSIBILITY OF WANG FORMING CABINET: KMT

TEXT.P: The possibility of Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng forming a Cabinet is low, because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not be willing to cede the central government's power to the opposition parties, a lawmaker of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday.

KMT legislative caucus whip Tsai Chin-lung made the prediction while answering questions from reporters after the China Times quoted an unidentified DPP heavyweight as reporting that Wang, a KMT member, might be nominated by President Chen Shui-bian to form a Cabinet as Chen "might very probably" replace Premier Su Tseng-chang in the short term in an attempt to secure his presidency amid a nationwide campaign seeking his ouster.

As Chen has not yet nominated Wang to take over the premier post, it is better to refrain from speculating on the issue, Tsai said, adding that in any case, conditions are not yet ripe for such a nomination to occur.
Although Tsai speculated that Su is likely to step down soon, he said Wang will not be nominated by Chen for the premiership.
Besides Wang's need to acquire Chen's nomination, the KMT's stance and support is equally important, Tsai said, expressing his skepticism that the DPP is willing to cede power.

However, he contended that October would be a good time for the opposition parties to either initiate an impeachment or launch a second recall vote against Chen or propose a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet.

"Whatever move the opposition decides to make, the KMT cannot achieve it by itself, " Tsai said, adding that "matching the subjective and objective factors are extremely important" if success is to be ensured.

DOC.HEADLINE: PER CAPITA GDP EXPECTED TO TOP US$16,000 IN 2007: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's per capita gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to top US$16,000 in 2007, officials from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) predicted Thursday.
The GDP per capita is estimated to stand at US$15,580 this year, up US$289 from the figure posted in 2005, DGBAS officials said, adding that this increase is the basis for the 2007 forecast.

The officials predicted that the overall economy for this year will grow by 4.28 percent, the consumer price index will advance by 1.8 percent, the wholesale price index soar by 5.4 percent, while the per capita gross national product will top US$16,024, with the GDP per capita reaching US$15,580.

They forecast that Taiwan's foreign trade will return to a "normal track" in 2007 with the expansion of foreign markets slowing slightly. Domestic consumption will expand mildly as adverse factors such as the "credit card slave" issue are gradually resolved. Investment in the private sector is also expected to increase slightly next year, with investment in high technology industries continuing to flourish and procurement of passenger aircraft by private carriers increasing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDATORY LANGUAGE STUDY HOURS FOR FOREIGN SPOUSES TO BE SHORTENED

TEXT.P: The accumulated hours of mandatory Chinese language study by foreign spouses of Taiwanese nationals will be cut from the current 100 hours to 72 hours, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said Thursday.
Lee said the Ministry of the Interior will draft revisions to the law governing naturalization of foreigners to that end.
Under the current regulations, foreign spouses intending to acquire Republic of China citizenship are required to attend a total of 100 hours of government-sponsored Chinese language study programs.

Lee said the proposed cut in the duration of the language study is in line with programs initiated by the Ministry of Education (MOE) to help foreign spouses adapt to life in Taiwan, which include language study, tips on daily life and instruction in child- rearing. The MOE-prepared study programs tend to last for 72 hours, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD MIGHT APPEAL HIGHT COURT RULING IN SLANDER CASE

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), said Thursday that he reserves the right to appeal a Taiwan High Court ruling that upheld a district court judgment holding former President Lee Teng-hui guilty of slandering him but slashed the damages awarded to him from NT$10 million (NT$305,470) to NT$2 million.
Soong told reporters that he disagreed with the presiding judge's statement that the amount was reached because damages awarded in previous libel and slander cases have not exceeded NT$3 million.

The ruling would "set a bad precedent with far-reaching implications," he said, adding that by limiting the damages in all defamation lawsuits to under NT$3 million, it would mean that wealthy people willing to part with that amount "can now fabricate lies about others at will."

Soong, however, expressed appreciation for the fact that the high court upheld the guilty ruling against Lee, who insinuated in a public speech April 24, 2004 that Soong was playing mahjong with friends while his followers were fighting with police in a protest against President Chen Shui-bian's re-election.

The high court also ordered Lee to run an apology in three major newspapers for one day rather than in nine newspapers for three days in a row, as prescribed in the lower court's judgment of Nov. 18, 2005.

Soong said that if he is to appeal the high court ruling, he will ask that another mass-circulation newspaper -- the Apple Daily -- be added to the three major dailies -- the United Daily News, the China Times and the Liberty Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET STANDS GROUND DESPITE LOOMING STORM: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The administration has stood its ground despite the pall over the domestic political arena, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Thursday.

Cheng made the remarks after a local newspaper quoted an unidentified ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) elder politician as claiming that relations between President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang have soured and that Su is likely to step down sooner than Chen.

Acknowledging that the DPP administration might face a political storm of "deposing the president or toppling the Cabinet" in September when the Legislative Yuan opens its new session, Cheng said the Executive Yuan has stood its ground intact.

"None of the looming political upheavals have affected the administrative team's work schedule and communications between the president and the premier are smooth, " Cheng said, adding that Su had exchanged views with Chen extensively prior to the recent Cabinet reshuffle.

According to Cheng, the Cabinet is now busy with preparing the 2007 central government budget plan, which must be referred to the legislature for screening and approval during its upcoming new session.

In addition, Cheng said, the executive branch is drafting revisions to existing laws or initiating new legislation to implement a number of conclusions reached at the government-sponsored conference in July on sustaining Taiwan's economic development.
As for a campaign launched by some groups of political activists to depose Chen, Cheng said the Constitution has set clear procedures for recalling or impeaching the president.
"We should uphold constitutional provisions in this regard. None of the measures that go beyond the Constitution and existing legal framework are good," Cheng said.

He also lamented that many of the country's achievements have been deliberately ignored or overlooked amid the prevailing trrend of "politicizing" everything. Among others, he said the country's first high-speed railway will become operational later this year and that Discovery TV channel will broadcast a program featuring an architectural miracle -- the Hsuehshan Tunnel -- Aug. 27.
"Almost nonbody caes about them. As a result, we have made achievements, but do not have any sense of achievements, " he regretted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES CHINA'S CALL FOR TALKS ON OPENING TO TOURISTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan welcomes China's latest call for talks on issues regarding Chinese citizens making sightseeing trips to the island, the country's mainland policy planning agency said Thursday.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) was responding to a statement made by Shao Qiwei, director of China's National Tourism Administration who is also chairman of the China Tourism Association, earlier in the day that he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can negotiate terms for Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.
Shao made the appeal at a board meeting of the China Tourism Association being held in Qindao in northern China.

In response, a senior MAC official said the government has designated the ROC Travel Agent Association to negotiate with the China Tourism Association on technical details concerning Chinese citizens making pleasure trips to Taiwan.

"We have learned Shao's call and taken it as a positive step toward the realization of the new opening goal, " the official said, adding that the government will continue preparatory work for more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUG. 18 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, Aug. 18:
09:00, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang will attend a meeting on police administration and the domestic law and order to be held at the National Police Agency.
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with a Japanese wrestlers delegation.
13:35, Premier Su Tseng-chang will meet with Japanese sumo wrestling stars.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 18, or the 25th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, who through conquest created a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Adm. Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, located in present-day Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War 1, is born.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland, to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration of the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong.
1974: Taiwan baseball teams for the first time win the Little League, Senior League and Big League world titles in the same year.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its policy of apartheid.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action by launching a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the Republic of China leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy in San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: An earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
2000: The Paraguayan embassy in Taipei requests that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs lift an import ban on beef from Paraguay, saying that there have been no cases of foot-and-mouth disease reported among the country's livestock.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing, you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER MEETS HONDURAN PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Foreign Minister Huang Chih-fang met with Honduran President Manuel Zelaya Rosales in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa Thursday for wide-ranging talks.

According to news reached Panama City Thursday, Huang, on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, invited Zelaya to visit Taiwan at his convenience. Huang also expressed understanding and concern about Zelaya twice canceling plans to visit Taiwan in order to remain in Honduras for the country's political stability.
Huang arrived in Tegucigalpa at around noon Thursday after concluding his visit to Costa Rica.
He was met at Tegucigalpa's international airport by Honduran Vice Foreign Minister Eduardo Enrique Reina Garcia upon his arrival.

After a brief rest, Huang proceeded to the Republic of China Embassy in Honduras, where he was given a briefing by Ambassador Lai Chien-chung on the current domestic situation in Honduras as well as on bilateral ties between Taiwan and Honduras.

Huang is scheduled to meet Honduran Foreign Minister Milton Danilo Jimenez Puerto Friday for talks on issues of mutual concern. The two foreign ministers are also expected to confer decorations on each other as a token of friendship and their resolve to further cement bilateral ties between the two countries.
Huang and his delegation are scheduled to depart Honduras for Taiwan late Friday afternoon, concluding their three-country Central America tour, which has also taken them to Panama and Costa Rica.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRIVE TO DEPOSE PRESIDENT 'AN ABSURD DRAMA': DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh's campaign to oust President Chen Shui-bian "is about the most absurd drama in the world."

DPP Legislator Gao Jyh-peng was referring to Shih's "one million citizens to depose President Chen" campaign launched last Saturday in which he has called for every citizen to donate NT$100 (US$3) to the campaign.

Shih has said that if the target of one million donors can be reached within one month, the campaign to depose Chen will be launched Sept. 9 with daily sit-ins by protesters in front of the Presidential Office, and that if the target of one million can be achieved sooner, the daily sit-ins will be launched earlier than planned.

Gao, generally considered a protege of the embattled president, said "the whole world is erratic, " noting that Shih, with the "halo of being a former DPP chairman around his head, " has attracted core supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the main opposition Kuomintang and its ally, the People First Party.

Gao said that core "pan-blue" supporters total more than one million in number and that Shih is therefore sure to be able to reach the goal of his campaign. He added that even if the goal is reached, he doesn't see the campaign as having any legitimacy.
As of Thursday, the amount of money donated to the campaign had reached NT$65 million, according to Shih.

Another DPP legislator, Wang Shih-chien, said he hopes President Chen, who has been dogged by a series of corruption allegations implicating himself, his family members and close aides, will review what must be reviewed but will stick to his guns in these most difficult times. "This is the darkness before the dawn," he added.

Wang also said that Wang Peng-hu, a former TV host of a political commentary program, has decided to hold a rally at the 228 Peace Memorial Park Aug. 26 to highlight a drive to protect President Chen and Taiwan and to stand up to Shih.
Wang said that he expects at least 10,000 people will take part in the rally at this "critical point in time."

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH SIDES WANT MORE U.S. INVOLVEMENT IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Both Taiwan and China have put pressure on Washington to become more directly involved in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, an American expert on cross-strait affairs said Thursday.

Bonnie Glaser, consultant and senior associate at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, made the comment in agreeing with a similar analysis released last week by the Congressional Research Service.

On the China side, Glaser said, Beijing has worked harder to press the United States to take steps to restrain President Chen Shui-bian from "unilaterally changing the status quo, " including preventing changes in the language of sensitive parts of Taiwan's constitution.
She pointed out that Beijing pressed Washington to prevent Taiwan from abolishing the National Unification Council (NUC) and the National Unification Guidelines (NUG).
"Beijing now urges the U.S. to play a more active role than in the past, as long as its efforts serve China's objectives, " Glaser said.

However, in areas where the U.S. role is viewed as unhelpful, Beijing continues to hope for "less interference, " she said, noting that this includes arms sales to Taiwan and other forms of U.S.-Taiwan military cooperation, as well as approval of transits by senior Taiwan officials through the United States.
On the Taiwan side, Taipei has sought more help from the United States to promote Taiwan's participation in some international organizations such as the World Health Organization, Glaser said.

Taipei has also tried to elicit congressional support through non-governmental efforts for changing the one China policy and revising the Taiwan Relations Act and sought to convince Washington to support its effort to abolish the NUC and NUG, she said.
In addition, Taipei hopes Washington will not exert pressure to establish direct cross-strait transportation, business and postal links, she said.

Meanwhile, in light of the danger of cross-strait conflict and rising tensions between China and Taiwan, the United States has been compelled in its own interests to become more involved and has warned both Taipei and Beijing to forgo any steps that would unilaterally change the status quo, Glaser said.

While Washington has informed Beijing that any use of force against Taiwan, no matter how limited it might be, would lead to a U.S. response, it has also warned President Chen not to take any steps that could be provocative, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARITABLE FUND OFFERS INCENTIVE TO ENCOURAGE SELF-RELIANCE

TEXT.P: A local charitable foundation has launched a special program to encourage college students from poor families to be self-reliant, a spokeswoman said Friday.

The project, now in its second year, has proven successful in inspiring undergraduate students to manage their personal finances while studying hard and doing volunteer work, said Ho Chiu-hui, a staff member with the Tainan County branch of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF).

Under the project, selected college students who have received regular TFCF financial support are required to save between NT$1,000 and NT$4,000 per month and deposit the money in their accounts at Chinatrust Commercial Bank. At the end of the year, the bank will give each student an amount matching that which they have saved during the course of the year.

Since the program was launched last year, many college students from impoverished families have applied to join, according to Ho. He said that 10 students were selected for the program last year and that seven have been chosen this year.
During the one-year period, each participant has to do 100 hours of volunteer work at the TFCF and attend 40 hours of training courses in financial management and social functions, Ho said.
