DOC.HEADLINE: EFFORTS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC ORDER HAVE HAD EFFECT: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The government's efforts to improve the country's law and order over the past five months have begun to bear fruit, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said Friday.
According to Lee, the number of criminal cases declined during the period between March and Aug. 6, while the case resolution rate increased.
Also, the police's efforts to crack down on sex-related businesses and their efficiency in resolving major criminal cases have suppressed organized criminal activities, Lee said.

Lee said that since Premier Su Tseng-chang announced on March 15 that he would step down to take responsibility if law and order were not improved in six months, the police have worked very hard to try to achieve the goal.
However, the government's resolve to improve law and order will not last only six months but will continue after that, Lee said.
The minister made the remarks during a conference on police affairs held by the National Police Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND COMPLETES ASSESSMENT ON PURCHASE OF F-16C/D FIGHTERS FROM U.S.

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has completed a combat assessment on the planned purchase of 66 F-16C/D fighter aircraft from the United States, although the matter is still at the stage of program establishment, MND spokesman Wu Chi-fang said Friday.
Wu also said the ministry has no comment on whether the United States has agreed to the sale and whether the funds have been included in the national defense budget for next year.

The administration plans to raise the budget for national defense next year to 2.85 percent of gross domestic product (GDP), which will mean an increase of about NT$40 billion (US$1.23 billion) over this year's defense budget, MND officials said.
The officials noted that because of military streamlining, personnel spending will not increase rapidly. Next year's increased spending will go mainly toward defense buildup, they added.
According to a Reuters report from Washington late last month, Taiwan is planning to purchase the F-16C/D fighters over a period of five to 10 years, and the deal could be worth US$5.5 billion.
The F-16 C/Ds procurement is part of the Taiwan's arsenal renovation plan as Taiwan has decided to phase out its aging F5E/Fs.,

DOC.HEADLINE: THUNDER TIGERS TO PERFORM AEROBATICS IN CELEBRATION OF AIR FORCE DAY

TEXT.P: The Air Force "Thunder Tiger Team" will perform aerobatics and demonstrate their combat skills at the Kangshan Air Base in Kaohsiung County Saturday in celebration of the Aug. 14 Air Force Day, according to the Air Force Command Headquarters.
The performance will be the last and best show of a series of Air Force Day celebrations beginning Monday at the southern Taiwan base, the Air Force Command Headquarters said.

In addition to the air show, there will also be an exhibition of various military aircraft, including F-16 fighters, and a garden party at the base in the Air Force's biggest public activity in history.

Meanwhile, the Army Airborne and Special Operations Command will open its Kueijen Base in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, to the public Saturday and organize an exhibition at the base to display different helicopters, including those for combat, transportation and training, as well as armored vehicles and various types of equipment for special operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS BLAST MA FOR ALLOWING INDEFINITE SIT-IN

TEXT.P: Two legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lashed out at the Taipei City government Friday for allowing an "indefinite, round-the-clock" sit-in to be staged in front of the Presidential Office to unseat President Chen Shui-bian.

DPP Legislator Wang Shih-chien lambasted Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, for approving the sit-in on Ketagalan Boulevard to be staged from Sept. 9 by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh and his supporters calling for one million people to come out to depose the president.

Wang said Ma was drafting a "Shih Ming-teh Clause" by allowing Shih and his supporters to launch the round-the-clock sit-in in front of the Presidential Office. He ridiculed Ma by asking him whether in the future all people who apply to hold demonstrations or sits-in in Taipei City would be allowed to stage the activities indefinitely and round-the-clock.
Wang said Ma should bear responsibility for whatever might occur during the sit-in.
Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Lin Kuo-ching criticized Ma for "leading Taiwan's capital to become a chaotic society where there is no justice and people cannot tell right from wrong."
In contrast, a whip of the opposition People First Party legislative caucus gave the thumbs up to Ma, saying that Ma has "improved" concerning affairs regarding public demonstrations.

Shih, who has been nicknamed Taiwan's Mandela after being imprisoned off and on for 25 years for democratic movement activities, announced the sit-in drive last weekend, saying that the protest will begin after the campagin obtains the endorsement of one million people and NT$100 million in donations.
According to National Taiwan University professor Ho De-fen, who is also a spokeswoman for the campaign, more than 600,000 people have signed up and NT$65 million has been raised as of Thursday.
As public support has been far higher than expected, the sit-in on Ketagalan Boulevard may begin ahead of the originally scheduled date, probably some time next week, Ho said.
President Chen has been embroiled over the past several months in a string of corruption allegations involving his family members and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI 'NEUTRAL' OVER ANTI-PRESIDENT FUNDRAISING, SIT-IN

TEXT.P: Administrative neutrality will be the guiding principle for the government when looking at a populist campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian through a "NT$100-per-citizen" fundraising and sit-in publicity stunt, Minister of the Interior (MOI) Lee Yi-yang said Friday.

Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh's "one million people campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian" has raised the questions of whether the "political" fundraising is legal and whether Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou was being fair when he said the city police have the authority to decide whether to crack down on sit-in protesters after 10 p.m.
MOI officials have claimed that since the sit-in is a political activity, donations to the campaign are illegal from the perspective of the law governing political donations.

But campaign organizers and the public have ignored the officials' warning, with an estimated 500,000 people contributing over NT$65 million barely a week after Shih kicked off the campaign last weekend.
Some DPP lawmakers attacked Ma, who is also chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), for adopting what they claim is a double standard with regard to enforcing the law on marches and assemblies.
Lee, whose ministry is responsible for regulating both political fundraising and street protests and petitions, said both laws have nothing to do with policy.
Rather, the responsible authorities will use their professional standards to interpret and implement the laws on the principle of administrative neutrality, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKER LASHES OUT AT NO LABELING OF CHINESE CHOCOLATE

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker complained Friday that Chinese chocolate is not properly marked with its place of origin, which she claimed seriously affects the rights of consumers and food sanitation.

Legislator Lai Shin-yuan of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) made the remarks at a news conference attended by officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Department of Health (DOH).

Lai noted that Taiwan opened its market to Chinese chocolate April 1, but despite an MOEA pledge that it would demand China to mark the place of origin of the chocolate, it had failed to do so, citing the reasons of protracted administrative procedure and poor inter-agency coordination.
She said that the norm of the World Trade Organization is that all imported food has to be labeled with its place of origin.
Moreover, all domestic manufacturers have to label the place of origin when exporting to China, so Taiwan must in turn demand that China follow the norm, she said.
She noted that chocolate imported from China accounted for 12.25 percent, or 28,564 kg, of all imported chocolate in May, and she expressed worry that it is easily available on the market.
Noting that there is a commodity label law and food sanitation law to govern the matter, she lamented that the MOEA and the DOH have failed in their responsibilities.
Chen Ta-wei, a commerce department official under the MOEA, said that food imported from China should adhere to food sanitation regulations.
Hsiao Tung-ming, director of the DOH Bureau of Food Safety, said the DOH has coordinated the matter with related agencies and will carry out the labeling regulations "as soon as possible."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN LOSES APPEAL IN TAX EVASION CASE

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong has to pay NT$26.42 million in unpaid gift taxes and fines to the national treasury after the Supreme Administrative Court rejected Thursday his appeal of a lower court's decision in his tax evasion case.

The National Tax Administration (NTA) discovered that Soong failed to pay a gift tax when he remitted more than NT$42 million left over from his 1994 gubernatorial campaign funds into his daughter-in-law Wen Jeou-hui's U.S. bank account in five installments under five different names.

The amount exceeded the ceiling for non-taxable gifts, the NTA said. According to the NTA's calculations, Soong must pay NT$13.21 million in gift taxes. As Soong never declared the amount when filing his tax return, the NTA slapped him with a fine equal to the amount owed.

Soong, who was Taiwan's first and last popularly elected governor, appealed the ruling, but it was upheld by the Supreme Administrative Court. In the country's administrative litigation system, the Supreme Administrative Court's ruling was final.

The supreme court rejected Soong's arguments that the money remitted into Wen's account was not a gift but instead a donation to the IHE Foundation -- an organization jointly established by him and a Dutch technology institute -- and for financing travel expenses by him and his staff during a U.S. trip in late 1998 soon after his stint as governor ended.

As Soong never listed the sum in his subsequent asset reports to the Control Yuan in line with the public functionary property disclosure law, the court said in its ruling, it could reasonably be argued that Soong no longer counted the money as part of his personal assets.

Moreover, the court said, Wen did not remit a sum of US$ 1 million to the IHE Foundation until December 2001, more than three years after she received remittances from her father-in-law. Given the long time lapse, the remittance should be regarded as a dealing between Wen and the IHE Foundation and as having nothing to do with Soong, according to the court.

If the money was truly meant as a donation to the IHE Foundation, the court said, Soong did not need to remit it to his daughter-in-law through so many channels, including his mother-in-law's account, in the first place.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20 CHINESE FISHING BOATS NABBED FOR POACHING IN ROC WATERS
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Twenty Chinese fishing boats were nabbed off the coast of Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen Friday for poaching in Republic of China territorial waters, according to maritime police sources.

In a sweeping action dubbed "Operation Ching Hai, " some 30 maritime police officers started to patrol the waters surrounding Kinmen in eight patrol vessels at 6 a.m. Friday, and apprehended 20 Chinese fishing boats poaching in ROC waters.

The officers brought the 20 fishing boats and 33 crew members to a base in Kinmen's Liaolo port for questioning. A total of 56 fishing nets and gear were confiscated while nearly 100 kg of fish found aboard the boats were thrown back into the sea, according to Tu Chien-yeh, leader of the operation.

During the operation, the maritime police officers also intercepted four other Chinese fishing boats and boarded the vessels for inspection. The four vessels with seven crew members -- all from Fujian Province -- were expelled after the inspection, Tu said.

The operation was conducted by officers from the Kinmen office of the Coast Guard Administration, the Kinmen Coast Guard Authority and the fishery protection task force of the Kinmen county government.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN ACCUSES TAIPEI MAYOR OF DISREGARDING RULE OF LAW

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun accused Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Friday of sacrificing the rule of law in the wake of reports that the city government will approve a round-the-clock demonstration for almost one month against President Chen Shui-bian.
Yu claimed that if such a demonstration is permitted, Taipei residents will become the greatest victims because there will be no peace in the city for the next couple of months.

A group led by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh has filed an application with the city government for the right to stage a demonstration on the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office between Aug. 23 and Sept. 17 to pressure Chen to step down over alleged corruption.

Although there has not been any precedent in which a 24-hour demonstration has been allowed, Ma, who is also chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, reportedly has hinted that this application might be approved as the country's public assembly law has not set any time limit on such activities.
Yu said that Taiwan is a country ruled by law and that it is wrong for people to try to topple the president through a public movement.
He said this will result in a vicious circle and encourage others to resort to the same method whenever they want to topple those in power in the future.
He said the move will lead to conflicts and confrontation and he urged Ma to deal with the matter responsibly.
Meanwhile, he called on Shih to exercise self-restraint to help stabilize the country's politics and facilitate the operation of the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi: Italy not involved in Hezbollah disarmament.
Premier Romano Prodi said Thursday that the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon has no authority to disarm Hezbollah and that it would not form part of Italian contingent's tasks. Italy is expected to contribute around 3,000 troops to a 15,000-man UN force to be deployed in southern Lebanon.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Record A-level grades fuel debate on reform
One in ten A-level students achieved at least three grade As this summer, increasing pressure for reform of the examination.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORRUPTION WITNESS ACCUSES FORMER PRESIDENTIAL AIDES OF PRESSURING HER

TEXT.P: An Australia-based businesswoman claimed Friday that two former aides to President Chen Shui-bian have pressured her during her week-long stay in Taiwan when she testified against officials suspected of doctoring accounting books on a special "state affairs" fund.

Lee Hui-fen, who runs Taiwan Ang Corp., claimed before returning to Australia that Hsu Chih-jen, a former bureau director at the Presidential Office, and Tseng Tien-sze, former chief secretary to the president, put pressure on her since she arrived in Taipei early Monday. She claims that Hsu used invoices provided by her to illegally claim "state affairs" expenses between 2003 and 2004.

Lee said her invoices were given to presidential staff through her cousin Lee Pi-chun, a suspect in the case who has been banned from leaving the country and who told investigators she had "no idea" why Hui-fen's invoices ended up in the Presidential Office's accounting books to cover the "state affairs" expenses.
Lee Hui-fen claimed that she was "persecuted" because she defied "the rulers' intention" by giving testimony that has "hurt them to the quick."

She claimed that the persecution took the form of repossession of an office she rented at the Taipei World Trade Center building that she claimed was taken back "for no good reason, " causing her a loss in interior decoration fees.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 12.38 points to close at 6,721.08.

The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,761.4 and dipped to the day's low of 6,719.75 during trading. A total of 2.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$81.52 billion (US$2.5 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most at 1 percent and cement stocks and banking and financial shares both increasing 0.1 percent.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent, textile stocks at 0.6 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 695 to 333, with 127 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES JAPAN'S TOP SUMO WRESTLERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with six of Japan's highest-ranked sumo wrestlers and Japan Sumo Association Chairman Toshimitsu Kitanoumi at his office Friday, where he extended a warm welcome to the wrestlers who are on what is seen here as a significant visit to Taiwan.

Including Asashoryu Akinori, a yokozuna, which is the highest sumo rank, and Hakuho Sho, an ozeki -- the rank immediately below yokozuna, 42 sumo wrestlers, as well as dozens of judges of the sport and logistics workers from Japan arrived in Taipei Thursday for a five-day visit.

This is the first visit to Taiwan by sumo wrestlers since the end of World War II and it is also a major Taiwan-Japanese cultural exchange since Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China in 1972.
During the meeting, Chen said it is an honor for the Taiwanese people to be able to see Japan's sumo wrestlers fighting on the island.

The wrestlers are scheduled to conduct exhibition competitions Aug. 19-20 at the Taipei Arena, marking the first overseas sumo matches since June 1993, when a group of sumo wrestlers demonstrated the sport in Hawaii.

Chen also expressed his excitement when he saw Akinori and Sho -- two successful wrestlers from Ulan Bator, Mongolia, saying that when he was Taipei mayor before elected president in 2000, he had made efforts to push for sisterhood ties between Taipei and Ulan Bator.
He praised the two wrestling stars as the pride of Mongolia.
In response, Akinori expressed his thanks for Taiwan's warm reception and said he hopes to perform well in the upcoming matches in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAILY DEMANDED TO CLARIFY 'DIAMOND REPORT' OR FACE LAWSUIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming demanded Friday that the Chinese-language United Daily News (UDN) clarify within three days a report it printed about Chao's recent sale of a giant diamond ring or face a lawsuit.
Ku Li-hsiung, Chao's attorney, quoted Chao as complaining that he has never had such a diamond ring as the UDN alleged.

Ku said Chao was hurt by the report and planned to file a lawsuit against the UDN for libel on the same day of the report. Ku added, however, that he persuaded Chao to give the daily three days to clarify and apologize.

The UDN reported in a front-page story that day that Chao consigned former Taiwan Development Corp. Chairman Su Teh-chien to sell a13-carat diamond ring after Chao was freed on bail July 10 after he was taken into police custody May 25 on charges of insider trading.
The daily said the diamond was sold to a Hong Kong-based jeweler for around NT$6 million -- about NT$10 million lower than the stone's value.
In a July 10 indictment, prosecutors recommended that Chao and Su be sentenced to eight years behind bars, with 10 years for businessman You Shih-yi.

Meanwhile, Ku confirmed that Chao's wife Chen Hsin-yu, who is President Chen Shui-bian's daughter, plans to move to another apartment in Taipei City to avoid the annoyance of the media's paparazzi-style interruption of her daily life.

It is uncertain, however, whether Chao will be allowed to move along with his wife to the new apartment as he is still banned from leaving the country or changing residence without due notice as part of his bail conditions, Ku said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYORAL ASPIRANT PLANS 20-DAY RALLY AT CITY HALL

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's nominee for Taipei mayor unveiled a plan Friday to hold a 20-day rally at the square in front of Taipei City Hall to speak up for disadvantaged groups.
Chou Yu-kou, who filed an application with the city government Friday for the right to use the square starting Aug. 28, said the rally will comprise speeches and a sit-in for 24 hours a day.

According to Chou, the failure of a policy by incumbent mayor Ma Ying-jeou to reconstruct traditional markets has forced a lot of vendors to quit their businesses and many veterans have also lost their residences after villages for members of the military and their dependents have been razed.
There are also a lot of unemployed people in the city who need help, Chou said.

Officials at the New Construction Office of the city's Public Works Department said the office has "agreed in principle" to Chou's application to use the square but that it will be up to the police to decide whether she is allowed to hold a rally there.

Chou filed the application in the wake of reports that the city government will approve a round-the-clock demonstration for almost one month led by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh, aimed at pressuring President Chen Shui-bian to step down over alleged corruption.

While the New Construction Office has granted its permit to Shih's group to use the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office between Aug. 23 and Sept. 17, the police have not decided on whether to allow them to use the place for a demonstration.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune: Aid agencies stymied by war in Sri Lanka
Aid workers find themselves hemmed in not only by surging violence in a long-running civil war but also by suspicion, hostility and deadly attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OPPOSES VIOLENCE AGAINST FORMER CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged its supporters Friday to refrain from using violence against former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who has initiated a populist campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian.

Tsai Huang-lang, DPP deputy secretary- general and spokesman, made the call after an organizer of the "one million people campaign to depose President Chen" claimed that some radical "pan-green camp" activists have threatened to hurt the former chairman.
Wang Li-ping, director of the campaign headquarters, said she has forwarded the threatening messages to the police and has demanded police protection of the campaign leader.
She quoted Shih as urging his opponents to calm down, as he is willing to have a "rational dialogue" with them.
Shih has vowed to begin a sit-in once a million people in Taiwan have donated NT$100 each to his campaign, and he claims he will not stop his sit-in until Chen has stepped down.
As of Friday, barely a week after Shih launched his campaign, an estimated 800,000 citizens had contributed more than NT$81 million in support of his cause, according to the campaign headquarters.
Campaign spokeswoman Ho De-fen said volunteers at the campaign headquarters have received many "name-calling and intimidating" phone calls.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up three points to close at 6,698, with 16,755 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October rose eight points to finish at 6,700, with 65 contracts traded, while December futures gained nine points to close at 6,700, with 10 contract transactions.
March futures moved up six points to close at 6,700, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,695 for September, 6,692 for October, 6,691 for December, 6,694 for March and 6,689 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
September TE futures lost 1.15 points to close at 290.55, with 2,869 contracts traded, while October TE futures dropped 1.35 points to finish at 290, with 23 contract transactions.
December TE futures moved down 1.35 points to close at 290.4, with 13 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 0.45 points to close at 291, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.
September TF futures moved down 2.6 points to close at 916.2, with 2,097 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up 0.2 points to finish at 920.2, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.04 to close at NT$32.667.
A total of US$596 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.725 and hit a low of NT$32.450.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BID FOR RIGHT TO HOST 2008 INT'L SMALL BUSINESS CONGRESS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will support Taiwan's bid to host the 2008 International Small Business Congress (ISBC) now that Britain has reportedly given up the right to host the annual event, Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Friday.
Chen made the remarks after visiting Lin Ping-pin, president of the National Association of Small & Medium Enterprises, Republic of China.

Lin noted that when he attended the ISBC conference last year, he found that Japan, South Korea and Singapore had sent large delegations to the conference and that they took part in various activities. In contrast, the Taiwan delegation numbered barely 10, mainly because it had no financial support from the government.
Lin said Taiwan is important in the ISBC and that if Taiwan can host the 2008 meeting, it will help raise the nation's profile as well as promote exchanges with other countries.
The ISBC holds an annual conference in a different country every year and Taiwan is one of its member states.
Chen also promised Lin to help solve financing and labor shortage problems facing small- and medium-sized businesses, as well as to help them in innovation and research and development.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DENIES CONSPIRING WITH FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) denied Friday that there is a conspiracy between KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh to oust President Chen Shui-bian.

KMT spokesman Huang Yu-cheng told reporters that there is no such conspiracy as described in claims printed in a pro-DPP newspaper, although Ma did meet recently with Shih in his capacity as Taipei mayor to discuss Shih's application to the Taipei city government for permission to stage a round-the-clock sit-in in front of the Presidential Office.
According to Huang, Ma made no commitments to Shih, who has launched a campaign inviting a million people in Taiwan to join him in the sit-in to pressure the scandal-ridden president to step down.

Huang said there are no double standards in handling applications for permission to hold a rally or parades, and that the city government would grant permission to all applicants who act within the bounds of the law.

Asked why Ma, as mayor of Taipei, ordered police to disperse protesters in an April 10, 2004 rally in front of the Presidential Office, Huang explained that it was because some angry protesters began to resort to violence by trying to break through police barricades.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNSHIP PROGRAM GIVES EXPERIENCE TO OVERSEAS TAIWANESE YOUTH

TEXT.P: Approximately 300 overseas Taiwanese youths presented the results of their summer internships at an academic conference Friday, rounding up the eight-week Taiwan Tech Trek (TTT) 2006 program.

The TTT, organized by the National Science Council (NSC) , is a program in its second year that offers overseas Taiwanese youths hands-on internships at government agencies, non-profit organizations, private companies and special group projects.

"The NSC believes that the program not only provides internships to overseas Taiwanese youths but also helps them to know more about Taiwan, " said Lin Kwang-lung, director-general of the NSC's Department of International Cooperation.
More than 280 interns were selected out of over 1,000 applications collected by Taiwan's foreign agencies, most of whom came from the United States. The program started in late June.
Most of the members are native-English speakers but also have a basic command of Mandarin and Taiwanese, Lin said.
"By working with Taiwanese in local government agencies and companies, the members got to know more about 'the Taiwanese way' and what we are working on right now, " Lin said.
"On the other hand, their employers and colleagues have benefited from their creative ideas and new thinking, " he added.

TTT, with a budget of over NT$30 million and the cross-departmental cooperation of numerous government agencies, is designed to attract talent from overseas, which countries like India and China are also working on, according to Lin.
"We have received pleasing and promising results so far. Two of our 2005 members have been hired by local companies, " he said.

The academic conference was categorized into four groups -- natural sciences, engineering, life sciences and the humanities -- with topics such as cancer studies and Taiwan's strategy for inclusion in the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF ORGAN DONORS INCREASE AFTER CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: After long-term efforts, the number of organ donors in Taiwan has increased, but it still lags far behind the demand for organs, an organ donation and transplant registration center said Friday.
The center said that confined by the traditional Chinese thought that the body should be kept intact, organ donation is still not as popular as it is in other countries.
The number of organ donors was 109 as of Aug. 14 and their organs have benefited 350 patients, the center said.
The number of donors represents an increase of around 14 percent from the same period of last year, or 50 percent from the same period in 2004.
Despite the increase in donor numbers, it has still failed to meet the needs of 7,000 patients who are currently awaiting organ transplants, many of whom will die while waiting, the center added.

Liu Chia-chi, vice executive director of the organ donation and transplant registration center, said the increase in donor numbers can be attributed to 12 hospitals around the country that have advocated organ donations and 141 hospitals who are collaborating with them.
Liu urged more people to agree to donate their organs after death so as to give new life to patients who need them.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-PRESIDENT CAMPAIGNS BOISTEROUS BUT NOT CRUCIAL: EX-PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Campaigns and statements calling on scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian to step down are nothing but "boisterous" political gestures and are not critical to Taiwan's survival, Chen's predecessor Lee Teng-hui said Friday.

The former president was quoted as saying these anti-Chen campaigns have "political significance, " but are not crucial. The most urgent task at hand for Taiwan is to revitalize its economy by increasing domestic investment, Lee was quoted as saying.

Lee made the remarks while meeting with a group of Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislators and several think tank leaders, including Chang Jung-feng, vice president of Chung Hua Institute for Economic Research, Taiwan ThinkTank Chairman Chen Po-chih and Taiwan Futures Exchange Chairman Wu Jung-yi.
According to Taiwan Advocates -- a think tank Lee set up and heads -- Lee was saddened by the fact that university graduates in Taiwan earn little more than NT$20,000 (US$612) per month.
In Lee's view, the low average salaries paid to Taiwan's young office workers can be blamed on the integration of Taiwan's and China's economies.
Lee explained that with increasing economic integration, Taiwan's wage level has been lowered by China, whose workers are offered lower wages because of the massive labor force.

Lee asked participants to discuss ways and means of reviving Taiwan's economy, partly in response to the conclusions reached at the Cabinet's recent Taiwan Economic Sustainable Development Conference.

The former national leader was pleased by TSU legislators, who during the conference successfully stopped the government from adopting a "pro-big businesses" stance in cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic policy, according to participants.

Lee urged them to discuss how to increase Taiwan's investment ratio, which stands at a low of 16 percent, and how to correct the "erroneous view" of some government officials and business leaders about cross-strait trade and economy.

What Lee considered "erroneous" was the view that the government should encourage more economic exchanges with China by increasing the cap for Taiwanese companies investing in China, for example, which is currently set at 40 percent of a company's net assets.
Another topic raised by participants was a growing disparity in development for different regions of Taiwan.

For example, some participants pointed out, northern Taiwan -- with Hsinchu as its southern border -- accounts for 75 percent of Taiwan's economic output, while only 20 to 30 percent of the population lives there.
In contrast, only 25 percent of the gross national product is generated south of Hsinchu, where a majority of the people live.

The participants agreed to hold a series of seminars to find ways of increasing domestic investment and promoting emerging industries; to put forth a forward-thinking report on Taiwan's society and economy in the year 2020; and to publish a series of booklets to debunk China's economic myths.

The TSU legislative caucus promised to monitor Premier Su Tseng-chang's "revisionist" economic policy closely, for instance, by examining the advantages and disadvantages of allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Timothy J. Hwang)
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Inquiry Suggests Marines Excised Files on Killings
A high-level military investigation into the killings of 24 Iraqis in Haditha last November has uncovered instances in which American marines involved in the episode appear to have destroyed or withheld evidence, according to two Defense Department officials briefed on the case.
The investigation found that an official company logbook of the unit involved had been tampered with and that an incriminating video taken by an aerial drone the day of the killings was not given to investigators until Lt. Gen. Peter W. Chiarelli, the second-ranking commander in Iraq, intervened, the officials said.
Wall Street Journal:Terror Plot Exposes Flaws in How U.K.Tackles Extremism
Soon after last year's suicide attacks here, officials in Walthamstow, a shabby east London neighborhood, joined with the area's biggest mosque and a privately run Islamic youth center to try to counter the appeal of extremism. They organized a big party with live music and free food for around 500 local Muslim youth.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER URGES DPP TO DISTANCE ITSELF FROM PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should heed public opinion and distance itself from President Chen Shui-bian if the party wishes to survive the current political crisis triggered by a series of corruption and embezzlement scandals involving Chen, his family members and senior aides, an opposition lawmaker said Friday.

Legislator Tsai Chin-lung, a legislative caucus whip of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), noted that according to results of a China Times poll released Friday, approval ratings for Chen and the DPP have both dropped to a record low of 18 percent.
Tsai warned that if the DPP continues to defend the president and undergird his leadership, it will only squander opportunities for the party to tide over the crisis.

He deplored the extent to which some DPP members, including legislators, "debased themselves" by criticizing former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh in a "vulgar and vicious" manner for launching a campaign to oust the president.
Tsai admired the courage of DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung for stating openly that he felt "ashamed" of the bad manners demonstrated by fellow DPP members in leveling criticism against Shih.
"The DPP must reflect upon itself, heed the voice of Taiwan's people and distance itself from the president. This is the only way the DPP can expect to make a comeback as a political party," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTHING ILLEGAL FOUND IN PRESIDENT'S CONTROVERSIAL BANK ACCOUNT

TEXT.P: An investigation by the Control Yuan concluded Friday that nothing illegal was found in President Chen Shui-bian's Taishin International Bank account, which an opposition lawmaker had alleged was being used to launder money.

Hsieh Yu-nan, director of the Control Yuan's department in charge of reporting on senior officials' private assets, said the president did not include the suspected account in his six reports to the Control Yuan as of November 2005.
Moreover, what Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiu Yi called Chen's "secret account" was in fact closed before the law governing political contributions went into effect, Hsieh said.
Therefore, he said, the president's Taishin Bank Nanmen Branch Office account has broken neither the public functionary private assets registration law nor the political contribution law.
He noted that said account was set up Jan. 5, 2004 and closed April 1, 2004. The presidential election was held March 20, 2004.
Since the account was closed right before the political contribution law took effect April 2, 2004, there is no question that the bank account was -- as alleged -- in violation of the law, he said.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party has claimed that the disputed account was set up to receive campaign donations.

The Control Yuan said that according to law, candidates must register their assets with the Central Election Commission (CEC) when they apply for candidacy, and that it is the CEC's duty to determine whether the president should have registered his Taishin Bank account with the CEC or whether it had been used properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TAKE EFFORTS TO PROMOTE INTEGRATED AUTOMOBILE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The government will upgrade Taiwan's technology and expertise within the integrated automobile industry in coming years, a senior official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday.

Huang Jung-chiou, head of the MOEA's Department of Industrial Technology, announced the plan at a closing ceremony of the Executive Yuan's 2006 conference on strategies to develop industrial technology, which began Aug. 14 at a hotel in Taipei.

More than 100 officials, academics and experts in the industrial manufacturing sector attended the four-day conference to discuss four major topics -- smart cars, intelligent living space, the soft electronics manufacturing industry and enterprise solutions platforms for information and communications technology (ICT).

On the topic of "smart cars, " over the next four years the government plans to inject NT$6 billion (US$184 million) into the automobile industry to upgrade automobiles to include high-end information and communications technology, as well as other relevant technologies that would save fuel, cut down on pollution and minimize accidents, Huang said.
It has been assessed that the upgrade in technology could create trade opportunities worth some NT$300 billion for related local businesses in the automobile sector, according to the MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SU RECEIVES JAPANESE SUMO WRESTLERS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang welcomed on Friday 42 Japanese sumo wrestlers who are on a five-day visit by showing them the best Taiwan has to offer -- the Taipei 101 building, Taiwan-grown fruit and hand puppets.
This is the first visit to Taiwan by a Japanese sumo team since the end of World War II, and the first foreign visit for the Japanese sumo team in 13 years.
"That shows the strong cultural connection between Taiwan and Japan," Su said at a reception in Taipei 101 before presenting the sumo wrestlers with gifts of Taiwan-made fruit and hand puppets.

Su described the visiting wrestlers as "Japan's national treasure," and said he was glad to see exchanges between Taiwan and Japan are at an all-time high, with visitors between the two countries exceeding 2.4 million and bilateral trade exceeding US$60 billion last year.
A 42-game promotional sumo tournament will be held at the Taipei Arena on Saturday and Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CONDEMNS CHINA FOR PERSECUTING HUMAN RIGHTS LAWYERS, ACTIVISTS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) condemned China Friday for persecuting human rights activists, saying Beijing should release all detained activists and lawyers immediately and offer its people due rights protection.

The denunciation came on the heels of foreign wire service reports that Gao Zhisheng, an outspoken Beijing lawyer who launched a rotating hunger strike to protest police brutality against lawyers and dissidents early this year, has been detained by Chinese security authorities since Tuesday.

The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward China, said China has imposed constant surveillance on human rights activists, political dissidents, Falun Gong followers and pro-democracy activists, particularly those who dare to stand up to corrupt communist authorities and expose social injustices.

Stressing that the international community should not keep silent on China's persecution of its political dissidents and human rights activists, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said major international human rights organizations should voice strong concern about China's abuses and violations.

Noting that human rights protection, the realization of social justice, the promotion of democracy and rule of law are common duties of civilized countries around the world, Liu said China's human rights abuses and unwarranted arrests and persecution of political dissidents and human rights activists are in stark contrast to its recent rise as an economic powerhouse.
As Taiwan is always concerned about China's human rights status and political development, Liu said China should strive to improve its human rights record for the well-being of its own people.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN, OVERSEAS CHINESE INVESTMENT GROWS NEARLY FOURFOLD

TEXT.P: Approved investment by overseas Chinese and foreign nationals during the first seven months of this year increased nearly fourfold over the same period last year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Thursday.

Figures released by the MOEA showed that its Investment Commission approved 861 investment cases submitted by overseas Chinese and foreign nationals between January and July of this year, valued at a total of US$8,341.89 million, up 386 percent from the same period in 2005.
In July alone, there were 195 newly-approved cases submitted by overseas Chinese and foreign investors, with the total reaching US$1,396.38 million.
The Investment Commission had said earlier this month that the total value of overseas Chinese and foreign investment in Taiwan for 2006 was expected to set a new record.

Figures also showed the commission approved applications from 37 Taiwanese companies to invest a total of US$431.5 million abroad. For the January-July period, there were 289 approved cases totaling US$2,223.17 million, representing an increase of 38.15 percent.

Taiwanese investment in China also increased 31.38 percent in the first seven months of this year, with 601 cases approved, totaling US$3,943.23 million, including 82 cases in July totaling US$386.97 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER TO ATTEND U.S.-TAIWAN DEFENSE CONFAB

TEXT.P: Deputy Defense Minister Ko Cheng-heng will attend an annual U.S.-Taiwan defense industry conference to be held Sept. 10-12 in Denver, Colorado, military sources said Friday.

The conference, the fifth of its kind since 2002, will be organized by the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, a private U.S. association dedicated to promoting trade, economic and financial relations between Taiwan and the United States in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

In the past, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) tended to send its deputy defense minister in charge of armament affairs to the meeting. If Ko, who is in charge of military policy and strategic affairs, attends the meeting, it would set a precedent.
MND officials said that as the conference will focus on themes related to defense industry policy, it would not be unusual to send Ko to the meeting.
Ko is expected to deliver a keynote speech on Taiwan's policy toward defense industry development and its stance on arms procurement at the opening ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K.-BOUND PASSENGERS URGED TO STAY VIGILANT

TEXT.P: Passengers bound for the United Kingdom should remain extra vigilant with regard to their personal safety, the Consumer Protection Commission under the Executive Yuan said Friday.

The commission made the call after receiving a notice from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) earlier in the day that the yellow-level travel advisory for U.K.-bound travelers remains in place as Britain may still fall victim to terrorist attacks after it uncovered an alleged plot earlier this month to blow up trans-Atlantic planes in mid-flight.
The commission advised U.K.-bound travelers to check up on various foreign airport security inspection measures on the MOFA's consular affairs Web site at www.boca.gov.tw prior to overseas travel.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUG. 19 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Aug. 19:
11:40, President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend an annual meeting of an association of Tainan County natives residing in Taipei.
13:45, Premier Su Tseng-chang will watch a Japanese sumo match at Taipei Arena.
15:45, Vice President Annette Lu will attend the opening a woodcarving festival in Sanyi, Miaoli County.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO HOLD SEMINAR ON IMPACT OF CHINA'S RISE

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will organize a seminar Aug. 24-25 on the implications and impacts of China's rise as a big power on the Asia-Pacific geopolitics and security situation, an official said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun told a news conference that many famed academics from the United States, Japan, Britain, Sweden, India, Thailand and Hong Kong will attend the two-day seminar.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu will deliver a keynote speech on China's rise and relations across the Taiwan Strait, Liu said, adding that the seminar will focus discussions on how Asia-Pacific countries are grappling with challenges arising from China's accession to big-power status.

High on the agenda will be topics related to China's economic development strategies, crisis management and prevention, regional strategy as well as challenges to Taiwan and response strategies adopted by the U.S. and Japan, Liu said.
Academia Sinica's Asia-Pacific research center will co-sponsor the seminar, Liu said.

Meanwhile, Liu said Taiwan welcomes the inception of the Cross-Strait Tourism Exchange Association in Beijing which is expected to handle technical details regarding expansion of tourism exchanges Taiwan and China.
"The establishment of the association is a positive step toward the realization of Taiwan's further opening to Chinese tourists by year's end," Liu said.

In April, China unveiled a package of regulations to lay the groundwork for Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan. It also mentioned that a private association will be created to manage day-to-day affairs, including negotiations with Taiwan.

"After a long wait, the organization was finally inaugurated. We have long designated the Taipei-based Travel Agent Association as our intermediary body to deal with its Beijing counterpart. We are hopeful that the two bodies will speed up talks to hasten realization of policy goal of allowing more Chinese citizens to sightsee in Taiwan and get a taste of Taiwan's democratic way of life, " Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OUTPACES SOUTH KOREA IN RATIO OF DOCTORS PER 1,000

TEXT.P: Taiwan outpaces South Korea, Singapore and China in terms of the ratio of doctors per 1,000 head of population, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Saturday.
In 2005, Taiwan had 1.7 doctors for every 1,000 people, lower than the ratio of 2.56 doctors per 1,000 people in the United States and 1.98 doctors in Japan, DGBAS officials said.
Nevertheless, Taiwan's number of doctors per 1,000 people was 0.13 higher than South Korea's ratio, 0.3 higher than Singapore's and 0.54 higher than that in China.

Quoting tallies compiled by the Department of Health, the officials said Taiwan had 19,433 medical institutions at the end of 2005, marking an increase of 193 from the 2004 level. Of the total, 18,877 were clinics, up 227, while the number of hospitals decreased 34 to 556 because of mergers.
Meanwhile, Taiwan had 4.6 nurses for every 1,000 people, lower than America's ratio of 9.37 and Japan's 7.79, but higher than Singapore's 4.24, South Korea's 1.75 and China's 1.05.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 19, or the 26th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under U.S. tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch a full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980 and again from 1982 until he was elected U.S. president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years in detention.
1966: An earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a U.S. withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- "glasnost" and "perestroika" -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stresses that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits the Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
1999: The Taiwan Independence Party nominates its chairman, Cheng Pang-chen, as its candidate for the ROC's next presidential election slated for March 2000.
2000: An agreement sending International Cooperation and Development volunteers from the ROC to Nicaragua is passed during a regular meeting of the Executive Yuan.
2001: A 36-hour course on conducting election campaigns launched by the newly-established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Taiwan's 95th political party, begins at the Grand Hotel Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but once you try to figure out a thing, you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Wiretap Project Ruled Illegal. A federal judge in Detroit ruled Thursday that the government's warrantless domestic wiretapping program is unconstitutional and must be halted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 3-day weekend starts today
A three-day non-working weekend starts today for 31.5 million workers, 1.4 million of whom are in government service, occasioned by the observance of the 128th birth anniversary today, Aug. 19, of the late Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon, and the 23rd death anniversary on Monday, Aug. 21, of Sen. Benigno "Ninoy" Aquino Jr.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Big sea cleanup ordered
JORDAN, Guimaras -- Seeking to defuse what experts warned was a ticking ecological time bomb, President Macapagal-Arroyo ordered the deployment of more ships, equipment and personnel to check what has become the country's worst oil spill disaster.
The Philippine Star: Nurses' oath-taking stopped
The Court of Appeals (CA) stopped yesterday the scheduled oath-taking of new nurses who passed the licensure examination conducted last June, which was tainted by the alleged leakage of exam questions.
The Manila Times: Petron Corp. faces probe into oil spill
Petron Corp. faces a congressional investigation over the oil spill in Guimaras, Iloilo, that has blackened kilometers of coastline and disrupted the lives of thousands of fisherfolk.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times North Korea
nuclear test feared: report Reclusive North Korea, which last
month defied the international community by test-firing missiles,
could now be preparing its first test of a nuclear bomb, U.S.
officials as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CONDEMNS CHINA FOR PERSECUTING HUMAN RIGHTS LAWYERS, ACTIVISTS(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) condemned China Friday for persecuting human rights activists, saying Beijing should release all detained activists and lawyers immediately and offer its people due rights protection.

The denunciation came on the heels of foreign wire service reports that Gao Zhisheng, an outspoken Beijing lawyer who launched a rotating hunger strike to protest police brutality against lawyers and dissidents early this year, has been detained by Chinese security authorities since Tuesday.

The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward China, said China has imposed constant surveillance on human rights activists, political dissidents, Falun Gong followers and pro-democracy activists, particularly those who dare to stand up to corrupt communist authorities and expose social injustices.

Stressing that the international community should not keep silent on China's persecution of its political dissidents and human rights activists, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said major international human rights organizations should voice strong concern about China's abuses and violations.

Noting that human rights protection, the realization of social justice, the promotion of democracy and rule of law are common duties of civilized countries around the world, Liu said China's human rights abuses and unwarranted arrests and persecution of political dissidents and human rights activists are in stark contrast to its recent rise as an economic powerhouse.
As Taiwan is always concerned about China's human rights status and political development, Liu said China should strive to improve its human rights record for the well-being of its own people.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN, OVERSEAS CHINESE INVESTMENT GROWS NEARLY FOURFOLD(repeat)

TEXT.P: Approved investment by overseas Chinese and foreign nationals during the first seven months of this year increased nearly fourfold over the same period last year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Thursday.

Figures released by the MOEA showed that its Investment Commission approved 861 investment cases submitted by overseas Chinese and foreign nationals between January and July of this year, valued at a total of US$8,341.89 million, up 386 percent from the same period in 2005.
In July alone, there were 195 newly-approved cases submitted by overseas Chinese and foreign investors, with the total reaching US$1,396.38 million.
The Investment Commission had said earlier this month that the total value of overseas Chinese and foreign investment in Taiwan for 2006 was expected to set a new record.

Figures also showed the commission approved applications from 37 Taiwanese companies to invest a total of US$431.5 million abroad. For the January-July period, there were 289 approved cases totaling US$2,223.17 million, representing an increase of 38.15 percent.

Taiwanese investment in China also increased 31.38 percent in the first seven months of this year, with 601 cases approved, totaling US$3,943.23 million, including 82 cases in July totaling US$386.97 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER TO ATTEND U.S.-TAIWAN DEFENSE CONFAB(repeat)

TEXT.P: Deputy Defense Minister Ko Cheng-heng will attend an annual U.S.-Taiwan defense industry conference to be held Sept. 10-12 in Denver, Colorado, military sources said Friday.

The conference, the fifth of its kind since 2002, will be organized by the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, a private U.S. association dedicated to promoting trade, economic and financial relations between Taiwan and the United States in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

In the past, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) tended to send its deputy defense minister in charge of armament affairs to the meeting. If Ko, who is in charge of military policy and strategic affairs, attends the meeting, it would set a precedent.
MND officials said that as the conference will focus on themes related to defense industry policy, it would not be unusual to send Ko to the meeting.
Ko is expected to deliver a keynote speech on Taiwan's policy toward defense industry development and its stance on arms procurement at the opening ceremony.

A new Singapore is needed to lure a new generation of tourists here and boost the services sector. This will ensure that jobs in this sector remain here and provide opportunities for Singapore workers, said Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew last night.

Economic conditions favorable for good growth in Singapore in next five years. Japan is recovering; Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore are doing well; China and India are growing fastest and lifting up the whole region, said Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew last night.
