DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Officer Called Haditha Routine; Marine Said Deaths Didn't Merit Inquiry.
The Marine officer who commanded the battalion involved in the Haditha killings last November did not consider the deaths of 24 Iraqis, many of them women and children, unusual and did not initiate an inquiry, according to a sworn statement he gave to military investigators in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE TO VISIT JAPAN SEPT. 12-17

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will depart for Japan Sept. 12 and return to Taiwan Sept. 17, according to a news statement released Saturday by Lee's office.
The six-day trip will be made purely for the purposes of sightseeing and cultural exchanges, the statement said, adding that the details of Lee's itinerary are still being arranged.
Lee first indicated his plan to visit Japan in September during a news conference Aug. 13 in the southern city of Kaohsiung.

According to Japan's public station NHK on Thursday, the Japanese government has agreed in principle to Lee's visit since Lee is visiting the country for sightseeing purposes and has no intention of engaging in political activities.

It will be Lee's third trip to Japan since his retirement in May 2000. He first visited Okayama prefecture in April 2001 to receive medical treatment for heart disease and made a second trip between December 2004 and January 2005 to several Japanese cities, including Nagoya and Kyoto.
Lee had originally planned to visit Japan again in May this year but cancelled the trip after catching a mild case of tuberculosis in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S COMPETITIVENESS IN 2005 RANKS 2ND IN ASIA: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's competitiveness ranked second after Hong Kong among 79 Asian economies in 2005, slipping from first place the previous year, according to a report released Friday by Singapore's Institute of Policy Studies (IPS).
Other economies on the top five list were Singapore, Guangdong and Malaysia, in that order.

The study was conducted by the IPS in cooperation with Nanyang Technological University on 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, 35 Indian states and union territories, 34 greater China economies including Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan and 31 Chinese provinces, municipalities and autonomous regions. Japan and South Korea were not included in the study.
Among the Chinese provinces and municipalities surveyed, Shanghai ranked sixth, Beijing ranked eighth, Zhejiang ranked ninth, Macau ranked 10th, Jiangsu ranked 11th and Shandong ranked 13th.
In terms of business environment, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau seized the top three places, in that order.
Taiwan placed third in terms of economic environment, government efficiency and social environment, lagging behind Hong Kong and Singapore.
Meanwhile, the study showed that China is better than India in terms of infrastructure, the standard of education and political development.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Peace mission to Lebanon approved.
Both the Cabinet meeting and the House and Senate committees approved unanimously Friday the deployment of Italian troops in Lebanon as part of a 15,000-man United Nations peacekeeping force aimed at securing peace in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TAKES CYCLING TOUR TO PROMOTE TAIPEI'S RIVERSIDE PATHS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, heading a group of city officials, conducted a cycling tour Saturday to promote Taipei City's riverside bike trails, which cover a distance of over 100 km.

Ma set off on a rented bicycle at Tachia Riverside Park in the northern city district of Tachih and rode to Taipei County's Kuantu, where he met up with Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei and his team of cyclists.
Before departing, Ma noted there are eight places along the trail where bicycles can be rented, and they can be returned at any of the other rental stations.
The facilities are easy to use and designed to provide the public with a healthy and relaxing leisure activity, the mayor said.
There are currently six bicycle trails along different rivers and creeks throughout Taipei city and county, with a track length totaling 250 km.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBALIZATION HAS LED TO WIDENING GAP BETWEEN RICH AND POOR: CEPD

TEXT.P: The trend of globalization has led to an inequitable distribution of wealth and a widening gap between rich and poor in Taiwan, the nation's top economic planner said Saturday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, was commenting on reports by the Directorate General of the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics that the income of Taiwan's wealthiest group was 6.04 times that of the poorest group in 2005, or slightly higher than 6.03 in 2004, showing the gap between the rich and the poor has made no remarkable improvement.
Hu said that Taiwan's economic performance is actually quite good, but because of globalization wealth distribution is not equitable.
The fruit of Taiwan's economic growth was enjoyed by 30 percent of people instead of being shared by the remaining 70 percent of people, he added.
Hu said that amid globalization, Taiwan cannot raise wages in view of China's cheap labor. Thus, salary increases are not in proportion to economic growth.
Since workers have not felt the benefits of economic growth, they will naturally feel blue, Hu said.

But he stressed that "the government has made great efforts, " citing such short-term measures as social welfare programs, temporary short-term work, as well as providing long-term vocational training.
"Without such efforts on the part of the government, the gap between the rich and the poor would be even larger," He said.

He said the CEPD will pay close attention to the matter from a long-term perspective, saying that equitable wealth distribution will have to depend on long-term policy, create job opportunities for disadvantaged groups, and provide an equal quality education for children in remote areas so as to gradually narrow the gap between rich and poor.
Per capita income in Taiwan now stands at over US$15,000, Hu said, and the CEPD envisions that it will surpass US$30,000 by 2015.

Hu said the CEPD hopes the benefits of economic growth will be shared by all, saying the council would actively address the nation's long-term issues, such as a graying population, industrial transformation, the nurturing of talent pool, and the strengthening of research and development as well as the service industry.

He noted that research by Global Insight, a leading economic and financial analysis, forecasting and market intelligence organization, showed that Taiwan's per capita income may reach US$32,700 by 2015, compared with South Korea's US$31,100.

Touching on why Taiwan's economic growth has not translated into an increased income for its people, Hu said this was due to the depreciation of the new Taiwan dollar over the past few years. (By Lilian Wu) endite/diGm

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWYERS LAUNCH SIGNATURE DRIVE CALLING FOR PRESIDENT'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Representatives of 14 bar associations around the country launched a signature-gathering campaign Saturday urging President Chen Shui-bian to resign over the recent spate of alleged corruption scandals surrounding his administration and family.

The initiators of the campaign included former Taiwan Association for Human Rights President Wei Chien-feng, former Consumers' Foundation Secretary-General Su Chin-hsia, former Taipei City councilor Chiu Chin-tien, former Taipei Bar Association board member Tai Sen-hsiung and Hsinchu Bar Association President Lo Ping-cheng.
They said they hope to collect at least 1,000 signatures from their colleagues.
The lawyers said in a joint statement that only if Chen resigns will Taiwan be able to "say goodbye to corruption and welcome the rule of law."
They said when Chen -- a lawyer turned democratic activist -- won the presidency on March 18, 2000, all members of the profession were proud of his achievements.

However, a number of recent developments prove that Chen can no longer assume responsibility for promoting the rule of law and clean politics in the country, they said. These include the alleged irregularities involving Chen's family members and close aides, his failure to disclose his assets truthfully, his alleged use of others' receipts to claim expenses under his special state affairs expense allowance and the alleged collusion between his administration and business groups, they noted.
Even worse, the judicial investigations into these cases are not trusted by the public and are eroding the foundation of social justice, they said.
Various private groups have called on Chen to step down following the exposure of the alleged scandals.

While a group of pro-Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) academics issued an open letter urging Chen to resign to take responsibility over the allegations last month, a group led by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh is set to stage a large-scale demonstration starting next week to further pressure the president to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA'S VICE MINISTER OF COMMERCE TO VISIT TAIWAN IN LATE AUGUST

TEXT.P: India's vice minister of commerce and industry in charge of investment, Ajay Dua, will head a trade delegation to visit Taiwan in late August to seek Taiwanese investment in his country, an official of Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday.
India, being one of the promising "BRIC" countries (Brazil, Russia, India and China) , is the largest country in South Asia, boasting a population of 1.09 billion.

To profit more from trade with BRIC countries, the MOEA's priority is to help domestic entrepreneurs develop markets in Russia, Brasil and India in accordance with the consensus reached at a July conference in Taiwan on the nation's sustainable economic development.
In a period of increased economic exchanges between Taiwan and India, Ajay Dua's visit will mark the highest-level official within India's government to visit Taiwan in recent years.

During the delegation's stay in Taiwan from Aug. 31 to Sep. 2, Ajay Dua will introduce India's business climate and trade opportunities at a trade seminar to be jointly held by the MOEA and India-Taipei Association Sept. 1.

Ajay Dua will focus on India's industries of leather, shoe making, and textile machinery, and introduce the business climate in the provinces of Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, and West Bengal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES RICE AID TO AFRICAN COUNTRIES, LAOS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has plans to ship 17,500 tons of rice this year to Swaziland, Lesotho and Laos as a form of relief to poverty-stricken people in those countries, COA Agriculture and Food Agency officials said Saturday.

With the cooperation of World Vision Taiwan, the COA donated and transported 5,000 tons of rice to Swaziland in May, the official said, noting the rice is likely to feed an estimated 105,000 people for four months.

A few days ago, 2,500 tons of COA rice was shipped to Lesotho for destitute children, people suffering from chronic diseases and those who are infected with HIV/AIDS. Some 64,400 individuals are expected to be benefited by Taiwan's donation, according to the COA.
As for Laos, the council is scheduled to begin transporting 10,000 tons of rice there in September to help relieve the country from an urgent demand for food.
Besides the aid, the COA will also assist Laos in creating a "food guarantee" mechanism as part of efforts to help the country forever resolve the problem of food shortages, the COA officials said.
Due to limited rice production, most children living in poverty in Laos suffer from serious malnutrition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S OUSTER SHOULD BE ACHIEVED THROUGH LEGAL MEANS: DPP

TEXT.P: Anyone who wants President Chen Shui-bian to step down should seek to achieve that goal via legal means rather than taking to the streets, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday.

Yu pointed out the country's laws stipulate the president will be removed from office if he is impeached, if a presidential recall proposal is passed in a public referendum or if he is convicted of sedition or treason.
However, so far Chen has not been proven to have committed any crimes, Yu noted.

Yu said while he respects the protesters' freedom to express their opinions, trying to topple the president through public demonstrations will only severely jeopardize political stability and affect the life of local residents, he said.
He claimed the method will also result in a vicious cycle that encourages people to resort to the same methods of toppling those in power in the future.

Yu made the remarks during a trip to the northeastern county of Yilan, ahead of a large-scale demonstration initiated by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh to pressure Chen to step down over alleged corruption scandals.

In June, the opposition People First Party (PFP) and its ally, the Kuomintang, initiated a motion to recall Chen on grounds that Chen should take responsibility over alleged irregularities involving members of his administration and family. But the motion failed to obtain the support of a two-thirds majority in the legislature -- the threshold that must be passed before such a motion can be put to a public referendum.

Early this month, the PFP further initiated a campaign to impeach Chen in the wake of revelations that Chen had failed to disclose his assets truthfully and allegedly used receipts received by others to claim state affairs funds.

The impeachment motion must be endorsed by more than 50 percent of legislators before it can be presented to the legislature for consideration. If more than two-thirds of legislature votes for the motion, it will be referred to the Council of Grand Justices for review. The president will be removed from office if the council finds the impeachment motion well-grounded.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION TO INCREASE WITH STABLE CLIMATE

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) officials estimated Saturday that production of several agricultural goods is expected to increase over last year if no serious natural disasters occur before year's end.

Unlike last year when several strong typhoons hit Taiwan the weather so far this year has been fine, causing agricultural officials to revise production estimates upwards for several agricultural goods, such as tea, pomelos and oranges.
According to the COA crop estimate report, tea production will reach 20,417 metric tons this year, a growth of nine percent over the previous year.

The officials forecast orange production will reach 225,874 metric tons this year, an increase of 17 percent over last year, while production of Chinese honey oranges will reach 111,704 metric tons, registering a 20-percent year-on-year growth.

Starfruit production is estimated to reach 24,086 metric tons this year, a growth of 15 percent over last year, while pomelo production will reach 75,409 metric tons, an increase of eight percent over 2005, the officials added.

As damage caused by recent minor typhoons has been recuperated, the production of vegetables will resume, the officials said, estimating production of leaf vegetables to reach 38,334 metric tons in August, a slight increase of three percent over July.
As for cut flowers, August production of chrysanthemums and lilies is expected to decrease eight percent over July, while rose output will increase three percent over the previous month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH SPEED RAIL TO BEGIN COMMERCIAL OPERATIONS AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Speed Rail (HSR) will begin services at the end of October as scheduled, the contractor constructing the railway said Saturday.

In a press release, Taiwan High Speed Rail Corporation (THSRC) denied media reports of a possible second delay in launching commercial services for the new system, following the company's postponement of operations last September from Oct. 31 to the same day this year.
THSRC said that since Aug. 1 the company has been engaging in trial operations of the new system, with different drills in normal, unusual and emergent scenarios.
All of the work is aimed at ensuring the system will offer guaranteed safety in railway transportation service, THSRC noted.

The Taiwan HSR line runs approximately 345km from Taipei in northern Taiwan to Tsoying in Kaohsiung in the south of the island, passing through 14 major cities and counties, and 77 townships and regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Quake aid 'is linked to terror suspects'
The Pakistan earthquake appeal has emerged as a potential link between some of the terror suspects arrested over the alleged plot to destroy transatlantic aircraft using liquid bombs, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO 'BODY PACKERS' ARRESTED FOR DRUG TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Two men were arrested at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport early Saturday for attempting to smuggle heroin into Taiwan by concealing the drugs inside their body.

Acting on tips that two men from central Changhua county were planning to smuggle illegal drugs into Taiwan by concealing the contraband in their body cavities, police intercepted the duo at CKS Airport upon their return from Thailand.

The two body packers, identified by their family names as Huang and Yao, were taken to a hospital for X-ray examinations which showed suspicious substances inside their bodies. They were given enemas and eight small packs of heroin wrapped in condoms were removed from their bodies.

Police warned that using body cavities for smuggling contraband is extremely dangerous and life-threatening because the packages may rupture and leak internally. The two "mules" have been transferred to the Changhua Prosecutor's Office for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS 'NOT TO FALL NO MATTER WHAT DIFFICULTIES LIE AHEAD'

TEXT.P: Embattled President Chen Shui-bian strongly reaffirmed Saturday his commitment to fulfilling his mandate, saying he "will never fall no matter what difficulties may lie ahead."

The president made the remarks while delivering a speech to supporters from his hometown in Tainan County at a gathering in Taipei. Also on hand were Premier Su Tseng-chang, Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen, ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Taipei mayoral candidate Frank Hsieh, as well as several DPP legislators.

Chen, facing public demands for his ouster in the wake of a series of corruption and embezzlement allegations implicating himself, his family members and top aides, said he was particularly heartened by the boost from his long-term supporters.
Chen pledged he will put up with any difficulties ahead, saying "no matter how vicious the attacks and smears are, I'll stick to my guns and will never fall or lose my will."
The president refused -- even under heavy pressure -- to renege on the mandate given him by voters, vowing to "bravely go down the right path and pursue my goals and campaigns."
He stressed that he would follow the path of "insisting on a separate identity for Taiwan, and the realization of social justice."

He reaffirmed his four goals -- increasing investment in Taiwan, creating employment opportunities, narrowing the gap between urban and rural areas as well as the gap between rich and poor. A recent report by the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics showed that the income of Taiwan's wealthiest individuals was 6.04 times that of the poorest in 2005.

The president said he would also insist on three campaigns -- joining the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, crafting a new Constitution that would be "timely, relevant and viable," and retrieving the opposition Kuomintang's ill-gotten assets, which were obtained during the authoritarian era.
He said he as an individual is insignificant, but that safeguarding Taiwan is very important, saying "everyone should cherish what Taiwan has today."

"What is the meaning if we continue this boisterous squabble," he asked, adding that if "incessant fighting throws Taiwan into a pandemonium, and China takes advantage of the situation to invade Taiwan, then what good will it bring to Taiwan?"
The president said that Taiwan is a democratic country, and democracy means freedom and rule of law, which he said is the pride of Taiwan.

But he urged respect for this freedom, saying that if the public does not heed the rule of law it will mean chaos for Taiwan. Any problems should be solved within a legal framework, and should not be settled through violence or means outside the existing system, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO TAKE LEGAL ACTION AGAINST MEDIA OVER FALSE REPORTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will take legal action against media outlets that have recently made unfounded reports targeting the president, an official from the Presidential Office said Saturday.

David Lee, director of the Department of Public Affairs, made the remarks after China Times daily claimed that the Presidential Office had repeatedly used NT$10 million (US$306,750) gift vouchers from a posh department store to obtain reimbursement from the "state affairs fund" set aside for President Chen's discretionary use, thus embezzling around NT$30 million from the state fund.

Lee, quoting Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general to President Chen, said the reports were totally unfounded, adding that the reports did not quote investigators from the Taiwan High Prosecutor's Office and were "purely speculation."

Lee stressed that the president has always respected the judiciary system, and that judicial authorities are currently investigating the case, and that the office "will not comment on the individual case.'
As for false reports by some media, Lee said the Presidential Office is sorting out all related information and will file lawsuits in due time.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT'S IMPROPER TO HANDLE CONSTITUTIONAL PROBLEMS WITH RALLIES: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that she does not believe it is proper to handle the country's constitutional problems with mass movements.

Lu made the remarks after 14 lawyers' associations around the country joined a campaign launched by former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh to depose President Chen Shui-bian, who has been caught up in several corruption scandals allegedly implicating his family members and close aides.
While attending a seminar, Lu discussed factors that have caused what she described as "the current unrest in society."
One political factor, she added -- the power transfer from the Kuomintang (KMT) to the DPP -- still has not completely rooted out the concept of a "rule by man," a belief that is still held by many.
In addition, Taiwan has too many elections, and because of these costly elections those who win sometimes try to recoup their losses from the elections after assuming the post, Lu went on.

As for economic factors, Lu said the relocation of many domestic enterprises to China has seriously damaged Taiwan's industries, while an era of knowledge-based economies and globalization has created enormous challenges for traditional industries -- and more unemployment.

Referring to lawyers joining in the campaign to oust President Chen, Lu stressed that constitutional problems should be handled in accordance with the Constitution. Noting the opposition-proposed motion to recall President Chen did not clear the legislature, Lu said this indicates the case has been resolved through constitutional procedures.

Upset over so many social and political disturbances, as well as financial burdens, some 4,200 people chose to commit suicide last year, Lu said, adding that this is why she organized a series of seminars to promote social harmony, reconciliation among political parties, as well as peace between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lu urged the public to hold a rational attitude toward dealing with various challenges facing the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE APPROVE ROUND-THE-CLOCK SIT-IN ON KETAGALAN BOULEVARD

TEXT.P: Taipei city police conditionally approved Saturday a controversial application for staging a "round-the-clock" sit-in in front of the Presidential Office on Ketagalan Boulevard to pressure President Chen Shui-bian to step down.

The application was filed by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh and his supporters earlier this week as an attempt to push Chen to resign over a spate of corruption allegations implicating his family members and aides.

According to police, the planned 24-hour sit-in campaign can be held from Aug. 23 to 10 p.m. Sept. 7, excluding the day of Aug. 26, when another organization has been approved to hold activities on Ketagalan Boulevard.
In order to maintain tranquility in the neighborhood, the use of horns, sirens and loudspeakers are banned between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m each day during the period.
Explaining the planned "anti-Chen" campaign, police said that the organizers call it a "public forum, " which will be attended by 1,000 activists and headed by Shih.
Only the section of Ketagalan Boulevard spanning between Park Road and Chungshan South Road are allowed for the sit-in, the police noted.

Since the authorities in charge of assembly and parade activities are local police district stations, under the Assembly and Parade Law the proposed Ketagalan sit-in can be carried out after the Chungcheng police district station gives the green light.

This is the first time police approval has been secured for a round-the-clock rally, according to Taipei city police, who said tallies show that in the past every rally in the capital city only lasted about three or four hours.
It will be a tough challenge for police to maintain order and peace in the upcoming 15-day campaign aimed at ousting the president, they said.

Shih and his supporters have been calling for 1 million citizens to come out to support deposing President Chen after several of his family members and close aides were allegedly involved in a string of corruption and embezzlement scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WON'T COVER UP PRESIDENT'S MISTAKE IF HE REALLY MADE ONE: YU

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday that the party would "absolutely not cover up" President Chen Shui-bian's mistake if he has really committed one.

At a training seminar held for DPP party staff in Taipei County, Yu said the current campaign organized by former DPP Chairmen Shih Ming-teh to oust President Chen is "wrong, " as he believes Chen has made no wrongdoing in the corruption scandals allegedly involving his family members and close aides.

If the president really makes an error, the public can press him to step down through constitutional procedures, such as a recall or impeach motions, Yu stressed, urging the public not to resort to those movements outside the constitutional system.
Noting that the corruption allegations are still under judicial investigation, Yu urged stronger solidarity among members of the DPP in promoting reforms within the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU HAPPY TO SEE CHEN FOCUS ON 'TAIWAN FIRST' FOR REMAINDER OF TERM

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is happy to see President Chen Shui-bian is committed to fulfilling his mandate of "Taiwan first" during the remainder of his term, which expires in May 2008, a legislative caucus whip of the pro-independence party said Saturday.

TSU Legislator David Huang made the remarks in the wake of the beleaguered president's pledge that he "would never fall, no matter what difficulties may lie ahead," and that he would follow the path "of insisting on a separate identity for Taiwan and on the realization of social justice."

The president, dogged by a series of corruption and embezzlement allegations implicating himself, his family members and top aides, pledged to pursue four goals -- increasing investment in Taiwan, creating employment opportunities and narrowing the gap between urban and rural areas as well as the gap between rich and poor.

The president also said he would insist on three campaigns; namely, joining the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, crafting a new Constitution that would be "timely, relevant and viable," and the return of the opposition Kuomintang's ill-gotten assets.
Huang said that President Chen's advocacy "conforms with former President Lee Teng-hui's line," and the TSU would offer him full support. Lee is the spiritual father of the TSU.
He expressed hope that President Chen would speed up reforms and deliver on promises during the rest of his term in office.

Meanwhile, as long as Premier Su Tseng-chang -- who had earlier advocated a more open cross-strait policy -- can identify with the "Taiwan first" concept and work with President Chen's goals and campaign, the TSU will throw its support behind him.

Huang said the TSU does not care who serves as premier, whose appointment lies with the president, but that it is concerned whether the premier's administrative ideals are in line with the former president's.

DOC.HEADLINE: AWARD-WINNING DOCUMENTARY EXPLORES LIFE AND DEATH

TEXT.P: Facing life and death is never easy, but the award-winning documentary "Doctor" tries to explore the meaning of life and death by telling the story of a Taiwanese doctor who loses his only son to suicide and then a Peruvian boy to cancer.
The documentary, which was directed by Chung Mong-hong and won the award for best documentary in the 2006 Taipei Film Festival, will premiere Sep. 29.
In the film, Chung begins with an unusual case of teen suicide occurring on July 4, 1996, in which 13-year-old Felix Wen, Wen Pi-chian's only son, hangs himself in the closet for unknown reasons.
Trying to come to terms with Felix's death, Wen -- a radiologist in Iowa, U.S. -- later spends time with Sebastian, a Peruvian boy who arrived in the U.S. with his parents to seek cancer treatment.
During the treatment, Dr. Wen looks back at Felix's short life and tries to save the boy. However, Sebastian dies the following year.

"This documentary does not try to be a tear-jerker, as I was attempting to keep a distance in this film," said Chung, who took three years to produce the work. "I think it's important to face life and death with more sense than sensibility. We need to face it, cope with it and not fear it."
He does not expect to come up with the answer to life and death with this film, because these are unpredictable events, Chung said.

"The story of Felix Wen tells us that not every case of teen suicide occurs due to a lack of attention and care from one's parents. Every teenager has his own character and different way of thinking," said Claire Teng, a psychiatrist at Municipal Wang Fang Hospital.
Chung said Wen Pi-chian and his wife were model parents and Felix Wen was a bright student with a maturity beyond his age. The only unusual thing was that he talked about death a lot.
Just as Chung demonstrated in the film, sometimes life and death are very complicated and hard to explain, Teng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Timothy J. Hwang)
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Ford Is Slashing Production 20% for 4th Quarter
The Ford Motor Company, which is struggling to keep its grip on second place in the American car market, said Friday that it would cut by one-fifth the number of vehicles it plans to build in the final three months of the year.
The slowdown represented the deepest production cuts since the industry's crisis of the 1980's. It also underscored the difficulty that Detroit, whose business relies on sales of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, is having as gas prices remain around $3 a gallon. Detroit's market share has dropped to its lowest level in history, while Asian brands, known for their fuel efficiency, are setting sales records.
Wall Street Journal:Why Israel's Plans To Curb Hezbollah Went So Poorly
When its bombs began falling on southern Lebanon 39 days ago, Israel had high hopes that it could severely damage or even destroy Hezbollah, the militant Islamist group rooted there. Crippling it, they and their Washington allies hoped, would rid Israel of an implacable enemy. It would also set back Iran, a longtime supporter of the group, at a crucial time in Iran's nuclear negotiations with the West.
But with the fighting stopped, Hezbollah remains far from defanged. Indeed, in many eyes it is the victor, having faced down the mighty Israeli military and hugely enhanced its standing with the anti-Israeli populations across the Mideast.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMED ESSAYIST EXPRESSES VIEWS ON CAMPAIGN TO DEPOSE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's current priority lies in refining its liberal democratic system rather than deposing President Chen Shui-bian through populist means outside the country's legal system, a renowned essayist said Saturday.

Lung Ying-tai, whose poignant and critical essays have in the past contributed toward Taiwan's democratization process, made the remarks at a seminar for her new book, entitled "Please Convince Me with Civility."

Referring to an ongoing "one million people" campaign launched by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh to unseat President Chen over a spate of corruption allegations implicating his family and aides, Lung said that despite her personal respect for Shih, she did not "see eye-to-eye" with him on what constitutes Taiwan's urgent priorities.

"Taiwan has come a long way in the pursuit of democracy. Its most important goal at present is not which individual should step down or ascend to power. Its most urgent task lies with consolidating and refining its democratic system, as well as upgrading the quality of its democracy," Lung said.

If upholding Taiwan's democratic system and its quality are core values, Lung said, one's thinking would not center around how to boot out Chen, nor on using drastic means or "shedding blood on the streets" to depose the president.
As people didn't have the right to elect national leaders under authoritarian rule, Lung said, they could not but use radical means to protest injustices or government brutality.

"But gone are the days of taking to the streets or resorting to violent means to express discontent with the administration or those in positions of power. Nowadays, we have universal sufferage. Every citizen has the right to vote in political elections," Lung said.

At this time of political turmoil, Lung said the greatest challenge to Taiwan's people is how to control their angry emotions and to really understand what the nation's ultimate core values and goals are.

Quoting passages in her recent essay, titled "Character, " Lung said the historical meaning of the failed opposition-initiated motion in late June to recall Chen lies in confirming the value of following due process of law to hold a head of state to political responsibility.

"What really matters is whether the motion succeeds or not. What really matters is that the people of Taiwan, through the recall motion in the legislature, have unequivocally declared that democracy is not populism, " Lung explained, adding that this same judgment principle is applicable to Shih's ongoing campaign against Chen.

Shih, who was jailed for 25 years during Taiwan's martial law era for his pro-democracy and pro-independence stance, launched the "one million people" campaign last weekend to pressure Chen to resign and will start a round-the-clock sit-in near the Presidential Office to keep up heat on Chen when one million ordinary citizens have each donated NT$100 to show their support for his cause. The campaign has so far received enthusiastic response from Chen's detractors, including the ruling party's previous supporters.

Lung said she respects and admires Shih as a true hero. But Lung said she has not made any donation and disapproves of the Shih-led populist campaign because she most yearns to see at present is the refinement Taiwan's democratic quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY, SCHOOL PLAY IMPORTANT ROLES IN TEEN SUICIDE PREVENTION

TEXT.P: A group of social workers said in a seminar Saturday that families and schools can play a key role in preventing teenagers from committing suicide, as the year's fifth case of teen suicide was recently discovered in southern Taiwan.

In fact, there are far more teens who consider committing suicide than people imagine, said Hsiao Hui-ying, President of the National Alliance of Parents' Organizations. It's just a few who really take action, he said.

"Today, the thoughts running 'round teenagers' minds are highly complicated. If you don't spend time with them, there's no way to understand them. This is why parents should be able to listen [to what their children say] and allow kids to make mistakes," said Cheng Pi-hua of the Humanistic Education Foundation (HEF).
In school, where teenags spend most of their daily lives, the importance of "life education" should be stressed and teenagers' self-respect and dignity should be protected, not abused, Chang said.

While it is almost impossible to prevent teen suicide, adults should pay closer attention to their kid's behavior and talk with them to better understand their state of mind, said Claire Teng, a psychiatrist at Municipal Wang Fang Hospital.
According to statistics from the Department of Health, between the years 2000 and 2005, suicide ranked as the eleventh greatest cause of death for those under 14 in Taiwan.
A HEF report indicated that lack of emotional control was the main reason for teenager suicide, and committing suicide is a way to express anger and seeking help for teenagers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DISMISSES RUMOR OF REPLACING PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday any plot to drive a wedge between him and Premier Su Tseng-chang will be futile.
Speaking at a gathering with his supporters from his hometown in Tainan County, Chen said rumors were circulating in recent days that he would soon replace Su.
"The rumors are ill-motivated to sow seeds of discord in my administration. I would not fall into the trap, " Chen assured his supporters.
Amid the pall of corruption allegations implicating Chen's family members and close aides, the approval ratings of both Chen and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party have plunged to record lows.
Noting that he and Su are in the same boat, Chen said they have been working in concert to ensure smooth functioning of the government.

In the six months since Su's assumption of premiership, Chen said Taiwan's economy has continued spiking up, with exports recording the highest single-month growth rate in July and trade surplus for the first seven months of the year nearly doubling the year-earlier level. "Su deserves credit for all these achievements," he added.
The embattled president also said he will travel to Palau early next month to attend the first summit meeting between Taiwan and its South Pacific allies.

Despite the domestic political upheaval, Chen said he will embark on the diplomatic mission as scheduled. "We have spent more than half year preparing the meeting," Chen said, adding the government plans to hold a similar summit meeting with the country's African allies in the future.
Taiwan suffered a diplomatic setback earlier this month with the central-north African country of Chad switched recognition to Beijing from Taipei.
Chen said the government will redouble efforts to shore up ties with all of its diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 SANYI WOOD-CARVING FESTIVAL KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The Sanyi Woodcarving Festival, one of Taiwan's most important annual cultural events, kicked off in the hilly township of Sanyi in northern Miaoli County Saturday with much fanfare.

Vice President Annette Lu attended the outdoor opening ceremony to wish the event a great success. She lauded the Miaoli county government for its ardent efforts in organizing the festival to promote woodcarving arts and tourism.
The festival, now in its 14th year, will showcase more than 200 works by woodcarvers from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Indo nesia, Vietnam and 14 African countries, including Ghana and Mali.
Many noted Asian and African woodcarving artists and craftsmen traveled to Sanyi to attend the opening ceremony and celebrate the beauty and diversity of woodcarving arts.
Maioli County Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung said this year's activities feature exotic themes to promote cultural exchanges with Asian and African countries.

With "metamorphosis and a happy life" as the festival's main theme, Liu said that the festival's series of woodcarving demonstrations and training programs will enable interested individuals to experience the beauty of woodcraft and stimulate their interest in the art.
Sany has been known internationally as the center of Taiwan's woodcarving and woodworking industry. Its streets are perfumed with the fragrance of freshly cut sawdust.
In 1995, the Miaoli Wood Sculpture Museum was established to house sculptures by members of both aboriginal and Han groups in Taiwan, and representing numerous ethnic traditions around the world.
As Miaoli County is one of Taiwan's major Hakka communities, many Hakka artifacts and culinary specialties will be showcased during the festival which will run until aug. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 20, or the 27th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1741: Danish explorer Vitus Bering discovers Alaska on a mission sponsored by Russia.
1833: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, is born. The first Pan-American Conference took place (1889) during his administration, which passed the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in 1890.
1860: Raymond Poincare, French statesman and president from 1913 to 1920, is born.
1905: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had been exiled for his involvement in the anti-Ching movement, organizes the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo. The organization, headed by Dr. Sun, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1912: William Booth, British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army in 1878, dies at the age of 83.
1925: Liao Chung-kai, one of a 16-member steering committee that established a national government in July 1925, is assassinated in Canton, five months after the demise of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Peking. Liao was 47.
1928: Both the Wen River and the Mi River in the province of Shantung overflow their banks, drowning 18,000 people and leaving some 30,000 others homeless.
1940: A total of 153 Japanese military aircraft carry out a heavy bombing raid on Chungking, the war-time capital of the Republic of China.
1940: Radar is used for the first time, with the British employing it during World War II.
1940: Leon Trotsky, one of the leaders of the Russian Revolution, is stabbed to death by a Spanish communist with an alpine ax in his home in Coyoacan, near Mexico City. He was 61.
1944: Representatives of China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics meet in Washington, D.C., to discuss the establishment of a world organization after World War II.
1944: Rajiv Gandhi, former Indian prime minister, is born. The son of Indira Gandhi was assassinated on May 21, 1991.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a second invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14, 1945.
1955: Gen. Sun Li-jen, chief military aide to the president, submits a request for disciplinary action against himself as a gesture of self-reproach in regard to a communist espionage case involving Kuo Ting-liang.
1967: A total of 247 people, including Taipei City Councilor Lin Shui-chuan, are arrested for attempting to stage an armed rebellion for Taiwan independence.
1968: Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops begin the invasion of Czechoslovakia in an attempt to crush the "Prague Spring" reforms.
1972: The Republic of China Mei Ho baseball team defeats a U.S. team from California 9-0 to win the Senior League world title.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Lugar, chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lugar says that the U.S. government has not changed its basic support of the Republic of China and that he hopes the ROC will open its markets to reduce the ROC-US trade deficit.
1988: A U.N.-mediated cease-fire between Iran and Iraq takes effect, ending nearly eight years of war.
1995: An express train collides with another train in northern India, killing nearly 300 passengers and injuring more than 200 others.
1999: The Central Bank of China announces that Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments surplus amounted to US$5.47 billion, the highest single-quarter total in 12 years.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation arrive in Gambia at the start of his one-week, three-nation African tour which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad.
2001: Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation makes its 300th bone marrow donation, with the recipient a college student in Hangzhou City, in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to sift out, but when you once try to sift out a thing, you must never give it up until you have sifted it out clearly and distinctly."

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI TO PRESENT NEW TECHNOLOGIES AT INVENTION SHOW

TEXT.P: The non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) is set to present a large number of new technologies for commercial applications at an upcoming international invention exposition in Taipei.

The ITRI -- the key industrial research and development arm in Taiwan established by the government to attend to the technological needs of the country's industrial development -- will display some two dozen new technologies at the 2006 Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart (TIIST) slated for Aug. 31-Sept. 3 at the Taipei World Trade Center for the convenience of private companies which are interested in applying the ITRI know-how in their production processes.

The new technologies to be displayed include a process for making PV inverters, which are also known as a high voltage commercial scale power conversion gear capable of producing solar photovoltaic utility interactive renewable energy. Also to be displayed is a portable blood test kit -- an easy-to-operate electroluminescent micro date instrument that can detect multiple metabolites in a single drop of blood.

The TIIST -- Taiwan's largest technologies and patent rights exhibition -- is expected to attract some 310 inventors and high-technology organizations and companies from home and abroad to take part and present some 1,000 of their latest cutting-edge technologies and products. Big names from abroad taking part in the show include Lockheed Martin, GE and Mitsubishi.

Some 500 new technologies in the fields of semiconductors, photocatalysts, wireless telecommunications and printed solar PV panels are set to be traded during the show, according to officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), one of the key sponsors of the exhibition.

On the sidelines of the TIIST will be a workshop on international technology transfers, with representatives from research and academic institutes from Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States, South Korea, Israel and the host Taiwan taking part.

According to the MOEA officials, the number of registered new technologies owned by the ITRI, the military Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology and other research institutes in Taiwan and ready to be provided to private companies for commercial application has reached 18,000 to date.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAILY APOLOGIZES TO PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW FOR DIAMOND RING REPORT

TEXT.P: The Chinese-language United Daily News published an apology on its front page Sunday for alleging without prior verification in an Aug. 18 report that President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, had pawned off a large diamond ring through a friend.

In the printed apology, the editorial department of the newspaper -- one of four mass-circulation dailies in Taiwan -- said it would like to apologize to Chao; his friend Su Teh-chien, former chairman of Taiwan Development Corp.; as well as readers for failing to verify the story with Chao and Su before publishing the report that Chao had asked Su to sell a 13-carat diamond ring for him.
The United Daily News made the apology after Chao threatened through his attorney to file a libel suit against the newspaper.

The daily's Aug. 18 report said that Chao had asked Su to sell the diamond ring worth about NT$16 million (US$490,722) shortly after Chao was released on bail July 10 following 47 days in detention on charges of insider trading.

The report alleged that the diamond ring was now in the hands of a Hong Kong-based jeweler for a tentatively agreed price of about NT$6 million -- nearly NT$10 million lower than the ring's actual value.
In a July 10 indictment, prosecutors recommended that both Chao and Su be sentenced to eight years behind bars on charges of insider trading.
Asked about his reaction to the printed apology by the United Daily News, Ku Li-hsiung, Chao's attorney, said that it "is not completely satisfactory but acceptable."
Ku said he will advise his client to call off his plan to file a libel suit against the newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Reppublica: Tragedy in waters near Lampedusa, 10 illegal immigrants drown.
A 10-meter boat with more than 100 illegal immigrants on board was discovered in waters near Lampedusa Saturday. Some 70 were rescued and 10 others were dead. The authorities estimated that another 40 were missing. All of the illegal immigrants were Africans of various nationalities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA PLANNING TO ALLOW PRIVATE COMPANIES TO RUN AIRPORTS

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) is planning to allow private companies to operate commercial airports in an effort to help the government balance its books.

The CAA will shortly invite companies from the private sector to offer suggestions on privatizing airports, officials from the administration have said. Under the current civil aviation law, only government agencies or local governments are allowed to run airports

According to the Ministry of Audit, 15 out of the 18 airports in the country have been losing money in recent years. Among the 18 airports, only Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway; Hsiao-kang Airport in the southern port city of Kaohsiung; and Taipei City's Sungshan Airport have been making money-making.
The combined deficit of the 15 other airports, most of which are located in offshore areas, exceeded NT$900 million (US$27.5 million) for 2005, ministry officials said.

CAA officials attributed declining business in the domestic air service market mainly to the opening of the second north-south freeway in recent years. The opening of the high-speed railway along Taiwan's west corridor later this year is expected to further dent the money-losing domestic air service business if remedial measures are not adopted shortly, they added.
Late last year, the legislature asked the CAA to conduct a study and come up with a remedial plan within 10 months.

Against this backdrop, the officials said, the CAA began from late last year considering allowing private companies to run airport operations without compromising the government's jurisdiction over navigation, control towers, as well as airport security and quarantine affairs.
Allowing private companies, including foreign firms, to run certain aspects of the airports will help diversify the airports' operations, they said.

It is hoped that opinions and suggestions from the private sector on privatizing airports can be referred to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications by the end of this month for approval, facilitating the CAA's efforts to make appropriate revisions to the current law and submit them to the Legislative Yuan in September for approval, the CAA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REITERATES 'HANDS-OFF' STANCE REGARDING DRIVE TO OUST CHEN

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) reiterated Sunday its "hands-off" stance regarding a nationwide campaign to oust President Chen Shui-bian but disclosed that a KMT ad hoc task force has begun gauging possible developments in the populist movement.

KMT Policy Coordination Committee Director Tseng Yung-chuan made the remarks when answering questions from reporters as the sit-in movement led by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh is slated to kick off Sept. 2 on the square in front of the Presidential Office -- ahead of the originally scheduled date of Sept. 9.

Tseng stressed again that the KMT will not meddle in the activity so as to avoid confrontation between the "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan-green camp, " although he said that the party has not banned individual KMT members from taking part.

He also revealed that a KMT task force already met once last week to study possible developments in the movement and that it will continue to meet to assess countermeasures to deal with any scenarios that may arise.

Meanwhile, Shih's office estimated that at least 200,000 people will participate in the sit-in aimed at ousting President Chen, who has been embroiled in scandal allegations involving himself, his family and close aides in recent months.
As of Friday, a total of NT$81.2 million had been collected in Shih's campaign calling on "one million people each to donate NT$100 for the sit-in" since its launch on Aug. 14.
Shih said when cash donations reach the NT$100 million target, he and his supporters will immediately begin the planned sit-in.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN POLICE LAUNCH CAMPAIGN AGAINST FRAUD, DRUGS IN MILITARY

TEXT.P: Police on the outlying island of Kinmen have launched a campaign to help military personnel prevent fraud scams and drug abuse, according to a spokesman for the Kinmen county police station.

Kinmen police authorities have sent officers to explain the notion and useful methods to personnel and troops stationed at military bases across the island on how to stay alert against increased burglary, drug abuse and scams by fraud rings as a growing number of military members have fallen into these kind of traps set by criminal rings, the spokesman said.

He warned military personnel to pay extra attention to fraud scams through telephone or cell phone text messages or lottery and tax rebate fraud by criminals posing as members of government agencies -- such as post, tax and labor insurance offices.
The Kinmen police authorities are planning to hold 50 seminars on the subject to help combat these crimes to which more and more military personnel have fallen victim, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY MAY IMPACT TAIWAN'S DOMESTIC AIRPORTS: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Aviation officials expressed concern Sunday that the scheduled opening of the 345-km high-speed railway linking Taipei and Kaohsiung in October may drive another nail into the coffin of most of Taiwan's 16 domestic airports.
The officials noted that the 16 domestic airports in Taiwan and its outlying islands have seen their passenger volumes plummet since the government began implementing an open-sky policy 10 years ago.

Citing Sungshan Airport in Taipei City as an example, the officials said the airport handled some 500 flights per day 10 years ago but that the number of daily flights has dropped to less than half that figure at present.

The opening of 12 east-west highways in the past four years and the inauguration of Taiwan's second north-south expressway in early 2004 have brought increased convenience to road travelers but have also caused domestic airlines to lose many customers, the officials noted.
They expressed fear that the opening of the high-speed railway linking Taiwan's two largest cities in northern and southern Taiwan may add to the airports' difficulties.

Although the Civil Aeronautics Administration plans to use outsourcing management services to run these airports, they will continue to be dogged by the major problem that there are simply not enough passengers, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIRAYA SCENIC AREA ADMINISTRATION OFFERS TREK TOURS TO DRAW VISITORS

TEXT.P: The National Siraya Scenic Area Administration and nine hotels in southern Tainan county have jointly marketed a two-day "Discovering Siraya" trek on a trial basis in the hopes of attracting visitors to the newly opened scenic area, according to an administration spokesman.

Administration Director Tseng Han-chou, said that the experimental "Discovering Siraya" activity will kick off Sept. 18 to help the public gain an understanding of the newly established scenic facilities in Tainan county.

There are three different routes on which visitors can enjoy treks, passing through the surrounding areas of the Tsengwen Reservoir, Wushantou and Hutoupei, respectively, Tseng said, adding that the administration will sponsor 12 tours on each route.

Visitors taking part in the tours will only be required to pay for accommodations, while the administration will take care of the meal and transportation expenses, Tseng said. The results of the trial activity will serve as a reference for the administration to perfect future tours on a regular basis, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TECH TREK 2006 ENDS WITH FRUITFUL RESULTS: NSC

TEXT.P: This year's Taiwan Tech Trek program ended with fruitful results Saturday night, with 277 members presenting their research findings and artistic works at the farewell party in Taipei, a National Science Council (NSC) spokesman said Sunday.

The program, organized annually by the NSC since 2005, hosted these "trekkies" -- young Taiwanese studying overseas -- with eight-week internships at 53 institutes and companies around the island in the hopes of convincing them to work in Taiwan after graduation.

During the Saturday night event, the trekkies offered works on topics ranging from "Palm-sized LED Microscope" and nanotechnology research to genetic medical science and "beetle-nut babes" field observations.

Ethan Lan, the inventor of the LED microscope, said he used the seven weeks at the National Applied Research Laboratories (NARL) to work on his gadget -- a tiny metal barrel with a diameter of only five centimeters which can offer a magnification of up to 10x.

The device, equipped with both ultra-violet and white LEDs, can also be used for detecting counterfeit banknotes and verifying credit cards, he said, adding that he and his colleagues at the NARL have started a new project to make devices with magnifications up to 30x or 50x.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE BEMOANS UNFAIRNESS OF KMT'S ASSETS REPORT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui accused the KMT Sunday of trying to divert the public's attention away from the issue of the party's assets by focusing on investment losses during the time he served as party chairman.

According to a statement issued the same day by Lee Teng-hui's office, Lee said that it is extremely unfair for the KMT to only focus on the NT$42.7 billion in investment losses during the period when he concurrently served as ROC president and KMT chairman between 1988-2000 in its report on the party's assets and liabilities to be made public Wednesday.

The KMT has been Taiwan's largest opposition party since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power in 2000. Lee stepped down from the presidency and from the party chairmanship that same year.

The statement said that it is unfair for the KMT to fail to mention how much money Lee helped the party earn to maintain the party's operations -- some NT$8 billion per year -- during the period of his presidency. It stressed that Lee's morality and behavior can be fully scrutinized by the public.
The KMT, as Taiwan's ruling party during that 12-year period, had the responsibility to assist in government-led investment projects both at home and abroad, the statement said.

Pointing out that "these kind of projects were all thoroughly screened by a set of mechanisms within the KMT, the statement claimed that "there is no way that just one or two people could make a final decision on these issues."

The KMT should not ascribe its present financial difficulties to only a part of its failed investments in the past, the statement said, adding that public now is more concerned about the party's net assets -- an issue that it pointed out the KMT must provide a clear explanation of to the public.

As to a plan by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to put the KMT's asset issue to a public referendum, KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen called it "political fighting" and expressed his regret over the DPP's plan to do so.

According to KMT legislative caucus whip Tsai Chin-lung, the party's assets currently amount to only about NT$6 billion or NT$7 billion when its some NT$80 billion in debts and over NT$40 billion in investment losses are subtracted. He said the party's assets amounted to as much as NT$140 billion during the period when Lee served as chairman.
The KMT will give a detailed report to the people on Aug. 23 on how it has handled its assets, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO EVENTUALLY WITHDRAW FROM ALL BUSINESS OPERATIONS: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou vowed Sunday to see to it that the KMT eventually withdraws from all businesses operations that have nothing to do with party affairs.
Ma said that following its withdrawal from media outlet operations last year, the KMT has begun moving to withdraw from other business operations not related to party affairs.

Citing the fact that a proposed political party law will stipulate that no political party should engage in business operations, Ma said he agrees that political parties have a legitimate right to own property and other assets but should not operate businesses for commercial gain.
"Quitting all business operations is the KMT's set policy, " Ma reiterated.

Ma said that he has asked his staff to tackle the controversy over the KMT's assets "as soon as possible" since being elected chairman in July last year and that now it's time for him to give some explanations on the changes concerning the KMT's assets since 1949 and the current make-up of the KMT's properties one year after becoming the leader of the party.
Ma is scheduled to explain Wednesday how the party has handled its assets, which its rivals claim are "ill-gotten" assets acquired during the party's five-decade rule of the country before 2000.

On Ma's planned explanation on a report on the KMT assets Wednesday, Tsai Chin-lung, a KMT legislative caucus whip, stressed that the report -- prepared by the party's Deputy Secretary-General Chang Che-chen and lawyer Lee Yung-jan -- does not target any specific individuals and instead is an "objective and comprehensive account of changes in the party's assets, including investment profits and losses, over the past five decades.

Tsai made the remarks in response to a newspaper report Sunday which quoted the KMT assets report to be released Wednesday as indicating that former President Lee Teng-hui, who doubled as the KMT chairman during his 10-year stint as the ROC president, had squandered some NT$42.7 billion (US$1.3 billion) on failed investment projects.

Tsai dismissed speculation that the report is going to come as a bombshell in Taiwan's political arena, saying that the report -- describing how the assets were managed when Chiang Kai-shek, Chiang Ching-kuo, Lee Teng-hui, Lien Chan and Ma Ying-jeou were at the helm of the party -- has been compiled for the sole purpose of dispelling the public's misunderstandings concerning the KMT over the years.

Meanwhile, a private group is reportedly planning to initiate a nationwide referendum to try to force the KMT to return its assets to the national coffers. The group questioned last week why the KMT assets, valued at around NT$150 billion (US$4.58 billion) under the leadership of former Chairman Lien Chan between 2000 and 2005, have diminished precipitously to some NT$5 billion since Ma took over the party's helm last year.

Discounting the report as "the result of misunderstanding, " Ma said that this is exactly why he will explain following a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday how the party has handled its assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW RAZOR BARBED WIRE BARRICADES WON'T BE USED FOR SIT-IN: POLICE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The new batch of razor barbed wire barricades recently acquired by the Taipei City police will not be used in an upcoming demonstration being organized to push for President Chen Shui-bian's ouster, a Taipei City police officer said Sunday.

Pan Hung-hua, the director of the Logistics Division under the Taipei City Police Department, said the barricades were provided by the the National Police Agency (NPA) for use in protecting public buildings against terrorist attacks, and not for crowd control at public rallies.
He said the barricades will not be used in the upcoming sit-in demonstration being organized by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh with the aim of ousting the president.

Pan was responding to warnings Sunday by Taipei City Councilor Lin Yi-hua of the opposition Kuomintang who demanded that police not use the barricades for public rallies as the sharp edges of the metal strips on the razor wire pose a safety hazard.
Lin said she used a chunk of pork to test how sharp the barbs are and was surprised to find that the fang-shaped blades could easily pierce through the meat.
The sit-in being organized by Shih is tentatively scheduled to take place Sept. 2 on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

A NPA spokesman acknowledged Sunday that the agency bought 6,600 new-typed barricades after London's Heathrow Airport mounted an anti-terrorist operation recently, triggering a worldwide alert for international airports.
He explained that these barricades are not targeted at people staging protest demonstrations, but are meant for protecting public buildings against terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: 52 PATIENTS WITH RARE DISEASES ENJOY TRIP

TEXT.P: A group of 52 patients with rare diseases wrapped up a two-day trip to Hsinchu County Sunday, thanks to the help of a group of volunteers and the private non-profit Rare Disease Foundation.

The patients, who suffered from 17 different diseases and 13 of them are confined to wheelchairs, were accompanied on the trip by 63 family members, 13 volunteers, 19 staff members from the Rare Disease Foundation and one doctor.
They toured the Window on China Theme Park in Lungtan, Taoyuan County, lodged at a leisure farm near Hsinchu city and tried their hands at making rice noodles for dinner at that farm.

A mother, who toured with her two sons with multiple sclerosis, said having a trip is something she and her sons daren't imagine as their daily life is preoccupied with visiting doctors and their only journey is between the hospital and their home.
Because she had seldom gone out to any place other than the hospital , the woman said she would lost even outside the small township she lived.

A patient who had been honored as an distinguished teacher before falling victim three years ago to primary pulmonary hypertension said he used to avoid visiting crowded public places because his desease makes him out of breath for just walking a few steps and he often being scorned by others for walking so slowly in a crowd.

The former teacher said he really valued the pleasure of this trip and the chance to learn that he is not alone in his fight against his disease, there are many others who are fighting their diseases persistently and bravely everyday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Timothy J. Hwang)
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:
Every year since 1999, New York City has reported that it has all the money it needs to pay for the pensions that have been promised to city workers.
With the retirement plans said to be financially sound, state politicians have happily showered city employees with generous pension enhancements -- annual cost-of-living increases, holiday bonus payments, early retirement with full benefits -- that are the envy of private- sector workers, whose pension benefits have eroded.
But a close inspection of city pension records shows that the funds committed to the plans may fall well short of the city's promises to hundreds of thousands of current and retired workers. They look fully funded chiefly because the city has been using an unusual pension calculation that does not comply with accepted government accounting rules. Even the city's chief actuary, who helps produce the annual reports, says the official numbers are "meaningless" when it comes to showing the plans' financial health.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 21, or the 28th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal-gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: Republic of China Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: A massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes in Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian Parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of a coup attempt by hardliners.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
1999: Over 96 percent of the Kuomintang's party delegates vote to support Vice President Lien Chan as the party's candidate in the following spring's presidential election.
2000: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui proposes the establishment of an Asian monetary fund to promote economic cooperation in Asia.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his Gambian counterpart Yahya Jammeh sign a joint communique pledging to continue enhancing close cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterates while meeting with visiting Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli that the ROC government will abide by the memorandum of trade and investment signed by the ROC and Paraguay to further cement the established ties between Taipei and Asuncion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LAUNCHES 'HEALTH-AT-WORK' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Sports affairs authorities have designed a set of stretching exercises for working people in their on-going program aimed at promoting regular exercise for the sake of good health.

The National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) published a CD featuring the stretching exercises last week and has been working to distribute the CDs and training kits since then to Taiwan-based enterprises in the hopes that they will promote exercise among their employees, according to the council.

According to a NCPFS survey in 2005, the number of people in Taiwan who do not exercise amounted to 26.7 percent of the total population. The survey also found that those who do not like sports are predominantly white-collar workers.

Last year, the number of Taiwan people who exercise regularly increased to 15.5 percent of the whole population from 11.8 percent a year ago. However, when compared with the figure of 30 percent in Japan, there is still a lot of work to be done to encourage more Taiwan people to exercise regularly, NCPFS Deputy Minister Chen Yu-hsin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANGHAI FAVORITE CHOICE FOR AIRLINES OFFERING CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Shanghai has proven to be the favorite choice among domestic airlines applying to operate cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services for the upcoming Mid-Autumn Festival, Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Monday.

CAA officials said six domestic airlines have applied to provide a total of 24 cross-strait charter flights between Sept. 29 and Oct. 8. Among the 24 flights, 16 are between Taipei and Shanghai, compared with four each to and from Beijing and Xiamen.

The officials noted that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reached a consensus in early July that airlines from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can operate passenger flights during the Chinese New Year, Tomb Sweeping Festival, Dragon Boat Festival and Mid-Autumn Festival holidays between Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Xiamen in China and Taoyuan and Kaohsiung in Taiwan.
For this year's Mid-Autumn Festival, which falls on Oct. 6, cross-strait flights will be offered between Sept. 29 and Oct. 13, the officials said.

Among the six domestic airlines, EVA Airways Corp., Trans Asia Airways and Far East Air Transport Corp. have applied to fly to and from Shanghai, while China Airlines and Mandarin Airlines have applied to fly to and from both Shanghai and Beijing.
UNI Airways Corp. has only applied to fly to and from Xiamen. No airline has applied to fly to Guangzhou, CAA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP POLITICIAN LAUNCHES DRIVE IN SUPPORT OF PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) politician in the southern port city of Kaohsiung called on the public Monday to donate NT$1 each to express their support for President Chen Shui-bian.

The campaign was launched to counter a drive initiated by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh aimed at forcing Chen to resign over alleged corruption scandals. Shih has called for 1 million people to donate NT$100 each to sponsor the cause.
Hung Ping-lang, who is running for Kaohsiung City councilor, said he aims to fill 2,500 piggy banks and raise NT$750,000 for charity.
Accusing Shih of causing social unrest and undermining a local DPP-led administration, Hung urged the public to take part in his campaign to show their disapproval of Shih.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT DENIES PLANNING TO RESIGN OR QUIT DPP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu denied Monday rumors suggesting that she plans to resign or quit the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

In a press statement, Lu said she never mentioned any intention of "making a big move" during the DPP's founding anniversary celebration on Sept. 28 and stressed that she has repeatedly called on the ruling and opposition parties to work together to protect the constitutional system and the rule of law.
Lu said nobody has the right to speak on her behalf without obtaining her consent, adding that people should not spread any untruthful or defaming remarks about her.

The vice president was responding to comments made by two local journalists on a TV talk show Sunday. The pair claimed that they had heard from people close to Lu that the vice president would "make a big move" during the DPP's founding anniversary celebration.
While one of them speculated that Lu would announce her decision to resign from the post of vice president, the other speculated that she would announce her decision to quit the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICBC NAME CHANGE DRAWS CRITICISM

TEXT.P: The official designation of the International Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) is scheduled to be changed to Mega International Commercial Bank Monday, drawing criticism from opponents of the move.

Cheng Shen-chi, chairman of Mega Holdings Co., which recently merged with ICBC -- one of the oldest and most reputable banks in Taiwan -- is scheduled to make the announcement on the name change Monday afternoon.

Criticizing the planned name change of the century-old bank, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Fei Hung-tai said he suspects Cheng is making the move as part of efforts to materialize President Chen Shui-bian's goal of "desinicizing" public-run organizations in Taiwan.

Speaking at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan, Fei lashed out at the Ministry of Finance for defying a resolution passed by the Finance Committee of the Legislative Yuan May 29 demanding that the finance ministry submit to the Legislative Yuan an assessment report on the impact of the name change before actually going through with it.
Fei said that the name change should be stopped and that Cheng should be fired by the board of directors of Mega Holdings -- in which the government holds a majority stake -- for dereliction of duty.

Fei threatened to block the budget for the finance ministry in the legislature's next session which begins in September if Mega Holdings' board of directors does not elect a new chairman to replace Cheng.

Also speaking at the news conference, Tsai Chiu-fa, a leader of the ICBC Workers' Union, said the government "has treated the feelings of the 3,400 workers of ICBC and their interests as dirt" by rashly moving to change the name of the bank which was established more than 100 hundred years ago.
