DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Embrace talent, technology to secure S'pore's future: PM.
A global city with citizens firmly anchored to the country and welcoming of new immigrants to add to its vitality.
That was the Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong envisioned last night that would do best in a rapidly changing world.
The Lianhe Zaobao: To attract new immigrants, to connect with emigrants.
The Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said last night that the Singapore's future is bright. Singapore wants to attract more immigrants to keep it's economic growth and have more connections with emigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Cold War Missiles Target of Blackout; Documents Altered To Conceal Data.
The Bush administration has begun designating as secret some information that the government long provided even to its enemy the former Soviet Union: the numbers of strategic weapons in the U.S. nuclear arsenal during the Cold War. (By Jorge Liu)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Israeli Incursion Strains Truce With Hezbollah.
Israeli commandos dropped deep into Lebanon on Saturday, clashing with Hezbollah fighters in a raid at Boudai that left on Israeli soldier dead and put the first serious strain on the region's 6-day-old cease-fire.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT'S LABOR POLICY NOT SATISFACTORY: TSU SURVEY

TEXT.P: The labor policy of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has not been at all satisfactory, according to the results of a survey by the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) which were released Monday.
Ho Min-hao, executive director of TSU's Policy Committee, unveiled the results of the survey on the DPP's labor policy since coming to power in 2000.
Overall, the DPP administration only received a score of 41.19 points for its labor policy in the survey, with 60 points representing a passing grade.

The survey found that most respondents have not felt any dramatic improvement in labor rights since 2000 and that 91 percent of the respondents expressed dissatisfaction with the advancement in labor rights under the DPP administration.

The survey also found that 93 percent of the respondents think that domestic labor unions have not become more powerful since 2000 and that 70 percent think that the planning of labor pensions has not conformed with social justice.
Eighty-four percent said that the current unemployment benefits don't meet the economic needs of the jobless and their families.

The survey also found that 93 percent are not satisfied with the government's foreign labor policy and that 70 percent do not think the government has attached importance to the human rights of foreign laborers.

The survey also found that labor unions and labor movement organizations hope the DPP administration will make reducing unemployment and promoting employment for middle-aged and older workers a priority during the remainder of its term.
The survey was conducted on 100 labor unions and labor movement organizations Aug. 14-17, with 43 valid samples collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC DISPELS RUMORS OF BIRD FLU CASE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A pathogenic analysis report made public by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) Monday dispelled rumors that a human bird flu case had recently been reported in Taiwan.

CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting said that after conducting chemical and pathological analysis, CDC experts found that the samples taken from a man from northern Taiwan were free of avian flu virus, dispelling a rumor circulating around Taiwan over the weekend that a man had died of bird flu.
The fears sparked by the rumor contributed to sharp 215-point drop in the Taipei stock market Monday, one of the steepest single day declines in the Taiwan bourse in recent years.

Lin said the northern Taiwan man, in his 30s, was admitted to hospital recently after displaying symptoms of respiratory disease. The man had not traveled abroad for tourism but he had come into direct contact with live birds, including Japanese white-eyes, he added.
The man is still in hospital, Lin said.

The CDC has sponsored nationwide bird flu drills since Aug. 17 to test the country's ability to deal with an avian flu pandemic despite the fact that Taiwan remains free of the highly pathogenic avian flu.

Recent reports of new cases of bird flu -- including cases in Thailand, Russia and a case in China's Xinjiang Province, in which a person died after being infected with the avian flu virus -- have raised concerns among World Health Organization specialists that the avian flu virus may be making a comeback after having mutated into new and more lethal strains.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES PLUNGE

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange plunged Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 215.16 points to close at 6,505.92.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,715.72 and hit a low of 6,498.18 during trading. A total of 3.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.09 billion (US$2.69 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 5 percent, followed by foodstuff issues and machinery and electronics shares both at 3.9 percent, paper and pulp issues at 3.5 percent, cement stocks at 3.4 percent, textile stocks at 3.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 2.6 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,076 to 49, with 31 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT INVITES FOREIGN STUDENTS TO MAKE STUDY TOURS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Representatives of foreign groups interested in organizing "in-Taiwan study tour" packages began a one-week, inspection-oriented Taiwan tour Monday at the invitation of the Ministry of Education (MOE).
The representatives come from eight countries, including the United States, Japan, Australia, South Korea, Canada, Germany, Malaysia and Singapore.
In an effort to encourage foreign students to get acquainted with Taiwan by visiting the country, the government launched a "Study Tour in Taiwan" program this summer with 20 exquisite travel routes.

It is hoped that the program will not only offer a good opportunity for foreigners to learn Chinese but also attract foreign backpackers to visit townships and villages islandwide to experience the "mosaic culture" for which Taiwan is famous, MOE officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Israel prefers to have Italy leading U.N. peacekeeping force in Lebanon.
Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert told his Italian counterpart Romano Prodi Sunday that Israel prefered to have Italy leading the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon that will be expanded to a 15,000-strong one. France commands the existing U.N. force in Lebanon.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERYONE FREE TO EXPRESS OPINIONS IN DEMOCRACY: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Monday that it is no problem in a free country like Taiwan for anybody to express their own opinions, referring to his deputy's support in public of actions to unseat President Chen Shui-bian.

When Lee was asked by reporters what he thinks about Academia Sinica Vice President Ovid Tzeng's voicing of support publicly the day before for the planned sit-in to be staged in front of the Presidential Office starting next week by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh and his supporters calling for "one million people to come out to depose the president," he answered: "I think it's a good thing that Tzeng, like anybody else in Taiwan, is allowed to express his own opinions on an issue."

Tzeng, who was the first education minister in the DPP administration after President Chen assumed the presidency in 2000, reportedly confirmed during a talk with journalists Sunday that he will pitch in with Shih's campaign after he retires from the post of vice president of Academia Sinica in October. Tzeng reportedly said that he admires Shih's courage in initiating the drive to oust Chen.
President Chen has been embroiled over the past several months in a string of corruption allegations involving his family members and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINGERPRINT FLASH DISKS INTRODUCED ON TAIWAN MARKET

TEXT.P: Flash disks with fingerprint sensors have been introduced into the domestic market recently to further protect users' information, a manager of SanDisk Taiwan said Monday.
The SanDisk CEO noted that the high-tech devices are particularly suited to meet the needs of business people who have to carry a large quantity of documents and information while traveling.
The CEO said the products are already available in United States, with the main buyers being business people.

With its high added value, the fingerprint flash disks are priced high in the United States, where they have registered a market share of only between 1 percent and 2 percent, the CEO said. He predicted that the price of the product will soon drop as it becomes more popular.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES KMT CHAIRMAN TO FACE HIS PAST AS 'STOOL PIGEON'

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) politicians called on opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Monday to face what they called his past as a "stool pigeon" against Taiwan's human rights supporters overseas.
The group said that unless Ma deals with the matter honestly, he will not be qualified to run for the presidency.

They were pointing to allegations that when studying in the United States in the late 1970s and early 1980s, Ma had acted as a spy for KMT government at the time to collect evidence to be used against political dissidents.

Showing a note signed by then President Chiang Ching-kuo approving Ma's appointment as director of the Presidential Office's first bureau on April 22, 1981, DPP Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni claimed that Ma was designated for the post when he was still overseas because he had "performed excellently" as a snitch.
Hsieh said the task assumed by Ma undermined human rights and hampered Taiwan's democratic development.

Meanwhile, Taipei City Councilor Yen Sheng-kuan displayed a picture taken Jan. 28, 1978 in Boston, in which Ma is shown being driven away by a group of Taiwan students studying in the United States who were staging a demonstration against unfair elections and human rights persecution in Taiwan.
According to Yen, Ma was unwelcome by the protesters because he was there taking photos of them, triggering displeasure among the protesters.

Yen said that because Ma had "snitched" on the students, a lot of them were blacklisted by the KMT government and could not return home. However, Ma has never admitted to this or apologized to the victims, he added.

Huang Wei-che, another DPP legislator, said that when the Kaohsiung Incident happened in 1980, Ma and the KMT both considered it a riot, with key participants, including Shih Ming-teh, Yao Chia-wen and Lin Yi-hsiung, being charged with sedition.

However, Ma is now honoring Shih as a hero because Shih is leading a campaign to topple President Chen Shui-bian, Huang noted, urging Ma to face up to history honestly in order to win respect from the public.
In response, Ma challenged the DPP Monday to present evidence to back up the allegations, such as specifying who had been set up by him and what photos he had provided to the KMT.

Ma pointed out that early this year, some people said that Jerome Cohen, his professor at Harvard University, had called him a KMT spy and that Cohen has clarified that the matter was a misunderstanding.

Dismissing the DPP's allegations as ridiculous, Ma said the DPP is only making the allegations to try to divert public attention away from the alleged corruption scandals surrounding Chen's administration and family.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 238 points to close at 6,460, with 51,454 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October dropped 236 points to finish at 6,464, with 269 contracts traded, while December futures lost 246 points to close at 6,450, with 42 contract transactions.
March futures moved down 239 points to close at 6,449, with 23 contract transactions, while June futures dropped 220 points to close at 6,472, with 14 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,698 for September, 6,700 for October, 6,696 for December, 6,688 for March and 6,692 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

September TE futures moved down 12.1 points to close at 278.45, with 6,752 contracts traded, while October TE futures dropped 11.2 points to finish at 279.05, with 29 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 8.65 points to close at 282.1, with four contracts traded, while March TE futures dropped 14.05 points to close at 278.9, with five contracts traded.
June TE futures moved down 3.6 points to close at 284.5, with one contract traded.
September TF futures lost 25.2 points to close at 891, with 2,553 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 23.6 points to finish at 895.2, with 12 contracts traded.
December TF futures lost 17.6 points to close at 899, with 15 contracts traded, while March TF futures moved down 12.4 points to close at 901, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: KRTC CHAIRMAN SPEAKS ON HARMONIOUS LABOR-MANAGEMENT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Relations between the management and Thai laborers have improved greatly since a riot by the laborers a year ago, Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) Chairman Chiang Yao-chung said Monday.
Chiang said the labor-management relations are so harmonious that some of the workers are reluctant to leave after their contracts expire.

He made the remarks on the first anniversary of the riot by Thai laborers working on the southern port city's MRT system construction. The riot was sparked by grievances over the maltreatment of the workers by Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management company, which was commissioned by the KRTC to manage the some 1,700 Thai laborers.

Chiang noted that in the wake of the riots, the company has adopted a series of measures to address the issue, including terminating its contract with the manpower company and setting up an agency exclusively for the Thai workers.
The agency has since improved the laborers' living environment, adopted a more humane way of management and established a communication channel with Thai laborers.

He noted that since the KRTC took over the management of the Thai laborers, it has built more dormitories to relieve the crowded situation and improve the food, sanitation and facilities in the living quarters.
He said that Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Lee Yin-yuan praised the new living quarters during a visit to them in January.

A Thai laborer identified only as Pui said that he wants to stay for another year after his two-year contract expires, and many of his colleagues share his feelings. But he was disappointed to learn that related authorities might not want to extend the contracts.
Over 10,000 laborers are working on constructing Kaohsiung's MRT system, with more than 8,900 being local workers.

KRTC officials said that local workers are still the mainstay of the labor force. The project employs more than 6,600 from Kaohsiung city and county and over 800 from Pingtung County. The MRT system construction project has made a great contribution to employment in southern Taiwan, the officials added.
With Thai laborers working on the project having begun to leave in June, the number of Thai laborers had dropped to around 1,100 as of the end of July.
With nearly 100 Thai laborers leaving each month, the labor shortage problem could become more acute, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.023 to close at NT$32.690.
A total of US$817 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.667 and fluctuated between NT$32.630 and NT$32.742.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD UNCONCERNED ABOUT KMT ROLE IN DRIVE TO OUST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou claimed Monday to be unconcerned about whether his party will become an outcast after former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh launched a campaign to oust scandal-tainted President Chen Shui-bian.

Ma made the comments during an informal meeting with reporters after a planned nationwide sit-in led by Shih to boot out Chen has won enthusiastic response from the public since its launch a week ago.
The headquarters of Shih's campaign has announced that the sit-in is slated to kick off Sept. 2 -- an advance from its earlier projected date of Sept. 9.

Although Ma said that the KMT would not feel squeezed even if Shih succeeds in deposing Chen, he said that the KMT still needs to cautiously gauge its next move and maintain as much flexibility as possible.

But he added that the KMT will not take part in the sit-in, despite the fact that the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" partner, the People First Party, proposed a motion to recall Chen in late June at the Legislative Yuan.
The presidential recall motion failed due to a lack of two-thirds majority approval at the legislature.

The KMT will be closely watching the developments of Shih's campaign to oust Chen, Ma said, adding that Taiwan's political situation has entered "an era of uncertainty" and that the party must be very careful in assessing the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLISHING PARTY ASSETS WOULD VERIFY `HISTORIC TRUTH:' KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: A plan by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to publish a list of its assets and liabilities Wednesday is aimed at helping verify the "historic truth" of the issue, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.
Speaking during an informal meeting with a group of reporters, Ma said his party will honestly face up to history when making the report on its assets and liabilities to society that day.

According to Ma, the report will not target anyone and hold him accountable for the party's investment losses, including former President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently served in the two posts during the 1988-2000 period.

When the KMT was Taiwan's ruling party, it contributed a great deal to the country's development, including the period when Lee was KMT chairman, Ma said, dismissing a media report that he has ever accused anyone of embezzling the party's money.
The Wednesday report will be very transparent and will allow the public to gain a good understanding of how the KMT has handled its assets, according to Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES PUBLIC TO VIEW PRESIDENT'S VISIT IN RIGHT PERSPECTIVE

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang urged the public Monday not to view a state visit to Palau by
President Chen Shui-bian from the perspective of internal affairs.

Huang was responding to questions about the timing of the president's departure against the background of an upcoming sit-in protest campaign in front of the Presidential Office to seek his ouster over a series of corruption and embezzlement allegations against himself, his family members and top aides.
Some opposition politicians have questioned why Chen picked such a time to visit Palau and alleged that he is attempting to evade the looming storm at home.

Huang did not answer directly when asked whether Chen will visit Palau Sept. 3 as earlier reported, saying only that the ministry is finalizing the president's itinerary. The ministry will discuss the matter with the Presidential Office soon and elaborate on the visit in a news conference, he added.

On whether Chen's visit will also cover other countries, or transit through Guam, as Chen did on past visits to South Pacific countries, Huang only said the primary concern will be a convenient time schedule.

He noted that a summit meeting between the leaders of the Republic of China and South Pacific allies has been planned for the last six months and that the agenda of the summit meeting has also been temporarily set.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY CHIEF THREATENS TO DISSOLVE PARTY

TEXT.P: The chief of the tiny opposition New Party, Yok Mu-ming, threatened Monday to dissolve the party unless all of its four candidates in the year-end Taipei city council elections are elected.

In a meeting with journalists, Yok claimed that his party's candidates -- including three incumbent councilors Pan Huai-tsung, Ho Kuan-chun, Lee Ching-yuan and a political novice, Wang Hung-wei -- are the best choices for the city's voters.

Noting that Wang is a journalist with 17 years of experience, Yok said Wang gave up her job to bear the party's standard in the race because of her strong identification with the party's cause of "advancing social justice."
"I will take the loss of any one of them as the party's failure to appeal to its traditional supporters, which would seal the fate of any political party, " Yok said.

In order to ensure that all four of them are elected, Yok said he will serve as Wang's campaign manager in the election and will ask main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou for help by allowing KMT lawmakers who used to be New Party members to stump for New Party candidates.
The New Party, which is a breakaway group of the KMT, boasted 11 councilors in the city council and 21 lawmakers in the legislature during its peak, but now has only one lawmaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIWANESE STUDENTS RECEIVE BTCO SCHOLARSHIPS

TEXT.P: Four Taiwanese students received scholarships from the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) and will soon depart for one-year Master's courses in the U.K., a BTCO official announced Monday.

Michael Reilly, Director of the de facto British embassy, who met with the scholars and said: "Since the start of the BTCO scholarship program in 1990 nearly 200 young Taiwanese have received scholarships to study in the U.K. and have gone on to contribute to the advancement of Taiwan."
Applicants are selected on both their academic strength and their commitment and ambition to make a difference on their return. Each scholarship winner receives 15,000 to 20,000 pounds.

The four scholarship recipients include Yen Shu-yi, who will major in criminology and criminal justice at Loughborough University, Hsu Po-han (environmental technology at Imperial College) , Chan Chi-ya (global politics at the London School of Political and Economic Science), and Amy Hsieh (international political economy at the London School of Political and Economic Science).
The scholarship program is operated by the BTCO and administered by the British Council.
According to the BTCO, U.K. accounts for 28.2% of the Taiwanese overseas study market.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 200,000 WILL TAKE TO STREETS AGAINST PRESIDENT: CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: At least 200,000 people will take to the streets in the first week of a nationwide campaign led by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh demanding that President Chen Shui-bian quit the presidency, a spokeswoman for the campaign predicted Monday.

Ho De-fen, a professor at Nanhua University in southern Chiayi County who serves as spokeswoman for the populist movement to boot out Chen, made the remarks while answering questions from reporters at the campaign's headquarters in Taipei.

As security will be a top concern when Shih and supporters begin gathering from Sept. 2 on the square in front of the Presidential Office to stage a sit-in calling for Chen's ouster, "everything must be ensured" before the activity can kick off, Ho said.

Ho estimated that more than 200,000 people will take part in the demonstration in the initial stage and gave his assurance that the organizers will do their best to maintain order and discipline to prevent provocation and confrontation.

According to Ho, the campaign led by Shih, a pioneer in Taiwan's democracy movement, aims to attract more than 1 million people to take to the streets to "force" Chen to step down. He claimed that it can be considered the second big wave in the country's democratization following the historic power transfer in 2000.

Shih's campaign to oust Chen has gained a warm response from the public since its launch only a week ago, and this can be attributed to the profound awakening of the Taiwan people toward a "disgraceful and unjust national leader," Ho claimed.

If the people display strong enough power to show their desire for Chen's ouster, the president will "not dare" to go abroad at a time when the public are poised to take to the streets against him, Ho speculated.
Chen has announced that he will embark on a visit to Palau and Nauru in early September -- a time that is set to coincide with Shih's campaign.
Chen has been dogged by a series of corruption allegations involving himself, his family members and close aides in recent months and public disgruntlement with him is mounting.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: British kit found in Hezbollah bunkers
An urgen investigation was launched last night after Israel accused Britain of indirectly supplying Hezbollah terrorists with military night-vision equipment that helped them to target Israeli soldiers in Lebanon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU MEMBERS URGED NOT TO GET INVOLVED IN RALLIES FOR OR AGAINST CHEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang said Monday that the public should focus their attention on the problems related to the welfare of the people, instead of working to depose or support President Chen Shui-bian.

Su made the remarks in response to the campaign launched by former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh to oust Chen, who has been caught up in several corruption scandals allegedly implicating his family members and close aides.

Many elite of the society, including lawyers associations and academics, have promised to join the campaign which will launch a large-scale demonstration in front of the Presidential Office in September.
Meanwhile, the DPP supporters will also launch a rally headed by a well-known talk show host on Aug. 26 as a countermeasure against Shih's demonstration.

At the meeting of TSU's central executive committee held Monday, Su ordered TSU staff not to join or involve in all the activities to depose or support Chen, saying that his party will focus its efforts on resolving the problems related to the welfare of the people and the economy of the country at a time when the political situation is unstable while laborers are suffering hardship.
Su also expressed worry that violent conflicts may break out during those activities in favor of and against Chen, which he said may cause Taiwan's democracy to move back.
Su urged all the politicians launching those activities to oust or support Chen to try to prevent bloody conflicts or assume their responsibilities for the possible violent conflicts.
Former President Lee Teng-hui, who is the spiritual leader of TSU, has said recently that these campaigns to get rid of Chen will do nothing good to Taiwan.
Lee urged Chen to resolve his own problems by saying that TSU respects all the activities in favor of or against Chen, but will not involve in them.
Lee also urged other political parties not to involve in the activities to prevent possible bloody conflicts.

Meanwhile, Su added, Monday is the first anniversary of the riot caused by some 100 Thai laborers working on the mass rapid transit (MRT) railway project in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, but the fact of the riot has not been clear so far.
Su urged the Council of Labor Affairs Minister Lee Ying-yuan to prevent such incident to occur again.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO JOIN DPP IN PROMOTING REFERENDUM TO RECLAIM KMT'S ASSETS

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) announced Monday that it will cooperate with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to promote a public referendum to reclaim the ill-gotten assets of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang said the party has collected 40,000 signatures in support of the campaign and will put forth along with the DPP a proposal to hold the referendum.
Last week, DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang said his party will submit more than 80,000 signatures to the Central Election Commission (CEC) for review by Aug. 23.

Tsai said that after the CEC finishes the review process, the DPP will kick off a second-stage signature drive with the goal of collecting 800,000 signatures by the end of this year and having the referendum held next year.

On reports that the KMT will publish a report Wednesday to show that the party lost NT$42.7 billion because of investment failures during the chairmanship of Lee Teng-hui -- who is now the so-called " spiritual leader" of the TSU, Su said the KMT should not release the details regarding the party's assets selectively and should give a clear account of the spending during presidential elections, legislative elections and various local elections.

Su said that Lee established during his chairmanship a system to manage the KMT assets to ensure that they were not embezzled by individuals and tried to put the assets to effective use to help promote national development.
He urged incumbent KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to stop selling the party's assets and to return the party's ill-gotten assets to the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VIETNAM COOPERATE IN FIGHT AGAINST EPIDEMICS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has signed an agreement with Vietnam to jointly set up and run an "infectious disease laboratory" where medical researchers of the two countries can share experience in fighting epidemics.

Su Ih-jen, chief of Taiwan's National Health Research Institute (NHRI) Division of Clinical Research, signed the agreement with Ho Chi Minh City Children's Hospital No. 1 Director Tang Chi Thuong Aug. 16 in the southern Vietnamese city of Ho Chi Minh, witnessed by Taiwan Representative to Ho Chi Minh City Chen Shan-lin and Ho Chi Minh City Director of Health Ngnyen The Dung.
According to the agreement, the laboratory will be used to perform quick tests to diagnose suspicious cases the might be enterovirus, aviation influenza and dengue fever.

The cooperation will be on a reciprocal basis, with Taiwan controlling guidelines for physicians diagnosing enterovirus infection and giving proper medical treatment, and Vietnam giving advice on treatment of dengue hemorrhagic fever, NHRI officials said.
In 1998, Taiwan was hit by an outbreak of enterovirus 71 that killed dozens of people. The experience helped Taiwan develop an efficient procedure in fighting against the disease.

For the latest Taiwan-Vietnam medical cooperation, the NHRI and Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University Hospital have promised to share with their Vietnamese counterparts their treatment methods for children suffering from enterovirus, especially the best way to monitor vital signs.
In Vietnam, the death rate of patients infected with malignant enterovirus is more than 50 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYORAL CANDIDATE DREAMS OF 2020 OLYMPIC GAMES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Taipei mayoral candidate Frank Hsieh claimed in a seminar Monday that there is "no way" Taipei cannot host the 2020 Olympic Games.

However, he then said the road to a successful bid will not be easy, and that it is highly possible that Taipei might fail. But "the last thing Taipei city needs right now is defeatism and pessimism, " Hsieh said, adding that a successful leader is the one who has vision and the ability to lead people.

In a forum titled "2020 in Taipei," Hsieh said the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is expected to decide on a host city for the 2020 Olympic Games in 2013, seven years before the games take place. Bidding cities will have to submit applications in 2011. Therefore, a country should decide in 2009 or 2010 as to which city will represent it.

History shows that many host cities have been reborn and changed because of the Olympics, Hsieh said. Since it takes the cooperation and resources of central and local governments to organize the games, organization will facilitate urban redevelopment. Tourism and employment also benefit, he said.

But the most important advantage will be national pride, according to Hsieh. Regardless of whether Taiwan wins the bid, the bidding process will be able to "bond the whole nation together for one big task" and create national identity, he claimed.
"It took Beijing three tries before winning the 2008 bid. Everything is possible, " Hsieh said.

He also said that 2009 will be an important year for Taiwan, as it will host the Deaflympics in Taipei and the World Games in Kaohsiung. If both competitions are successful, Hsieh said, it will help Taiwan in the Olympic Games bidding process.

Bidding for the 2020 Olympic Games has been one of Hsieh's most important initiatives in his mayoral campaign so far. Hsieh had challenged his opposition Kuomintang (KMT) opponent Hau Lung-pin to a public debate on the challenge was rejected.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune: Saddam's next trial Kurdish genocide
Many Kurds will have their first taste of retribution on Monday, when Saddam Hussein is scheduled to stand trial for what prosecutors charge was an attempt to annihilate the Kurdish race.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Aug.21 [CNA] The Moscow Times: '91 Foes Linked by Anger and Regret
They squared off on opposite sides of the barricades in 1991, the Communists seeking to prop up a dying regime, the democratic activists fighting to tear it down. This weekend, they were allied in anger and disillusionment. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN URGED TO SEEK CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT PEACE UNDER U.N. FRAMEWORK
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Japanese government was urged Monday to facilitate efforts to seek peace across the Taiwan Strait under a United Nations mechanism.

Sachio Kiyasu, a seasoned and prolific Japanese writer, wrote in a letter to the editor of the Sankei Shimbun newspaper Monday that in order to prevent China from invading Taiwan, it is imperative that the U.N. moves fast to make possible an environment in which debate can be conducted on cross-strait peace and stability.

In his letter titled "Maintaining Taiwan Strait peace under U.N. Initiative, " Kiyasu called for the Japanese government to adopt active and useful moves to facilitate cross-strait peace and stability.

Kiyasu noted that China passed its "Anti-Secession Law" targeting Taiwan in March 2005, in which the Beijing leadership reserved the right to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan if the island is found moving toward formal independence.

The Chinese authorities have warned that up to 820 missiles will be fired at Taiwan if the nation makes moves that run counter to the will of China or takes measures to decide its own future, Kiyasu said.
He added that Taiwan has tried for years to join the U.N. as a full member but has been thwarted by Beijing and there is not an environment in which the cross-strait issue can be tackled efficiently.

Kiyasu reminded the Japanese leadership that in the event of Chinese missiles flying across the Taiwan Strait, the damage the missiles would cause for Japan's national security and economy would be so huge that the damage caused by Pyongyang's missile tests into waters near the Japan Sea would pale in comparison.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARBIN TOURISM PROMOTION GROUP VISITS KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A six-member tourism promotion group from Harbin City in China's northeastern province of Heilongjiang took part in a seminar Monday with representatives from the local tourism industry in Kaohsiung City to boost bilateral exchanges.

The group, led by municipal tourism bureau head Du Chuandong and composed of officials and two ice sculptors, met tourism industry representatives from the southern Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas in a Kaohsiung City hotel.

According to Du, the purpose of his group's visit to Taiwan is to explore the country's history, customs, landscapes, cultural relics and economic development with an aim of depicting Taiwan's most attractive features in the 2007 Annual Harbin Ice Festival which will begin late this year.
Organizers are planning to set up a "Taiwan pavilion" at the coming festival to show Taiwan's attractions to the rest of the world, Du said.
The two-month festival usually opens by the end of December and is a major activity in Harbin, which courts more than 1 million visitors, Du said.

According to one of the two ice sculptors, she was deeply impressed by the 101 tower in Taipei and by Sun Moon Lake and Alishan in central and southern Taiwan, but had failed to get inspiration from Kaohsiung's landscape or historic monuments.

The Harbin tourism mission, which arrived Aug. 20, is slated to leave Taiwan Aug. 29 after a tour of Taiwan and meetings with executives from Taiwan's six leading travel associations to forge the possibility of two-way exchanges and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT APPLIES FOR VISAS FOR CHINESE DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has submitted visa applications for a Chinese delegation to visit Taiwan for an agricultural seminar to be organized by the party, a KMT-run think tank said Monday.

According to the think tank, the party will hold an agricultural seminar in mid-October, to which officials, industry representatives and academics of both sides of Taiwan Strait will be invited in order to strengthen cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural exchanges and cooperation.
The Chinese delegation will include Chen Yunlin, director of the Communist Party of China's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, and representatives of major Chinese agricultural product companies.

After the seminar, to be held Oct. 22-23, the delegation will visit farmland in central and southern Taiwan to have first-hand contacts with local farmers in order to better understand the real agricultural development of Taiwan.
According to the KMT think tank, the Chinese delegates have expressed strong interest in signing letters of intent with Taiwan farmer's associations for the purchase of their products.
"The agricultural seminar has a significant meaning in cross-strait exchanges, especially at a time when relations between the two sides are at a low ebb, " a KMT official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Europeans Delay Decision on Role Inside Lebanon
The shaky, United Nations-brokered cease-fire in Lebanon suffered another blow on Sunday when the European countries that had been called upon to provide the backbone of a peacekeeping force delayed a decision on committing troops until the mission is more clearly defined. Haunted by their experiences in Bosnia in the 1990's, when their forces were unable to stop widespread ethnic killing, European governments are insisting upon clarifying the chain of command and rules of engagement before plunging into the even greater complexities of the Middle East.
Wall Street Journal: Applied Science With Its Future Now Uncertain, Bell Labs Turns to Commerce
Lucent Technologies Inc.'s Bell Labs, the birthplace of the transistor and the laser, has been through a decade of turmoil during which it was reduced to a third of its size. Now, some of its scientists are warily embracing a former submarine officer and entrepreneur as perhaps the laboratory's best hope of maintaining its relevance. Over eight decades, Bell Labs produced a series of seminal inventions, including the solar cell, the electronic microphone and the digital computer. Eleven Bell Labs scientists have shared in six Nobel Prizes. But while the labs won glory, other companies marketed and profited from its inventions. Bell Labs managers had little financial incentive to pursue commercialization of new technologies. The 1984 breakup of AT&T, followed by the 1996 spinoff of Lucent, ushered in an era of uncertainty for the labs. Bell Labs' scientists are no longer rejecting commercial approach to science.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHEDULED SIT-IN PROTEST LEGAL: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: A sit-in campaign organized by Shih Ming-teh, who once headed the Democratic Progressive Party before the party took power in 2000, to seek the ouster of embattled President Chen Shui-bian has been approved by a Taipei local police station and will be legal, government officials said Monday.

The officials were responding to a request by David Huang, a caucus whip of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), that the National Police Agency (NPA) revoke the permission for Shih's scheduled sit-in in front of the Presidential Office.
Huang had claimed that the sit-in will not only violate the March and Assembly Law but will also take a tremendous toll on society.
Huang said the law is for individuals to express their views, but the rights of other individuals should also be heeded.

The Taipei city government should not approve the 24-hour rally, according to Huang, who added the claim that if the "the sinister precedent is set, Taipei's judicial and traffic system will enter a nightmarish period."

He pointed out that quite a few elementary, high schools and the city campus of Soochow University, as well as government agencies and National Taiwan University Hospital, are in the vicinity of Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential OFfice where Shih is scheduled to stage the sit-in.
The tranquility of the neighborhood and traffic will be greatly affected if the sit-in takes place, he added.
However, Vice Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang pointed out that the Taipei police has approved the application, so the sit-in will be legal.
NPA Secretary-General Tsai Yi-chang said that while the NPA is not in favor of the sit-in, it will not revoke the permission.
Meanwhile, a spokeswoman for Shih's campaign said the sit-in will start Aug. 27 at the earliest and Sept. 9 at the latest, the final decision left up to Shih.

She also said that four or five days before the sit-in, there will be an "international" news conference and that there will be ads in all media to mobilize the people to join the sit-in three days before the start.
Shih, who served as DPP chairman from 1994 to 1996, announced Aug. 12 his plan to call on 1 million people to donate NT$100 (US$3) each to finance the campaign to oust Chen.
Shih said that if the target of 1 million donors can be reached within a month, the campaign will be launched Sept. 9 with daily sit-ins by protesters in front of the Presidential Office.
If the target can be achieved sooner, the campaign will start to roll earlier than planned, Shih added.
The spokeswoman said that as of Monday, the donations had amounted to NT$94.61 million and she estimated that the target of NT$100 million would be reached Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIENNIAL DOCUMENTARY FILM FESTIVAL TO TAKE PLACE IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The 2006 Taiwan Biennial International Documentary Exhibition, scheduled to take place Oct. 27-Nov. 5 at the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts in Taichung, will present more than 700 documentary films from over 50 countries, including 150 by Taiwanese directors.
The exhibition, sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, will be the fifth since its inception in 1998.

Through the years, the event has established itself as an important arena for international documentary professionals, with the number of entries in each exhibition increasing from some 100 in past years to more than 700 this year.
According to organizers, the 10-day festival is expected to attract thousands of participants from both home and abroad.

This year's event will feature the preview of a 100-minute documentary film titled "Greater Taichung Chronicle," created by 10 Taiwanese directors who each contributed a 10-minute clip to introduce the history, culture and other aspects of the central Taiwan city.

The 700-odd entries will compete for awards in four categories -- international feature-length documentaries, international short documentaries, Taiwan-themed documentaries and Asian vision -- for 10 prizes ranging from US$2,500 to US$10,000, plus trophies for grand prizes.
This year there are more entries submitted by directors from Germany, France, the Netherlands and Israel than from the other countries involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE OFFICIAL MEETS ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Eric Altbach, the deputy assistant U.S. trade representative, met with Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long Monday to exchange views on the enforcement of the bilateral Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA).

A Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Altbach has come to Taiwan to review the results and effects of the TIFA implementation. The official refrained, however, from going into further detail with regard to the purpose of Altbach's current visit and the content of his talks with Chen.

Smooth implementation of the TIFA has been widely seen as a critical step toward the signing of a free trade agreement between Taiwan and the United States. The MOEA official declined to reveal whether Chen touched on free trade pact issues during his talks with Altbach, saying that the U.S. authorities preferred to keep his visit low profile.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD MIGHT REVIVE PLAN TO HOLD TAIWAN EXPO

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning Development (CEPD) -- Taiwan's highest economic planning agency -- is considering reviving a plan to hold a Taiwan Exposition in 2011.

At a regular meeting Monday, CEPD members, most of whom are Cabinet ministers in their own right, reached a decision that the Ministry of Economic Affairs should present an analysis on whether a Taiwan Expo with a target date of 2011 would be feasible.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government originally planned to hold a Taiwan Expo from May to September 2008 to showcase Taiwan's vitality and creativity in science, technology, tourism and culture with a budget of NT$19.5 billion (US$597 million). The plan was included as one of its 10 New Major Construction Projects program.
However, the plan was aborted because the opposition-controlled legislature would not pass a bill to grant the needed budget on the grounds that the cost was too high.
The government estimated that the expo would attract 5.5 million visitors, including 5 million from abroad, and bring NT$5 billion in revenues and NT$95 billion for the tourism and other industries.
Opposition legislators disagreed, saying the expo is unlikely to attract 5 million visitors from abroad and pointing out that fewer than 2 million tourists visit Taiwan each year.
CEPD members acknowledged that they still entertain high hopes that the expo can be held in 2011 to highlight Taiwan's high technology and expose Taiwan's abundant fruit production to the world.

Noting that preparations for a large-scale expo usually take five or six years to complete, they said that if the 2011 Taiwan Expo is to take place, related government departments must begin planning and coordinating their efforts as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO CARRY ON DESPITE DIFFICULTIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated his pledge Monday to hang on and serve out his term in office no matter what challenges might lie ahead.
Chen made the reaffirmation while meeting with a visiting group of Taiwan-friendly Japanese parliamentarians headed by Hisaoki Kamei, a member of the lower house of the Diet.

Without directly mentioning a campaign led by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh to press for his resignation, Chen told his guests that all newly emerging democracies tend to face a host of thorny problems.
"Taiwan is no exception, " Chen said, adding that Taiwan's politics are even more complicated and treacherous due to its divided national identity and prickly cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Nevertheless, Chen, who is embroiled in a series of corruption allegations implicating members of his family and close aides, said he has full confidence in Taiwan's democracy and rule of law.

"Under our liberal democratic system, all kinds of political advocacies and opinions are respected and protected. All disputes should be resolved by due process of law. I don't think our people and society will use violent or non-peaceful means 'outside the institution' to settle differences," Chen said.

For all the challenges and difficulties he faces, Chen said he will carry on courageously and will never fall. "No matter how big the difficulty may be, I'll endure it. No matter how spiteful the smearing may be, I'll stand my ground and perform my duties until the end of my term May 20, 2008."

Turning to Taiwan-Japan relations, Chen said he was delighted to learn that former President Lee Teng-hui will visit Japan next month, describing the event as symbolizing a further upgrading of substantive bilateral ties.

Despite the absence of diplomatic ties, relations between the two coutnries have continued to grow, Chen said. Two-way trade exceeded US$60 billion last year, with Japan enjoying a trade surplus of US$30 billion. Civilian exhcnages also set a record last year, With Taiwan people making 1.3 million visits to Japan and the number of Japanese visits to Taiwan also breaking the 1 million mark for the first time.

After Taiwan's high-speed railway becomes operational in late October, Chen said he beleives more Japanese tourists will come to Taiwan to get a taste of the new bullet train service which uses Japan's Shinkansen system.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 YILAN FILM FESTIVAL TO KICK OFF AUG. 27

TEXT.P: A special film festival catering for children and juveniles will kick off in northeastern Yilan County Aug. 27, a county government official said Monday.
A total of 14 films, including feature and animated films produced by Taiwan, the United States, Japan, South Korea and Thailand, will be screened during the festival, the official said.

The festival, now in its fourth year, will run until Aug. 30, the official said, adding that despite its financial straits, the county government has earmarked funds to support the festival for children's fun and fondness.
The festival will open with a Thai film, titled "Dorm," and ends with the South Korean movie "Empress Chun."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday Aug. 22, or the 29th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog, according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a Japanese protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement calling on the people to obey the National government and join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprised of China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Warsaw Pact tanks enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named U.S. secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure had forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese person to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang-kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the party's nomination and to instead run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
1999: A China Airlines passenger plane with 315 on board crash-lands at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during a typhoon, killing two and injuring 211.
2000: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong says that it is still too early to talk about overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification as the government has yet to demonstrate consistency regarding its cross-strait policies.
2000: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore decorades visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Grande Croix in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties.
2001: Republic of China Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, along with a 20-strong delegation, attends the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds though ten efforts, use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L PAYMENTS SURPLUS DROPS TO US$480 MILLION IN Q2 2006

TEXT.P: Taiwan's balance of international payments posted a surplus of US$480 million in the second quarter of 2006, down from US$2.2 billion in the previous quarter, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Tuesday.

CBC officials attributed the drop to Taiwan individuals' preference to invest in foreign mutual funds and local insurance companies' tendency to invest in overseas markets, with the financial account registering a net outflow for the fourth consecutive quarter.

The international payments surplus amounted to US$2.72 billion in the first half of 2006, with a surplus of US$10.63 billion on the current account and a net outflow of US$10.25 billion on the financial account, the officials said.
In the second quarter of 2006, direct investment and equity investment saw a net outflow of US$790 million and US$6.64 billion, respectively, they said.

In terms of equity investment, residents accounted for a net outflow of US$11.51 billion, which was the second highest single-quarter level after the US$12.37 billion recorded in the second quarter of 2003, they said.
During the same period, equity investment made by non-residents in Taiwan amounted to only US$4.87 billion, they said.
Meanwhile, investment in financial derivatives registered a net outflow of US$380 million, while other investment also registered a net outflow of US$1.37 billion, they said.

On the current account, merchandise trade posted a surplus of US$4.87 billion, trade in services registered a deficit of US$1.53 billion, income booked a surplus of US$2.49 billion, and current transfers posted a deficit of US$1.13 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LABOR SURVEY TOO CASUAL TO BE ACCEPTABLE: CLA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU's) handling of an opinion survey on the government's labor management was too casual to be acceptable, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Tuesday.

The TSU unveiled a day earlier the results of a survey of labor unions and advocacy groups on their assessment of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's performance in labor management.

The TSU, which has the same pro-independence stance as the DPP but differs with it on some economic and social policy issues, sent out 100 copies of questionnaires by fax from Aug. 14-17 and collected 43 valid replies.
Given the fact that the number of valid samples was so low, the CLA officials, the accuracy of the results is questionable.

According to the TSU survey, the DPP administration received a mere 41.19 points for its labor policy initiatives and management, far below the passing grade of 60 points. Most of those surveyed said they didn't feel any dramatic improvement in labor benefits since the DPP came to power in 2000. The survey also found that 91 percent were dissatisfied with the slow advancement in labor rights over the past six years.

CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said the TSU's criticism is "far from true, " claiming that the number of labor rights acts passed during the past six years has exceeded the number for any other period of similar length in Taiwan's history.
