DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO RAISE REWARD FOR REPORTING LITTERING

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) announced Tuesday its decision to raise the reward for those who provide information on littering in a bid to boost the effect of an upcoming cleanup campaign.

The government is set to launch a nationwide environmental cleanup campaign in mid-September, with those who fail to keep the area within a 4-meter radius around their homes or businesses clean being subject to fines of up to NT$6,000.

Beginning in October at the earliest, the EPA will give out 30 percent to 50 percent of the fines received from litterers as reward money for those who report the littering, which means the maximum amount of the reward will be NT$3,000, EPA officials said.
At present, only 10 percent to 20 percent of the amount of the fines is given out as reward money, the officials noted.
Also, the EPA will shorten the process involved in the payment of the reward money in order to increase the incentive for the public to report littering, they said.
When making a report, people should provide information on the identity of the literers and when and where the offense took place as well as attach photos or videotapes as proof, the officials said.

Local environmental protection authorities will fine the offenders if the reports are confirmed to be true and will pay the reward to the informers as early as possible after they receive the fines, they said.

According to EPA Minister Chang Kow-lung, the purpose of the campaign is to use the least possible amount of resources in ensuring that everyone is responsible in maintaining the cleanliness of their neighborhoods.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, LATVIA EXCHANGE EXPERIENCES IN PROMOTING DEMOCRACY
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Baltic states conference on democratic development kicked off Monday in Riga, the capital of Latvia, with scholars from the four countries as well as the United States, Germany and Canada attending.

According to Taiwan diplomats posted in Geneva, the two-day conference, being co-hosted by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy and the Latvia Academy of Sciences, is aimed at giving the participants the opportunity to exchange views and experiences in democratic development.

Lin Wen-cheng, chief executive of the Taiwan foundation, was quoted as saying at the conference that Taiwan and Latvia are very similar in terms of democratic development -- with both being young democracies that despite being situated in the shadows of a major foreign power have unceasingly worked to reinforce their democratic systems.

Taiwan, which was a colony of Japan between 1895-1945, has been under constant military threat from China since 1949, Lin said. He also mentioned that Monday was the 15th anniversary of Latvia regaining its independence from the former Soviet Union.
Lin said he admires the Latvian people for their will and strength in seeking their freedom and independence.

In addition to Lin, members of the Taiwan delegation taking part in the conference include Taiwan's Representative to Latvia Lee Shih-ming, professor Sung Chen-chau of National Chengkung University, professor Hsiao Wen-sheng of National Chungcheng University and professor Chang Chi-lu of National Sun Yat-sen University.

Before participating in the conference, the delegation paid a visit to the Latvia Academy of Sciences and attended a ceremony presided over by Latvian President Vaira Vike-Freiberga to celebrate the 15th anniversary of Latvia regaining independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY TO INAUGURATE DRUG CONTROL CENTER

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung County government is preparing to inaugurate a drug hazard control and prevention center Aug. 29, which will be staffed with anti-drug police as well as health and educational experts trained in helping drug addicts quit their vice.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing will be director of the facility, which will also be staffed by social and labor affairs officials, said Chen Chun-yung, secretary-general of the county government, after attending a preparatory meeting for the project Monday.

Missions of the planned center will include advertising the dangers of drug abuse, providing counseling services, assisting drug addicts to check in to rehabilitation centers, and training an anit-narcotics squad in efforts to crack down on drug trafficking, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOPPING QUALITY ASSURANCE SYSTEM KICKS OFF IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Tourists to Taiwan will be fully protected while shopping on the island after tourism officials announced the start of a shopping quality assurance system Tuesday.
Tourism Bureau Director General Hsu Wen-sheng and Lin Chin-lung, president of Travel Quality Assurance Association (TQAA), jointly made the announcement.

Hsu said that tourists, whether they are traveling as individuals or in groups from home or abroad, can rely on the system if they have disputes with shops over the commodities they buy, as long as their itineraries are arranged through travel agents.
He said that if travel agencies arrange for tourists to head to shops with unreasonable prices, then such travel agencies have no need to exist and should have their licenses revoked.

Hsu also said that the idea of the system came from complaints by Chinese tourists, who said in letters that they enjoyed their trips in Taiwan but were not satisfied with the tea they bought at the scenic Mount Ali, also known a Alishan, and the jade stones bought in Hualien, claiming they were of shoddy quality and unreasonable price.
TQAA Secretary-General Chen Yi-chuan said that the system divides Taiwan's commodities into six categories, including jewels, wood carvings as well as food and agricultural products.
Any shops can apply with the association and be accepted as members if they pass the screening process and make a deposit and pay the annual fees.
Chen said that tourists can file complaints with the association, and a team will then rule whether the shops should return the money or compensate the tourists for their losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Aug.22 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Market Blast Kills 10 and Injures 55
A bomb exploded in Cherkizovsky market Monday morning, killing 10 people and injuring as many as 55 in what appeared to be the work of acriminal gang. Yury Syomin, head of the City Prosecutor's Office, on Monday afternoon would not rule ou t a terrorist attack at the eastern Moscow market. [By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 79 points to close at 6,539, with 30,828 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October increased 81 points to finish at 6,545, with 151 contracts traded, while December futures rose 53 points to close at 6,517, with nine contract transactions.
June futures moved up 25 points to close at 6,500, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,460 for September, 6,464 for October, 6,464 for December, 6,449 for March and 6,475 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

September TE futures moved up 5.8 points to close at 284.25, with 4,333 contracts traded, while October TE futures rose 4.3 points to finish at 283.35, with 24 contract transactions. December TE futures dropped 0.05 points to close at 282.05, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures gained 5.8 points to close at 896.8, with 1,617 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 0.6 points to finish at 891.2, with one contract traded. December TF futures moved up 1.6 points to close at 896, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PAY RAISE FOR GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Government employees, military personnel and public schoolteachers will not get a pay raise next year, a senior official said Tuesday.
"It was a conclusion reached at a recent meeting of the government's pay scale screening committee, " said Chou Hung-hsien, head of the Central Personnel Administration (CPA).

According to Chou, the committee made the decision after carefully reviewing a number of factors, including the pay scale adjustments in the private and public sectors, the government's financial status, as well as inflation and economic growth rates.

As the inflation rate remains mild and salaries in the private sector have not spiked substantially, Chou said the committee decided not to raise the pay scale for civil servants, military service members and public schoolteachers in the coming year.

Over the past six years, Chou said, the government has twice adjusted its pay scale -- a 3-percent hike in 2001 and 2005, respectively. During the same period, he said, salaries in the private sector rose only 4.6 percnet on average.

Meanwhile, Hsu Jan-yau, head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said that if the government were to raise its pay scale by another 3 percent next year, its financial burden would increase NT$20 billion.
The Executive Yuan is scheduled to discuss the 2007 central government budget plan at its weekly meeting Wednesday.

According to Hsu, the government's 2007 expenditure is projected at NT$1.66 trillion, marking a nearly 6 percent year-on-year increase. Hsu said the increased budget will mainly finance procurement of three big-ticket weaponry items.

After listening to a briefing on the government's budget planning early this month, President Chen Shui-bian instructed that the 2007 budget bill should be drafted in line with four principles -- boosting investment in Taiwan, creating job opportunities, bridging the gap between rural and urban areas and promoting equitable distribution of wealth.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi: Italy ready for leading U.N. peacekeeping force in Lebanon.
Prime Minister Romano Prodi said Monday that Italy is ready for leading the would-be-expanded United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon. He said that he told U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan in a telephone conversation Italy's position on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 84.28 points to close at 6,590.2.
The bourse opened at 6,524.72 and fluctuated between 6,590.2 and 6,517.28 during trading. A total of 2.44 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.04 billion (US$1.92 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.84 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.74 percent, textile stocks at 1.25 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.99 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.84 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent.
The other two major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down at 0.06 percent and cement stocks decreasing 0.03 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 767 to 244, with 153 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL EXPORTS DOWN 10.2% FOR FIRST HALF OF YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural exports reached US$1.61 billion for the first half of this year, a decrease of 10.2 percent over the same period last year, according to statistics released by the Council of Agriculture (COA) Tuesday.

At the same time, the island's agricultural imports totaled US$4.59 billion, leaving an agricultural trade deficit of US$2.98 billion, a slight increase of 1.5 percent over the same period in 2005, a COA official said.

By category, livestock products topped the list with exports amounting to US$590 million, or 36.6 percent of total agricultural exports, followed by aquatic product exports at US$570 million, farm produce at US$380 million, and forestry products at US$67 million.

By product, cow-hide exports represented the bulk of total agricultural exports, amounting to US$260 million, or 16.3 percent of total agricultural exports, followed by frozen tuna exports at US$230 million.
Japan was the largest market for Taiwan's agricultural products, taking 27.3 percent of the island's agricultural exports for the period, followed by Hong Kong, China and the United States.

Meanwhile, farm produce imports topped the list in agricultural imports, amounting to US$2.72 billion, or 59.3 percent of total, followed by livestock product imports at US$980 million, forestry products at US$610 million, and aquatic products at US$270 million.
By product, corn imports represented the bulk of total agricultural imports, amounting to US$380 million, followed by soybean imports at US$310 million.

The United States was the largest source of agricultural imports to Taiwan, with 30 percent of the island's total agricultural imports coming from that country during the period, followed by Australia and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO FOCUS ON DEVELOPING PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION: CEPD

TEXT.P: Developing public transportation will become the main focus of the government's transportation policy in the future, according to a report unveiled Tuesday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
The CEPD concluded that the government will reduce its funding for highway development year by year and transfer the investment to the development of subway and railway systems.
In 2007, the budget for highway development projects will decrease to NT$29.4 billion, while the budget for rail transportation projects will increase to NT$25.9 billion, the report said.

The report noted that Taiwan's transportation policy has always emphasized highway development and that the government has for a long time funneled huge amounts of resources on an annual basis to building the country's highway systems.

As a result, the highway density of the country expanded from 791 meters per square kilometer in 1991 to 1,070 meters per square kilometer in 2005, which has had a negative impact on the environment, the report said.

Citing tallies released during a national energy conference held in 2005, the report pointed out that the amount of greenhouse gas emissions by the transportation sector has continued to increase, with vehicles on highways accounting for more than 85 percent of the emissions.
By 2025, the amount of greenhouse gas emissions by the transportation sector is expected to increase more than four-fold over the level in 1990, the report said.

Since 2003, the transportation sector has accounted for more than 15 percent of the country's total energy consumption. While highway transportation has accounted for as high as 93.4 percent of the energy consumption of the sector, rail transportation has accounted for only 2 percent, according to the report.

As the increase in the number of cars and motorcycles has led to problems such as over-consumption of energy, increased greenhouse gas emissions and traffic congestion, the government needs to adopt a new transportation policy that focuses on the development of public transportation to conserve energy and reduce pollution and noise, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.07 to close at NT$32.760.
A total of US$690 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.740 and fluctuated between NT$32.730 and NT$32.774.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGEOVER CEREMONY HELD FOR MOTC MINISTER

TEXT.P: New Transportation and Communications Minister Tsai Duei took the helm of the ministry Tuesday at a changeover ceremony presided over by Minister without Portfolio Lin Si-yao.
Speaking at the ceremony, Lin hailed the outgoing minister, Kuo Yao-chi, as the "iron lady" of Taiwan for her strong determination in carrying out her work.

According to Lin, the construction of the Hsuehshan tunnel on the Peiyi freeway faced a problem at the Lunar New Year in late January this year when the ministry had contract problems with its electrical and mechanical contractors. Kuo, who had just assumed her post at that time, exercised her coordination ability and finally got the work to go ahead, Lin added.
Thanks to her hard work, Lin said, the construction of the 12.9-km tunnel -- the longest highway tunnel in East Asia and the fifth-longest in the world -- was finally completed in June.
Lin also hailed the new minister for his long-term efforts in resolving problems related to transportation.

Tsai had been political deputy minister of transportation and communications since 2002. Of his 37 years in public service, Tsai served 36 of them in the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
Due to the increasing public expectations toward the quality of transportation projects, Tsai said he would like to work with MOTC officials to implement those projects properly and on schedule.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SUPPORTERS IN KAOHSIUNG TO RALLY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: More than a thousand of President Chen Shui-bian's supporters from southern Kaohsiung City will rally in Taipei Aug. 26 in solidarity with the president, City Councilor Cheng Hsin-chu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Tuesday.

Cheng said his office has booked enough buses to transport just over 1,000 supporters to Taipei for the rally, which is being organized by a TV host to show support for Chen, whose critics are trying to bring him down by staging a sit-in in front of the Presidential Office in late August or early September.

According to Cheng, Chen supporters who are angered by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh's attempts to bring Chen down through the sit-in have flooded his office in the last few days with calls asking to join the Aug. 26 rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Raids revealed bomb-making equipment and martyr videos
Two converts to Islam and the mother of an eight-month-old baby are among eleven people charged yesterday over an alleged plot to blow up aircraft flying from Britain to America.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER ADVISES POLITICIANS TO RESPECT DIFFERENT OPINIONS

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh urged politicians Tuesday to respect different opinions after ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) former Chairman Shih Ming-teh emotionally condemned a lawmaker's remarks against him and described him as Hsieh's "jackal."

Shih's character has been under severe criticism by supporters of President Chen Shui-bian since he launched a campaign to pressure the president last week to resign over a string of corruption allegations implicating Chen, members of his family and close aides.

DPP Legislator Wang Shih-chien questioned a day earlier at the Legislative Yuan Shih's motive for launching the anti-Chen drive and accused him of accepting a businessman's donation of a large mansion in exchange for his political influence.
In response to the accusation, Shih demanded that Hsieh restrain his "protege's barbarian behavior."
Hsieh said different opinions are allowed in a democratic society like Taiwan.
Hsieh said that he will advise Wang to express opinions in a more polite way. He also suggested Shih himself respond to questions posed by Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPLAINT ABOUT PUBLIC NUISANCE FILED EVERY FOUR MINUTES: EPA

TEXT.P: Environmental protection authorities around the country received a total of 61,403 complaints about public nuisance in the first half of 2006, with one complaint being lodged every four minutes on average, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
Of these cases, complaints about noise accounted for the highest ratio at 31 percent, followed by complaints about odor, with a ratio of 22 percent.
Complaints about environmental sanitation and about waste and garbage took third and fourth places, respectively.
By region, the largest number of complaints were received in Taipei City, with more than 14,000 cases, followed by Taipei County, with 10,000 cases.
While neighbors were mentioned in more than 28 percent of the complaints as the source of pollution, other sources mentioned included factories, businesses, construction projects and motor vehicles.
EPA officials said the average number of complaints received per month in the first half of 2006 dropped 76 percent and 47 percent, respectively, compared with the same period of 2004 and 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune: Iran defiant on nuclear program as deadline nears
Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said his country would continue to "forcefully" pursue its nuclear program. The remarks came before a Tuesday deadline for responding to a package of incentives aimed at persuading Iran to voluntarily stop enriching uranium.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER URGES NO USE OF BARBED WIRE BARRICADE

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker urged the government Tuesday to give up the use of barbed wire barricades to control large demonstrations, saying that they could be lethal.
Legislator Joanna Lei of the Kuomintang claimed that "no countries in the world" use barbed wire barricades to deal with demonstrators, but use alternative means.

Lei issued her plea amid reports that the National Police Agency (NPA) recently took delivery of a new kind of barbed wire barricade fitted with sharp blades as part of a project to provide better protection against terrorist activities.

Reports said the new barricades will be used in an upcoming sit-in protest in front of the Presidential Office to pressure President Chen Shui-bian to resign over a spate of corruption and embezzlement allegations against himself, his family members and senior aides. But after public criticism, NPA Director-General Hou Yu-ih said the barricades will not be used in the protest, instead, Hou instructed police departments islandwide to send old barbed wire barricades to Taipei.

Lei said Taiwan boasts of itself as a democratized country, but has nevertheless introduced the razor wire barricades, which she claimed are used "against criminals, enemies, and not on people who have the rights to march and assembly."

She pointed out that Article 11 and 14 of the Constitution enshrine the people's freedom of speech and assembly. The scheduled sit-in protests launched by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, is an activity protected by the Constitution, she said.
If the government has misgivings that the demonstration might run out of control, it should use alternative means to control traffic and separate crowds, she said.

She also said that if Taiwan's democracy wants to move forward, it has to amend the Demonstration Law, changing the outdated concept of "prior permission" from to "prior reporting" to the police station for staging a rally, Lei said.

She said she will work with her colleague, KMT Legislator Kao Sze-po, to make an amendment of the Demonstration Law in the next legislative session to "realize" the right of the people to march and assembly.

The Demonstration Law, enacted in 1988, bans people from staging demonstrations in front of key government offices such as the Presidential Office, the five Yuans including the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan, the courts and foreign embassies or representative offices.
However, the law is largely ignored, prompting calls for an amendment to bring the law into conformity with reality.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OUSTER CAMPAIGN FUND REACHES OVER NT$100 MILLION

TEXT.P: Supporters of a "1 million people campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian" donated over NT$8.64 million to the campaign fund Tuesday, bringing to more than NT$103 million (US$3.14 million) the total donations as of that day, according to the campaign organizers.

The organizers also reported that the number of donors has reached some 1 million since Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , initiated the drive last week to push Chen to resign over a string of corruption allegations against himself, members of his family and close aides.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Tang Pi-er from Tainan City in southern Taiwan, was set to sue Shih Wednesday at the Tainan District Prosecutor's Office for what she claimed as "illegally collecting money" from citizens, Tang's assistant said.
The planned move is part of a drive launched by several DPP members a few days ago to counter the anti-Chen campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES OF MERCURY-CONTAINING BATTERIES TO BE RESTRICTED FROM SEPT. 1

TEXT.P: The manufacture, import and sales of dry cell batteries containing more than five parts per million (5 ppm) of mercury will be banned from Sept. 1 under new government regulations, environmental authorities of the central city of Taichung said Tuesday.

Officials at the Bureau of Environmental Protection of the Taichung city government pointed out that the restricted dry batteries include manganese-zinc batteries and non-button alkaline manganese batteries.

According to regulations announced by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), manufacturers and importers are required to submit documents, including a test report issued by an accredited laboratory, to the authorities.

They are also required to label their products with the message in Chinese that translates as: "This product has been confirmed by the EPA to have a mercury content of less than 5 ppm," plus the confirmation number issued by the authorities.
Mercury is a hazard to the environment and to health.
The EPA adopted the regulations late last year, setting restrictions on the mercury content in dry cell batteries in line with European Union standards.

Manufacturers and importers who violate the regulations will be subject to a maximum fine of NT$300,000 (US$9,152), while vendors could face fines of up to NT$6,000 if they sell batteries containing an excessive level of mercury.
EPA officials have estimated that the new policy will help Taiwan reduce the circulation of more than 200 kg of mercury per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Says Iraq Pullout Would Be 'A Disaster'; President Acknowledges A Strain on U.S. 'Psyche'.
President Bush laid down an impassioned defense of his Iraq policy yesterday, saying the United States must stay in the fight despite an escalating death toll, increasing calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops and growing public sentiment against the war.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIND TURBINE PLAN QUESTIONED OVER ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE

TEXT.P: Eco-friendly activists questioned Tuesday a plan by the Changhua County Government to install 240 wind turbines along the coast, citing concerns over the machines' potential to damage the natural environment.

Environmentalists raised the question based on the argument that more wind turbines might damage their surrounding environments and affect the migration paths of the many seabirds that overwinter every year along Changhua's coast in central Taiwan.

But according to Lee Hung-shin, an official at the Bureau of Economic Development under the Changhua County Government, no studies from home or abroad have proved that wind turbines damage nearby eco-systems, as long as they are installed "at safe distances."

In Changhua's case, each turbine is set at a distance of between 300 meters and 500 meters from its neighbor, he said, adding that studies in other countries have even found that birds build nests upon wind turbines.

To take advantage of the steady winds in the Changhua area, the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) and four private power companies have applied to establish wind turbines in an effort to step up economic development and create jobs in power-related industries such as steel and electrical engineering, Lee said.
The installation of 60 out of the 240 turbines have gained approval from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, while the installation of Taipower's 23 turbines is near completion, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR CAUTION AMID POLITICAL UNCERTAINTY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called Tuesday for extreme caution amid rising political uncertainty, suggesting that all parties concerned must act responsibly and rationally to avoid confrontation.

Lu issued the call while answering questions from reporters prior to a ceremony to mark the 10th anniversary of the founding of the women's affairs department of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), in which DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, former Premier Frank Hsieh and former Council of Labor Affairs Chen Chu also took part.
Hsieh and Chen are the DPP's candidates for the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections in December, respectively

In view of a populist movement led by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh to pressure scandal-tainted President Chen Shui-bian to resign, it is hard to predict changes in Taiwan's political situation even in the next week, Lu said, appealing for caution and seriousness by all sides for the sake of the future of the people.

Although the people's basic rights should be respected, Lu said, all parties concerned must do their utmost to prevent any incidents. "Otherwise, all the people will have to pay a huge price, " she warned.
The vice president also denied that an overseas visit planned by Chen for next month is a "scheme" to escape strong public pressure demanding that he step down.

"The president's visits to Palau and Nauru in early September have been arranged for some time, " she said, dismissing speculation that Chen is trying to evade a sit-in to be organized by Shih on the square in front of the Presidential Office that might start late this month or early next month.
Lu also clarified media speculation that she is to make a major announcement on Sept. 28 -- the 20th anniversary of the DPP's founding.
According to Lu, what the ruling DPP needs now is unity at a time of trouble and contrary to what the report has speculated, she will not quit the DPP or make any waves in her report.

DOC.HEADLINE: WARM RESPONSE TO DPP PROPOSAL ON KMT ASSETS

TEXT.P: More than 11,000 people in southern Tainan city have signed a proposal initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to hold a referendum on forcing the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to return what the DPP calls "ill-gotten" KMT assets, a spokesman for the DPP's Tainan city branch said Tuesday.

The number has well exceeded the first-phase target of 8,650 people set for Tainan city -- a stronghold of the pro-independence DPP, the spokesman said, adding that the local branch has submitted the endorsement to the party's headquarters, which will put forth a petition endorsed by more than 80,000 people to the Central Election Commission (CEC) Wednesday for screening.

After gaining the CEC's approval, a second-phase endorsement campaign to continue the referendum proposal can kick off in the hope of collecting endorsements from 830,000 people nationwide so that the proposal can be put to a public referendum.

The KMT, once labeled the world's wealthiest political party, is slated to publish a report on its assets and liabilities Wednesday in an attempt to explain to the public how it has handled what it claims is its property since 2000 when it lost power to the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO PROPOSE REFERENDUM TO FORCE KMT TO RETURN ASSETS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will submit a proposal to the Central Election Commission (CEC) Wednesday to initiate a national referendum as the first step toward pressuring the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to return its ill-gotten assets to the national coffers.
DPP legislators Trong Chai, Yen Wen-chang and Chiang Chao-yi made the announcement at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan.

Chai said that the proposal will seek speedy legislation requiring political parties to return ill-gotten party assets so as to force the KMT and its related organizations to return their assets, except for party member fees, political donations and campaign subsidies.

Chai said the proposal will be sent to the CEC to coincide with the scheduled publication of the KMT's party assets, which reportedly will amount to only about NT$6 billion or NT$7 billion when its NT$80 billion in debts and over NT$40 billion in investment losses are subtracted. The party's assets reportedly amounted to as much as NT$140 billion during the period when former President Lee Teng-hui concurrently served as party chairman.
Chai expressed the hope that the CEC will review the proposal quickly so that the DPP can move toward the second stage of a planned referendum voting.

Chai recalled that his proposal at a DPP Central Standing Committee meeting three months ago to use a national referendum to force the KMT to return its party assets received an enthusiastic response.
This, Chai claimed, has put tremendous pressure on KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, leading to his planned publication of the party assets.

The DPP lawmaker noted that the first stage of referendum requires the signatures of 0.5 percent of eligible voters, or around 83,000 voters. The next stage will be to collect the signatures of 5 percent of the eligible voters, or 830,000 voters, within six months before it can be put to a referendum vote.

Chai expressed the hope that the CEC will pass the screening in one month so that the DPP can launch the second stage signature drive Sept. 28, when the DPP will celebrate its 20th founding anniversary.

Chao also warned Ma not to divert public attention by means of unveiling the party assets, saying that the people are most concerned about how many assets are left and how they are to be returned to the people.
Ma is scheduled to explain Wednesday how the party has handled its assets, which its rivals claim are "ill-gotten" assets acquired during the party's five-decade rule of the country before 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JOBLESS RATE FOR 2006 EXPECTED TO DROP TO LESS THAN 4%

TEXT.P: The government is confident that Taiwan's unemployment rate will fall below 4 percent for this year, although the monthly rate for July soared to the year's new high of 4.05 percent, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.
Statistics released by the DGBAS show that 428,000 people were jobless in July, representing an increase of 10,000 people over June.
DGBAS officials attributed the increase mainly to seasonal factors, as July is the month when many new college graduates enter the job market.
They pointed out that the average jobless rate for the first seven months of this year is 3.89 percent, a decrease of 0.28 percent from the same period of 2005.
The officials said they expected the rate to continue rising in August and to slide gradually from September until the end of the year.
They expressed confidence that the unemployment rate for 2006 will drop to below 4 percent, down from the 4.13 percent for 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO HELP TAIWAN-U.S. JOINT VENTURE OVERCOME DIFFICULTIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Tuesday that the ministry will help a Taiwan-U.S. joint venture aircraft company overcome problems with its operations.

Chen was referring to difficulties faced by the Sino Swearingen Aircraft Corp. (SSAC) , a Taiwan-U.S. joint venture established in 1995 and headquartered in Texas and in which the Taiwan government holds a more-than 90 percent stake.

According to Chen, SSAC's SJ30-2 business aircraft, which received a "Type Certificate" from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) last year, faces technical problems with its wings that might delay mass production, while the company as a whole suffers from a long-term financial burden.
Chen said he has instructed MOEA staff and aviation experts to visit SSAC to better understand the company's problems.
Last Friday, MOEA agreed that SSAC could lay off 150 workers and postpone materials purchases.
Noting that the SSAC has received purchase orders for more than 300 SJ30-2 business jets and has received US$7.5 million in prepayment, Chen said the government will not abandon the company.
However, Chen added that the MOEA will also determine who should assume responsibility for the aircraft's technical problems and any wrong decisions made by the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: VERBAL ATTACKS BLUR ANTI-CORRUPTION EFFORTS: EX-DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh expressed sorrow Tuesday over verbal attacks and smears against him in recent days, describing them as being against the public's desire for clean government.

Shih said he felt extremely sad about the many accusations and mudslinging by various DPP lawmakers against him, and added that the strategy will just blur the focus of his anti-corruption movement that calls for 1 million people to donate NT$100 each and take part in a sit-in planned for late August or early September to pressure President Chen Shui-bian to step down.
Shih announced the donation campaign Aug. 12 and vowed that a sit-in on the square in front of the Presidential Office will begin as soon as the cash donations exceed NT$100 million.

According to the campaign organizers, cash contributions from the public totaled over NT$103.26 million as of Tuesday evening -- meaning that around 1 million people have endorsed Shih's campaign to depose Chen.
The cash donations will go on to gain greater momentum for the campaign, said Shih's aides.
Shih, a pioneer of Taiwan's democracy movement, said the people will not cease their efforts to combat corruption until scandal-tainted Chen steps down.
"I'm not the leader who leads people to the streets. Rather, I'm the one driven by the people to do so," he said.
Shih also called on leaders of the various opposition parties and some of his former reform-minded DPP peers to sit down and talk should Chen give in to the people's demands and quit the presidency.
Taiwan cannot afford to be further crippled by confrontation
and political leaders need to collaborate and negotiate to inject a new lease of life into the country, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Timothy J. Hwang)
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Britain Charges 11 in Plane Case; Bomb Gear Cited
The British authorities charged 11 people on Monday in connection with a suspected plot to blow up United States- bound airliners, and said investigators had discovered "martyrdom videos" and bomb- making materials in a far-reaching search of homes, cars, woodland and other locations.
At least 8 of the 11 were thought to form a hard core of bombers who planned to assemble liquid-based explosives on board airplanes and detonate them, they said.
Wall Street Journal:Energy Security Is Hostage to Supply Of Oil Professionals
Mohammed al-Jibouri belongs to Iraq's premier business fraternity: the geologists, engineers and finance men who run the country's vast oil industry.
Through decades of war and trade sanctions, these professionals kept Iraq pumping. By last year, Mr. Jibouri, an oil economist, was a top contender to head the state Oil Marketing Organization, a powerful agency that sells Iraq's crude oil abroad.
But senior Iraqi oil men were getting caught up in bitter political feuds. Other senior oil men were being murdered by insurgents. One of Mr. Jibouri's aides was gunned down. So instead of lobbying for the important oil post, the 57-year- old industry veteran packed up late last year and moved to Jordan, joining a legion of elite technocrats fleeing the chaos.

DOC.HEADLINE: REAL INCOMES CONTINUE TO SLIDE

TEXT.P: Average monthly incomes in real terms continued to slide in the first six months of this year, although at a slower rate than before, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

While the individual average monthly wage for the January-June period totaled NT$47,207 (US$1,444) -- up 0.96 percent from the same period of last year -- the income in real terms amounted to only NT$34,694, representing a decrease of 0.26 percent.

DGBAS officials admitted that although the 0.26 percent decrease compared favorably with the 0.87 percent drop recorded for the same period of 2005, the modest improvement is not up to public expectations.

The officials said that mergers between banks, the privatization of state-owned enterprises, and soaring commodity prices on the global market were the factors that contributed to the decrease in people's real incomes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER YUNLIN COUNTY PROSECUTOR GETS LIFE SENTENCE FOR CORRUPTION
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin County, central Taiwan, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The Yunlin District Court sentenced former Yunlin County Prosecutor Hsu Wei-yu to life imprisonment on four counts of corruption Tuesday and deprived him of his civic rights, as well as fining him NT$10 million (US$305,064).
Hsu was arrested last September after evidence showed that he used his position as a public prosecutor to solicit money from people who had become targets of criminal investigation.
He indicated after the sentence that he will appeal the case to the Taiwan High Court.

There were 16 other defendants in the same case, including Hsu's elder brother Hsu Pao-yen and sister-in-law Li Meng-hui, who were both sentenced to 12 years in prison, plus fines of NT$1 million each because of their roles as the former prosecutor's accomplices.
Hsu's second elder brother, Hsu Pao-ying, got a 10-year sentence and was ordered to pay a fine of NT$500,000.
Six other accomplices received sentences varying from eight months to two years and six months.
The other seven defendants, including Hsu Wei-yu's wife, Huang Cheng-fang, were found not guilty.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TURN OFF TV' CAMPAIGN LAUNCHED TO PROMOTE READING

TEXT.P: A local publishing company joined with Kingstone Bookstores, one of the largest bookstore chains in Taiwan, to launch a "Turn Off the TV, Turn on Life" campaign Tuesday to encourage people to read more.
Booklife Publishing Co. said the campaign has received hearty support from many local literati, including poet Hsi Mu-jung, choreographer Lin Hwai-ming and academic Lee Chia-tung.
A Booklife spokesman said the campaign is aimed at inspiring people to turn off their TVs for at least an hour a day and devote the time to reading.

"At a time when our society is embroiled in noisy and turbulent political campaigns to depose or support the president, we should not spend too much time watching TV programs that tend to feature spiteful barbs between the rival camps, " the spokesman said, adding that Booklife and Kingston are introducing a myriad of interesting titles to entice readers.

Lin Hwai-ming, founder of the world-renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, said he wholeheartedly supports the campaign because reading is the best way to enrich an individual's life and regain peace of mind in a boisterous environment.
"A full hour of reading in tranquility will bring you enjoyment, vitality and inspiration," Lin said.

Lee Chia-tung, a former president of National Chi Nan University in Nantou County, said too much TV stops people from taking part in a wide variety of healthy activities, including reading, exercise and interaction with friends and family.
"Turn off the TV and spend time reading and exercising. You'll find a new life. I assure you that you'll smile even in your sleep if you read more," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TO DEPOSE PRESIDENT MUSTERS OVER NT$100 MILLION

TEXT.P: The "1 million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian" campaign launched by a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) had received donations surpassing the NT$100 million-mark as of late Tuesday.

Coordinators of the campaign, initiated by Shih Ming-teh, said total funds from donors stood at NT$103.26 million as of Tuesday afternoon, which they claimed meant that the number of supporters for the campaign had reached the target of 1 million people.

Shih launched the campaign Aug. 13, calling for a million people to take part in a protest to seek the ouster of the scandal-ridden president, who has been dogged by a series of corruption and embezzlement cases implicating himself, his family members and senior aides.

Shih urged supporters to each donate NT$100 to finance the campaign and promised to begin a round-the-clock sit-in in front of the Presidential Office after 1 million donors had pledged their support through the donations.
One of his assistants indicated that the sit-in could begin at any time between Aug. 27 and Sept. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILM ON HSUEHSHAN TUNNEL TO PREMIERE ON DISCOVERY CHANNEL

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged the public Tuesday not to miss a documentary on the Hsuehshan tunnel -- described as an "architectural miracle" for the engineering difficulties its builders had to contend with -- to be shown on Discovery TV channel Aug. 27.
Speaking at a news conference to announce the show, Su said the tunnel, a centerpiece of the newly completed Peiyi freeway linking Taipei and Yilan County, is the pride of Taiwan.
"I hope all of my fellow countrymen can take time out to view the film to witness our country's progress in engineering and tunnel construction," Su said.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei said the communications system inside the tunnel is the most comprehensive and advanced in the world. "We'll enjoy a lead in this regard for quite some time to come," he said.

Given the special terrain of the mountain under which the tunnel passes and from which it takes its name, the engineering team employed the most sophisticated equipment, including the world's biggest tunnel boring machine (TMB) . It marked the first time that Taiwan had ever used TMB tunnel construction methods.

The 55.3-km freeway was opened to traffic in June after the 12.9-km Hsuehshan tunnel was completed after 15 years of painstaking construction. The freeway's construction cost more than NT$100 billion (US$3.11 billion).
Of the 25 workers who died during the tunnel's construction, 13 were Taiwanese and 12 were Thai.

The tunnel set many new records. It is Asia's longest and the world's fourth-longest highway tunnel, as well as being the world's longest twin-bore tunnel. The clay and rocks excavated from the tunnels spanned 5.09 million cubic meters, or twice the volume of the Egyptian pyramids. The mixed concrete used in building the tunnel was enough to build seven Taipei 101 towers.

It has been dubbed the "tunnel beneath troubled waters" because of the engineering difficulties encountered. MInister Tsai said the tunnel actually has a third bore which is reserved for use of ambulances in emergency situation.
During the excavation of the tunnel, 48 geological accidents occurred in the main tunnel while the pilot tunnels suffered 42 accidents.

The documentary will be broadcast in eight languages to 23 Asian countries with an audience of 114 million. The documentary will be premiered in Taiwan at 9 p.m. Aug. 27 and in other Asian countries at 9 p.m. Monday. The film will also be broadcast on Discovery global channel later.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOLD FIREWORKS FESTIVAL AT DA DAO CHENG WHARF

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government announced Tuesday it will organize a dazzling fireworks and music festival at Da Dao Chen Wharf in the city's western district this weekend.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said all city dwellers are welcome to attend the fun-filling show and celebrate the second Chinese Lover's Day in leap July.
The program will start at 5:30 p.m. and runs through 9:30 p.m. Blazing fireworks will be presented in six episodes from 8:30 p.m. to 9 p.m.
Many rock bands and pop singers will also performed in the festival, city officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S TRAVEL SCHEDULE YET TO BE FINALIZED: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The itinerary for President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming diplomatic tour of two South Pacific countries has not yet been finalized, senior government officials said Wednesday.
Chen is scheduled to visit two of Taiwan's South Pacific diplomatic allies -- Palau and Nauru -- in early September.

According to the officials, the president's itinerary is still being worked out. Any media reports about the president's possible transit destinations are just speculation and could be misleading, the officials said.
Before the Presidential Office makes a formal announcement, the officials said, the media should refrain from such speculation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 23, or the 30th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1305: Sir William Wallace, Scottish patriot who demanded independence for his country, is hung, drawn and quartered in London.
1754: Louis XVI, king of France at the time of the outbreak of the French Revolution, is born.
1818: The first steamship service opens on the Great Lakes in North America.
1821: Mexico gains its independence.
1912: Gene Kelly, American dancer, choreographer, singer, actor and director, is born. He starred in Hollywood musicals, including "Anchors Aweigh," "Singin' in the Rain" and his "Invitation to Dance."
1914: Japan declares war on Germany.
1926: Screen actor Rudoph Valentino, the idol of millions, dies of peritonitis in New York's Polyclinic Hospital. He was 31. The Italian-born American actor was known for his romantic leading roles in silent films such as "The Sheik" and "Blood and Sand."
1927: In one of the most controversial cases in American legal history, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti are sent to the electric chair. In July 1921, a jury found the two Italian political anarchists and immigrants guilty of the murder of a factory paymaster and a guard during a robbery in South Braintree, Massachusetts.
1928: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung and Chu Teh, and their troops flee to Chingkangshan in Kiangsi Province after being outflanked and besieged by government forces from both the provinces of Hunan and Kiangsi.
1933: Gandhi is released from Poona jail after his hunger strike almost kills him.
1939: The USSR and Germany sign the Molotov-Ribbentropp Non-Aggression Pact, a terrible shock to the Western European leaders.
1940: German bombers begin night raids on London.
1945: Soviet troops occupy Manchuria.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a third invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him Aug. 14 to come to Chungking for a conference and the again Aug. 20.
1958: The Battle of the Taiwan Strait begins with Communist China firing 57,000 rounds in 2 hours at the islands of Kinmen. Many defenders are killed, including Gen. Chi Sing-wen, deputy commander of the Kinmen Garrison Command.
1963: Ambassador to the United States Tsiang Ting-fu signs the nuclear test ban treaty on behalf of the Republic of China.
1981: One hundred and ten people die in the crash of a Far Eastern Air Transport plane. The incident represents Taiwan's worst air disaster.
1990: East and West Germany choose October 3 as the date for reunification.
1990: Amenia declares its independence from Moscow.
1992: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with South Korea.
1998: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks his government and names former premier Viktor Chernomyrdin as acting prime minister.
1999: ROC Premier Vincent Siew is awarded an honorary doctorate in public service by Ohio State University.
2000: Eight mountaineers from Taiwan successfully climb to the 3,776-meter peak of Mount Fuji, thus writing a new page in climbing history.
2001: The 12th Taipei Chinese Food Fair, featuring various kinds of Chinese noodles and delicacies, opens with lively performances at the Taipei World Trade Center.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The Emperor Shun might perhaps be considered in the highest sense of the word a pious man. In moral qualities, he was a saint. In dignity of office, he was the ruler of the empire. In wealth, all that the wide world contained belonged to him."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO START FTA TALKS WITH U.S. NEXT SPRING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan official expressed the hope Tuesday that Taiwan and the United States could start negotiations on the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) next spring.

During a seminar held by the Center for National Policy in Washington D.C., Republic of China deputy representative to the United States John Deng noted that many Asian countries have sought to sign bilateral FTAs with other countries.

For example, Singapore has signed FTAs or engaged in FTA talks with more than 20 countries, and China has entered talks with members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Australia and New Zealand, Deng said.

Meanwhile, the United States has signed an FTA with Australia and is holding talks with South Korea, Deng pointed out, adding that Taiwan, being a major trading partner of the United States, should not be ignored.
Statistics show that bilateral trade between Taiwan and the United States totaled US$58 billion for 2005.
Deng said the establishment of a Taiwan-U.S. FTA will help expand bilateral trade, especially exports of beef and automobiles to Taiwan.

However, several American academics taking part in the seminar observed that in light of Washington's diplomatic agenda and the situation across the Taiwan Strait, the start of Taiwan-U.S. FTA talks might involve complicated political issues.

Early this month, Thomas Christensen, newly-appointed U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said that the timing for the signing of an FTA between Taiwan and the United States has not matured yet.
Christensen said Taiwan should try harder to improve its free trade climate so as to create favorable conditions for the signing of an FTA in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TO DEPOSE CHEN ATTESTS TO FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An ongoing campaign to unseat President Chen Shui-bian over a string of alleged corruption scandals attests to Taiwan's freedom of expression, the country's representative to France said Tuesday.
Yang Tzu-pao made the remarks in an interview with Radio France Internationale.

According to Yang, French government officials are concerned about the latest political developments in Taiwan, particularly the campaign launched by a private group led by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), to depose Chen. Radio France's French- and Chinese-language sections have also interviewed him about the situation.

Yang said his response tends to focus on three key points. First of all, the campaign attests to Taiwan's liberal-democratic advancement which has allowed its people to express their opinions without fear. Second, its national leader is "not a god or divine authority." Third, another dimension of liberal-democratic systems is the rule of law which requires members of the public to respect due process of law and judicial judgment.
Yang said European countries generally agree that the peaceful proceeding of the anti-Chen campaign embodies progress in Taiwan's democratic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY HAS NEVER CONDUCTED DRILLS IN FOREIGN TERRITORIAL WATERS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy has never conducted training exercises in other countries' territorial waters, a military official said Wednesday.

Vice Adm. Sun Yi-cheng, director of the political warfare department at the Navy Command Headquarters, made the remarks in response to media reports that Okinawa officials have asked the Japanese central government to push Taiwan to stop naval drills in waters near Yonaguni, one of Okinawa's outlying islands.

According to the reports, the ROC Navy announced on the Internet that it would conduct training exercises in airspace and waters west of Yonaguni Island Aug. 3, Aug. 8 and Aug. 11. The reports said the Japanese Foreign Ministry had asked Taiwan through the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) to change its military exercise location. The JIA is a quasi-official body auhtorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties.

The reports said Japanese authorities didn't confirm whether the ROC Navy conducted another round of exercises in the area on Aug. 15, Aug.18 and Aug. 22 as scheduled. The reports instead quoted Japanese Foreign Ministry officials as saying that Taiwan should have informed Japan in advance of its military training plans near Yonaguni Island.
In response, Sun said that since the Navy is unlikely to enter any foreign country's territorial waters, it need not serve a prior notice to any neighboring country about its military training plans.

Moreover, Sun said, the Navy has invariably declared its training schedules and exact locations with sufficient explanations plus graphics and illustrations. "Questions raised by Japanese authorities might arise from misreading our vector graphics," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD TO VISIT D.C. NEXT MONTH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of China policy is scheduled to visit Washington, D.C. early next month to bolster ties between Taiwan and the United States, diplomatic sources said Tuesday.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , is expected to arrive in Washington in early September to meet with U.S. officials in charge of Taiwan and China affairs in addition to delivering a lecture at a think-tank on Sept. 5, according to the sources.
Wu is expected to deliver a speech on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and Taiwan's future prospects at the Washington-based Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.

Wu's forthcoming Washington visit is seen as a positive gesture aimed at mending fences with the United States following a spat over the issue of President Chen Shui-bian's U.S. stopover location on his visit to Central America in May, when U.S.-Taiwan bilateral relations slid to a new low, the sources said.

U.S.-Taiwan relations have been "warming" again since June after a visit to Taiwan by American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt, during which Chen reiterated his resolve to stick to his "five noes" pledge, the sources said.

In his 2000 inaugural address, Chen pledged that as long as Beijing has no intention of using military force against Taiwan, he will not declare independence, not change Taiwan's name, not add the state-to-state theory into the Constitution, not promote a referendum on the issue of independence versus unification, and not scrap the National Unification Guidelines during his time in office -- known as the "five noes" doctrine.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMENDED FOREIGN LABOR MANAGEMENT REGULATIONS TO BE PUT INTO EFFECT

TEXT.P: Those who are in charge of foreign labor management must meet certain criteria, according to amended foreign labor management regulations which will be put into practice soon.

Under the amended regulations, those who are in charge of foreign labor management will have to obtain licenses for professionals. If the employers have not followed the rules in hiring management staff, or the management staff have not met certain criteria, then the employers will have their permission to hire foreign laborers revoked unless they improve the situation after being notified.

The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) began working on the amendment to the foreign labor management regulations after a riot last August by some Thai laborers working on constructing Kaohsiung City's mass rapid transit (MRT) system. The riot was triggered by harsh treatment by a manpower management company commissioned by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. to build the MRT system.
A CLA team sent to investigate the causes of the riot found that the living quarters of Thai laborers were too crowded and that the toilets, restaurants and management staff were substandard.

According to the amended regulations, the employers will have to notify local labor authorities to check on their management after hiring foreign laborers so that the labor authorities will also contribute to foreign labor management.
