The Straits Times: Most people able to pay health costs using Medisave.
The Health Ministry yesterday released data to assure Singaporeans that health care here has remained affordable.
The Lianhe Zaoba: U.N. will take Singapore's experiences in water management.
Singapore's experiences in water resoures and wastewater management will be included into the United Nations's Development Report - U.N. World Population Report report.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRANT-IN-AID RECIPIENTS ENGAGE IN MORE VOLUNTEERISM: POLL

TEXT.P: Former recipients of grants-in-aid engage more in volunteer work than non-recipients do, according to the results of a recent poll released Wednesday.

According to the poll conducted by the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) last month on 1,000 former beneficiaries of TFCF grants-in-aid, 42.1 percent of them have consistently or occasionally engaged in social service volunteer work. These beneficiaries have completed their college education with the financial aid provided by the TFCF.

By comparison, TFCF officials cited tallies compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) as indicating that in the most recent year, only 17.09 percent of Taiwan citizens with college or higher education backgrounds who were not recipients of grants-in-aid engaged in volunteer work.

The poll also found that 45.4 percent of the former TFCF aid recipients who are college graduates have made cash donations regularly or occasionally to social welfare causes during the most recent year.
By comparison, only 38.77 percent of non-recipients with college degrees have made such cash donations during the same period, according to the DGBAS tallies.

The TFCF -- the Taiwan version of the U.S. Christian Children's Fund -- conducted the poll in July, receiving 497 valid responses. The beneficiaries received an average of NT$100,325 (US$3,068) in aid from the TFCF.

Huang Hung-wen, a graduate of Hsuan Chuang University's Department of Sociology and a former TFCF grants-in-aid beneficiary, said he never would have been able to obtain a degree without the help of the TFCF program as his father was paralyzed in a car accident when he was a child and his family had been surviving on welfare.

Huang, now a TFCF volunteer worker, said he has been trying to live up to his father's expectations that he give back to society as much as he can for the help he received in completing his education.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGED TO CLARIFY QUESTIONS SURROUNDING PARTY ASSETS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang challenged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Wednesday to clarify several questions regarding the party's assets, including how much was obtained from the national coffers.
Su made the remarks during a weekly Cabinet meeting, in response to the KMT's plan to release a report on its assets later the same day.
Su said the issue of the KMT assets is not an internal affair of the party but is a serious one that concerns whether transitional justice can be upheld in the country.

According to Su, what the people care about is not how much the KMT has earned or lost or how much it has left. Instead, what they care about is how much of the KMT's assets were obtained from the national coffers during its authoritarian control of the country in the past, as well as where and when they were used, and whether the KMT intends to return them to the country and the people, Su said.
Su urged KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to answer in detail a list of questions to address the public's doubts.
The first question is how much in subsidies did the KMT, KMT-run businesses and KMT-affiliated organizations obtain from government agencies, he said.

The second, he continued, is what assets were owned and are still owned by the KMT, KMT-run businesses and KMT-affiliated organizations, how many were transferred from the government or state-owned enterprises, and how were the transfers made and what was the total value of these assets.

The third, he said, is how much was earned by the KMT-run businesses and KMT-affiliated organizations owing to the privileges they enjoyed in the past, how much was saved in tax deductions or exemptions granted by the government, how much in retirement pensions and severance pay for KMT staff was paid out of the national coffers, and what amount was spent on election campaigns and political activities.

Claiming that only if these questions are clarified will Taiwan be able to establish a sound democratic system, Su instructed related agencies to look into the national archives to try to find the answers to the questions.
After the investigation is completed, a special task force under the Ministry of Finance will report the results to the public, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFIRMS UPCOMING VISIT TO PALAU
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian confirmed Wednesday that he will head to Palau, one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, Sept. 3 for a state visit.

Chen told members of the military during a ceremony held on the frontline island of Kinmen to mark the anniversary of victory in a battle against China 48 years ago that he will set out for Palau Sept. 3 for a three-day visit. While there, he said, he will attend the first summit meeting between Taiwan and its six South Pacific diplomatic allies.

The Battle of the Taiwan Strait began with China's shelling of Kinmen Aug. 23, 1958, in a failed attempt to pound Kinmen into submission. China lobbed 480,000 shells in a 44-day barrage, leaving Kinmen pockmarked with craters.
Chen paid tribute to those who sacrificed their lives in the battle, saying he admires their selfless patriotism.

He was accompanied by Defense Minister Lee Jye, Chief of the General Staff Li Tien-yu, and other senior government and military officials on the visit to Kinmen, which lies closer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan proper.

It was Chen's third visit to Kinmen this year, following visits on Jan. 17, during which he announced the naming of a new premier, and June 22, when he reiterated his authority as commander-in-chief of the ROC armed forces while embroiled in a string of corruption allegations against his family and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR URGES TAIWAN NEWS MEDIA TO LOOK BEYOND DOMESTIC POLITICS

TEXT.P: A scholar who opposes using street rallies to depose the president said Wednesday that Taiwan news media are focusing too much on domestic politics.

"Look at Taiwan's electronic media and you'll find the same people discussing the same political issues on the same programs day after day as if there is nothing left for Taiwan except politics, " said Lee Chia-tung of National Chi Nan University.

After he expressed differences with supporters of former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh's campaign calling on "one million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian in a mass sit-in," he was criticized as "too high-brow."

He said Chen indeed should step down to take moral and political responsibility for leading a government with a poor administrative record and being embroiled in a spate of corruption scandals, but "legal channels must be followed to achieve that purpose."

In an interview with the CNA, Lee said Taiwan's media have focused only on Taiwan's politics while Iran's missile test and nuclear program have caused international tension that might lead to soaring oil prices from which Taiwan will not be able to escape.
"But in Taiwan's media, this major international issue is almost non-existent while our government does not seem to have prepared itself well for an impact caused by the Iran issue," he said.
He ridiculed Taiwan's media for adopting an insular world view, locking their audience to "this small island of Taiwan, particularly to its domestic politics."

In fact, he added, there are many more important issues that warrant in-depth reports by the media, such as education, the economy, industrial development, and especially the professional education issue which has been ignored for too long.
"The world is immense. There are not just political stories happening. The media here should broaden their horizons," he said.

Lee, along with another "dissident intellectual" -- writer Lung Ying-tai -- has been accused by Democratic Action Alliance (DAA) leaders of living in an ivory tower and not knowing what is causing great pain to many people.
Lung, complaining that her views have been taken out of context by Taiwan's "lazy media," has promised to elaborate on the subject in an article that she will publish Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES BUDGET PROPOSAL FOR 2007

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved Wednesday the government's budget proposal for 2007, which lists NT$1.51 trillion (US$46.07 billion) in projected revenue and NT$1.66 trillion in projected expenditures.
Hsu Jan-yau, head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said the proposal will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for review next week.
According to the budget, projected revenue for 2007 is NT$127.1 billion, or 9.2 percent, higher than the figure for 2006, with tax revenue contributing NT$118.7 billion to the increase.
The projected deficit for 2007 is NT$152.1 billion, down NT$35 billion from the figure for 2006.
Meanwhile, the projected expenditures figure for 2007 is NT$92.1 billion, or 5.9 percent, higher than that for 2006.

While the projected defense spending for 2007 is listed at NT$323.5 billion, up NT$71 billion, or 28.1 percent, over 2006, the projected spending on science and technology development projects is listed at NT$86 billion, up NT$8.4 billion, or 10.8 percent.
The projected spending on public construction projects for 2007 is NT$139.4 billion, up NT$5.5 billion, or 4.1 percent, over 2006.
A total of NT$82 billion is earmarked for projects related to the maintenance of law and order, up NT$3.4 billion, or 4.4 percent, from 2006.
A total of NT$128.2 billion is earmarked for the establishment of a long-term care system, provision of social relief and subsidization of tuition fees for disadvantaged students.
Also approved Wednesday was a NT$77.4 billion special budget proposal for expanded investment in public construction projects.

The items covered by the special proposal include NT$15 billion for the development of top universities and research centers, NT$4.3 billion for the construction of an international art and pop music center, NT$10 billion for the "M-Taiwan" project, NT$6.5 billion for the project to transform the country's railway system into urban commuter lines, NT$9 billion for the third wave of highway development, NT$800 million for the building of a container center at the Kaohsiung port, NT$25 billion for the construction of subway systems in northern, central and southern Taiwan, NT$6.3 billion for the construction of a sewerage system, and NT$500 million for the establishment of a seawater desalination plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Aug.23 [CNA] The Moscow Times: No Survivors in Jet Crash in Ukraine
A Pulkovo Airlines Tu-154M jet carrying at least 171 passengers and crew members from the Black Sea resort of Anapa to St. Petersburg crashed Tuesday afternoon near the Ukrainian city of Donetsk, killing everyone on board. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO FORM 'GRAND ALLIANCE' TO RETRIEVE KMT-STOLEN NATIONAL ASSETS

TEXT.P: Accusing the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) of selling out its "ill-gotten" party assets that belong to the people of Taiwan, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vowed Wednesday to form a "grand alliance" to retrieve the "stolen" national assets.

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Su Tseng-chang said the KMT's report on its party assets, made public for the first time earlier in the day, was but an attempt to inform the people of how the party has sold out the assets under its name while other critical information remains in the dark.

The DPP leaders announced that the party has gathered 100,000 signatures calling for a national referendum to demand that the KMT return all of its "ill-gotten" assets to the national coffers. A DPP proposal is expected to be sent to the Executive Yuan in early September urging it to hold a referendum on the issue.

Yu said his KMT counterpart, Ma Ying-jeou, chose to publish the party assets report at this point in time, when a campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian is being pushed feverishly, indicating that he is trying to unload the political baggage associated with the party's assets.
Yu said the KMT report does not deal with whether the party's assets were obtained legally or legitimately, "nor did it give a full picture of the assets."

"The issue now is not how much of the suspicious party assets remains under KMT control. Rather, the party should tell the people clearly how much of the national assets it obtained illegally, " Yu said.

He demanded Ma divulge where the funds from the sale of party assets are, the amount by which the assets have shrunk since Ma became party chairman, whether there has been money laundering or conflict of interests, why he has not made good on his campaign promise to return the party assets to the state and who has gained from profits generated by party-owned enterprises.
He also asked whether the account books of party enterprises showing net losses have been doctored so the party can make legal claims.
He asked how much of its overseas assets have been included in the report and how much of them have been re-invested or registered under private names, as are some of the KMT's domestic assets.

Yu said that as Ma will not respond to these questions in a positive manner, and because the KMT has sped up the process of selling its assets -- a total of NT$25 billion-worth recently -- it has become an urgent task to form a "grand alliance" to demand that the KMT return its ill-gotten assets to the state.

Before the campaign to retrieve the KMT assets goes into the second phase of signature-collecting, Yu urged Ma to stop money laundering in connection with the sale of party assets, to stop selling more of its assets and to hand them over to the government.
The KMT, once described as the richest political party in the world, claimed in its report that only NT$27.7 billion-worth of the assets remain in Ma's control.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER RESOURCES AGENCY VIEWS DEEP SEA WATER AS 'BLUE GOLD'

TEXT.P: The Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs is collaborating with the quasi-official Industrial Technology Research Institute to help local companies develop deep sea resources off Taiwan's east coast, resources that the WRA views as "blue gold."

So far, at least three companies have been allowed to start commercial development of Taiwan's deep-sea water resources, which WRA authorities believe could be transformed into the country's new "cash cow" using the inexpensive, "always available" resources from the deep ocean.
WRA officials believe that commercial development of Taiwan's deep-sea water resources could generate business worth some NT$18 billion (US$550 million) a year after investment begins to recoup.
WRA Director Chen Shen-hsien said commercial development of deep-ocean water resources is considered by the government as one of the most important plans in terms of water resource development.

Chen said the WRA is responsible for field research and investigations into sites chosen for commercial development and will be the official unit receiving and supervising applications for the construction of water piping systems.

Chen said Japan and the United States have begun to develop deep-ocean water resources, but Taiwan has much better conditions for such development, given that the country is situated beside the Continental Shelf, while major Pacific Ocean currents regularly pass along the island's east coast.

Chen said the deep-sea regions in Taiwan's exclusive economic zone off the east coast can be used to cultivate high-value fishery products by taking advantage of the water cleanliness, low temperature and richness in minerals and other valuable substances.

Of the three companies, Chen said, one in the eastern county of Hualien is expected to become fully operational later this month after the WRA helped it secure breakthroughs in its operational bottlenecks.

The company is expected to put onto the market newly developed liquors, bottled drinking water, cosmetics and cultured fish and shellfish using clean and cool deep-sea water by the end of this year at the earliest.

Meanwhile, Chen said, the second facility -- financed and set up by Taiwan Fertilizer Co. -- will pump up 2,400 tons to 2,600 tons of ocean water per day from 710 meters below the surface to produce bottled drinking water.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Heral d Tribune: Iran offers to enter 'serious talks'
Iran said Tuseday it was prepared to enter serious talks over its nuclear program, even as it refused to suspend enrichment of uranium, the primary demand of United Nations Security Council, acccording to an European official.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 BUDGET APPROPRIATIONS CONFORM TO ADMINISTRATIVE GOALS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday the central government's budget appropriations for 2007 will conform to the goals of his administration.
Su was referring to the goals of developing the economy, strengthening law and order, taking care of disadvantaged groups, as well as promoting integrity in his administration.
Su made the remarks after the Cabinet passed the budget proposal for 2007 as well as a special budget for expanded public construction projects in a meeting earlier in the day.

The proposed budget for 2007 lists total revenues of NT$1.5117 trillion. The expenditures for 2007 will be NT$1.6638 trillion, up 5.9 percent, over the figures for 2006, representing the largest increase in eight years.
The budget lists NT$323.5 billion in defense spending, up 28.1 percent over 2006, mainly for the purchase of new military equipment.
Su said that budget deficit for 2007 will be NT$152.1 billion, down NT$35 billion, or 18.7 percent, from 2006, which he said was "not achieved easily."
"This shows that the government, while promoting all kinds of administrative works, has taken into consideration financial stability and cutting the budget deficit," the premier said.
He also said that the funds for priority projects, such high-tech sector development, public construction projects and higher education spending, have been listed first in the budget.

The premier said the budget proposal and special budget for public construction projects will be sent to the Legislative Yuan by the end of August for review. The next session of the legislature is scheduled to begin Sept. 19.
The premier urged Cabinet ministers to step up communication with the legislature to facilitate passage of the budget and special budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ASSETS NOW WORTH NT$27.7 BILLION

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Wednesday it has assets valued at NT$27.7 billion (US$0.85 billion) , down from NT$80.8 billion in March, 2000 when the party lost power.

The party made public a "general illustration" report on its assets, which have long been a point of contention between the former ruling party and other political parties in Taiwan that have been demanding that it return its "ill-gotten" assets to the national coffers.

During a central standing committee meeting, KMT Vice Chairman Chang Che-chen said the report was prepared to illustrate the changes in the party's assets from the authoritarian period of 1950-1988 through the transitional period of 1988-2000 to the democratic period of 2000 until the present.
The report shows that in March 1994, when the party registered itself as a "civic group" with the government, it had assets worth NT$38.5 billion.

The assets swelled to a peak of NT$91.8 billion in Dec. 1998, when investments by its enterprises reached a historic high. The figure went down to NT$80.8 billion in March 2000, when the KMT lost ruling power to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Lien Chan took over the party chairmanship from Lee Teng-hui.
In August 2005, when Ma Ying-jeou took over the party helm, the party's assets were worth NT$31.1 billion. By July 2006, they had fallen to NT$27.7 billion.

The NT$3.4 billion difference was caused by the sale of several party properties, including the former party headquarters building, funds from which were used to pay for the party's daily operations over the past year.

According to the report, the current net value of NT$27.7 billion includes NT$2.3 billion in real estate and NT$23.3 billion in businesses that have assets worth NT$44.3 billion and debts totalling NT$21 billion.
The party's real estate includes 612 pieces of land worth NT$1.6 billion and 415 housing units valued at NT$700 million.
The KMT was once described as the richest political party in the world and the DPP has vowed to form a "grand alliance" to demand that it hand back all of its "ill-gotten" assets to the state.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGED TO CANCEL OVERSEAS VISIT PRIOR TO SIT-IN PROTEST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should cancel a planned visit to Palau and Nauru in early September, in response to demands that he step down from the presidency, a spokeswoman for a campaign to depose Chen said Wednesday.

Ho De-fen, a professor at Nanhua University in southern Chiayi County, who serves as spokeswoman for the populist movement led by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh to oust scandal-tainted Chen, made the remarks at a news conference.

Although Chen is perfectly entitled to leave Taiwan at a time when Shih and supporters are planning to start a sit-in on the square in front of the Presidential Office to pressure him to resign, Ho claimed that as head of state, Chen should not "evade the issue."
"The problem will remain even if Chen escapes Taiwan, " she said, urging Chen to heed the public's requirements.

Commenting on the question of when the sit-in to unseat Chen will kick off, Ho replied that it will be decided in the coming days and that volunteer workers have been preparing for necessary arrangements.
She called on the public, regardless of their political affiliation, to take part.
Meanwhile, Chen announced earlier the same day that he will set out for Palau and Nauru Sept. 3 as originally scheduled.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOPOVER REQUESTS TO BE DEALT WITH ACCORDING TO PRECEDENT: STATE DEPT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Ada Tsai)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's domestic politics will play no role in Washington's processing of any requests from Taiwan for transit stops by its president on U.S. soil, a State Department official said Tuesday.

In response to journalists' questions, the official said the State Department will process any such requests based on precedent and will take into account the Taiwan leader's safety, convenience, comfort and dignity.
The official said that it has always been Washington's policy not to get involved in any of Taiwan's domestic political disputes which he added should be resolved by the people of Taiwan.

The official dismissed questions by reporters on whether the United States will allow Chen to make a transit stop in Guam on his way to Palau early next month, saying that he would comment on Taiwan newspaper speculation.

Chen's critics at home are trying to organize a sit in to get rid of him, and have claimed that his trip -- planned, like most state visits, months in advance -- was actually planned at the very last minute to pre-empt the sit-in, which only began to be organized Aug. 12.

They have also claimed that Chen is mulling whether to travel aboard a military jet described by the press as "Taiwan's Air Force One" rather than his more normal use of a civilian aircraft, which would be a symbol of sovereignty on his trip in order to score diplomatic points to divert attention away from growing pressure at home for him to step down over a spate of corruption scandal allegations involving himself, members of his family and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU POPULATION ON DECLINE

TEXT.P: The population of the Matsu island group totaled 9,930 as of the end of July, a drop from 10,066 recorded in late May, according to the Lienchiang county government, which administers the outlying island group.
The Matsu population broke the 10,000 level for the first time in July last year, but has begun declining since that time, county government statistics show.
County government officials attributed the negative growth in population to a steady outflow of residents -- some 50 people per month -- since the three-in-one elections late last year.

They predicted that Matsu's population will only grow until the next election -- which usually draw some "ghost population" -- people from outside the area who register their households there six months prior to an election in order to gain voting rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH CLEANING UP POLLUTED RIVER IN KAOHSIUNG COUNTY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has begun cleaning up the Erjen river in southern Kaohsiung County -- a highly polluted river that has turned into a synonym for environmental pollution in Taiwan, an EPA spokesman said Wednesday.

According to the spokesman, the EPA has commissioned Kaohsiung County with a budget of NT$63 million to carry out the task of cleaning up the river, which has long been polluted by toxic chemicals released by waste circuit boards illegally dumped in the river by factories.
The task, which has recently begun, aims to clear some 4,900 metric tons of waste circuit boards and rehabilitate the river by the end of October, the spokesman said.

Some of the circuit boards to be dug out from the river will be recycled and provided to the public for "art creation, " he said, adding that a contest will be sponsored to select creative works made with recycled circuit boards.
The winning artworks will be displayed at an exhibition sponsored by the county's Environmental Protection Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 24 points to close at 6,515, with 54,678 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October dropped 26 points to finish at 6,519, with 669 contracts traded, while December futures lost 28 points to close at 6,512, with 119 contract transactions.
March futures moved down 28 points to close at 6,500, with six contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,539 for September, 6,545 for October, 6,540 for December, 6,528 for March and 6,548 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

September TE futures moved down 1.25 points to close at 283, with 6,545 contracts traded, while October TE futures dropped 1.6 points to finish at 282.2, with 41 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 0.25 points to close at 284, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures lost 7.8 points to close at 889, with 2,595 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 4.8 points to finish at 890, with 11 contracts traded. December TF futures dropped 15 points to close at 881, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.019 to close at NT$32.779.
A total of US$800 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.780 and fluctuated between NT$32.745 and NT$32.832.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILL 'RESPECT' FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN'S SIT-IN PROTEST

TEXT.P: Embattled President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he will "respect and be tolerant of" an upcoming protest mobilized by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

In his first response to Shih's campaign, the president also said while receiving a German parliamentary group of the Social Democratic Party at the Presidential Office that Shih's protest will be protected by law.

Chen was referring to a planned sit-in protest by Shih in front of the Presidential Office to pressure him to resign over a series of corruption and embezzlement allegations implicating himself, his family members and senior aides.

Shih called for a "one million people to depose the president" campaign Aug. 12, asking the public to donate NT$100 (US$3) each to support his cause. A spokesman for the campaign said the donations passed the NT$100 million mark Tuesday and that the sit-in protest will be held sometime between Aug. 27 and Sept. 9.
The president noted that Shih, a pioneer in Taiwan's democracy movement who was incarcerated for many years for promoting his ideals, was politically persecuted in his early days.
Chen said a letter allegedly written by Shih asking for forgiveness from the late President Chiang Kai-shek "deserves our sympathy."
A DPP legislator displayed the alleged letter Tuesday to vindicate his claim that Shih is not hero he is portrayed as. Shih has denied that the letter was penned by him.
Chen said that anyone who stands up against an authoritarian government is bound to be persecuted.
But he added that Taiwan is now fully democratic and that all "diverse political views and advocacy should be absolutely tolerated, respected and protected."
The president gave his assurance that as a leader of a democratic country, Shih will not be thrown in jail for his sit-in protest.

Chen rose to prominence after serving as one of the defense lawyers for the defendants, including Shih, of the Kaohsiung Incident, a peaceful rally Dec. 25, 1979 to mark World Human Rights Day that turned violent and was suppressed by the then Kuomintang government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREFERENTIAL TREATMENT FOR FORMER PREMIERS TO BE CANCELED

TEXT.P: Preferential treatment for former premiers will be canceled at the end of August following a review, Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Wednesday.

Considering the fact that there is no legal basis for such preferential treatment and because it is difficult to institutionalize the practice, the Executive Yuan has decided to cancel it, Cheng said.
Cheng's remarks came after former Premier Hau Pei-tsun recently returned his chauffeur to the government, raising questions from the media and legislators.

Cheng said the Executive Yuan started to learn about the attitudes toward preferential treatment for former premiers early this month and asked the former premiers themselves about their feelings. All of them said they did not want such treatment.

At present, former presidents and vice presidents have statutes governing their preferential treatment after they step down, while former premiers receive mainly limousines, chauffeurs, free water, electricity and telephone services. When a former premier dies, the privileges are revoked.

Former premiers Lee Huan, Hau Pei-tsun and Vincent Siew, all of the former ruling Kuomintang, receive preferential treatment, while Lien Chan, a former premier as well as vice president under the KMT, is supported by the statute governing preferential treatment for vice presidents.
Former premiers Tang Fei, Chang Chun-hsiung, Yu Shyi-kun and Frank Hsieh of the DPP have not received preferential treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN'S ANTI-PRESIDENT FUND RAISING ILLEGAL: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang claimed Wednesday that as former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh is not allowed to accept political donations, his campaign to depose the president violates the political donations law.
An estimated 1 million people have donated over NT$100 million to Shih's campaign calling on "one million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian" through a mass sit-in protest.
Lee countered critics who claim Shih's campaign is legal, claiming that their argument has committed "two great fallacies."

Campaign supporters have argued that Shih is not a public office holder and is not running for any public office, so accepting donations is not something that should be regulated by the political donations law.
According to Lee, only political parties, groups or individuals running for elected office can accept political donations to hold political activities.
Shih is not qualified to accept political donations or set up bank accounts for that purpose, both of which would implicate that he has broken the law, the minister claimed.

Campaign organizers have argued that the NT$100 (US$3) donations will be used to repay donors attending the sit-in in the form of lunch boxes or bottled water. It can also be seen as a registration fee for the activity and therefore should not be regulated by the political donations law, they claimed.

In response, Lee claimed that all donations in excess of NT$100 are in violation of the law, and that "many people have donated hundreds, thousands and even tens of thousands of dollars to the campaign, and these law-violating donations should be investigated by the Control Yuan.

As to criticism that the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has violated the rule of bureaucratic hierarchy by commanding the Control Yuan to crack down, Lee said his ministry is in charge of the political donations law.
"If we do not call on the government authorities in charge of enforcing the law to do its job, the MOI could be charged with negligence," he claimed.

He also fought back at critics who claim that the MOI has been trying to play a dominant role in enforcing the march and assembly law, claiming that these critics have made statements contrary to the fact.

"If the MOI was fully in charge of the march and assembly law, we would not have given permission to stage a 15-day, 24-hour-a-day sit-in that would affect Taipei citizens' rights to attend school, visit hospital and live normal lives," Lee said.

As to how police will handle the sit-in, he said that as a rule, the city police will take care of order and only when the situation turns so bad that it is beyond the city police's capacity will the National Police Administration under the MOI intervene.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, sliding 33.87 points to close at 6,556.33.
The bourse opened at 6,584.66 and fluctuated between 6,587.46 and 6,454.71 during trading. A total of 2.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$76.05 billion (US$2.32 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement shares moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by banking and financial issues at 1.4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.3 percent, construction stocks at one percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent, and textile stocks at 0.3 percent.
The other two major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up at 0.6 percent and plastic and chemical stocks increasing 0.03 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 692 to 333, with 140 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Suspects charged over airline bomb plot 'will deny all the allegations'
Eleven people, including the mother of an eight- month-old baby, appeared in court for the first time yesterday in connection with an alleged plot to blow up transatlantic airliners.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iran Won't Give Promise to End Uranium Effort
Iran responded Tuesday to a set of incentives from Europe and the United States aimed at ending its nuclear program, but did not agree to suspend the enrichment of uranium by the end of the month, the West's primary demand.
In its response, Iran offered "serious talks" over its nuclear activities but did not raise the issue of suspending enrichment by Aug. 31, the deadline established by the United Nations Security Council, Western diplomats said.
"What they have not done is address the key point, whether or not they are going to suspend, said one senior European official involved in the Iran negotiations. Following traditional protocol, the official and other diplomats spoke only on condition of anonymity.
Wall Street Journal:Housing Slump Proves Painful For Some Owners and Builders
For years, real-estate brokers and home builders promised that the soaring property market eventually would glide to a soft landing. These optimists predicted that home prices, which had more than doubled in parts of the country between 2000 and 2005, would continue to rise, but at a more normal pace of 5% or 6% a year.
It isn't working out that way. The rapid deterioration of the market over the past 12 months has caught many homeowners and builders off guard. Some are being forced to cut prices far below what their homes could have fetched a year ago. It's too early to say how hard the landing will be, but at a minimum it will be bumpy for many people who need to sell homes. And the economy as a whole, buoyed in recent years by the housing frenzy, could suffer.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 NATIONAL SAILING TOURNAMENT TO BE HELD IN YILAN

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei Yachting Association will sponsor a national sailing championship Aug. 26-27 in Yilan County, eastern Taiwan, an association spokesman said Wednesday.

Yachtsmen from sailing clubs as well as those from high schools and universities around Taiwan will take part in the 2006 President Cup tournament, which is an important ranking race to select national representatives for international yacht races, the spokesman said.
As a natural, eco-friendly and pollution-free activity, sailing has become more and more popular in Taiwan, he said.

Taiwan's first national sailing tournament was held in 2003 in Fulung, in northern Taipei County, and the 2006 national sailing championship to be held on Yilan's Tungshan river is expected to help generate greater local interest in the sport, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CALLS FOR REINVESTIGATION INTO '319 SHOOTING'

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) called for a new investigation into the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu Wednesday after a report released by the second "319 truth commission" a day earlier claimed that the lone suspect in the incident did not kill himself but was murdered.

The 150-page report, released by the 17-member commission formed in May according to an amended statute to unearth the truth about the incident, used about 60 pages to present a forensic analysis led by James Chun-i Lee, a professor at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Forensic Medicine.

The report said the only suspect, Chen Yi-hsiung -- whose body, wrapped in a fishing net, was found in Tainan's Anping harbor 10 days after the incident -- did not die because he fell into the water and drowned, and nor did he "commit suicide because he feared punishment," as claimed by an investigation task force formed mainly by prosecutors from the Tainan Public Prosecutor's Office.

"Chen Yi-hsiung's body was dumped into the water after he died, and it is most likely that he was murdered," according to the forensic analysis, based on an re-examination of the photos and other evidence collected from the scene where his body was found.

Commenting on the new findings, Legislator Tsai Chin-lung, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said the KMT caucus will ask the legislature to pass a resolution to request that the Supreme Prosecutor's Office reopen the case.

Tsai deplored that members of the second "319 truth investigation commission" met strong resistance from the Cabinet in the past three months when they asked to go through related documents about the incident.

He said that after the next legislative session opens Sept. 19, the KMT caucus will also ask the legislature to submit the names of all those uncooperative officials to the Control Yuan -- Taiwan's highest watchdog body -- for impeachment.

The March 19 shooting occurred when the president and vice president were campaigning in a jeep in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan. The KMT and its ally, the People First Party, believe the incident generated sympathy votes for Chen and Lu, helping them to win the election by a mere 29,500 votes.

The opposition parties also suspect that the incident was staged. Their demand to form a commission to investigate the shooting met strong resistance from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
The first commission formed according to an organic statute passed by the legislature flopped because the Council of Grand Justices ruled that some clauses of the statute were unconstitutional.

After the opposition-controlled legislature amended the statute in April, the second commission was established and empowered to ask any organization to provide documents and evidence for its examination.
The commission is required to submit a written report to the Legislative Yuan and the Control Yuan every three months. It is expected to complete its probe in six months.
In August last year, the Tainan Public Prosecutor's Office closed the case after concluding that the lone suspect in the shooting incident apparently committed suicide.

Chen Yi-hsiung's wife, who had previously admitted that her husband carried out the shooting because he was depressed about being unemployed and blamed the president's policies, told a news conference in March that she was coerced into giving false testimony implicating her husband.

Claiming that her husband was murdered, she presented what she described as new evidence from a videotape about the "critical 17 seconds" in the "hot zone" of the shooting and asked that the case be reinvestigated to clear her husband's name.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TOUTS ADMINISTRATIVE ACHIEVEMENTS IN 1ST HALF YEAR

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that the government has achieved major policy goals in the first half of this year, with the economic growth rate reaching an estimated 4.74 percent.

Su made the remarks at a weekly Cabinet meeting in which the central government's 2007 budget plan was reviewed and approved. The draft budget bill will be referred to the Legislative Yuan next week for approval in the new legislative session set to open in September.
Also discussed at the meeting was a draft version of the premier's administrative report to be delivered at the opening session of the legislature.
Su said he will give a detailed account of the government's major achievements in the first half year and its future agenda in his administrative report to the legislature.

In the first-half year, Su said, the domestic economy kept booming, with external trade and export orders continuing fast growth and industrial production and job openings increasing steadily. Compared with the same period of last year, nearly 200,000 new jobs were created while the inflation rate was relatively mild.

Until May, Su said, the government's economic monitoring index consistently flashed a green light symbolizing stable growth for 10 months. In June, the index turned "yellow blue" signaling an economic slowdown because of a combination of factors, including skyrocketing crude oil prices, a global stock market slump and the domestic political upheaval over corruption allegations against members of the first family and the president's close aides.
Su said the administration should redouble its efforts in the second half of the year to keep the economy humming along.

Quoting a report by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Su said the domestic economic growth rate reached 4.74 percent in the first half of the year and the growth rate for the whole year is estimated at 4.28 percent, representing a 0.25 percent increase year-on-year.

Since the government launched a crime-fighting campaign in March, Su claimed that public satisfaction about law and order has rebounded. According to statistics, the number of criminal cases and violent crimes declined between March and August from the year-earlier level, while the crime solution rate has been rising steadily. The number of theft and fraud cases declined by 13.36 percent and 10.79 percent, respectively, during the same period.
"All these figures point to a marked improvement in law and order through concerted efforts of police and other government agencies, " according to Su.

On the promotion of welfare benefits and services for disadvantaged groups, Su said the central government has launched a new aid program for youngsters from impoverished families and has assisted local governments in hiring more professional social workers to protect children and juveniles from abuse or maltreatment.
During the first-half year, Su said, the Executive Yuan also submitted to the legislature draft packages of revisions to the
laws governing national health insurance, welfare for the elderly and employment services.

In an unprecedented move to boost clean politics, Su said, the Executive Yuan unveiled early this year a basket of rules requiring political appointees to put their assets into trust after they assume office.

To show its determination to boost political integrity, accountability and transparency, Su said the Executive Yuan is drafting revisions to the public functionaries assets disclosure law to expand the scope of assets subject to mandatory disclosure, require mandatory entrustment of their assets, introduce a dynamic assets disclosure mechanism and investigate unaccountable asset increases.

"We hope the revision bill can clear the legislature in the near future to prevent public functionaries from influence peddling or abusing their power for illegal financial gains as part of the campaign to wipe out political corruption," Su said.

The Washington Post: Iran Pushes For Talks Without Conditions U.N. Demand for Freeze On Nuclear Work Rejected
Iran offered yesterday to enter into immediate and "serious" negotiations on a broad range of issues with the Bush administration and its European allies but refused to abide by a U.N. Security Council demand that it suspend work at its nuclear facilities by the end of the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIGENOUS YOUTHS EXPERIENCE TAIWAN ON 10-DAY TOUR

TEXT.P: A group of indigenous youths said Wednesday they have learned a lot from a 10-day tour that focused on cultural exchanges and environmental protection and took them from aboriginal tribal villages to nuclear power plants and Taipei City.
The tour, which was co-organized by the National Youth Commission (NYC) and the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU), is part of the NYC's Youth Action Plans initiative.

Seven of the eight teenagers on the tour come from the Tao tribe, which resides on Lanyu island, located 76 km off the coast of southeastern Taiwan. During the trip, they picked up a new partner from Smangus, a Taiya tribal village in Hsinchu County.

The youths from Lanyu were especially emotional when they visited the No. 1 and No. 4 nuclear power plants, TEPU secretary-general Ho Tsung-hsun said at a press conference Wednesday, as their home is used by the Taiwan Power Co. as a nuclear waste dump, he said.
They also visited Smangus, a village that has implemented a "communist" social system that has been passed down from their ancestors, to get a feel for the culture of a different tribe.
Other locations they visited on the tour included Tainan City, Chiku Lagoon, Sandimen township in Pintung County, and the Taipei Artist Village.

The culture experience tour is one of more than 40 programs organized by NYC in cooperation with non-governmental organizations to encourage Taiwanese youth participation in local affairs, according to NYC Minister Cheng Li-chiun.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST E-LEARNING EXHIBITION TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The first e-learning exhibition showcasing the work of government agencies and the e-learning industry will be held from Aug. 25-27 in Taipei, the organizers announced Wednesday.

The "e-Learning World, Taipei" exhibition will present the latest developments in one of the fastest- growing online industries, said Wu Ming-chi of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

"The e-learning industry has taken the world by storm. In Taiwan, it went from a gross market value of NT$700 million in 2002 to NT$10 billion this year. I'm proud to say that Taiwan is doing well compared to other countries, " Wu said.

The exhibition is being held against the background of a global fever of Chinese learning. Ten governmental agencies and more than 30 companies will participate in the show of more than 250 booths and more than 25,000 visitors are expected over three days.

Local businesses have been paying attention to the trend of e-learning, Wu said. The number of top 1,000 local businesses that have implemented e-learning platforms in the past three years has increased threefold, he added.

The development in Taiwan reflects the global trend, said Yen Shan-wu, president of teh e-Learning Industry Alliance. Yen said that the global e-learning market value has gone from US$2.1 billion in 2001 to US$67 billion in 2006 and shows that everything -- even learning -- has become digital in the Internet age.

The free exhibition is being organized by the Taipei Computer Association and directed by the National Science and Technology Program for e-Learning. It will be held in Hall 2 of the Taipei World Trade Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS URGES KMT TO RETURN ILL-GOTTEN PARTY ASSETS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which published a report on its party assets, to "spit out" the assets that belong to the people of Taiwan Wednesday.
Yeh Yi-jin, caucus secretary- general, said the KMT's "general illustration" report on its party assets was trying to hide the fact that a majority of the assets were obtained through improper means.
By expressing apology, the KMT actually was not doing anything about the key point at the heart of the issue -- to return what is due to the people of Taiwan, she said.

Deputy Finance Minister Lee Rui-tsang called on the KMT to make public all of its account books and help pass a statute on political party assets as a means of showing its sincerity in facing the issue.
According to the Ministry of Finance's Bureau of National Properties, the KMT has to date returned only 1.29 percent of state-owned real estate to the government.

The KMT will only win the people's trust when its helps legislate a law on political party assets and cooperate with the government in building a mechanism for political parties to engage in fair competition, Lee said.

KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao suggested that the KMT focus on legislating the political party law instead of the party assets law so that political parties will be obligated to publicize their finances regularly.
Lai, also a member of the KMT central standing committee, had the support of other members and more importantly, that of Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, for his proposal to enact a political party law.
Under such a law, Ma said, political parties must abide by rules when they raise and use political funds and when they hold party elections, and violators will be disciplined.

Ma admitted that many of the party's assets were ceded to Taiwan by the previous Japanese government, which ruled Taiwan from 1895 to 1945, and claimed that the KMT's ownership of these assets is legal but "morally questionable."
He said that a political party that owns assets is not violating any law, but must not manage any profit-making business.

Based on that principle, he said the KMT's Central Investment Corp. will be closed by 2008 and all party assets will be put in trust following an actuary account of regular spending on running the party.
He estimated that NT$2 billion is needed per year to pay for a pension fund for the party's workers, with another NT$900 million required to pay for retired workers' monthly pensions.

The party's assets report shows that between 2000 and 2005, the KMT's assets shrank by NT$49.7 billion mainly because its seven investment holding companies lost a total of NT$42.7 billion from investments that were ravaged by the 1998 Asian financial crisis.

The report said that the KMT used its own funds to help relieve small- and medium-sized businesses that were in financial trouble, a decision that it claimed was made in consideration of the nation's overall economic interest.

However, if "human factors" were involved in some of the losing investment projects, a task force will be formed to investigate and legal action will be taken against possible irregularities, said Chang Che-chen, the party's vice chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO SUE KMT LEGISLATOR FOR SLANDER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will file a slander suit against an opposition lawmaker for alleging on television that funds designated for state affairs were used to pay for miscellaneous expenditures of the first family, the Presidential Office said Wednesday.

A statement released by the Presidential Office said that Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiu Yi made false accusations against the president and his family when he said that allowances for state affairs were used to pay for his grandson's English books, his son-in-law's expensive pen and dog food.
The allegations discredited the first family, and the president has no choice but to sue Chiu for defamation, the statement said.
It added that Chiu should base his remarks on facts rather than on speculation or rumor because as a legislator, his words are likely to fall on receptive ears.
Chiu is a frequent whistleblower on corruption scandals involving government officials. Some of the alleged irregularities he has exposed have led to investigations by public prosecutors.

According to an unofficial count kept by TV commentators, the president, his family and senior aides of the Presidential Office have been dogged by 32 corruption and embezzlement scandals, some of which have entered legal proceedings.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW-INCOME HOUSEHOLDS ACCOUNT FOR 1.16%: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan had 85,183 low-income households at the end of June this year, accounting for 1.16 percent of the total number of households, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.
The number marked an increase of 22,000 households from that registered in 2001.

Among them, 4,171 households, with a total of 4,414 members, could not make a living by themselves and had to wholly rely on social welfare. Over the past five years, the number of this category of households remained almost the same but if compared with the 2001 level, the number of family members in the category marked a 3-percent decline.

A second category of low-income families, which refers to households that have no more than one-third of members working and their per capita monthly income falling below the level of NT$7,750, numbered 22,200 households, with a total of 45,107 family members.
Compared with the 2001 level, the number of households in this category dropped 1.6 percent and the number of their total family members slid 0.6 percent.

A third category of low-income households refers to households that had a per capita monthly income of NT$14,377. The number of households in this category stood at 60,792, up 10.6 percent from the 2001 level, while the total number of family members in this category reached 156,786, marking a 10.5 percent increase.

DGBAS officials attributed the sharp rises in the third category of households and their family members mainly to hikes in the minimum living expenses and increased awareness among poor families that they can apply for social welfare subsidies.
In the first six months of this year, the government appropriated NT$2.53 billion for living subsidies for low-income families, up 1.7 percent from the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACE CANNOT RELY ON ENEMY'S GOODWILL: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reminded the public Wednesday that peace can never be built on the basis of an enemy's goodwill and that robust defense capabilities are the bedrock for achieving lasting peace.

Chen made the remarks while presiding over a ceremony on the outlying island of Kinmen to mark the 48th anniversary of victory in the Battle of the Taiwan Strait, known locally as the "823 Battle, " against China in 1958.

The "823 Battle " began on Kinmen Aug. 23, 1958, with China shelling the Taiwan-held island. The battle was regarded as the second-biggest military confrontation to occur in the Taiwan Strait since 1949.

On that day, China's People's Liberation Army, in a bid to take the island, launched an intensive attack and fired heavy artillery at several islands off Kinmen. In 85 minutes, they had fired more than 30,000 shells.
The artillery bombardment continued until Jan. 7, 1959 with the total number of shells fired at Kinmen and the surrounding area exceeding 480,000.
The intense artillery assault was eventually repulsed by the Republic of China troops stationed there, although many soldiers and civilians were killed or injured.

Chen said the victory in the "823 Battle" lay a solid basis for Taiwan's survival and development in the following decades and a crucial factor for peace in the Taiwan Strait over the past half century.

"While commemorating the victory and paying tribute to those who gave their lives in the operations, we must not forget the historical lesson that peace cannot be built on the basis of an enemy's goodwill," Chen said.

In the face of China's deployment of more than 800 missiles aimed at Taiwan, Chen said, the country should continue beefing up its defense capabilities and modernizing its military arsenal to safeguard national security and maintain cross-strait peace.

Chen was accompanied by Defense Minister Lee Jye, Chief of the General Staff Li Tien-yu, and other senior government and military officials on the visit to Kinmen, which lies closer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 24, or the first day of the leap seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The small but very bitter war being fought between Britain and the United States continues, with British forces razing many Washington, D.C. landmarks, including the White House.
1923: A "Dr. Sun Yat-sen mission" led by Chiang Kai-shek leaves Harbin for Moscow on a fact-finding tour.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's Nationalist government, signs the ratification instrument of the U.N. Charter.
1945: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China ratifies the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: Communist China sends troops into Tibet.
1954: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the Communist Control Act, outlawing the Communist Party.
1954: Brazilian President Getulio Vargas shoots himself to avoid scandal as well as demands that he relinquish power. He was 71.
1968: Taichung's Golden Dragons baseball team defeats the U.S. West team 5A-0 to win the 23rd Little League World Championship.
1981: A Manhattan Supreme Court judge jails Mark David Chapman for 20 years to life for shooting dead John Lennon the previous December.
1983: The auditorium of Fengyuan High School in Taichung County collapses, killing 27 students and injuring 83 others.
1983: Communist Chinese pilot Lt. Col. Sun Tien-chin, who flew to South Korea from mainland China in a MiG-21 jet fighter Aug. 7, arrives in Taiwan.
1985: Communist Chinese pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, flies an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea and requests political asylum in the ROC.
1986: The ROC Little League baseball team "Kungyuan" defeats Tucson, Arizona, and recaptures the Little League World Series title after four years.
1991: The Ukraine declares independence from Moscow.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as head of the Soviet Communist Party and urges its leadership to disband the party.
1992: Communist China and South Korea establish diplomatic relations.
1995: President Juan Carlos Wasmosy of Paraguay leads a delegation to Taipei for a four-day visit.
1995: Beijing expels Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu shortly after he was sentenced to a 15-year prison term for spying and leaking state secrets.
1996: The ROC wins the 1996 Little League World Series in the U.S. city of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
1999: A UNI Air plane from Taipei crash-lands at Hualien Airport in flames, injuring 28 passengers.
1999: Ever Decent, a Panamanian-flagged container ship owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp., is hit by Norwegian Dream, a Bahamas-registered cruise ship, injuring three people aboard the cruise ship.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian wraps up his visit to Chad ahead of schedule after issuing a joint communique with Chadian President Idriss Deby.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian officiates at the opening of the plenary session of the much-anticipated Economic Development Advisory Conference Friday, a series of meetings and discussions designed to invigorate Taiwan's floundering economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses great moral qualities will certainly attain a corresponding high position, a corresponding great prosperity, a corresponding great name, and a corresponding great age."

2001: President Chen Shui-bian officiates at the opening of the plenary session of the much-anticipated Economic Development Advisory Conference Friday, a series of meetings and discussions designed to invigorate Taiwan's floundering economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRITER LUNG NOT AGAINST TAKING TO STREETS AS DEMOCRATIC EXPRESSION: MA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that writer Lung Ying-tai, who has declined to donate NT$100 in support of a populist campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian, is not opposed to the idea of taking to the streets as a means of "democratic expression" of one's political views.

Ma was commenting on a long article written by Lung which appeared in the Thursday edition of the China Times newspaper, in which she explained why she has chosen to stick with the "institutional approach" -- namely using one's vote -- to drive an unpopular political leader out of office.

Lung said she agrees with former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who initiated the campaign calling on "one million people to depose the president" through a mass sit-in protest, that Chen should step down to take moral and political responsibility for a spate of corruption scandals involving his family members and close aides.
However, Lung added that she does not agree with Shih's "street demonstration" approach to unseat a president whose integrity and credibility are highly in doubt.

In Taiwan's democratic system, people can demand that their head of state resign by pushing their representatives in the Legislative Yuan to recall or impeach him, she said, adding that if those two constitutional methods do not work, then the people should try to have the "rules of game" amended, rather than taking to the streets to make their point.

Lung, a former cultural bureau director in Ma's Taipei City government, asked the people of Taiwan to think about "the possible consequences of trying to depose a president through pressure expressed on the streets."
Ma, who doubles as mayor of Taipei, said Lung did not rule out "taking to the streets" as a means of expressing one's views in a democratic country.
"Like professor Lee Chia-tung (of National Chi Nan University) , she is just worried that street demonstrations might turn violent and that Taiwan could become a 'mobocracy,'" he added.
But taking to the streets does not necessarily mean "mobocracy" will ensue, Ma said. "There is some misunderstanding in this respect," he added.

He pointed out that what Lung was trying to drive home in her article is that in a democracy, there are different options to force a politician out of office, including street demonstrations and the ballot box.

Ma himself has donated NT$100 in support of Shih's campaign in his capacity as a private citizen. His party has encouraged party members to join the upcoming mass sit-in organized by Shih and his supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: CATHOLIC CARDINAL WILLING TO MEDIATE RULING-OPPOSITION STANDOFF

TEXT.P: Cardinal Paul Shan Kuo-hsi said Thursday he would like to act as a go-between if the ruling and opposition leaders are willing to have a dialogue, hoping that "things can be worked out peacefully."

However, the cardinal said he suspects "the two of them" -- referring to President Chen Shui-bian and opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou -- are "mature enough" to have meaningful dialogue that could bring harmony to Taiwan society.

Chen and Ma had a rare dialogue in early April without reaching any major consensus. Since then, the president has been busy with "damage control" measures to save his political future as one after another corruption scandal allegations involving his family and close aides have arisen.

Shan, who has recently been diagnosed with pulmonary cancer, said he is worried by a rising tide of radical calls for the president to step down and for protecting the "president of Taiwan, " after former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh launched a campaign to depose Chen.

Ma has voiced his support for Shih's campaign and encouraged party members to join his upcoming sit-in protest, and the DPP has countered with a national campaign to retrieve the KMT's "ill-gotten" assets, creating more turmoil in an already tense society.

Shan said he respects his "good friend" Master Hsing Yun, a Buddhist leader, for issuing a statement calling on the president to voluntarily step down to prevent possible social unrest and "maintain his dignity as a decent national leader."

However, Shan said he would not wade into politics. "Political matters should be left to political figures, " he said, urging them to exercise self-restraint and refrain from radicalism and violence so as not to "blur the focus" and create "ethnic and political divisions."
Shan, whose illness is now under control, said he would like to dedicate the rest of his life to promoting ethnic harmony and cross-Taiwan Strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUAM STOPOVER A NATURAL CHOICE ON PRESIDENT'S TRIP TO S. PACIFIC: MOFA

TEXT.P: It would be very natural for President Chen Shui-bian to plan to stop over in Guam during his upcoming visit to the South Pacific, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

MOFA deputy spokesman Wang Chien-yeh noted that the U.S. territory of Guam would be a convenient choice since it is located in the region and that the United States has made it clear that it will take into account factors such as safety, comfort, dignity and convenience in processing any requests from Taiwan for its president to stop over on U.S. soil.
Wang declined to comment on whether Chen is planning to travel to the South Pacific on a military jet, on the grounds that the issue does not fall under the authority of the ministry.
Chen is scheduled to depart Sept. 3 for Palau to attend a leader summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the South Pacific before heading on to Nauru for a visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO ATTACH IMPORTANCE TO ORAL HEALTH OF CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The government should attach more importance to the oral health of school children given the fact that the average 12-year-old child in Taiwan has more than three cavities, the Association for Dental Sciences of the Republic of China said Thursday.
Chang Chin-shun, an association adviser on oral health, cited statistics as showing that the incidence of cavities in Taiwan children below the age of five is as high as 89.5 percent.

Meanwhile, 12-year-old children in Taiwan have 3.31 cavities on average, which he said is quite far from the goal set by the World Health Organization (WHO) of 90 percent of children under five years old having no cavities and of 12-year-old children having no more than two cavities by the year 2010.
Chang urged the government to pay attention to the worsening oral health of Taiwan children and to pass the budget for a "five-year project for oral health" speedily.
In addition to adding fluorine to water, he also urged the use of more effective fluorine coating on children to prevent cavity.
He noted that less than 10 percent of the Taiwan people visit the dentist at least once a year, making the work of promoting oral care from an early age even more important.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL RESEARCH TEAM DEVELOPS 'VIRTUAL BIOPSY' METHOD

TEXT.P: A local medical research team announced Thursday that they have developed a new cancer diagnosis technique called "virtual biopsy, " which uses femtosecond laser pulses to scan the human body without the pain and hazards involved in conventional needle biopsies.
The newly developed biopsy method can run 100 million scans per second, as well as generating up to three images every second, according to the team.
The immediate next steps of the team are to increase the scanning frequency and to combine the technique with endoscopes, in order to obtain biopsy images deep inside the body.

The team, led by professor Sun Chi-Kuang at National Taiwan University's (NTU) Electrical Engineering Department, includes members from Sun's department, NTU's Institute of Molecular and Cellular Biology, the Center of Nanoscience and Nonotechnology at National Chung-hsing University, National Taiwan University Hospital, and the Institute of Molecular Medicine at National Cheng-kung University.
The virtual biopsy project is being funded by the National Health Research Institute, with a total budget of NT$9 million for the three-year term.

The new biopsy method utilizes Cr: forsterite laser to generate scanning beams at a center wavelength of 1230 nanometers and a pulse frequency of 100 femtoseconds, or one-ten trillionth of a second, Sun noted, adding that due to the extremely short duration of laser penetration, the pulse does not damage the tissue being observed.

Su explained that when passing through larger cells, laser pulses will turn into red-light; and while passing through smaller ones, the light expression will be blue-purple. All the light, received by a collecting device, can later be translated into biopsy images for diagnosis.

When it comes to conventional needle biopsies, Su said, the first problem is that the pain scares patients, adding that the needle sometimes brings cancer tissue residuals around, "contaminating" normal cells and thus accelerating metastasis.

The team has already tested the virtual biopsy method on mice and zebra fishes, and it has also made observations on zebra fish's cell nuclei, cell divisions, and blood capillaries, Su said, adding that all the animals "came out without a scratch."
