DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER INDICTED FOR SUSPECTED VIOLATION OF STOCK EXCHANGE LAW

TEXT.P: Lin Wen-lang, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator, was indicted Thursday on charges of violating the Stock Exchange Law.

The Taipei District Prosecutors Office charged that Lin had used insider information to speculate in the stocks of a textile company and a cable and wire company between April and June of 2002 and had hid his stock earnings in the bank accounts of his brother and an acquaintance.

Lin replaced Chiu Yung-jen in May 2006 as a DPP legislator-at-large, who along with another DPP lawmaker, Lin Chin-hsing, were prosecuted on charges of defrauding the national health insurance program.

Chiu lost his status as a party-nominated lawmaker under the proportional representation system after he was expelled from the party. Lin, also kicked out of the DPP, remains as a member of the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT REPORTEDLY POSTPONES JAPAN TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Ada Tsai)

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui has postponed his trip to Japan because of personal health concerns, the Japan Broadcasting Corp. (NHK) reported Thursday.
The NHK report did not elaborate on Lee's health concerns or the source of the information.
Lee's office in Taipei, which announced Aug. 19 that the former president would be traveling to Japan Sept. 12-17, had no comment on the NHK report.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOSE FRIEND EXPRESSES OPPOSITION TO SHIH'S CAMPAIGN TO OUST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Chen Chu, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidate in the year-end Kaohsiung mayoral election, expressed Thursday her disapproval of a campaign led by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh to depose President Chen Shui-bian.

Chen Chu, who like Shih was jailed on charges of sedition under martial law in the 1979 Kaohsiung Incident and who has since become a close friend of Shih, voiced her opinion on the matter in an open letter titled "believe in democracy, there is no single hero."

Chen wrote that she disagrees with Shih's intent to make the campaign the final battle of his life as if it is a revolution and that she believes Shih is as pained as she is by the prospect of the confrontation and hatred expected to be brought about by the campaign.

Chen said that although she has never doubted Shih's ideals, she wants to remind Shih that "there are only people, and no single hero, " referring to what she called the media's attempts to paint a heroic image of Shih.

Chen noted that the president was elected by the people through a democratic process and that if the people want the president to step down, there are constitutional methods such as initiating a motion to recall or impeach the president.
"The Constitution is not designed to protect Chen but instead to prevent the loser in a democratic election from using various strange reasons to try to reverse the results," she said.

No matter how disappointed Shih is in the president and how corrupt he believes the president to be, he has no right to use his personal judgment to negate the choice of the people made at the ballot box in 2004, Chen said.
Chen said that despite her disagreement with Shih's advocacy and conduct, she respects his right to do so and objects to the personal attacks made on him recently by some DPP members.

She pointed out that the fact that Shih has successfully raised NT$100 million in a short period of time for his campaign indicates that a large segment of the population is angry with the DPP's rule, and she urged the DPP to tolerate and take this resentment seriously.

She said the DPP should tolerate the Shih-led sit-in protest for as long as it lasts and should stop the party's politicians from leading another group of people to the scene to counter Shih's action.
Stressing that the people have the right to express their anger at the government, Chen called on the DPP to conduct self-examination sincerely and face the people's anger squarely.
She urged the DPP to stop its politicians from resorting to "mud slinging and provocative moves" that might lead to violence so as to allow the matter conclude peacefully.
Meanwhile, she urged Shih to try to "resolve hatred with compassion and transcend conflict through democracy."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR SHARES IDEAS ON BUILDING HEALTHY CITY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou shared his ideas on building a healthy city Thursday with his counterparts from 27 domestic and foreign cities at an international conference held in Taipei City.
Ma spoke of his efforts in improving public restroom facilities, garbage collection and sewage treatment in Taiwan's capital.

He noted that since he assumed the mayorship in 1998, he has promoted improvement of the city's public restrooms, saying that over 70 percent of the approximately 10,000 public toilets in Taipei are labeled excellent in terms of safety and cleanness.
He also honored restroom cleaners, saying that they should be respected for their contribution to the city.

He also noted that Taipei has implemented a garbage separation and recycling program during his mayorship, pointing out that the program has led to a significant reduction in the amount of garbage. He added that Taipei is expected to reach the goal of "zero burial of garbage and full recycling of all reusable resources" by 2010.

Ma also spoke of the improvements made in the city's sewage treatment system and noted that with the assistance of three local chiefs, the level of pollution in the Keelung River has been reduced significantly in recent years.

Meanwhile, Pete McHugh, a supervisor in the city of Santa Clara, Calif., also shared his city's experiences in implementing a green business program. He said that under the program, private companies with fewer than 300 employers will join the environmental protection program so as to cut the city government's costs in environmental protection monitoring.
Other participants in the conference talked about various issues, including developing suitable residential cities, creating pride in one's city, and good city governance.
The two-day conference ended Thursday evening, with participants taking a tour to the famous Shihlin night market.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP HEAD'S NEPHEW PAYS UNCLE'S NT$2 MILLION DEBT TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A nephew of former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh paid NT$2 million (US$60,910) to President Chen Shui-bian Thursday to help his uncle clear his debt with the head of state, whom Shih has recently been campaigning to have deposed.

Shih Chao-lung visited the Presidential Office with a petition and a check for NT$2 million. A Presidential Office official accepted the petition but declined to take the check on the grounds that he does not have the authority to receive checks or cash on behalf of the president. Shih then went to a nearby post office to send the check to the president by registered mail.
Shih said Chen Shui-bian loaned the money to his uncle to pay for his daughter's medical bills. "Clearing the debt will be good for both the president and my uncle," he added.

Shih pointed out that he and his wife lent NT$6 million at zero interest to the former DPP chairman to buy a house so that he would not become a "stray dog," as Koo Kuan-min, a former senior advisor to the president and a staunch advocate of Taiwan independence, referred to Shih Ming-teh recently.
The nephew called on Chen's supporters to stop trying to dig up dirt from his uncle's past, including posing questions about Shih's ownership of a house in an expensive neighborhood.

The nephew also called on the DPP to treat Shih's former wife Chen Li-chu properly, instead of using her to attack Shih for failing to treat her and their daughters well while he was imprisoned by the KMT government at the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 5.69 points to close at 6,550.64.
The bourse opened at 6,540.03 and fluctuated between 6,570.62 and 6,525.36 during trading. A total of 2.25 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$58.42 billion (US$1.78 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.7 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 527 to 460, with 186 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS NOT INDICTED FOR REVEALING TAICHUNG MAYOR'S MEDICAL RECORDS

TEXT.P: Taichung prosecutors decided Thursday not to indict 12 doctors who were sued by the Taichung mayor over alleged forgery, defamation, leaking of business secrets, and violation of the election and recall law in May due to lack of evidence.

Mayor Jason Hu filed a complaint at the Taichung District Prosecutors' Office in late May against Legislator Lin Chin-hsing and 11 practicing physicians in the central city after they held a joint news conference a few days prior to the mayoral election Dec. 3, 2005, to unveil Hu's personal medical records in an attempt to thwart the re-election bid of the popular mayor from the opposition Kuomintang.
Lin was also a practicing physician at the time.

Hu, who once suffered a minor stroke, was then dogged by questions from supporters of Lin Chia-lung, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate in the mayoral election, about whether he was healthy enough to serve another four-year term.
Prosecutor determined that the medical records unveiled at the news conference were all genuine and were undoubtedly leaked by Taichung Veterans General Hospital.

As none of the 12 doctors had ever personally treated Hu and as no proof could be found demonstrating that any of them had any connection with doctors or their assistants at the Taichung hospital, the prosecutor in charge of the case determined that the accused should not be indicted on the charge of leaking business secrets.

As to the defamation charge, the prosector said that because the accused were found having been active in the promotion of a proposed bill demanding that administrative leaders publicize their health records as proof of their administrative capability during the election campaign last year, it is too difficult to determine whether their act of revealing Hu's "weak" health condition was aimed at defaming the popular mayor's name or exposing Hu's "personal secrets."

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY 80 ORGAN DONORS IN FIRST HALF OF 2006: DOH

TEXT.P: While 6,905 people around Taiwan were on a waiting list for an organ transplant as of June 30, 2006, there were only 80 organ donors in the first half of this year, according to tallies released Thursday by the Department of Health's (DOH's) Tainan Hospital.

Of the patients waiting for an organ transplant, 3,789 were in the northern region, 2,129 were in the southern region, 831 were in the central region, and 160 were in the eastern region, the tallies show.
The organ donors included 43 in the northern region, 17 in the southern region, 13 in the central region and seven in the eastern region, according to the tallies.

The Times: Hezbollah warns Blair: you're not welcome in Beirut

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REBUTS REPORT ON USE OF TANKS TO QUELL PROTESTS

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office rebutted Thursday a cable TV report that the office is prepared to use tanks to crack down on demonstrators who cross the red lines marked on a road designed to keep them away from the Presidential Office.

Presidential Office officials discounted as "unfactual and exaggerated" a TVBS report the day before claiming that the Presidential Office would use tanks to ward off demonstrators if they turn a peaceful sit-in into a mob riot and cross the red lines on Chungching South Road leading to the Presidential Office.

Describing the report as "unbelievably untrue, " the officials said that Taiwan is a country which upholds the rule of law and that the Presidential Office fully respects the people's right to assemble.
The officials, however, stressed firmly that the government will not tolerate any actions aimed at inciting violence.

Former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh and his supporters plan to stage a sit-in in front of the Presidential Office starting next week calling for "one million people to come out to depose President Chen Shui-bian."
President Chen has been embroiled over the past several months in a string of corruption allegations against his family members and close aides.

The Presidential Office officials said that the office hopes the planned sit-in will be conducted in a rational and peaceful manner and that the office will not add extra hands in efforts to protect the president's safety and maintain order in areas surrounding the Presidential Office during the sit-in period.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY UNVEILS PLAN TO HELP DROPOUTS RETURN TO SCHOOL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) unveiled Thursday a plan aimed at helping school dropouts return to school.

While the ministry will keep tabs on any schools with more than 15 dropouts and schools with relatively high dropout rates, education authorities in various counties and cities should prepare charts comparing the number and ratio of dropouts every month and provide guidance to the concerned schools whenever necessary, according to the plan.
Also, schools should pay extra attention to students who are absent from school for more than seven days.
The plan was announced during a meeting of chiefs of education bureaus held in the southern county of Pingtung.
MOE tallies show that a total of 7,448 students dropped out of school during the 2005-2006 academic year.
As of the end of June this year, 5,491 dropouts had returned to school, or 73.72 percent of the total number of dropouts.
While the number of dropouts stood at 4,156 as of the end of July 2005, the number had decreased to 2,981 as of the end of July this year.
MOE officials said there are 10 schools with a high number or ratio of dropouts, with four in Taipei County, three in Taoyuan County, two in Kaohsiung County and one in Keelung City.

Common reasons cited for students dropping out of school include family problems, such as parents going into hiding from their creditors and single parenthood, as well as personal problems, such as unhealthy living habits and addiction to hanging out at Internet cafes, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDICIAL YUAN PRESIDENT VISITS MATSU
DOC.DATELINE: Matsu, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Yu Hao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng paid a visit to Taiwan's outlying island of Matsu Thursday to inspect judicial services that the central government provides to the people living on the island situated off the coast of China's Fujian Province.

After inspecting the Lienchiang District Court on Matsu, Weng, who is the first Judicial Yuan president to visit Matsu, said he was impressed with the high morale demonstrated by legal personnel working on Matsu even though the Lienchiang District Court is the smallest court in the country with the smallest workforce.

Weng said he was relieved to see that the Lienchiang District Court -- which was established in December 2003 under Weng's espousal -- provides efficient services to meet the judicial needs of the Matsu residents, who currently include some 6,000 military personnel and around 5,000 civilians.

Weng said he was equally impressed by the environment around Matsu, which he described as a "quiet and clean retreat" blessed with blue sky, emerald seas, the pleasure of island hopping and breathtaking defense works built along steep cliffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOULD STEP DOWN: BUDDHIST MASTER

TEXT.P: An influential Buddhist master urged embattled President Chen Shui-bian Thursday to heed "the will of the people" and step down.

Master Hsing Yun, founder of the Fo Guang Shan International Buddhist Order, which is headquartered in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan and supports temples worldwide, made the remarks to elaborate on why he wrote a letter published prominently in a major local daily that day.

The respected monk called for the voluntary resignation of the president, who is facing an imminent sit-in protest launched by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, to pressure his resignation over a string of corruption and embezzlement allegations against himself, his family members and senior aides.
The master said in the letter that both Chen and Shih have had the experiences of rising up on the stage and stepping down and should not "take the matter so seriously."

Hsing Yun said he sent the letter "out of respect for the president, " adding that he could not bear to read any more news against him. Chen has visited the Fo Kuang Shan temple and is like a friend, said Hsing Yun.

Chen is a civil servant and has served more than six years as president. When it's time to go, he should not hang onto his post, the master continued. In fact, Chen's second and last term will expire in May 2008.
With mounting public outcry for the president's resignation, if "he can go resolutely now, it will not only be a plus to the DPP, but will keep his own dignity," according to Hsing Yun.
He also lauded Shih, saying that he deserves respect in that he bears no grudges against anyone despite spending a quarter of a century behind the bars for his political ideals.

Although the political ideals of Shih are different from those of Chen, the unrelenting assault against Shih recently by some DPP politicians is no good for the party or for Chen and will only further alienate the people, according to the Buddhist master.
Hsing Yun is one of the few religious leaders to have expressed a stance on the current political storm.
Rev. Kao Chun-ming of the Presbyterian Church said he will remain neutral but he believes Chen should serve out his term.

Cardinal Paul Shan Kuo-hsi said Thursday he would like to act as a go-between if the ruling and opposition leaders are willing to have a dialogue, hoping that "things can be worked out peacefully, " while Master Sheng Yen of the Dharma Drum Mountain and Master Cheng Yen of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation refused to comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ACCUSES GOVERNMENT'S 2007 BUDGET OF IGNORING ECONOMY

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) accused the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration Thursday of ignoring the needs of Taiwan's economy after the Executive Yuan made public the 2007 expenditure budget for the central government a day earlier.
KMT legislative caucus whip Tsai Chin-lung made the comment while answering questions from reporters on the issue.

The Executive Yuan approved Wednesday the central government's expenditure and income budget plans of NT$1.66 trillion and NT$1.51 trillion, up by 5.9 percent and 9.2 percent, respectively, year on year. Budgets for the Ministry of National Defense totaled NT$323.5 billion, an annual increase of 28.1 percent, or about NT$71 billion.
According to Tsai, the large growth in budget allocations for military purposes reflects a lack of concern by the DPP government for the people's livelihoods.

Criticizing the government's increased military spending budgets as turning a deaf ear to the people's call for a better economy, Tsai urged Premier Su Tseng-chang to pay heed to the public's complaints about rising product prices and stagnant salaries.

"The people want a better economy, not an overemphasis on the military, " he said, adding that the KMT will definitely scrutinize the government's budget bills in the next legislative session which will open in mid-September.
The Executive Yuan is slated to put forth next week its 2007 budgetary program for the central government for legislative screening.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR NAVAL BASES TO HAVE OPEN DAY

TEXT.P: Four naval bases will be opened to the public Aug. 26 as a means of helping to strengthen the public's awareness of national defense, a spokesman for the Naval Fleet Command said Thursday.

The navy's bases in Tsoying and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, Keelung in northern Taiwan and Makung on the outlying island of Penghu will be open to visitors Sunday, the spokesman said, adding that parents are encouraged to bring their children to see them.

The public will be allowed to enter the cabins of the various classes of vessels anchored at the ports -- including Kangting-class and Chengkung-class frigates and Zwaardvis-class submarines -- to gain a first-hand understanding of the working conditions and everyday lives aboard the ships.

On the same day, a painting contest will be held at the four bases with the aim of spicing up the visitor's day -- a channel through which the navy hopes to help step up the public's national defense concept and increase contact with them, especially families of navy personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP SHOULD BE READY TO TAKE OVER AS PRESIDENT: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu should distance herself from scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian and be prepared to take over as president if the "1 million people to depose the president" campaign succeeds, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday.

Speaking at a news conference of the Democratic Action Alliance, Hsu Hsin-liang, who co-founded the DPP in 1986 and served as its chairman twice from 1991 to 1993 and 1996 to 1998, suggested that Lu should sever connections with the president bravely.
"A vice president is not just an assistant to the president but also a president-in-waiting," Hsu said, adding that Lu's opportunity is here after serving as vice president for six years.

Hsu also urged main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to join the campaign to depose Chen launched by another DPP chairman, Shih Ming-teh, who has vowed to stage a round-the-clock sit-in in front of the Presidential Office until Chen agrees to step down.

"The campaign is the people's movement against government corruption and has nothing to do with confrontation between political parties. KMT leaders and their supporters should not stand aloof from this campaign," Hsu added.
He pointed out that holding protest demonstrations to pressure the president to step down is a right granted by the Constitution.
"The campaign to depose Chen has become necessary because the built-in mechanism in the Constitution is not sufficient to make a corrupt president relinquish his post," he said.

Chen is facing a grave political crisis because he himself, his family members and senior aides have been implicated in more than 30 corruption and embezzlement scandals, some of which are being investigated by public prosecutors.
The campaign to depose Chen has received more than NT$108 million (US$3.3 million) from some 1 million people who each donated NT$100. The sit-in is expected to begin at some point in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMISTS WORRY OVER ANTI-PRESIDENT CAMPAIGN'S IMPACT ON ECONOMY

TEXT.P: If the ongoing "1 million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian" campaign continues to expand, it will have a great impact on social stability and will affect private investment in the country, researchers of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) predicted Thursday.

They further speculated that Taiwan's economic growth in 2006 could further drop from the 4.03 percent of the previous year due to the anti-Chen campaign and a planned round-the-clock sit-in initiated by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, in an attempt to get Chen to resign.
The researchers claimed that the assessment was conducted "purely out of economic concerns, " noting that the stock market in Taipei had dropped over the past few days.

They said that if the political turmoil resulting from the public's disappointment over Chen's leadership cannot be settled quickly, Taiwan could be faced with a downgraded national rating by independent international rating institutions.
To an international investor, the political stability of a country is the first and foremost concern in deciding whether or not to invest in that country, the economists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DEPOSE CHEN' CAMPAIGN TO PREPARE FOR SIT-IN PROTEST

TEXT.P: A campaign to force embattled President Chen Shui-bian to resign will end its donation drive and move to the next stage -- preparation for a sit-in protest, a spokeswoman for the campaign said Thursday.

He Teh-feng made the remarks at a news conference as she announced that the two bank accounts and one post office account opened to accept donations for the "1 million people to depose the president" would close at midnight Thursday.

Former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who served as party chairman from 1994-1996 before leaving the party in 2000, called for members of the public to donate NT$100 (US$3) each to support his cause. When the donation reached NT$100 million mark, it would be time to stage a sit-in protest in front of the Presidential Office to pressure Chen to resign over a series of corruption and embezzlement allegations implicating himself, his family members and senior aides, according to Shih.

Noting that the donation passed the NT$100 million mark Tuesday, she said that to avoid diminishing the momentum that has been building up, Shih, after consulting with campaign officials, decided to close the three accounts to focus on the preparation for the sit-in, although anyone wanting to send money can still transfer the money through ATMs, she said.
She also said that as of Thursday, the accumulated donations had come to NT$109,180,809.
She said the sit-in will probably start Sept. 1 or Sept. 2, prior to Chen's scheduled departure for an official visit to Palau Sept. 3, or Sept. 8 and Sept. 9, after his return from the visit.
Lawyer Wei Chien-feng, a long-term supporter of the president before joining the campaign, also addressed a call by Rev. Kao Chun-ming of the Presbyterian Church for Shih to stop his campaign.

Wei pointed out that the campaign was not launched by Shih, but was proposed by academics and civic groups irrespective of their political stripes, and that Shih only is one of many who promote the campaign.

On Kao's questioning of Shih's moral standards, Wei also said that this has "blurred the line between the public and private domains, " claiming that the campaign has "nothing to do" with the follow-up action by the opposition parties after they failed to recall the president in late June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARREFOUR BECOMES TAIWAN'S NO. 1 HYPERMART AFTER ACQUIRING TESCO

TEXT.P: The French retail group Carrefour SA became Taiwan's largest discount hypermart Thursday with 44 outlets after taking over British Tesco Plc's business operations in Taiwan.
Carrefour Taiwan General Manager Loic Dubois announced at a Carrefour outlet in Taoyuan the merger of all Tesco's six outlets in Taiwan into Carrefour Taiwan.

At the same time, Tesco, the world's third- largest retailer, withdrew completely from the Taiwan market Thursday after swapping its Taiwan operations with 15 outlets that Carrefour has until now operated in Czech Republic and Slovakia.

Talks about the Carrefour-Tesco swap deal began late last year and the swap started to take place in March this year after Carrefour SA -- the largest retailer in Europe and second-largest in the world -- and Tesco were given the green light by the authorities from the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Taiwan.
Taiwan's business giant, Unipresident Enterprises Corp., is a major partner of Carrefour Taiwan, holding about 30 percent of the stakes of the Taiwan operations of Carrefour.

Allan Tien, chief of Carrefour Taiwan's Development Division, said currently there are 102 hypermart outlets operating around Taiwan with annual transactions totaling some NT$110 billion (US$3.35 billion). This retailer business, he said, is expected to double to some NT$240 billion in years to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Aug.24 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Black Boxes From Plane Crash Found
Flight data recorders from the Pulkovo Airlines plane that crashed in eastern Ukraine, killing all 171 on board, were recovered Wednesday. Bad weather is believed to be at least partly to blame for Tuesday's crash of the 14-year-old Tu-154M. All of the bodies have been found. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.066 to close at NT$32.845.
A total of US$858 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.830 and fluctuated between NT$32.816 and NT$32.850.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September remained unchanged at 6,515, with 31,298 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October decreased four points to finish at 6,515, with 159 contracts traded, while December futures decreased 12 points to end at 6,510, with 18 contract transactions.
March futures moved down 20 points to close at 6,500, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,515 for September, 6,519 for October, 6,522 for December, 6,520 for March and 6,524 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

September TE futures moved down one point to close at 282, with 4,032 contracts traded, while October TE futures decreased 2.05 points to finish at 280.4, with 15 contract transactions. March TE futures decreased 2.35 points to end at 280.7, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and June.

September TF futures lost three points to close at 886, with 1,291 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 2.8 points to finish at 887.2, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION CHIEFS MEET ON BETTER CARE FOR DISADVANTAGED STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Education bureau chiefs in cities and counties around the country met in the southern county of Pingtung Thursday to discuss how to integrate resources for better welfare services for disadvantaged students.
The meeting, organized by the Ministry of Education, will last through Friday.

The agenda focuses on themes with regard to priority enrollment to government-run kindergartens for children from low-income families, mentally and physically challenged children, aboriginal children and children born to disadvantaged mothers.

Other topics to be discussed will include enlisting retired teachers, disadvantaged college students and reserve teachers to offer tutoring services to disadvantaged elementary and junior high school students, as well as to expand after-school care and tutoring services for working mothers.
Also on the agenda is a comprehensive plan to pool education, police and social resources to help dropouts return to school.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE IDENTITY-CONSCIOUS MEDIA WATCH GROUP FOUNDED

TEXT.P: A media watch group focusing on media reform with a priority on Taiwanese identity has been established and it will soon launch an attack on mainstream media to encourage accurate and fair news reporting, organizers said Thursday.
The society, which has not been given an English name, is a coalition of former journalists and political commentators and will officially announce its establishment Saturday.
Falsification and human rights abuse within journalism will be two issues the group will be keeping an eye on at all times, said group director Chung Nian-huang, an ex-reporter with a 15-year career.

"We want to make clear that people not only have the right to know but also the right not to know. And people have the right to say `no' to sensationalist news reporting as well, " Chung said, pinpointing the biggest complaints about the sorry state of Taiwan's media.
Chen Li-hung, deputy director of the group, also stressed that Taiwanese identity will be one of the main focuses of the group, which opposes the current media trend of tilting toward China.
"We're not trying to be an enemy of the media. We are trying to bring journalism back to where it is supposed to be, " Chung said.
Among the founding members of the group are former journalists Huang Kuan-chin, Hsu Chi-chih, Hsieh San-tai and political commentators Chin hen-wei and Paul Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: In New Method for Stem Cells, Viable Embryos
Biologists have developed a technique for establishing colonies of human embryonic stem cells from an early human embryo without destroying it. This method, if confirmed in other laboratories, would seem to remove the principal objection to the research.
It could also redirect and intensify the emotional political debate over current limits on federal financing for research on human embryonic stem cells, which give rise to the cells and tissues of the body and which scientists and patient advocate groups see as a potential source for treatments for diseases like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and diabetes.
Wall Street Journal:China's Big Push To Stoke Economy Rattles Rural Tibet
China is trying to revive poor rural regions through economic development. In Tibet, the plan has hit a snag: Ni Ma won't slaughter his yaks.
Duan Xiangzheng, a Chinese Communist Party official charged with stimulating the economy here, is pushing for the systematic slaughtering of yaks to kick-start a meat- packing industry. Mr. Duan says exporting the beefy tasting meat and the animals' black wool to markets elsewhere in China makes economic sense and is an "inevitable" development.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SINCERE ON PARTY ASSETS ISSUE: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is sincere in honoring its promise to return its improperly acquired assets, and its report on the issue does not mean to target anyone, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou claimed Thursday.

The KMT report on its assets and liabilities made public a day earlier is not aimed at holding anyone accountable, rather it is a sincere apology to the public, Ma said, adding that the KMT is willing to return its ill- gotten assets to the public or the government.

According to the KMT report, the KMT recorded a loss of NT$42.7 billion due to 28 money-losing investment cases -- all made during the 1988-2000 period when former President Lee Teng-hui also served as head of the party.

The KMT hopes that the report will verify "historical facts" regarding the issue and that some of the party's properties, although acquired through legal means in the past, are also available for public scrutiny, Ma said, pointing out that he himself also has to be examined by the public.

KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen told a news conference at the party's headquarters later in the day that an 11-member panel has been set up to take charge of responding to comments on the party's assets on behalf of the party.
In the future, no other individuals or KMT members are entitled to make comments on the issue on behalf of the party, he said.
Meanwhile, the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) questioned the motive behind Ma's move in publishing the report.
TSU legislative caucus whip David Huang described Ma's move as an attempt to pave the way for his participation in the 2008 presidential election "in the name of reform."

"Ma not only has failed to return the KMT's illegally acquired assets to the people, but he is also trying to forge a clean and reform-minded image prior to the 2008 presidential election, " Huang said.
The TSU will continue promoting various "sunshine laws" to demand that the KMT return all its assets unlawfully obtained during its authoritarian rule of Taiwan to the people, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S MILITARY THREAT TO TAIWAN SERIOUS: ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: China's military threat to Taiwan is serious and if the current situation persists, there are only two feasible cross-Taiwan Strait scenarios in the future -- the fall of Taiwan or an armed conflict -- a Japanese professor warned at an international seminar Thursday.

For all China has done, a reasonable prediction would be "if Taiwan does not accept unification on China's terms, China will unify Taiwan by force in 10-15 years, regardless of Taiwan's government policy, " said Masako Ikegami, director of the Center for Asia Pacific Studies at Stockholm University in Sweden.

Ikegami made the prediction in a lecture titled "Anatomy of Peaceful Rise: Driving Forces Behind China's Grand Strategy" at the two-day seminar on the rise of China and Beijing's strategies and implications for the Asia Pacific, which was organized by Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's top research institute.

China wants to be recognized as a world-class power, said Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu in his opening remark, adding that this is why China "wants some international problems to be there so that it can play a role in international relations. " Wu was referring to the Iranian and North Korean issues.
"We need to encourage China to be more aggressive in living up to the expectations and responsibilities as a superpower, " Wu said.

Commenting on China's military threat to Taiwan, Wu said the priority would be to increase Taiwan's military budget and shore up a defensive capability to "show China that it can't take Taiwan quickly."

On the diplomatic front, there are only 24 allies left for Taiwan now, he said, which means that working with Australia and Japan is vital in order to maintain peace and stability in the Asian Pacific region.

According to Wu, co-existence with China in a peaceful way is "a long-term goal for Taiwan, " adding that if China becomes more democratic, it will be more attractive for Taiwanese people to think about political or economic integration in the future."
The seminar will conclude Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICIANS CRITICIZED AS 'BAD EXAMPLES' TO YOUNG GENERATION

TEXT.P: The newly launched Action Alliance to Promote Character Education formed by 10 educational organizations and foundations criticized Taiwan's politicians Thursday for setting bad examples to the younger generation.

The domestic political environment has rapidly depraved the character of Taiwan people, whose moral standards have dropped far lower than six years ago when the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was still not in power, executives of the alliance claimed.

Quoting statistics from a recent survey carried out by the alliance, they said 73 percent of the respondents agreed that the character of Taiwan people has been deteriorating over the past six years, with another 90 percent believing that the conduct of politicians has a big influence on social mores.
They blamed this phenomenon of moral regression mainly to the behavior of politicians whose vulgar language and bad manners offer "the worst examples" for children in their formative years.
More recently, the situation was made even worse because of the series of corruption scandals involving President Chen Shui-bian, his family members and senior aides.

They said bluntly that something was "definitely wrong" with the character education in the first family, and urged that character education should be a priority in all levels of schools, as well as in society.
"Taiwan should begin an immediate overall review of the moral crisis it is in," the alliance officials said, adding that a mechanism should be established to strictly monitor cronyism of politicians.

The 10 educational organizations and foundations that initiated the alliance include the Thousand Generation Cultural and Educational Foundation, Shih Chien University, and Wei Chuan Cultural and Educational Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOURNALIST REMOVED FROM POST AFTER SHOUTING AT PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A journalist with the Chinese-language United Daily News was removed from his post Thursday after he shouted "step down" at President Chen Shui-bian during an award presentation ceremony.

The journalist, identified as Ting Wan-ming, reportedly shouted "Chen get down! " at the president while waving a placard saying "Depose Chen" after Chen delivered a speech at a ceremony marking the presentation of awards to top quality products and their producers.
Ting was immediately subdued by security guards.

Responding to Ting's behavior, the United Daily News authorities issued a statement later in the day saying that Ting had severely violated the principle of journalism and broken the work ethics as a journalist. As a journalist, the statement said, Ting should know how to separate his personal political affiliation and his job.
The United Daily News respects every staff member's personal political affiliation but also strictly requires all staff to observe journalism ethics while on duty, the statement said.
The statement said Ting will be removed from his post as a journalist and will be transferred to another post at the daily.
Ting said he was speaking for what he claimed is "over 60 percent of the Taiwan people" who think Chen should be unseated as he has lost the trust and respect of the people.

He said that only by speaking directly to the president can the "Depose Chen" drive succeed, adding that the "one million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian" campaign initiated by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh and his supporters is "meaningless."

DOC.HEADLINE: GREEN ISLAND RESIDENTS AGAINST TOURISM CONTROL

TEXT.P: In response to a government plan to impose a visitor quota control to conserve the natural environment of Green Island off southeastern Taitung County, a group of island residents expressed opposition Thursday to the idea, claiming that it will not help improve their livelihoods.

The residents voiced their disagreement to the plan in a township meeting after it was reported that the Executive Yuan is considering whether to limit the number of visitors to the tiny island to under 4,000 per day and that it is also projecting to make the island a national park to better conserve it.

Claiming that a quota control will not help effectively resolve its deteriorating environment, they suggested that the government consult with local residents -- mainly fishermen and tourism-related businesses -- to work out complementary measures.

If tourism controls is imposed on Green Island without advance auxiliary measures to help local residents, their livelihoods will be adversely affected, the Green Island township representatives said.

In addition, they went on, some tourist agency operators have begun considering to give up organizing tours to the island -- a development that will lead to losses in other sectors, including hoteliers and restaurant owners.
According to the township representatives, it is much more important to upgrade the quality of travel to Green Island and to "simultaneously protect local environments with eco-friendly measures."
Imposing a quota control on visitor numbers alone will not resolve the many problems facing the islands, such as overfishing and backward tourist and fishing facilities.
What the government should do is help Green Island go international and make it into a world-class eco-friendly resort island, they said.

Until recently a quiet backwater where unregulated tourism has been allowed to run rampant, Green Island is now overrun by hordes of tourists on weekends and holidays, spelling disaster for the delicate on and offshore ecosystems.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND URGED TO REMAIN NEUTRAL ON 'DEPOSE PRESIDENT' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker accused the Ministry of National Defense (MND) Thursday of not keeping a neutral stance toward the "1 million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian" campaign.

Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung, who serves on the legislature's National Defense Committee (NDC), said that by issuing a statement to express the military's support for the scandal-ridden president, the MND has violated the principle of administrative neutrality.
Ting also blasted the Combined Services Force Headquarters for asking post offices near military barracks to provide the names of servicemen who donated NT$100 each to help finance the campaign.
"This is a blatant violation of personal privacy," he said, noting that members of the armed forces are also entitled to basic human rights under the Constitution.
Ting said he welcomes military personnel to report cases of such violations to the NDC, and he promised that he will have those military leaders found responsible dealt with according to law.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER ASHAMED OF DPP'S INACTION AGAINST ATTACK ON EX-CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: An outspoken ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker said Thursday he feels utterly ashamed of his party's connivance over certain party members' scathing attack on a former party chairman.

Legislator Lee Wen-chung made the remarks after some DPP politicians have continuously castigated former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh over the past few days in retaliation for Shih's launch of a "1 million people campaign" to depose President Chen Shui-bian over a string of corruption allegations against himself, members of his family and staff.

Earlier in the day, two of his colleagues even accompanied Shih's divorced wife Chen Li-chu in unveiling a letter allegedly dictated by Shih to seek leniency from the authoritarian Kuomintang (KMT) authorities when he was kept behind bars for his pro-democracy and pro-independence advocacy.

Lee said he felt "outrageously embarrassed" by his DPP colleagues' move and guilty about the DPP headquarters' failure to stop all the tit-for-tat defamation of Shih, who is described by some as "Taiwan's Mandela" as he was incarcerated for 25 years as a prisoner of conscience during Taiwan's infamous martial-law era.

Acknowledging that Shih should be subject to public examination since he has long been a political figure, Lee said such scrutiny should be confined to matters related to public interests and political ethics. The recent attacks on Shih by some DPP politicians have gone beyond acceptable boundaries and have infringed upon Shih's privacy, Lee said.

Lee said the DPP used to be suppressed and demonized in mass movements in its long process of fighting against authoritarian rule. Once in power, he said, the DPP should be magnanimous enough to tolerate people's right to stage street rallies and demonstrations against the government.

The DPP should also not ignore the public discontent and grivances accumulated over the past six years since its ascent to power, Lee said, adding that Shih is just a catalytic figure for the unfolding anti-Chen campaign.

Lee said he feels those DPP politicians who have exploited Shih's behavior during the notorious martial-law era to attack him are as cruel as the former KMT rulers who demonized Shih as a "seditious devil."
He further said entire society and the media should also conduct self-reflection.

"When society and the media questioned some radicals' defamation against Shih, they should also think about that over the past six years, they have acquiesced numerous unfounded accusations against President Chen that have almost 'destroyed' his character and tainted his images," Lee said.
For instance, he said society and the media have never questioned the style of KMT Legislator Chiu Yi's constant sensational accusations against the president and the first family.

While he personally opposes any retaliatory action, Lee said he still feels that the outrageous "smearing Shih" actions taken b y some DPP radicals and pro-independence die-hards are related with the society's and the media's long silence over Chiu's frequent indecent acts.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DECIDES TO CANCEL PART OF ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATIONS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has decided to cancel some of the party's planned public rallies slated for September in Taipei due to an expanding campaign aimed at pushing President Chen Shui-bian to resign, a DPP official said Thursday.

Deputy DPP Secretary-General Tsai Huang-liang explained that the canceled activities were organized as celebrations for the DPP's 20th founding anniversary and that the party had planned to take advantage of the events to campaign for its candidates in the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayor elections.

Despite the cancellation of the activities after thousands of people expressed support to the "1 million people to depose President Chen" initiated by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh Aug. 12, Tsai said the DPP will still invite all party founders to a party planned for Aug. 28 at Taipei's Grand Hotel, where the DPP was established in 1986.

The founders include President Chen, Premier Su Tseng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh, incumbent DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung and National Security Council Secretary-General Chiu Yi-jen.
The anti-Chen campaign will include a planned "round-the-clock" sit-in in front of the Presidential Office, likely to kick off at the beginning of September.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUG. 25 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, Aug. 25:
09:30, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend a seminar on reform and innovation of civil service to be held at National Taiwan University Hospital conference hall.
10:40, The Presidential Office will hold a news conference to announce the itinerary for President Chen Shui-bian's South Pacific diplomatic tour.
16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-LAWMAKER'S VIOLENT ACT ON TV SPURS CONDEMNATION

TEXT.P: Former Legislator Lin Cheng-chieh became the focus of an overwhelming outcry after he assaulted a political commentator with punch and kicks in a television program Thursday night.
Lin, an outspoken critic of President Chen Shui-bian, beat Chin Heng-wei, the editor-in-chief of Contemporary Monthly Magazine, in a Formosa TV (FTV) talk show emceed by Hu Wan-ling.

Chin, a longtime supporter of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , sustained injuries to his nose, forehead and leg. He reported the case to police after receiving emergency treatment at a hospital.

Chin was also once attacked by a China-born veteran for his support for the pro-independence DPP. Chin, whose parents also came to Taiwan from China after the Chinese communists took over the mainland, said he forgave that elderly soldier. But he said he cannot forgive Lin and will definitely bring him to justice.
The TV program continued after a brief interruption. Lin apoligized to the emcee, FTV and its audience, but he showed no sign of repentance in his hatred of Chin.
His act of gratuitous violence in brute display shocked society and immediately spurred vehement condemnation from various social quarters.
FTV authorities said their program offers a platform for people of different political affiliations to air their views, but they added they cannot tolerate any act of violence.

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun paid a visit to Chin to extend his regards. Yu denounced Lin's violent act and urged Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to maintain law and order in the city so that everybody can freely express their opinions without fears.

Yu also urged all DPP members and supporters to remain calm and refrain from taking any retaliatory actions to add up to social unrest ahead of an unprecedented round-the-clock sit-in street demonstration to force Chen to resign.
The Taipei Society, a group founded by liberal scholars to monitor parliamentary and government operations, issued a press statement condemning Lin's act of violence before TV audience.

"It seems to us that the brute display of violence symbolizes a death knell for Taiwan's fledgling democracy, " the statement lamented, adding that the group frets whether the shocking incident would herald the start of a bloody conflict stoked by a long-running feud between the country's two major political camps or even the start of a "revolution" advocated by some media personalities.

According to media reports, the statement went on, Lin and an underworld gang leader have organized a team of bodyguards to protect former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who is leading the "1 million people to depose Chen" campaign.

"If the reports are ture, we are worried about the possibility of the imminent massive sit-in going out of control and leading to violent confrontation with radical DPP supporters, " the statement said, adding that law enforcement authorities should investigate the case and exercise public authority in order to protect personal safety.
Meanwhile, the headquarters of the Shih-led "1 million people" campaign was quick to distance itself from Lin, stressing that Lin is not a staff member of the campaign headquarters.
He Teh-fen, spokeswoman for the Shih-led campaign, said Lin's act of violence has nothing to do with the campaign.

"We condemn any act of violence. Any individual intending to take part in the sit-in protest must abide by our rules and discipline. We have stepped up peronnel training to maintain order and discipline at the sit-in site after the protest begins early next month," He said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGED TO RESPOND TO ANTI-CHEN CAMPAIGN IN STYLE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should respond to former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh's "depose President Chen Shui-bian" campaign with democratic decency and depth of historical insight, an academic said Thursday.

Wu Nai-teh, a researcher with Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's top academic institution -- made the call in an open letter issued after some radical DPP politicians have scathingly attacked Shih for several days in retaliation for his initiation of the "1 million people to depose Chen" camapign.

Shih is described by some as "Taiwan's Mandela" as he was incarcerated for 25 years as a prisoner of conscience during Taiwan's infamous martial-law era for his pro-independence and pro-democracy advocacy.
Wu said Taiwan's democracy was jointly created by many "ordinary people" like Shih.

"In a difficult time of fighting social injustice and government brutality, many ordinary people have made an extraordinary moral choice. Even some of them might show occasional weakness, they deserve our respect as they have contributed to the process of our country's democratization, " Wu said in his open letter.

Wu was referring to the exposure Thursday by two radical DPP lawmakers of a letter allegedly dictated by Shih during his days behind bars in the 1960s seeking leniency from then-authoritarian Kuomintang government.

"The DPP lawmakers' attempt to destroy Shih's heroic image by exposing the letter, they have not only negated the DPP's previous fight against the authoritarian regime but have also demolished important values of Taiwan's democracy," Wu lamented.

Wu, who himself joined a group of pro-DPP scholars and social activists in issuing an open letter July 15 urging Chen to resign, urged the DPP to be more broad-minded and far-sighted in dealing with the unfolding Shih-led campaign to pressure the president to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MEMBERSHIP BID POSTED ON U.N. WEBSITE

TEXT.P: The United Nations has posted on its Website two proposals filed by Taiwan's diplomatic allies with regard to the 23 million Taiwan people's representation and participation in the world body and the U.N.'s role in maintaining peace and security in East Asia, officials said Friday.

According to officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the U.N. Secretariat has documented the two proposals in six languages -- English, Chinese in simplified script, French, Spanish, Russian and Arabic.

The documents regarding the "participation" and "peace" proposals, with ordinal number A/61/194 and A/61/193, respectively, have been distributed to the U.N. missions of all member countries, MOFA officials said.

Even though many difficulties may lie ahead toward Taiwan's pursuit of a U.N. seat due to China's boycott, the officials said Taiwan's voice can be heard globally via the posting of the two documents on the U.N. Website and the distribution of the documents to U.N. missions of all member states.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 25, or the second day of the leap seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1718: The city of New Orleans, named in honor of the Duke of Orleans of France, is founded.
1819: Allan Pinkerton, Scottish-born founder of the famous Pinkerton National Detective Agency in the United States, which specialized in railroad theft, is born.
1822: Sir William Herschel, the German-born English astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, dies at the age of 84. He also cataloged more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1825: Uruguay declares independence from Spain.
1867: Michael Faraday, the English chemist and physicist who invented the first electrical cell (battery), dies at the age of 76.
1875: Englishman Matthew Webb makes history by becoming the first person to swim the English Channel. The 27-year-old master mariner covers the 34-km stretch from Dover to Calais in 21 hours 45 minutes.
1900: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the German philosopher whose written works include "Thus Spake Zarathustra," dies at the age of 55. He reasons that Christianity's emphasis on the afterlife makes its believers less able to cope with earthly life.
1912: The Chung-kuo ke-ming tung-meng hui (Society of the Common Cause) is reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) and holds its inauguration meeting in Beijing.
1917: Dr. Sun Yat-sen forms a military government in Canton, southern China.
1919: The first scheduled international air service begins between Paris and London.
1921: Germany and the United States sign a peace treaty ending the state of war between them.
1930: Sean Connery, the Scottish actor who played the leading role as "007" in seven James Bond movies and won an Oscar for best supporting actor in "The Untouchables," is born.
1940: Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are incorporated into the Soviet Union.
1943: Lord Louis Mountbatten is appointed Supreme Allied Commander in Southeast Asia.
1944: Paris is liberated when the local German commander, General von Choltitz, surrenders to the Allies, ending a four-year long ordeal that Paris and her citizens suffered at the hands of the Nazis.
1945: Vietnamese communist leader Ho Chi Minh announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (DRV).
1989: The spacecraft Voyager 2 beams back to earth pictures of Neptune.
1960: The Republic of China Olympic team carries a large sign reading "Under Protest" in the opening procession of the Olympic Games in Rome to protest the International Olympic Committee's ruling compelling ROC athletes to compete under the name of "Taiwan" instead of the "Republic of China."
1961: The second phase of the Yangmingshan Forum opens to study the ROC's educational and cultural issues.
1968: Lesotho Premier Leabua Jonathan arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1986: ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports open in Taipei. Both sides failed to settle disagreements on pricing and advertising for American products during the nine-day talks, and a new round of negotiations was planned.
1991: Byelorussia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1992: Niger's Prime Minister Amadou Cheiffou arrives in the ROC to advance mutual understanding between the two countries.
2001: The opposition People First Party (PFP) unveils the theme of "respect for history, acknowledgment of reality and joint efforts for peace" as the guidelines of its mainland China policy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "For God in giving life to all created things is surely bountiful to them according to their qualities. Hence the tree that is full of life He fosters and sustains, while that which is ready to fall He cuts down and destroys."

DOC.HEADLINE: MND URGED TO REMAIN NEUTRAL ON 'DEPOSE PRESIDENT' CAMPAIGN(repeat)

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker accused the Ministry of National Defense (MND) Thursday of not keeping a neutral stance toward the "1 million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian" campaign.

Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung, who serves on the legislature's National Defense Committee (NDC), said that by issuing a statement to express the military's support for the scandal-ridden president, the MND has violated the principle of administrative neutrality.
Ting also blasted the Combined Services Force Headquarters for asking post offices near military barracks to provide the names of servicemen who donated NT$100 each to help finance the campaign.
"This is a blatant violation of personal privacy," he said, noting that members of the armed forces are also entitled to basic human rights under the Constitution.
Ting said he welcomes military personnel to report cases of such violations to the NDC, and he promised that he will have those military leaders found responsible dealt with according to law.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER ASHAMED OF DPP'S INACTION AGAINST ATTACK ON EX-CHAIRMAN(repeat)

TEXT.P: An outspoken ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker said Thursday he feels utterly ashamed of his party's connivance over certain party members' scathing attack on a former party chairman.

Legislator Lee Wen-chung made the remarks after some DPP politicians have continuously castigated former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh over the past few days in retaliation for Shih's launch of a "1 million people campaign" to depose President Chen Shui-bian over a string of corruption allegations against himself, members of his family and staff.

Earlier in the day, two of his colleagues even accompanied Shih's divorced wife Chen Li-chu in unveiling a letter allegedly dictated by Shih to seek leniency from the authoritarian Kuomintang (KMT) authorities when he was kept behind bars for his pro-democracy and pro-independence advocacy.

Lee said he felt "outrageously embarrassed" by his DPP colleagues' move and guilty about the DPP headquarters' failure to stop all the tit-for-tat defamation of Shih, who is described by some as "Taiwan's Mandela" as he was incarcerated for 25 years as a prisoner of conscience during Taiwan's infamous martial-law era.

Acknowledging that Shih should be subject to public examination since he has long been a political figure, Lee said such scrutiny should be confined to matters related to public interests and political ethics. The recent attacks on Shih by some DPP politicians have gone beyond acceptable boundaries and have infringed upon Shih's privacy, Lee said.

Lee said the DPP used to be suppressed and demonized in mass movements in its long process of fighting against authoritarian rule. Once in power, he said, the DPP should be magnanimous enough to tolerate people's right to stage street rallies and demonstrations against the government.

The DPP should also not ignore the public discontent and grivances accumulated over the past six years since its ascent to power, Lee said, adding that Shih is just a catalytic figure for the unfolding anti-Chen campaign.

Lee said he feels those DPP politicians who have exploited Shih's behavior during the notorious martial-law era to attack him are as cruel as the former KMT rulers who demonized Shih as a "seditious devil."
He further said entire society and the media should also conduct self-reflection.

"When society and the media questioned some radicals' defamation against Shih, they should also think about that over the past six years, they have acquiesced numerous unfounded accusations against President Chen that have almost 'destroyed' his character and tainted his images," Lee said.
For instance, he said society and the media have never questioned the style of KMT Legislator Chiu Yi's constant sensational accusations against the president and the first family.

While he personally opposes any retaliatory action, Lee said he still feels that the outrageous "smearing Shih" actions taken b y some DPP radicals and pro-independence die-hards are related with the society's and the media's long silence over Chiu's frequent indecent acts.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DECIDES TO CANCEL PART OF ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATIONS IN TAIPEI(repeat)

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has decided to cancel some of the party's planned public rallies slated for September in Taipei due to an expanding campaign aimed at pushing President Chen Shui-bian to resign, a DPP official said Thursday.

Deputy DPP Secretary-General Tsai Huang-liang explained that the canceled activities were organized as celebrations for the DPP's 20th founding anniversary and that the party had planned to take advantage of the events to campaign for its candidates in the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayor elections.

Despite the cancellation of the activities after thousands of people expressed support to the "1 million people to depose President Chen" initiated by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh Aug. 12, Tsai said the DPP will still invite all party founders to a party planned for Aug. 28 at Taipei's Grand Hotel, where the DPP was established in 1986.

The founders include President Chen, Premier Su Tseng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh, incumbent DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung and National Security Council Secretary-General Chiu Yi-jen.
The anti-Chen campaign will include a planned "round-the-clock" sit-in in front of the Presidential Office, likely to kick off at the beginning of September.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIC TAIWAN DESERVES U.N. MEMBERSHIP: TAIWAN OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan deserves U.N. membership like all other democratic countries, a Taiwan official posted in the United States said Thursday.

"Taiwan is an asset to regional stability and, thus, to world peace," said Owen Hsieh, director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Miami, in a letter to the editor published in the Miami Herald.

Hsieh was reacting to recent remarks by China's ambassador to the United Nations, Sha Zhukang, that "it's better for the United States to shut up" when he was asked to comment on U.S. concerns about China's military buildup during a BBC radio interview.
Hsieh said Sha's remarks demonstrate Beijing's arrogance with its newly gained clout in the international arena as China has subtly translated its economic prowess into political and military might.

Hsieh noted that China's 2.3 million People's Liberation Army troops could be devastating to regional peace in East Asia, which is facing other security concerns such as North Korea's nuclear program.
He noted that the fact that the military balance in the Taiwan Strait has tilted in China's favor can no longer be avoided.

"A militarily strong China threatens the delicate balance that the United States has endeavored to maintain for years, " Hsieh said, adding that "if the balance tilts too much to one side, the whole security structure in East Asia could cave in."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CONDEMNS TV TALK SHOW VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou condemned Friday the violence "broadcast live" in a news talk show the day before in which a former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator gave a political commentator a bloody nose.

Commenting on former DPP Legislator Lin Cheng-chieh's attack on Contemporary Monthly editor-in-chief Chin Heng-wei during the Formosa Television talk show "The People Talk, " Ma said that no violence of any kind should be tolerated.

During the live show, Lin, who supports the "one million people campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian" initiated by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh and scheduled to be staged next month, suddenly slapped Chin on the face, following that with punches and kicks after the two exchanged curses.
Chin, who suffered a bloody nose in the altercation, received emergency treatment at a hospital, including five stitches on his nose.
Ma said "everybody hopes President Chen steps down, but the goal should never be pursued by violent means."
Meanwhile, he declined to confirm whether he will take part in the "depose Chen" sit-in to be staged in front of the Presidential Office at the start of next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO FILE SLANDER SUIT AGAINST TV HOST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will file a slander suit against TV talk show host Sisy Chen over her claim that the president plans to take advantage of his upcoming South Pacific visit to ship his valuables overseas, the Presidential Office said Friday.
In a press statement, the Presidential Office said such malicious defamation is totally unfactual and has seriously damaged the president's reputation.

During her show Thursday, Sisy Chen claimed that President Chen's plane will take off from Taipei's Sungshan military air base for his South Pacific visit to evade customs inspection to facilitate his plan to ship his valuables abroad.
Chen is scheduled to depart Sept. 3 for Palau to attend a leader summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the South Pacific before heading on to Nauru for a visit.
The president reportedly is planning to travel on a military jet, instead of a civil plane.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO VISIT PALAU, NAURU IN EARLY SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will depart Sept. 3 for an official visit to Palau and Nauru, two diplomatic allies of the Republic of China in the South Pacific, Liu Shih-fang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, announced Friday.
Liu said the president's visit to Palau will mainly be to attend a leader summit between Taiwan and its allies in the South Pacific Sept. 4 with the aim of cementing relations with the allies.

Liu said the themes of the summit will include medical care, alternative energy resources, agricultural and fishery cooperation, digital government, economic partnership, tourism, and Austronesian culture exchanges.
The president will sign a declaration with the six heads of state at the conclusion of the summit, Liu said.
The president will then proceed to Nauru Sept. 5 for his first visit to the country since assuming the presidency in 2000.

While there, the president will deliver a speech at the Nauru parliament, visit a Taiwan product exhibition as well as attend an inauguration ceremony for an air carrier before returning to Taiwan Sept. 6.

On whether the president has shortened the overseas trip because of turmoil at home, Liu said the original plan is being followed. The president is facing an imminent mass sit-in protest being organized by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, to pressure him to resign over a string of corruption and embezzlement allegations against himself, his family members and senior aides.
On whether the president will stop over in Guam or any other countries, Liu said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is still working out the matter and that it will make an announcement next week.
A MOFA official said Thursday that it would be very natural for President Chen to plan to stop over in Guam during his upcoming visit to the South Pacific.
