DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY TO PROMOTE 'RIDE TO SCHOOL' PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will launch a program to encourage students to ride bicycles to school to increase the amount of their exercise, a ministry official said Friday.
The program was put forth during a meeting of chiefs of education bureaus held in the southern county of Pingtung.

Ho Cho-fei, director-general of the MOE's Department of Physical Education, noted that in addition to being good exercise, riding a bicycle instead of driving a car can help reduce energy consumption and pollution and thus help slow down global warming and improve the environment.
Ho said that through the program, the MOE hopes that all elementary school students in the country will learn to ride a bicycle and ride to school.

After school reopens in September, the MOE will survey how many elementary students do not know how to ride a bicycle and will prepare teaching materials on cycling and hold briefings to promote the program, Ho said.
Bicycles will also be made available at schools so that students who do no own a bike can practice riding one, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION TO VISIT U.S. TO RECRUIT TALENT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Timothy Hwang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation will visit New York in mid-September to recruit overseas Taiwanese or foreign talent to work on the island.

The delegation, to be led by Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching, will be made up of representatives of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , the National Science Council (NSC) , various science park administrations around the island, as well as some 20 prominent domestic companies.
According to a report conducted by the Cabinet-level CEPD, Taiwan faces a shortage of some 10,000 science and administration workers annually.

To make up for the shortage, the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research has been commissioned by the MOEA to expand the talent recruitment project abroad, which will target Taiwanese expatriates, foreigners, and Chinese academics residing in the United States for more than four years, a MOEA official said.
Those interested in the program can visit the Web site set up by MOEA and the institution at hirecruit.nat.gov.tw for more information, the official added.

Andrew Hsia, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, noted that a similar talent recruitment meeting held in 2004 attracted the participation of some 200 people. He urged anyone who is interested not to miss the activities to be held by the delegation Sept. 13-14 in New York.

Meanwhile, officials from Taiwan's Cabinet-level Science and Technology Advisory Group, which will also have representatives in the delegation, will hold a trade seminar Sept. 14 at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York to introduce Taiwan's investment climate in order to attract foreign investment to the island, Hsia added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 24.42 points to close at 6,526.22.
The bourse opened at 6,594.82 and fluctuated between 6,600.94 and 6,526.22 during trading. A total of 2.19 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.5 billion (US$1.81 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 0.23 percent, followed by banking and financial issues at 0.07 percent.

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.86 percent, followed by textile shares at 1.12 percent, machinery and electronics issues at 0.63 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.54 percent, construction stocks at 0.17 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.12 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 639 to 361, with 172 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISTS TO BE ABLE TO EXCHANGE YUAN IN TAIWAN: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: When Chinese tourists come to Taiwan, they will be able to exchange Chinese currency for local currency, the nation's top Chinese policy planner said Friday.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, also said at a news conference that a cross-strait currency clearance and liquidation agreement for exchanging Chinese yuan and New Taiwan dollars is now being cautiously assessed by Taiwan's Central Bank of China.
Wu noted that Premier Su Tseng-chang instructed recently that when Chinese tourists come to Taiwan, all complimentary measures should be in place.

He pledged that when both sides of the Taiwan Strait reach an agreement on opening up Taiwan to Chinese tourists, Taiwan will work out measures on security management of the tourists as well as the opening of currency exchange services.
Wu said recently that according to the progress of talks between the two sides concerning Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan, there will be a result by the end of this year.
Presently, Taiwan only allows the new Taiwan dollar-yuan conversion on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu on a trial basis, but has not allowed the conversion on Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 26 points to close at 6,489, with 35,082 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October dropped 24 points to finish at 6,491, with 238 contracts traded, while December futures lost 17 points to close at 6,492, with 17 contract transactions.
March futures moved down 16 points to close at 6,501, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,515 for September, 6,515 for October, 6,509 for December, 6,517 for March and 6,524 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

September TE futures moved down 2.1 points to close at 279.9, with 5,342 contracts traded, while October TE futures dropped 2.05 points to finish at 279.5, with 42 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 2.9 points to close at 279.6, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures gained 3.2 points to close at 889.2, with 1,699 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up 0.2 points to finish at 887.4, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW GROUP TO BE SET UP TO ACCELERATE CROSS-STRAIT TOURISM EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A new group is set to be established shortly to serve as a counterpart agency to a Chinese organization to jointly accelerate tourism exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's top official in charge of China policy said Friday.

It is hoped that the new group -- expected to be named the Taiwan Strait Tourism Association (TSTA) -- will immediately serve as a lift to expedite the opening of Taiwan to all Chinese citizens for tourism, said Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu at a news conference.

It is also hoped that cross-strait negotiations on the issue regarding Chinese citizens coming to Taiwan for tourism can be started under the "Macau formula" soon after the TSTA's establishment, Wu said.

Wu note that Hsu Wen-sheng, director general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, will serve as chairman of the TSTA, which is scheduled to be formally established Aug. 27.
The TSTA will serve as a counterpart agency to China's Cross Strait Tourism Exchange Association (CSTEA) established only this month by the National Tourism Administration of China, Wu noted.
The non-profit TSTA will have an organizational structure and personnel representation similar to those of the CSTEA, Wu added.

Hsu Wen-sheng, who was also present at the news conference, said the TSTA will have a nine-member to 11-member board of directors that will include officials from the Tourism Bureau, the Immigration Office and the Taiwan Visitors Association, as well as leaders of travel agency associations.

Wu said the Republic of China Travel Business Association -- which was established in July last year to serve as a window of contact with China -- has completed its "segmental missions, " and the issues that should be discussed in cross-strait tourism negotiations involve many other important matters including air and sea transportation, border management, and public order, making it imperative for the government to establish the TSTA.

Besides, Wu added, one of the many conclusions reached at the government-sponsored Conference on Sustaining Taiwan's Economic Development held last month was that Taiwan should open its doors completely to Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: DDP CALLS FOR HALT TO PLANNED ANTI-PRESIDENT SIT-IN AFTER TV VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers urged the party's former chairman Shih Ming-teh Friday to halt his plan to stage a sit-in aimed at forcing President Chen Shui-bian to step down.

The call came after a violent incident the previous evening on a live TV talk show in which former DPP Legislator Lin Cheng-chieh punched and kicked pro-DPP commentator Chin Heng-wei, giving him a bloody nose.
DPP Legislator Wang Shih-chien warned that Shih should be held responsible for the incident and stop his campaign to depose the president since Lin was a "core member of the campaign headquarters."
Chin himself said Lin's violence could be blamed on Shih and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who is also mayor of Taipei.
Ho De-fen, spokeswoman for Shih's "one million people to depose President Chen Shui-bian" campaign, stressed that Lin is not a staff member of the campaign headquarters.
"We condemn any act of violence. Any individual intending to take part in the sit-in protest must abide by our rules and discipline, " she added.

Kao Chih-peng, a DPP legislator, said the physical attack during the talk show is a "major incident" that will not only affect the perpetrator but also worsen Taiwan's political divisions marked by the standoff between the "pan-green camp" and the "pan-blue alliance."
Pro-independence supporters in Taiwan will soon unite and prepare to fight back as they will not tolerate being bullied or abused, Kao said.

Cheng Yun-peng, another DPP lawmaker, urged the Shih campaign to "restrain" a violent man like Lin Cheng-chieh. Cheng said he can no longer remain confident that the campaign will be able to "effectively control" the sit-in crowd for long.
In spite of the campaign's denial of any link with Lin, Hsieh Hsin-ni, a DPP legislator, still accused Lin of being "one of the key organizers" of the Shih campaign.
"If they can't stop him from resorting to violence on a televised TV show, then how can they guarantee there will be no violence during the sit-in?" she asked.
"Since Taiwan cannot afford to witness any bloodshed over a political campaign, the sit-in should be canceled," she added.

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, worried that the anti-president campaign has induced violence and social division, also urged Shih to stop his campaign. Yu also called on Ma to reconsider his permission for an overnight sit-in.

The sit-in "definitely will not be stopped, " Ho claimed, noting that campaign organizers have even asked the city government to extend the permit for using Ketagalan Boulevard to Sept. 25, from Sept. 7.
The organizers have yet to announce when the sit-in will begin, saying they will run newspaper ads three days prior to the start date.
She said they will also be careful in deciding on a date to end the sit-in since the crowd will be closely monitored by a "fierce and well-organized state machine."
Ho emphasized that the campaign organizers "definitely do not have any plan to encourage the sit-in participants to step beyond the red line or swarm into the Presidential Office."

She reported that the campaign headquarters has been preparing hand fans printed with the words "love" and "peace" and with a "thumbs down" sign to help participants stay cool during the warm summer nights when the sit-in is held.

She also encouraged interested members of the public to show their creativity and come up with "works of art" that can be displayed in "all the corners of Taiwan society" calling on the president to respect the public's expectation that he step down gracefully.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS GROUPS CALL 'DEPOSE CHEN' CAMPAIGN UNDEMOCRATIC

TEXT.P: Several overseas Taiwanese groups criticized former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh Friday as "leading Taiwan's democratic development backward" for launching a campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian.
The groups said in a statement that overseas Taiwanese are extremely surprised and disappointed at the campaign and firmly opposed to the vicious political struggle.

They included the North America Taiwanese Women's Association, the Formosan Association for Human Rights, the Taiwanese Hakka Association of U.S.A., the Taiwanese Canadian Association of Canada and a pro-Chen organization in Japan.

They asked Shih if he has forgotten that he was jailed because of his pursuit of democracy for Taiwan and why he is now allying himself with his former persecutors to damage Taiwan's democratic system.

Arguing that efforts to terminate corruption should be carried out through enactment of sunshine laws, they said Shih should not demand that Chen step down based on some "empty moral appeal" when there is no substantial evidence that Chen has committed any crime or before judicial authorities have completed their investigations into related cases.

They said the alleged irregularities involving Chen's family members and his close aides have nothing to do with the president himself and that it is unjustifiable for Shih to force him to step down over these matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.043 to close at NT$32.888.
A total of US$890 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.865 and fluctuated between NT$32.844 and US$32.910.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG SOCIETY CALLS FOR ATTENTION ON ISSUES OF GREATER IMPORTANCE

TEXT.P: Members of an opinion leaders society in Taichung, central Taiwan, called Friday for proponents of a campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian to pay more attention to other national issues of greater importance.

Members of the Taichung-based Society of Taiwan told legislators from the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party that the society will support the campaign as soon as the opposition lawmakers pass 10 draft bills into law that have greater significance and urgency than unseating President Chen.

Members of the Society of Taiwan, including medical professionals, academics and owners of small- and medium-size enterprises in central Taiwan, called for "pan-blue" legislators to first pass a bill calling for Taiwan to bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan before throwing their support behind an unprecedented round-the-clock sit-in being led by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh to oust President Chen.

They said the opposition lawmakers should also direct their energy and time away from the campaign and focus on other important issues, including the Kuomintang's controversial assets, the appointment of Control Yuan members, the amendment to the national health insurance program, the long-stalled arms procurement bill, the name change for Taiwan's offices overseas, and the engineering of a new Constitution that will better reflect Taiwan's current realities and better meet the needs of Taiwan.

They stressed that they will play an instrumental role in pushing for President Chen to step down when the 10 important draft bills are passed into law and when Taiwan moves toward becoming a "normal country."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO SPEND BIG ON RFID INFRASTRUCTURE

TEXT.P: The government will funnel between NT$400 million (US$12.2 billion) and NT$700 million per year between 2006 and 2009 to develop the infrastructure for the radio frequency identification (RFID) industry in a bid to be a trailblazer in the application of RFID technology in Asia and to turn Taiwan into a major hub in the world's RFID industry, a Cabinet official said Friday.

It is the government's goal to increase the production value of the RFID industry in Taiwan to NT$70 billion by 2013, said Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching, after a meeting of the Cabinet's National Information and Communications Initiative.
According to a forecast by ABI Research, global production of RFID tags is expected to amount to US$33.8 billion by 2013, while that of RFID readers is expected to reach US$11.4 billion.
Pointing out that Taiwan has a strong foundation in terms of hardware manufacturing, Lin said the country should try to gain at least a 10-percent share of the world's RFID hardware market.

Lin said the government will work to make possible by 2013 the establishment of at least one international-class RFID application company in Taiwan, the launch of at least two RFID products or services that rank within the world's top five in terms of market share, and the completion of at least two RFID application integration projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOAL TO INAUGURATE HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY IN OCTOBER UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) reiterated Friday that its plan to inaugurate the high-speed railway linking Taipei and Kaohsiung at the end of October remains unchanged.

The THSRC made the statement in a press release after publication of media speculation that a delayed inspection of the nation's first high- speed railway could scuttle its plan for an October inauguration.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications had not received an application for inspection Aug. 21 and extended the application dateline to Aug. 25. According to the media, the delay could affect an inspection team's completion of its inspection before mid-October.
THSRC officials did not deny media reports that it will not apply for inspection until Sept. 8.
The officials said the railway line is undergoing testing of its integrated mechanical and electrical systems, as well as various other preparation work prior to the inauguration.
They promised to ensure the inauguration at the end of October under the principles of safety, comfort and convenience.
The 345-km railway linking Taiwan's two largest cities is the nation's first construction project under the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model.
The line was originally set to be inaugurated in October 2005, but was delayed for a year mainly because of difficulties encountered in integrating the core mechanical and electrical systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Chirac: 2,000 soldiers to Lebanon.
French President Jacques Chirac announced Thursday that France will send 2,000 troop to Lebanon and hopes to retain command of the United Nations peacekeeping force there.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Immigration and rising birthrate push population over 60 million
Tee population of the United Kingdom has topped 60 million for the first time after rising last year at the fastest rate in 40 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU RESEARCH TEAM DEVELOPS DISEASE TESTING BIOCHIPS

TEXT.P: A research team at National Cheng-kung University (NCKU) has developed a new series of disease testing biochips, allowing shorter determination time and less cost per unit, a spokesman of the National Science Council (NSC) said Friday.

The team, organized by professor Li Gwo-bin at NCKU's Engineering Science Department, applied the knowledge of microfluidics to detection biochips, which can now produce results in two to three hours and can be provided at a cost of NT$100 per unit.
The research and development of the new biochips has been conducted for eight years, and it began receiving funding from the NSC two years ago.

While making comparisons with conventional tests, Li noted that the biochemical test for bacteria, although costing as low as NT$50, requires more than 24 hours or even several days to complete; while the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, or ELISA, can complete the identification process within 30 minutes at a cost of NT$200, although it can only be utilized in the later stages of disease development.
Li added that microfluidic biochips can be used in the early stages, at an acceptable cost and duration of time.

Currently, the biochip can be used to detect Streptococcus pneumoniae, Group A Streptococcus, and dengue fever, and the team is working on expanding the application range, Li said, adding that the biochip can be operated in two modes, either one piece for four persons for a single disease, or one piece for one person for four diseases.

The project is expected to be completed by this November following testing on humans in September at NCKU Hospital's emergency room. The team will then apply for sales permits in both Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-CHEN GROUP DISTANCES ITSELF FROM THUG ACTIVIST

TEXT.P: The group sponsoring a campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian distanced itself Friday from a thug activist who attacked a political commentator during a live TV news talk show the day before.

Ho Teh-fen, spokeswoman for the "1 million people campaign to depose Chen, " condemned former Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lin Cheng-chieh's attack on Contemporary Monthly editor-in-chief Chin Heng-wei during the Formosa Television talk show "The People Talk" Thursday, saying that the "Depose Chen" group deplores any kind of violence.

Ho said Lin is not a staff member of the campaign headquarters, that his act of violence had nothing to do with the campaign, and that he will be barred from the sit-in scheduled to be launched in front of the Presidential Office at the start of next month.

During the live show, Lin, who supports the "Depose Chen" campaign initiated by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh, suddenly slapped Chin on the face, following up with punches and kicks after the two exchanged curses.
Chin, who suffered a bloody nose in the altercation, received emergency treatment at a hospital, including five stitches to his nose.

According to Ho, Lin had suggested that a team of bodyguards be organized to protect Shih's safety during and before the sit-in. Ho added that Lin's suggestion was rejected immediately by campaign organizers.

"We condemn any act of violence. Any individual intending to take part in the sit-in protest must abide by our rules and discipline. We have stepped up personnel training to maintain order and discipline at the sit-in site after the protest begins early next month, " Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELATIVES OF NEW IMMIGRANTS TO BE INVITED TO TAIWAN FOR REUNION

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government will invite relatives of 15 new immigrants in Taipei to visit Taiwan for family reunions and to attend a new immigrant festival to be held in Taipei Oct. 1, a city government official said Friday.

Chung Tse-liang, director of the city government's Department of Civil Affairs, said the city government will hold a lucky draw in mid- September for a total of 30 relatives of 15 new immigrants in Taipei to visit Taiwan before Oct. 1.
Each new immigrant can apply for visits by two of their relatives to Taiwan, with the Taipei city government subsidizing NT$10,000 (US$305) in air ticket prices for each relative, according to Chung.

Chung expressed hope that the activity will help the next generation of new immigrants in Taiwan to familiarize themselves with the cultures of their parents so that they can have more confidence in themselves during the process of integrating into local society.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY COMMANDER OBSERVES JAPANESE MILITARY DRILL
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Yang Min-chu and Ada Tsai)

TEXT.P: Japan's Kyodo news agency reported Friday that Taiwan's Army Commander Gen. Hu Chen-pu observed Japan's largest live-fire war drill in Shizuoka a day earlier.
Hu was invited to observe the annual exercise conducted by Japan's Self Defense Forces despite the absence of diplomatic ties between Tokyo and Taipei, according to Kyodo.
China, which had learned in advance that Hu would attend the drill, filed a protest with the Tokyo authorities, Kyodo said.
Thursday's live fire demonstration was the preview of the Self Defense Forces' annual war drill conducted exclusively for overseas observers, according to Kyoto.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS URGE POWER-HOLDERS TO BECOME 'STABILIZING FORCE'

TEXT.P: Several ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers and one former DPP lawmaker called on the party leadership Friday to prove that the party is capable of reflection and willing to be a "stabilizing force" in Taiwan society.

Hung Chi-chang, Kuo Cheng-liang, Cheng Yun-peng and former Legislator Tuan Yi-kang launched a petition urging the party to adopt a resolution restraining party members who hold public office from joining or encouraging supporters to join a "counter-Shih Ming-teh" campaign.

Shih, a former DPP chairman, is leading a "1 million people campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian," angering quite a number of DPP fanatics who have vowed to organize "counter-Shih campaigns" to "stare down" Shih and his supporters.

The four DPP politicians proposed that those who fail to honor the resolution be disciplined severely. They also urged the party's top leaders, including Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, as well as Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral candidates Frank Hsieh and Chen Chu, to sponsor their proposal to adopt the resolution.
Social tension worsened the previous evening when Lin Cheng-chieh, a former DPP legislator, physically assaulted a pro-DPP commentator when they quarrelled during a live TV talk show.

Tuan, an outspoken DPP politician, and the three DPP lawmakers claimed that "reflection starts with tolerance" and that "it's a natural duty for the ruling party to act as a stabilizing force in society."

Tuan said that when Shih, a former DPP chairman, kicked off his campaign to depose the president, some DPP leaders, instead of trying to talk to him, were overwhelmed with emotion while the party's top leader did nothing, allowing the party rank and file to develop a "wrong attitude" toward a "wrong campaign."

Tuan added that the TV violence incident is an indication that irrationality prevails in some sectors of society, and under such circumstances, the ruling party has an even greater responsibility to control its supporters -- a position it should make clear long before the sit-in protest begins.

Kuo Cheng-liang said Shih has not been reasonable by insisting on using a street rally to attempt to unseat the president, but neither has it been constructive for some DPP supporters to assassinate Shih's character.
Shih's two former wives have made public statements to discredit him.
If the DPP encourages its supporters to wage "counter-Shih" activities, "we must understand that even the KMT regime in the old days did not do things like that," Kuo pointed out.
In short, he said, neither the character assassination of Shih nor "counter-Shih" campaigns are the right solution to the issue.
Hung Chi-chang said freedom of expression and freedom of assembly are part of the "core values" the DPP has fought for and vowed to protect, so there is no reason for the party to discount them now.
"At the very least, tolerating a different view is what we should do now," he added.
In response to the proposal, Yu said the party knows how to reflect on itself and does not want to see personal attacks against Shih.
Kao Chih-peng, a DPP lawmaker, ridiculed the four's proposal as "unrealistic" and "standing on too high a moral ground."
No party rules and regulations ban party members from fighting back in the face of physical assault, Kao said. "Yes, we could start our reflection with tolerance, but not tolerance of violence."

DOC.HEADLINE: REFUSAL TO DIVULGE SOURCE OF JEWELRY SETS `BAD EXAMPLE': LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's refusal to explain the source of his jewelry assets has set a very bad example for the public, a lawmaker of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday.

Tsai Chin-lung, a KMT caucus whip in the legislature, made the remarks after the Presidential Office said it could not accommodate the Control Yuan's request to provide the names of relatives and friends from whom Chen and his wife claim to have borrowed jewelry because those involved do not want their privacy infringed upon.
Tsai claimed that Chen, a lawyer-turned-politician, is "playing with the law."
He said Chen, under the pretext of borrowing from others and protecting the privacy of others, has set a bad example in the filing of assets of public functionaries.
If other public functionaries follow suit, the Public Functionaries Asset Disclosure Law will be rendered unenforceable, he said.

The first couple sent a corrected version of jewelry assets to the Control Yuan in early July, listing 15 pieces of jewelry and luxury watches that they own, with a total value of NT$3.72 million (US$114,110).

Legislators from the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party then produced photos of 31 pieces of jewelry worn by the first lady on various occasions. The Control Yuan therefore asked for an explanation of those pieces from the first family within 15 days.

The first couple replied on the last day of the deadline that they had acquiesced to the Control Yuan's request by filing reports on their jewelry but had not reported on jewelry "borrowed from relatives or friends" because the relatives and friends were not being audited and should have the privacy of their assets protected. The Control Yuan then made the request for disclosure of the names of the relatives and friends.
According to the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, any piece of jewelry, including watches, owned by public functionaries and worth over NT$200,000 should be listed with the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'E-LEARNING WORLD' EXHIBITION KICKS OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2006 e-Learning World Exhibition kicked off Friday in Taipei, with government agencies presenting the results of their efforts to build digital educational and training facilities.

Liu Chao-han, director of the National Science and Technology Program for e-Learning (NSTPEL), which organized the three-day event, said the main purpose of the show is to provide a place for people to "learn happily."
"Learning in a joyous manner" is the best way to raise learning efficiency, said Liu, who is also president of the Taoyuan-based National Central University.

In addition to Liu, National Science Council Minister Chen Chien-jen and Minister of Labor Affair Lee Ying-yuan, as well as officials of the Ministry of Education, the Council of Cultural Affairs and the Department of Health also attended the show's opening.

The exhibition is divided into two areas -- the Government Pavilion and a section featuring the e-learning industry of Taiwan, with 10 government departments presenting their achievements in promoting the NSTPEL program in the Government Pavilion.
In addition, several forums and seminars in which experienced e-learning professionals have been invited to lead discussions are taking place at the exhibition, which will end Aug. 27.
The exhibition is free.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER URGED TO RESIGN OVER ALLEGED BAN ON DONATIONS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) demanded the resignation of Minister of National Defense Lee Jye Friday over a controversy over reports by a military run newspaper suggesting that military personnel do not endorse a donation campaign aimed at deposing President Chen Shui-bian.
KMT legislative caucus whip Lin Hung-chih issued the call at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan.
Lin accused the Ministry of National Defense (MND) of twisting the Constitution and law by threatening to punish personnel who make
donations, under the pretext that doing so is against the neutrality required by the military under the law.

The MND has deliberately given a misleading interpretation of the relevant law and Lee should step down to take responsibility for the matter, Lin said, pointing out that according to the National Defense Law, military personnel are perfectly entitled to participate in political activities after work or on leave.

In view of the populist campaign led by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh to unseat scandal-tainted Chen, the military-run Youth Daily has printed a series of features in recent days stressing that neutrality must be maintained in the military.

Although the MND has not publicly banned military personnel from donating NT$100 to Shih's campaign, ministry officials said that those who have done so might be viewed as having violated the neutrality requirement and might be punished if reported to their superiors.

The MND denied that an investigation is under way to find out who has made donations but MND-affiliated agencies have repeatedly required personnel to maintain neutrality and professionalism, MND officials said.
According to a spokesman for the Air Force, it is not good for military personnel to take part in political activities.

The articles recently run by the Youth Daily are aimed at strengthening personnel's awareness of the need to maintain neutrality in any politically charged movement, the spokesman sad, adding that the military has adopted a "business as usual" attitude in the face of a sit-in protest led by Shih that is expected to kick off in the coming days.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN-MACAU CHARTER FLIGHTS TO OPEN IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Two-way charter flights between Macau and Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen will be inaugurated Sept. 19 in line with the Kinmen county government's bid to open the island wider to the rest of the world, a local tourism industry executive said Friday.
Kinmen County Tourism Association Chairman Wu Chia-chiang made the announcement at a news conference in a local hotel.

According to Wu, the decision was made after a delegation organized by the association headed to Hong Kong and Macau in early August to inspect the two markets -- a move in line with the Kinmen county government's efforts to better connect Kinmen with the world and sell the offshore county to foreign visitors as a tourism destination.
The Macau Government Tourist Office responded positively and reached agreement on opening two-way charter flight services with the Kinmen tourism promotion association, Wu said.
Wu expressed the hope of being able to better promote bilateral tourism exchanges between Kinmen and Macau and jointly explore cooperation opportunities with the charter services.
The Kinmen County Tourism Association hopes that a 194-seat Airbus A321 jet of Trans Asia Airways can be used to make the Sept. 19 maiden charter flight between Kinmen and Macau.
The plane is slated to depart from Macau at 6: 10 p. m. that evening and land on Kinmen at 7: 20 p.m. before returning to Macau at 8:20 p.m., the association said.
The association is also organizing five-day group tours from Kinmen to Macau and Hong Kong that will begin with the maiden flight.

Meanwhile, the UNI Airways Corp. also inaugurated a charter flight service from Makung on the outlying island of Penghu to Hong Kong Thursday, following its launch of similar services to Seoul, Hanoi and Macau.
The aviation company used a 152-seat MD-90 airplane for the round-trip flight that will return from Hong Kong to Macau Aug. 28.

To celebrate the opening of charter flight services on the Makung- Hong Kong route, UNI Airways also marketed a tour group especially designed for families, which will take participants to Disney World in Hong Kong and to the nearby Shenzhen special economic zone in China's Guangdong Province.
Driven by sluggish business in the domestic air travel market, Taiwan's aviation companies are seeking to expand overseas by operating international charter flights, according to a UNI executive.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRICT REGULATIONS TO HINDER RETURN OF CAPITAL: TIER

TEXT.P: Taiwanese investors in China now face a problem in that their profits made in China cannot flow back freely to Taiwan due to the government's strict financial regulations, according to a report released Friday by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER).

Lee Hui-ping, an assistant researcher at TIER, said that investment by Taiwanese enterprises in China accounted for 70 percent of Taiwan's total outbound investment in 2005 and estimated that the percentage will remain approximately the same this year.

While the government has been encouraging local businessmen to remit their profits reaped in China back to Taiwan for the research and development of more higher-end products, the businessmen are worried that they might be phased out of the Chinese market if they do not pour more money into the fierce competition there, Lee noted.
In addition, Taiwan's strict financial regulations make the businessmen unwilling to bring their capital here, Lee added.

Although the investments in China have contributed partially to Taiwan's prosperous exports in recent years, there is a trend that Taiwanese entrepreneurs are purchasing more Chinese goods and hiring more Chinese people, Lee went on.

He urged the government to relax capital control while planning a policy to lure more investment to Taiwan. According to Lee, the policy is aimed at ensuring a more-than 4 percent annual economic growth for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ENCOURAGES OFFICIALS TO LEARN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang encouraged the nation's 600,000 government employees to absorb new knowledge in the hope that it will improve government services and boost national competitiveness.
Speaking at a seminar on "innovating government service manpower, " Su said that all countries are doing their best to enhance government competitiveness in this era of globalization.

As a member of the global village, he said, "Taiwan must not lag behind" in terms of government competitiveness that can be measured in how a government makes and implements economic, defense, communications, cultural and other policies.

Government officials must "learn from the world and from businesses" so their knowledge and ideas are updated because they must "face the real world." They should not work "behind closed doors, " he added.

Su said a key principle in hiring new employees is to "put the right persons at the right positions, " a principle he claimed to have followed when he was magistrate of Pingtung County in southern Taiwan.
"I assigned people to the right positions according to their competency and expertise without regard to their racial or political affiliations," he said.

When he became premier earlier this year, he said some unions "warned" that he must assign "the right persons" to the chairmanships and CEO posts of major state-owned enterprises such as Chung Hua Telecom and Taiwan Power Corp.

"These unions threatened to take to the streets if I didn't use the right, professional people in those key positions. When they learned who had been assigned, they wrote to me to express their appreciation, " said Su.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC URGES TV NETWORKS TO USE BROADCAST DELAY DEVICES

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) suggested Friday that television networks in Taiwan should be equipped with broadcasting delay devices to prevent profanity and violence in their talk shows from being aired live.
Liu Zong-de, a deputy chairman of the NCC, made the remarks when asked to comment on a violent incident that occurred in a Formosa Television talk show aired live the previous evening.

In the incident, one of the invited guests -- Lin Cheng-chieh, a former legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- punched another guest, Contemporary monthly's editor-in-chief Chin Heng-wei, injuring his nose, which required five stitches.
Liu said the incident has highlighted the need for Taiwan's TV networks to use broadcast delay systems to guard against broadcasting similar incidents in the future.
A broadcast delay device creates a buffer of up to 20 seconds and allows the control room of a TV station to delete a profanity or obscenity before it airs.
Liu commended the talk show hostess for making the right decision by requesting that the show be interrupted with commercials immediately following the assault.
However, he noted that Formosa Television's subsequent news programs used the violent footage repeatedly.

"The NCC is reluctant to impose its own judgment on Formosa Television because there is room for discussion on whether the repeated playing of the violent footage might actually spur positive thinking among the viewers," Liu said.
He added, however, that the NCC will not tolerate bloody, gory scenes or indecent exposure in TV programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOLS URGED TO STRENGTHEN CHARACTER EDUCATION

TEXT.P: The effects and outcomes of character education will be included in school management evaluation and will serve as reference when providing grants to local schools, Vice Education Minister Wu Tsai-shun said Friday.
The new policy is part of the Ministry of Education's efforts to encourage elementary and junior high schools to strengthen character education, Wu said.
Wu made the remarks at a meeting of education bureau chiefs from city and county governments around the country.

Noting that character education is an essential mission of schools, Wu said the goal of character education lies in helping children develop good dispositions that will enable them to flourish intellectually, personally and socially.
Wu further said that character education does not amount to simply a lesson or course, a quick-fix program, or a slogan posted on the wall.

As character education is an integral part of school life, Wu said, schools should initiate a diversity of programs for character education, including selection of model students, classroom discipline rules, boy and girl scout activities, volunteer service, sports events and daily campus clean-up activities.

With successful character education, Wu said, schools can become communities in which virtues such as responsibility, hard work, honesty and kindness are taught, expected, celebrated and continually practiced.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENROLLMENT OF POLICE SCHOOLS TO EXPAND NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) will expand the enrollment of police schools next year as part of efforts to resolve a national police shortage, NPA Director-General Hou Yu-ih said Friday.

The 2006 enrollment of two police schools -- Taoyuan County-based Central Police University and Taipei-based Taiwan Police College -- will expand to 2,000 recruits per year, Hou said in a community security meeting held by the Tainan County Police Bureau in southern Taiwan.

Tainan County Councilor Lai Mei-huei asked in the meeting for an increase of the police force in the southern county, pointing out that the county has only 2,374 police officers, 300 short of the figure the county needs to maintain social order.

In addition to the shortage of law-enforcement personnel, Paiho township administrator Liu Mi-shan and many borough administrators in the county all voiced the need for money for closed circuit surveillance systems in local communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT CLARIFIES RUMOR ON GAY MARRIAGE CEREMONY

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government dispelled a rumor Friday that it will sponsor a public wedding ceremony for gay men and women in September, pointing out that same-sex marriages are not legal in Taiwan.

Chung Che-liang, head of the municipal Bureau of Civil Affairs, made the remarks while answering questions from Taipei City Councilor Li Keng Kuei-fang during an interpellation session at the Taipei City Council.

Li Keng said that the work and living rights of gay men and women should be fully protected, but she claimed that Taipei is the only city in the world that would hold a gay activity with public funds.

She asked municipal officials to clearly explain whether gay marriages are lawful in Taipei and what are the city government's countermeasures to prevent the spread of AIDS and build a healthy city. She did not elaborate on what she felt was the relationship between gay marriage and the spread of AIDS.
The city council woman and various religious representatives expressed their disagreement with the idea of the Taipei city government holding a public wedding ceremony for gay couples.

It had been rumored that some 30 gay couples from home and abroad had been planning to take part in the public wedding ceremony in Taipei and that homosexuals and lesbians from other Asian countries might gather in Taipei, taking advantage of the occasion to make the city into a prominent "gay heaven."

Denying that Taipei will hold a collective gay wedding ceremony, Chung explained that the city government is only planning to sponsor a seminar on "gay civic movement" with the aim of helping the public build "a correct concept" toward the gay community and learn how to respect minority groups.
According to Chung, gay couples cannot register their marriages or households with the municipal authorities and are not allowed to adopt children.

No matter whether gay men or women are well- accepted in local society, the public should be lenient with them and help them "come out, " Wu said, adding that this is the purpose of the city government's planned seminar.

According to a claim by municipal Department of Health Director Sung Yen-jen, gay men are "prone to having AIDS" if they don't take precautions when having sex. But he admitted that the spread of AIDS is unrelated to their marriage status.
On the other hand, gay people should think of their roles on the social, legal and cultural fronts when living together, urged municipal Department of Social Affairs Director Hsueh Cherng-tay.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. BASKETBALL STAR TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. basketball star Kobe Bryant, who plays for the Los Angeles Lakers, will make a whirlwind 24-hour visit to Taiwan Sept. 7, Nike Taiwan announced at a press conference Friday.

Bryant, who will be visiting Taiwan for the first time, will meet 4,000 fans in the National Taiwan University Gymnasium, where he will conduct a short basketball clinic, according to Nike Taiwan General Manager Roxanne Chiu.
Bryant will meet the local media at a press conference and will leave for Seoul the next day, Chiu said.
Taiwan is the third stop for Bryant on his Sep. 4- 9 Asia Tour, which also includes Tokyo, Hong Kong, Seoul and Beijing.
However, he is not expected to put on an extensive demonstration or competition as he is still in rehabilitation following knee surgery in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: F.D.A. Approves Broader Access to Next-Day Pill
The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved over-the-counter sales of the morning-after contraceptive pill to women 18 and older, resolving one of the most contentious issues in the agency's 100-year history.
Nationwide over-the-counter sales of the drug, Plan B, are expected to start by the end of the year. It will be sold in pharmacies and health clinics only, and buyers must show proof of age. Anyone under age 18 will still need a prescription. Men may also buy Plan B for a partner.
Wall Street Journal: Wine Sales Thrive As Old Barriers Start to Crumble
The business of wine is breaking free of one of the world's most archaic and tangled retail systems. The result: a rise in sales, and an explosion of new ways to buy wine.
One of wine's new winners is Gary Vaynerchuk, a 30-year-old Belarus immigrant who recently dipped his nose into a glass, inhaled deeply, and stared into a videocamera. "Bell pepper, green pepper, red pepper," he declared. "This smells like a salad."
The market is in upheaval because its many barriers are starting to crumble. Recently, a Seattle federal court struck down state rules forcing retailers to buy through wholesalers at pre-established prices. Several states are lifting rules that prevent consumers from buying wine directly from out-of-state producers and retailers producers and retailers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI'S POSITION AS GLOBAL CITY `WORTH CONTEMPLATION:' ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: Taipei should look at itself and contemplate how it fits into the global cities network in order to be a better city, University of Chicago Professor Saskia Sassen said in an interview with CNA Friday.

As a "super platform" of global cities has surfaced after the "merging of major East Asian cities" and the competition between cities has become history, Taipei should think about it fits in the network, according to Sassen, a prominent sociologist and economist.
"The Global City" is a term coined by Sassen in the 1980s to describe how cities became strategic "transnational spaces in the global economy" and later "joined forces as a denationalized network."

"A global city is a platform for international investors and foreign professionals, and a partly denationalized space as well. It is far more oriented to other financial centers of the world rather than its neighborhood, " she explained.

Global cities like London, Tokyo and New York are subnational units that are key structures for a new form of power that globalization has brought with it, said Sassen, who is considered by her peers as a "leading scholar of globalization."

More and more global cities are working together, Sassen said. Paris, Amsterdam, Brussels and Madrid -- four of Europe's largest global cities -- have formed an alliance to "compete" with London, she added.

As an East Asian city, Taipei probably should look at the fact that there are more than 400,000 Taiwanese professionals in China and that its busiest transnational professional circuits are the Taipei-Shanghai and Taipei-Guangdong/Hong Kong flights, and think about its position in the network, Sassen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPOSE-PRESIDENT CAMPAIGN CALLS FOR POLICE PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The spokeswoman for a campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian called on the police Friday to ensure safety for campaign workers as a radical ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker has announced he will lead 60 buses of people from the president's hometown in southern Taiwan to demand that Shih Ming-teh, who initiated the campaign, pay back what they donated to him years ago when he was chairman of the DPP.
Ho De-fen pointed out that DPP Legislator Wang Hsing-nan was targeting the wrong people, as Shih's campaign to depose Chen has nothing to do with his private life.

Wang said Chen's hometown supporters are very angry at Shih's action and they want their donations to him back. Shih said the NT$1.8 million he received from Tainan County supporters was donated to a family support center in Tainan.
The 60 buses, carrying an estimated 2,400 people, are scheduled to arrive in Taipei Saturday afternoon.

Ho said the campaign office will be closed for the weekend and that no press conference will be held, but some volunteer workers might still work at the office. She said she has asked them to be careful and ignore the protesters from Tainan.
She urged the police to provide protection to the campaign workers and the office, and to "take full responsibility for what happens" when the protesters shout anti-Shih slogans outside the office.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPOSE-PRESIDENT CAMPAIGN RECEIVES NT$110 MILLION

TEXT.P: As of Thursday evening, when three designated bank and postal accounts were closed, the campaign to depose the president had received NT$110,291,563 (US$3.34 million) from more than 1 million donors, the campaign headquarters announced Friday.

The campaign was initiated by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who called on members of the public to contribute NT$100 each for him to organize a mass sit-in calling on President Chen Shui-bian to step down.

The campaign headquarters said it would hold a training session Sunday on Ketagalan Boulevard facing the Presidential Office for 1,000 "security and order volunteers." It had not yet decided when to begin the sit-in.
The campaign will ensure that the sit-in remains non-violent to underscore its theme of "love, peace and reason, " according to the organizers.
It said it welcomes donations of food and water, but because the office space is limited, donors are asked to send them directly to the sit-in site after it begins.
A "Forrest Gump Youth Corps" and an "abien886" blog are cooperating with the campaign office in launching an unprecedented popular movement to unseat the scandal-ridden president.
Chuang Kuo-hsin, spokesman for the youth corps, said corps members will join the work to maintain order and security.
Blogger Su Yi-chen said the blog site rhymes with "Bye-bye, President A-Bian, " and she welcomes the public to share their feelings about deposing the president with blog readers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV TALK SHOW HOSTESS TO FILE COUNTER-LAWSUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Renowned television talk show hostess Sisy Chen said Friday that she will file a counter-lawsuit against President Chen Shui-bian for defaming her with a false and malicious accusation if Chen sues her for slander over remarks she made on a TV program Thursday.
She told a press conference at the Legislative Yuan that the president, being a lawyer himself, must know that if he intends to sue someone, he must have good reason.
She said the threat to sue her is apparently a "political action" indicating that the Presidential Office is at its wit's end in its attempts to defend the president.

She claimed that what she said in her show must be viewed "in a broader context" instead of being compressed into "a single brief claim" that the president plans to take advantage of his upcoming South Pacific visit to ship his valuables overseas by traveling on Air Force One -- a short-range jet plane -- that will take off from Taipei's domestic Sungshan Airport.
The TV hostess questioned the motive of the president in choosing Air Force One for his visit to Palau and noted that the president's 2005 visit to Palau used a chartered flight of China Airlines.
She pointed out that all of the president's 10 overseas visits in the past six years have relied on either Eva Airways or China Airlines flights.

Giving four possible reasons for the change, she said either the scandal-ridden president might be concerned about his own safety because CAL's air crew might not be so obedient as he wants, or he could be worried about being embarrassed by protesting crowds along the way if he has to go to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan County for departure.

The third possibility, according to her, would be that by taking off from Sungshan Airport on a military plane, the president could avoid customs inspections and could easily ship his wife's questionable valuables abroad.
Another possibility would be that the president might want to help his son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming -- a defendant in an insider trading case -- to flee abroad.

The Presidential Office said in a statement earlier Friday that her "malicious" defamation is "totally unfactual" and has seriously damaged the president's reputation, and that the president will file a slander suit against her.

President Chen is under enormous pressure from the people who want him to step down because of a series of corruption scandals surrounding the first family and senior aides of the Presidential Office.

Amid angry cris that he should stay in Taiwan to listen to the people's complaints, the president announced he will depart Sept. 3 for Palau to attend a leaders' summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the South Pacific before heading on to Nauru for a visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TALKS ON TOURIST OPENING SLATED FOR MID-SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait will begin talks in mid-September on terms under which Chinese citizens can make sightseeing trips to Taiwan, a senior official said Friday.
Hsu Wen-sheng, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said the talks will pave the way for Taiwan opening to Chinese tourists.

The agenda will focus on non-political technical issues, including verification of Chinese tourist identities, the repatriation formula for absconding tourists and treatment of travel disputes, said Hsu.

Hsu has been designated to concurrently head a quasi-official travel association to deal with its Chinese counterpart, the China Tourism Association, on issues regarding Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan. The association is scheduled to hold its first board meeting Sunday.

It remains uncertain whether the talks will follow the format adopted in previous cross-strait talks on opening direct charter flights during traditional festivals or for special purposes, known locally as the "Macau formula."

Hsu said only that Tourism Bureau Deputy Director-General Lai Se-chen will represent Taiwan, while Zhang Xichin, deputy director of China's National Tourism Administration, will be the top Chinese negotiator.
As China refuses any official contact with Taiwan, the two sides have to set up quasi-official travel associations to negotiate and manage the issue.

Meanwhile, the ROC Travel Agent Association, which has been responsible for laying the groundwork for tourist opening, said it has completed its "trailblazing" function. Hereafter, the association said, it will play a supporting role, taking charge of delivering travel papers, allocation of travel quotas, management of the absconding prevention deposits and discipline of travel agents.

According to Taiwan's plan, a maximum of 1,000 Chinese tourists will be allowed to enter Taiwan per day for a maximum 10-day stay. Chinese tourists are required to "enter and leave in group, " and the host Taiwan travel agency will be fined NT$200,000 for each absconded Chinese tourist.

To ensure travel quality, travel agencies must sign up a discupline agreement. Any travel agency that violates the minimum daily travel expenses of US$80-to-US$100 will have its tourist quota allocation suspended for one month.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES DEMANDING MILITARY PERSONNEL TO SHUN SIT-IN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) denied Friday that it has demanded military personnel stay away from an imminent round-the-clock sit-in protest to force President Chen Shui-bian to step down.

MND spokesman Wu Chi-fang made the denial after opposition lawmakers accused the ministry of not keeping a neutral stance toward the "1 million people to depose Chen" campaign by demanding military servicemen sign a document promising not to take part in any anti-Chen acitvities, including making cash donations or taking part in sit-in.

Wu said the military has just stepped up education programs to enhance military personnel's awareness of the virtures of delinking the military from politics and the necessity for the military to maintain administrative neutrality.

He also denied media reports that Defense Minister Lee Jye went to the maximum-guarded Hengshan command center Thursday to instruct all service members not to take part in the upcoming anti-Chen sit-in protest near the Presidnetial Office.
"The reports were not factual. The minister didn't have such a work schedule the day before," Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUG. 26 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Aug. 26:
13:40, President Chen Shui-bian will visit an elderly citizen care center in Yulin County.
16:00, President Chen will attend the inaugural ceremony for a new media watch group.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 26, or the third day of the leap eventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1850: Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King" of France who abdicated rather than face a middle-class revolt, dies.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the killed-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The US legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Unions announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, US assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo Hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
2001: Seven Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives write a letter to State Secretary Madeleine Albright, requesting that the State Department "take the necessary steps to end the inappropriate ban on high-level visits between elected Taiwanese officials and U.S. officials, including the democratically-elected president of Taiwan."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."

Manila Bulletin: Cha-cha petition filed with Comelec
Multi-sectoral coalition Sigaw ng Bayan and the Union of Local Authorities of the Philippines (ULAP) filed with the Commission on Elections (Comelec) yesterday a 30-page petition seeking amendments to the 1987 Constitution through a "people's initiative."
