China and Singapore yesterday agreed to restart negotiations for a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA), which promises to lift strategic and economic ties to new heights.
The Lianhe Zaobao: S'pore and China will start FTA talks.
Singapore and China agreed to start negotiations for a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA).
The decision was made at the 3rd Joint Council for Bilateral Co-operation meeting between Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Wong Kan Seng and his Chinese counterpart Wu Yi in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO PROVIDE POVERTY AID

TEXT.P: The government will launch an emergency relief program targeting the portion of the population deemed to be "near-poverty" and "newly poor" in September, a Cabinet official said Friday.

Citing tallies from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Minister without Portfolio Lin Wan-yi noted that there is a group of people who earn NT$7,500 per month or less on average but who are not qualified for subsidies for low-income households because they own fixed assets and therefore described as being "near poverty."

Meanwhile, there is another group of people who might downgrade from the middle-class to the near-poverty class at any time owing to the trend of globalization, knowledge-based economy and transformation of the industrial structure, who are known as the "newly poor," Lin pointed out.
These two groups of people received little social relief in the past and will be the priority targets of the program, Lin said.
Under the program, the government will launch a service hotline for those needing help and establish a system for the reporting and transfer of such cases.
While local governments will evaluate these cases and work out a plan to assist them after receiving reports, they will also track the conditions of the relief recipients on a regular basis.

The emergency relief includes cash, shelter, medical subsidies, medical treatment for those with mental diseases, employment assistance, schooling aid, legal aid, physical safety and property protection, care for children, elderly and physically or mentally challenged from these families, and services helping the "newly poor" population start their own businesses.
Lin said the relief will be provided for three months in each case and can be extended for another three months if necessary.
The program will continue until the government amends the social relief law to include the "near poverty" and the "newly poor" by the end of 2008, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italy to lead U.N. force after France.
Italy will lead the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon in March, 2007 after France hands over the command, according to an agreement reached Friday in a meeting of European Union foreign ministers held in Brussels.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALE OF DESTROYERS AN EXAMPLE OF U.S. COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN: PENTAGON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The sale of Kidd-class destroyers to Taiwan marks a perfect example of the U.S. commitment to helping the country maintain sufficient self-defense capability as set forth in the Taiwan Relations Act, a Pentagon official said Friday.

John Toolan, principal director of the Asian-Pacific Affairs Office of the U.S. Secretary of Defense, made the remarks during the departure ceremony for two Kidd-class destroyers sold to Taiwan. Two other Kidd-class destroyers have previously been delivered to Taiwan.
Toolan said it is no coincidence that Taiwan has enjoyed peace and stability for the past 50 years.
"The strength of Taiwan's military has kept the threat at bay, which has allowed the democratic transformation and economic development to take place," he said.

He said the foundation of the United States' lasting relationship with Taiwan is much deeper than the provision of defense articles and services as it is based upon shared values and common principles.

"We are both peace-loving peoples, nurturing our respective democracies, committed to the rule of law, and dedicated to our shared commitment to human rights. We also share in an understanding that our values and principles are best secured through strength, " he said.
Toolan said the U.S. government's decision to sell the warships to Taiwan is an investment in the continuation of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Toolan reiterated that the United States opposes unilateral changes by either side to the cross-strait status quo and the use of force or coercion by Beijing to compel a resolution to the cross-strait dispute and does not support Taiwan independence.
He urged Beijing to open a dialogue with the elected leadership of Taiwan and to demonstrate more transparency in describing the purpose of its military buildup.

Meanwhile, he called on Taipei to work harder to ensure continued stability in the Taiwan Strait, pointing out that Taiwan's defense modernization efforts have been hampered by domestic politics and that the country is losing its traditional technological edge over China.
"Leaders in power and in the opposition shoulder a collective burden of providing for the security of Taiwan's 23 million people, " he said.
Toolan said the U.S. government encourages Taiwan to address in a balanced way both immediate needs and long-lead future capabilities.
"In doing so, millions more across East Asia will be safer from the horrors of war, because Taiwan will be preparing responsibly to preserve the peace," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PROMOTES 'SAFEGUARDING TAIWAN WITH NO CORRUPTION' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has been making aggressive efforts to organize presentations around the country as part of what it calls its "Safeguarding Taiwan with No Corruption" campaign since its failure to promote a legislative motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian in late June.
The KMT has planned a total of 1,500 presentations, with the last activity to be held in mid-September in the central city of Taichung, according to the KMT headquarters.

In the Taichung presentation, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-yeou will give a report on the party's efforts to oust Chen because of the spate of corruption scandals involving the president, members of his family and close aides.

Commenting on an ongoing "anti-Chen" movement and a planned sit-in initiated by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen said Saturday that the KMT encourages its party members to join the sit-in in person but that the party itself will not be involved.

The KMT will keep its distance from the sit-in in order to prevent DPP supporters from twisting the "anti-Chen" campaign into a conflict between the DPP-led "pan-green camp" and the opposition "pan-blue alliance," Huang explained.

The organization of the KMT-initiated "Safeguarding Taiwan with No Corruption" campaign presentations is the second phrase of the opposition party's efforts to depose Chen following a failed recall motion at the Legislative Yuan June 27, according to the KMT.

The second-phrase of efforts aimed at pushing Chen to step down are scheduled to be completed before Sept. 19, when the Legislative Yuan will open after its summer recess, the KMT said, noting that after that day, the party will begin the third phrase of its campaign.
So far, the KMT has not yet planned any moves for the third phrase, KMT Director of Organization Affairs Huang Chung-hsien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD SEEK TO IMPROVE TIES WITH CHINA: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu proposed Saturday that the country seek to improve its relations with China in the face of the rise of Taiwan's giant neighbor.

Addressing a meeting of the Taiwan Heart group, Lu claimed that Taiwan has made significant progress in terms of its foreign exchange reserves, national income and competitiveness under the leadership of the Democratic Progressive Party.
Although China still lags far behind Taiwan in its development in almost all fields, it has been trying hard to catch up in recent years, Lu said.
In the face of China's rise, Taiwan should not continue to paint an ugly image of China or turn a blind eye to it like it has in the past, Lu said.
She said Taiwan must adopt a new mindset in dealing with China and seek to resolve the hostility between the two sides while ensuring that Taiwan does not concede its position or lose its dignity.
She also said Taiwan should not pin all its hopes on China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MEMBERS TO STAGE SIT-IN TO HIGHLIGHT SOCIAL HARMONY

TEXT.P: The Tainan office of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will launch a series of sit-ins from Sept. 1-9 as a countermeasure against a campaign to be led by a former DPP chairman to depose President Chen Shui-bian.

Kuo Kuo-wen, director of the DPP's Tainan office, said at a pledge ceremony held in front of the Huian temple in Chen's hometown of Kuantien that Taiwan is a democratic country in which the public can only sack a government official through judicial process.
He said the campaign to be led by DPP former Chairman Shih Ming-teh to oust Chen is inadequate in a democracy.
Shih will lead a sit-in in front of Presidential Office to press Chen to step down for a spate of corruption scandals allegedly implicating Chen's family members and close aides.
According to Kuo, the sit-in to be staged by them in Tainan will be conducted in a peaceful and rational manner, which he claimed will be in contrast to those to be launched in Taipei.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih said at the ceremony that Shih's campaign is covered by the shadow of violence, adding that Shih and Ma Ying-jeou, Taipei mayor and chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , should take responsibility for any violence that erupts in a series of rallies to be staged in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHERS DISCOVER 56 NEW FUNGI

TEXT.P: A decade-long survey has discovered 56 new kinds of fungi in Taiwan, according to a statement issued Saturday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

The Endemic Species Research Institute (ESRI) under the COA has conducted the islandwide fungus survey since July 1992, discovering seven entirely new species of fungus and 49 species not previously recorded in Taiwan.

According to the ESRI, the new species are sinoboletus fuscus, sinoboletus magnisporus, boletus tubulus, sinotermitomyces taiwanensis, xerocomus taiwanensis, an as-yet unnamed one in the amanita family and another in the agaricus family still under taxonomic review.

To date, the institute has observed and collected 91 kinds of boletus in Taiwan, an ESRI researcher said, adding that although most tropical boletus species are found in low-altitude areas, while most temperate ones exist in mid- and high- altitude zones, they found surprisingly that there are eight tropical ones found in areas above 1500 meters, which is an extremely rare phenomenon.

The researcher noted that the institute has also made some progress in the survey of the amanita family and has recorded one new species, three not previously recorded in Taiwan and seven without available taxonomical reference.

As for the new one in the agaricus family, the researcher said it was found in the area between Chiuchiushan and Chunghsing village in the central county of Nantou. The institute will later apply confirmation from international scientific journals on the newly found fungus.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANNED 'ROUND-THE-CLOCK' SIT-IN IN TAIPEI WILL NOT BE PERMITTED

TEXT.P: Permission for a planned "round-the-clock" sit-in in Taipei initiated by a former ruling Democratic Progressive Party chairman to push President Chen Shui-bian to resign has been denied by the city police authorities, according to media reports Saturday.

Asked about the reports, Ho De-fen, spokeswoman of the "campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian, which is trying to organize the sit-in initiated by Shih Ming-teh, told CNA that the campaign organizer has not yet been informed as to why permission for the planned "24-hour" sit-in Sept. 11-23 in front of the Presidential Office was denied.
Ho said the organizer will appeal against the police's decision and will continue efforts to convince the authorities to reverse it.

Reports said that taking traffic, social order and community tranquility into account, the Taipei Police Office's Chungcheng Division, which is in charge of assembly applications, only agreed to allow a 9 a.m.-10 p.m sin-in Sept. 12-15.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TOPS IN HEALTHY LIFESTYLE SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taipei City is Taiwan's top city in terms of "lifestyle of health and sustainability" (LOHS), followed by Taichung and Tainan cities, according to the results of poll released Saturday.

The Common Health magazine conducted the survey based on physical health, psychological health and social security, city and county residents' responses to environmental protection, city and county government efforts in upgrading public health, as well as promotion of environmental protection by city and county governments.

In terms of physical health, Taipei City tops the list, followed by Kaohsiung and Taichung cities. On the ratio of obese residents as well as the prevalence of betel nut chewing, Taipei City is at the bottom and is second in terms of the amount of vegetables eaten.
On tobacco use prevention, Taipei City is top, followed by Tainan City, with Kaohsiung and Hsinchu cities both ranking third.
The survey also found that Taiwan people have developed a stronger sense of no smoking. Nearly 70 percent of those polled said they do not like to have smokers around when they eat out.

In terms of environmental protection, residents in Yunlin, Nantou and Chiayi counties are most restrained in the use of air conditioners (either not using them or setting them above 26 degrees celcius), while residents in Taipei city and county were found to be the most unrestrained.

The survey also found that more and more Taiwan people have LOHS sense, citing as examples that 77 percent are in favor of banning smoking in restaurants, 61 percent will report environmental problems and 43 percent will buy more expensive dishwashing detergent if it is environmentally friendly.
The survey was conducted via telephone between June 27 and July 16. A total of 10,225 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of between 5.0 and 4.7 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH SAILING BOAT RESCUED OFF KINMEN

TEXT.P: A British sailor aboard a motor yacht was rescued Friday by a Taiwanese fishing boat in waters near Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen, coast guard officials on Kinmen said Saturday.

Sixty-one-year-old Alastair Peter Alexander was found Friday night by the fishing boat near Kinmen with his six-ton yacht incapacitated due to engine failure. The boat was then towed to a nearby port to await help.
Kinmen coast guard officials offered Alexander tools, food and water and he was expected to resume his journey later that night, the coast guard said.
Alexander, who lives in Hong Kong, said he started his voyage Aug. 24 in Santou, in China's Fujian Province. His destination was South Korea.
A sailor for more than 20 years, Alexander has visited more than 50 countries in Europe, Asia and the Pacific.
He extended gratitude for the help he received on Kinmen and promised to visit again in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF URGES PEOPLE TO BE CALM AMID ANTI-CHEN, PRO-CHEN RALLIES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou urged the people -- no matter they are supporters of embattled President Chen Shui-bian, or those who want him booted out -- to remain calm when taking part in rallies to demonstrate their feelings.
Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, made the call Saturday at a KMT meeting in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan.
Ma said the Constitution protects the right to assemble and parade in a peaceful manner, but those who join in such events in a "non-peaceful" way will be "evacuated by a predominant police force."

Out of discontent with Chen's refusal to relinquish the presidency after a string of corruption allegations implicating himself, his family members and close aides, former ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh initiated a "1 million people to depose Chen" campaign Aug. 12 to push Chen to resign.
The campaign organizer, claiming to have won the support of 1 million people around the country, has planned a sit-in in September in front of the Presidential Office.
Meanwhile, some "pro-Chen" lawmakers launched a drive to counter the Shih-initiated campaign with a rally in Taipei Saturday involving a few thousand "pro-Chen" activists from southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILL NOT MOBILIZE AGAINST ANTI-CHEN PROTESTERS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun called for calm and rationality Saturday as the nation continued its frenzy about unseating President Chen Shui-bian.
Yu said the party's principles are "no counterreacting and no mobilization for the sake of public stability."

He said that the party will stand to its "core values of Taiwanese identity, social justice and sustainable development" and asked for understanding for what he described as "the erratic behavior" of a few politicians, adding that the DPP will continue to reflect upon itself.

Yu made the remarks as a rally titled "safeguarding Taiwan and encouraging President Chen" sponsored by media personality Wang Pen-hu and DPP Legislator Wang Shih-Chien was held at the 228 Peace Memorial Park in downtown Taipei.

In addition, DPP Legislator Wang Hsin-nan led more than 2,000 people from Tainan, Chen's hometown, to the headquarters of the "depose the president" campaign in Taipei to demand that the organizer of the campaign, former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh, repay money they donated to him when he was running for the legislature in the 1990s. Shih is set to stage a mass sit-in in front of the Presidential Office.

Asked about some DPP politicians who are mobilizing people to counter the "depose Chen" campaign, Yu said the party is adopting a dissuasive approach, telling those who intend to travel to Taipei that they must not counterreact or provoke but should "express their views rationally."

Also Saturday, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih led a parade in the southern city Saturday to drum up support for a sit-in Sept. 1-9 to show support for Chen, who is dogged by a string of corruption and embezzlement allegations implicating himself, his family members and senior aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROHIBIT LIVE POULTRY TRADE

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan is planning to prohibit live poultry trade and slaughtering in traditional markets around Taiwan by 2008 to prevent possible avian flu outbreaks, a government official said Saturday.

The Cabinet will present a series of accompanying measures in this regard in September. Once the policy is implemented, Taiwan will become the second Asian country to have carried out such policy, following Singapore.
Hong Kong also plans to follow suit by 2008.
The H5N1 strain of avian influenza began to hit Vietnam, Thailand and Cambodia in 2004 before spreading to Europe, Africa and other parts of the world more recently.
To ensure Taiwan's protection from avian flu, the government has put the anti-avian flu task on the list of affairs related to national security.

At a national security meeting on avian flu in March, President Chen Shui-bian instructed related agencies to study the possibility of prohibiting live poultry slaughter in traditional markets to prevent avian flu being transmitted from poultry to humans.

An interministerial ad hoc group was then formed by the Executive Yuan, which will present a series of measures next month to prevent an avian flu outbreak in Taiwan, including an increase of qualified electrical slaughterhouses around the island and educating poultry vendors and the public how to prevent the disease.
Some academics believe that the popularity of live poultry slaughter in Asia's traditional markets causes the transmission of avian flu.
Many poultry vendors opposed the policy at the beginning due to fear that they will lose customers who prefer to buy newly killed poultry, Taipei city government officials said.
However, they are now more willing to accept the policy since they believe that it will attract more clients in the long run, the official added.
According to the officials, there are some 400 poultry vendors selling newly slaughtered poultry in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: POOR EDUCATION SYSTEM DISSUADES PEOPLE FROM BEARING CHILDREN: POLL

TEXT.P: A poor education system, in addition to economic factors, has dissuaded many Taiwan people from bearing children, according to the results of a recent survey released Saturday.
Hsu Kan-lin, an assistant professor at the National Cheng Kung University's College of Medicine, conducted the survey on Taiwan people's attitudes toward bearing and raising children.

According to the results of the telephone survey conducted among 1,033 adults around the country aged between 25 and 44, the three major factors that dissuade people from bearing children are economic factors, a confusing education system and deteriorating living quality.

Most of the respondents said they believe improving the education system is the best way to increase the birthrate, followed by improving social order and the economy, and offering birth subsidies and child-care services.

Two kids is still the ideal for most respondents. When asked why they want to have children, the respondents named several reasons, such as strengthening the marriage and having a son to carry the family name.
Thirty seven percent of the respondents said they plan to marry at the age of between 30 and 34, with more than half of them wishing to bear children two or three years after marriage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV VIOLENCE RESULT OF DELIBERATE INSTIGATION OF HATRED: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that it was a deliberate instigation of hatred that led to a violent incident that occurred in a live TV talk show Thursday.

Chen was referring to Lin Cheng-chieh, one of the invited guests and a former legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), who launched a frenzied physical attack on political commentator Chin Heng-wei after a heated debate on a campaign to depose President on a Formosa Television talk show. Chin required five stitches to his face as a result of the assault.

Chen made the remarks while attending the inauguration ceremony of the Taiwan Herald Society, a civic group established by pro-independence Taiwan Society Head Wu Shu-ming. The Taiwan Herald Society boasts of its Taiwan identity and media professionalism, in contrast to the mainstream media, which it claims, under the facade of press freedom, spreads unfounded speculation, tramples the judicial dignity and creates social rivalry and disturbance.
Chen greeted Chin, a member of the society, before delivering his speech.
The president said he was "saddened" to learn that Chin was attacked because of his views.

"This is not purely an issue of suppressing the freedom of speech of an individual, " Chen said, but is the "result of deliberate instigation of hatred, confrontation and violence and the expansion and spreading of such sentiment."

Chen is facing the prospect of an imminent mass sit-in launched by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, to pressure him to step down over a series of corruption allegations implicating himself, his family members and senior aides.

"When politicians, through a passionate incitement of revolutionary ideas, attempt to force a popularly elected president to step down and upset constitutional order by using outside institutional means, a mentality of promoting only those who comply with one's views and suppressing those who are opposed to one's views will be naturally formed," he said.
He said that "to promote a revolution during democratic constitutional rule is tantamount to a complete denial and slighting of democracy."
"To resort to violence and threats under a democracy is to trample and challenge basic human rights and government authority, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STAYS CLEAR OF 'CHAOTIC' MEDIA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he cannot accept the incessant smearing and sensationalist allegations in the media and has chosen to "ignore them."

The embattled president, who is embroiled in a political storm because of a spate of corruption allegations implicating himself, his family members and senior aides, made the remarks while addressing the inauguration of the Taiwan Herald Society, a civic group established that day that touts its Taiwanese identity and journalistic professionalism in contrast to the mainstream media.
Chen noted that after the peaceful transfer of political power in 2000, misgivings have always outweighed tolerance and rivalry and confrontation have always outweighed mutual trust.

"The persistence of these negative sentiments can be attributed to the difficulty of the ruling and opposition parties in adjusting to the new political situation, but it is also due to the incessant instigation of the media, which has replaced differentiation between right and wrong with its preset stance, and journalistic professionalism with sensationalist allegations."
The president said that he cannot accept the incessant smearing and allegations of many media outlets and has chosen to "stay clear of them."
"My life has not been affected by them, " Chen claimed, saying that he lives "happily."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISTS TO BOOST TAIWAN'S PRIVATE SECTOR SPENDING: CEPD

TEXT.P: Chinese tourists are expected to contribute NT$16 billion per year to Taiwan's private sector spending after travel restrictions for Chinese citizens are lifted, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said Saturday.
This will mean an increase of 0.1 percentage points in Taiwan's gross domestic product, Hu said.

The estimate is based on the assumption that there will be 365,000 Chinese tourist arrivals per year, with each tourist staying 7.61 days on average and spending an average of NT$5,600 per day, Hu said.
Hu said that with hotels in Taiwan providing a total of only 21,000 rooms, the government will allow visits by only 1,000 Chinese tourists per day.

Taiwan has since 2002 allowed Chinese citizens meeting certain criteria to make pleasure trips to Taiwan and is now engaging in talks with China on measures to allow more Chinese citizens to visit the country.
The Mainland Affairs Council has recently said that the two sides are expected to come to an agreement on the issue by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORTERS OF PRESIDENT RALLY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A rally organized by a TV talk show host Wang Peng-hu at the 228 Peace Memorial Party in Taipei drew tens of thousands of people Saturday.
The participants, some of whom came from as far away as the president's hometown of Tainan, southern Taiwan, packed the park to full capacity.
They braved pouring rain to listen to politicians' speeches and followed them by chanting pro-Chen slogans.

DPP politicians and leading pro-independence activists took turns at the rally to lambaste former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who is trying to organize a sit-in to push for Chen's ouster.
Prominent among the speakers were Shih's former wife Chen Li-chu, who condemned Shih for "betraying her trust" and warned the public against following Shih's calls for Chen's removal.
The rally was a preemptive gathering with the purpose of deterring Shih from pressing ahead with his attempt to depose the president via his sit-in.

The climax of Saturday's peaceful rally was the appearance of political commentator Chin Heng-wei, who was hit in the face Thursday by one of the president's critics when he fiercely defended the president in a heated TV debate.
He was greeted at the rally with deafening applause.

Before the rally ended at 6:30 p.m., Wang urged Shih to stop his campaign and appology to Taiwan people, and warned Ma Ying-jeou, chief of the opposition Kuomintang that Taiwan people would pay him in his own coin if he aids Shih in his campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN GOVERNMENTS PLAY CRITICAL ROLES IN E-LEARNING DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Government planning and support is a critical role in e-Learning industry development, experts from Japan, Korea and Taiwan agreed on in an e-Learning international forum Saturday.

Korean government offered more help to the e-Learning industry and the investment showed promising result, as Korea was ranked fifth -- top in Asian countries -- globally in a 2003 e-Learning world ranking released by Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU).
Taiwan and Japan were ranked 16th and 23rd, respectively.

Starting in 1999, Korea's Ministry of Labor offered an 80% subsidy for workers' e-Learning expenditure, said Kim Young-soon, President of Korea e-Learning Industry Association. The program prompted an e-Learning fever among workers.
"It's the key reason why on-line learning surpassed traditional learning for the first time in 2004, " said Kim.
Korea's Ministry of Education also launched "cyber university" programs in 17 universities in 2000 to encourage e-Learning. There are more than 55,000 graduates already up to this year, Kim said.
In Japan, the government also set up and funded e-Learning programs in selected universities, said Toshio Okamoto, a professor at University of Electro-Communication.

More than 86.1% of Japanese corporates with more than 5,000 employees set up e-Learning programs, according to Japan's e-Learning white paper. "However, Japanese government should do more, compared to Korea and Taiwan, " admitted Hidekuni Komatsu, President of Japan e-Learning Consortium.

For Taiwan, the government also should do more, and it will, said Lin Li-chieh, Director of Taiwan's e-Park Development Center. A five-year plan is expected to be launched in 2008 to follow up the work of National Science and Technology Program for e-Learning. Taiwan's e-Learning program will focus on bigger corporates, public servants and teachers and try to bring up the percentage of on-line learning from 4% to 30% in the future, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAMENTED MEDIA DISORDER, URGED MEDIA SELF DISCIPLINE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lamented Taiwan media disorder and urged self discipline against irresponsible journalism from "The Fourth Estate" in the founding ceremony of a media watch group Saturday.

"Media is not above the law. And self discipline is better than other discipline, " Chen addressed the crowd in the founding ceremony of a media watch group, which has not been given its English name.

Commenting on his views of how journalism should be and the current status of Taiwan media, Chen cited the cases of former CBS anchor Dan Rather and Taiwanese Major League pitcher Wang Chien-ming and expressed his concerns.

Rather resigned from his post after citing forged documents to question U.S. President George W. Bush's military service. Wang Chien-ming announced two weeks ago that he would not be interviewed by all Taiwan media thereafter, claiming the media seriously invaded his parents' privacy.
With the media nowadays replaces right and wrong with positions, there is more hatred than tolerance, more confrontation than trust in Taiwan society, Chen said.
Many people have called for media regulation, Chen said, but he always believes that "media control is the beginning of the autarchy" and the freedom of speech should be respected first and foremost.
"Maybe I was wrong. And that's why I'm a victim, " he added.

Chen, referring to the incident that former Legislator Lin Cheng-chieh assaulted Chin Heng-wei in a Formosa TV political talk show Wednesday, also described the incident as "a challenge to basic human rights and public power."
The president concluded his speech encouraging the media for reporting "the true, the good and the beautiful."
The media watch group, a coalition of former journalists and political commentators, will focus on media reform with a priority on Taiwanese identity.

New York Times: Europe Pledges a Larger Force Inside Lebanon
After a week of confusion and missteps, Europe pledged to add up to 6,900 troops to the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon, officials said at an emergency meeting of European Union foreign ministers here on Friday.
But the officials cautioned that the force would not be used to disarm Hezbollah. That job, if it is done at all, will be left to the Lebanese government and army.
Wall Street Journal: Plaintiffs' Lawsuits Against Companies Sharply Decline
Companies involved in many of the largest and most controversial legal clashes of recent decades are seeing a sharp decline in the number of lawsuits filed against them.
In recent months, judges have dismissed or challenged tens of thousands of individual cases, in matters ranging from claims of lung damage from asbestos and silica dust to allegations that the diet drug fen-phen caused heart problems. Moreover, fewer new claims like these are being launched, as state and federal courts and legislators attack the methods used by some attorneys to round up plaintiffs for large-scale litigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 27, or the fourth day of the leap seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1813: France's Napoleon Bonaparte, with a force of 130,000, wins his last great battle at Dresden, Germany, against a superior Austrian, Prussian and Russian allied force of 200,000.
1859: The world's first oil well is drilled by Edwin L. Drake at Titusville, Pennsylvania.
1883: The 1,800 meter Krakatoa on the Indonesian island of Rakata erupts with a fury that is heard in Australia, more than 3,541 km away, and gigantic tidal waves of up to 36 meters devastate the coastal towns of Java and Sumatra, leaving an estimated 36,000 people dead, and making the eruption the most catastrophic volcanic event ever recorded.
1891: Russia and France sign an entente cordiale.
1908: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the office after John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He won the 1964 election but faced increasing criticism over the mounting US involvement in Vietnam, and did not stand for reelection in 1968.
1910: Thomas Alva Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, shows his "talking picture" for the first time at his New Jersey laboratory.
1910: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, the Yugoslavian-born Albanian nun dedicated to the poor and sick, particularly in India, is born. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, in an attempt to impose dictatorial rule after assuming the provisional presidency in Beijing in March, 1912, orders the arrest of eight members of a constitution-drafting committee.
1916: Italy declares war on Germany.
1916: Romania declares war on Austro-Hungary, thus entering World War I.
1928: The Kellogg-Briant Pact, or Pact of Paris, an international agreement to condemn all war as a means of settling dispute, is signed by representatives of 15 nations.
1939: The world's first jet-propelled aircraft, the He-178 developed by German manufacturer Ernst Heinkel, makes its first flight at Marienehe, in northern Germany.
1946: A pilot's ejector seat prototype is successfully demonstrated at Wright Airport in the United States.
1946: France and Laos conclude an agreement establishing a kingdom under French domination.
1952: Israel and West Germany reach agreement in their negotiations on Nazi war crime indemnity. Under the agreement, the West German government will pay 3 billion Reichsmarks in 12 years to compensate Israeli people for their loss of lives and properties caused by the Nazi regime during World War II.
1962: The International Amateur Athletic Federation issues statement revoking its ratification for Indonesia to hold the Fourth Asian Games following the southeast Asian country's rejection of the Republic of China delegation to the games.
1972: The Taipei Little League baseball team wins the world title.
1977: The ROC's Lih Teh Little League baseball team wins the world title. Both Senior League and Big League baseball teams from Taiwan also won the 1977 world titles in earlier competitions.
1979: Lord Louis Mountbatten, former admiral and viceroy of India, is murdered by a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army as he and members of his family enjoy an outing on his 30-ft. fishing boat off Mullaghmore, County Sligo in the Irish Republic. He was 79.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Finance decides to lower the highest tariff rate to 57.5 percent and reduce duty rates on products with high import tariffs but limited import volume.
1987: A 13-year-old Chinese girl who was left to live with a family of pigs returns to normal life after three years of special training.
1991: Moldova declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1995: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign an agreement in Cairo to expand Palestinian autonomy from Gaza to the West Bank.
1999: Actress-singer Bai Guang dies at her home in Kuala Lumpur at the age of 79.
2003: A three-day six-nation meeting on North Korean nuclear weapon program opens in Beijing.
2004: Taekwondo athlete Chen Shi-hsin wins the ROC's first-ever Olympic gold medal in the Athens Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The power of spiritual forces in the Universe -- how active it is everywhere! Invisible to the eye and impalpable to the sense, it is inherent in all things, and nothing can escape its operation."

DOC.HEADLINE: DAA'S CAMPAIGN TO OUSTER PRESIDENT TO BEGIN SEPT. 1

TEXT.P: The Democratic Action Alliance (DAA) announced Sunday that its campaign to drive the scandal-ridden president, Chen Shui-bian, out of office will officially begin at 7 p.m. on Sept. 1.

DAA convener Huang Kuang-kuo, a psychology professor at National Taiwan University, told a press conference at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial that the campaign will begin by resuming a round-the-clock "democracy night market" at the memorial.
Huang said a ceremony will be held Sept. 2 to "bid farewell to a god of plague," hoping that Chen would never come back to Taiwan if he insists on departing Sept. 3 for a visit to Palau and Nauru.

He said it is "extremely irresponsible" that Chen has decided to go abroad when he should stay in Taipei to explain to the people what he intends to do about the long series of corruption and embezzlement scandals implicating himself, his family and senior aides.
Huang warned the president that he will be a "destined loser" if the people of Taiwan take their campaign into the streets.
"Actually he has already become a loser, with the majority of the people giving the thumbs down on him," he said.

Huang urged former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh, leader of the "One million citizens to depose President Chen" campaign, to announce as soon as possible when its followers will begin a round-the-clock sit-in in front of the Presidential Office, so that the two campaigns can reinforce each other.

Also speaking at the press conference, Hsu Hsin-liang, another former DPP chairman, said that Taiwan is not yet a mature democracy, which is why the people are unable to use a built-in mechanism in the Constitution to force Chen to resign.
"Democracy in Taiwan will be strengthened and become more mature with the success of the campaign to ouster the president," he said.

Hsu pointed out that the campaign to depose Chen is not a stand-off between the DPP as a ruling party and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, because when Chen steps down, his successor will be Vice President Annette Lu, meaning the DPP will remain in power.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERS OF CAMPAIGN TO DEPOSE CHEN DISAPPOINTED AT PRESIDENT'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: Leaders of the "1 million citizens to depose President Chen Shui-bian" campaign said Sunday they now despair that the president will respond to their call for a clean government after Chen claimed he was the "victim" of a "smear campaign" and "irresponsible journalism" a day earlier.

Ho De-fen, spokeswoman for the campaign, deplored that instead of explaining what he intended to do with the long series of corruption and embezzlement scandals surrounding himself, his family and senior aides, Chen complained in his speech at the inauguration of a civic organization that the news media's sensationalist allegations and incessant incitement were to blame for the current crisis he is facing.
Ho also expressed regret that the president's remarks Saturday further alienated Taiwan's society by deepening the confrontation between ruling and opposition parties.

She disclosed that campaign leader Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and senior staff will reach a decision before Sept. 6 as to when the campaign to oust Chen will formally begin.
Noting that the campaign was originally scheduled to begin Sept. 9, she assured that the new date will not be later than that and asked supporters of the campaign to be patient.

The campaign has planned to stage a round-the-clock sit-in Sept. 11-23 in front of the Presidential Office, but local police authorities have only allowed the protesters to use the streets from 9 a.m. to 10 p.m. Sept. 12-15.
Campaign organizers said they will appeal that decision and ask authorities to reconsider their application.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q2 IC INDUSTRY OUTPUT UP 33.6% FROM 1 YEAR AGO; Q3 PROSPECTS GOOD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's IC industry production reached NT$337.1 billion (US$10.25 billion) in the second quarter of this year, up 33.6 percent over the same period last year and 9.8 percent from the previous quarter, according to a government think tank.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) forecast that third-quarter output will grow to NT$350.8 billion and annual output will top NT$1,363.3 billion (US$41.44 billion) in 2006, an increase of 22 percent from 2005.

According to Peng Mao-jung, an ITRI analyst, since the second quarter is traditionally a slack season for IC designing and is affected by a slower market demand for TFT displays and an oversupply of LCD-driven ICs, most IC-designing companies did not register a strong performance during the season.
However, small LCD-driven IC-designing companies were little affected, recording better sales than during the previous season, he pointed out.

Sales of consumer electronic products turned brisk in May, with IC makers also enjoying good business, enabling IC designers to score a production value of NT$77.5 billion in the second quarter, an increase of 6.5 percent from the previous quarter and 19.8 percent over the same time last year, Peng said.

IC manufacturing faced a similar situation, churning out an output in the second quarter -- traditionally a slack season -- that was 12.5 percent higher than the previous quarter. Contract chip-making accounted for 5.5 percent of IC manufacturing output.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) , the world's largest contract-chip maker, reported a 5.5 percent growth in the second quarter over the first, and a yearly growth of 36.9 percent.

United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , another of the world's leading contract-chip makers, scored similar seasonal and yearly growths for the second quarter -- 5.6 percent and 32.4 percent, respectively. Profit margins improved and the utilization of its production capability rose to 80 percent, up slightly from the first quarter, according to ITRI.
DRAM business has been the main driving force behind the substantive growth in Taiwan's IC manufacturing industry in the second quarter of 2006, Peng said.
He attributed this to improved production capability and yield of the DRAM business's 12-inch wafer plants, as well as their improved production technologies.

Internationally, major DRAM makers switched some of their production facilities to producing NAND Flash, bringing down the supply of DRAM chips and raising DDR and DDR2 prices, according to the analyst.
He said Taiwan's IC manufacturers produced a total of NT$183.9 billion in products during the second quarter of 2006, a whopping growth of 40.8 percent from the same period in 2005.

As for the testing and packaging business, he said the second quarter output registered only single-digit growth from the first quarter, influenced by the slow recovery in the personal computer (PC) market. Still, the output figure represented a double-digit growth from the same time last year, he added.

The less impressive performance of Taiwan's testing and packaging business was also due to Microsoft Corp.'s decision to delay marketing of the new Vista operating system which affected sales of PCs and peripherals. Slow sales of low-end cellphones also cooled the demand in testing and packaging of low-end communications chips.

As a whole, the utilization of the testing and packaging business's capabilities went down to 80 percent in the second quarter, but is expected to pick up in the third quarter as PC sales are anticipated to rise when the academic semester begins in September.

For the second quarter, Taiwan's IC-packaging business registered an output of NT$52.3 billion, up 6.7 percent from the previous quarter and 27.6 percent year-on-year, with the IC-testing business registering an output of NT$23.4 billion for a quarterly and yearly growth of 7.8 percent and 45.3 percent.

The ITRI forecast that Taiwan's overall IC industry output will reach NT$350.8 billion in the third quarter, up 4.1 percent from the second, and that 2006 output will reach NT$1,363.3 billion -- a 22-percent increase over 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP REAFFIRMS 'NO CONFRONTATION' PRINCIPLE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will abide by the principles of "no mobilization, no confrontation" toward an unfolding movement to force President Chen Shui-bian to step down, an influential lawmaker said Sunday.

Legislator Yeh Yi-jin, who concurrently serves as chief secretary of the DPP's legislative caucus, made the remarks after two of her colleagues staged two separate rallies in Taipei the day before to support the beleaguered president and oppose Shih Ming-teh, a former DPP chairman who is spearheading a campaign asking for a million people to each donate NT$100 toward Chen's ouster.
Yeh said all the rallies in support of Chen were spontaneous activities that were unrelated to the DPP's legislative caucus or party headquarters.

"As the legislature is in summer recess, the DPP caucus has not been involved in any pro-Chen activities, " Yeh said, adding that she personally thought it "would not be too bad" if DPP supporters vented some anger over what they consider to be a rampant opposition-engineered smear campaign against the president over the past several months.

Nevertheless, Yeh said the DPP's legislative caucus has invariably refrained from stoking irrational emotions among party supporters against the opposition's frenzied involvement in the anti-Chen campaign.

"Congruent with the DPP headquarters' 'no mobilization, no confrontation' directive, the DPP caucus is hopeful that both Chen's supporters and detracters can remain rational, exercise self-restraint and avoid personal attacks for the sake of social harmony and national well-being," Yeh said.

President Chen has been under fire from the opposition and some former allies for more than four months over allegations that members of his family and inner circle exploited their proximity to the executive for illegal financial gain.

Shih recently announced he will hold a round-the-clock sit-in near the Presidential Office building early next month to force Chen to bear political and moral responsibility and to resign over all the alleged corruption scandals.

Shih's "one million to depose Chen" campaign has raised passions and stirred fears of violence, especially after a Shih supporter kicked and slapped a rival political commentator on a live TV talk show Thursday.

DPP Legislator Wang Shih-chien, who joined with some independence activists in organizing a pro-Chen rally at 228 Peace Memorial Park in downtown Taipei near the Presidential Office Saturday, said the rally was designed for Chen's proponents to express support for the president.

"The rally proceeded and ended peacefully. We want Taiwan to grow with stability and order. We just want Shih to exercise similar self-restraint and refrain from inciting resentment and social unrest to rock national stability," Wang said.

DPP Legislator Wang Hsing-nan also took more than a thousand supporters to Shih's office in Taipei Saturday, saying they had demanded a refund for political donations they made toward Shih's campaign to become a lawmaker in the 1990s.

The demonstrators mocked Shih for his claims that he has collected money from 1 million donors for his current campaign to depose Chen. Protesters stayed at the site for about an hour and then left peacefully.

Also Saturday morning, in Chen's hometown of Kuantien in southern Tainan County, about 500 supporters gathered in front of a temple, waving banners of green -- the DPP color -- to voice support for the embattled president.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TO DEPOSE PRESIDENT NEEDS SUPPORT OF DPP LAWMAKERS: KMT

TEXT.P: The success of a campaign to oust scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian will require the support of Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators of conscience and principle, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) indicated Sunday.

Noting that two civic movements aimed at forcing Chen out of office are set to begin in early September, Legislator Tsai Chin-lung, a KMT legislative caucus whip, told news media that Chen is unlikely to buckle under pressure and step down.

Claiming the DPP as a ruling party lacks the capacity for self-examination, Tsai said if the campaign to oust the president and create a clean government is to succeed, it must have the support of those DPP legislators still in possession of a conscience.

In response to the Democratic Action Alliance's call on the KMT and other opposition parties to join the campaign and provide material support, Tsai said the KMT had in fact begun its own campaign to oust Chen in June when it proposed a motion in the legislature to recall the president.
The recall motion failed to pass a high threshold requiring the support of a two-thirds majority among all legislators before the issue could be determined through a national referendum.
The main opposition KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally, the People First Party, maintain only a slight majority in the 221-seat legislature.
Tsai said the KMT has already held more than 1,000 discussion sessions throughout Taiwan over the past several months, based on the need to replace Chen's administration with a clean government.

He added that after the legislature reconvenes Sept. 19, the KMT will consider a series of strategies to force Chen to step down, including introducing a legislative motion to topple the Cabinet through a no-confidence vote, renewing a motion in the legislature to recall the president and asking the Council of Grand Justices to impeach him.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT EARNED NT$200 BILLION FOR KMT: TSU

TEXT.P: Former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lee Teng-hui helped the party earn more than NT$200 billion (US$6.08 billion), the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) claimed Sunday.

Lee Hsien-jen, the caucus' office director, said the main opposition KMT's recent report on the party's assets had unfairly stated the former chairman had presided over huge losses on the part of party-owned enterprises.

The KMT report "purposely ignored" the fact that during Lee's term, when he was also president of the country from 1988-2000, huge sums of money had to be spent on the party's daily operations and its nominees for various elections, Lee Hsien-jen said.

He estimated that during that time, more than NT$8 billion was required annually to keep the party running. Without mentioning where the funds had come from, the KMT report "intentionally failed" to mention that Lee had helped the party turn a profit of at least NT$200 billion, he added.
He criticized KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's plan to use party assets -- now standing at NT$27.7 billion -- to pay for party workers' retirement pensions.
"If these assets had been obtained through improper means, how can he make use of them in such a way?" he asked.

Sources for the party's finances should be limited to membership dues, government subsidies, political donations and generated from interest, "and all of the other assets should be seen as questionable," Lee said.
He said his party, which considers Lee Teng-hui as its spiritual leader, has long called for legislation to regulate how political parties manage their assets.

The KMT itself should certainly be blamed for boycotting such legislation, he said, adding that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- which beat the KMT in 2000 -- was also to blame for not having worked hard enough to pass the bill in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO RIVAL CANDIDATES FOR TAIPEI MAYOR SET OUT ON OVERSEAS TRIPS

TEXT.P: Two rival candidates running in the year-end Taipei mayoral election -- Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Hau Lung-pin of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- set out on overseas trips Sunday.

Both Hsieh and Hau said their travel plans were scheduled long ago and neither agreed with speculation that they are deliberately going abroad to avoid a looming political storm that may arise from the launch of a campaign of "one million to depose" President Chen Shui-bian, spearheaded by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh.

Hsieh, a lawyer-turned-politician who previously served as legislator, Kaohsiung mayor and premier, said prior to his departure for New York that his U.S. tour is mainly to attend the inauguration of a Taiwanese expatriate group in support of his bid for Taipei mayor.

If possible, Hsieh said. he would like to take time out of his busy schedule in the U.S. to watch a New York Yankees baseball match that will be started by Taiwan-born pitcher Wang Chien-ming who has quickly emerged as a new star in the U.S. Major League, with 15 wins so far this season.

Touching on Chinese officials' seizure of Republic of China flags from two of Taipei's delegates at a children's international sports tournament in Thailand the day before, Hsieh said he considered it a very serious incident.
"Such an act of violence should not be accepted. We should lodge a solemn protest. We hope the Taipei city government can properly deal with the incident," Hsieh said.

According to reports from Bangkok, Chinese sports officials seized ROC flags from two Taipei swimming champions attending the International Children's Games in Bangkok after they wrapped them around their shoulders and walked toward a stage to collect their gold medals Saturday.

Shortly after Hsieh's departure for the U.S., Hau, former head of the Environmental Protection Administration, arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to check in for a flight to Japan for a three-day visit.
Hau said he will visit two Japanese metropolises -- Tokyo and Yokohama -- to learn from their major urban development projects and administrative reforms.
"The findings of my trip will serve as reference for my platform for the year-end mayoral camapign," Hau said.

Asked whether he would take part in Shih's upcoming round-the-clock sit-in near the Presidential Office building to force the embattled president to resign over corruption allegations against members of his family and staff, Hau said he personally supports the campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCU SEEKING ENTRANCE TO PAN-STARRS PROJECT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's astronomers are currently seeking a chance to cooperate with the Pan-Starrs Project based in Hawaii, National Central University (NCU) Vice President Ip Wing-huen said Sunday.

The Pan-Starrs project -- Panoramic Survey Telescope & Rapid Response System -- aims at spotting large "near-Earth objects" (NEOs), such as asteroids and comets, that may have perilous consequences if they are moving toward Earth.

In the past, the definition of "large NEOs" meant rocks with a diameter greater than one kilometer; however, after more careful calculations, the standard has now been lowered to a diameter larger than 140 meters -- a size determined as great enough to bring catastrophe.

The project has been in operation at the University of Hawaii's Institute for Astronomy since it obtained congressional funding in 1998. The project's first telescope has been deployed June this year, and all four telescopes should be operational by 2010.

Ip said NCU astronomers have found great success in spotting asteroids, and that if they are accepted as a partner in the Pan-Starr project, the NCU would be helpful in finding "killer asteroids" -- a term sometimes used to describe rocks in space racing towards Earth.

According to Ip, the university launched Lulin Sky Survey (LUSS) in March this year, under which the team at Lulin Observatory at Jade Mountain -- the highest peak in East Asia -- has already discovered 101 NEOs since the beginning of the search -- approximately 15 to 20 new ones per month.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Timothy J. Hwang)
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Whispers of Mergers Set Off Suspicious Trading
The boom in corporate mergers is creating concern that illicit trading ahead of deal announcements is becoming a systemic problem.
It is against the law to trade on inside information about an imminent merger, of course.
But an analysis of the nation's biggest mergers over the last 12 months indicates that the securities of 41 percent of the companies receiving buyout bids exhibited abnormal and suspicious trading in the days and weeks before those deals became public. For those who bought shares during these periods of unusual trading, quick gains of as much as 40 percent were possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RAPS CHINA FOR LACKING DEMOCRATIC CULTURE, SPORTSMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Taiwan strongly criticized China Sunday for "possessing not even one iota of democratic culture" after Chinese team officials seized national flags from Taiwanese teenagers preparing to accept medals at the 2006 International Children's Games in Thailand Saturday.

The Taiwanese athletes had draped Republic of China (ROC) flags around their shoulders for the award ceremony, but officials from the Chinese team forcefully yanked the flags from the athletes and even out of the hands of audience members, according to Chin Fu-tsung, the deputy mayor of Taipei and leader of the Chinese Taipei delegation to the sporting event in Bangkok, Thailand.
Chin has lodged a protest with games organizers and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou described it as a "shocking and regrettable" incident over which he said Taiwan should vehemently protest.

Cheng Wen-tsan, the Executive Yuan's government information minister, said China is a country that does not know what sportsmanship is and without "even one iota of democratic culture, " as it regarded a sporting activity purely from a political perspective and violated the principle of sportsmanship in a civilized society.

Cheng said that China has always adopted a two-pronged strategy toward Taiwan -- on one hand, it "wears a smiling face" but on the other it takes fierce, unrelenting steps toward stifling Taiwan's breathing space in the international community.
"Now everyone in Taiwan has clearly witnessed China's barbarous act," he said, urging Taiwan's athletes and sports officials to help maintain national dignity.
During a telephone interview with CNA, Chin said when he asked the Chinese team staff why they had used violence against the Taiwanese children, a staff member told him, "We have no alternatives."
Chin said he had quoted the Chinese team member in his written protest to the Olympic organizing committee.

Another Taipei City government official quoted the Chinese team as "explaining" the incident had occurred because "the United Nations recognizes the People's Republic of China as the only legal representative of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: 57% SKEPTICAL ABOUT KMT ASSET REPORT: DPP POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of respondents in an opinion survey are skeptical about the veracity of a party asset report released by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Sunday.

Lo Cheng-fang, deputy chief executive of the DPP's policy coordination committee, made the remarks at a seminar on issues related to rectifying past injustices and huge party assets believed to have been illegally or improperly amassed by the KMT during its 55-year rule of Taiwan ending in May 2000.
The DPP conducted the survey from Aug. 21-22 on randomly chosen adults. A total of 1,073 valid samples were collected, with a margin of error of 3 percent.
Nearly 57 percent said they were skeptical about the contents of a KMT asset report released earlier this month, which claims the party's assets now stand at NT$27.7 billion.
Only 20.7 percent said they thought the KMT asset report was convincing, Lo said, adding that even among the KMT's traditional supporters, skeptics slightly outnumbered proponents.

More than 60 percent said they disagreed with the KMT's piecemeal sale of its estates and other assets, and up to 78 percent said the KMT should return its ill-gotten party assets to the nation's coffers.
Lo noted the KMT and its "pan-blue" ally the People First Party have blocked a bill aimed at regulating political party assets from being added to the legislative agenda on a total of 77 occasions.

Against this backdrop, Lo said the DPP has decided to give priority to pushing for early completion of the long-overdue ill-gotten party assets treatment legislation during the new legislative session set to begin in mid-September.
To force the KMT to return its ill-gotten party assets to the nation and the people, Lo said the DPP cannot but initiate a national referendum on the issue.

A DPP-led alliance to realize that end will be formed Sept. 4, Lo said, adding that the alliance will present a proposal to the Executive Yuan to push for the initiation of a referendum on the issue. The alliance hopes to collect endorsement from 830,000 citizens to qualify for holding a referendum in 2007, he added.

Speaking at the same occasion, Deputy Finance Minister Lee Jui-chang said the KMT should unveil a comprehensive report detailing its party assets, liabilities and working capitals to shed light on changes and flows of its wealth since it moved its seat to Taiwan.

According to Lee, the KMT was not as sinsere and honest as it claimed in releasing its asset report. The KMT just answered part of questions previously posed by the watchdog Control Yuan and the National Property Bureau under the Ministry of Finance, Lee noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOLUNTEERS PREPARE TO KEEP THE PEACE IN CAMPAIGN TO DEPOSE CHEN

TEXT.P: More than 100 volunteer peacekeepers braved heavy rain Sunday afternoon to take part in simulated clashes between riot police and protesters during the forthcoming round-the-clock sit-in aimed at driving scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian out of office.

Conspicuous among the the peacekeepers were a number of Buddhist nuns, who volunteered to help maintain peace and order during the sit-in, which begins in early September in front of the Presidential Office on Ketagalan Boulevard.

They acknowledged to reporters that they wanted to help the campaign to depose Chen because they were "disgruntled with the corruption in the Democratic Progressive Party [DPP] government and because it lacks the ability for self-examination."

In a nearly one-hour drill, the volunteer peacekeepers practiced how to join hands and form a human shield separating protesters from challengers trying to provoke a fight, as well as how to react if police use water cannons in an attempt to disperse demonstrators.

Wang Li-ping, chief coordinator of the campaign of "one million to oust President Chen," estimated that some 200,000 protesters will join the sit-in on weekends, and is expected to draw between 8,000 and 10,000 people on weekdays.
A spokeswoman for the campaign indicated earlier Sunday the sit-in is expected to formally begin no later than Sept. 9.
Former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who initiated the campaign, has vowed that he and his supporters will not cease their sit-in until the president agrees to step down.

According to an unofficial count kept by television commentators, the embattled president, his family and senior aides are embroiled in 32 corruption and embezzlement scandals, some of which are being investigated by public prosecutors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLAG-SEIZING BEIJING OFFICIALS PETTY-MINDED: TAIPEI OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The "petty-minded" act of Chinese delegation officials who seized Republic of China national flags from teen-aged Taiwan athletes at the International Children's Games (ICG) in Thailand has damaged sportsmanship and demonstrated their rudeness and barbarity, Deputy Taipei Mayor Chin Fu-tsung said Sunday.
Chin made his remarks upon arriving back from Bangkok, Thailand where he witnessed Chinese team officials seizing the national flags from Taiwan athletes preparing to accept medals.
After he protested with games organizers, they decided that all winners must not carry their national flags when they receive medals.
Chin said the ICG charter does not prohibit winners from draping their national flags around their shoulders when they step on the podium to accept medals.

The Chinese officials' small-minded behavior on the international occasion was disgusting as it served only to spoil the peaceful atmosphere in which teen-agers from different countries and cultural backgrounds were making friends with each other by competing in sports events, he said.

Taiwan's young athletes, who had won four golds, one silver and two bronzes, were not affected by the unhappy incident as they continued to have pleasant exchanges with athletes from other countries, he reported.
He estimated that Taiwan athletes could win two more gold medals at the games Monday. The games are held for people aged between 13 and 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRAVEL GROUP FORMED TO PAVE WAY FOR TOURIST OPENING

TEXT.P: The long way toward the goal of allowing Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan took a crucial step forward Sunday with the creation of a quasi-official travel association to handle relevant negotiations with China.

The new organization -- the Taiwan Strait Tourism Association (TSTA) -- will be in charge of talks with its Chinese counterpart -- the Baijing-based China Tourism Association -- on technical details regarding Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists.
The TSTA will have a paid-in capital of NT$1 million, with the government contributing NT$500,000 and five major travel services associations investing NT$100,000 each.

A donors meeting was held Sunday, during which nine board directors were elected, with four from government agencies and five from the private sector. The board members then elected from among themselves Hsu Wen-sheng, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, to concurrently serve as TSTA chairman of the board.

All of the four board directors representing the government are officials in charge of tourism and travel matters -- Hsu, Tourism Bureau Deputy Director Lai Se-chen, Wu Chao-yen, a Tourism Bureau division chief, and Wu Hsueh-yen, deputy director of the Immigration Bureau under the National Police Agency.
No official from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , which charts Taiwan's policy on China affairs, will seat on the TSTA board of directors.

Hsu said after the donors' meeting that the new organization, to be housed in the Tourism Bureau building, will be formally inaugurated after completing registration with the Ministry of the Interior in the near future.

"The TSTA will contact its Chinese counterpart immediately after its inauguration on the schedule for bilateral negotiations on the tourist opening measures, " Hsu said, adding that the chief delegate to the talks will be determined depending on the topics to be addressed.

Hsu said he personally hopes that all relevant talks can be finalized by the end of this year. He was quoted as having said previously that the first-round talks could start in mid-September and his deputy Lai Se-chen may represent Taiwna in the talks. But the MAC later denied such reports, stressing that the timing and the chief delegate for the tourism opening talks have yet to be decided.
Hsu said the new association will be responsible for tourist exhcnage talks only and is not authorized to touch on issues regarding the opening of direct cross-strait charter flights.
As China refuses any official contact with Taiwan, the two sides have to set up quasi-official travel associations to negotiate and manage the issue.

Meanwhile, the ROC Travel Agent Association (TAA), which has been responsible for laying the groundwork for tourist opening, said it has completed its "trailblazing" function. Hereafter, the association said, it will play a supporting role, taking charge of delivering travel papers, allocation of travel quotas, management of the absconding prevention deposits and discipline of travel agents. The TAA head is among the five TSTA board directors representing the private travel sector.

According to Taiwan's plan, a maximum of 1,000 Chinese tourists will be allowed to enter Taiwan per day for a maximum 10-day stay. Chinese tourists are required to "enter and leave in group, " and the host Taiwan travel agency will be fined NT$200,000 for each absconded Chinese tourist.

To ensure travel quality, travel agencies must sign up a discupline agreement. Any travel agency that violates the minimum daily travel expenses of US$80-to-US$100 will have its tourist quota allocation suspended for one month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET WILL UNVEIL PROGRAMS TO BOOST INVESTMENT, RID POVERTY

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will espouse new "flagship initiatives" in mid-September to boost domestic investment and eliminate poverty, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said Sunday.

Cheng said the "flagship initiatives" are formulated to realize four major policy goals outlined by President Chen Shui-bian at the government-sponsored conference on sustaining Taiwan's economic development held in last July that called for increased investment in Taiwan, creating more jobs, bridging urban-rural gaps and promoting equitable distribution of wealth.

Over the past three days, Cheng said, Premier Su Tseng-chang has been briefed on highlights of the "flagship initiatives" proposed by all relevant government agencies and presented his opinions on various proposals and options.

The "flagship initiatives" will be publicized after amendments and improvements on certain points, Cheng said, adding that the Council for Economic Planning and Development document the final versions of various initiatives.

According to Cheng, the initiatives in the pipeline comprise a total of 47 programs in five packages. The Cabinet will choose the most feasible, most urgent or most likely to be brought to fruition to form "flagship initiatives" for implementation in the next three years.
Between 2007 and 2009, Cheng said, the "flagship initiatives" will focus on industrial development, financial market reform, talent pool cultivation, infrastructure construction and social welfare.

In addition to boosting domestic investment, Cheng said, priority tasks in the "flagship initiatives" will also include measures to offer financial aid for those are not qualified for low-income family subsidy at present, also known as "near poverty, " or those who just lost jobs and were caught in financial straits.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO DO MORE TO HELP FOREIGN SPOUSES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian promised Sunday to have relevant government agencies study the feasibility of easing financial requirements for foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens intending to acquire ROC citizenship.

Chen made the promise while visiting a community development association in th southern Pingtung County that is dedicated to helping foreign spouses adapt to Taiwan's customs and lifestyle, including handicraft training, Chinese language study, and counseling on daily life and child rearing.

During the visit, some foreign spouses complained that they have become disadvantaged groups after coming to Taiwan by marriage. For one thing, they said they have to wait for a long period of time -- eight years for those from China and three years for those from Southeast Asian countries -- to get citizenship. Moreover, they have to produce financial statements proving they have a deposit of at least NT$400,000.

In response, Chen said all countries, including the United States, impose certain restrictions and requirements on naturalization. But he promised to ask relevant government agencies to do their utmost to offer better welfare services for foreign spouses. If possible, he said, the government will lower financial requirements for foreign spouses in their pursuit of citizenship.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 28 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Monday, Aug. 28:
09:30, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang will attend the opening of an international seminar on eliminating all sorts of discrimination against women.
09:35, Vice President Annette Lu will visit the Miaoli County Government.
10:00, Government Information Office Director-General Cheng Wen-tsan will hold a news conference on Taiwan's U.N. bid.
11:30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURING SECTOR FACES DIRE LABOR SHORTAGE

TEXT.P: The manufacturing sector faced a severe labor shortage in the second quarter of this year because of a stronger-than-expected export boom, a government agency said Sunday.
The sector reported 82,000 job vacancies in the April-June period, a new high in four years, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said.
