DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 28, or the fifth day of the leap seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn, near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1849: Venice surrenders to the Australians, having been under siege since July 20 after proclaiming independence from Austrian rule.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949 , is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for Psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang (KMT) branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by US Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold a meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues as national unity.
1963: US civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration in favor of furthering the cause of civil rights.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1974: The Republic of China and Thailand conclude a maize trade agreement.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Bolivian Vice Foreign Minister Hernando Garcia Vespa and his wife.
1980: Premier Y.S. Sun leaves for Costa Rica, Panama and the Dominican Republic for official visits.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during an exhibition in front of a crowd of 300,000 at the US Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party, is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang convenes the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's nominees for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt -- sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGNITUDE 6.1 QUAKE SHAKES EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A magnitude 6.1 earthquake rattled the northeastern county of Yilan in the early morning hours Monday, with no immediate reports of damage or injuries, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
The earthquake was centered 130.9 km off the coastal city of Suao, at a depth of 118.9 km below the surface of the sea, the weather bureau said. Suao is located about 120 km southeast of Taipei City.
The quake had an intensity of 3.0 in Nanao, Yilan County and in Hualien City and Yienliao in the eastern country of Hualien.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA REPRESENTS ONLY OBSTACLE TO TAIWAN'S U.N. ENTRY: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Huang Jaw-pyng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: China has been the only obstacle blocking Taiwan from becoming a member of the United Nations and from expanding its relations with the international community, a Taiwan diplomat posted in New York said Sunday.

Taiwan, however, has not been daunted by China's diplomatic suppression and has always believed that if a consensus is reached in the international community on Taiwan's cause, then the country's bid to join the U.N. will be successful, said Andrew Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York.
Hsia made the remarks in a speech to a gathering of Taiwan community leaders in the greater New York area hosted by the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace.

Taiwan's bid to enter the U.N., which has failed each year since 1993, has, however, drawn increasing attention from the international community, Hsia said, adding that Taiwan will submit two proposals this year as it did last year.

In its failed bid in 2005, Taiwan called for the U.N. to help maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait and for the international body to pay attention to the representation of Taiwan's 23 million people at the United Nations.

Citing recent public opinion polls as indicating that some 70 percent of the Taiwan people are in favor of the government bidding to gain U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan," Hsia said he will press with this bid, using whatever name determined by the Taipei authorities.
Taiwan has used the title "the Republic of China" in its U.N. bids for the past 13 years. All attempts have failed due to the intervention and opposition of Beijing.

The ROC has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971, when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the China seat to Beijing at Taiwan's expense. While Resolution No. 2758 resolved the issue regarding China's U.N. representation, it did not address the representation of Taiwan's people.
Hsia said Taiwan is a sovereign state which has the right to ask that the United Nations face squarely the fact of Taiwan's existence and the basic rights of its people.

"In terms of the principle of universality prescribed in the U.N. charter, the U.N. cannot ignore the issue regarding peace in the Taiwan Strait as well as the voice of the Taiwan people, " he asserted.

Hsia, who has been playing a major role as Taiwan's voice in its U.N. bid, is scheduled to be interviewed on the "Asian America" program on the N.Y. television station WNYE-TV Monday to talk about the progress of Taiwan's "U.N. movement."

DOC.HEADLINE: F-5F FIGHTER BELLY-LANDS IN TAITUNG

TEXT.P: An Air Force F-5F fighter plane made an belly landing Monday morning after it developed problems with its landing gear upon its return to the Chihhang air base in Taitung, eastern Taiwan.
Neither the pilot nor co-pilot were injured in the incident, Air Force officials said.
The officials said the dual-seat fighter plane ran into problems while heading back to the base at 9: 05 a.m. after completing a routine training flight.
A team comprised of experts from the base and flight safety organizations has begun an investigation into the cause of the incident, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO VISIT ALLIES IN SOUTH PACIFIC AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday that Taiwan's diplomatic allies in South Pacific have not caved in to Chinese pressure and that President Chen Shui-bian will visit two of the allies in the region Sept. 3-6 as scheduled.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks while attending a news conference held by the Government Information Office on the publicity drive of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.

Lu was responding to reports that quoted diplomatic sources as saying that with China actively soliciting Taiwan's allies in the South Pacific, the ministry has been watching the situation closely to avoid a repetition of Chad incident, referring to Taiwan's severance of diplomatic ties with Chad on the eve of Premier Su Tseng-chang's scheduled visit in early August after learning that the African country was about to establish diplomatic ties with China.

Lu noted that Taiwan's six allies in the South Pacific have not caved in as the report said and that the president will depart as scheduled on Sept. 3 for Palau for a summit meeting with the heads of state of the allies the next day.
The president will then proceed to Nauru Sept. 5 before returning to Taiwan Sept. 6, he said.
However, Lu also urged the public not to expect goodwill from China, especially in the diplomatic arena.
China has always been relentless in scuttling Taiwan's relations with its allies, Lu said, adding that the ministry will do everything possible to try to cement its relations with its allies.

Asked which of Taiwan's South Pacific diplomatic allies Beijing has been targeting, Lu said China's obstruction efforts have not been confined to the South Pacific alone and have been directed at all of Taiwan's 24 allies around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO OPEN SECOND DISASTER RELIEF CENTER

TEXT.P: Taipei City's second disaster prevention and relief center will begin operations by the end of the month, city officials said Monday.

It will be Taiwan's first disaster prevention center serving as a "backup" facility which is capable of taking over operations of the the Taipei City Fire Department's relief command headquarters in the event that the latter fails in efforts to deal with a disaster, such as an earthquake or epidemic, and to prevent it from expanding.

The new facility can replace existing relief-oriented systems and integrate all available resources to carry out emergency rescue and disaster relief missions in the shortest possible period of time, the officials said.

Construction of the new disaster prevention center, situated on Chengchou Road, began in October 2001. The total cost of construction of the 10-story building exceeded NT$170 million (US$5.16 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEPPING UP EFFORTS TO WOO TAIWAN YOUTH: MAC

TEXT.P: China has stepped up its efforts to win the hearts and minds of Taiwanese youth, Huang Wei-feng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Monday.
Huang said China regards Taiwan youths as a major factor in dictating the island's future direction, and it has therefore made "wooing Taiwan youths" as one of its major tasks.

He noted that Beijing authorities have stepped up their efforts through various channels over the past several years. They have used China's emerging economic power to offer subsidies in hosting Taiwan students visiting the country for various exchanges with their mainland counterparts, he said.

The exchange activities have included visits to scenic spots, famous universities and the hometowns of the Taiwan youths' ancestors, as well as activities related to the 2008 Olympic Games, Huang said.
"China hopes to lure Taiwan students to study in China and to promote a sense of identification with China among Taiwan students, " he pointed out.
He said that China has a series of policies, such as promoting exchanges, recruiting Taiwan students and providing job opportunities, that have a long-term political aim.

He noted that several thousand Taiwan youths have visited China to take part in such exchange programs this summer, and the sponsors have covered civic groups affiliated with the Communist Party of China and the Chinese government.
"This shows that China has mobilized every organization to promote its efforts to woo Taiwan youths," Huang added.

Faced with China's systematic offensive targeting Taiwan youths, Huang said Taiwan will address the question by nurturing the concept of Taiwan's separate identity from China through its educational system.

"Taiwan will also encourage more Chinese students to come to Taiwan for exchanges so that they will learn more about the island's academic freedom, political democratization and pluralistic society," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S GROUP CALLS FOR TAIWAN BID TO JOIN U.N. CEDAW

TEXT.P: Taiwan should strive to join the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) adopted in 1979 by the U.N. General Assembly, a women's group said Monday.

It's a pity that Taiwan -- which boasts the highest gender development index (GDI) in Asia and ranks high in the world in terms of gender empowerment measure (GEM) -- has not joined CEDAW, which has been signed by national women's groups from 183 countries around the world, said Chen Man-li, chairwoman of the National Union of Taiwan Women's Associations (NUTWA).
Chen urged the government to enable Taiwan's women as a whole to join the CEDAW as a state party in the convention, which is often described as an international bill of rights for women.

She said that although Taiwan has formidable political barriers to cross to accede to a U.N. organization, it is the government's duty to enable Taiwan to ratify CEDAW, which accepts non-U.N. member countries in a category known as "state parties."
Chen made the call during a NUTWA-sponsored international workshop on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.

Also speaking at the workshop, Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said that although Taiwan's accession to CEDAW might also be obstructed by Beijing, it is the right of the Taiwan people to voice their expectations to the international community.
Lee said it is the administration's responsibility to enable NUTWA to accede to CEDAW to reflect the people's basic rights.
He promised that until CEDAW accession is achieved, the Ministry of the Interior will strive to eliminate all forms of discrimination against Taiwan's women in accordance with the CEDAW criteria.

During the two-day CEDAW workshop, several experts from abroad, including Denise Scotto, vice chairwoman of the NGO Committee on the Status of Women, and Nancy E. Wallance, an expert in international advocacy in mental health, will share their experiences in promoting CEDAW efforts with their Taiwan audience, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S GROUP TO PUSH FOR TAIWAN'S INCLUSION IN U.N. CONVENTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's devotion and success in promoting women's rights is obvious, and this is why Taiwan should be accepted as a party to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) , a women's group said Monday.

Taiwan ranks in the top 30 among 177 countries in two of the most important women's rights indexes -- 24th in the Gender Development Index (GDI) and 19th in the Gender Empowerment Measure (GEM) , said Mary Chen, chairwoman of National Alliance of Taiwan Women's Associations (NATWA).
"The success and hard work has been ignored as Taiwan is not yet a member state of CEDAW, which has been signed by 183 countries, because of political factors," Chen said.

Taiwan's government has made its move. Premier Su Tseng-tsang approved a proposal for Taiwan to seek to join the CEDAW in July, and the proposal will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan in the next session for ratification, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang has said.

According to a NATWA release, the CEDAW is one of three U.N. conventions that accept non-U.N. members, which means it's possible for Taiwan to become a party of the convention barring political interference by China.

Taiwan's ratification of the convention, in the meantime, shows that the government has the ability and determination to fulfill its duties in the international community -- even if it is not a U.N. member yet, Lee said.

The CEDAW, adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1979, is often described as an international bill of rights for women. The convention defines what constitutes discrimination against women and sets up an agenda for national action to end such discrimination.

To promote understanding of the convention, NATWA is conducting a two-day international conference from Aug. 28-29. Denise Scotto, vice chairwoman of the U.N.'s NGOCSW (Committee of the Status on Women) , and Nancy Wallace, main representative of World Federation for Mental Health at the U.N. headquarters, have been invited as speakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CHIEF, PROSECUTORS CHARGED WITH DESTROYING EVIDENCE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) filed a lawsuit against National Police Agency (NPA) Director-General Hou You-yi and three Tainan prosecutors Monday, charging them with dereliction of duty and destroying evidence in connection with the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

Tsai Chin-lung, caucus secretary-general, said the charges were based on a report of the legislature's special committee investigating the shooting, a case that the government had closed after blaming it on a lone alleged shooter named Chen Yi-hsiung.

Chen was found dead 10 days after the incident in Tainan, the city where the incident took place. His family has raised questions concerning his death and has accused police investigators of forcing them to give false testimonies.

Lawyer Sun Yu-hui, acting on behalf of the KMT caucus, quoted the special committee's report, which was published Aug. 22, as raising four major points of suspicion concerning the police probe and prosecution of the case:

-- The National Security Bureau (NSB) on March 18, 2004 had information that an attempt to assassinate the president might be in the offing, information that security officers like Hou knew and yet failed to pursue.

-- The bullets found in the jeep in which the president and the vice president were shot at and those found at Chi Mei Hospital where the two were treated were of different caliber and therefore could not be determined to have been fired from the same pistol.

-- The pants and underwear that the president wore on that day did not have any gunshot holes or bloodstains, but Hou and the investigators he led ignored and hid this critical piece of evidence, a move that can be seen as "misleading the direction" of the investigation.

-- Hou and his investigative team deliberately adopted the strategy of using the bullets to trace the gun and using the gun to trace its owner, without ever attempting to find evidence to prove that the shooting could have been a "self-directed" drama, concluding that Chen Yi-hsiung was the only suspect and closing the case based on this sloppy conclusion.
In fact, Sun quoted the report as pointing out, many questions remain with regard to Chen's death, further indicating that Hou and his team did not try to seek the truth about the shooting.
Hou at the time was the criminal police chief. He was later promoted to his current position.
Also being sued are Tainan District Prosecutor's Office Chief Prosecutor Liu Wei-tzung, as well as prosecutors Wang Sen-jung and Kuo Chen-ni, who was spokeswoman for the special investigative team.

Sun said these four officials are suspected of having committed the offenses of malfeasance and destroying evidence. Under the criminal code, they could be sentenced heavily if found guilty, Sun added.
Hou would not respond to the accusation except to say he had asked the Criminal Investigation Bureau to give "professional" answers to the legislative committee's questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: `RESPECT' KEY WORD IN GENDER EQUITY: WOMEN'S RIGHTS ADVOCATE

TEXT.P: Regulation of the law is the last line of defense in terms of gender equity and respect is the key word in solving issues like sexual crime, sexual harassment and employment discrimination, a women's rights advocate said Monday.

"In that sense, gender equity education may be the most important task for us, although women also need the protection of the law at all times, " said Ku Yen-lin, Director of the Taipei Public Service Institute, on the sidelines of an international conference of U.N. Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW.)

Since the establishment of the Committee for Promotion of Women's Rights under the Executive Yuan in 1997, Yen said, the passage of bills such as the Sexual Harassment Prevention Law, Sexual Crime Law, Domestic Violence Prevention Law and Gender Equity Education Act has provided more protection than before for women.
But those bills focus on details and punishments, she said.

"Do we really need a law to tell us which parts of a woman's body a man can and cannot touch or what a man should and should not say to a woman? " she asked, adding that there have been many problems regarding the implementation of the laws.
Integration of the law should be done as well, Yen said. For example, it is sometimes confusing that the issue of sexual harassment is regulated by three different bills.
"Government policy should be goal-oriented and priorities should be established, " she said, adding that the protection of "new immigrant women" is also an urgent task.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA 'SERIOUSLY CONSIDERING' U.N. BID UNDER NAME OF 'TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is "seriously considering" pushing for Taiwan's entry into the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan, " a MOFA spokesman said Monday.

Responding to a reporter's question at a news conference as to whether Taiwan is bidding to gain U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan" this year, Michel Lu, the MOFA secretary-general who doubles as spokesman, said using "Taiwan" as the representing title is one of the options in this effort.

Lu added that this "Taiwan option" was proposed by MOFA after conducting strenuous discussions with academics and U.N. representatives of Taiwan's allies and has been approved by the Executive Yuan for implementation.
Cheng Wen-tsang, Executive Yuan spokesman, claimed at the news conference that Taiwan and its people have been known as "Taiwan" and "nothing else" in the international community for decades.
Promoting Taiwan's U.N. bid under the title of "Taiwan" -- an effort only made in the most recent several years -- is the only way to reflect the representation of Taiwan's people, Cheng said.
Taiwan has used the title "the Republic of China" in its U.N. bids for the past 13 years and all attempts at entry have failed due to the intervention and opposition of Beijing.

The ROC has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971, when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the China seat to Beijing at Taiwan's expense. While Resolution No. 2758 resolved the issue regarding China's U.N. representation, it did not address the representation of Taiwan's people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES CLOSE LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 81.46 points to close at 6,444.76.

The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,515.08 and dipped to the day's low of 6,422.38 during trading. A total of 2.3 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$51.03 billion (US$1.55 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 3.8 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 2.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.4 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.1 percent, cement stocks at 0.9 percent, textile stocks at 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 963 to 121, with 93 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER WANTS 'MEANS WITHIN INSTITUTION' FOR OUSTING PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reiterated Monday his opposition to a campaign launched by Shih Ming-teh, a former DPP chairman, to depose President Chen Shui-bian.

DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung was referring to an imminent mass sit-in on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office to pressure the embattled president to resign over a spate of corruption and embezzlement allegations implicating himself, his family members and senior aides.
Lee noted at a news conference in the Legislative Yuan that there are ways within the institution to oust the president so that a democracy will not fall prey to frenzied passion.

Lee noted that democracy relies on regular elections and that only such institutional means as a recall or impeachment can force the president to step down, adding that the design of such is to ensure the stability of constitutional democracy.
"Only when constitutional or legal means cannot function is it necessary to use channels outside the institution," he said.

Chen survived an opposition-initiated recall vote in the legislature June 27 because it failed to gather the endorsement of two-thirds of the legislators to put it to a national referendum. Opposition parties have complained that the threshold for recalling a president is too high, noting that Chen won the 2004 presidential election by only slightly more than 50 percent of the votes.
Lee continued that when the "anti-Chen" sentiment is gathering momentum to the level of being big enough to unsettle, if not unseat, Chen, it is very likely that serious confrontation will erupt.
On grounds of constitutional provisions and social price, Lee said he is opposed to Shih's "depose Chen" campaign.

But he also said that instead of attacking Shih, as some DPP politicians have done, the DPP's best response to Shih's drive would be to remain quiet so that society will see that the DPP has begun genuine self-reflection. The party's popularity has plummeted following a series of high-profile corruption cases that came to light early this year.
Lee also said that as a ruling party, it should provide the maximum convenience for the participants for the mass sit-in so that it can end peacefully without confrontation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE DROPS TO NEW LOW: SURVEY

TEXT.P: August's consumer confidence dropped to the lowest level since December 2001, with the confidence in the economic prospects for the next six months suffering the greatest loss from the previous month, according to the results of a survey released Monday.
The consumer confidence index (CCI) fell to 67.67 in August, a drop of 0.26 from July, according to the Research Center for Taiwan Economic Development of the National Central University.
Of the six major indicators, it said, only the interest to buy durable goods over the next six months rose slightly, by 0.3 points, to 117.30 from last month, while all other indicators fell.
The confidence in the next half-year's economic prospects fell 0.7 from July to 52.05 points, the biggest retreat, which was followed by confidence in employment, which dropped 0.65 points to 74.95.

The indicator of the coming six months' family economic situation went down 0.3 points to 55, while that of domestic consumer prices was down 0.15 points to 39.4. Consumer confidence in the stock market declined 0.1 points to 67.3 points.
Of the six indicators, those on the family economy and domestic consumer prices fell to the lowest levels since January 2001, when the center began the monthly survey.

The CCI index and the indicator on the economic prospects were the lowest since December 2001, an indication that the public is not confident in the nation's economic prospect while international oil and commodity prices remain high.
The survey was conducted Aug. 18-21 among 2,689 people aged 20 or above around the country, with a margin of error of 1.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRONG TYPHOON IOKE FORMED IN PACIFIC

TEXT.P: Strong typhoon Ioke, the twelfth to form in the Pacific this year, began formed in the eastern Pacific Monday, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
Centered about 1,300 km northeast of Wake island, the bureau said Ioke was moving west at 16 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of 190 kph.
As it was still 6,000 km from Taiwan, the bureau said it was difficult to predict whether it will affect the island, although forecasters will keep a close eye on its movement.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES TAKE TODDLER AWAY FROM FATHER WHO LEFT HER ALONE

TEXT.P: Social welfare officials in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan took a toddler away from a single father Monday who left her at home alone.
The two-year-old was taken in by a foster family, officials said.

The girl's father, identified only by his family name of Chen, will be allowed to visit her daughter weekly but will only be allowed to take her home again after he is capable of taking good care of her, the officials said.

The toddler was found living in a second-floor apartment with her father, who is a truck driver and spends most of his time working. He supplied food and water to his daughter using a crude pulley arrangement when he happened to pass by.

The father said he used the pulley arrangement because he was "too busy" to enter the apartment and if he went in, his daughter "would not let him out again." The toddler's plight was discovered Sunday by a neighbor who heard the girl crying incessantly in the apartment and called the police, who entered the apartment and found the child in a state of hunger.
The man claimed to be unable to afford to pay for a baby sitter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 87 points to close at 6,402, with 38,685 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October decreased 86 points to finish at 6,405, with 311 contracts traded, while December futures decreased 83 points to end at 6,409, with 21 contract transactions.
March futures moved down 92 points to close at 6,399, with four contract transactions, while June futures decreased 88 points to end at 6,410, with one contract transaction.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,489 for September, 6,491 for October, 6,492 for December, 6,491 for March and 6,498 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

September TE futures moved down 4.3 points to close at 275.6, with 5,256 contracts traded, while October TE futures decreased 3.2 points to finish at 276.3, with 16 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

September TF futures lost 8.4 points to close at 880.8, with 1,292 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 13.2 points to finish at 878.8, with 12 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.030 to close at NT$32.918.
A total of US$881 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.918 and fluctuated between NT$32.898 and NT$32.959.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RESPECTS MEDIA AS '4TH ESTATE'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday she respects the media as the "fourth estate" in a democratic society, but added her hopes that Taiwan's media will stop being "mirrors of distortion" in which truth is distorted.

Speaking to the media after visiting Miaoli officials at the Miaoli county government's headquarters, Lu said she would not shut herself away from dailies and television since she is very concerned about things happening at home and abroad.

Nevertheless, she called for the media not to downgrade themselves into "mirrors of distortion" or "magic mirrors, " in which no truth is reflected and she urged the media to exercise self-discipline when reporting news to truly reflect society and people's mindsets.

When asked about former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh's initiation of a "1 million people campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian " to be staged early next month, Lu said she hopes Shih will take other more rational paths to make known his desire for Chen to resign.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOAX BOMB FOUND OUTSIDE 'DEPOSE CHEN' HEADQUARTERS

TEXT.P: A spokeswoman for a campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the campaigners will not be "intimidated" after a device they suspected might be a bomb was found outside the campaign headquarters in downtown Taipei.

He Teh-feng said the staff of the headquarters found a black computer bag outside the headquarters and reported it to the police as suspicious. Police later confirmed that the bag contained no suspicious substances.

The spokeswoman claimed that the placing of an unidentified object outside the headquarters was aimed at obstructing the campaign's upcoming sit-in in front of the Presidential Office to pressure President Chen to resign over a spate of corruption and embezzlement allegations implicating himself, his family members and senior aides.
The act was also aimed at creating the possibility of violent clashes, according to the spokeswoman. Shih has repeatedly said that the sit-in will be peaceful.
Meanwhile, a DPP official questioned the incident, saying it could have been "staged" by Shih's headquarters.

Tsai Huang-liang, deputy secretary-general of the DPP, said a "forgotten bag" had been exaggerated to the point of being a suspected explosive device. The calling out of a police bomb squad by police and airing the incident on TV were a tremendous waste of money, he added.

Tsai alleged that Shih's headquarters had a two-fold purpose in staging the event -- to put the blame on the DPP to further smear the party and to build up momentum for the sit-in scheduled for Sept. 9.

Meanwhile, police questioned a man surnamed Tsai, who was identified via CCTV as the person who placed the object in the early hours of the morning, to find out his motives in placing the bag at the scene.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY FINDS GROWING PESSIMISM IN POLITICAL STABILITY

TEXT.P: A survey found that both political and economic confidence indexes have fallen for three months in a row, with public confidence in domestic political stability declining by a substantive margin, probably owing to high-level corruption scandals and campaigns to depose the president.

The Global View Monthly magazine published its August survey on the Taiwan Public Mood Index (TPMI) Monday, which showed that both the political confidence index (PCI) and the economic confidence index (ECI) have fallen for three consecutive months, to 36.3 and 31.5 respectively.

The PCI dropped 3.2 points from the previous month and the ECI shed 0.9 points for a composite TPMI fall of 2.1 points to 33.9 points, indicating that politics have played a greater role than economics in souring the public mood in Taiwan.

In terms of PCI, people's trust in the ruling party or Ruling Side Trust Index (RSTI) fell to 35.2 while political optimism index (POI) fell to 38.1, signifying the public's low confidence in the ruling party's performance.

The indicator on their expectations of next month's domestic political stability (or outlook index) declined 4.4 points to 26.1, as they turned increasingly pessimistic about Taiwan's political future.
In terms of ECI, the economic optimism index (EOI) of 37.4 is higher than the current economic situation index (CESI) of 25.6, but both remained in negative territory -- under 50.

The current personal finance index (34.2) is higher than the current domestic economy index (16.9) . Again, both are in the negative territory. And the personal financial improvement index (40.6) is higher than the domestic economic improvement index (34.1), as both received negative evaluations.
The magazine's survey research center interviewed 1004 people aged 20 or above across Taiwan Aug. 14-16, with a margin of error of 3.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION OFFICIAL EXPLAINS MEASURE OF DISSOLVING MINI SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) explained Monday a controversial measure to dissolve "mini elementary schools" -- schools with a total number of students less than 100 -- in order to increase class sizes, which ministry officials claimed are "more helpful" for interactive learning.
The explanation was made in a response to an article published in the September edition of the Global Views Monthly, a general-interest current affairs magazine.

The article, titled "My School Disappears; So Difficult to Have A School To Study, " revealed the results of a survey showing that since 1999, the government has dissolved more than 100 public elementary schools due to lack of students.
Because of the closures, some students are forced to travel long distances to another school, while some have to reside far from home to get an education, the article said.

The article claimed that abolishing mini schools not only affects the will of the students to learn, but also leads to a gradual disappearance of the culture of remote communities that have to send their children to bigger towns for schooling.

It will become more and more difficult for children living in remote areas to be well educated, the article claimed, urging the MOE to stop the measure which it claimed was formed to reduce spending and ease financial pressure on local governments.
Vice Minister of Education Wu Tsai-shun denied the reason for abolishing small primary schools is to save money.
Wu claimed that the measure was carried out based on the concern that young students need to have "interaction with classmates" and a stimulation of different cultures" to achieve better learning.

To the school kids who have to travel long to reach a school, the government offers accommodation and travel subsidies for children forced to go to school away from their homes and families, he added.
According to official statistics, there were 566 mini elementary schools in Taiwan in 2005. Students of these schools totalled 36,377, the tallies show.
The schools are faced with a destiny of disbandment under the MOE existing policy of breaking up mini schools.

The measure, however, will not apply to small schools that are the only ones in a town or village, the only ones serving indigenous populations, or ones located in areas where there are major travel problems, such as mudslide-prone areas, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE GROUPS SET UP VENTURE FUND TO SUPPORT SMALL SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: The Eden Social Welfare Foundation and Global Views Monthly magazine have jointly set up a venture capital fund to save "mini elementary schools" in Taiwan's remote areas from being dissolved because of financial difficulties.

The two private organizations announced Monday the establishment of a charitable venture fund aimed at generating at least NT$10 million -- an amount sufficient to support the operations of four to 10 small, remote primary schools, whose students number less than 100.
Yang Ma-li, editor-in-chief of the Taipei-based magazine, indicated that the bid to save the schools was triggered by the government's attempt to close them.

Under the measure, 35 elementary schools would no longer exist as of the new semester in September, Yang cited a magazine survey as saying, noting some schools would be directly dissolved and others downgraded into a branch facility of other schools.

Since 1999, 144 elementary schools have been disbanded because of the lack of students, Yang said, arguing the measure has "deprived children in remote areas of their right to an education" because "it is so difficult for them to go to school."

When their schools close, most students are forced to travel long distances to another school, while others must live far from home to pursue an education, according to an article published in the magazine's September edition.
As a result, some students whose schools are disbanded would rather give up schooling than leave home, said the article, entitled "My School Disappears; So Difficult to Have a School to Study."
Members of the public are urged to donate toward the fund to support the "mini schools."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Real Wages Fail to Match a Rise in Productivity
With the economy beginning to slow, the current expansion has a chance to become the first sustained period of economic growth since World War II that fails to offer a prolonged increase in real wages for most workers.
That situation is adding to fears among Republicans that the economy will hurt vulnerable incumbents in this year's midterm elections even though overall growth has been healthy for much of the last five years.
Wall Street Journal:Koizumi's Success Charts the Path To Japan's Future
Five years after he took over as prime minister of a moribund nation, Junichiro Koizumi is preparing to leave behind him a different Japan. An economic has-been that mourned its waning international influence has been transformed into a surprise revival story -- sprouting skyscrapers and shopping centers -- while becoming Washington's most reliable ally in Asia. Mr. Koizumi turned into one of the most influential leaders in modern Japanese history -- and his impact is likely to endure, because he created a template for future leaders for how to centralize power and influence public opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HOPES ANTI-CHEN CAMPAIGN CONCLUDES PEACEFULLY

TEXT.P: Government Information Minister Cheng Wen-tsan said Monday that regardless of who organizes a public rally, it should begin and end in peace and abide by the law.

Cheng was referring to former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who announced earlier in the day that his campaign to "depose" President Chen Shui-bian is being renamed as "one million people's anti-corruption action." The action is to begin Sept. 9, Shih said.
Shih said he was refraining from using the word "depose" for fear it might invoke a counter-campaign to "protect the president, " or lead to bloodshed.
Cheng said all marches and assemblies must be conducted within the boundaries of law, and that he hoped no participants would break the law or create social unrest.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO VISIT U.S. ONE DAY AFTER SIT-IN LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun is scheduled to embark on a visit to the United States Sept. 10, one day after a former DPP chairman launches a mass sit-in aimed at unseating President Chen Shui-bian, DPP Deputy Secretary General Tsai Huang-lang said Monday.

Yu has for a time considered canceling the visit because of uncertainties in Taiwan's political situation after former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh announced a campaign calling on 1 million people to "depose" scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian. Shih has since changed the name of his campaign to "one million people's anti-corruption action."
Yu will reach New York Sept. 10, proceed to Washington, D.C. and return to Taiwan from Los Angeles Sept. 16, according to the DPP.

Tsai said Yu will be the first senior ruling party official to visit Taiwan's most important ally this year and that the U.S. is curious about the DPP's views on politics in Taiwan, so Yu will try to present the ruling party's stance to his U.S. hosts.
Yu is expected to meet with U.S. Congressman Jim Leach and Senator Tim Johnson, among others, in addition to speaking to a think tank and journalists.
He is also expected to meet with overseas Taiwanese during his stay in the U.S., Tsai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CAMPAIGN TO DEPOSE PRESIDENT' TO BEGIN SIT-IN SEPT. 9

TEXT.P: A campaign to drive scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian out of office will begin a round-the-clock sit-in in front of the Presidential Office Sept. 9, a former leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced Monday.
Shih Ming-teh, who served as DPP chairman from 1994-1996 before leaving the party in 2000, said at an outdoor press conference that the sit-in will continue until Chen agrees to step down.

According to recent opinion surveys, the president's approval ratings have plunged to about 18 percent, mainly because Chen, his wife, son-in-law and senior aides have been embroiled in more than 30 corruption and embezzlement scandals, some of which have entered legal proceedings.
Shih noted that the campaign of "one million people to depose Chen" has already collected more than NT$110 million in only seven days, with more than 1 million people each donating NT$100 (US$3).
"The people of Taiwan have demonstrated their determination to fight against corruption; this will provide the force necessary to help Taiwan rebuild a clean government," he said.

Shih urged the campaign's supporters not to bring any national or party flags to the sit-in for fear they may distort the campaign's primary objectives: public opposition to corruption and calling for the president to step down.

He explained that the presence of such flags at the sit-in may give those in power grounds for leveling false accusations against the campaign by claiming the demonstration is a showdown between rival political parties or between pro-independence and pro-unification groups.

Commenting on verbal abuse and insults heaped upon him by DPP legislators and supporters, Shih said no such assaults would bring him down -- only make him more determined to carry on with the campaign.

The former DPP chairman, who was imprisoned twice between 1962 and 1989 -- for a total of 25 years under the Kuomintang's (KMT) previous authoritarian regime -- called on KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to not just sit idly by and wait for the campaign's labor to bear fruit, but to actively support it.

Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, and his police chiefs have the authority to approve or deny Shih's application to use Ketegalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office as the site of the sit-in.

In April 2004, Ma ordered police to disperse anti-Chen protesters from Ma's own party and the KMT's ally -- the People First Party -- because they had overstayed the allowed period of time. It is unclear whether he will do the same again this time toward Shih's campaign.

Shih and Ma appear to be on a collision course, as Shih has vowed repeatedly that his round-the-clock sit-in from Sept. 9 will persist until the president resigns, while local police authorities have only allowed campaign organizers to use the streets in front of the Presidential Office from 9 a.m. to 10 p.m. Sept. 12-15.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-SPEED RAIL TO HIRE 52 FOREIGN TRAIN CONDUCTORS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs gave permission to Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) Monday to hire 52 train conductors and 18 technical advisers from abroad for a period of no more than two years.

A CLA spokesman said the permission was granted after THSRC indicated in an application that it does not have enough locally trained conductors to operate the trains, now that the high-speed rail service is set to begin by the end of October.

The foreign train conductors will undergo a brief training enabling them to obtain a license from the Ministry of Transportation and Communication before they are authorized by the CLA to begin working.
THSRC has agreed to pay each conductor about NT$100,000 per month, well above the minimum monthly wage required by law of NT$48,000 for white-collar foreign workers.
The CLA spokesman pointed out that THSRC will be required to phase out foreign train conductors in two years as locally trained conductors take over the positions in stages.
He said the first group of Taiwanese train conductors are expected to complete training and receive licenses in eight months.
The 345-km railway linking Taipei and Kaohsiung will reduce travel time between Taiwan's two largest cities to about 90 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIT-IN CAMPAIGN AGAINST CHEN EXPECTS 200,000 ON FIRST DAY

TEXT.P: A campaign to oust scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian is expected to draw 200,000 supporters on the first day of a sit-in Sept. 9, according to the former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who initiated the campaign.

Shih Ming-teh, who served as DPP chairman between 1994-1996 before leaving the party in 2000, told reporters Monday that at the site of the sit-in -- facing the Presidential Office -- there will be only 2,300 seats, and that those who want to make sure they have a seat when they arrive should register through the campaign's Web site.
He said each supporter is allowed to reserve a seat for one hour.
Shih also said he is often asked why he will not allow the campaign to begin sooner, since more than 1 million people have already pledged support, totaling NT$110 million in donations.
"It takes time to organize supporters and turn them from a rabble of angry citizens into a regular army," he explained.

"The campaign will be doomed to failure if it depends merely on people's anger and hatred for corruption," he said, adding that internal organization is critical at present to delegate duties, including logistics, medical services, publicity and peacekeeping.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICG OFFICIALS RETURN ROC FLAGS TO TAIPEI DELEGATION
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Oscar Wu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Organizers of the International Children Games (ICG) returned two Republic of China flags to Taipei officials Monday that Chinese officials had seized from Taiwanese teen medalists prior to an award ceremony.
The organizers also apologized to Taipei participants for having failed to prevent such an uncivilized incident from occurring after lodging "private" complaints with Beijing sports officials.
Chinese sports officials had forcefully seized the ROC flags from Taiwanese athletes as they prepared to receive medals Saturday, triggering angry protests from Taipei City officials.
In Taipei, Government Information Minister Cheng Wen-tsan denounced China for its actions against the Taiwanese youths, claiming it showed China's lack of sportsmanship and democratic culture.

The ICG concluded Monday after four days of competitive events in which Taiwanese athletes won six gold medals, one silver and two bronze for an overall ranking of fifth, after Bangkok, Beijing, Seoul and Italy's Brescia.

DOC.HEADLINE: 52% FRET ANTI-CHEN SIT-IN COULD TURN VIOLENT: DPP POLL

TEXT.P: Proponents of an imminent round-the-clock mass sit-in to force President Chen Shui-bian to step down outnumber opponents, according to the results of an opinion poll released by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Monday.

The overwhelming majority of respondents said they would not take part in the planned sit-in on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office, with more than half worrying the event may turn violent.

The DPP conducted the telephone survey Aug. 21-22 to gauge public opinion on the unfolding "1 million to depose Chen" campaign spearheaded by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh. A total of 1,073 valid samples were collected with a margin of error of 3 percent.

According to poll results, 47.6 percent support Shih's campaign which called for a million people to each donate NT$100 to finance a sit-in in front of the Presidential Office scheduled to start Sept. 9 to push for Chen's resignation; 37.9 percent said they opposed such a movement.
An overwhelming 88 percent said they would not participate in the sit-in, with 11.7 percent saying they would.

Meanwhile, 52 percent were concerned that violent conflict might erupt between Chen supporters and detractors during the unprecedented round-the-clock, indefinite sit-in, but 44.6 percent said they didn't think such a scenario would become reality.

The poll also found that 50.3 percent deemed the Taipei city government's approval of a round-the-clock sit-in as "inappropriate," compared to 36.1 percent who gave a thumbs-up to the city government's decision.

As for the effects of the movement, only 7.1 percent believed the sit-in would successfully force Chen to resign over a spate of corruption allegations against members of his family and staff, while 77.5 percent said they thought otherwise.

An in-indepth analysis of poll results found 80 percent of DPP-led pan-green camp supporters do not support Shih's campaign. In contrast, 83 percent of the opposition Kuomintang-led "pan-blue" alliance members support Shih's cause.
"The figures are a bad omen of further deterioration, division and hostility between the two main political camps domestically, " said Chang Yi-fen, the DPP's public opinion research center.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST MODIFIED BOEING 747-400 LCF ROLLS OFF ASSEMBLY LINE

TEXT.P: Boeing Co. took delivery from Taiwan's Evergreen Group Monday of the first of three 747-400 Large Cargo Freighters (LCF), a plane modified to transport giant-sized Boeing 787 "Dreamliner" assemblages.

A rollout ceremony was held at a hangar of Evergreen Aviation Technologies Corp. (EGAT), an Evergreen subsidiary, at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to mark completion of the world's first modified Boeing 747-400 LCF.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei, Evergreen Chairman Chang Jung-fa and several other senior officials attended the ceremony.

The enormous airplane is the first of three specially converted jets that will be used to transport major assemblages back to the Boeing factory in Everett, Washington for final assembly of the all-new Boeing 787 "Dreamliner."
Speaking at the rollout ceremony, Scott Strode, a senior Boeing executive in charge of the 787 "Dreamliner" project, lauded EGAT staff for their highly efficient work.

"It's hard to believe it's been only 18 months since we announced that EGAT would modify this unique fleet of airplanes," Strode said. "This team has set a new standard for partnership, performance and achievement while working to a very aggressive schedule."
The specialized work began in 2005, with the three-aircraft conversion program slated for completion in 2007.
The LCF -- a modified Boeing 747-400 passenger aircraft -- can haul more cargo by volume than any other airplane in the world.
The LCF can carry loads three times larger than the original Boeing 747-400 freighter. (By Ada Tsai) edntiem/diG

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUG.29 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Aug. 298:

09: 30, Premier Su Tseng-chang and Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang will attend the citation ceremony for outstanding financial institutions for their achievements in lending to small- and medium-sized enterprises and maintaining market order.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO BE MORE PRAGMATIC TOWARD CROSS-STRAIT TRADE

TEXT.P: China should be more pragmatic toward commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait for mutual benefits, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Monday.

Su made the remarks while meeting with senior executives of the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT), who suggested that Taiwan further ease restrictions on cross-strait economic exchanges, including opening its market wider to Chinese products.

Noting that Taiwan is willing to hold trade consultations with China under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework to pave way for Taiwan's further opening to imports from China, Su said China has stubbornly refused to sit down to talks with Taiwan.

Moreover, Su said, China has continued to try to suppress Taiwan diplomatically, politically and economically. Against this backdrop, Su said the ROC government has been compelled to impose some restrictions on China-bound investments. "Our measures have not gone beyond normal limits, " he added.

Given the facts that China has deployed hundreds of missiles targeting Taiwan and that 70 percent of Taiwan's overseas investments is in China, Su said cannot afford to adopt a laissez -faire attitude toward China-bound investments.

During the meeting, ECCT executives questioned fairness of the ROC government's procurement bidding. Su said the government has consistently followed the "fair and reciprocal" principles in handling its major procurement projects.

ECCT Chairman Ralf Scheller said European countries are interested in Taiwan's service industry development and also intend to further expand their market shares in Taiwan and to expand into other neighboring Asian countries.
The two sides also exchanged views on implementation of Taiwan's WTO entry terms, perceived import barriers and upgrading of Taiwan's competitive edges in the financial service market.
Su directed the Council for Economic Planning and Development to keep close contact with the ECCT to boost mutual understanding and cooperation.

An overwhelming 88 percent said they would not participate in the sit-in, with 11.7 percent saying they would.

Meanwhile, 52 percent were concerned that violent conflict might erupt between Chen supporters and detractors during the unprecedented round-the-clock, indefinite sit-in, but 44.6 percent said they didn't think such a scenario would become reality.

The poll also found that 50.3 percent deemed the Taipei city government's approval of a round-the-clock sit-in as "inappropriate," compared to 36.1 percent who gave a thumbs-up to the city government's decision.

As for the effects of the movement, only 7.1 percent believed the sit-in would successfully force Chen to resign over a spate of corruption allegations against members of his family and staff, while 77.5 percent said they thought otherwise.

An in-indepth analysis of poll results found 80 percent of DPP-led pan-green camp supporters do not support Shih's campaign. In contrast, 83 percent of the opposition Kuomintang-led "pan-blue" alliance members support Shih's cause.
"The figures are a bad omen of further deterioration, division and hostility between the two main political camps domestically, " said Chang Yi-fen, the DPP's public opinion research center.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST MODIFIED BOEING 747-400 LCF ROLLS OFF ASSEMBLY LINE(repeat)

TEXT.P: Boeing Co. took delivery from Taiwan's Evergreen Group Monday of the first of three 747-400 Large Cargo Freighters (LCF), a plane modified to transport giant-sized Boeing 787 "Dreamliner" assemblages.

A rollout ceremony was held at a hangar of Evergreen Aviation Technologies Corp. (EGAT), an Evergreen subsidiary, at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to mark completion of the world's first modified Boeing 747-400 LCF.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei, Evergreen Chairman Chang Jung-fa and several other senior officials attended the ceremony.

The enormous airplane is the first of three specially converted jets that will be used to transport major assemblages back to the Boeing factory in Everett, Washington for final assembly of the all-new Boeing 787 "Dreamliner."
Speaking at the rollout ceremony, Scott Strode, a senior Boeing executive in charge of the 787 "Dreamliner" project, lauded EGAT staff for their highly efficient work.

"It's hard to believe it's been only 18 months since we announced that EGAT would modify this unique fleet of airplanes," Strode said. "This team has set a new standard for partnership, performance and achievement while working to a very aggressive schedule."
The specialized work began in 2005, with the three-aircraft conversion program slated for completion in 2007.
The LCF -- a modified Boeing 747-400 passenger aircraft -- can haul more cargo by volume than any other airplane in the world.
The LCF can carry loads three times larger than the original Boeing 747-400 freighter. (By Ada Tsai) edntiem/diG

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 800 MISSILES DEPLOYED BY CHINA AGAINST TAIWAN: MND REPORT

TEXT.P: China had deployed 784 Dongfeng-series short-range ballistic missiles against Taiwan as of the end of 2005, with the number increasing by between 75 and 100 every year, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said in its annual national defense report released Tuesday.
According to the report, the missiles are capable of reaching Taiwan proper about seven minutes after launch.

The MND estimates that China's military buildup has focused on upgrading the precision of its guided and cruise missiles so as to be able to make precise attacks on specific political and military targets in Taiwan.

The report noted that China has in recent years actively introduced advanced weaponry systems and technology, including Sukhoi high-performance fighters, AWAC planes, large transportation planes, Kilo-class submarines, and Sovremennyy-class destroyers.

These, coupled with upgraded ballistic and cruise missiles as well as domestically-designed weaponry systems, have gradually shifted the military balance in the Taiwan Strait in China's favor, the report said.

The report also estimated that if China launches an attack on Taiwan in or around the year 2008, it will probably use intimidation strategy. Between 2008 and 2010, if the military balance in the Taiwan Strait continues to tilt toward China, then it will be favorable for China to combine "intimidation, paralysis and invasion" strategies together, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 35.15 points to close at 6,479.91.
The bourse opened at 6,485.98 and fluctuated between 6,500.89 and 6,460.67 during trading. A total of 2.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$51.83 billion (US$1.57 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down 0.9 percent and textile stocks decreasing 0.1 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 635 to 366, with 182 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post: The President and His Critics Mark Anniversary Along Coast; A year after Hurricane Katrina devastated Mississippi and Louisiana, President Bush and Democratic leaders are converging on the Gulf Coast this week to commemorate the losses while continuing the political argument over the federal response to the country's largest natural disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S TRANSIT ARRANGEMENTS UNDER NEGOTIATION: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is still negotiating with the "concerned party" on details related to President Chen Shui-bian's stopover plan for his upcoming South Pacific visit, a ministry official said Tuesday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that the ministry is arranging for the president's stopover plan according to the principles of "safety, comfort, convenience and dignity" and that the negotiations with the "concerned party" are expected to be completed by the end of this week.
However, Lu would not confirm whether the "concerned party" is the United States.
Chen is scheduled to depart Sept. 3 for Palau to attend a leader summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the South Pacific before heading on to Nauru for a visit.

While the president reportedly is planning to make a transit stop in the U.S. territory of Guam on his way home, the MOFA has not openly confirmed such a plan on the grounds that related arrangements have yet to be ironed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD FORCES DISPERSE CHINESE BOATS DURING 'YUNG HO' MISSION

TEXT.P: Taiwan coast guard forces launched a crackdown on intruding Chinese fishing vessels Tuesday in waters off the Taiwan-controlled outlying island of Kinmen in an effort to safeguard Taiwan's territorial waters and protect Taiwan fishermen's rights and interests.

The move was part of a 12-hour mission, code named "Yung Ho, " launched by the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Monday evening in cooperation with Kinmen military police and regular police forces, as well as Kinmen county fishery authorities.

The CGA dispatched an 1,800-ton frigate and four coast patrol boats to carry out the mission aimed at clearing seas off Kinmen's coast as part of efforts to safeguard national security, with Cheng Chang-hsiung, director-general of the CGA Maritime Patrol Directorate General, named to supervise the mission, the administration said.

Before the mission was completed in the early morning hours of Tuesday, the coast guard forces had dispersed 12 Chinese fishing boats illegally operating in Kinmen waters and detained 12 others. A total of 39 Chinese fishermen were also detained for illegal fishing in Taiwan waters.
In addition, the coast guard confiscated 200 pieces of fishing equipment and gear, including gill nets, which Cheng described as the most harmful fishing tool to the marine ecology.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND SEEKING SUPPORT FROM SPEAKER FOR PASSAGE OF ARMS PACKAGE

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye called on Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng Tuesday to solicit his support for speedy passage of an arms procurement package in the next legislative session, which will open Sept. 19.

Lee noted that the arms procurement package from the United States -- six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries, eight electric-powered submarines and a squadron of P-3C anti-submarine aircraft -- has been stalled in the opposition-controlled legislature for three years and that the United States has continued to express discontent with the delays.
Lee reportedly showed Wang a message sent by Taiwan's representative office in the United States in which Washington uses tough language in expressing its displeasure.
Addressing the complaints by the opposition about the exorbitant price tag of the arms package, the ministry has done its best in coordinated efforts to cut the price, Lee said.
"We have calculated the price precisely, hoping to cut it by as much as possible so that it can be accepted by the public," Lee said.
He urged the ruling and the opposition parties to end their political squabbling and view the matter from a military perspective.
Wang said that additional budget for the arms procurement package as well as the national defense budget for 2007 have been sent to the legislature.

He noted that the ruling and opposition parties are more in agreement on the part of the additional budget. He wouldn't comment on the possible consequences of further delays in passing the arms procurement package.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 37 points to close at 6,439, with 20,856 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October rose 36 points to finish at 6,441, with 101 contracts traded, while December futures gained 23 points to close at 6,432, with nine contract transactions.
March futures moved up 30 points to close at 6,438, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,402 for September, 6,405 for October, 6,409 for December, 6,408 for March and 6,432 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

September TE futures moved up 2.8 points to close at 278.4, with 3,200 contracts traded, while October TE futures gained 2.6 points to finish at 277.5, with 16 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures lost 5.6 points to close at 875.2, with 1,613 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 0.8 points to finish at 878, with 15 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
