DOC.HEADLINE: 40% CEILING ON INVESTMENT IN CHINA NOT TOO HARSH: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said Tuesday that the current 40-percent ceiling on investment in China by domestic companies is not too harsh.

Chen made the remarks at a speech delivered to members of the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association in Taipei, in which he introduced the current situation concerning Taiwan's outbound investment and the Ministry of Economic Affairs' (MOEA's) efforts in helping local business people expand their investment abroad.
Noting that nearly 70 percent of overseas investment by Taiwan businesses in recent months has gone to China, Chen stressed that concentrating too much investment in one country is very risky.

According to Chen, the regulation preventing domestic enterprises from investing more than 40 percent of their net assets in China is aimed at preventing too much concentration of capital in certain countries and fields and thus protecting investors. "Even the United States has similar regulations," he added.

Meanwhile, in response to criticism from some business tycoons that the 40-percent ceiling has hindered their development there, Chen said that the policy has been in place for a long time and that businesses cannot break the rules first and then complain about the government's policy later.
Chen pointed out that the amount of capital the companies can invest in China will naturally increase if the net assets of their enterprises grow.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DENIES INVOLVEMENT IN ZAMBIAN ELECTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan supports democratization around the world, but it would never interfere in the democratic elections in any other countries regardless of whether or not they maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan, an official said Tuesday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu was responding to foreign wire service reports that Zambian opposition leader Michael Sata has been accused of having received funding from Taiwan for his presidential election campaign.

According to an AFP report, Zambian media outlets have said that Sata, the key challenger to President Levy Mwanawasa in the Sept.28 presidential election, has received aid from Taiwan on the condition that if he wins the election, Zambia will establish diplomatic ties with Taiwan. Sata was also quoted as having threatened to kick out Chinese traders operating in Zambia.

Commenting on the report, Lu said Taiwan has been supportive of the global democratic movement. "We respect the democratization process in other countries, but we have never tried to interfere or get involved in democratic elections in other countries," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY EARMARKS BUDGET FOR PURCHASING F-16S NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has set aside a budget for purchasing F-16 jet fighters from the United States next year, a senior defense official said Tuesday.

Deputy Defense Minister Kao Kuang-yi made the remarks as reports from Washington, D.C. indicated that the White House's National Security Council and the State Department had recommended that the Bush administration reject the sale of 66 F-16C/D fighters to Taiwan.
Defense Minister Lee Jye said he met with a few U.S. representatives Monday to exchange views on Taiwan's plan to purchase more jet fighters.
He added that before things become clearer, the MND will keep working on the procurement plan.

According to Kao, the ministry's budget proposal for fiscal 2007, which begins Jan. 1 of next year, includes funds for the procurement of three major weapons systems that has been stalled in the legislature.

The government's proposal to purchase anti-missile batteries, submarines and anti-submarine aircraft has not cleared the legislative floor mainly because of opposition from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party.

Lee visited legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng Tuesday to again seek his support, and he called for the opposition lawmakers to approve the proposal which they have blocked over 40 times over the past three years.

Lee said the U.S. agreed that Taiwan needs the three major weapons systems to beef up its defense capability, adding that he hopes the lawmakers will rise above their political differences to help boost the nation's defense in the face of the growing military threat from China.

Kao said this year's defense budget was NT$71 billion (US$2.16 billion) more than last year. As the government's total spending was up by NT$90 billion, increased defense spending has not affected the budgets of other government departments, he noted.

He pointed out that the additional funds were mainly used in military investment and the ministry's daily operations. More than NT$20 billion was used to buy precision bombs and improve ammunition depots, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY MUST REMAIN NEUTRAL: DEFENSE CHIEF

TEXT.P: National Defense Minister Lee Jye reiterated Tuesday the importance of military officers and soldiers remaining neutral regarding political events.

Lee made the remarks in response to media inquiries concerning the military's stance prior to the start of a sit-in organized by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, to push for scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian to resign.
Lee said that according to his ministry's regulations, military officers and soldiers are banned from attending political events.
Asked whether the military has plans to address possible violent confrontations at the upcoming "anti-Chen" sit-in slated to begin Sept. 9, Lee said he refuses to make any comments or presumptions.
Lee also declined to answer a question on whether he had donated money to the Shih-initiated anti-Chen campaign.

Asked whether military personnel could attend the sit-in when they are not on duty, Lee did not give a direct answer, responding by asking the reporters: "Is it proper for an officer or soldier to head straight to a sit-in after getting off duty and taking of his uniform?"
Lee denied a rumor that the Ministry of National Defense has demanded that all officers and soldiers sign a statement that they will not join the "anti-Chen" sit-in.

He stressed that the military is required to strictly follow the rules of administrative neutrality and respect for the Constitution. No political party or government can demand that the military do anything that goes against the principle of following and safeguarding the Constitution, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.038 to close at NT$32.880.
A total of US$656 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.918 and fluctuated between NT$32.850 and NT$32.930.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAKE SLEEPING PILLS BEING SOLD AT SOME TAIWAN PHARMACIES

TEXT.P: More than 30 percent of pharmacies in Taiwan sell sleeping pills unlawfully to consumers without a prescription, with 10 percent even selling fake sleeping pills containing potentially harmful substances, according to the results of an inspection released Tuesday by the Department of Health (DOH).
The inspection was conducted by the DOH's National Bureau of Controlled Drugs (NBCD) in July on 103 pharmacies in 10 counties and cities in northern, central and southern Taiwan.
It was found that 33 of the pharmacies inspected had sold sleeping pills to consumers who did not have a prescription.

Meanwhile, sleeping pills sold at 11 of the pharmacies were unlicensed products of unknown origin, and tests on the drugs indicated that they contained potentially harmful or addictive substances such as nimetazepam, zolpidem and haloperidol, the inspection showed.
According to Lin Chieh-liang, a toxicologist at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, nimetazepam is a commonly abused sedative which can inhibit breathing and lead to coma, shock or death if overdosed.
Haloperidol is an antipsychotic drug which can cause side effects such as muscle-stiffness and tremors if used over a long period of time, Lin noted.
NBCD officials said pharmacists involved in the unlawful acts could face imprisonment of up to seven years and a fine of up to NT$5 million.
They advised people with anxiety or sleep problems to seek medical treatment and take medication according to their doctors' prescription, instead of buying sleeping pills at pharmacies on their own.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE MOTORBIKE PARTS ID NUMBER IMPRINTING PROGRAM CUTS INTO THEFT

TEXT.P: The number of motorbike thefts in Taiwan has decreased considerably since police began a free service in March to mark vehicle identification numbers on components of motorcycles and scooters, the National Police Agency said Tuesday.
An NPA spokesman said police have imprinted etched vehicle serial numbers on 1.17 million motorbikes since March 15 to deter theft by making it more difficult for thieves to sell their loot.
As a result, thefts of motorbikes in Taiwan dropped 21 percent in the past five months, he said.
He urged those motorcyclists who have not made use of the free service to bring their motorbikes along with their driver's licenses and other relevant documents to an imprinting station.
Statistics show that there are more than 11 million motorcycles and scooters in Taiwan. Approximately 700,000 new motorbikes are sold on the domestic market each year.

An average of 200,000 motorbikes are stolen in Taiwan each year. Most of the stolen bikes are taken apart, with the parts being sold in China, the Philippines and West African countries, including Nigeria.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER URGES MORE INVESTMENT IN CENTRAL, SOUTH AMERICA

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said Tuesday that the government can invest in enterprises that Taiwanese business people set up in Central and South America to help those companies in their operations there.
Chen made the remarks in a speech to members of the Taipei-based Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association.

According to Chen, the government's Development Fund can invest up to 49 percent in the operations of the enterprises established by Taiwanese business people in Central and South America. The capital will be withdrawn after a business is deemed well established to operate independently, he said.
The policy is aimed at giving those companies a free hand in their operations in the region, Chen added.

Noting that Taiwan business people have focused much of their investment in China and South East Asian countries, Chen suggested that they now set their sights on Central and South America by strengthening relations with countries in the region.

In addition, these Central and South American countries have all signed free trade agreements (FTAs) with the United States, which Chen stressed will be conducive to strengthening Taiwan-U.S. trade ties.

Chen revealed that the Ministry of Economic Affairs, which is seeking Taiwanese enterprises to invest in an industrial park built by the Taiwan government in El Salvador, plans to draw companies in the fields of information services, research and development, food-processing, textiles and logistic services.
Describing Salvadorans as "the most diligent people in Central America," Chen urged local business people to invest more there.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TRIAL' SIT-IN TO PRESSURE PRESIDENT TO STEP DOWN TO BEGIN SEPT. 1

TEXT.P: A sit-in protest slated for Sept. 9 to push for President Chen Shui-bian's resignation will be preceded by a "trial" sit-in beginning sept. 1, a spokesman for the campaign said Tuesday.

Fan Ke-chin said the trial sit-in with 230 participants for the "one million people against corruption" campaign initiated by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Shih Ming-teh will be held every night between 6 p.m. until midnight in front of the Presidential Office Sept. 1-7.

Fan said the sit-in time for each participant will be one hour on a rotational basis, pointing out that those taking part "are not doing so to fight the natural elements but instead to fight against corruption."
He estimated that the number of people taking part in the sit-in could reach 1 million in one week at the earliest.

When the sit-in formally begins Sept. 9, there will be 2,300 seats to signify the 23 million people on the island, Fan said. He expressed the hope that all the Taiwan people will come out and that they will become "the last straw that breaks the back of President Chen."
He said the venue of the "trial" sit-in will move to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall Sept. 8 to prepare for the official mass sit-in in front of the Presidential Office the following day.

People can register online starting Sept. 1 for one of the 2,000 seats available each day during the official sit-in, with the remaining 300 seats being left open for those who want to register at the sit-in venue.

Fan said that Shih will be at the sit-in area around the clock. There will be two zones in the sit-in area, with a series of activities being held in one zone and sun-screening facilities in the other zone so that children or elders can also take part.
He stressed that the name of the campaign, which was originally "one million people to depose Chen, " has been changed to its present one in order to clearly define the significance of the campaign.

"The campaign is not about Shih Ming-teh versus President Chen Shui-bian, " Fan said, adding that "it is about making a corrupt government step down, and not about overthrowing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party."
President Chen has dogged in recent months by a spate corruption and embezzlement allegations implicating himself, his family members and senior aides.
"Depose Chen" can give rise to a "support Chen" force, but "anti-corruption" will not lead to a "support corruption" call, Fan added. (By Lilian Wu) endtiem/Li

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE INJURES HAND WHILE RESCUING FIRE VICTIM

TEXT.P: A Taipei city policeman fractured his right hand Tuesday while catching a man who fell from a second-floor apartment during a fire rescue.
The fire was reported in the early morning hours by the police officer, Liao Shun-ping, who noticed the blaze while on patrol in the northern district of Taipei.

Liao said firefighters put out the fire soon after they rushed to the scene, but the apartment was enveloped in dense smoke when they found two men trapped on the balcony of their second-floor apartment.

Liao and some neighbors placed a ladder by the balcony to rescue them, but it was not long enough to reach the second floor. The two men were forced to make a risky maneuver to get to the ladder. The older man lost his balance and fell while doing so.
Liao was able to catch him, but he fractured his hand in the process. The older man suffered burn wounds and injuries to his head sustained in the fall.
Liao and the two men were rushed to hospital for treatment. All three are in stable condition, according to hospital officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE CHINESE MILITARY AIRCRAFT CROSSING MIDDLE LINE OF TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: A large number of Chinese military aircraft and frigates have been detected crossing the middle line of the Taiwan Strait or trespassing into Taiwan's exclusive economic zone over the past decade, according to a report released Tuesday by the Ministry of National Defense.
The 2006 National Defense Report said that the Chinese military has been expanding the scope of its activity since Taiwan held its first popular presidential election in 1996.
While Chinese military aircraft crossed the middle line of the Taiwan Strait on 1,100 occasions in 1999, the frequency increased to 1,200 in 2000 and further to 1,500 in 2001, the report said.
The frequency dropped to 1,300 in 2002 and further to 940 in 2004 but soared to 1,700 in 2005, the report said.

It said that over the last three years, Chinese scientific research vessels have been increasing their activity in the Taiwan Strait, with more than 20 such cruises recorded per year on average, including many in which they trespassed into Taiwan's territorial waters.
Chinese military frigates have appeared frequently in the Taiwan Strait to gather sea and air intelligence and test the response time of the ROC Navy and Air Force, the report said.
Over the past several years, China has repeatedly sent oceanographic survey ships to Japan's exclusive economic zone for hydrographic study, with 30 such cruises recorded in 2003, the report said.

In November 2003, a Chinese Ming-class submarine was found surfacing near Japan's Kyushu Island, and in November 2004, a Chinese Han-class nuclear-powered submarine was discovered in Japan's territorial waters, the report said.
From April to September 2005, Japan's Air Force intercepted 30 Chinese planes trying to enter the country's air space, according to the report.

The report reasoned that the Chinese Navy has been increasing its intelligence-gathering activities in the East China Sea in a bid to ensure sea and air dominance to prevent intervention by the United States or Japan in the event of a war in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: RING SELLING TAINTED BEEF INDICTED BY TAINAN PUBLIC PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: Public prosecutors at the Tainan District Court indicted 21 members of a ring Tuesday that had been selling tainted meat from dead and diseased cattle since 2002 and recommended prison terms varying from four months to four years and six months.

According to the prosecution, law enforcement agents in Yunlin County found in May that beef butcher Chang Mao-hsiung and his wife Tsai Kui-wei were selling meat from dead and sick cattle that should have been either destroyed or turned into animal feed.

Further investigation led to the discovery that since 2002 the couple had worked with Chiu Szu-chien and Lien Jung-chi to buy dead and diseased cattle at low prices from farms in Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan counties.
They ignored health concerns and sold the questionable beef, knowing that the meat would be processed for resale and human consumption.
The prosecution recommended a prison term of four years and six months each for Chang, Tsai, Chiu and Lien, plus a fine of NT$1.5 million (US$45,630).
Another defendant, Yang Chen-hsun, who helped transport the carcasses and sick animals, could face two years in prison and a fine of NT$800,000.
The 16 others, who worked on farms that supplied the dead and sick cattle, could face prison terms varying from four to eight months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO RESPONDS TO FORMER DPP HEAD'S TRAITOR REMARK

TEXT.P: Koo Kuan-min, a former senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian and a staunch advocate of Taiwan independence, responded Tuesday to former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh who a day earlier called him "Taiwan's Quisling."

Shih quoted historian Shih Ming's "Four Hundred Years of History of the Taiwan People" as stating that in 1972, Koo, leader of the Taiwan independence movement in Japan, sneaked back to Taiwan to surrender to the Chiang Kai-shek government.

Shih Ming-teh said he has always looked down on independence "advocates" who pursue the goal with mere slogans, adding that some people have praised the "quisling of Taiwan" as "a senior leader of the Taiwan independence movement."
Koo, who was scheduled to return to Taiwan from Japan Wednesday, issued a statement to explain that part of history.

In 1971, before the Republic of China was expelled from the United Nations, Koo said, he wrote a letter to Chiang Ching-kuo, son of Chiang Kai-shek, urging the government to "seriously consider" the impact of withdrawing from the U.N.
Chiang Ching-kuo twice invited him back to Taiwan to discuss "national affairs, " so he returned to meet with Chiang after receiving his official invitation, Koo said.
When they met, he added, he suggested that Chiang resolve the issue of "provinces as birth places" and allow the establishment of opposition parties.
But when he returned to Japan, his "comrades" in the independence movement would not forgive him, so he withdrew from the Taiwan Independence League, Koo said.
He said Shih complained that he was "smeared" and his personality "assassinated, " "but isn't he using the same method to smear others and assassinate their characters?"

Koo said since Shih is determined to use a non-institutional method to topple Taiwan's democratic system and its democratically elected president, he must receive "the harshest scrutiny" from all sectors of society.

He challenged Shih to pledge to quit politics if his current attempt to depose President Chen Shui-bian fails. "Otherwise, Shih will become an irresponsible campaign leader who looks at toppling a popularly elected president as a childish game," Koo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF DENGUE FEVER CASES THIS SUMMER INCREASING AT ALARMING RATE

TEXT.P: The number of indigenous dengue fever cases has reached 116 so far this summer, or 29 times the figure for the same period last year, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said Tuesday.
The officials said that since the fist indigenous dengue fever was detected in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan June 26, the number has increased rapidly.

Among the 116 reported cases, 88 are in Kaohsiung City, 26 in Kaohsiung County, and one each in Pingtung County and Tainan County. The 116 cases compared with only four cases in Chihchin, Kaohsiung City during the summer of 2005.

The officials noted that this summer, dengue fever has spread rapidly from Chiencheng, Kaohsiung to other districts of the port city and has even spread to the counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung as well as the city of Tainan.
CDC officials expressed worries about the rapid spread, saying they are concerned that an outbreak similar to that of four years ago will occur.
CDC Deputy Director Lin Ting said that during the last dengue fever outbreak in 2002, 5,336 people were infected, and there were 242 dengue hemorrhagic fever cases, leading to the death of 21 people.
Lin expressed concerns that with the rapid increase in the number of dengue fever cases, more serious cases or deaths will come soon.

To stem the spread of dengue fever, the CDC has targeted Chiencheng district for an environmental cleanup campaign. Those who fail to keep the environment around their homes or businesses clean will face fines of between NT$3,000 (US$92) and NT$15,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES SIT-IN AGAINST HIM WILL END PEACEFULLY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Tuesday that a large-scale demonstration set to start next month to depose him will end peacefully.

Chen said the recent conflict between Lebanon and Israel has "indicated the importance of peace" and that he has been working hard to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and in Taiwan society.
Chen made the remarks while receiving visiting U.S. Representative Dan Burton.
Describing Burton as the U.S. Congressman most supportive of Taiwan and the best friend of Taiwan, Chen noted that Burton has frequently expressed his friendliness and support for Taiwan.
He pointed out that when he made a transit stop in Miami in September 2005, Burton greeted him at the airport despite bad weather caused by a hurricane.

A group led by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh is scheduled to start a sit-in on the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office Sept. 9 to pressure Chen to resign over a spate of alleged corruption scandals involving himself and members of his family and administration.
Shih said the sit-in will continue until Chen agrees to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: OTOP LOCAL CULTURE INDUSTRY PROGRAM TOUTED AT INT'L CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: "One Town, One Product" (OTOP) , an initiative which was born in Japan 28 years ago, has now become a global concept in developing local cultural industries, especially in Asia, representatives from Asian countries said in an international conference said Tuesday.

The OTOP initiative was the brainchild of Morihiko Hiramatsu, former Governor of Japan's Oita Prefecture. Hiramatsu started the campaign in order to raise incomes in local communities in the prefecture and make citizens feel proud of their hometown.
In Hiramatsu's own words, the initiative was aimed at boosting GNP (gross national product) as well as "GNS (gross national satisfaction)."

The success of the campaign in Oita Prefecture led other countries, including Taiwan, Thailand, Korea and China, to follow the model. Similiar programs have been implemented in more than a dozen countries to date.

Taiwan started its OTOP project in 1989 under the supervision of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and it now has over 110 towns with developed cultural products or events which helps local tourism as well.

According to a report by Global Vision magazine, "the Yilan International Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival", "the Pingtung Black Tuna Season, " and "Yilan Green Fair" are the three most successful culture tourism seasons in the country.

The project is also an integral part of small- and medium-size businesses (SMEs) promotion in Thailand, which launched its "One Tambon (Town) , One Product" project in 2001, said Nitnirun Suwannagate, deputy director general of the Thailand Office of SMEs Promotion.
"The Thai government is now using the OTOP as the new tourism promotion, " she said, adding that by the end of this year, 60 OTOP villages will be developed and promoted as tourism villages.

The project has been transformed into different names and slogans in various countries, such as "One Company, One Village" in Korea, "One Village, One Treasure" in China, and "One Parish, One Product" in the U.S. state of Louisiana.

As successful as the OTOP was in Oita Prefecture 28 years ago, the worldwide OTOP phenomenon has definitely been well beyond Hiramatsu's expectations, said Kimoto Shoji, planning director of Oita's OTOP International Exchange Promotion Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC LAUNCHES PROJECT TO PROMOTE LOCAL CULTURAL INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: An Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) project which includes a virtual exposition and an international forum kicked off Monday, with the aim of promoting and creating small- and medium-size business opportunities in local cultural industries for its members.

The APEC Local Cultural Industry Virtual Exposition (ALCIVE) , a one-year online exhibition of cultural craft items from APEC's 14 members and one observer, will be displayed on the Internet until July 2007. The APEC Local Cultural Industry Market Development Forum is taking place in Taipei from Aug. 29-30.
The project was initiated by Taiwan in APEC's Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) working group last year, receiving endorsement of the other member countries.

The initiative looks to enhance the capacity of SMEs and micro-enterprises in the local cultural industries, build a platform for local cultural industries in demonstration of their products to all APEC economies, and strengthen cross-border cooperation in the APEC region in promotion of the development of overseas markets for local cultural industries, Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said in the opening ceremony.
Moreover, the project helps retain cultural heritage and create more employment in remote areas for every country, Chen said.

During the two-day forum, more than a dozen speakers from Taiwan, Japan, Thailand, Papua New Guinea, the United States, Peru, Chile and Mexico will deliver topical speeches in five sessions of wide-ranging discussions. The topics include economic implication, policy environment, marketing strategy, market access and case study of market development of local cultural industries.
The ALCIVE Web site, at www.alcive.tw, simulates the layout of the 2005 Aichi Expo, with each APEC member country displaying its products in a virtual pavilion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER FIGHTER SUCCUMBS TO DISEASE

TEXT.P: A woman known for her courage in fighting cancer succumbed to her disease Monday at the age of 28, according to a press release issued Tuesday by her alma mater, Huafan University in Taipei.

Tiffany Chen, who authored two books about her hopeless battle against a number of cancers, wrote in her newly published book, that "no matter how long I'm going to live, I will keep telling myself that living happily will be more significant than living with sadness."
Chen was diagnosed with fibrosis when she was seven and despite three operations, the illness did not ease, leaving her dependent on painkillers.

During later surgery on her pelvis when she was 23, Chen nearly exhausted the hospitals blood reserves, prompting her classmates at Huafan University to launch a blood drive to provide her with 30,000 c.c. of blood donated by 120 teachers and students.
However, Chen's tragedy did not end and she was diagnosed with bone cancer not long after the operation, which was treated with chemotherapy.
After Chen had liver surgery in October 2003, she was diagnosed with bile duct cancer, and doctors predicted she would not survive beyond the age of 30.
However, the illnesses did not conquer Chen's will and she wrote two books in an effort to influence the public to face their lives with courage.
"No matter how life changes in the future, now I have seen the beauty of life. That's enough," Chen wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL MOTORCYCLE SHOW SLATED FOR OCTOBER

TEXT.P: An international motorcycle industry show will be held at the third exhibition hall of the Taipei World Trade Center Oct. 27-29, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Tuesday.

The fair, the first of its kind in Taiwan, is aimed at helping the international community better understand the strength of Taiwan's motorcycle industry, from production of key components and parts to finished vehicles, TAITRA officials said.

In connection with the show, two forums will be held Oct. 27, with Roberto Marabese, an executive with the Italian motorcycle design company Marabese Design Co., and Tim Buche, president of the U.S. Motorcycle Industry Council, as keynote speakers.
Registration for the two forums begins Sept. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Islamic Revival Led by Women Tests Syria's Secularism
Enas al-Kaldi stops in the hallway of her Islamic school for girls and coaxes her 6-year-old schoolmate through a short recitation from the Koran.
In other corners of Damascus, women who identify one another by the distinctive way they tie their head scarves gather for meetings of an exclusive and secret Islamic women's society known as the Qubaisiate.
These are the two faces of an Islamic revival for women in Syria, one that could add up to a potent challenge to this determinedly secular state. Though government officials vociferously deny it, Syria is becoming increasingly religious and its national identity is weakening. If Islam replaces that identity, it may undermine the unity of a society that is ruled by a Muslim religious minority, the Alawites, and includes many religious groups.
Wall Street Journal: Viacom Discovers Kids Don't Want Their MTV Online
MTV, which has long stayed on top of its fickle and elusive teen audience, finds that its Web sites are being whipped by rivals such as MySpace, the new home of the MTV generation.
This time, the kids didn't follow. "MTV Overdrive," a free video Web site featuring music videos, news and MTV's hit programming, attracts fewer than four million unique visitors a month, a small fraction of MTV's 82 million monthly U.S. television viewers. More worrisome: MTV's Web sites are being whipped by rivals such as MySpace, the new home of the MTV generation. MySpace gets nearly 55 million unique visitors in the U.S. a month. YouTube, a fast-growing video Web site, draws 16 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Elderly patients face risk of hospital malnutrition
More than half of the older patients in Britain's hospitals suffer from malnutrition which may set back their recovery because nurses do not have time to help them eat, a survey has found.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMITTEE RULES CHINA'S TOWEL DUMPING HURTS TAIWAN BUSINESSES

TEXT.P: A trade investigative committee of the Ministry of Economic Affairs ruled Tuesday that imports of cheap Chinese towels has caused real damage to Taiwan's towel industry.
The ruling will be sent to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) , which has 10 days to decide whether or not to levy anti-dumping duties on the imports.

The government has since March been investigating the towel issue after receiving complaints from domestic towel manufacturers about their market being flooded with cheap Chinese imports. The trade investigative committee confirmed earlier findings that China had been dumping its towels on the Taiwan market, causing substantive losses to local manufacturers.

The committee said imports of Chinese towels began in 2002 and that by 2003, China had become Taiwan's main source of supply. By 2005, Chinese imports had taken a 70 percent share of Taiwan's towel market, causing "evident and adverse impact" on the domestic towel industry.
The Chinese towels are much cheaper than Taiwan towels and quickly replaced Taiwan products, forcing domestic manufacturers to compete in higher-priced markets.

The committee also said that between 2002 and 2003, the prices of Taiwan towels were suppressed, while from 2004 to 2005, the prices of Taiwan-made towels did not reflect the rise in manufacturing costs, further indicating that Taiwan producers could not raise their prices because of Chinese imports.
The committee reported that orders for Taiwan towels began to decrease after Chinese products entered the market, while domestic production kept falling.

Even though Taiwan manufacturers tried to find new outlets for their products in higher-priced markets, they could not compete with the Chinese imports, and sales of their products in the domestic market shrank, with little prospects for them to improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 20,000 PIRATE CDS FOR EXPORT SEIZED IN TAIWAN THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Customs officials have confiscated more than 20,000 counterfeit movie DVDs and VCDs destined for export since January this year, the Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance said Tuesday.

Chen Jui-jung, a senior customs official, said that under the government's policy of protecting intellectual property rights, customs officials have been working with the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) to weed out counterfeit DVD and VCD movies.

Chen pointed out that anti-piracy personnel from the MPAA, which represents eight major Hollywood studios, have been stationed in Taiwan to work with customs officials at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and post offices in Taipei.
He said that since January, they have cracked 26 piracy cases and seized 26,196 DVD and VCD movies that were in the process of being shipped abroad.

Chen disclosed that John G. Malcolm, executive vice president and director of worldwide anti-piracy operations for the MPAA, paid a visit to the Directorate General of Customs to express his thanks and commend the success of the two sides' cooperation in combating piracy.
The cooperation between the MPAA and Taiwan customs officials will continue on a long-term basis, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF OF GOVERNMENT INFORMATION OFFICE LEAVES FOR SEOUL

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Cheng Wen-tsang headed for Seoul Tuesday to attend the Broadcast Worldwide 2006 conference, according to a press release issued by the GIO.

Traveling at the head of a delegation consisting of local film and TV producers, Cheng will help the local film and TV industry break into the South Korean market and promote exchanges between the two countries in the fields of movie and TV production.
He will also attend a prize-presenting ceremony held to promote South Korean's TV programs to overseas audiences, according to the press release.
He is scheduled to return Sept. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ARMED FORCES TO BE CUT TO 275,000 BY 2008

TEXT.P: The government is continuing its efforts to downsize the armed forces, with a target of cutting the number of troops to 275,000 by 2008, Defense Minister Lee Jye announced Tuesday.

Lee made the announcement as he presided over a meeting to publish the 2006 national defense report, which reaffirms the nation's main defense policy goals of war prevention, homeland defense and anti-terrorism.
Wu Chi-fang, spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense, explained that the armed forces started to downsize in 1997, cutting the number of troops from 450,000 to 380,000 within three years.
After that, a new program was put in place with a schedule to reduce the troops to fewer than 300,000 by 2009, but now the minister has moved that schedule forward again, he noted.

According to the report, the ministry is also reforming its recruiting system, aiming to change its current conscription system so that by 2008, 60 percent of the service men and women will be voluntary, with the other 40 percent conscripted.

The term of conscription has also been shortened, so that from January this year, drafted service personnel who have served one year and four months will be discharged. Formerly, the service period was one year and 10 months.
Another reform of the armed forces is to lower the age from 40 to 35 whereupon discharged members then become reservists. The measure will bring down the number of reservists.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKS SHUT DOORS ON DPP OVER FEARS OF POLITICAL REPRISALS: DPP

TEXT.P: Two state-owned banks have refused to extend loans to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for fear of offending the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which controls the legislature with the help of its political ally the People First Party, DPP Deputy Secretary-General Tsai Huang-liang claimed Tuesday.

Tsai said his party, which is anticipating a financial shortfall of NT$50 million in the runup to the year-end elections, has approached the state-owned Bank of Taiwan Bank and the Land Bank of Taiwan seeking loan
on the security of two DPP-owned buildings worth a total of NT$40 million.
However, Tsai claimed, the party's request was rejected by the banks on the grounds that they do not want to risk their budgets at the legislature by offending KMT lawmakers.
However, Tsai's accusation was dismissed by KMT Legislator Hsu Hsao-ping as "groundless."

Banks lend money to anyone who can offer security and it is the ruling party that controls the government, Hsu said, adding that the ruling party should review the market prices of its collateral rather than blame the opposition for any DPP bungles.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT DEFENDS CONCUBINES' RIGHT TO ALIMONY

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court was simply following precedent when it ordered a man to pay alimony to his estranged concubine, a spokesman for the court said Tuesday.

In a defense of the court's decision, which raised eyebrows among conservative people when it was handed down a couple of days ago, Hsiao Guo-heng cited precedent set by the Supreme Court in 1944 as saying that concubines who plunge into hardship after being deserted without justification by their live-in boyfriends are entitled to alimony.

Rather than promoting cohabitation between men and women outside the bounds of marriage, Hsiao said, the seldom-used precedent is intended to protect the concubine and conforms with convention and justice.

He refused to speculate as to whether the ruling will be applied to men who are left penniless after being deserted by their concubines, saying it should be determined by the judges who preside over such cases.
The controversy stemmed from a case in which a man was ordered by the Supreme Court to pay his estranged concubine NT$500,000 for ending a 10-year cohabitation without any reason.
The woman, now in her 60s, claimed alimony before the court, arguing that the termination of the cohabitation, for which she claimed she was not responsible, rendered her unable to live.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 30, or the seventh day of the leap seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30 B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives US Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian receives Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcomes his visit aimed at strenthening exchanges between the ROC and Australia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLINE 'SUPPORT TAIWAN'S U.N. BID' PETITION KICKS OFF
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A global online petition supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations was launched by Taiwan diplomatic officials in Los Angeles Tuesday.
All people around the world are encouraged to sign the petition, which urges the United Nations to consider the right of the 23 million people of Taiwan to be represented in the world body.

The Republic of China on Taiwan has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971, when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the China seat to Beijing at Taiwan's expense. While Resolution No. 2758 resolved the issue of China's U.N. representation, it did not address the issue of the representation of Taiwan's people, officials from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in L.A. said.

The petition also urges the U.N. to help maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait as this year is the 10th anniversary of China's launch of missile tests in the Taiwan Strait in 1996 and as China continues to increase its missile deployment against Taiwan, the officials said.

China's passage of its "Anti-Secession Law" in March 2005 has been widely viewed as a move to provide a legal pretext for the use of force against Taiwan, the officials said, adding that the law endangers peace and stability in the East Asia region. They further said that the U.N. has to facilitate measures to secure peace across the Taiwan Strait.

The U.N.'s exclusion of Taiwan violates the principles and spirit of the U.N. Charter, in particular the fundamental principle of universality, as well as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the officials said.
They called for people around the globe to pay attention to Taiwan's plight and to support its bid to gain U.N. membership.

In order to help people around America to voice their support for Taiwan via the online petition, the TECO in L.A. has also distributed bookmarks with the words "Support Taiwan's U.N. Bid" and a Web site address at meetings, speeches and other related events.
Those interested in signing the petition can do so by visiting the GoPetition Web site at http://gopetition.com, the officials said.
They added that the "Suport Taiwan" online petition activity will continue until Taiwan gains U.N. membership.
