DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS GROUPS VOICE SUPPORT FOR U.N. BID UNDER NAME OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A total of 56 overseas Taiwanese groups called on the government Wednesday to make a bid for the country to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, instead of the Republic of China.

The groups noted in a joint statement that over the past 13 years, Taiwan has pretended to be China and tried to rejoin the United Nations under the name of the Republic of China, in what they called a strategy bound to fail.

While overseas Taiwanese have repeatedly advised the government to seek to join the United Nations as a new member, they are again urging President Chen Shui-bian to take this right path, the groups said.
The groups said Taiwan should stand up proudly and apply to join the United Nations in its capacity as an independent sovereign state, and they pledged to assist the government in achieving the goal.

The signatories of the statement included the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, the North America Taiwanese Professors' Association, the World Federation of Taiwanese Association, the World United Formosans for Independence, the North America Taiwanese Women's Association and the Taiwanese Hakka Association of U.S.A.
They made the move ahead of the 61th session of the U.N. General Assembly, which is set to open Sept. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA MAKING LAST-MINUTE EFFORTS TO FACILITATE CHEN'S STOPOVER PLAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is making last-minute efforts to facilitate President Chen Shui-bian's stopover plan for his upcoming South Pacific visit, a ministry official said Wednesday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu declined to comment on a United Daily News report Wednesday that U.S. authorities have rejected the MOFA's request for Chen to make a transit stop in the U.S. territory of Guam on his way home after state visits to Taiwan's Pacific allies of Palau and Nauru Sept. 3-6 aboard the president's "Air Force One" plane.

Lu, however, said that the foreign ministry is still making last-minute efforts to arrange for the president's stopover plan and engaging in negotiations with a "concerned party" over a possible transit stop in Guam and the type of aircraft that is going to carry Chen and his entourage for the upcoming trip.

The daily also speculated that the U.S. authorities have asked Taiwan to have Chen fly aboard a civilian aircraft instead of the "Air Force One" military plane if he plans to make a transit stop in Guam.

A MOFA official who spoke on condition of anonymity said that the U.S. government previously had no particular opinion about the president's planned stopover in Guam on his way home from Nauru Sept. 6 but that the U.S. officials have changed their attitude in recent days as the campaign to unseat Chen has escalated in Taiwan.

The official said the United States is concerned about appearing to "endorse" President Chen by allowing him to make a transit stop in Guam aboard a military aircraft amid the volatile political situation in Taiwan where a "Depose Chen" campaign is kicking into high gear.

President Chen is scheduled to depart Sept. 3 for Palau to attend a leaders summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the South Pacific before heading on to Nauru Sept. 5 for a visit, according to Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: NTUC sets bold vision as a movement for all.
The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) is rolling out an ambitious plan to attract all workers across all ages, nationalities and professions.
It also intends to gear up its cooperatives to see if there are new services to offer. The aim: to serve everyone, from babies to retirees.
The Lianhe Zaobao: S$150m to help SMEs develop technology and innovation

DOC.HEADLINE: EXAMINATION YUAN HEAD TO ATTEND INAUGURATION OF SAO TOME PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen will head a delegation to Sao Tome and Principe Thursday to attend President Fradique de Menezes' inauguration for a second term slated for Sept. 3, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Wednesday.

In addition to attending the inauguration ceremony on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, Yao will also visit high ranking Sao Tome and Principe officials, as well as officials at Taiwan's diplomatic mission stationed in the African country, the MOFA official said.
Yao and the delegation are scheduled to return to Taiwan Sept. 7.
De Menezes, who was first elected as Sao Tome's president in 2001, was re-elected in the presidential election held in July, garnering 60 percent of the vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Senate starts hearings on Cha-cha The Senate Committee on Constitutional Amendments, Revision of Codes and Laws yesterday started public hearings on various proposals on Charter change.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Militant solon hits NPA for extortion A WELL-KNOWN LEFTIST leader has accused the communist New People's Army of"downright gangsterism"after NPA rebels torched a truck belonging to an export company that refused to pay P30 million in revolutionary taxes.
The Philippine Star: Tanker captain: Don't look at me The captain of the MT Solar I denied yesterday any liability in the sinking of the vessel off Guimaras island last Aug. 11, a disaster that has created the country's worst oil spill.
The Manila Times: Captain of tanker was inexperienced The captain of the M/TSolar 1 on Tuesday admitted before the Board of Marine Inquiry he has no experience handling an oil tanker like the vessel that sank off Guimaras.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Kremlin Bails Out Madonna Concert
At times it seems that nothing gets done in Russia without direct intervention from the Kremlin. On Tuesday, Madonna's upcoming Moscow concert proved to be no exception.
After weeks of confusion and backroom wrangling, it emerged Tuesday that the pop diva's show would most likely be held Sept. 12 at Luzhniki stadium.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: An unfinished journey for New Orleans.
When Hurricane Katrina burst News Orleans' levees one year ago, it left about 1,500 people dead, wiped out 100,000 homes and reduced vibrant neighborhoods to twisted debris. The city is still struggling to bounce back. Some residents remain too overwhelmed to start over. Some can't afford to, and the wait for federal assistance fills them with doubt.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Ramsey suspect Karr cleared by DNA evidence
Prosecutors on Monday abruptly dropped their case against John Mark Karr, the itinerant schoolteacher arrested in the decade-old murder of JonBenet Ramsey, saying his DNA did not match blood recovered from the crime scene.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi: Historical mission for Italian troops in Lebanon.
Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi encouraged troops in a ceremony held Tuesday prior to their departure for Lebanon that their mission will be delicate and of great historical significance. An advance contingent of some 1,000 soldiers left for Lebanon Tuesday aboard five Navy ships to participate in the United Nations peacekeeping force.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20,000 FOREIGN WORKERS TO BE INTRODUCED TO WORK IN '3K' INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: The government is preparing to grant permission for 20,000 foreign workers from abroad this year to work in Taiwan's industrial sector, particularly in the "3K" industries -- referring to those sectors where work is "dirty, " "dangerous, " or demands "hard labor."

The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) already granted approval for 12,425 foreign workers earlier this year to work in "3K" manufacturing industries around Taiwan and permission for 7,575 other foreign workers is expected to be given later this year, beginning Sept. 1, CAL officials said.

The 7,575 prospective foreign workers will be allowed to work in 20 "3K" sectors, including mold manufacturing, manufacturing of fire-retardant materials, the food refrigeration industry, organic fertilizer processing, papermaking, garment manufacturing and the stone carving and processing industry, CLA officials said.

Applications can be filed between Sept. 1-30 and screening of the applications is expected to be completed by the CLA by the end of this year, paving the way for the foreign workers to begin work from early next year, CLA officials said.
Taiwan has not allowed new foreign workers into the country's manufacturing industries for the past several years in a bid to protect the interests of domestic workers.

Following a request from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said last August that 20,000 foreign workers would be allowed into Taiwan in 2006 for certain manufacturing jobs in 19 industries to help boost Taiwan industries' international competitiveness. He added that the 20,000 quota would be allocated in two phases at a ratio of two foreign workers for every three domestic workers in the "3K" industries.
Lee said the 2: 3 worker format will be implemented for one year on a trial basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COUNTY CHIEF CALLS FOR STRONGER INTERNATIONAL AIR LINKS

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng urged aviation companies Wednesday to help the outlying island county better connect with the rest of the world by setting up air links between Kinmen and overseas destinations.

Lee issued the call during a meeting with two executives of Far East Air Transport Corp. (FEAT) , one of whom is being promoted to a position at the company's office at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport while the other will take over the post he vacates. County government officials in charge of tourism and economic development were also present.

In addition to expressing his hope that carriers can step up air travel services between Kinmen and Taiwan proper, Lee called on them to help Kinmen develop local tourism by opening more international routes.

With the start of operations of the Taiwan High Speed Railway slated for October, Kinmen is set to play a bigger role in air travel between the outlying islands and Taiwan proper, Lee said, adding that the Kinmen county government is poised to explore Kinmen's potential in global travel.

Hailing FEAT as the pioneer in establishing routes between Kinmen and destinations on Taiwan proper, Lee urged the company to take the lead in helping Kinmen lure more foreign tourists by setting up more flight services from the county to overseas destinations.

The two FEAT executives echoed Lee's viewpoint and said that they are willing to offer flight services when the Kinmen county government organizes a tour that will take part in a "World Kinmen Day" in Malaysia slated for late this year.
They promised to cooperate with the Kinmen county government to help tourists from around the world visit the island and enjoy its unique ambiance and speciality food.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD FREEZE ASSETS TO SHOW SINCERITY TO PEOPLE: TSU

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) officials suggested Wednesday that the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should freeze its controversial assets until such time as the legislature passes a law governing political parties' assets.
This would be the minimum the KMT could do to show its sincerity to the people of Taiwan, according to Lee Hsien-jen, director of the TSU's legislative caucus office.

Lee suggested that the KMT freeze the assets -- worth an estimated NT$27.7 billion -- apart from those made up of membership dues, government subsidies to the party, political donations and interest generated from the party's own funds.

He said KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou should stop selling his party's assets as this is not just a financial issue but a political one, because when the KMT claims all of its assets were obtained legally, it is referring to laws legislated by itself as the ruling party.
If Ma uses funds raised from selling party assets to pay for party workers' retirement pensions, they will not feel ease of mind and the party will have difficulty facing the people, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET OFFERS TO HELP TAIPEI MAINTAIN ORDER AT ANTI-PRESIDENT SIT-IN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang pledged Wednesday that the National Police Agency will help the Taipei city government maintain order at an upcoming large-scale sit-in against the president should the need arise.

During a weekly Cabinet meeting, Su said the Cabinet respects the city government's decision to approve the demonstration, adding that the city government has the responsibility to handle the situation, since it has made the decision to allow the protest to go ahead.

Claiming that the city government has "made an exception by permitting the demonstration to continue around the clock, " Su said this is expected to increase the burden on the police in maintaining order, especially in light of the large turnout expected and the sultry weather.
Su urged the city government to map out a proper plan to cope with any possible contingencies.
He also said he hopes the protesters will not resort to violence at the protest.

A group led by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh is scheduled to start a sit-in on the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office Sept. 9 to pressure President Chen Shui-bian to resign over a spate of alleged corruption scandals involving himself and members of his family and administration.
Shih said the sit-in will continue until Chen agrees to step down.
Also during Wednesday's meeting, Su condemned former Legislator Lin Cheng-chieh for assaulting political commentator Chin Heng-wei on a TV talk show last week.
Expressing his disapproval of Lin's unapologetic attitude and attempt to justify his thuggish behavior, Su said Taiwan society must not tolerate such behavior.
Also, Su said he was surprised that no academics or human rights lawyers have stood up to condemn Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI 'QUEERS TOGETHER' MOVEMENT ENTERS SEVENTH YEAR

TEXT.P: The 2006 Taipei Homosexual Civic Movement -- the seventh of its kind since 2000 -- is scheduled to kick off Sept. 17 for one month aimed at championing equality, mutual trust and diversification in Taiwan society.

Highlights of the 2006 Taipei Homosexual Civic Movement will include an open forum in which academics and homosexual residents will exchange views on homosexuals' human and civic rights as homosexuals, according to Wang Ping, secretary-general of the Gender/Sexuality Rights Association Taiwan, which is sponsoring the movement under the authorization of the Taipei city government.

Other activities of the one-month movement will include an exhibition of artworks by homosexuals from around Asia and a teacher's workshop tackling homosexual and gender identity issues at school, according to Wang.

According to officials from the Taipei city's Bureau of Civil Affairs, the city government has earmarked NT$1 million in annual budget since 2000 to financially support activities regarding homosexuality in a bid to make Taipei a more global city that is culturally open and diverse and where homosexual residents are also allowed to take part in public and civic affairs.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a Harvard-trained legal scholar-turned-politician, is considered largely instrumental in supporting the annual homosexual movement. Ma has said that as the mayor of Taiwan's capital city, he is obliged to support gay rights as part of basic human rights' protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 124 points to close at 6,563, with 42,254 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October rose 114 points to finish at 6,555, with 526 contracts traded, while December futures gained 118 points to close at 6,554, with 24 contract transactions.

March futures moved up 138 points to close at 6,580, with four contract transactions, while June futures gained 91 points to finish at 6,560, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,439 for September, 6,441 for October, 6,436 for December, 6,442 for March and 6,469 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
September TE futures moved up 6.6 points to close at 285, with 5,627 contracts traded, while October TE futures rose 5.65 points to finish at 283.3, with 33 contract transactions.

December TE futures gained 2.6 points to close at 281.25, with one contract traded, while March TE futures moved 5.5 points to finish at 284.05, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

September TF futures moved up 9.2 points to close at 884.4, with 1,895 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures rose 3.2 points to finish at 881.2, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: International Herald Tribune: Annan demands Israel lift blocage on Lebanon. Israel must lift its blockade of Lebanon, Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, said in a joint news conference with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel on Wednesday, but won no commitment from Israel.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SOAR ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange soared Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 107.21 points to close at 6,587.12.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 6,523.68 and peaked at 6,602.81 during trading. A total of 2.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$80.6 billion (US$2.45 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.9 percent, followed by construction issues at 2.7 percent, machinery and electronic shares at 2.2 percent, textile stocks at 1.4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.3 percent, banking and financial shares and cement stocks both at 1 percent, and construction issues at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 892 to 174, with 126 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: First the Flood, Now the Fight; Critics Say FEMA Is Impeding Gulf Coast Rebuilding As Disputes Hold Up Nearly $1 Billion in Relief Funds.
Someone had to pay to remove 3,000 dead trees in New Orleans. The trees, insisted the Federal Emergency Management Agency, couldn't have been killed by Hurricane Katrina's floodwaters because they weren't toppled to a certain angle. New Orleans would have to pay.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DISCOVERING SIRAYA' TREK WILL KICK OFF IN MID-SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: A "Discovering Siraya" trek will kick off in the middle of September, offering visitors the chance to explore the newly opened scenic area in southern Tainan County, National Siraya Scenic Area Administration Director Tseng Han-chou said Wednesday.
According to Tseng, the scenic area was opened in December last year, employing 34 staff members to take charge of introducing the area to the public.

Every two visitors who apply to take part in a two-day trek together in the area will only have to pay a total of NT$2,500 during the two-month period beginning Sept. 18, while the administration will take care of their insurance, meals, accommodation, guide and entry ticket expenses, Tseng said.

The trek, divided into three different routes according to the surrounding scenic features, will allow visitors to gain an in-depth understanding of the area -- which will be a departure from the more usual cursory tours available at scenic areas, Tseng said, expressing his belief that the response from the public will be warm.
He added that participants will also be given a gift bag containing speciality products from the Siraya scenic area.

A total of 12 tours will be organized on the three routes -- to the Tsengwen reservoir, Wushantou and Hutoupei -- and visitors will be treated to attending a festival of the Pingpu tribe. Registration for the trek will begin Sept. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.03 to close at NT$32.910.
A total of US$774 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.880 and fluctuated between NT$32.827 and NT$32.910.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION TAIWAN HELPS POOR EASTERN TAIWAN STUDENTS PAY TUITION

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan said Wednesday that it has helped more than 8,400 students in eastern Taiwan pay their next semester's tuition fees.

However, the charity group's eastern Taiwan office said three of the students who have received its financial aid still cannot afford to go to university for their freshman year and might have to quit.

The office, which looks after the less privileged in Yilan, Hualien and Taitung counties, said its fundraising campaign has not been successful for the new academic year and that it faces a shortfall of NT$50 million (US$1.52 million) in funds to help all the disadvantaged students around the nation who hope to continue their studies.
World Vision Taiwan called on the public to donate money to help children and young people from poor families to continue their education.

World Vision Taiwan has established 45 Sponsorship Service Centers around the nation to help children and their families in underdeveloped regions, offering them assistance to get out of the poverty cycle.
The sponsorship projects have reached as far as the islands of Lanyu and Penghu, as well as Taiwan-ruled small islands near the coast of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times:
Overweight women may lose right to free IVF
Childless women who are obese should not get NHS fertility treatment unless they lose weight, and the most seriously overweight should not be treated free at all, an influential group of IVF specialists said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BAN LIVE POULTRY TRADE AT TRADITIONAL MART FROM 2008

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan announced Wednesday that it will ban live poultry trade and the slaughter of chickens in traditional markets around Taiwan from April 2008 in an effort to prevent avian flu outbreaks.

Council of Agriculture (COA) Vice Minister Hu Fu-hsiung made the announcement at a press conference that was also attended by Vice Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang, National Science Council Minister Chen Chien-jen -- who is also convener of the Cabinet-level anti-avian flu ad hoc group -- and Council of Labor Affairs Minister Lee Ying-yuan.

According to Hu, those involved in the live poultry trade and slaughter will have a six-month grace period from April 2008 to October of the same year. Violators of the policy will then face fines of up to NT$500,000 (US$15,198), and will have any slaughtered poultry destroyed.

Asked if the government was overreacting, Chen pointed out that when an avian influenza outbreak erupted in Hong Kong in 1997, most of those infected were poultry slaughterers. There is already no live poultry slaughtering in traditional markets in Japan and Singapore, and Hong Kong will also follow suit by 2008, Chen added.

In comparison with Vietnam, Thailand and Indonesia, where the World Health Organization has confirmed human cases of avian flu, Taiwan has a denser population and higher ratio of traditional markets, and therefore should adopt more strict measures to prevent avian flu outbreaks, Chen said.

To allow customers to continue to enjoy fresh poultry, the COA has approved a project to construct 20 new electrical slaughterhouses around Taiwan, in addition to the current 23, and will also encourage and offer subsidies for the construction of more small-scale electrical slaughterhouses, according to Hu.
Shih said poultry vendors can also apply for subsidies for the purchase of refrigerators and machines for packing frozen food.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRALIZED BURNING OF GHOST MONEY GETS BEST RESULTS IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Taipei County residents had a total of 950 tonnes of ghost money burned at environmentally friendly centralized facilities in the seventh lunar month of this year, officials said Wednesday.

The amount was 50 tonnes higher than the same month -- known as ghost month in Chinese tradition -- of last year and nine times higher than three years ago, according to officials at the county's Environmental Protection Bureau.
This is the third consecutive year that Taipei County has burned more ghost money through this method than other counties and cities, the officials said.

They estimated that burning the ghost money through centralized facilities instead of doing so outdoors has prevented the release into the open air of 109 tonnes of pollutants, which are tantamount to the total load of five articulated trucks.
However, the officials stressed that the centralized burning service is not aimed at encouraging the public to burn ghost money but to raise their environmental awareness.
They said it would be best if the public could avoid burning ghost money altogether because the substances released upon burning can be harmful to the health.
A survey conducted by the Consumer's Foundation last year shows that ghost money and incense release hazardous substances such as benzene, methyl benzene and ethyl benzene upon burning.

Environmental protection authorities in various counties and cities have offered the centralized burning service during specific festivals, including Ghost Festival, for the last three years, with the amount of ghost money burnt in this manner having increased from 260 tonnes to 1,800 tonnes over the past three years, according to the Environmental Protection Administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANS DESIGNED TO SUSTAIN ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: CEPD

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 plans designed to realize the conclusions of a national economic conference were submitted at a Cabinet conference Wednesday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
CEPD Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said each of the 516 conclusions reached at the Conference on Sustaining Economic Development need at least one plan.
However, Hu said there is no plan to relax the restriction that limits investment in China to 40 percent of a firm's assets, as there was no consensus on this issue reached during the conference.

Among the plans put forward by the CEPD Wednesday were several to revise 37 legislations and enact 17 pieces of legislation that the CEPD chairman said should be worked out by the Executive Yuan by the end of this year in the hope they can pass the legislature before June next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERU, CHILE PROMOTE LOCAL CULTURAL INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: The governments of Peru and Chile are working hard to promote their local cultural industries and help boost their economies, Peruvian and Chilean officials said in a two-day international forum that concluded in Taipei Wednesday.

The two South American countries, both of which have rich histories and cultural heritages, are working through government initiatives to promote the development of their local cultural industries, Chilean official Javier Chamas and Peruvian official Madeleine Burns said during the APEC Local Cultural Industry Market Development Forum.

In 2003, the Chilean government established the National Council of Culture and Arts (NCAC), which started financing cultural projects with a US$17 million annual budget, said NCAC Secretary-General Chamas.
"The projects are selected on a competitive basis, by means of public contests, " he said, adding that approximately 20 percent of all submitted projects are annually financed.
NCAC's biggest challenge will be moving from financial aid into the promotion and broadcasting of local cultural goods, while trying to promote Chile's cultural industry in foreign markets.
The Peruvian government has also launched a campaign of establishing CITES -- technological innovation centers of handicrafts and tourism -- as the regional integrator.

"Peruvian crafts are very important, involving at least 2 million people located in rural and suburban areas and bringing women and young people into productive activity, " according to the director of the Peruvian Ministry of Foreign Trade and Tourism.
There are 100,000 registered workshops and 12 CITES that have been approved or are under evaluation in Peru, she said.

To provide easier access to markets, the Peruvian government also helps the local cultural industry to establish Web sites and produce digital catalogues to promote the development of exportable offers, she explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET CLAIMS BUDGET PROPOSAL DOES NOT CONTRADICT POLICY GOALS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet department in charge of budget claimed Wednesday that its budget proposal for fiscal 2007 did not contradict its own four major policy goals and that the goal of collecting NT$1,171.1 billion (US$35.6 billion) in tax revenue is not over-optimistic.

The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) made the statement in response to a United Daily News editorial that criticized the government for putting forth a budget proposal that is "deceiving and self-deluding" and unlikely to win the legislature's support.

The DGBAS said that although the revenue is 11.9 percent higher than the fiscal 2006 budget, it is only 4.6 percent higher than the real income for fiscal 2005 for an average annual increase of 2.3 percent -- lower than the 4.4 percent average economic growth rate.

The 2007 figure is a realistic projection in light of the fact that from January to July this year, the national coffers took in 3.5 percent more revenue than they did in the same period of last year, it noted.

The Cabinet proposal to spend NT$1,663.8 billion next year represents a 5.9 percent increase over this year, with increases focusing on defense spending, which will go up 29.5 percent from the current fiscal year, according to the DGBAS.

For economic development, which tops the Cabinet's administrative goals, the Cabinet has earmarked NT$534.2 billion in regular and special budgets, up NT$9.8 billion from the current fiscal year, including a special budget for flood control and infrastructure improvement projects.
Of that total, NT$261 billion will be used to make fixed investments through profit-making and non-profit making government funds, it noted.

It pointed out that an NT$86 billion budget has been set aside to help boost the nation's science and technological development as part of the government plan to use its "budget tool" to develop the economy.

The DGBAS said the budget outlays do not contradict the Cabinet's four major policy goals of economic development, improving social order, taking care of the less privileged, and leading a clean government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR'S APPROVAL RATING FALLS TO EIGHTH PLACE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's approval rating has fallen to eighth place this year among Taiwan's 25 mayors and county magistrates, according to results of a survey released by Common Wealth Magazine Wednesday.
Ma, who was elected chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in July last year, kept the No. 1 spot in the magazine's 2003 and 2004 polls but dropped to third place in 2005.
The 2006 survey, conducted between July 17 and Aug. 6, drew valid responses from 10,225 respondents.

Figures showed that Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun topped all others with a 71.5 percent approval rating, followed by Hsinchu Mayor Lin Jung-tzer and Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin in second and third places, respectively.
Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair made the most progress, moving from 15th place last year to seventh place this year.

Although Ma placed eighth with an approval rating of 65.1 percent, he retained the No. 1 spot in terms of personal integrity, winning endorsement from 64 percent of those polled and 74 percent of Taipei residents.

The city of Taipei also topped the 24 other cities and counties as the "happiest" administrative area, based on criteria of economy, environment, education and social welfare. Hsinchu City placed second, followed by Yilan, Penghu and Taoyuan counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Repeats Vow to Help New Orleans U.S. President Bush said Tuesday that he took "full responsibility" for the slow federal response to the disaster as he made a carefully choreographed pilgrimage New Orleans that suffered most from the Hurricane Katrina. He told citizens gathered for prayer services at Warren Easton Senior High School, "I've come back to New Orleans to tell you the words that I spoke on Jackson Square are just as true today as they were then." He also said he would try to get Louisiana a greater share of offshore oil revenues and urged businesses to return to the region.
Wall Street Journal: Desk Job, Consumer Demand and Growth In Laptops Leave Dell Behind
Dell, the world's largest personal-computer maker, is facing its worst crisis in years, due to the change of buying behavior in the PC world. For years, Dell -- famous for selling products directly over the phone and the Internet -- was a dynamo thanks to bulk sales to corporations, mostly of desktop computers. Its direct-sales business model made the Round Rock, Texas, company a widely admired paragon of efficiency. But in the past few years, buying behavior in the PC world has changed. Much of the growth has come from consumer demand rather than the business market on which Dell focused. Dell has missed sales or earnings projections three times in the past five quarters. Dell's stock is down more than 60 percent from its peak closing price of US$58.13 on March 22, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: HALF OF NON-SMOKING WOMEN EXPOSED TO SECOND-HAND SMOKE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Despite a drop in the rate of exposure to second-hand smoke in the workplace in Taiwan, half of non-smoking women said they continue to be threatened by the hazard of second-hand smoke, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by the Bureau of Health Promotion.
The survey conducted between 2003 and 2005 showed that the rate of second-hand smoke exposure in the workplace declined year on year.

While the ratio of personal offices with the problem fell from 37.6 percent in 2003 to 25.3 percent in 2005, the ratio of shared offices with the problem also slid from 38.1 percent in 2003 to 25.7 percent in 2005, the survey indicated.
Meanwhile, at workplaces where smoking is banned, 15.2 percent had the problem of second-hand smoke in 2005, compared with 17.7 percent in 2004 and 24.7 percent in 2003, according to the survey.
However, with 90 percent of women workers being non-smokers, half of these non-smoking women complained that they were constantly exposed to second-hand smoke.
Also, the survey showed that the problem of second-hand smoke was more severe in smaller workplaces.
Over the past two years, workers at more than 30 percent of workplace with fewer than 30 staff were exposed to second-hand smoke, compared with 20 percent among workplaces with 100 to 299 staff.
At workplaces with more than 300 staff, 20 percent to 16 percent had the problem of second-hand smoke over the past two years, the survey shows.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ MULLING SERIAL RAPIST'S PAROLE APPLICATION

TEXT.P: A serial rapist known locally as the "Huakang Wolf" because most of the crimes he committed in the mid-1990s were at Huakang, Chinese Culture University's campus in suburban Taipei, has applied for parole for the seventh time, an official said Wednesday.
Vice Minister of Justice Lee Chin-yung said the Taipei Prison has tentatively approved the application and referred the case to the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) for endorsement.
"The ministry will screen the case with great prudence based on the results of the inmate's correctional education and the chances of his repeating the crime," Lee said.

The inmate, identified only by his family name of Yang, was sentenced on more than 30 counts of sexual assault and robbery. He has served more than half of his 16-year prison term and qualifies for parole application.

Yang, now in his 30s, made headlines five years ago when he passed exams to enter prestigious National Taiwan University, but was later denied admission because the MOJ turned down his parole application amid social misgivings about the chances of recidivism.

Even if the MOJ finally gives the green light to Yang's parole application, Vice Minister Lee said, he will be subject to stricter surveillance measures, such as being required to wear an electronic tag or being subject to polygraph tests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURNOVER OF MANUFACTURING SECTOR REACHES US$81 BILLION IN Q2

TEXT.P: The sales volume of Taiwan's manufacturing sector totaled NT$2.69 trillion (US$81.85 billion) in this year's second quarter, a growth of 9.88 percent over the same period last year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Wednesday.

During that period, products worth NT$1.38 trillion were sold domestically, an increase of 5.31 percent over the same period last year, while goods for export reached NT$1.3 trillion, representing an annual growth of 15.17 percent, the statistics show.

Cumulatively, the manufacturing sector's sales volume totaled NT$5.23 trillion in the first half of this year, a year-on-year growth of 9.32 percent. Of that amount, the volume of goods sold within the country registered NT$2.71 trillion, an increase of 4.33 percent over the same period last year, while the value of exports totaled NT$2.52 trillion, an annual growth of 15.22 percent.

Among the different industries experiencing sales volume increase in the second quarter, petroleum and coal products moved up most at 32.87 percent in the second quarter, followed by electronic components at 19.27 percent, chemical products at 17.13 percent, and the electrical and machinery sector at 14.53 percent.

Regarding sectors registering a decline in sales, vehicles moved down the most at 16.18 percent over the same period last year, followed by the tobacco sector at 13.73 percent, garment industry at 9.27 percent, leather products at 5.2 percent, and plastic products at 1.6 percent.

Regarding sales volume, that of electronic components reached NT$640.2 billion in the second quarter, followed by chemical products posting a sales volume of NT$312.4 billion, basic metal products at NT$229.6 billion, and vehicles at NT$135.3 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SET UP 'MORE EFFECTIVE' CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGE MECHANISM

TEXT.P: The government will set up a "more effective" mechanism for exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, according to a Cabinet report to the Legislative Yuan on the government's 2007 administrative plan.

The report, which was sent to the legislature Wednesday prior to a new legislative session opening Sept. 19, pledged to push ahead "direct" charter cargo and passenger flights between Taiwan and China.
The Cabinet also committed itself to normalizing people-to-people exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, particularly for professionals, noting the measure will bring "order" to such exchanges.

The Cabinet's administrative report said that under the framework of "active management and effective opening, " the government will seek to amend the law governing relations between the peoples of Taiwan and China and other related regulations.
A priority will be allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan and helping Taiwan's farmers sell their products to Chinese consumers, said the report.

It said, the government will "gradually remove" restrictions on visits to Taiwan by China's businesspeople and "gradually promote" financial exchanges between the two sides, as it tries to improve its services to Taiwan investors in China.

The government is demanding the Mainland Affairs Council explain to foreign governments, think tanks and media that Taiwan is seeking to establish a framework for "peaceful and stable interaction" across the strait, according to the report.
In the meantime, it noted, the government will also assist the children of "taishang" or Taiwan business people in China to strengthen their sense of identity with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYORAL CANDIDATE HOPES TO BUILD WORLD TRADE CENTER IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Former Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu pledged Wednesday that if she wins the year-end election to become Kaohsiung mayor, she will have a world trade center built in Taiwan's second largest city.

Chen, who was nominated in March as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate for Kaohsiung mayor, told the city's Chamber of Industry that a Kaohsiung World Trade Center would save southern Taiwan's manufacturing companies the trouble of moving their products to exhibitions at the Taipei World Trade Center in northern Taiwan.
She said that if elected Kaohsiung mayor, she would ask the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to allow its institute for commercial research to be located in Kaohsiung.
Chen added that she would also invite organizations for product and technology certification, as well as the MOEA's Industrial Technology Research Institute, to set up branches in Kaohsiung.
The former CLA chairwoman is running against two opponents -- Kaohsiung's former deputy mayor Huang Chun-ying and Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lo Chih-ming
Recent polls show Chen lagging far behind Huang, with about 37 percent of respondents saying they would vote for her -- nearly 20 percent less than support for the KMT candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMENDED PROPERTY DECLARATION LAW TO INCREASE PENALTY FOR OFFENDERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) announced Wednesday that it has completed a draft amendment to the Act on Property-Declaration by Public Servants which would increase the penalty for offenders.
Vice Minister of Justice Lee Chin-yung said the draft will be submitted to the Cabinet for approval before it is sent to the legislature.
He said the draft amendment was completed after the MOJ consulted with experts and scholars, leading to the conclusion that offenders should be subject to increased fines instead of criminal charges.

Citing an example, Lee said if those public officeholders who are required by law to declare their assets try to hide them and deliberately ignore the law, they could face a maximum fine of NT$4 million (US$121,710).
He also said the scope of the law's application will be broadened to add some 10,000 public officeholders to the present list.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA MULLING WAYS TO LURE 'TAISHANG' BACK FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: In view of the fact that China may implement a new round of austerity measures to cool off its red-hot economy, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will be examining ways to lure back Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, known locally as "taishang, " Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung said Wednesday.

According to the MOEA, Chen said that the ministry will begin assessing workable measures to attract "taishang" to invest at home, as Chinese authorities are likely to soon halt incentives to some Taiwan companies and because Beijing is weighing a new round of measures to cool the economy.
Apart from that, Chen said, China-based Taiwan companies are facing increased labor shortages, materials and power supply difficulties and an appreciating Chinese yuan.
It is known that some of the China-based Taiwan enterprises are prepared to shift operations to other countries, according to Chen.

To take advantage of China's changing investment climate, the MOEA will revamp its policies and offer more attractive and effective incentives to encourage Taiwan companies to return home and make investments here, Chen said.

The MOEA is poised to conduct a survey to gauge Taiwan companies' willingness to invest in the domestic market, and to disseminate information on government investment incentives such as assistance in land, capital and labor acquisition and special loans from a NT$20 billion fund, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PROMOTES CALENDAR FEATURING DISABLED

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou volunteered Wednesday to serve as a spokesman for a 2007 calendar featuring 12 physically or mentally challenged individuals, hailing their perseverance and courage.

Speaking at a news conference to mark the calendar's publication sponsored by the ROC federation for spinal cord injuries and the Taichung Welfare Promotion Association for the Disabled, Ma said he was deeply moved by the stories behind the 12 figures representing all walks of life, and encouraged the public to learn from their vigor and experience.
Ma also greeted the audience in sign language and posed with the 12 men and women for a photo session.

To aid the hearing impaired, six years ago the Taipei City Government began offering a cable news reporting program in sign language, and it has been training municipal officials to assist both physically and mentally challenged citizens, Ma said, adding that he himself is still learning sign language.

It is important to fairly treat people with physical and mental disabilitie because their work and human rights are fully protected by the Constitution, Ma said, adding that they deserve equal treatment and respect for their perseverance.

Ma said the municipal team has been routinely defeated every year in races on the day of the Dragon Boat Festival by a team composed of physically and mentally challenged citizens -- proof the disabled are not necessarily weaker than others.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRAUD CASES ON THE DECLINE: MOI

TEXT.P: The number of fraud cases has been on the decline since the government launched an all-out crackdown and set up an anti-fraud hotline, Vice Minister of the Interior Lin Chung-sen said Wednesday.
Lin made the remarks at a public hearing called by the legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on the country's law and order situation.

Speaking at the hearing, Tsai Chin-lung, a KMT legislative caucus whip, accused the government of inaction in reining in rampant telephone-related fraud on the domestic front, claiming that Taiwan may have become a "republic of cheating."

In response, Lin said such an accusation was untrue and unfair. Since a toll-free anti-fraud hotline "165" was created in 2005, Lin said, more than 1.04 million calls reporting telephone-related fraud have been received, indicating the public is now aware of the hotline as a means to report fraud.
Thanks to the concerted efforts of relevant government agencies, Lin said, the number of such fraud cases has declined by 2,660 in the past five months from the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP BIGWIGS URGE PRESIDENT TO REFRAIN FROM RESPONDING TO SHIH

TEXT.P: As a campaign to unseat President Chen Shui-bian gears up for sit-in protests, some Democratic Progressive Party heavyweights recommended Wednesday that Chen make fewer remarks against the campaign's leader, former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh.

During a DPP central standing committee meeting, Legislator Chao Yung-ching said the party's response at the grassroots toward Chen's remarks were not constructive, and said it was difficult for him to defend the president.
Chao was referring to Chen's recent remarks that he was "leading a happy life" without watching TV or reading newspapers full of negative reports about him and his family.

Chen has also poked fun at Shih, saying Shih "need not fear being put in prison" for leading a sit-in against the president, or have to write a beseeching letter to the president begging for Chen's leniency.
In response to Chao, Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general to the president, said Chen made the emotional remarks because he felt he had been smeared by Taiwan's media.
Urging DPP leaders to "understand" the president's feelings, Chen said he would forward Chao's message to the president.

Vice President Annette Lu agreed that recent media reports have been "unfriendly" toward Chen, but added that whatever remarks are made by DPP leadership will be broadcast to the general public, so "we have to be very careful in what we say and be psychologically prepared for the consequences."
Lu's remarks were interpreted as targeting DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, who claimed that Shih at one time "begged for a job" from the president, a claim that Shih has vehemently denied.

Other DPP central standing committee members did not buy into calls for caution and self-restraint. Chen Sheng-hung and Wu Ping-jui, for example, said if no attempt is made to fight back against Shih, his campaign may gain greater momentum.
Tan Sun Chen expressed hope that Shih's anti-Chen campaign will end soon, because if it continues for long social chaos may erupt and foreign investors will not dare invest in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHANGES STRATEGIES TOWARD 'CAMPAIGN TO DEPOSE CHEN'

TEXT.P: A task force formed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to handle a crisis triggered by the "campaign of one million people against corruption" decided Wednesday that party members should minimize confrontation with the group.

According to DPP sources who declined to be named, the task force decided at a meeting that DPP members should instead stress to the public how the campaign's planned round-the-clock sit-in in front of the Presidential Office will affect social order and harm the nation's economy.

The sources quoted insiders as saying the DPP should also take advantage of contradictions between the campaign's initiator -- former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh -- and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang.

Members of the DPP task force learned during the Wednesday meeting that according to the DPP's latest poll, Ma's approval rating dropped from 55 percent in July to the present 49 percent -- the lowest this year -- after Shih severely criticized him for hampering the campaign by not allowing protesters to use the street facing the Presidential Office on a 24-hour basis.
At the same time, public satisfaction with the KMT also plunged from 41 percent to 31 percent, while the DPP's approval rating remained unchanged at around 18 percent.

Leaders of the campaign to depose scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian have decided to change the campaign's name to "one million people against corruption" for fear the mass movement may lose its focus.

Shih has vowed that the round-the-clock sit-in, scheduled to begin Sept. 9, will continue until Chen agrees to step down to take responsibility for the corruption and embezzlement scandals surrounding himself, his wife, son-in-law and senior aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: LENOVO HEAD SPEAKS ON CORPORATE CULTURE, OPTIMISTIC ABOUT FUTURE

TEXT.P: Lenovo Group Chairman Yang Yuanqing spoke on the successful integration of Lenovo and IBM corporate cultures Wednesday, almost 20 months after Lenovo purchased IBM's personal computer (PC) division, and said he was optimistic about the company's future.

Regarding Lenovo's transition period following the US$1.25 billion acquisition in December 2004, the 42-year-old Yang said "On a scale of 1 to 100, I think I'll hand out a score of 90," after his lecture in Taipei, which was organized by Global Views Monthly magazine.
The deal made Lenovo Group, China's largest PC giant, the world's third-largest PC manufacturer behind Dell and Hewlett-Peckard.

But the integration has not been easy, "Especially because we're in a case of a Chinese company acquiring a Western company," said Yang, who asked everyone at Lenovo to call him by his first name instead of Chairman Yang or Mister Yang.

The first priority after the deal, Yang said, was to redefine the company's core values. a surprisingly easy task since two companies share the same core values, such as satisfaction-guaranteed service and integrity.

On the other hand, he tried to change some of IBM's "old ways," replacing them with basic must-haves in the fast-paced PC industry -- speed, efficiency, aggressiveness in seeking change and discipline.
Basically, Lenovo tried to preserve the strengths of both sides, Yang said, as Westerners are more aggressive and outgoing while Easterners are better at execution.
"The mix of Chinese and international staff helps everyone to adjust, respect and learn from others, which is good for Lenovo's development," Yang said.
Yang reiterated that the integration is "a cultural fusion of two corporations," not "a war of the East and the West."

The deal that has been described as "a snake eating an elephant" has shown optimistic results, as Lenovo's revenues have increased in the past 20 months, reversing a trend in previous merger cases that saw dramatic losses in the first two years following a merger.

Yang also expected an increase in Lenovo's cooperation with Taiwanese high-tech companies in future because "the IT supply chain is concentrated in the Greater China region. Our cooperation with Taiwanese corporations is natural and obvious."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-CANADA COOPERATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan looks forward to boosting substantive cooperation with Canada in various fields, including health and legal affairs.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a visiting Canadian parliamentary delegation.

During the meeting, Chen said Taiwanese made 100,000 visits to Canada last year and that Taiwan was the seventh largest source of Canada's foreign students, indicating that civilian exchanges between the two countries are cordial and robust.
Chen urged the Canadian government to follow Japan's example of granting visa-free treatment for Taiwanese tourists to facilitate further growth in bilateral tourist exchanges.

In response to Canadian parliamentarians' questions about an ongoing campaign to unseat him, Chen said any citizen can criticize the government or the national leader now that Taiwan has evolved from an authoritarian rule to a liberal democracy. But Chen stressed that using non-peaceful or violent means to sabotage the country's constitutional system and order is impermissible.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARSHER PENALTIES PROPOSED FOR CONCEALING ASSETS

TEXT.P: Public functionaries who deliberately conceal their assets will be subject to harsher penalities, according to a draft package of amendments to the existing Public Functionaries Asset Disclosure Law.

The daft amendment package was initiated by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) and will be presented to the Executive Yuan for approval in the near future, Vice Justice Minister Lee Chin-yung said Wednesday. With the Executive Yuan's consent, he said, the package will then be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

If the package clears the legislature, Lee said, public functionaries who fail to honestly report to their assets to the watchdog Control Yuan will be slapped with fines ranging between NT$200,000 and NT$4 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 31 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Aug. 31:
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will deliver a speech at the opening of the 2006 Taipei International Invention Show & Technomart.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news briefing.
14:45, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend an award-presentation in honor of outstanding trading companies.
15: 00, A news conference on selection of English-speaking diplomacy volunteers will be held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 31, or the eighth day of the leap seventh month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
12AD: Caligula, originally Gaius Caesar, Roman emperor remembered for his murderous reign, is born. He succeeded his adopted father Tiberius. After a severe illness, he displayed the ruthlessness, extravagance and megalomania that led to his assassination.
1422: Henry V, King of England, who reopened the Hundred Years' War, defeating the French at Agincourt in 1415 and capturing all of Normandy by 1419, dies of dysentery in France at the age of 35. His son Henry VI accedes to the throne at the age of nine months.
1907: The Anglo-Russian Convention is signed in St. Petersburg, settling differences between the two over Tibet, Afghanistan and Persia.
1907: Ramon Magsaysay, president of the Philippines from 1953 to 1957, is born.
1939: Adolf Hitler announces the invasion of Poland. Three days later, both Britain and France declared war on Germany, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: The Nationalist government divides the three northeastern provinces in Manchuria into nine provinces.
1957: Malaysia achieves independence from Britain with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first president.
1961: President Chiang Kai-shek tells 70 visiting American reporters that Kinmen and Matsu "are as important as West Berlin."
1962: The former British possessions of Trinidad and Tobago become an independent nation.
1962: The Republic of China recognizes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.
1965: Pakistan and India threaten war over Kashmir.
1968: A strong earthquake rocks northeastern Iran, killing 12,000 people and injuring over 100,000 others.
1974: The first plant to produce high-density polyethylene resins in the Republic of China is dedicated at Toufen in Miaoli County.
1976: Little League, Big League and Senior League teams return to Taipei after winning world titles in the United States.
1980: The ROC Mulan soccer team wins the championship at the first International Women's Soccer Tournament held in the United States.
1989: Buckingham Palace officially confirms that the marriage of Queen Elizabeth II's daughter, Anne, and Captain Mark Phillips is on the rocks.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun advises the Legislative Yuan that ROC relations with mainland China will operate under the concept of "one country, two areas."
1992: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expresses support for the ROC's entry into the GATT during her visit to Taipei.
1993: Beijing makes public a white paper reiterating its position of solving the Taiwan problem by "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," while refusing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
1994: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly preside over a farewell ceremony marking an end to half a century of military presence on German soil by troops of the former Soviet Union.
1994: The IRA declares an unconditional end to its 25-year armed struggle for a united Ireland and its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.
1995: The ruling Kuomintang nominates incumbent President Lee Teng-hui as its presidential candidate.
1997: Britain's Princess Diana and her millionaire companion Dodi Al Fayed are killed in a Paris car crash.
1999: Raymond F. Burghardt, the newly appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
2000: ROC Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen says that the military will continue to try to obtain an early warning system after recent war games revealed Taiwan's limited means to counter mainland Chinese missile attack.
2001: Compaq Computer Inc. and Taiwan's Academia Sinica, the highest academic researrch institute in Taiwan, sign a cooperative memorandum to engage in gene and biotechnology research in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he, in the world, who possesses absolute truth who can get to the bottom of the law of his being. He who can get to the bottom of the law of his being will be able to get to the bottom of the law of being of other men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times: Writing to play key role in basic competency tests starting next year
The United Daily News: No dispersal if depose-president sit-in remains peaceful
The Liberty Times: Rare disease causes high cholesterol level in 10-year-old boy
The China Post: DPP lawmaker alleged to have affair with ex-aide
The Taiwan News: MOFA refuses to comment on Chen's Pacific stopover
The Taipei Times: Scheme to oust Chen backfires on Ma

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD SEEK OWN WAY AS CHINA KEEPS SUPPRESSING IT: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top envoy to France said Wednesday that if China keeps suppressing Taiwan internationally, Taiwan should find its own way to promote "substantive diplomacy."

Yang Tzu-pao, who will assume the post of vice foreign minister in Taipei Sept. 15, said that in order to carry out substantive diplomacy, he would prioritize national security and development over national dignity.
In an exclusive interview with CNA, Yang said that whenever Taiwan tries to participate in an international activity that involves "national" status, China will try to block the island country.

"We should pursue overall diplomacy, and not limit ourselves to engaging in political activities. Rather, we could try to interact with other countries in educational, scientific, cultural and other areas," he said.

He continued that in all these domains, Taiwan's participation will help the world community better understand Taiwan and to interact more effectively with it. Through this process Taiwan can make its own contributions to the world.
For example, he said, the government can encourage the academic and business sectors to participate in international conferences or hearings that do not involve state-to-state relations.

For the business community, they could use the international context to expand their business opportunities; academics can raise their profiles as they make professional contributions to the international community, he said.
Therefore, Yang added, "I think both the businesspeople and academics would like to join non-governmental international forums."

The engineer-turned-politician said Taiwan will not be excluded from international forums on environmental protection, sustainable development and information technology -- issues regarded as important in this era of globilization -- if it seeks to participate.

Even though China spares no effort to obstruct Taiwan's participation in international activities, "it won't be able to block all roads. If it keeps opposing us, we will keep finding a new way out. This is the Taiwan spirit," Yang said.

To demonstrate its flexibility, he suggested Taiwan give up its old principle of sending Cabinet-level officials to sign pacts on scientific and technological cooperation with countries like France by sending lower-ranking officials.

Taiwan could also send representatives with the official delegations of its diplomatic allies to international conferences to demonstrate that it attaches more importance to "substantive participation" rather than "formal or official participation, " he added.

As for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, a task undertaken every September when the U.N. General Assembly convenes in New York, Yang said "since this is a major national goal, it will be reached eventually."

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET UNVEILS POLICY REPORT FOR 2007

TEXT.P: The Cabinet sent its policy report for 2007 to the Legislative Yuan Wednesday, in which it emphasized that national security, social harmony and economic development are essential to ensuring the country's sustainable development.

The report said the core values of the government's national security policy are to protect the country and its people and that to do so, Taiwan needs to strengthen its defense capabilities to effectively address the cross-Taiwan Strait military imbalance that is tilting in China's favor.

To help develop a popular consensus on national identity, the country needs to stick to focusing on "Taiwanese consciousness, " standing firm on its position and moving forward pragmatically, the report said.

Regarding cross-strait relations, the government will follow the principles of "sovereignty, democracy, peace, equality" and promote cross-strait economic and trade exchanges and cooperation based on the principle of "active management, effective opening, " the report said.
On social peace, the Cabinet will prioritize improving law enforcement, attacking crime at its roots and enhancing public order, the report said.
As for economic development, achieving prosperity and wealth equity will be the government's main objectives, the report said.
It said the Cabinet will implement an economic development strategy encouraging businesses to deepen their foundations in Taiwan and to map out a global strategy to expand their business network.

The Cabinet will lead the country toward developing a high value-added knowledge-based economy, promote various economic reforms and assist local industries to transform or upgrade themselves in order to sustain Taiwan's competitiveness, the report said.
It said while promoting economic development, the government must uphold social fairness and justice to enhance its care and protection of disadvantaged groups.

It noted that the government has enacted a law on minimum tax rates to address the unfairness in tax burdens and will continue to review any outdated taxation measures to broaden the taxation base, achieve taxation fairness and protect the disadvantaged.

Meanwhile, with the greying of Taiwan's society and decline in the country's fertility rate, the protection and care of the middle-aged and elderly populations will be an important issue in the government's policy, the report said.

It said the government will continue to provide subsidies for elderly farmers and senior citizens, promote a new retirement pension scheme for workers, improve the National Health Insurance system, plan a complete social security network, strengthen the care and protection of the disadvantaged, integrate existing retirement systems and speed up the launch of a national pension program.

The deal that has been described as "a snake eating an elephant" has shown optimistic results, as Lenovo's revenues have increased in the past 20 months, reversing a trend in previous merger cases that saw dramatic losses in the first two years following a merger.

Yang also expected an increase in Lenovo's cooperation with Taiwanese high-tech companies in future because "the IT supply chain is concentrated in the Greater China region. Our cooperation with Taiwanese corporations is natural and obvious."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-CANADA COOPERATION(Repeat)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan looks forward to boosting substantive cooperation with Canada in various fields, including health and legal affairs.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a visiting Canadian parliamentary delegation.

During the meeting, Chen said Taiwanese made 100,000 visits to Canada last year and that Taiwan was the seventh largest source of Canada's foreign students, indicating that civilian exchanges between the two countries are cordial and robust.
Chen urged the Canadian government to follow Japan's example of granting visa-free treatment for Taiwanese tourists to facilitate further growth in bilateral tourist exchanges.

In response to Canadian parliamentarians' questions about an ongoing campaign to unseat him, Chen said any citizen can criticize the government or the national leader now that Taiwan has evolved from an authoritarian rule to a liberal democracy. But Chen stressed that using non-peaceful or violent means to sabotage the country's constitutional system and order is impermissible.

DOC.HEADLINE: 84% OF TAIWAN'S REPORTERS WANT TO CHANGE JOBS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Sensing a deterioration in the media environment, as many as 84 percent of Taiwan's journalists want to leave their jobs, up from 64 percent just two years ago, according to a poll whose results were released Thursday.

The 1111 Jobs Bank made a survey of Taiwanese journalists Aug. 14-28 as Reporters Day falls on Sept. 1. Out of 376 valid samples, 91 percent of TV reporters said they wanted to leave their jobs, compared with 87 percent of magazine reporters and 72 percent working for Internet media.
The survey said 85 percent of female reporters are considering switching jobs, compared to 81 percent of male reporters.

Why are they so fed up? A little over 44 percent of journalists said they were most troubled by "not being able to make an appointment with an interviewee, " while 31.38 percent felt the profession held no future.

Almost one-third of reporters said when their stories are published they are not as objective as they would like. For example, TV executives demand that reporters come up with a story within the shortest possible time, making it difficult for reporters to schedule interviews with a source. The time pressure is unbearable, they said.

A fair majority of reporters thus feel they cannot choose journalism as a lifetime career. A substantial number of reporters were also irked that corporate "positions" influence how their stories are presented and what subjects are assigned.

Asked about their views on "rampant" paparazzi or muckraking culture, few responded that it was a positive situation. Over 39 percent lamented that it indicates the "low quality" of Taiwan's media; 19.15 percent acknowledged that prying into others' privacy destroys social mores; and 17.02 percent said such practices compromise the ethical standards and integrity of the profession.

What are the advantages of being a reporter? The Jobs Bank found journalists do appreciate certain aspects of their work. Over 74 percent said it increases their knowledge, 55.32 percent said it helps widen their connections, and 35.64 percent said they have a better grasp of current events and the "pulse of society" than other office workers.

However, these advantages are not enough to keep them on the job, as only 16.49 percent of reporters surveyed said they have not thought about hopping to a new one, whereas a whopping 83.51 percent said they want to switch. In 2004, the same survey found 64 percent wanted to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILL NOT STOP OVER IN PHILIPPINES: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Thursday denied reports that President Chen Shui-bian plans to stop over in the Philippines during his upcoming South Pacific visit.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the ministry is still negotiating with the United States on the president's plan to make a transit stop in Guam, and that the ministry will report to the public as soon as the two sides come to an agreement.
Lu said Taiwan has maintained smooth communications with the United States, adding that it is normal if both sides hold different opinions in that process of communication.
Lu acknowledged that China has exerted great pressure on the respective countries in an attempt to sabotage Chen's South Pacific visit.

Chen is scheduled to depart Sept. 3 for Palau to attend a leader's summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the South Pacific before heading to Nauru for a visit Sept. 5. On his return trip home Sept. 6, the president is reportedly planning to make a transit stop in Guam.
Local media reports said the United States is opposed to Chen's plan to stop over in Guam on a military jet and has requested the president fly a civil plane instead.
