DOC.HEADLINE: F-16 PROCUREMENT PROCEEDS AS PLANNED: MND

TEXT.P: The government's plan to procure 66 F-16C/D fighter jets is proceeding as planned, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Thursday.
MND spokesman Wu Chi-fang said communication between Taiwan and the United States on this issue has been proceeding smoothly although there are "many rumors out there."

Wu made the remarks in the wake of reports from Washington D.C. suggesting that the White House's National Security Council and the State Department had recommended the George W. Bush administration reject the sale of fighters to Taiwan.
On Tuesday, Deputy Defense Minister Kao Kuang-yi confirmed the ministry has included the procurement in its budget for next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER FSC HEAD INDICTED ON CHARGES OF BREACH OF TRUST

TEXT.P: Former Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng was indicted Thursday on charges of breach of trust and conflict of interest, offenses the prosecution said he committed while chairman of a state-owned enterprise.

The prosecution charged that as Taiwan Sugar Corp. chairman from January to June 2004, Kong violated the government procurement law by dividing a NT$13 million procurement project into more than a dozen smaller plans -- each worth less than NT$1 million -- to avoid the legally required bidding process.
The project was intended for Taisugar to add a new line of business by setting up "orchid coffee" chain stores that sell coffee at NT$500 per cup as well as orchids grown by the company.
The law explicitly stipulates that government organizations should not avoid the application of this law by dividing a major procurement plan into smaller, less than NT$1 million projects.
Kong was also charged for conflict of interest during the bidding process involving a cosmetic product, and in the employment of his wife's sister as an adviser to the orchid coffee shops.
Reports have said that Ling Mei-chen, the sister of Kong's wife, received a monthly salary of NT$100,000 without providing any service to the coffee shops.
The prosecution suggested that Kong be sentenced to seven years behind bars for breach of trust and conflict of interest.

When Kong was investigated in May, Premier Su Tseng-chang suggested that he step aside as FSC chairman but Kong refused. Su then suspended Kong from the job, and yet he still refused to tender his resignation.

During his tenure as FSC chairman, the "stock vultures" scandal erupted involving his key staff, Financial Examination Bureau Director Lee Chin-cheng, who now stands accused of leaking information and other offenses that prosecutors said are punishable by an eight-year jail term.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRONIC SURVEILLANCE OF PAROLED RAPISTS TO BE IN PLACE IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Convicted rapists who are released on parole will be subject to electronic surveillance to pevent recidivism and the monitoring devices are expected to be in place by the end of November, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Thursday.

The ministry commissioned a high-tech company late last year to develop an electronic surveillance system to track rapists on parole and the first-phase testing on the system was completed in March this year, MOJ officials said.
The second-phase testing is scheduled to begin in mid-September, the officials said, adding that if all goes smoothly the monitoring system will be formally launched at the end of November.
Under the new system, those released on parole after being convicted of a sexual crime will be required to wear the electronic monitors 24 hours a day in order to prevent recidivism.

Meanwhile, the officials said, the MOJ has also purchased three computerized polygraph sets for testing parolees. The ministry has drafted training plans under which selected staff members will be trained in operating a polygraph -- a device which measures and records several physiological variables such as blood pressure, heart rate, respiration and skin conductivity while a series of questions is being asked, in an attempt to detect lies.
The MOJ will install lie-detector panels in northern, central and southern Taiwan as part of efforts to keep close track of parolee behavior, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PINGTUNG COAST GUARD SEIZES DRUGS, ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Coast guard forces announced Thursday the seizure of drug traffickers, contraband drugs and Chinese immigrants in early morning raids in the southern port city of Kaohsiung and northern Taipei County.

Acting on tips, coast guard officers in southern Pingtung County raided a residential apartment in downtown Kaohsiung at dawn and seized four members of a drug trafficking ring. All of them have previous criminal records of drug trafficking and abuse.

Also seized were 19.5 grams of heroin, 388 grams of amphetamines as well as NT$195,000 in cash and amphetamine production equipment. The case has been referred to the Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office for further investigation.

Another team of coast guard officers from Pingtung found two illegal Chinese immigrants and three other Chinese citizens at a house in Wuku, Taipei County in another pre-dawn raid. The two illegal immigrants have been sent to a detention center while the three others who have overstayed their visas will be repatriated soon, coast guard officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO MAKE TRANSIT STOP IN GUAM AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will make a transit stop in the U.S. territory of Guam on his way home after state visits to Taiwan's Pacific allies of Palau and Nauru scheduled for Sept. 3-6, the Presidential Office said Thursday.

The president and his entourage are scheduled to depart from Taipei's Sungshan Airport Sept. 3 aboard his "Air Force One" for Palau on a three-day visit, mainly to attend a leader's summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, said Liu Shih-fang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.

The president's "Air Force One," according to Liu, will return to Taipei soon after flying Chen to Palau Sept. 3, as its mission will not include any flight to Guam, where the president and his entourage will transit Sept. 6 before they begin to head home the same day.

Under the request of the U.S. government, President Chen will not make his Sept. 6 transit stop in Guam aboard his "Air Force One, " which is a military aircraft carrying the Republic of China national flag on it, since Taiwan and the U.S. maintain no formal diplomatic ties, Liu noted.
A civilian China Airlines charter plane will depart from Sungshan Airport Sept. 5 for Palau to carry Chen and his entourage to Nauru Sept. 6 for a one-day state visit, Liu added.
Chen will be the first ROC president to make state visits to Taiwan's diplomatic allies aboard the president's exclusive plane.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 24.65 points to close at 6,611.77.
The bourse opened at 6,647.67 and fluctuated between 6,667.62 and 6,611.77 during trading. A total of 2.9 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.44 billion (US$2.71 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastic and chemical stocks moving up the most at 1.6 percent, followed by cement issues at 1.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronic stocks at 0.3 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 2.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp shares at 0.6 percent, construction issues at 0.3 percent, and textile shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 560 to 483, with 154 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 58 points to close at 6,621, with 37,036 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October rose 54 points to finish at 6,609, with 301 contracts traded, while December futures gained 56 points to close at 6,610, with 21 contract transactions.
March futures moved up 58 points to close at 6,638, with three contract transactions, while June futures gained 59 points to finish at 6,620, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,563 for September, 6,555 for October, 6,554 for December, 6,580 for March and 6,561 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

September TE futures moved up 2.8 points to close at 287.8, with 5,040 contracts traded, while October TE futures rose 3.65 points to finish at 287.9, with 25 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures gained 6.6 points to close at 891, with 3,287 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up 9.4 points to finish at 893, with 13 contracts traded. March TF futures rose 1.4 points to close at 899.6, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIMS TO BECOME R&D HEADQUARTERS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the government will continue encouraging businesses to engage in research and development, with the goal of turning Taiwan into an international R&D headquarters.

Chen said invention and creation are strongly related to a country's economic growth and competitiveness and that Taiwan has always enjoyed the reputation of being the "kingdom of invention," with the number of patents filed by Taiwanese ranking fourth in the world.

The government is actively encouraging multinational enterprises to set up their regional R&D bases in Taiwan, hoping the introduction of foreign talent, technology, resources and systems into Taiwan will complement that of domestic businesses, Chen said.
He said the government is also encouraging domestic businesses to work toward innovation and establishing their R&D centers in Taiwan.

Chen made the remarks while addressing the opening of the 2006 Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart, which brings together exhibitors from 11 countries including Taiwan, the United States, Japan, the United Kingdom, Hungary, Israel and South Korea.

Organizers estimated that at least 25 technology transactions worth more than NT$200 million in total will be wrapped up during this year's exhibition, which lasts until Sept. 3 at the Taipei World Trade Center.
Last year's exhibition attracted 42,000 visitors and facilitated technology transactions worth a total of NT$350 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: UP TO 4,700 POLICE TO BE DEPLOYED FOR ANTI-PRESIDENT SIT-IN

TEXT.P: As many as 4,700 police will be mobilized to enforce law and order at a planned mass sit-in next month calling on President Chen Shui-bian to step down, the National Police Agency said Thursday.

Of the total, 1,700 will be dispatched by the Taipei City Government while the other 3,000-strong "support force" will come from nearby cities and counties and other police units, such as railway police and national expressway police, the NPA said.
The city normally sends out 900 police officers for a protest event near the Presidential Office. When more people gather at the site, the police presence will increase to 1,700.
Of that number, 700 will be "back up" forces from the National Police Agency.

Former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh's "one million people anti-corruption campaign" is scheduled to begin a mass sit-in Sept. 9 at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
Though the organizers have stressed the protest will be peaceful, the authorities have prepared contingency plans for any untoward incidents, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEND 1 MILLION LETTERS TO JUDICIAL AUTHORITIES: ANTI-CORRUPTION GROUP

TEXT.P: An anti-corruption campaign on Thursday urged one million people to write letters to judicial authorities, pressing them to have courage and to impartially handle the corruption scandals allegedly implicating President Chen Shui-bian's family members and close aides.

Jerry Fan, spokesman of the anti-corruption campaign, said at a press conference that they are emulating the experience of South Koreans, who wrote tens of thousands of letters to the Seoul district court, urging it to investigate corruption cases involving the country's former presidents -- Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo.

The two ex-South Korean presidents were convicted of treason, mutiny and corruption in 1996, and were then imprisoned, which Wei Chien-feng, a lawyer in the campaign, attributed to the power of the people.

The campaign has been planning a massive sit-in in front of the Presidential Office in September to press Chen to step down for the corruption scandals allegedly involving his family members and close aides.

Fan, who made a series of commercials for Chen in the 2000 presidential election, stressed that if prosecutors can handle with impartiality corruption cases implicating the first family, the public would not have to hit the streets, which he said would exhaust much of society's resources.
Fan urged one million people to each write a letter to the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court as a prelude to the massive sit-in to be held in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIZE-WINNING 'SOCCER ROBOTS' ON DISPLAY AT INVENTION SHOW

TEXT.P: A collection of prize-winning "soccer robots" is being displayed at the 2006 Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart which opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Thursday.

The collection was created by students and researchers at Tamkang University's (TKU) Department of Electrical Engineering under a sport android development project, led by TKU professor Wong Ching-Chang.
The project, funded by the National Science Council, is dedicated to creating robots possessing global vision and the capacity to move in all directions.

The TKU creations captured a golden medal and a bronze in this year's robot-soccer world cup, held in Germany from June 30 through July 3 by the Federation of International Robot-soccer Association (FIRA).
One famous objective of FIRA is to create a robot soccer team that can beat the human world cup champions by 2050.

While explaining how the soccer-playing robots work, Wong said they are being equipped with 360-degree motion capturing cameras, allowing them to receive and analyze visual input. Based on this information, the robots calculate the best responses and use their moving ability to shoot the ball. If the ball is missed, then the process will restart again until the goal is made, added Wong.

Wong said that previously, the individual robot could only work as an "individual, " which means that it reacts only to create the best situation for itself; however, the current communication technology enables a team of robots to function like a team, which can make the best move for the team.

DOC.TEXT:
The Times:
Motorways get extra lane - on the cheap
Motorists will be able to drive on motorway hard shoulders at busy times as a cheap alternative to road widening.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENT DOCTOR MAKES 'BLOWFISH' WITH BONES RECOVERED FROM PATIENTS

TEXT.P: An ENT physician from Chiayi, southern Taiwan, has built a blowfish with fishbones he recovered from his patients' throats.

Dr. Chang Wen-yuan from St. Martin De Porres Hospital has recently spent two days building a blowfish with nearly 400 fishbones that he "unearthed" from throats or noses over the past six years during emergency operations he has performed on patients.
Chang then hanged the objet d'art in his office, where the balloon-like "fish" serves as a reminder to patients that they must be extremely careful when they eat fish.

Chang called on the public to be conscious of the fact that after fishbones are stuck in the throat, forcible swallowing of water, rice or noodles in an attempt to remove the fishbones from throats may be dangerous. The best way to handle the mishap is to see an ENT doctor immediately, who will in turn remove the bones professionally, he added.

"Being an ENT doctor, you never know what you might find in patients' bodies, " Chang said, adding that over the past six years, he has technically found everything in people's ears, noses and throats -- ranging from a moth, a cockroach, beetles, a mosquito, fries, spiders, bees to tiny crabs, small wall geckos, a leech, coins and steel balls.
He said accidentally getting a stuck fishbone in the throat might not only be dangerous to one's health, it could also be financially costly.

He marveled that the blowfish he built is actually worth about NT$400,000 since each emergency treatment for fishbones stuck in the throat costs about NT$1,000, which includes emergency registration fees, fees for diagnosis and costs of medication.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC ATHLETES TO KEEP ORDER AT ANTI-CORRUPTION SIT-IN SITE

TEXT.P: A hundred martial arts experts, including medal-winning Olympic athletes, will help maintain order at a mass sit-in calling on the president to step down, campaign organizers said Thursday.

Olympic Taekwondo silver medalist Huang Chih-hsiung, weight-lifting bronze winner Tsai Wen-yi, Asian Games boxer Kuo Chih-lai joined "one million people anti-corruption campaign" organization director Wang Li-ping at a press conference to underscore their determination that the mass sit-in will remain peaceful.

Lee Hsin, chairman of the Taipei City Taekwondo Association, said some 100 judo, taekwondo, qi gong, weight-lifting and other martial arts experts have pledged to enforce the campaign's "peace and non-violence" principle at the sit-in site.

The campaign will honor the principle of "love, peace and non-violence" throughout the activity, when between 30 to 50 martial arts experts will be on duty on an eight-hour shift, according to the campaign headquarters.
Wang Li-ping said the anti-corruption campaign will start a "trial sit-in" at 6:30 p.m. Friday in four half-hour sessions, each with 230 participants.
Seats for the first two sessions have been fully booked, and people interested in the last two sessions can register on-line or by phone, she added. The formal sit-in will begin on Sept. 9.
She said as of Thursday, less than 10 people have enquired about refunding their NT$100 donations.
"As long as they bring their receipts to us, we will reimburse them," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARADE IN TAINAN TO ECHO 'ANTI-CORRUPTION' SIT-IN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A parade to be held Sept. 9 in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan to echo the beginning of a round-the-clock sit-in in Taipei on the same day against government corruption is expected to draw 6,000 participants, organizers said Thursday.

Weng Jung-yi, main opposition Kuomintang's caucus whip in the Tainan City Council, told a press conference that although the parade is organized by the caucus, its purpose is purely to fight corruption and has nothing to do with party politics.
Weng estimated that some 6,000 protesters, including three KMT legislators elected by Tainan City, will take part in the parade.
Participants in the parade will assemble in front of the Tainan City Council and begin to march through the city at 9 a.m. on Sept. 9, according to Weng.

He said the parade will call on President Chen Shui-bian to step down to take responsibility over a series of corruption and embezzlement scandals implicating himself, his wife, son-in-law and senior aides.

The sit-in in Taipei is organized by the "campaign of 1 million people against corruption," initiated by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party who vowed that the sit-in will not cease until the president agrees to relinquish his office.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAM PROVIDES GREAT OPPORTUNITIES FOR TAIWAN PC BUSINESSES

TEXT.P: Vietnam provides the most stable investment environment in Southeast Asia for Taiwanese businesses, especially the personal computer sector, an analyst said Thursday.

Although Vietnam is still a communist country, it provides the most stable investment environment compared to other Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries, most of which are experiencing political unrest, said Linda Lin, a researcher at the Market Intelligence Center of the Institute for Information Industry.
Vietnam also boasts one of the best growth rates in gross domestic product and gross national income among the ASEAN nations.

"With the announcement of a new foreign investment policy in 2000 and the 2006-2010 national development plan in 2005, Vietnam is now a new 'hotbed' for foreign investment, " she said. And Taiwan is already the largest foreign investor in Vietnam.

Government agencies will be the driving force behind the Vietnam market, she said, as the Vietnamese government will be engaged in an upgrading period with projects such as e-government to embrace its "open door policy."
This is why northern Vietnam, where the capital city of Hanoi is located, will be a niche market for Taiwanese PC businesses, Lin predicted.

With Vietnam's membership in the World Trade Organization in sight, lower tariffs on information and communication technology equipment is also expected to provide another niche factor for Taiwanese PC businesses, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER'S PLAN TO LEVY ENERGY TAX COMES UNDER FIRE

TEXT.P: A plan by Finance Minister Ho Chih-chin to levy an energy tax from July 1 2007 came under heavy fire Thursday from opposition lawmakers who described him as "unfit for the job" and criticized him for being "callous" to the suffering of the Taiwan people.

Legislators of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) told a press conference at the Legislative Yuan that Ho seems interested only in extracting money from the people, as his tax reform plan will levy an energy tax on all forms of energy from July next year until 2016.
"The finance minister should not treat the people as the government's automatic teller machine, " said Legislator Tsai Chin-lung, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus.

Tsai estimated that the energy tax levy would translate into an extra burden of some NT$3,000 per year to the average household, which would in turn affect the manufacturing industries and cause many small- and medium-sized businesses to collapse.

The government should not be indifferent to the people's suffering, reflected by successive suicides by whole families who have chosen death rather than face up to their dire financial straits, Tsai said.

KMT Legislator Fei Hung-tai pointed out that the people's real income has been decreasing over the past few years. He estimated that Ho's plan to levy an energy tax will cause average personal incomes in real terms to drop another 3 percent.
Yang Chiung-ying, another KMT legislator, said the finance minister should encourage enterprises to invest more instead of increasing their financial burdens and adding to their difficulties.
Ho is a former National Taiwan University economics professor who replaced Joseph Lyu as finance minister July 4.
He returned to Taiwan three years ago after serving in senior posts in the United States Department of Justice and the U.S. Treasury for 15 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HELP VITAL FOR CORPORATE ACCESS TO INDIA: FORUM

TEXT.P: Fueled by Taiwan's "Go South" policy and growing uncertainty in the China market, interest on the part of Taiwanese corporations when it comes to investing in India has increased vastly. Help from Taiwan's government will be vital for corporate access to India's market, forum participants said Thursday in Taipei.

There is so much the government of Taiwan can do to help corporations that are interested in -- but having difficulty -- investing in India, Sean Kao of the Market Intelligence Center (MIC) said in a forum that discussed boosting bilateral investments between Taiwan and India.

For Taiwanese corporations, investing in India is a problem of great complexity because there are different regulations and tax rates in 28 states and the language barrier issue, said Lin Shih-chia, Deputy Secretary-General of Taiwan-India Cooperation Council (TICC) -- the forum's organizer.
"The government can be a great help [for corporations], from setting up a one-stop service, shortening customs clearance to establishing a Taiwanese industrial park, " Kao said.
Taiwan is also keen on a free trade agreement (FTA) with India, said Eric Wu, General Manager of iSuppli Taiwan. Once accomplished, the FTA will also help Taiwanese businesses in India.
As Taiwanese businesses are more curious than ever about India, they should also deal with it cautiously, warned Kung Ming-yi, Vice President of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.
"The situation in India has been a little bit confusing for Taiwanese businesses. Because they see niches and difficulties at the same time, " Kung said.

"It is why I encourage all businesses that want to invest in India should take a good hard look in the mirror and ask themselves what they really want. Are you going there for Indian technology talents, making money in India market, or try to establish a base of production there? " Kung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MOTC OFFICIAL CONVICTED OF TAKING BRIBES IN ETC SCANDAL

TEXT.P: A secretary of former Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san was convicted Thursday by the Taipei District Court of receiving bribes relating to the electronic toll collection (ETC) system on the country's freeways.
Sung Nai-wu was sentenced to 12 years in prison and will be deprived of his civil rights for eight years.

Meanwhile, Tsai Chin-hung, a former assistant manager of Systex Corporation, which formed, together with three other firms, the Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collection Co. (FETC) that won the ETC contract, was convicted of offering bribes to Sung in order to win the contract.
Tsai was sentenced to two years and six months in jail and will be deprived of his civil rights for one year.
Sung said he will appeal against his sentence.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO TAKES TAIWAN AS MODEL IN HELMET LAW IMPLEMENTATION

TEXT.P: The World Health Organization (WHO) has recently published a road safety manual citing Taiwan as a model because of the government's success in implementing helmet laws for motorcyclists.

In the brochure titled: A Road Safety Manual for Decision-makers and Practitioners published Aug. 29, WHO experts said wearing a helmet is the single most effective way of reducing head injuries and fatalities resulting from motorcycle and bicycle crashes.

About 3 million people in Taiwan ride motorcycles to work every morning and the first thing that these motorcyclists do before riding off is to put on their helmets, an action that was extremely uncommon prior to 2000, when the authorities made wearing a helmet mandatory for motorcyclists and scooter riders.
Taiwan is now considered a "model country" in terms of reducing injuries and fatalities from road crashes, according to the WHO manual.

The brochure quoted an article authored by Chiu Wen-dah, president of Taipei's Wanfang Hospital, and published in the U.S. magazine Public Health in 2001 as indicating that after motorcyclists were required to wear helmets, head injuries resulting from motorcycle crashes were reduced by 33 percent from seven years ago, while the average number of days spent in hospital as a result of road accidents has also fallen significantly.

Noting that motorcyclists who do not wear helmets are at a much higher risk of sustaining head injuries and of dying from these injuries, the brochure quoted Taiwan statistics as proving that wearing helmet can reduce injuries by 70 percent and fatalities by 40 percent.
Taiwan is the only country in Asia cited by the WHO as illustrating that wearing a helmet is the single most effective way of reducing head injuries and fatalities resulting from motorcycle crashes.

According to Chang Wu-hsiu, director-general of the Bureau of International Cooperation under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, the WHO brochure is being distributed worldwide to be used by the authorities "in every country in the world" to bolster road safety.
The WHO authorities also urged governments around the world, particularly poor or less-developed countries, to work out national plans to implement helmet laws, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Officials Reach California Deal to Cut Emissions
California's political leaders announced an agreement on Wednesday that imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon dioxide emissions in the nation, putting the state at the forefront of a broad campaign to curb the man-made causes of climate change despite resistance in Washington. The deal between the Democratic-controlled Legislature and the Republican governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, calls for a 25 percent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by 2020, and could establish controls on the largest industrial sectors, including utilities, oil refineries and cement plants. The state has already placed strict limits on automobile emissions, although that move is being challenged in federal court.
Wall Street Journal: Disorderly Conduct, As Mexico Awaits Vote Decision, Social Upheaval Is on the Rise
With conservative Felipe Calderon now all but certain to become Mexico's next president, he faces a critical issue that will determine the success of his six-year term: How to prevent growing political confrontation from undermining the country's transition to democracy and free markets. Calderon's narrow July 2 defeat of his leftist opponent Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador landed in a court, which this week rejected Lopez Obrador's contention that the balloting was marked by fraud. The electoral court is now widely expected to name Calderon the president by the legal deadline of Sept. 6. As Lopez Obrador refuses to recognize judicial power and is promising to make the country ungovernable, social upheaval is on the rise.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CONDEMNS CHINA FOR OPPRESSING PRESS FREEDOM

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official condemned China Thursday for seriously oppressing press freedom in convicting a Chinese journalist for spying.

MAC Vice Minister Liu Teh-hsun issued the condemnation after learning that Ching Cheong, a Hong Kong-based journalist for Singapore's Straits Times, had been sentenced by a Chinese court to five years in jail on charges of spying for Taiwan.
Liu said Taiwan, a country that fully respects freedom of the press and speech, has expressed great concern about the case, which he said has attracted the attention of the international community.

"Although China has gained some progress in economic development, it is going backward in many other fields, " Liu said, adding that the MAC will keep close watch on China's developments in press and speech freedom in the hope that the Chinese people can gain more freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TRANSPORT MINISTER SUSPECT IN ETC CASE: COURT RULING

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court ruled Thursday that former Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san should be tried as a suspect instead of being a mere witness in the case of the electronic toll collection (ETC) scandal.

The court ruling was seen as a further blow to investigators and public prosecutors who have long been held in low esteem by the public for being terrified to prosecute the powerful even if there is sufficient evidence to indict them.

In the same ruling, the court sentenced Soong Nai-wu, one of Lin's former secretaries, to 12 years in prison for taking bribes and leaking confidential government information other than national defense secrets during the Ministry of Transportation and Communications' bidding process to select a company to operate the ETC systems on Taiwan's freeways.

Soong will also be deprived of his civil rights for eight years. He was accused of accepting more than NT$700,000 (US$21,590) in bribes and leaking secret MOTC documents to the contractor, Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collection Co., before the ETC bidding took place.

The court also sentenced former Chingyeh Co. assistant manager Tsai Chin-hung to two years and six months' imprisonment for offering bribes to Soong, plus stripping him of his civil rights for one year.
Soong indicated after the sentencing that he will appeal to the Taiwan High Court. Tsai could not be reached for comment.

According to the ruling by the Taipei District Court, Tsai, who feared that public opinion was not favorable to Far Eastern's outdated infrared system at the time, suggested to Lin and Soong that they ask the MOTC's Institute of Transportation to put out a report recommending that the infrared system be adopted.

Lin and Soong accepted Tsai's proposal and then had the requirements of the bidding process tailored according to Tsai's request to favor Far Eastern. They also provided the names of the members serving on the screening committee, along with other confidential information about the MOTC's procurement plans.

In early August, the Administrative Supreme Court upheld the Administrative High Court's ruling that declared the government's partnership with Far Eastern void because the firm was unfairly favored during the bidding process for the project.

Commenting on the sentence, opposition People First Party legislators Lee Hung-chun and Liu Wen-hsiung said the MOTC should immediately revoke Far Eastern's rights to operate the ETC system -- not only because the bidding process was rigged but because the infrared-activated ETC system has a high failure rate and is far below required standards.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMEARING PRESIDENTIAL FUNCTION `AN INSULT TO PEOPLE:' PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that smearing his official function is tantamount to insulting and holding the Taiwan people in contempt because performing his official duties "symbolizes the common will of all fellow countrymen."

While attending an informal gathering with local journalists on the eve of Sept. 1 Reporters Day, Chen said the most vicious rumormongering and mudslinging against him in recent days is a rumor that he "will be fleeing abroad with a stash of jewelry and gold bricks" when he sets out for a two-leg South Pacific official visit this Sunday.
Chen, who has been dogged by a slew of corruption allegations against himself, members of his family and staff, said he can endure all sorts of attacks and curses at him.
But smearing the presidential functions or mocking his performance of his official duties authorized by the Constitution is impermissible and can never be condoned, Chen said.

In the face of China's perennial and ubiquitous diplomatic suppression of Taiwan, Chen said his administration cannot afford to watch as China is gearing up to lure away the country's diplomatic allies.

Noting that each of his overseas trips requires laborious arrangements and preparations, Chen said his upcoming South Pacific visit is no exception. "It is a solemn mission that should not be a target of mockery out of base intent," he contended.

Chen is scheduled to depart for Palau Sunday to attend a leader's summit with Taiwan's six South Pacific allies. He will also visit Nauru and make a transit stop in the U.S. territory of Guam before returning to Taipei Sept. 6.

The embattled president also took the occasion to tout Taiwan's progress in press freedom, saying that Taiwan has advanced nine notches to 35th in the 2006 world rating of press freedom released by the U.S. Freedom House.

"Moreover, Taiwan ties with Japan for the first time this year at the top of Asian countries in terms of the Freedom House global rating, " Chen said. "All of us should treasure this hard-won achievement."
Chen's upcoming transit stop in Gum will be the first time he has set foot on U.S. territory since he refused to make a transit stop i n Alaska on a trip to Latin America in May.

Chen will fly his official plane, known in Taiwan as "Air Force One," for the first leg of his trip to Palau Sept. 3. However, for the rest of his trip to Nauru and Guam, he will use commercial airlines.
Taiwan media have speculated that the U.S. objected to Chen's official airplane landing in Guam, because the plane is perceived as a symbol of state sovereignty.

Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Liu Shih-fang said the speculation was meaningless because the government took the initiative to withdraw its original plan for Chen to fly to Guam via his official plane.

DOC.HEADLINE: WVT CALLS FOR MORE FAMILIES TO JOIN FOSTER CARE SERVICE

TEXT.P: The World Vision Taiwan (WVT) charity organization said Thursday that it looks forward to seeing more local families participate in its foster care program for abused children and juveniles.

According to WVT tallies, the number of reported abused youngsters has been on a steady rise. In Taipei City alone, WVT, a Christian charity dedicated to helping disadvantaged people at home and abroad, have handled a total of 4,343 child abuse cases in the past four years.

Noting that an abused child represents a family in need of aid and help, a WVT executive said abuse, neglect or desertion tends to leave a heavy stain and burden on youngsters' psyches. "They not only need therapy but also a healthy family life to heal their pyschological wounds," the executive said.
WVT has been commissioned by the Taipei city government's Social Affairs Bureau to handle foster care for abused children and juveniles since 1990.
As of July this year, the executive said Taipei now has 131 families that offer foster care for 200 abused youngsters.

With the number of abused and neglected children increasing steadily, the executive said WVT hopes to recruit more qualified families to join its foster care program to offer temporary shelter for maltreated children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LYCHEE TO GAIN ACCESS TO NEW ZEALAND MARKET: MOEA

TEXT.P: If all goes well, Taiwan-grown lychees will be able to make inroad into the New Zealand market next year, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.
The ministry made the remarks after the conclusion in Taipei of the 13th annual economic consultation conference between the two countries.
MOEA officials said New Zealand has promised to speed up relevant inspection and quarantine work to facilitate the entry of Taiwan-grown lychees into its market.
MOEA Vice Minister Hsieh Fa-ta headed the Taiwan delegation at the just-concluded meeting while New Zealand was represented by Hsieh's counterpart, Derek Leask.

The two sides also reached agreement on many other matters, including customs information exchanges and cooperation in tourism, biotechnology, digital content and scientific research, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TRANSPORT MINISTER DISPUTES COURT RULING

TEXT.P: Former Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san disputed a Taipei District Court ruling Thursday that listed him as a suspect instead of a witness in the case of the electronic toll collection (ETC) scandal.
Lin claimed that the court ruling that he would have known his former secretary Sung Nai-wu's decision about the ETC case is wrong.

Lin told the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) that he plans to give a news conference the following afternoon during which he said he would explain the ETC decision-making process in detail.
Meanwhile, the Taipei Prosecutor's Office said it is still investigating the ETC case and that it will refer to the court ruling in investigating Lin's role in the case.

In the same ruling, the court sentenced Sung Nai-wu, one of Lin's former secretaries, to 12 years in prison for taking bribes and leaking confidential government information other than national defense secrets during the Ministry of Transportation and Communications' bidding process to select a company to operate the ETC systems on Taiwan's freeways.

Sung will also be deprived of his civil rights for eight years. He was accused of accepting more than NT$700,000 (US$21,590) in bribes and leaking secret MOTC documents to the contractor, Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collection Co., before the ETC bidding took place.
Sung said after learning of the sentencing that he will appeal to the Taiwan High Court.

In early August, the Administrative Supreme Court upheld the Administrative High Court's ruling that declared the government's partnership with Far Eastern void because the firm was unfairly favored during the bidding process for the project.
